HEADLINE: Administration Backs Revamping Of Banking and Securities System

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30

 BODY:
The Bush Administration threw its weight behind a broad reorganization of the commercial banking and securities industries today. It would permit banks and securities firms to merge and would remove barriers to interstate banking.
In a speech before the Securities Industry Association in Boca Raton, Fla., Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady sought to reassure critics of the approach, saying the Administration package would include strong "firewalls" between banking and non-banking arms of a company to guard against overextension of the sort that led to bank collapses in the Great Depression.
 
Substantial Restrictions
 Since then, banks have operated under substantial restrictions imposed by the Glass-Steagall Act of 1933, which limits their ability to underwrite and trade securities. In addition, the McFadden Act of 1927 limits their ability to open branches across state lines. 
 Mr. Brady, who came to Washington from Wall Street, said the Administration was responding to the declining profits in both the banking and securities industries, as well as their difficulties in competing with foreign firms. He said the constraints of the McFadden and Glass-Steagall laws had led the industry to choose "among the more risky and often less attractive kinds of lending -- such as commercial real estate and loans to highly leveraged companies."
Efforts to remove the barriers to interstate banking and to mergers of banks and securities firms have failed in recent years largely because of the securities industry's powerful lobbying efforts. But the risky condition of the bank insurance fund of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation makes change probable now. The fund, which insures bank accounts up to $100,000, is at its lowest level in its 56-year history and, some experts say, could become insolvent if a strong recession occurs or if a few large institutions collapse.
"The Administration feels strongly that issues of deposit insurance reform -- that is, the extent and charter of the safety net -- are so closely intertwined with the question of reform of the industry's structure that it makes no sense to treat them separately," Mr. Brady said.
Within the last year, the securities industry has also reversed course and said it would not oppose the mergers of banking and securities companies, if the two entities were run completely separately.
"From what we heard today, we strongly endorse it," said Robert Downey, the chairman of the Securities Industry Association and a partner at Goldman, Sachs & Company.
Lawmakers have said they will begin drafting legislation soon after Congress returns in January.
Administration officials want to recapitalize the bank insurance fund. One option under discussion would require all banks to buy equity in the fund, at a cost of 50 cents to $1 for every $100 in deposits.
 
 Insurance Premiums
 The Treasury Department is also considering basing premiums paid by banks on the level and nature of their capital. All banks holding Federally insured deposits now pay 12 cents for every $100 in deposits; in January the premiums will increase to 19.5 cents.
The Administration is also considering limiting coverage, so that insurance would no longer fully protect institutions that hold money in banks in so-called pass-through accounts and brokered deposits. At present, institutions like pension funds and insurance companies can benefit from insurance by dividing their funds into different $100,000 deposits.
Mr. Brady called the current banking regulatory scheme "outmoded, burdensome and inefficient," adding that its flaws "are an unseen contributor to our financial institutions' current difficulties."
 
Chipping Away at Barriers
 The Federal Reserve Board has already begun chipping away at the barriers to banks' underwriting securities in the Glass-Steagall Act, but the Federal Reserve's power to overturn the regulations is limited. In September, the Fed decided to interpret a regulation to permit J. P. Morgan & Company to underwrite and trade securities, but the law still heavily restricts its volume of new business.
Many states have agreements with one another allowing banks to cross state borders.
Treasury officials have said a primary aim of permitting banks to enter new fields of business is to encourage the flow of capital. This would help resolve the banking industry's current difficulties in two ways. Increased capital would provide a greater cushion against losses, and it would also discourage speculative investments and loans by the banks since more of their owners' money would be at risk. Such speculation, permitted by the deregulation of the savings and loan industry in the early 1980's, has led to the largest taxpayer bailout in American history.
"We've got to carry out this restructuring in a way that limits, rather than expands, the taxpayers' exposure," Mr. Brady said. "In the era of the S.& L. cleanup, that is the first hurdle that any reform proposal will have to clear.
"The securities industry has always conducted its business -- in good times and bad -- without the benefit of a Government safety net or subsidy. This is right and should not change."
Securities firms, as well as banks, would benefit from the changes, he said.
"It goes without saying that when the Glass-Steagall barrier is lifted, banks and securities firms should find themselves on a level playing field, favoring neither side," he said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, DECEMBER 1, 1990

 BODY:

Markets
An overhaul of the banking and securities industries was endorsed by the Administration. The plan would permit banks and securities firms to merge and would remove barriers to interstate banking. Treasury Secretary Brady told a securities industry convention the package would include "firewalls" between the banking and non-banking arms of a company. [Page 1.]
 Oil prices took a steep fall after President Bush proposed that the U.S. and Iraq hold talks. In New York trading, oil for delivery in January closed at $28.85, down $4.06 a barrel. [1.] The cost of gasoline at the pump rises a nickel a gallon today as a Federal tax increase takes effect. [11.]
 Stock prices soared in reaction to the President's moves regarding Iraq. The Dow Jones industrial average jumped 40.84 points, to 2,559.65, a gain of more than 1.6 percent. For the week, the Dow's gain was 32.42 points. [33.]
 Bond prices rose sharply as the steep fall in oil prices encouraged buying of inflation-sensitive long-term Treasury issues. [36.]
 The dollar and gold prices fell on speculation that Middle East tensions would ease. Gold was off $5.60, to $383.50, in New York. [41.] Wheat futures prices surged after the President said he would consider offering food export credits to the Soviets. [41.]
 
 The Economy
The index intended to forecast the economy fell 1.2 percent in October. With the October decline, the index of leading indicators has fallen for four straight months. Analysts often take three straight months of decline as a forecast of a recession. [33.]
 A regulator told the Senate ethics panel that Senator DeConcini was the only one of five Senators who crossed the bounds of propriety at a meeting with regulators about Lincoln Savings. [10.] A judge approved a plan to liquidate Lincoln's parent company. [10.]
 Prices farmers get for raw products declined 0.7 percent from October to November. [35.]
 
 International
 The U.S. delegation to the world trade talks next week expects a lot of hard fights and maneuvering -- and when that's done it will have to negotiate with other countries. [33.]
 Tonga's satellite plans were dealt a setback by an international regulatory board that told the kingdom to drop most of its claims to orbital slots over the South Pacific. [33.]
 
 Companies
 Chrysler will quit providing 10-day sales figures, saying that tabulating the numbers is too costly and that the data give a distorted picture of the market. Chrysler will continue to supply monthly sales data. [33.]
 More bankruptcies of airlines were predicted by the chairman of American, who said the industry is going broke because of higher fuel costs, falling revenues and fare discounting. [33.]
 Some fees in the Matsushita-MCA deal were disclosed. Lazard will get $16.75 million and Allen & Company $8 million. [34.]
 Western Union said it would buy back some of its bonds, ending months of negotiations with bondholders. [35.]
 Federal regulators took control of San Jacinto Savings, a Houston-based institution with $3.2 billion in assets. [37.]
 
Today's Columns
 A new device helps large trucks back into loading docks. The guidance device uses distance-measuring equipment developed for Polaroid instant cameras. Patents. [34.]
 Decisions about retirement finances are due this month for many workers who participate in employer-sponsored 401(k) plans. Typically, December is the month in which participants are allowed to alter the mix of their investments. Your Money. [34.]

HEADLINE: Gingrich Assails Bush's Budget Chief

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30

 BODY:
Launching another rocket in the fight for the soul of the Republican Party, Representative Newt Gingrich today called Richard G. Darman a "technocrat" in the mold of Michael S. Dukakis, and said the budget director should resign if he was not willing to overhaul the nation's economic and social policies.
"Ideological battles matter," said Mr. Gingrich, of Georgia, the House Republican whip and a leader of the conservative wing of the party. "If they didn't matter, we'd have President Dukakis." 
 Mr. Darman, a pragmatist and the most influential figure on economic and domestc issues in the first two years of the Bush Administration, has become the scourge of conservatives. They accuse him of persuading President Bush to abandon his stance against new taxes and of then joining hands with Democrats this fall to pass a budget with not only unnecessary higher taxes, but also insufficient spending cuts in domestic programs.
The dispute became most severe about two weeks ago after Mr. Darman, the director of the Office of Management and Budget, gave a light-hearted speech in which he mocked the approach taken by conservatives. He called it "little more than slogans" that did not address "the hard choices of detailed program design and resource allocation."
That set off a barrage from critics on the right, and in a luncheon speech today, Mr. Gingrich took on Mr. Darman point by point.
The budget director declined to comment on Mr. Gingrich's speech.
In the short term, the outcome of the battle is among those factors that will determine the shape of the President's State of the Union Message and budget presentation early next year. In the long run it could determine whether Mr. Darman will continue to dominate the Administration's domestic policy; whether Mr. Gingrich, who was re-elected by fewer than 1,000 votes, will remain a prominent voice in Republican councils, and whether the party will slide further to the right or more toward the center as the 1992 Presidential election approaches.
After his speech Mr. Gingrich told reporters that he and Mr. Darman had talked amicably by telephone on Thursday and would meet next week to see if they could resolve their differences.
"Everything is in suspension for two or three weeks," he said, "to see if we can work together to reform the system."
If not, the Congressman added, he will resume his attacks on Administration policy. His opposition to the original budget agreement struck by Mr. Bush and some Congressional leaders was largely responsible for its defeat on the House floor last month. The budget that was finally approved was considerably more attractive from the Democratic perspective and less favorable from the Republican point of view.
Speaking to the American Legislative Exchange Council, an organization of conservative state legislators, Mr. Gingrich asserted that there were two schools of thought in Republican politics. He placed Mr. Darman in what he called the "managerialism" school, consisting of those who accept the existing system of government and want to make it work better.
He himself, Mr. Gingrich said, belongs to the other school and wants to "invent a new paradigm or a new model."
"We are on the wrong track," he said, and the times demand "a new domestic order."
Mr. Gingrich said the existing system discourages values like working, saving, investing and learning and is dominated by an entrenched bureaucracy and an obsolete Civil Service. Rules and regulations, he maintained, "encourage dumbness and discourage common sense."
"I'm not as smart as the director of the budget -- I didn't go to the Kennedy School," Mr. Gingrich continued. Instead of coining new words, as Mr. Darman did in his speech two weeks ago, Mr. Gingrich said he would stick to "simple words, like 'dumb.' "
 
In Praise of Adolescence
 The Congressman was especially critical of Mr. Darman's contention that American politicians have a "chronic attraction to the new," a sort of "perpetual national adolescence."
With his high-pitched voice rising even higher, Mr. Gingrich asked: "Is it adolescent to believe that maybe the South Bronx could work? Is it adolescent to believe that someday every American will have adequate health care at a reasonable cost? Is it adolescent to believe that someday Saddam Hussein might leave the Middle East without a war?"
Mr. Darman, "because he's a technocrat," did not grasp "the great romantic vision of being American," Mr. Gingrich said.
He argued generally that the country needed lower taxes and other incentives to give people more control over their own lives and to make the economy work better. But, except for supporting enterprise zones, a plan that gives tax breaks to businesses that provide jobs in poor neighborhoods, he offered no concrete policy prescriptions and did not suggest how his vision would be financed.
As for the budget director's view that conservatives were unwilling to make "the hard choices," Mr. Gingrich retorted, "What we need is not hard choices, it's hard thinking."

HEADLINE: 2 STATES PLANNING L.I. SOUND CLEANUP

BYLINE: By ALLAN R. GOLD

 BODY:
The Federal Government and the states of New York and Connecticut agreed yesterday to begin cleaning up Long Island Sound by curbing discharges of pollutants that have made parts of it a dead sea in recent summers.
Under the plan, New York and Connecticut agreed to upgrade 19 coastal sewage treatment plants in New York and 24 in Connecticut to remove the pollutants before they reach the water. But because the cost could ultimately exceed $6 billion, questions have been raised about where the money would come from when both Albany and Hartford as well as Washington are struggling to make ends meet. 
 "We don't know where the money is going to come from," said Albert F. Appleton, New York City's Commissioner of Environmental Protection.
New York State and New York City would bear most of the cleanup costs because its plants are larger. But all the participants recognized that the region's economic doldrums have made huge investments unlikely, at least in the next few years. They are therefore exploring a host of ways to finance the project, including Federal and state grants and loans, and new taxes and fees.
The goal is to prevent what environmental officials call the Sound's severest pollution problem -- oxygen depletion -- from getting worse. Oxygen levels are lowered, and marine life is threatened, when nutrients like nitrogen are discharged into the water from several sources, including sewage treatment plants.
Low levels of oxygen can occur naturally. But officials say what is happening in the Sound can be attributed to the level of nutrients like nitrogen making their way from sewage treatment plants and agricultural and street runoff. Nutrients feed the growth of algae, which, when they die, sink to the bottom, where they decompose in a process that uses oxygen.
Improving sewage treatment to remove nitrogen would thus check the flow of nutrients. But if the states cannot find the money to improve the plants, construction projects would be affected because sewer hookups would have to be restricted to meet the no-increase commitment.
"They won't be able to do that if it increases the nitrogen level," Julie Belaga, the administrator of Region One of the Environmental Protection Agency, said of unrestricted sewer hookups. The agreement to limit nutrient pollution came in a meeting at the Region One headquarters in Boston.
 
A Serious Threat
 Also present were Constantine Sidamon-Eristoff, the agency's regional administrator for New York; Leslie Carothers, Commissioner of Connecticut's Department of Environmental Protection, and Robert L. Bendick Jr., a deputy commissioner for New York State's Department of Environmental Conservation.
Federal officials and the states of New York and Connecticut are in the fifth year of a six-year study of Long Island Sound pollution. They are expected to complete a management plan next November to address problems like oxygen depletion, toxic substances and floating garbage.
But oxygen depletion is viewed as such a serious threat that officials sought to begin dealing with it now.
Over all, officials expect the cleanup of Long Island Sound to go on for at least 20 years.
In recent summers, from July to September, severe oxygen depletion has been meaured in sections of the Sound from the Throgs Neck Bridge east to Port Jefferson, L.I., and Bridgeport, Conn. Almost all aquatic organisms require oxygen, and in its absence, habitat becomes unusable.
 
Upgrading Existing Plants
 About 50 percent of the man-made sources of nitrogen originate with sewage treatment plants, the study has found. Officials are evaluating ways to limit discharges from sources like farm runoff, but these are far more difficult to identify and control than the sewage treatment plants.
As a result, the major approach in coming years will involve upgrading existing sewage treatment plants. And new sewage plants must employ the best treatment technology, according to the agreement.
New York City officials say that following this approach is unfair and will cost billions of dollars that it does not have. Mr. Appleton, the Environmental Protection Commissioner, said that nitrogen levels discharged from its sewage treatment plants have not increased in 40 years, reflecting a declining population.
On the other hand, Connecticut and Long Island have grown substantially, leading to substantial increases in nutrient discharges like lawn fertilizers.
"New York City is not the chief culprit in the problems of Long Island Sound," Mr. Appleton wrote this week in an essay in Newsday. Even if the city were to make the huge investment proposed and spend a decade building nitrogen-removal plants, he said, within 10 years the continued growth of pollution from sources other than treatment plants in Long Island and Connecticut would largely eliminate any gains.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Under a plan by the Federal Government and the states of New York and Connecticut to begin cleaning up Long Island Sound, 43 coastal sewage treatment plants, including one at Wards Island will be upgraded to remove the pollutants before they reach the waters. (William E. Sauro/The New York Times) (pg. 28)

HEADLINE: Walesa Foe Touching Sensitive Polish Nerves

BYLINE: By STEPHEN ENGELBERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WARSAW, Nov. 30 --

 BODY:
Stanislaw Tyminski, the wealthy emigre businessman who has turned Poland's presidential race upside down, has drawn on a personal philosophy in his campaigning that mixes Amazonian mysticism with economic theorizing from seemingly contradictory schools of thought.
Mr. Tyminski, a member of the far-right Libertarian Party of Canada, a tiny fringe group, favors sharp reductions in the role of Government. Nonetheless, as he has appealed to Polish workers fearful of losing jobs and position, he has called for the maintenance of Poland's subsidized social programs. 
 In this overwhelmingly Catholic country, he has stressed his Catholic faith but his associates say his spiritual awakening took place after he suffered business losses in Peru and journeyed through the jungle with local Indian tribes. He has written mystically of his own rise to "a fourth dimension" of existence through the practice of "self observation."
On the campaign trail and in his book, "Sacred Dogs," which he published here as he entered the Presidential race, Mr. Tyminski extols the virtues of rugged entrepeneurship, tax cuts and small-business success.
 
Emigrant Status Garners Respect
 His message, coupled with his self-declared status as a millionaire, seems to have touched many sensitive nerves in this country where successful emigrants are viewed with great respect. "Tyminski plays with myths, with frustrations, with our Polish complexes," said Czeslaw Bielecki, a writer and architect who was a clandestine activist in the Solidarity movement.
As he describes his view of Poland's economic future in both his book and his speeches, Mr. Tyminski plays on Polish memories and fears of conquest and dismemberment, claiming that the country once again stands defenseless against an onslaught by Western capitalists. The message he tries to convey is that only a man who has succeeded overseas can outsmart them and avert a future in which Poles become, as Mr. Tyminski puts it, "white slaves" providing cheap labor for the West.
Along the way he stresses that Poland's poverty is the fault of the tax system, the Communists or the current economic reform program, not any shortcoming among Poles.
"Look at the Poles who emigrate to the United States or Canada," he said in a recent interview. "They have neither savings nor disposable income. They work so hard, day and night, three or four jobs some of them. They rise very quickly, average three years, to the level of some security for themselves and their families."
 
Walesa Ahead in Poll
 The first public opinion poll published since Mr. Tyminski reached the presidential runoff put his rival, Lech Walesa, into the lead with 58 percent to 30 percent for Mr. Tyminski. Mr. Walesa finished first in last Sunday's ballot with 40 percent while Mr. Tyminski garnered 23 percent.
Today, Poland's bishops released a letter that hinted at support for Mr. Walesa, the Solidarity chairman. It did not mention him by name but called on voters to turn out for the Dec. 9 ballot because "we realize that it is a great effort that the nation united by the idea of Solidarity has been making to throw off the burden of the totalitarian system."
In his book, Mr. Tyminski describes his own spiritual beliefs. It is a subject he alludes to only elliptically in his campaign appearances.
According to Mr. Tyminski, human beings can normally comprehend only three states of being: the body, the intellect and the emotions. But he writes that through a process of "self observation" he has reached the fourth, or "spirit," dimension.
 
'Man of the Fourth Dimension'
 He argues that this has permitted him to recognize a crucially important third force in physics which is neither action nor reaction. He writes: "A good leader can only be a man who will act on the higher level with full understanding of the laws of nature. It must be a man of the fourth dimension."
Addressing this country's historic fears of its neighbors, Mr. Tyminski writes on page 220 of his book that Poland should develop a force of "intelligent rockets of middle range that have a nuclear warhead of one megaton." Mr. Tyminski, who does not welcome extensive interviews, has repeatedly denied at news conferences ever making such a proposal, and has challenged reporters to cite the place and time of his alleged remarks.
Mr. Tyminski repeatedly praises the idea of expanding trade with the Soviet Union. He noted at a recent news conference that he had visited Moscow in September to sign a contract between his Canadian computer concern, Transduction, and a Soviet company involved with industrial automation. Poland, he said, should accelerate its exports of pigs and other food items to the Soviet Union, which he insists has dollars, crude oil and natural gas available for payment.
 
Wants Tax System Changed
 On the stump, Mr. Tyminski calls for scrapping the current tax system, which has been set up to choke off soaring inflation. Under the economic reform plan, state enterprises must now pay punitive taxes if they raise their wages above certain ceilings.
At the same time, some of Mr. Tyminski's thinking resembles the unpopular policies that brought down the Government of Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki. For example, in his book he wrote that enterprises unable to support themselves "should be allowed to die a natural death."
In his campaign, however, he has seldom mentioned this idea.

HEADLINE: On Front Lines of the News Circulation War

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON

 BODY:
Hozel Williams spent the night on the B train and woke up just in time to get off at the right stop. He walked down 72d Street to the juice-and-hot-dog emporium he calls "Gray Papa's." In the darkness before dawn, the Gray's Papaya sign was blazing and the Daily News delivery truck was waiting at the curb. Another day, another bundle of freshly printed copies of the strikebound tabloid.
Mr. Williams, 29 years old, is a foot soldier in the ragtag army of homeless people and the unemployed who have been hawking The Daily News around the city, adding an odd and poignant touch to a bitter labor battle. By the time the sun had climbed over Central Park, he had staked out his territory on 72d Street, between Tip Top Shoes and the Roy Rogers fast-food restaurant on the Upper West Side. His paperweights were in place -- two croissants from the Eclair bakery up the street, protecting his stack of copies against the chilly breeze. 
 "Whatever you sell, you keep," he said. "Fifteen to 20 dollars a day. Big money." Ad hoc salesmen like Mr. Williams have become a crucial force in the battle for The News, especially now that the paper has won permission for hawkers to sell it in subway and commuter railroad stations. The News's chief spokesman, John T. Sloan, said that 1,109 hawkers have joined management's fight to keep the paper on the streets -- everyone from Sikhs in turbans to homeless people in parkas like Mr. Williams. Mr. Sloan said The News expects to have 1,700 sellers by the end of the month.
Despite the hawkers and their decibel-raising read-all-about-it sales pitches, The News is still hard to find in many neighborhoods. Mr. Sloan said that the hawker work force had been selling up to 150,000 copies aday and that he expected that to increase to 200,000 by Dec. 31 because of the ruling on transit-line sales.
But he acknowledged that The News was selling only about half as many copies as before the strike -- 508,000 copies a day, compared to 1.1 million on weekdays before the strike, which began Oct. 25.
In the weeks since The News's corporate strategists enlisted the hawkers, they have played out a street-corner drama like something out of "Les Miserables." At first, some of the hawkers said, they seemed to be in a different world from that of the middle-class people in suits and ties who were rushing by -- and who were their best prospects. But now, they said, they have customers who come back every morning.
"I'm selling more papers now than when I started," said a hawker at 53d Street and Third Avenue who gave his name as Joey. "People trust me; I'm now the equivalent of a newsstand."
At first, he said, he was selling 75 of the 100 papers he picked up every day. Now, he said, he is taking 200, selling 175 and pocketing $40.
From their street-corner outposts, the hawkers know only too well that the strike has been violent. Delivery trucks have been firebombed and battered by bricks and several strikers have been arrested on weapons charges. But more than 20 hawkers questioned at random in different neighborhoods this week said they had had relatively few problems with attacks.
"People call me a scab and union buster," Joey said, "but as long as they don't physically bother me, I don't care."
Some said a bigger worry was rival hawkers trying to steal their papers. Terence Lewis, an unemployed underwater salvage worker who was hawking The News at 72d Street and Broadway, was making change for a customer yesterday when a man in a dirty Army jacket and a ski cap grabbed a bundle from Mr. Lewis's stack.
With nickels and dimes jingling in his Daily News apron, Mr. Lewis chased the man into the IRT subway station. He made the tight squeeze through through the turnstile -- no time to buy a token -- and clambered down the stairs to the platform. But Mr. Lewis returned to his above-ground purlieu empty handed.
 
'Slow, but It's Going'
 "He had a knife," said Mr. Lewis, who described himself as a former champion boxer accustomed to fending for himself, "so I just had to leave him be."
Mr. Lewis suffered no out-of-pocket loss: he got the bundles he was selling free from the same delivery truck as Mr. Williams. Some hawkers said they they pay for their bundles. More than one said it depends on the day: They said they have been told that weekday papers are free but the Sunday paper is not, so they do not show up on Sundays to claim bundles.
And on other days, some ad hoc vendors said, the papers do not sell themselves.
"It's slow but it's going," said Mike Hill, a handyman and sometime painter who said he had been selling 200 copies a day on the street near Grand Central Terminal.
 
400 Papers in Two Hours
 But others insisted they were making money -- good money. Gus Tsakanikus begins his day by picking up bundles at the News building on East 42d Street and banking on early-morning sales to lighten his load. Then he heads to the Holland Tunnel, where, he said, he sells 400 papers in two hours. "Some people give me a quarter; some people give me more," he said. "But I always make about $150 a day for about five hours' work."
Mr. Lewis -- a six-bundle-a-day man on Broadway who said he had been unemployed for more than three months -- said he sympathized with the strikers. But he voiced anger at the homeless hawkers. He said the unions and The News should negotiate a speedy end to the strike because the homeless "degrade this paper by selling at all different prices, and then its value will be nothing and the strikers' jobs and the benefits they want won't exist anymore."
A few steps away on 72d Street, Mr. Williams settled in for a morning of steady sales. He said he had worked as a cook at a fast-food restaurant in the Bronx and as a dishwasher at a restaurant in Greenwich Village. "That was a good job," he said as he sold a paper to a man with a German shepherd. "Six bucks an hour."
He said he saw his work as a job, not a career. "I'm not doing this the rest of my life," he said. "This is just something for right now."
Like anyone who has been doing a thing long enough to settle into a routine, he has good days and bad days. Thursday was a bad day.
"I overslept," he said, "so I missed my papers. That's what I get for sleeping on the A train. I woke up at Lefferts Boulevard in Queens."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "Whatever you sell, you keep," said Hozel Williams, who has been hawking copies of The Daily News on West 72d Street. "Fifteen to twenty dollars a day. Big money." (Bill Swersey for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Bolshoi is Born; East Texas is Midwife

BYLINE: By ROBERTO SURO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: COLLEGE STATION, Tex., Nov. 30

 BODY:
Here in the Brazos River country of East Texas, about 100 miles north of Houston, ballet is rarer than cowboys in sneakers. The university here, Texas A & M, is famed for its farmers, engineers and scientists but not for its fine arts.
This was bonfire week, a time marked by beer drinking and the singing of football fight songs with lyrics like, "Hullabaloo, Caneck! Caneck!" but this year Tchaikovsky's sweet melodies also rang out here. 
 Aggieland, as the campus is known to those who love it, has just served as the birthplace for a ballet company.
Surrounded by adolescent revelry, a new troupe of Soviet dancers led by Yuri Grigorovich, the artistic director of the Bolshoi Ballet, began an artistic and commercial experiment here. It was an experiment for both the dancers and for this college town, and there seems to have been a strange meshing of otherwise alien cultures.
On Thursday night thousands of students, alumni and mere fans watched the burning of a pyre 55 feet high to insure victory this weekend against their despised rival, the University of Texas at Austin. The police proclaimed it a relatively sedate evening since only about 20 people were arrested for public drunkenness and only 70 minors were cited for possession of alcohol.
 
'An Ideal Place'
 The Soviet visitors watched from afar, but they had their own bonfire party. Mr. Grigorovich, a master of Russian ballet for more than 30 years, donned a cowboy hat, struck rugged poses and hoisted margaritas to salute the debut of his latest and perhaps most ambitious creation, the Bolshoi Ballet Grigorovich Company.
"This was our birth for public performances and touring," Mr. Grigorovich said through an interpreter, "and this was an ideal place for it because ballet is about youth and our company is about youth and this is a young people's place and because everyone, everyone received us so warmly."
The 60 dancers he brought to Texas A & M from troupes and academies across the Soviet Union cheered him and his hat. Then they tried to eat fajitas with forks until laughing Aggies showed them how to use fingers.
Aside from the ages of the dancers, which range from 18 to 25, the most distinctive feature of Mr. Grigorovich's new company is that it claims to be the only major classical ballet troupe in the Soviet Union that operates without state subsidies or controls. It will dance at the Bolshoi Theater in Moscow and make use of Bolshoi dancers, replicas of its sets and its choreography. But as an independent company destined primarily for touring it will draw its income only from the box office.
Mr. Grigorovich remains artistic director for the main Bolshoi company, a post he has held since 1964. He said he intended to feature one or two established figures from the Bolshoi regularly, like Nadezhda Pavlova, who is traveling with the new company, but otherwise the new company will be made up of young artists, some with no professional experience.
 
Doing What They Want
 Most of all, Mr. Grigorovich said, the troupe he formed over the summer is a bid to break away from the Soviet cultural bureaucracy and to exploit the new economic freedoms.
"We will put on real Bolshoi performances," he said, "but we will be free to do what we want. We can keep dancers or sack them if they do not suit the company because they are under contract and we pay them with our money. If we can sell ourselves, good; if not, too bad."
If nothing else, Texas A & M provided the Grigorovich company with the commercial support it desperately needed to get off the ground. Hundreds of people camped out overnight by the box office before tickets went on sale, and all but one of nine performances at the 2,500-seat Rudder Auditorium have sold out.
The company has performed "The Nutcracker" and a mixed bill called "The Best of the Bolshoi" here. After its final performance Saturday, the troupe is scheduled to go to Miami to put on the mixed bill at the Jackie Gleason Performing Arts Center from Tuesday to Friday. In New York from Dec. 19 to Dec. 30 it will perform "The Nutcracker" at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
This version of Tchaikovsky's Christmas ballet has not been performed in the United States since the Bolshoi Ballet closed the old Metropolitan Opera House on a night in 1966.
Some of the Soviet dancers are already waxing nostalgic about Texas audiences. Natalya Bashkatova, an 18-year-old who has toured extensively with the Bolshoi Academy, said: "Nowhere else do people give this kind of reception. They applaud all the time, in the middle of the dance, at the end, they clap for everything you do. It is strange, but now I like it very much."
 
Troupes Visit Regularly
 As an all-male military school until the mid-1960's, Texas A & M developed as a place where rural boys went to get a technical education. Aggie jokes told all over Texas, except in Aggieland, are of the sort that mock the number of Aggies needed to screw in a light bulb.
Regardless of its reputation, deserved or not, Texas A & M manages to support regular visits by performing arts groups of national and international stature."
Mr. Grigorovich said he chose this site for his company's debut over 27 other places he visited in the United States because of Rudder Auditorium. It has a stage big enough to handle the company's sets, and it has an extra-springy dance floor that was built to the specifications of Rudolf Nureyev, who performed here in 1988.
 
Exceptional Experience
 For both the dance company and the community, however, this visit was an exceptional experience. The previous record for the longest run by a performing arts group here was three shows by a touring company of "Cats," and virtually all other visiting performers do just one show. Meanwhile, the Soviet troupe did more than simply perform. Under the slogan "Bolshoi and Bonfire," which was printed on thousands of T-shirts, they were absorbed into Aggie lore.
Arriving more than a week before the curtain went up for the first show, the company spent an extended rehearsal period developing its repertory. The company had only done three trial performances in Moscow.
Many of the dancers had never been out of the Soviet Union, and their visit may give them a thoroughly distorted view of America, if they think it is all like Aggieland. A series of official functions, including a ranch barbecue, a black-tie reception and an on-field appearance before a football game, made them all big people on campus. As a result, they have been taken to innumerable parties; restaurants have served them free and students have chauffeured them to their favorite destinations, nearby shopping malls.
Mr. Grigorovich says a kind of bonding took place. "This school is so closely connected to sport," he said, "and ballet is very physical like sport. With these young dancers, they've seen that our art is the art of the body. So maybe this is the beginning of something new here."

GRAPHIC: Photos: The Bolshoi Ballet Grigorovich Company of the Soviet Union made its debut this week at Texas A & M University in College Station, Tex. Above, ballet members at a fajita party with local residents. Yuri Grigorovich, the artistic di rector of the Bolshoi Ballet, with his new cowboy hat. (Photographs by F. Carter Smith for The New York Times)

LENGTH: 608 words

HEADLINE: Coping;
With Tipping in Lean Times

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS

 BODY:
In these less-than-flush times, what can you do if you can't afford a seasonal tip to the people who make your life run smoothly -- the mail carrier, the hairdresser, the household helper, the child-care worker, the doorman, the garage attendant?
 "I think that everyone understands what's going on in the economy," said Fred G. Sampson, a former board member of the National Restaurant Association. His advice is to give what you can. "Don't ignore the holidays," he said. "It may not have been a good year for them, either." 
 "Letter carriers appreciate any sort of expression that shows you think they gave a year of good service," said Drew Von Bergen, a spokesman for the National Association of Letter Carriers, which has 235,000 active members.
If you live in an apartment building, the staff will expect recognition, even if it is only a fraction of what you gave in the past.
 And what if you simply haven't got any tipping money? "Write a personal note of thanks," said Charles Rappaport, the president of the Federation of New York Cooperatives. "Or if you feel you can give something, even it's only a very small amount, explain in the note why you can't match last year's gift."
 Another solution is to organize a program of apartment-house-wide giving. Marvin Gold, president of a Brooklyn management company, said several buildings that his company manages are thinking of "a combined gift."
A number of co-op residents, he said, felt that it would be insulting to stuff an envelope with two or three dollar bills -- all they could afford -- and had decided to give nothing.
 Group gifts were a welcome alternative. "All you need is someone -- or a few volunteers -- to go around collecting from each apartment," Mr. Gold said.
He went on to say that in the buildings where this was tried, the "combined" amount given each employee was far more than the employee would have received if the residents had given individually.
Similarly, Ellen Galinksy, co-president of the Families and Work Institute in New York, a national group that conducts research on work life and family life, suggests that if you cannot afford something for each of your children's day-care or after-school teachers and their assistants, a combined bonus from all the parents, with a note of greeting signed by all of them, will save face.
 "People in the early-child field are so hopelessly underpaid that they really do need the money," Ms. Galinsky said.
 Buying a cheap gift -- a bottle of cologne, a packet of soaps -- rather than giving a small amount of cash may not be as thoughtful as it seems,especially for workers in the lowest-paid occupations.
"Cash still goes down better than almost anything else among our workers," said Henry Levy, vice president of the Metropolitan Route Dealers Association, an umbrella group for independent newspaper delivery services in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. "What can you do with 100 pens?"
But small, individual gifts of cash, he said, can add up: If 100 households give $5 each, the deliverer has an extra $500 to pay some bills.
For a maitre d'hotel, a waiter or a hairdresser who is routinely tipped the year round, a homemade or handmade gift is a possibility.
Sal Fodera, a board member of the National Cosmetology Association in St. Louis, said, "It's important to our people to feel appreciated, even if all you can manage is a box of chocolates, a bottle of wine or a cake baked at home for the salon's Christmas party."
 "A handmade gift is especially meaningful," said Kathy Robertson, president of the International Nanny Association in Austin, Tex.


GRAPHIC: Graphic: The Gift Most Sought? Cash
 
If you plan to give cash to those who serve you regularly through the year, here's a guide to tipping from professional associations. Remember that giving less in hard times is preferable to giving nothing.
 
Maitre d'hotel ..... $50 to $100
Doorman, building superintendent ..... $20 to $30
Handyman, porter, elevator operator ..... $10 to $20
Maid ..... One week's salary
Care giver ..... A week's salary or a gift equal in price
Paper deliverer ..... One month's service charge
Other deliverers ..... $10 to $30
Hairdresser, barber, manicurist ..... At least 20 percent of the cost of one visit

SECTION: Section 7; Page 22; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 2443 words

HEADLINE: ARCHITECTURE

BYLINE: By Martin Filler; Martin Filler, who frequently writes on architecture, is a contributing editor of Conde Nast Traveler, HG and Vanity Fair magazines.

 BODY:
LOOKING AT ARCHITECTURE. By G. E. Kidder Smith. 168 pp. (Abrams, $35.) It is difficult to imagine a more engaging introduction to the art of building than this collection of black-and-white photographs by the indefatigable G. E. Kidder Smith, who for more than 50 years has been recording architecture around the world for books that are now standard reference works. Trained as an architect, Mr. Smith has a sure grasp of what a building is essentially about, and he conveys the three-dimensional presence of a structure with remarkable power in his two-dimensional medium.
The photographer's selection of his own best pictures, sympathetically set off by Bob McKee's elegant book design, includes 80 landmarks renowned (the Parthenon, Taj Mahal and Eiffel Tower) as well as unfamiliar (the abbey of Pomposa in Italy, the country church of Havero church in central Sweden and the village of Baniane, Algeria). His striking images and pithy accompanying texts are personal, generous and illuminating. This is a man in love with architecture, and he transmits the pleasures of his life-long affair so joyously that few readers are likely to come away untouched by the broad expanse of his vision.
THE WORLD OF CHARTRES. By Jean Favier. 191 pp. (Abrams, $60.) No book can hope to capture the physical immediacy of the Cathedral of Notre Dame de Chartres, but this is a noble reminder of one of the consummate glories of Western architecture. Mostly built between 1194 and its dedication in 1260, to the designs of nine master masons, the present edifice replaced an earlier church destroyed by fire and believed to have been erected on the site of a pagan temple. Few who visit this overwhelming monument doubt that it is a sacred place, even though it possesses an insistently irrational quality at odds with the common perception of Gothic architecture as lucid and uplifting.
Chartres appeals to impulses embedded so deep in human memory that the spell this building casts quite defies explication through an inventory of its component parts. The narrative meanings of the biblical themes depicted in the cathedral's sublime stone sculpture and incomparable stained glass windows are more readily comprehended than the mysterious interactions of light and space within this stupendous, disturbing structure. For the immovable art of architecture, a book performs well if it makes one want to go to a building for a firsthand look, and at that this volume succeeds beautifully.
THE VILLA: Form and Ideology of Country Houses. By James S. Ackerman. 304 pp. (Bollingen Series XXXV, No. 34. Princeton University, $45.) Among the several histories of the country house published in 1990, this is easily the best. James S. Ackerman, the Arthur Kingsley Porter Professor of Fine Arts at Harvard University, is the acknowledged expert on Andrea Palladio, the late Renaissance architect and theorist whose classical villas in the Veneto region of Italy remained the international country house ideal for centuries, especially in the United States. Mr. Ackerman rightly places Palladio as the pivotal figure in his thoughtful, thought-provoking study of the villa from ancient Rome to the early 20th-century houses of Frank Lloyd Wright and Le Corbusier.
This is not an exhaustive chronological survey, but a series of focused chapters -- they were the A. W. Mellon Lectures in the Fine Arts given at the National Gallery of Art in 1985 -- on the villa and its patrons at important junctures, among them the Medici in Tuscany, the Earl of Burlington and his circle in Georgian England, and Thomas Jefferson at Monticello. In each of them the author strikes a judicious balance between formal analysis and social interpretation.
Mr. Ackerman is quick to point out that the villa is not synonymous with the country house, the former term being reserved for buildings conceived for the pure enjoyment of the countryside, not primary residences weighted down with practical requirements. But that definition, correct though it may be, gets somewhat stretched by the time we reach Jefferson's exceedingly functional farmhouse, to say nothing of Wright's suburban Coonley house in Riverside, Ill.
Perhaps the certainty with which the Renaissance scholar can assess an Arcadian past accounts for the gloomy way Mr. Ackerman views the present. Though he stops far short of contemporary villas because "no historian can see his own time clearly," he laments that "the traditional ideology that imputed spiritual and moral values to country life has finally been lost." That may be so, but for millions of city dwellers around the world, their villas, however modest -- from log cabins on the lakes of Minnesota to wooden dachas in the Lenin Hills of Moscow -- remain the safety valves that make modern urban life tolerable during the working week, between rural escapes.
LIFE IN THE GEORGIAN CITY. By Dan Cruickshank and Neil Burton. 288 pp. (Viking, $35.) Few epochs in the history of design have been more wrongly romanticized than the 18th century. But this account of what daily life was actually like for Londoners during that imagined golden age will make interesting reading for people worried about the declining quality of life in big cities now. These were the good old days, the authors recall for us, when streets were unsafe and dirty and traffic was impossibly congested; when the air was polluted, real-estate developers were greedy, and contractors were apt to cut corners.
Mr. Cruickshank and Mr. Burton are particularly good at detailing the middle- and upper-class social conventions that both shaped and responded to the rapid expansion of the capital city during Britain's ascent as the world's leading economic and colonial power. They also provide information on everything from bricklaying techniques and paint colors to water closets and garbage removal, making intelligent use of period illustrations as a source of documentation often overlooked by historians who favor verbal records. If not up to the sheer brilliance of Sir John Summerson's 1945 classic "Georgian London," this book helps explode the myth of 18th-century perfection, while offering convincing reasons why the general level of urban design was so much better then than it is today.
THE UNROMANTIC CASTLE: And Other Essays. By John Summerson. 288 pp. (Thames and Hudson, $35.) At the age of 86, Sir John Summerson is the greatest living architectural historian, and the publication of any new book of his is always a welcome event. This compendium of articles and lectures takes its title from Riber Castle, a mid-Victorian pile in Derbyshire that housed the author's old school and first aroused his awareness of the difference between good and bad architecture. His latest anthology is another virtuoso demonstration of the gifts that make him such a delight to read: a graceful style, an unflagging curiosity, an accomplished but never pedantic command of facts and an ability to put forth ideas with the assured ease of an enthusiast eager to share his thoughts with like-minded friends.
But Sir John's Apollonian temperament has not led him to the admiration of classical architecture alone, though of course he excels at that. In addition to his definitive essay on the 18th-century English country house, this book also contains several pathbreaking studies on Victorian architecture, including the once-despised semidetached suburban villas of London. He is also attracted to some of the more offbeat practitioners of classicism, including the bizarre neoclassical maverick Sir John Soane (of whose eccentric house-museum in London Sir John Summerson was curator for almost 40 years) and the early 20th-century mannerist Sir Edwin Lutyens, whose unexecuted scheme for the Roman Catholic cathedral of Liverpool, the author persuasively argues, would have been among the most awe-inspiring churches in Christendom.
Sir John, who is more than an antiquarian, concludes with an eloquent case for the history of modern architecture: "The main thing is to get that history right and to get it clear." Those are tenets this scrupulous, peerless scholar has always personified.
CLAUDE-NICOLAS LEDOUX: Architecture and Social Reform at the End of the Ancien Regime. By Anthony Vidler. 447 pp. (MIT, $50.) The French Enlightenment architect Claude-Nicolas Ledoux has become a patron saint of the post-modernists, who see in his pared-down but intensified version of classicism proof that ancient tradition can be recast in contemporary terms. Would that they possessed just a bit of his terrifying talent. Anthony Vidler, a professor of architecture at Princeton University, demonstrates with learned but lively authority that long before the Bastille fell, Ledoux's designs attained their visionary impact not just through daring manipulations of mass and detail, but because of the architect's uncanny knack for encapsulating timely theoretical issues in structural form.
Ledoux's incisively geometric customhouses surrounding Paris were architectural harbingers of the sweeping political changes about to occur, revolutionary sentinels in stone. His biggest chance to build -- the ideal city of Chaux, a royal saltworks erected on a radical plan near Besancon during the first decade of Louis XVI's reign -- was a metaphor for the orderly universe. Ironically, the new social system Ledoux helped presage condemned him as an accomplice of the monarchy, and thereafter most of his quirky variations on classical grandeur were fated to remain mere dreams of glory.
ELIEL SAARINEN: Projects 1896-1923. By Marika Hausen, Kirmo Mikkola, Anna-Lisa Amberg and Tytti Valto. 355 pp. (MIT, $125.) When he immigrated to the United States in 1923 after winning second prize in the Chicago Tribune Building competition, the Finnish architect Eliel Saarinen began the distinguished second half of his fertile career. He went on to design the richly ornamented Cranbrook Academy of Art in Bloomfield Hills, Mich., and a number of fine but much simpler church buildings. Yet by the end of his life he was eclipsed by the greater fame of his son, Eero, one of the leading lights of American architecture in the 1950's.
The earlier portion of the elder Saarinen's output, on which his reputation ought rightfully to rest, is not as celebrated as it should be. This extensive catalogue of his designs up to the age of 50 covers his best-known works in Finland -- his own country house, Hvittrask, and the Helsinki Railway Station -- as well as scores of proposals for everything from furniture to civic planning. In all of them, the architect struggled to devise an authentic national style for his homeland, then a grand duchy under Russian rule, in resistance against Czar Nicholas II's Russification campaign of 1899. The prodigious vigor of what might be termed Saarinen's Viking Art Nouveau phase -- compact, boldly emblazoned structures fairly bursting with folkloric energy -- makes this book one of the unexpected treasures of the season.
A SYSTEM OF ARCHITECTURAL ORNAMENT. By Louis H. Sullivan. 159 pp. (Rizzoli, $200.) Louis Sullivan was the Walt Whitman of American architecture, a sprawling genius of startling originality and unrestrained vitality whose spirit embraced multitudes. But for all his poetic inclination, Sullivan pursued his art in the hardheaded world of Chicago big business at the end of the 19th century, when he established himself as the master builder of the skyscraper.
After 1900, Sullivan's career soured, and with only a sporadic series of small bank commissions in small Midwestern towns to sustain him through two decades, he barely subsisted on the brink of destitution. In 1922, two years before his death, the Art Institute of Chicago's Burnham Library of Architecture paid Sullivan to set down, in words and drawings, his philosophy of organic design. The architect's response to his task was profound. He brought forth a manuscript of breathtaking beauty and heartfelt emotion, an exaltation of the life force in architecture as much as in himself.
Never has there been a more inventive ornamentalist. Sullivan's lush tangles of botanical forms and abstract patterns, reproduced in facsimile in this imposing folio with their delicate details intact, are wonders of complexity and coherence. First published by the American Institute of Architects in 1924, they offer timeless lessons in the dialogue between the whole of a design and its constituent parts. Above all, these mandala-like motifs are a testament to creative survival. Amid all this dazzling draftsmanship is the simple diagram of a sprout under which Sullivan inscribed his credo of regeneration: "Remember the Seed-Germ."
THE LIVING HOUSE: An Anthropology of Architecture in South-East Asia. By Roxana Waterson. 263 pp. (Oxford University, $49.95.) Architectural traditionalists have made much in recent years of the need for a return to evocative signs and symbols in building. That imperative is deemed most urgent for houses, in which elements such as the pitched roof, central front door and prominent chimney are believed to confer the sense of psychic protection fundamental to domestic shelter. Nevertheless, the problem remains that architecture alone cannot make people feel at home in the universe. If social and religious institutions do not give those comforts, there is little that a house can do to compensate for a lack of larger spiritual connection.
That is one pertinent conclusion to be drawn from Roxana Waterson's engrossing study of traditional architecture among some 70 tribal ethnic groups in Southeast Asia. Ms. Waterson, an anthropologist at the National University of Singapore, elucidates the concept of semangat ("life force" in Malay and many Indonesian languages) as an integral part of animist beliefs that imbue buildings with a living presence acknowledged by makers and inhabitants alike and manifest in every step of the construction process.
From the selection of a site (during which the permission of the land must be sought) and the propitiation of the indigenous deities (Thai architecture incorporates a miniature spirit house to accommodate gods displaced by building) to the raising of the center post (the all-powerful navel of a house) and the roofing of a structure (often a communal effort accompanied by complex rituals), the author presents a memorable chronicle of some of the richest architectural cultures on earth. This is an instructive example of how "primitive" ways of building can help us understand why most of our architecture no longer performs numinous functions for us.
