SECTION: Section 6; Part 2; Page 20; Column 1; Business World Magazine

LENGTH: 3762 words

HEADLINE: International;
Prague's Spring Into Capitalism

BYLINE: BY LAWRENCE E. JOSEPH; Lawrence E. Joseph, the author of "Gaia: The Growth of an Idea," is based in Brooklyn, N.Y.

 BODY:
WHEN THE MACHINES FROM America finally arrived, they were in crates stamped "DO NOT OPEN!" in big black letters. A dozen women, kerchiefs in their hair and mops and dustpans in their hands, wandered in to smoke cigarettes and steal a peek.
But Stanislav Kuthan was not about to let anyone play Pandora with his boxes. The deputy director of the Tesla Electronics factory in Raspenava, a hamlet two hours northeast of Prague, had worked too hard to risk any accidents now. 
 When Kuthan set out to modernize his company in 1988, he says, "we found out we had fallen 20 years behind the rest of the semiconductor industry." For two years, the slight, fair-haired engineer battled government bureaucrats and a Yugoslavian competitor, while playing hardball with American negotiators, to win a joint-venture agreement with a Vista, Calif.,-based company called Pacific Vista Systems.
Now the boxes from California were here, soon to be followed by a team of Pacific Vista technicians to set up a new production line. The transformed factory will increase Tesla's annual output of 150 million computer capacitors by a factor of 3,000 percent -- if Tesla's workers prove equal to the exacting demands of the new technology.
"We will compete openly on the world market by next year," says Kuthan. "We are confident of making a lot of profit -- unless, of course, our national economy collapses."
Kuthan's doomsday humor captures the national mood in Czechoslovakia a year after Vaclav Havel's "velvet revolution" swept the Communists from power. The country's transformation from a centralized command economy to a mixed, primarily free-market system is a period of giddy hopes and grave doubts.
Elsewhere, such careening emotions would indicate a national neurosis. But in the course of two trips to Czechoslovakia since Havel took power, I have come to realize that the rules applicable elsewhere are of limited relevance in the Czech and Slovak Federal Republic. In this land that inspired Franz Kafka's surrealism, a nation where today the president is a playwright and the American Ambassador a former movie tap dancer, a visitor often feels he has stumbled onto the set of an experimental film.
"We have an irrational, wasteful, nonfunctioning centrally planned economy," says Vaclav Klaus, the 41-year-old Finance Minister. "The transition to a free-market system must be radical, immediate and irrevocable."cw0
It is Klaus, graying but athletically lean at just under 6 feet tall, who has set his nation on that course. The economics point man for the Government of President Havel toils in a utilitarian office in the Finance Ministry, a 15-minute walk down the hill from Havel's stately suite in Hradcany, the Prague castle where the President and his aides hold court. Along with Havel, Klaus is implementing drastic new laws and policies designed to revive Czechoslovakia's atrophied economy by administering the tonics of competition, profit and private property.

LAUS, WHO MAJORED IN FOREIGN trade at the College of Economics in Prague, had little chance to shape policy under the Communists. In 1970 he was kicked out of the Czechoslovak Academy of Sciences, where he was a researcher, after a hearing in which he was branded "the leading counterrevolutionary" among Government economists.
Now, as his compatriots look to him for answers, the Finance Minister has adopted some distinctly capitalist role models. He has read extensively the works of Milton Friedman, the shaman of the University of Chicago thinkers who provided theoretical underpinnings for President Reagan's economic revolution. Klaus also admires Jeffrey Sachs, a Harvard professor who is a lead architect of Poland's growth-by-pain economic plan.
The most direct free-market influence, however, comes from another Harvard professor: Martin S. Feldstein, the former chairman of President Reagan's Council of Economic Advisors. Feldstein, who is now C.E.O. of the National Bureau of Economic Research in Cambridge, Mass., has traveled to Prague, dispensing capitalist advice and encouragement. He also has been holding a series of pro bono tutorials for Czechoslovakian economists sent to Massachusetts by Klaus to study Homo oeconomicus at Feldstein's knee. Among other prescriptions, Feldstein is advising Havel's Government to endow a market-driven social-security plan in which worker retirement accounts would be created, with the money invested in mutual funds.
Klaus has turned to America's free-market true believers in reaction to an absence of alternatives closer to home. Certainly, as economic anarchy sweeps Eastern Europe, Czechoslovakia can no longer blame -- or rely on -- Soviet domination. Comecon, the Communist Common Market that controlled almost three-quarters of Czechoslovakia's international trade, has disintegrated.
Meanwhile, the United Nations embargo of Iraq has clamped shut Czechoslovakia's access to the more than $2 billion in gas and oil that Iraq was to pay for tanks and other armaments. And Czechoslovakia's major oil supplier, the Soviet Union, has cut its shipments by about 35 percent. (The Soviets blame production problems at home, but many Czechoslovakians suspect the flow will resume after Jan. 1, when Moscow will begin demanding hard currency, rather than bartered goods, for Soviet oil.)
"A terrible coincidence, this oil crisis," Klaus tells me, with a disarming grin. "Too bad it didn't happen two years ago. We could have blamed the Communists."

KLAUS HAS HIS CRITICS WITHIN Czechoslovakia, and Valtr Komarek may be the most outspoken. "The social prices of these reforms have simply not been adequately discussed," complains Komarek, who believes Klaus is trying to change too much, too fast.
Komarek is taking a break between votes at the national Parliament, housed in an austerely post-modern building at the top of Prague's Wenceslas Square -- thus situating Parliament, locals joke, "halfway between the theater and the museum." A bearded bear of a man, Komarek is unofficial leader of the legislature's left-wing minority -- a shaky coalition of economic gradualists and some former Communists who fear that Finance Minister Klaus is leading the fledgling democracy into intense stagflation, massive unemployment and social disruption. Already, workers around the country have staged a series of demonstrations and brief, symbolic strikes.
The head of the Academy of Sciences' Economic Forecasting Institute in Prague, Komarek was Deputy Finance Minister in Havel's administration before losing out in a power struggle with Klaus. "Too many political careers have been launched mouthing the slogans of radical economic reform," Komarek complains. "There's an aggression to their politics, and a strong spiritual primitivism that reminds me of Castro coming to power in Cuba."
His critics notwithstanding, Klaus is second only to Havel in national popularity. In October he beat Havel's hand-picked candidate to win election as chairman of the Civic Forum, the coalition of dissidents responsible for last year's democratic revolution and now the nation's dominant political party.
Yet even Havel -- who appointed Klaus and took pains to express solidarity with the Finance Minister after the Civic Forum vote -- advocates a more gradual approach, as was evident in a September press conference. On a brilliantly sunny afternoon, Havel faced reporters in the great hall of Hradcany. It was the perfect opportunity to embrace free-market ideology, for appearing with him was Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain -- the woman who, along with Ronald Reagan, had been reviled by the previous regime as one of the great devils of capitalism.
But when I asked the president whether the time had come to turn over the marketplace to the entrepreneurs, Havel hesitated for a long, awkward moment before responding: "Right now we are in a transitional stage, where individual businesses are acting as though they were private, but without legal standing. The law must be articulated before we proceed."
Klaus, buoyed by his own burgeoning power, is impatient with such gradualism. "Whatever the social costs," he tells me, "they will be worse if we remain with this impossible status quo. There is no other way."

LET THE BUREAUCRATS worry about the paperwork. We are in the business of making meat," says Miroslav Petricek, a 36-year-old butcher, speaking for himself and his partner, Karel Klovcek, 32. In the bustling town of Hejnice, a half-mile down the road from the Tesla Raspenava factory, stands their popular new private meat market. This past summer Petricek and Klovcek were granted the right to take over the abandoned Government butcher shop, renovate it and start their own business.
"We make our salamis, smoke pork and even mix our own tea sausage. It disappeared from shelves because the state sausage makers were too lazy to make it," says Petricek. As he speaks, he cleaves a tenderloin from its thick layer of fat. "We plan to build a new smokehouse, as soon as we take full legal possession of our shop."
In the current environment, possession counts for considerably less than nine-tenths of the law. Under a law widely known as "the restitution act," which took effect Nov. 1, mom and pop businesses like the Hejnice meat market could be returned to their original owners. The claimants will need to prove that they lost their shops when the Communists nationalized private property in 1955. Tens of thousands of small businesses could be subject to such claims, with the resulting legal battles extending into the next century.
By opening debate on restitution, Czechoslovakia's legislators are asking a fundamental question about the nation's history: Is Czechoslovakia regaining a former state of freedom, or is it starting over again? "The whole issue of restitution is extremely difficult, perhaps impossible," says Klaus. "I don't know if there's an answer. I might almost be inclined to regard Communism as a natural dis aster and not give anything back to anybody," he says, less out of conviction than exasperation with the coming legal quagmire.
Under a law commonly called "the small-scale privatization act," several hundred thousand commercial establishments are expected to escape probate and simply be auctioned to the highest bidder. The terms: payment in full after seven days. Honest vendors, however, fear they cannot compete with the vast, illicit wealth of those who control Czechoslovakia's shadow economy: corrupt bureaucrats, black marketers and disgruntled members of the disbanding secret police. Petricek and Klovcek worry that bidding could drive the price of their butcher shop far beyond their reach.
President Havel -- who might be one of the richest men in Eastern Europe had the Communists not confiscated his family's wealth -- is determined to protect his nation from former Government officials who illegally accumulated riches during the Communist era. To Havel, this widely despised "Communist mafia" is the last and most powerful vestige of Soviet control.
In a speech Aug. 21, the anniversary of the 1968 Soviet invasion, Havel denounced "the extremely dark Slusovice-type practices" that he said were symptomatic of the moral and ethical problems plaguing Czechoslovakian industry. The reference to the United Agricultural Cooperative of Slusovice was shocking: Slusovice, a confederation of 14 villages in the Moravia region of central Czechoslovakia, had long been touted as the nation's economic showpiece; it was as if George Bush had insinuated that Disney World is a front for organized crime.
Slusovice was founded by the Communists in 1949 near Zlin, the village where Tomas Bata, the Czech shoe baron, a generation earlier had founded one of Europe's great industrial complexes. After the 1968 Soviet invasion, the once-humble Slusovice agricultural collective would become a country within a country, with massive chemical and computer factories and its own commercial airline. Under its director, Frantisek Cuba, the cooperative conducted its own foreign trade, amassed huge hard-currency reserves and -- as it now appears -- laundered perhaps hundreds of millions of dollars for Communist cronies.
The day after Havel's "dark practices" speech, Cuba resigned. This month, a law designed to confiscate assets acquired illegally by the criminal underworld is scheduled to take effect.

IN CAMBRIDGE, MASS., 3,900 miles from Prague, Martin Feldstein discusses the fledgling democracy as if he were talking about a bright but stubborn pupil. "I can hardly believe that the Havel administration's highest priority is finding out who has accumulated capital illegally," Feldstein tells me. "Their biggest problem is that after 40 years under a command economy, a lot of their businesses just cannot compete."
Even if Feldstein is sometimes displeased with the way his counsel translates into policy, he believes he has successfully imparted the notion that the capitalist system is not necessarily fair. "Members of the current administration are prepared to accept the fact that there will be some income inequality," he says. "Some people will own Mercedes automobiles, while others will do less well."
In rejoining the world community, Czechoslovakia is eager to be seen not as an Eastern bloc country but, simply, as a European nation. Prague is west of Vienna, and the capital of a nation that, though fashioned from the spoils of World War I, has thousand-year Holy Roman roots. There is a powerful consensus among the 15.6 million Czechs, Moravians, Slovaks, Hungarians and Gypsies (or Rom, as the Romanian-descended wanderers choose to be called) that ever since Stalin's Red Army drove the Nazis from the eastern two-thirds of Czechoslovakia at the close of World War II, the nation has been dominated by an alien culture.
While Germany's robust partnership between government and industry might logically serve as the appropriate European model, Czechoslovakia is loathe to take inspiration from its historically belligerent neighbor. "We now look to the United States for entrepreneurial spirit, aggressiveness, hard work and the willingness to take risks," says the Minister of Economics, Vladimir Dlouhy, 37, a reconstructed Communist who has become one of Klaus's closest allies.
Like Zeno's famous paradox of motion -- that, by successively halving the distance between oneself and a destination, a person can travel forever and never arrive -- America's radically free market stands as a beacon toward which Czechoslovakia can strive, but may never reach. Even ardent capitalists like Finance Minister Klaus expect that at least a third of Czechoslovakia's economy will remain in the hands of the state.
Still, Czechoslovakia should have increasing opportunity to learn American-style business first hand: in October, the United States Senate passed legislation granting "most-favored-nation" trading status to the country. The move, reducing tariffs, should stimulate trade between the United States and Czechoslovakia, which currently exchange only about $135 million worth of goods each year. The American Ambassador to Prague, Shirley Temple Black, is a personal friend of President Havel's and had lobbied Washington aggressively for the most-favored-nation bill -- not merely to give a break to her host nation, but to pave the way for American exports.

THE CENTER OF Slovakian industry and heritage is Martin, home to the giant Zavody Tazkeho Strojarstva (Z.T.S.) industrial complex, where military tanks are made. Ask anyone in Martin, "Who is in charge of the Z.T.S. complex?" and they will tell you how to find the house of the popular factory director, Jan Segla, who lives six miles away.
The three-bedroom split-level is modest, by American standards. In Slovakia, however, such a private home is a showplace. The bearded man who appears at the outside second-floor landing is clad in jeans and a "Levi's 501 Original" T-shirt. He has the build of an N.F.L. lineman. But he is a friendly giant, and he graciously welcomes the American visitors who have turned up at his door unexpectedly on a Sunday afternoon.
By the time he has poured a second round of Bulgarian brandy, Jan Segla is ready to speak his mind. "Havel and Klaus tell us to get out of the military business, but no one in the Government seems very interested in our future," says Segla. He is voicing a widely held sentiment that the current administration, dominated by Prague sophisticates, disdains the heavy industry that drives Slovakia's regional economy.
Regionalism remains a sensitive issue here in the easternmost of the country's three ethno-geographic areas. Moravia tends to look west to Bohemia's Prague for its cultural and political cues. But nationalists in Slovakia, which as recently as World War II was a semiautonomous German satellite, have struggled to preserve their Slovak heritage.
The factories of Slovakia made Czechoslovakia the world's sixth-largest arms exporter by selling low-priced weaponry to the Warsaw Pact nations and to the Middle East. Many Slovaks deride the plan of Havel and Klaus -- who are Czech -- to withdraw from the global arms trade as a "Pollyanna policy" that will emasculate the region's industrial might. But President Havel has argued that weapons are not only bad morals but bad business; more than half the bills, now most notably from Iraq, never get paid.
Segla, a Slovak, was elected director of Z.T.S. last February by the 14,000 employees of the complex, which is surrounded by barbed wire and guardhouses. "Our Zetor tractors are already the fourth-largest brand in the world, and our tank factories can be retooled to produce bulldozers, earth movers, steamrollers and dump trucks. But we need 3.7 billion crowns [about $150 million] in federal loan guarantees to do it."
Segla keeps the brandy flowing as he describes agreements he has negotiated with two manufacturers of construction equipment -- Germany's Hanomag and Dallas-based Dresser Industries -- to modernize Z.T.S.'s facilities and market Zetor products abroad. But those deals depend in large part on obtaining domestic financial backing.
Supplicants for federal support sooner or later find themselves in Prague, at the State Economics Ministry. There, in order to meet with Minister Dlouhy in his third-floor office, one must hazard the building's perpetual-motion elevator, a continuous loop of one-person cabins.
"The fact is that Czechoslovakians, per capita, are the heaviest producers and consumers of steel products in the world," says Dlouhy, who believes the nation must move beyond its reliance on heavy industry and evolve into a postindustrial economy. As the man spearheading the Government's privatization program, Dlouhy -- also a Czech -- will wield considerable influence over which businesses will survive. "Over the next few years there will be a substantial number of bankruptcies. If some of them hit inefficient heavy industries, then I say, thank God."
Working with Klaus, Dlouhy has crafted the pending "large-scale privatization act," designed to convert major state-owned enterprises like Z.T.S. into shareholding corporations -- where the profit motive would replace Communism's production-quota system. Under the innovative privatization plan, vouchers will be issued to virtually all Czechoslovakian citizens who, for a nominal flat fee, will then have the right to redeem vouchers for shares in any company they choose. The International Monetary Fund and the World Bank are helping the Government plan a stock exchange.
Vouchers will garner only about one third of all corporate shares issued, because redemption will generate no new capital. With domestic capital scarce and politically problematic, foreign investment becomes the obvious source of funds.
Czechoslovakia is also seeing some of its richest expatriates return to invest in the homeland. Thomas Bata, the 75-year-old son of Tomas, immigrated to Canada 50 years ago and built Toronto-based Bata into the world's largest shoe business. Today, Thomas Bata is negotiating to reclaim part of Czechoslovakia's state-run shoe company in Zlin, or form a joint venture with the Government to modernize the facility.
Boris Korbel, who fled Czechoslovakia for the United States in 1968, has come home in hopes of buying Sparta Prague, the nation's top soccer team. Korbel's Upper Deck Company of Yorba Linda, Calif., is one of the largest American producers of sports trading cards, and he hopes to use the Prague team as a way to launch a line of European soccer cards.

EVEN THOUGH HE speaks virtually no English and has no relatives in the United States, Jaroslav Leshner calls himself "a Czech-American patriot" because of his fascination with denim and its iconographic power in American popular culture. Leshner, 32, is the type of home-grown entrepreneur on which Czechoslovakia's capitalist experiment ultimately depends.
The Prague-based fashion designer invented a new method for dyeing denim in the mid-1980's. To obtain a patent, however, he was forced to swear that his process had been developed in conjunction with Polytechna, the Government's technical monopoly. The director of the Socialist Youth Organization, offended at the hip-hugging Western decadence inherent in denim, maneuvered to get the patent classified as a national secret. Leshner was forbidden to travel abroad for fear of what he might divulge. In retaliation, he recruited a corps of Prague fashion models to tour his designs across Western Europe in order to generate hard currency.
Since the revolution, Leshner has recovered his patent and reassembled his loyal team of 10 sales and production workers -- each of whom will become a partner after the privatization laws are passed. He recently contracted with a factory in Bohemia to fulfill his first export order, worth approximately $1.2 million, for a distributor who represents some 500 French clothing stores. That, he vows, is merely a start.
"I have hired a lawyer and a business manager, and I am also taking management courses," says Leshner, who has moved back into his Prague boutique, Monako. "The languages are the hardest. My best contacts are in France. And, of course, everyone says I must learn some English." He bends down to reclaim his denim hat from the teeth of his Great Dane puppy. "For 14 years I studied Russian," he says. "But the only time I ever used it was to curse the Soviets."

SECTION: Section 6; Part 2; Page 19; Column 1; Business World Magazine

LENGTH: 3251 words

HEADLINE: Technology;
Going It Alone, Bit by Bit

BYLINE: BY TIM RACE; Tim Race is an editor of this magazine.

 BODY:
AT 10:30 ON A THURSDAY MORNING, Michael Berger and Polly Siegel are at work, tracking the price activity of nearly two dozen futures contracts. Seven personal computers feed information from around the world into the four, color video monitors lined up in front of the traders.
The screens are divided into multiple windows, each window offering a different view of the relentless flow of numbers by which the futures game is played. One shows Standard & Poor's 500 Stock Index. Another gives the Dow Jones Industrials, down five points on this day. Over here are bond prices. Down there are precious metals; next to them, currencies; elsewhere such commodities as cocoa, coffee, sugar . . . 
 The kaleidoscope of raw data could seem bewildering -- unless like the 42-year-old Berger you've been betting the ebb and flow of commodities prices for the better part of two decades.
He types a keyboard command, and at the bottom of one monitor a gray band appears, displaying a rolling stream of stock symbols and prices from the New York Stock Exchange. Meanwhile, Siegel, 38, searches a screen for the talismanic clues that might tell her to buy a May coffee contract or unload September soybeans. A red bar at the bottom of her screen continually flashes a message: waiting for trades.
If the technology seems the minimum one would expect at any modern brokerage house, consider this: Michael Berger and Polly Siegel, husband and wife, are working at home. Much of the information on their screens comes from a satellite dish on the roof of their house, which sits in the rolling New Jersey countryside 50 miles southwest of New York City.
Suddenly, Siegel's monitor beeps. "Price check," she says. "Coffee." One of their trading programs has alerted them to a big price drop in the past five minutes for the commodity, which was already down 260 points (the equivalent of 2.6 cents) on the day. This is good news for Berger
and Siegel. They have three short positions in coffee, bets that the price will drop.
Siegel studies the data on the screen. "Are you interested in selling at the market price?" she asks, proposing they take a fourth short position. There is no excitement in her voice, no baccarat tension. She might just as easily be asking if he wants to subscribe to TV Guide.
"What signal is that on?" replies Berger, who has programmed a number of different buy-and-sell cues into the system -- signals that alert him to pricing patterns that might be of interest.
She identifies the signal that has just been activated by its shorthand name: "good close."
"Sure," he says. "Go ahead."
Siegel phones the broker: "Sell one September coffee at the market."
Berger types a command and a red bar appears -- the scoreboard for the $200,000 of their own money they have in play. "Right now," he says, "we're up $3,800 on the day."
They have been using their electronic trading post for more than a year. Each weekday morning, when much of the investment world is filing into the urban temples of high finance, Berger and Siegel simply walk upstairs to the second floor. There, in a room overlooking their indoor swimming pool, they log on to their personal computers and dive into the swift currents of the global financial data stream.
Berger and Siegel, emblematic of a small but growing number of financial professionals, are fulfilling the personal computer's long-vaunted promise of revolutionizing the way people live and work. In the past few years, a confluence of faster hardware, better software and the centrifugal forces spinning people and jobs away from Wall Street has made the PC an entrepreneurial enabler -- cutting adventurous investment professionals loose from institutional or corporate ties.
Frederic B. Shipley, editor of Computerized Investing, a newsletter published by the nonprofit American Association of Individual Investors, notes that the ranks of such investment go-it-aloners are probably thin. Still, he guesses that serious PC investors, like gold prospectors quietly working their claims, might be a larger group than he or anyone else realizes. "I suspect some of them have the feeling that they have something good going, and they don't want anyone to know about it."
Once a floor trader on the New York Commodities Exchange, Berger founded a discount commodities brokerage on Wall Street with his wife in 1978. In 1981, they sold the business and began trading for their own account from home, but without the high-tech equipment they now have.
Five years later, they dropped out of the commodities business to start a monthly public-affairs magazine that folded after 10 issues. When they resumed trading, in 1988, Berger says, "I found getting back into it very difficult. My risk tolerance had changed. People get more conservative as they age. So I decided that if I could develop a software system that would take the principles I've used over the years for trading and automate them, then the risk-tolerance factor would not hamper the results."
As of five minutes to noon, the couple, who typically take in between $3,000 and $8,000 a day, are up $8,600. "When I get some more aggressive trading strategies programmed in," says Berger, looking at the $75,000 worth of hardware and software arrayed before him, "this will be throwing off a considerable amount of money."
Siegel points to one of the ornaments in the room. Propped between a pair of brass bookends -- one a bull, the other a bear -- is a Cowardly Lion doll. "That's to give us the courage to do this," she explains. The doll wears a button that says, "Don't Postpone Joy."

 I N AN AGE WHEN MONEY increasingly is reduced to a stream of data, PC technology is letting individuals and small financial firms manipulate that data in complex ways.
"Without the personal computer, I wouldn't have a business," says 48-year-old Marc O'Brien, formerly a Lehman Brothers bond salesman and lecturer at the Harvard Business School. "When I started on my own in 1986, I started without a computer. It took me a month just to prepare the quarterly statements for five clients." Now, with two assistants and three networked I.B.M.-compatible PC's and a laser printer, O'Brien manages $15 million for the 80 investors he serves from an office in a Cambridge, Mass., six-story commercial building overlooking Harvard Square.
Specializing in no-load mutual funds, O'Brien uses a portfolio-management software package to perform detailed rate-of-return and asset-allocation analyses for his clients' accounts. Several times a day, he uses a modem to tap into such on-line data bases as the Warner Computer Systems Exchange Master service to keep tabs on the market and the 175 mutual funds he monitors. By retrieving prices and dividend data from the Warner service, and employing a $300 software package called Fund Master T.C. to mine that data for moving averages and other trends, O'Brien is able to apply his own criteria for comparing the relative performance of similar funds.
In mid-1989, O'Brien felt that common stocks were overvalued. "The reward-to-risk ratio seemed higher in foreign bonds," he says. But which foreign-bond fund would he pick? After analyzing the historical performance of the T. Rowe Price International Bond fund, the Scudder International Fund and several others, O'Brien shifted 20 percent of his clients' money into Scudder. In the last 12 months, the fund gave investors a total return of 19.97 percent -- 10 percentage points higher than the average for international income funds and more than 11.25 points better than the T. Rowe Price offering.
Like most professional PC users today, O'Brien employs computers based on the Intel 80286 microprocessor. Popularly known as the 286, this microprocessor is the thumbnail-sized, integrated-circuit chip that represents both brain and central nerv ous system for desktop computers.
The 286-based machines, either by I.B.M. or one of its imitators, are widely available for between $600 and $2,000. With such a computer, a user can insert a new pricing variable into a spreadsheet containing 2.1 million separate items of information and have the whole thing updated in 30 seconds.
These PC's, however, are rapidly giving way to faster (and more expensive) I.B.M.'s and I.B.M. clones based on 386 and even speedier 486 chips. Such machines, which generally sell in the $2,000-to-$20,000 range, have the processing capabilities once found only in mainframe computers costing millions of dollars. Berger and Siegel, who trade in real time and therefore demand high number-crunching ability, operate six 386 models in addition to their 286 machine; they pay two programmers $5,000 a month to keep this ensemble in tune and another $1,500 a month for on-line services.
Apple Computer's Macintosh personal computer, although widely praised for its ease of use, is rarely the first choice among investment professionals. "Real users are using I.B.M.'s or compatibles," says Shipley, of Computerized Investing. "There are 10 times the number of software programs available, relative to what's available for the Macintosh."
O'Brien has an estimated $15,000 invested in hardware and software and spends another $720 a year in on-line access charges and update packages for his software. "In the past, only a large institution could have afforded to do what I'm doing," he says.
If the big brokerage firms, with their legions of analysts and economists, do not yet feel threatened by the ascendant Little Guy, they are at least aware of his presence. "There's much more integration of information than there was 10 years ago. There's much more computerization," says Richard D. Malone, a partner at Edward D. Jones & Company, a brokerage house. Malone also serves as the chairman of the information systems committee for the Securities Industry Association, a group that represents most of the major houses. "The individual," he says, "can now access the same information that the brokerage houses can. If he's willing to pay for it."

A WEALTH OF INFORMATION is available instantaneously through on-line data bases. Plug into Mead Data Central's popular Lexis Financial Information Service, and you have electronic access to 10-K and 10-Q reports, plus abstracts of more than a dozen other types of Securities and Exchange Commission filings. Or dip into the Disclosure database, which makes you privy to abstracts of information that 11,000 companies have handed over to the S.E.C. in the past two years.
The cost, however, can be daunting. In the case of Lexis, rates run $39 an hour, plus $6 to $35 per individual search and a monthly service charge of $50. "You pay a lot of money for connect time," Shipley says, "and if you don't know what you want before you log on, you're going to go broke before you get rich." An alternative to using on-line data bases is the CD-ROM optical disk, which can store massive amounts of historical information but comes with its own steep price: $7,000 to $20,000 a year, depending on the data base and the options selected.
On the windswept steppe of south central Michigan, Margaret Moore, a portfolio manager, oversees a $5 million to $10 million portion of tiny Hillsdale College's trust funds. In addition, Moore manages $2 million for a handful of conservative private clients. She cannot afford extravagance, but she cannot afford to be without timely information, either. "I need to be on-line with a data base to do what I do," says Moore, 51, a former broker with a regional firm, First of Michigan.
Moore makes judicious use of the on-line Dow Jones News Retrieval Service, a broad compendium of news, stock quotes and other selected information from more than 20 separate financial data bases. According to Link Resources, a New York-based research firm that has studied the use of PC's among the work-at-home set, News Retrieval is the most popular financial-information service.
"I'm on and off it at least once a day," Moore says of News Retrieval. The prime-time connection fees can approach $3 a minute, meaning Moore must plumb News Retrieval efficiently to keep her monthly tab below $500.
To cite but one example: when she had an opportunity to buy 1997-series bonds from Southern California Edison, Moore took a quick tour through News Retrieval. She checked the company's bond rating, then looked to see "if there had been any news in the past year that might alert me to increased debt or any defaults by the company." Things looked bright for the electric company, so Moore purchased 25 of the discounted $1,000 bonds.
Moore has a full-time secretary and a part-time accountant to handle the extensive tax-reporting requirements for the college's trust funds. "Without my PC," she says, "I would need a lot more people."

KENT, CONN., 80 miles northeast of Manhattan, is the archetypal bed-and-breakfast New England village, replete with a steepled, white clapboard Congregational church. Scattered over the rolling, wooded Kent countryside are New Yorkers' weekend homes. It was here that, two years ago, James S. and Katherine N. Vick -- toting their M.B.A. degrees, two small children and a PC -- decided to take early retirement from the 80's and make a full-time residence of their weekend retreat. The plan: to chart and trade commodities.
Kate Vick, who is 38, had put in 10 years as a management consultant at Arthur Young & Company and a stint as chief financial officer at Aspex Inc., a small computer manufacturer in Manhattan's SoHo district. James, now 39, had 14 years of international finance experience in his portfolio, most recently as a vice president in the foreign-exchange department of Manufacturers Hanover Trust.
According to Kate, their son Charles, then 4, was "beginning to bounce off the walls" of their rented Greenwich Village apartment. Baby Sarah, then 1, was seeing more of the nanny than of her parents, whose long working hours kept them from enjoying much of what Manhattan has to offer its achievers. So the Vicks agreed to move to their "contemporary farmhouse" -- a modified saltbox they had built in 1985 on a secluded four-acre plot.
To subsidize their fledgling investment practice, Kate is drawing upon her New York business contacts to build a full-time consulting practice. James, meantime, spends each weekday in the office that was once their garage, creating algorithms that help him take positions in commodities futures. Although Kate acts as strategic planner for the trading operation, she leaves the market analysis to him. "One of the things I have realized is that to sit in this room in front of a computer screen will not make me happy," she says. "But it makes James very happy."
Compared with Polly Siegel and Michael Berger's command center, the Vicks' operation is minimalist. James, who claims he didn't even know how to turn on a PC before arriving at Manufacturers Hanover in 1986, calls himself a mathematician who happens to use a computer. He has one 286-based PC, with a modem he seldom uses, and a modestly equipped Zenith laptop computer. He gets his prices from the daily newspaper and by phoning his discount broker in Chicago. Mostly, James has his theories, which he first tested on a handful of commodities before venturing into deeper waters with $50,000 in margins and reserves.
"For some strange reason," he says drily, "an effective trading system doesn't just pop out at you from the computer. The approach that I've been taking is not to gear up with hardware or software or on-line systems before I really feel a need.
"When I was in banking, as a manager I became very aware of the overhead in this business. You can get all kinds of machines. You can get neat graphics and lots of computing power. But I became convinced while I was at the bank that all that fancy stuff didn't assure one of success in trading; if you build up your overhead, that means you've got to make significantly more money just to break even."

UNLIKE SIEGEL AND Berger, who are monitoring prices in five-minute intervals and may adjust their positions several times a day, James Vick follows only daily closes. His approach, therefore, can be more technologically lean, and he frequently holds a single contract for two or three weeks.
As do many commodity traders, James relies on technical analysis -- the study of a commodity's historic prices to discern subtle patterns that could recur in the future. It is a quantitative method that virtually disregards such real-world market influences as killer frosts in the Brazilian coffee plantations or Saddam Hussein's seizing Kuwaiti oil fields.
"The whole foundation of my trading systems is historical testing," he explains. "If you're just using monthly charts and drawing trendlines, you can do technical analysis with a pencil. And they've been doing it that way for 30 or 40 years. But computers can give you a greater degree of confidence. You can back-test data -- the more, the better."
When the Vicks first struck out on their own, James worked up six trading systems that he tested against two years' worth of historical daily market data. "The systems looked fantastic. We got them up and running. And over six months, we gradually lost money. We learned a few lessons, including: two years' worth of data is not enough."
And so, a little more than a year ago, he purchased a $2,000 software package called System Writer Plus from Miami-based Omega Research. With it, James has been able to devise five new systems and back-test his theories against market data going back 20 years.
In the few months he experimented with these new systems -- with positions in Treasury bills and bonds, Eurodollars, Swiss francs, British pounds and Japanese yen -- he made $1,000 a month on average. "It's small money for these positions, but it did help keep me abreast of the market," he says.
It was his wife, the strategist, who persuaded him to create a spreadsheet program to demonstrate how these positions and systems would have performed, had they been in effect for a randomly selected 10-year test period. The results, when tested against the 1977-1987 period: an annual 80 percent profit.
"What this shows," says Kate, explaining a printout, "is that 55 percent of the time you make money each day. Sixty percent of the time you make money each week. And 65 percent of the time you make money each month."
And 35 percent of the months are losers, she quickly adds. "We have to be prepared, financially and psychologically, to be down $40,000 at any given time in this portfolio."
Like just about everyone else in this relatively new game of PC investing, the Vicks are still feeling their way. If the master plan plays out, they will perfect their systems and eventually manage other people's money -- a business James says can net 20 percent of the client's trading profit. But, before then, he expects to spend many thousands more hours testing his ideas on the computer. "I don't consider five systems to be sufficient diversification," James says. "I would much rather have 10 systems, 15 systems."
And Kate is willing to stay the course. "I have a tendency, much more than James, to want to be in the fast lane," she says. "But the idea of sitting in the country and looking out my window and seeing grass and rabbits is bearable because I can also say, 'Yes, but we also have a contract in wheat, and there are exciting things going on in the market.' "

Airedale, Clancy, in the couple's trading room. (FRED R. CONRAD/THE NEW YORK TIMES)

PUB-DATE: December 2, 1990

SECTION: Section 6; Part 2; Page 13; Column 2; Business World Magazine

LENGTH: 4967 words

HEADLINE: COVER STORY;
The Travelers Rides Into The Storm

BYLINE: BY JILL ANDRESKY FRASER; Jill Andresky Fraser, the financial strategies editor at Inc., has been following the insurance industry for 10 years.

 BODY:
AS 1990 DRAWS TO ITS GLOOMY CLOSE, the landscape is littered with the fallen idols of American finance -- greedy corporate takeover artists and investment bankers and the spendthrifts of the savings and loans. Now a new candidate emerges from an unlikely quarter: the insurance industry with its $1.9 trillion in assets. Once synonymous with the utmost fiscal prudence, insurers, the experts in managing risk, are themselves at risk. Though the crisis has been building for a decade, it has gone almost unnoticed until the last few years.
1988. Following a consumer revolt over soaring prices and redlining, California's voters hurl Proposition 103 at automobile and property insurers, requiring them to roll back rates by 20 percent. The animus spreads. Within a year, more than 14,000 bills are brought before the nation's state legislatures to control an industry that is virtually without Federal regulation. 
 1989. An actuary's nightmare: Hurricane Hugo, the San Francisco earthquake and other acts of God cost insurers $7.6 billion, the worst year for natural-disaster claims in the United States. About 80 property-casualty and life insurance companies become insolvent.
1990. In June, The Travelers Corporation, the company that invented car insurance back in 1897, announces it will stop selling auto and homeowner policies in nine states. Other major insurers follow suit, thereby provoking further consumer ire.
Meanwhile, a Congressional subcommittee, having published its report detailing the rising number of insolvencies among property-casualty insurers, turns to life and health insurers. Many companies in this sector of the industry, which controls 72 percent of insurance assets, are mired in the most troubled areas of the financial markets. These giant investors have committed $278.9 billion to real-estate and mortgage holdings and $50.7 billion to junk bonds.

ON FRIDAY, OCT. 5, ALARM BELLS SOUNDED IN THE country's insurance capital, Hartford, Conn. Travelers reported it was adding $650 million to reserves against potential mortgage and real-estate losses and -- even more ominous -- that it was cutting its quarterly stock dividend by one third, the first dividend cut in the company's history. Insurance industry analysts, some of whom had been recommending the company's depressed stock as a buying opportunity, were outraged. Moody's Investor Service and Standard & Poor's immediately downgraded about $1 billion in Travelers' debt.
The following Monday morning, Columbus Day, Travelers called an early-morning meeting at Manhattan's Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in an effort to rally 100 analysts and institutional investors to its side. Edward H. Budd, the 57-year-old chairman of Travelers and the epitome of the hitherto anonymous executives who have traditionally run the insurance monoliths, strode confidently to the dais set up in the Jade Room. On his lapel, the graying C.E.O. wore a pin in the form of a red umbrella, Travelers' corporate symbol. The former actuary admitted that Travelers was preparing for its first year-end loss ever. (Indeed, three weeks later, the company announced a $499.3 million net loss for the third quarter.) But Budd's tone was upbeat. The dividend cut was a conservative step, he asserted, and Travelers, far from being the worst case in an ailing industry, was merely the first to acknowledge the current economic slump and to set aside money for future growth.
When Budd opened the meeting to questions, however, he was stunned by the audience's hostility. Brushing aside his generalities about prudence, the analysts demanded specifics about Travelers' investment portfolio.
Budd, along with Allan D. Schuster, the chief of Travelers Realty Investment Company, reluctantly disclosed that as much as 20 percent, or $3.5 billion, of the company's $17.2 billion mortgage portfolio had been classified as underperforming, and $275 million worth of loans were 90 days delinquent. Pressed further, Budd, sounding edgy, revealed that investment losses had cost his company $2 per share in 1989, and another probable $2.60 per share by the end of 1990.
At 10:20 A.M., a shaken Ed Budd adjourned the meeting. In the next few hours, Travelers' stock dropped $2, racking up a decline of nearly one-third of its value in two trading days. The shares of other insurance companies tumbled as well.
Gloria L. Vogel, an industry analyst at Bear, Stearns & Company who attended Travelers' meeting, says, "Management has lost its credibility with Wall Street. We don't know what's coming next." John B. Neff, portfolio manager of the Windsor Fund, which holds 5.3 million Travelers shares, laments, "I've never before seen this level of concern over the quality of their assets."
In an interview a week after the meeting, Budd professed surprise at the severity of Wall Street's response. "Before we decided to cut the dividend and increase reserves," he said, "we went through a very careful process of assessing all our options." With its real estate holdings caught in a depressed market, accounting measures seemed the only solution. "Our external options," he said, "are very limited."

WITH ITS MASSIVE HOLDINGS OF corporate and Government securities and real estate, the insurance industry has been a traditional bedrock of the economy. For investors, company stocks have represented a safe, sound way to participate in the best of American commerce.
"There isn't anything that goes on in this country -- economic change, social change, you name it -- that doesn't come through these doors," says Ed Budd. "You can't turn on your car without insurance. You can't get a mortgage without insurance. You can't start a business without it."
The insurance industry, one of the least glamorous of essential services, sells peace of mind. Its advertising slogans are couched in understated generalities -- Allstate's "You're in good hands"; State Farm's "Like a good neighbor"; Travelers' "You're better off under the umbrella" -- that nonetheless imply a social contract. The insurance company would provide protection for those who needed it and were willing to pay a reasonable price. But the contract began to unravel during the 1980's when insurers raised rates and refused to cover numerous would-be customers.
Bill Schwartz, a retail salesman in Rockville, Md., and his wife, Stephanie, bought car coverage from Travelers. From 1987 to 1990, the insurance rates on their Hyundai grew from $530 a year to $1,744 a year -- a 229 percent increase. "They raised us 11 times in 4 years," says Stephanie Schwartz, "but Travelers never told us why." The rate increases apparently resulted from moving violations and claims the Schwartzes made, yet in 1990 the couple was able to buy coverage from Allstate for $1,730 a year for both of their cars.
In order to attract customers, insurers often set rates below the company's actual cost of providing insurance. "Industry executives always say they're going to be disciplined about profit levels," complains Paul Gregory, a New York-based industry consultant. "But when everyone is cutting prices all around them, they're like a bunch of junkies who just can't say no." And, when faced with the inevitable losses caused by price slashing, insurers strayed beyond their traditional conservative investment strategies.

TRAVELERS, FOUNDED IN 1864, WAS THE NATION'S first provider of accident insurance, selling a Hartford banker a 2-cent policy against disaster during his daily four-block walk home for lunch. The following year, Travelers began selling life insurance. The company, which prides itself on being "multiline," offers a variety of coverage. By spreading costs over a spectrum of products, Travelers and other multilines try to balance out cyclical risks and maximize profits.
Today, Travelers is a giant of the industry with its 35,000 employees, $56.6 billion in assets and annual revenues of $12.5 billion. The Travelers Insurance Company ranks eighth in life insurance assets and the Travelers Insurance Group ranks tenth in property-casualty premiums. But the industry is so crowded -- 2,400 life insurers and 3,850 property-casualty companies -- even a company the size of Travelers holds no more than a 2 percent market share in any of its biggest lines.
Through the years, Travelers has shared its umbrella with victims of the 1906 San Francisco earthquake, the sinking of the Titanic and the torpedoing of the Lusitania. Property-casualty insurance covers the risks inherent in driving a car or owning a house or running a business. While an insurer cannot know when or whether a particular customer will file a claim, the actuarial premise holds that, given a large enough pool of customers, premiums from the whole will cover damages to the few.
But this equation has been battered in recent years by unforeseen developments -- lawsuits over product liability, for example, and environmental disasters such as the Exxon Valdez oil spill in 1989. Claims arising from such catastrophes can be huge, even though insurers spread their risk among other companies. Travelers is the lead insurer for the Shell Oil Company's cleanup of polluted ground waters at the Rocky Mountain Arsenal near Denver, a claim that could cost from $1 billion to $4 billion. Travelers has fought the claim on the grounds that Shell knew it was polluting the water.
Likewise, the tendency of juries in the mid-1980's to expand the notion of liability in workers' compensation cases has led to an industrywide leap in claims, from $17.8 billion in 1984 to $34.1 billion in 1989. Claim costs and expenses for workers' compensation have exceeded premiums since 1970. At Travelers, this line of insurance ranks second only to automobile insurance in property-casualty premiums. In 1989, it paid out $1.4 billion in workers' compensation claims on premiums of $1.35 billion.
"Insurance is unlike any other business," says Paul Gregory, the consultant. "It has simply gotten more and more impossible to predict the actual cost of insurers' products at the time that they're being priced and sold."
In the 1970's, when interest rates began to soar, a practice called "cash flow underwriting" spread across the property-casualty industry. Insurers cut prices far below projected costs in order to win market share and then shifted some premium payments away from such traditional investments as utilities and into high-yield Treasury bills, certificates of deposit and other interest-rate-sensitive instruments.
"The discipline of demanding good prices and underwriting results was weakened, because whatever cash was brought in could be invested at 13 percent or 14 percent," says Richard J. Shima, Travelers' chief investment officer. "Companies were actually able to operate at marginally unprofitable levels." Since 1980, Travelers has paid an average of $1.11 in claims and costs for each dollar's worth of property-casualty policies sold.
Property-casualty insurance is notably cyclical, with periods of competition and falling premiums, followed by insolvencies, reduced competition and premium hikes. But with cash-flow underwriting, another option was available. When interest rates started dropping from the double-digit levels of the early 80's, insurers -- rather than raise prices and lose hard-won market share -- shopped around for higher-yield investments.
Myron M. Picoult, a specialist in insurance industry finances at Oppenheimer & Company, calculates that Travelers' junk-bond and noninvestment-grade bond holdings add up to 20.5 percent of its property-casualty statutory surplus, the quantity of liquid assets companies are required to maintain in order to cover potential claims. "It's your statutory capital that supports your risks," says Picoult. "If you're leveraged this high, you can't afford to have many of your investments go wrong before you'll get into trouble."

THE PROBLEMS OF THE insurance companies do not exactly parallel those of the savings and loans, but there are some worrisome similarities -- particularly as concerns life insurance.
Unlike property-casualty, life insurance involves known risk: any given policy will eventually pay out. Life expectancy tables determine when that is likely to happen. The companies were thus able to invest in long-term, gilt-edged bonds and mortgages. Like savings banks, life insurers made their profits on the spread between the interest they credited to the customer's account and the yield they realized from investing the customer's money.
But in the 80's, the life insurers' tranquil world was threatened by competition. Banks and brokerages offered new, high-yield financial products such as cash management accounts that sophisticated consumers found more attractive than standard life insurance. Insurance companies responded with a host of higher-yielding policies such as variable life, universal life and guaranteed investment contracts.
At the same time, the life insurance industry was feeling pressure in another part of its empire. Health insurance had been a profitable line for life insurers -- until payments were pushed into the stratosphere by the high cost of such scientific advances as organ transplants, the increased demands placed on medicine by the growing numbers of older Americans and the spread of AIDS.
With operating costs escalating in health insurance, and new financial products competing with life insurers for customer dollars, the insurance companies -- in a pattern reminiscent of the savings and loans -- went hunting for higher returns on their own investments.
"That meant leveraging themselves with all kinds of risks -- real estate, junk bonds, lower-grade municipals, private placements, foreign loans and more," says Picoult. While property-casualty insurers stayed fairly liquid to meet liabilities, life insurers were able to plunge into long-term investment risks. According to A. M. Best Company, an industry rating service, Travelers' largest life company had 41 percent of its assets, or $13.1 billion, committed to mortgages in 1989.
One analyst, who followed the company until recently, confides, "We used to joke that Travelers owned the whole state of Idaho," the result of having to foreclose on so many nonperforming farm loans. Even more costly was what Travelers' investment guru, Shima, describes as a "geographic concentration of risk in oil- and energy-related areas" in the Southwest. At the October analysts' meeting, Allan Schuster reported that the company had been averaging losses of 33 percent on $1 billion worth of foreclosed property sales since mid-1988.
In 1987 the biggest office building in Austin, Tex., 111 Congress Street, was completed -- just in time for the collapse of the city's commercial real estate market. Travelers had invested $65 million in the project. Three years later, 19 percent of 111 Congress still stands vacant. The rest of the building has been leased out at rates Coldwell Banker's Austin office estimates at 50 percent below projected rents.
And real estate is not the only risky investment on the life insurance side. According to Picoult, in 1989 Travelers' $12 billion bond portfolio had $909 million -- 54 percent of its statutory surplus -- invested in junk and noninvestment-grade bonds. Included were a handful of Time Warner bonds and more than $85 million worth of R.J.R. Nabisco bonds, bearing a 12 percent interest rate. Even before the fall of junk bonds, the Travelers Insurance Company portfolio was lagging. Its $32 billion worth of life and health insurance assets yielded only 8.6 percent last year, according to A. M. Best, which ranked it near the bottom of the 20 largest life and health insurers in terms of performance. Only Equitable was worse, earning 8.2 percent.
Since insurers, like banks, carry many of their investments on the books at cost, rather than at the more realistic market value, it is difficult to assess the value of portfolios. And there is no telling what other losses exist in Travelers' mortgages and real-estate loans, nearly 75 percent of which are invested in office and apartment buildings.
In a serious recession, such investments could prove devastating. IDS Life Insurance, part of American Express, has conducted a six-month study into the solvency of the nation's largest life insurers only to conclude, in the words of James A. Mitchell, the C.E.O., that "20 percent of them would be at serious risk of failing in the event of an economic downturn." The biggest risk, he emphasizes, comes from investment illiquidity. "In a downturn, it won't just be junk bonds that become worthless and unsellable -- it will be real estate, mortgages, investments in affiliated companies and more."

IN 1945, THE INSURANCE industry mobilized Congressional support to pass the McCarran-Ferguson Act, under which insurers are exempt from Federal oversight. Insurance regulation -- what little there is -- takes place at the state level. With no uniform national standards of real significance, the regulatory system is sporadic and largely ineffectual. In its study, IDS found capital and surplus requirements too low. New York is the only state that requires insurers to match the duration of their investments and their liabilities.
"There are obvious differences in the quality and regulations throughout the states," acknowledges Terence Lennon, chief examiner of life insurance for the State of New York. His department, with 800 employees, is generally considered the best of the state regulators. "There are states that literally have only a handful of people regulating the entire industry."
John D. Dingell, chairman of the House Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations, has been running hearings into the soundness of the property-and-casualty insurance industry -- in response to the 300 percent rise in the number of "problem" insurance companies over the past decade. In his report, entitled "Failed Promises," Dingell warns, "Because the ill effects of fraud and gross incompetence may be hidden for 10 years or more after a policy is written, the problems . . . could quickly escalate into a real threat to the solvency of the insurance industry if reforms are not implemented very soon."
One insurer that drew subcommittee attention was Transit Casualty, chartered in Missouri, but based in Los Angeles. In 1985, after a state audit turned up worrying financial news, Missouri's regulators ordered Transit to stop selling policies.
During the four years between Missouri's audits, the subcommittee concluded, "Transit filed false and misleading regulatory reports. . . . There is no evidence of any regulatory review that discovered the errors."
The Missouri courts ordered Transit liquidated in 1985 and its receiver predicted the collapse would cost the state guarantee funds $400 million. That was before regulators discovered how fraudulent the insurer's filings were and how disastrous its underwriting mistakes had been. Current projections now run as high as $4 billion.
Since there is no national oversight, there is no obligation that the United States Government bail out basket cases like Transit. That responsibility has fallen to the industry itself, in the form of a patchwork system of guarantee funds, which operate in most but not all states.
When an insurer becomes insolvent, the insurance companies doing business in the state are responsible for paying off claims. With no nationwide regulations or funding standards, many state funds appear woefully inadequate when their financial reserves are compared to potential liabilities. "We've got a solvency guarantee system that counts on healthy insurers bailing out insolvent companies," says John B. Chesson, a counsel to the House subcommittee. "We're afraid that the cost of future bailouts could get so high it could push even the healthy companies under." And, needless to say, the consumers in the state end up footing the bill, in the form of higher premiums.
Chesson says, "Just as with the savings-and-loan industry, the regulatory system only works for companies that want to comply. The system isn't geared to prevent problems, to detect problems and to punish wrongdoers."
Congress, therefore, has put heat on state insurance regulators. "We have clearly gotten the message that either the states will shape up or someone else is going to take over our regulatory responsibilities," says Earl R. Pomeroy, the North Dakota insurance commissioner and outgoing president of the National Association of Insurance Commissioners. He and other state regulators are seeking to establish uniform standards. First and foremost, they want the state agencies to perform C.P.A. audits of the insurers' annual filings (35 states do not) and on-site audits every three years.
Industry experts believe that, even with regular audits, more insurers will fail if consumers demand lower rates while the industry's investment portfolio worsens. Analyst Martin Weiss of West Palm Beach, Fla.-based Weiss Research recently concluded that only 91 out of the 2,000 life insurers monitored were adequately capitalized to withstand a severe recession.
Travelers was not among them. Neither were four of the nation's five other major providers of both life and health insurance: Aetna, Cigna, Kemper and Transamerica.

FROM A DISTANCE, Hartford, Conn., looks something like the Emerald City, a landscape of gleaming glass-and-steel buildings; up close, the decay of the urban center becomes apparent. Three giants of the insurance industry make their home here -- Aetna, the I.T.T. Hartford Group and Travelers.
The headquarters building of Travelers, one of 22 company sites in the city, is a landmark 1919 pink granite-and-marble edifice. There in July, three months before the huge Travelers charge against earnings, Ed Budd talked about his life and the insurance industry.
A salesman's son who was raised on the outskirts of Hartford, Budd grew up convinced he would never choose insurance as a career. "I would watch neighbors who worked for insurance companies," he said. "They drove black, four-door sedans and left home each morning at 7:53 and arrived home each evening at 4:47. I said to myself, 'It's probably frightfully dull.' "
After a stint in the Navy, Budd took a bachelor's degree in physics at Tufts University in 1955, and started at Travelers the same year -- as an actuary. "It has never been dull," he says, "not one single day." Within a dozen years he was a vice president and became C.E.O. in 1981.
On a desk in his mahogany-lined corner office he keeps a marble cube engraved with the Chinese characters that spell out the word "crisis" -- one character representing danger, the other opportunity. "I hold it a lot," Budd said, turning the cube in his hands.
"We can't absorb all the uncertainties on the insurance side," he said, "and also absorb uncertainties in our investments." He looked bleak when discussing the consumer revolt. "If we were to conclude that California's rate rollback had a long life, it would be a conclusion that this country is abandoning important economic principles. I have more faith than that."
Budd places most of the blame for the industry's problems on what he calls "a continuous expansion in the theory of entitlement." In industry lingo, "entitlement" refers to everything from who's entitled to buy insurance and for what price to who's entitled to receive insurance payouts and for how much. Most recent insurance battles have centered around entitlement issues: How much should insurance cost a day-care center or a car owner in an inner-city neighborhood? Who will provide life insurance for an AIDS patient?
"Expansions in entitlement run contrary to the notion of predictability," Budd grumbled, turning to his favorite actuarial theme. He feels that the public expects too much from insurers -- what he calls the "socialization of people's expectations for compensation."
Back in July, Budd characterized his company's earnings problems as "short-term." Then, on Oct. 31, the company announced its disastrous third quarter figures.
"The problems at Travelers may be much worse than any of us know," says Herbert E. Goodfriend, an industry analyst. "I'm afraid there may have to be more dividend cuts and more write-offs, maybe next year."
Martin Weiss, the Florida analyst, calculates that Travelers would only have 30 percent of the capital it needed to withstand a major economic downturn, because of mortgage defaults and the illiquidity of its investments. The company, however, does have a substantial cushion against hard times: an investment portfolio -- half of it invested in fixed income securities -- which pulls in $3.5 billion a year.

WHEN I WAS GROWING up, my father, an insurance salesman, taught me that insurance was a business of faith -- of one man's word to another," recalls Robert Hunter, a former industry executive who runs the National Insurance Consumer Organization, a consumer activist group based in Alexandria, Va. "Now insurance has become a kind of schlock operation."
To counteract hostility, Travelers has devoted $50 million to lobbying, advertising and public relations. Timothy R. Campbell, the vice president for government affairs, says, "If we can work together with consumers who are organized already to seek safer automobiles and safer highways, then we know that will result in lower insurance claim costs." It may also help lessen consumer suspicion.
Campbell's additional mandate: to defeat state activists eager to put the screws to the industry and to counter the watchdogs in Congress who are seeking to repeal the McCarran-Ferguson Act. This year, in what has become an annual event, the House Judiciary Committee approved a repeal measure, which failed to reach the floor before Congress adjourned. Further action is expected when Congress returns in January.
Beyond damage control, Travelers is eager to cut losses on its basic businesses. This year, in an attempt to "flatten" the organizational hierarchy, the company eliminated 14 business units.
Budd has announced that, if regulations and rollbacks on automobile rates hit any one state too hard, Travelers will pull out of auto insurance in that state. Instead it will cherry-pick among the most profitable states and markets. But that approach can backfire. In mid-August, New Jersey's regulators warned the Hartford Group that, if one of its subsidiaries pulled out of the state's car insurance market, the entire company would be barred from doing business in the state.
Outside its basic business, Travelers is counting on income from a subsidiary that includes Dillon, Read, an old-line investment bank it bought in 1986 when many insurance companies were trying to become financial supermarkets. The subsidiary was responsible for $55 million in profits last year.
Travelers looks for future profit in the growing field of managed health care, which offers corporate clients Health Maintenance Organizations and employee health education. Last year, Travelers provided managed care to approximately 8.8 million people, for revenues of $2.6 billion. The operation, however, showed profit margins of only 1 percent.
Meanwhile, as the economy disintegrates, Travelers is facing an increase in fraudulent claims on both health and property-casualty insurance. In response, the company is exploring the use of artificial intelligence to pick out suspicious health claims, such as a visit to a doctor on a Sunday, the Fourth of July or Christmas or a major discrepancy in the patient's and doctor's ZIP codes. For the first nine months of this year, Travelers achieved savings of $22.4 million from its investigations.
But Travelers' efforts to rein in costs and increase profitability in its basic business are not likely to make a dent in investment losses if the real-estate market continues to fall apart. Not only Travelers, but the entire insurance industry, will be at risk should the nationally-chartered banks be allowed to sell and underwrite insurance. Only a Federal Reserve ruling in September stopped Citicorp from selling life insurance through a subsidiary in Delaware.
In fact, the insurance industry has already lost one-third of its market share to so-called "captive" insurance companies. According to H. Felix Kloman, a vice president and principal at Stamford, Conn.-based Tillinghast, a risk-management consulting firm, roughly 80 percent of the Fortune 500 companies have set up captives to provide their own insurance coverage. So have groups of small businesses and nonprofit organizations.
"Companies are fed up with the highly erratic prices, erratic levels of product availability and claims service they saw during the 1980's," says Kloman. "Companies don't do things like cash-flow underwriting when they run their own insurance captives."
Robert Hunter believes that cash-flow underwriting and other practices will lead to an industrywide shakeout. "We have -- what -- 6,000 insurance companies in this country? Most are very inefficient and badly managed. What we need is a thousand or so that know how to operate in their business profitably."
Ed Budd, faced with critics who expect the worst, recognizes that the industry -- and his company -- must adapt in order to survive. "I think in the last six months we've changed as fast as I've seen in my 35 years," he says. "When I first came to the company, I helped Travelers switch to monthly premium payments, which had never been done before. People kept saying, 'We can't keep up with the pace of change.' One fellow even had a nervous breakdown."
He pauses to offer a rare smile. "Change," he says, "is always going to be with us."

SECTION: Section 10; Page 1; Column 2; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 252 words

HEADLINE: Postings: From Realtors' President;
The Silver Lining

 BODY:
Although much of the country is in a real estate recession, there are encouraging words from the heartland. "Business is still very brisk in a lot of areas," said Harley E. Rouda, a Columbus, Ohio, realtor who last month was elected president of the National Association of Realtors, the country's largest trade organization of real estate professionals.
Mr. Rouda said that those regions where home sales are slumping, including the New York area, New England and Southern California, are distinquished from others by the torrid pace at which their housing rose in price in the 1980's. Where prices rose more gradually, he said, markets have remained robust. Among the healthiest states, he said, are Oregon, Washington, Oklahoma, Ohio and North Carolina.
Nor is it likely, Mr. Rouda said, that the real estate brokerage business is in for a deep, long-term decline. He predicted that the National Association, with 800,000 members this year, probably would shrink moderately to about 780,000 members next year.
Mr. Rouda, president of HER, Realtors, the largest brokerage in central Ohio, was elected to head the National Association for a one-year term running to November, 1991. Among his responsibilities will be to pitch the industry's point of view to Congress. He said his two top priorities are lobbying for a decrease in capital gains taxes on real estate and for the reinstatement of passive loss provisions for investors in rental housing, which were eliminated with the tax reform of 1986.
