LENGTH: 1474 words

HEADLINE: Perspectives: Mixed-Income Housing;
In Strong Locations, Economic Diversity

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
IN Manhattan, the mixed-income building financed with tax-exempt bonds came into its own as a successful form of rental housing in the mid-80's. Market rents were high enough to provide an internal subsidy for 20 percent of the tenants. They could live in new luxury buildings in desirable locations for rents of about $400 or $500 a month because other tenants were willing to pay two or three times as much to live in the same building.
Now this so-called 80-20 housing is having a harder time getting into construction, although builders with sites are available. The main problem is that banks have drawn away from construction lending. Despite the fact that tax-exempt bonds are available for the permanent financing, a bank letter of credit must be obtained by builders to guarantee the bondholders against the risks in the construction process itself. Banks are paid a fee for undertaking the risk. 
 One building company that found a bank to guarantee the construction is The Related Companies, which has accordingly gone into construction with a mixed-income building on the northwest corner of Third Avenue and 96th Street. The bank is the Mitsubishi Bank Ltd.
This as-yet unnamed building, designed by the Manhattan firm of Costas Kondylis Architects, will have 520 apartments in 30 stories and a broadly curved brick and glass facade facing southeast. The market-level rents will be about $1,400 a month for a one-bedroom apartment on a midlevel floor and $1,700 for a two-bedroom. Rents for the assisted tenants will be about a third as much.
The project testifies once again to the remarkable ability of Manhattan locations to promote economic integration, since the span of tenant incomes in these 80-20 buildings is striking. At the same time, it suggests that the cultural and educational backgrounds of tenants, more than their incomes, are what draw people together comfortably as neighbors in multifamily housing.
On the income side, occupants of market-rate units in Upper East Side mixed-income buildings are turning out to have earnings ranging from $45,000 to $75,000, or up to 200 percent of median income for a family of four in the city. Nearly everyone works. Moreover in convertible one- or two-bedroom apartments (about 40 percent of the total), there are typically two workers. Household income per two-bedroom apartment ranges from $80,000 to $130,000.
Accordingly, market rents for two-bedrooms can range upward from $20,000 a year, or about $1,700 a month. Meanwhile, moderate-income retirees and lower wage earners are living in the same building. But like their higher-earning neighbors, they are usually drawn from white-collar occupactions -- graphic arts and performing arts, publishing, social work, teaching, office work.
"YOU need a top product and a top location to make it work," says David J. Wine, president of Related Management Corporation, the management arm of The Related Companies, of the mixed-income developments. Since 1987, the number of tenants drawn from the financial services industry has declined significantly, Mr. Wine said. "But the residents are coming from other industries," he said.
Related has done 85 residential projects in the Northeast and Florida, and it manages 15,000 apartments. It is one of the country's largest users of government-assisted housing programs. Its experience with mixed-income housing is strikingly different in other locations from what it has been in Manhattan. Usually there is little difference in income between market-rate and subsidized tenants.
Typically, the difference in rent between the market-rate and the subsidized tenant is only $50 to $75 a month, Mr. Wine says. In places like Missouri, Minnesota and Florida, new rental housing is affordable to tenants earning 70 to 100 percent of median income. Even in Boston, a high-cost city, unassisted rentals are affordable to people with income of 115 percent of median.
But in New York City the market rents are almost three times more than the assisted rents. The basic reason is that there are so many working people per household. The degree of economic integration is at its zenith.
Not all buildings have been free of fiscal problems, however, despite successful rent-ups. Rents have gone up, but not at the pace predicted five years ago. At that time, some builders were mainly worried about the prospect of rising interest rates during the construction process. To the Milstein Organization, builder of the large mixed-income Normandie Court development on East 96th Street, which also used tax-exempt state bonds, it seemed prudent to get a commitment for a 10 percent fixed-rate loan. The underwriting was based on projected gains in rents of about 5 percent a year through lease renewals and turnover rents.
BUT rent increases have lagged, averaging well below permissible levels of rent stabilization guidelines, and the project is delinquent on mortgage payments. The Milstein Organization is accordingly trying to negotiate an adjustment in mortgage terms with the state's Housing Finance Agency.
The Related Companies and some other builders were luckier. They chose variable-rate mortgages that gave an effective debt cost of about 6 percent. It was a winning gamble. Had market interest rates risen, these developments, too, would have been hurt by lagging market rents.
New York City issued $250 million in bonds for mixed-income housing in 1985 and about $150 million has been used so far. The rest is committed to projects, but "credit enhancement" from major banks is needed to get them started. "Our hope is that some or all of the rest will be used in the next year," said Charles Brass, director of development for the Housing Finance Agency, the finance arm of the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development, which has worked with developers to find the necessary financing.
It is not used in Manhattan projects only. In the Bronx, $11 million in tax-exempt financing has been plugged into the $33 million gut rehabilitation of 10 city-owned buildings on or near Sheridan Avenue from 167th Street to 170th Street, east of the Grand Concourse. Sparrow Construction Corporation, the developer, was selected for the work in January 1989. Occupancy will start in two weeks.
In this development, the city provides $18.5 million in financing at 1 percent interest, which permits the 80 percent market-rate rents to be truly affordable to the market. Tenants pay $435 to $510 for a one-bedroom, $519 to $614 for a two-bedroom and $607 to $683 for a three-bedroom.
"In the borough the program works better for rehabilitation than for new construction," said Barry Zelikson, development director for Sparrow.
In Manhattan these mixed-income developments are also helped by the automatic availability of the city's Section 421a tax abatement. For developments that are 100 percent market rate, the benefits are unavailable in the area from 14th to 96th Street unless the developer pays for certificates to generate off-site low-income housing.
The new project by Related qualifies even without these payments since its site on the north side of 96th Street is outside the excluded zone, but other sites for mixed-income buildings are within it. Developers of fully market-rate buildings in Manhattan say they have paid about $18,000 a unit to buy the certificates. By enabling them to accept lower rents or calculate reduced taxes for condominium buyers, the abatement lowers development risk, enhancing the builder's ability to get a loan.
The automatic availability of the 421a benefit is a key reason that the Brodsky Organization, for example, is considering seeking tax-exempt financing for its site on West End Avenue between 61st and 64th Street, a parking lot that formerly was the site of a New York Times printing plant. Before it went out of existence, the Board of Estimate approved a plan for 950 apartments there. Tax-exempt financing would mean that 20 percent of the apartments would rents for about $400 or $500 a month, said Daniel Brodsky, a partner in the company. But like other builders, Brodsky must find a big bank to take the construction risk.
As for Related, it too has another potential mixed-income site, on the east side of Amsterdam Avenue between 89th and 90th Streets. The company expects to build an 18-story 267-unit rental, in partnership with Kreisler Borg Florman Inc., the construction company. Cooper & Partners and Shuman Lichtenstein & Claman are the architects.
The building will complete the development of the West Side urban renewal area, where several vacant Columbus Avenue parcels were done successfully in the 80's as mixed-income rentals. The timing of construction depends on the availability of the letter of credit to guarantee bondholders during the construction period.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property: Book Publishers;
Random House Elects to Stay in Its Midtown Tower

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
SHOULD Random House ever discard the snug little cottage that has been its colophon since 1927, it could confidently choose as its new trademark a 40-story International style skyscraper.
For at least 29 years, the world's largest English-language trade book publisher will lease all 450,000 square feet in the office tower at 50th Street and Third Avenue where it has long been a tenant. 
 The Random House deal -- one of the largest this year in New York -- is noteworthy in several ways. The decision by the corporate giant to stay at 201 East 50th Street underscores how the falling real-estate market has restored mid-Manhattan's competitiveness against less traditional commercial areas, although downtown locales continue to draw tenants in the publishing industry.
Random House did not go into Zeckendorf Towers, on Union Square East, between 14th and 15th Streets, where some 350,000 square feet have been vacated by Integrated Resources, the financial services concern that filed for bankruptcy earlier this year.
Nor did it go into one of two projects that would add new towers to former department stores: B. Altman on Fifth Avenue, between 34th and 35th Streets, and Siegel-Cooper on the Avenue of the Americas, between 18th and 19th Streets. Nor did it go to the popular destination of Park Avenue South.
"With the Midtown market deteriorated, the need for an alternative market like Park Avenue South becomes less important," said David W. Levinson, senior managing director of the Edward S. Gordon Company, who brokered the Random House deal, with Carol Nelson and Mary Ann Tighe.
"When Midtown rents were $35 to $40 a square foot, with limited concessions, in the mid-80's, Park Avenue South was very attractive," he said. "As the market deteriorated, the gap between Midtown and Midtown South narrowed. Given the choice of being on 50th Street and being on 18th Street, our client preferred 50th Street."
Douglas Durst, vice president of the Durst Organization, which built and owns the Random House building, said the publisher's decision "demonstrates the underlying strength of the Midtown office market."
"We did not place any conscious limitations on our choices within Manhattan," said Alberto Vitale, the chairman, president and chief executive officer of Random House. "The main thing is to try to remain in Manhattan. Which part does not determine your contacts and relationships with the rest of the publishing community.
"You want to look at all of your options. The fact that we've been able to come up with an optimal -- or, let us say, competitive -- arrangement on this site presents the added advantage that we are saving ourselves the trauma of a move. People get used to the place where they work. Whether it's comfortable or not isn't the deciding factor -- they get used to it."
In its early history, Random House jumped from 73 West 45th Street to 20 East 57th Street to the Villard Houses, at Madison Avenue and 51st Street. Then, in 1969, it moved to the 50th Street skyscraper.
Random House and its imprints -- Alfred A. Knopf, Pantheon Books, Crown Publishing Group, Villard Books, Times Books, Schocken Books, Ballantine-Del Rey-Fawcett-Ivy, Vintage Books, Modern Library and Fodor's Travel Guides -- now occupy 20 floors, about 250,000 square feet.
Random House also has some 80,000 square feet in 225 Park Avenue South, at 18th Street, which it gained in 1988 with the acquisition of Crown and which it will sublet. After its consolidation at 50th Street, Random House will occupy about 350,000 square feet. It will also have 10 subtenants, some of whose leases run into the 21st century.
ONE key part of the Random House deal is the extent to which it allows the company to remain whole. "Many businesses move certain kinds of their activities out of the city, leaving only the editorial operations behind," said Alexander MacGregor 3d, executive vice president for administration. "We probably will do less of that than other publishers have been forced to do."
"While there's a premium that has to be paid for keeping a company unified in Manhattan," said Ms. Tighe of the Gordon company, "I think what you're seeing with the Random House deal is that major publishing companies are realizing that it's well spent. To keep vitality, there has to be interaction between the editorial and business sides."
What prompted the search by Random House was the impending expiration of its lease in 1994. "We wanted, as soon as was practical, to come up with a resolution of this problem so we wouldn't be faced with last-minute decisions that can cause dislocations for so many people," Mr. Vitale said.
He would say nothing about the rent under the new lease other than to call it "favorable." In a memorandum to Random House employees, Mr. Vitale also said that as a result of the new arrangement, "we will be able to fix all of the problems that have confronted us in the past (air-conditioning, elevators, ventilation, etc.)."
While Random House stayed in mid-Manhattan, Penguin USA has moved as far downtown as 375 Hudson Street, between Houston and King Streets, which is also headquarters of Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising. Included in this move were Viking Penguin, which had been at 40 West 23d Street, and NAL Dutton. NAL, the New American Library, had been at 1633 Broadway, between 50th and 51st Streets. E. P. Dutton had been at Two Park Avenue, between 32d and 33d Streets.
"The first goal was finding a suitable location within the economic constraints that were set by Penguin," said Michael R. Laginestra, vice president of Cushman & Wakefield, who brokered the deal. "Then we had to find a floor size and a building image that met the financial criteria. Then we had to match that up with a landlord who would be willing to do the kind of funding necessary for work and willing to make a contribution toward lease takeovers."
Mr. Laginestra said Peter Mayer, executive chairman of Penguin USA, was quite specific in his criteria. "He wanted people on two floors or less," the broker said. "He believes in that synergism created by constant contact with one another. And when you're looking for 60,000-square-foot floors, you have a limited supply."
SOME relatively new arrivals on Park Avenue South include Houghton Mifflin and Rizzoli International Publications. Rizzoli moved last year from the old Scribner Building, at Fifth Avenue and 48th Street, to 300 Park Avenue South, at 22d Street. Last week, it completed an expansion within that building from one to three floors, where it has been joined by its holding company, RCS Rizzoli Corporation New York.
"We moved down here because we believed it was going to develop as a Publishing Row," said Gianfranco Monacelli, the president, publisher and chief executive officer of Rizzoli International. "In fact, it has. Not that we have many contacts with our competitors, but it gives comfort that they are around."
Houghton Mifflin moved last year to 215 Park Avenue South, at 18th Street, from Vanderbilt Avenue and 45th Street. "There was some trepidation about leaving midtown," said Ms. Tighe, who was involved in the deal, "but they've found that it works very well. The pacing of the neighborhood seems to suit the industry."
"The buildings are very individualistic," she said, "not cookie-cutters. The companies liked the high ceilings and big windows. There's a sense of light, air, trees and gardens that people became used to. Housing in the immediate area is more in an acceptable price range than the Upper East Side or even Upper West Side. It's a natural environment for publishing."

GRAPHIC: Photos: 375 Hudson Street, left, is home of Penguin USA; 201 East 50th Street, center, is leased by Random House. (Photographs by Bill Swersey for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: The Demise of 3 Hotel Proposals

BYLINE: By JOSH KURTZ

 BODY:
FIVE years ago, with an eye on the two new office complexes under construction in Somers, developers approached the neighboring towns of North Salem and Lewisboro with proposals to build three large, luxury hotels near Interstate 684.
Worried that the International Business Machines and Pepsico projects in Somers would spawn a building boom in their own rural areas, North Salem and Lewisboro changed their zoning laws in the years that followed. Hotel construction is now prohibited in Lewisboro and permitted in only a sliver of North Salem.
By all appearances, the three hotel proposals -- to build a Sheraton Country Inn in the Lewisboro hamlet of Goldens Bridge, a Crowne Plaza Hotel in the North Salem hamlet of Croton Falls, and a Ramada Inn in Croton Falls -- are dead.
One of the would-be Croton Falls developers, Gene Boshes, has just decided to sell his long-term lease on the property. Alvin Lukashok, who owns the other Croton Falls property, is suing North Salem for rezoning his property to prohibit hotel construction. And the Goldens Bridge developer, Peter Brock, has decided he would rather switch than fight and is considering town houses for his property.
 
Looking Over the Prospects
 All three developers have expressed varying degrees of irritation with the towns. But prospects for any sort of commercial development in Westchester in the next few years are so dim, said S. J. Schulman, president of the Westchester County Association business group, that "there's sort of a Rip Van Winkle feeling about development in the county."
Mr. Schulman said hotels might have been needed in the northern part of the county if more office development had taken place along I-684, as predicted in the mid-1980's.
The economic slowdown in the region -- and the fact that I.B.M. and Pepsico said they did not need hotels near their Somers plants -- has not stopped Mr. Lukashok from fighting North Salem in court, or Mr. Boshes and his partners from insisting that a hotel could be viable.
 
Benefits to Area Seen
 Alan Scheffler, a Mount Kisco lawyer who represents Mr. Lukashok, said the Manhattan-based developer was confident that with I.B.M. and Pepsico in Somers and the Trans World Airlines corporate headquarters in Mount Kisco -- all "within yelling distance" of Mr. Lukashok's 160-acre property in Croton Falls -- a hotel would benefit the area.
It is not just the corporations Mr. Lukashok is trying to serve, the lawyer said: the proposed 134-room Ramada Inn would have conference rooms, ballrooms and restaurants that would also serve North Salem and neighboring communities.
Nevertheless, Pepsico, which has 1,000 people at its beverage division in Somers, said employees from out of town who visit Somers on business are generally put up in one of several company-owned apartments throughout the county.
Jim Ruderman, an I.B.M. spokesman, said that because out-of-towners typically tour several company offices in the area in addition to the building in Somers, they could stay at hotels elsewhere in the county.
"In the worst case, people would have to drive 10 or 15 miles," he said.
 
County Called Overbuilt
 Wherever visitors in the county go nowadays, they are likely to find rooms available. Ernst Rechtermann, president of the Westchester County Hotel Association, said the present 62 percent occupancy rate for the county's 4,170 hotel rooms was relatively low.
"I think the entire county is completely overbuilt," he said. "I don't see any potential for any new construction of hotels."
After the North Salem Town Board established new zoning laws in 1987 that prevented hotel construction everywhere except for a small commercial district near the junction of Route 22 and Hardscrabble Road, Mr. Lukashok sued North Salem and town officials in an effort to overturn the zoning laws. He is also seeking $14.7 million in damages. The case is expected to be heard next spring in State Supreme Court in White Plains.
Mr. Lukashok first presented his proposal to the North Salem Planning Board in late 1984 and has spent "hundreds of thousands of dollars" on environmental studies, drilling costs and consultants' fees, Mr. Scheffler said.
"We wouldn't have spent all that time and all that money if we hadn't been encouraged by the town in the first place," he said.
Lois Lippmann, chairwoman of the North Salem Planning Board and the Town Supervisor when the town changed its zoning laws, said she could not comment on the lawsuit. But she said that after years of negotiations, she was surprised when Mr. Boshes, the other would-be hotel developer, stopped in her office on Election Day to tell her that he was trying to sell his long-term lease on the 12.8-acre property near the Mona Trattoria restaurant off Route 22.
 
Length of Process Deplored
 "Essentially, we're just tired," Mr. Boshes said. "It has taken so long to go through the approval process that the market has finally caught up with us."
When North Salem changed its zoning law, it cut in half the density of hotels allowed on that property, ruling out Mr. Boshes's proposed 240-room Holiday Inn Crowne Plaza. He later changed the proposal to a hotel of about 130 suites, but with no ballrooms, meeting rooms or swimming pool.
Edward Kelly, who owns the property, said another developer was sure to make some sort of proposal eventually because "the site can accommodate a number of uses."
Down the road in Lewisboro, developers of a proposed 300-room Sheraton Country Inn faced the same problem when the town changed its zoning laws in 1988. But after considering a lawsuit of their own, they withdrew their proposal and are now trying to work with the town to see what residents want at the 32-acre site, which is next to the Goldens Bridge Shopping Center.
Peter Brock, a New Rochelle developer who owns 23 of those acres, said that he was angry that he had "lost time, effort and money" after preparing the hotel proposal, but that he had decided "it's always more fruitful if you can work things out and not fight."
Mr. Brock has joined a citizens' group known as the Concept Committee, which was set up by town officials to meet periodically and discuss what sort of development should be encouraged there.
"I think it was a wise choice," he said. "I think it's a bad rap that you can't work with these towns."
The developer is considering building town houses near the shopping center. The reaction of town officials to such a project has so far been favorable.

HEADLINE: State Owed Millions in Uncollected Sales Tax

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO

 BODY:
AS state officials search for ways to close an anticipated $600 million budget gap, tax experts say that hundreds of millions of dollars in taxes owed to the state by residents will probably never be paid and are virtually impossible to collect.
The millions owed are a result of a 1967 United States Supreme Court decision that exempts out-of-state businesses like mail-order companies from charging another state's sales tax on taxable purchases. And though residents are required by New Jersey law to pay the taxes on out-of-state purchases, officials say that only a small percentage actually report the taxes, as required, on their New Jersey tax returns. 
 Though the decision may provide residents with a convenient, albeit unlawful, respite from recently increased sales taxes, some legislators say it should be legislatively rectified since lost revenue is eventually paid by all taxpayers, including those who do all their shopping in New Jersey.
 But with the persistent antitax sentiment sweeping the nation, tax experts say, any support for a new law or an aggressive collection effort would be a politically unpopular undertaking. In addition, they say, the decision hurts businesses in the state by giving out-of-state companies an unfair advantage. The nonresident businesses, they say, can offer otherwise taxable goods at what amounts to a 7 percent discount.
Some legislators, however, say that while the state may have an interest in increasing revenue, a tax collected on mail-order purchases might have a negative impact on consumers, particularly the elderly and disabled.
At the same time, representatives of the mail-order industry say that estimates of lost taxes are greatly exaggerated and that many smaller and mid-sized direct-mail companies would have to raise prices if they were required to collect sales taxes.
The issue arises as state officials estimate that sales tax revenue will be $450 million less than anticipated, roughly three-quarters of the $600 million shortfall expected in the current fiscal year.
"It's hard to get a fix on the numbers," said Richard Kaluzny, chief of the Office of Tax Analysis in the State Division of Taxation. "But I think the estimate a couple of years ago was that we were losing $100 million a year in tax revenue."
Mr. Kaluzny was referring to a study conducted by the United States Advisory Commission on Intergovernmental Relations that estimated New Jersey's 1988 sales tax loss from out-of-state sales to be $107 million.
Robert D. Ebel, director of finance research for the commission, said the estimated sales tax loss for the state would have increased to approximately $113 million by the end of this year. The loss, Mr. Ebel said, is at least partly the result of increasing mail-order sales.
"You have a choice of buying through a catalogue or you can drive down to the shopping mall," Mr. Ebel said. And though consumers may have various reasons for choosing one alternative over the other, he said, one factor that might be considered is that the out-of-state mail-order companies typically do not collect the New Jersey sales tax.
"Right off the top you can save 7 percent on a television or a computer system," Mr. Ebel said. "And that's not small dollars."
And while the amount of lost taxes is difficult to estimate, most officials agree that any additional revenue would be welcomed.
 "Certainly our revenue picture would be brighter if these companies would collect our sales tax," said Amy Collings, a spokeswoman for the State Department of the Treasury. "But that requires Federal action."
<> <> Ms. Collings said that as a result, state officials can only continue their present efforts to enter into voluntary agreements with other states and to lobby for Federal legislation.
New Jersey is not the only state losing tax revenue on out-of-state sales. The advisory commission's study estimated that in 1988 the 45 states with sales tax statutes were losing almost $2.5 billion. And while New Jersey, like most states, has a "sales and use tax," which requires residents to pay a use tax on items purchased outside the state, relatively few taxpayers actually report or pay the tax.
According to the State Division of Taxation, 3,584 taxpayers paid a total of $273,420 in sales taxes on out-of- state purchases in 1987.
In the 1967 Supreme Court decision, made in the case of National Bellas Hess v. Illinois Department of Revenue, the Court ruled that a state could require sales tax collection at the time of the sale only if the company making the sale had a physical presence in or "nexus" with that state.
<> <> Dr. Marilyn Marks Rubin, associate professor of public administration and economics at John Jay College in New York, said: "What constitutes nexus? That's the whole issue here. If I call Macy's in New York and buy snorkel gear and have them send it to New Jersey, Macy's has to charge me tax." The reason, she said, is that Macy's has stores in New Jersey.
"But," she said, "if L. L. Bean puts a catalogue in my mailbox, does that mean that L. L. Bean is doing business in New Jersey?" L. L. Bean's only store is in Maine.
The answer to that question is not clear cut, Dr. Rubin said, although the concept of what constitutes nexus, which traditionally required that a business have a physical presence in a state, has changed over the years.
Indeed, some experts say that modern marketing techniques, including the use of telemarketing, credit cards and computers, have created a new standard for determining nexus.
"The mail-order companies are present electronically and they are present economically," said Alan H. Friedman, general counsel to the Multistate Tax Commission, a Washington-based interstate agency. "Physical presence is no longer the benchmark; it should be economic presence as well."
 
Not a New Tax
 Another area of confusion, Mr. Friedman said, involves the common perception that a tax on out-of-state sales would be a new one.
"The taxes on those sales are already owed," he said. "There's no legal or factual doubt about it." But state tax officials, he said, are often hesitant to take aggressive measures to collect those taxes.
Mr. Friedman said that proposed Federal legislation, however, would clarify the nexus issue and allow states to require mail-order companies with more than $12.4 million in national sales or $500,000 in state sales to collect a state's sales tax.
That legislation, however, died in committee after meeting with strong opposition from the Direct Marketing Association, a New York-based group that represents more than 3,500 companies tied with the direct-mail industry.
The association dismisses essentially all the issues raised by those in favor of allowing states to compel sales tax collection by out-of-state businesses.
Robert J. Levering, vice president for governmental affairs for the association, said, for example, that New Jersey's revenue losses were far less than the estimates projected by the Advisory Commission study.
"Our bottom-line estimate of the potential revenue gain for New Jersey is $12 million," Mr. Levering said. The commission, he said, inappropriately took into consideration goods, like clothing, that were tax exempt. In addition, he said, the commission did not account for out-of-state companies that were already voluntarily collecting and remitting states' sales taxes.
 
Collection Problems Cited
 Mr. Levering also said that collecting tax at the point of sale was not as easy as proponents might believe. The idea that the seller can simply add the state sales tax to the customer's credit-card bill, he said, does not hold true for many of smaller and mid-sized direct-mail companies.
"They may be selling cheese and fruit and fruitcakes," he said, "but they might have 50 percent check-payers, and that screws everything up."
Customers who pay by check, he said, would have to figure the tax on their purchases and include that amount in their payments.
"Imagine making a semi-impulse purchase like that?" Mr. Levering said. "Those people would just put the catalogue aside and wait for a better time."
As far as some of New Jersey's Federal legislators are concerned, that would be good news for businesses in the state.
 
'A Hard Time Competing'
 "Businesses in our state have a hard time competing with the mail-order companies," said Representative William J. Hughes, Democrat of Ocean City. "Their fixed expenses are much more than the mail-order houses that don't have a presence in the state."
 Representative Hughes, who is a member of the House Judiciary Committee, was a co-sponsor of the bill that would have required out-of-state companies to collect states' sales taxes.
"It is argued that the consumers benefit from direct mail because they're able to purchase lower priced goods," he said. "But in the final analysis, when you include the drain on the public treasury and the damage to local businesses, we lose the benefits we think we gained."
Representative Hughes said he expected the bill to be reintroduced in the next session of Congress.
Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, Democrat of Montclair, however, said he opposed the legislation. The convenience of mail-order sales was cited as a valuable option for consumers.
"Not only does it make shopping easier, cheaper and less time-consuming," Mr. Lautenberg said, "but it is also particularly important to people who are confined to their homes by age or disability or illness."
Though states may have a strong interest in increasing their revenue, he said, the sales tax issue must be viewed in light of such consumer concerns.
 
Agreements With States
 But rather than wait for Federal legislation to clarify the issue, New Jersey tax officials have entered into agreements with several states to provide for sharing of sales tax information that results from state tax audits.
 New Jersey, for instance, was the first state to enter into an agreement for sales and use tax reporting with the State of New York in 1986.
Under the terms of the agreement, New York tax auditors report to New Jersey tax officials all untaxed New York sales made to New Jersey residents. New Jersey provides the same information to New York. In addition, more than 6,000 merchants in both states are registered in the program and report out-of-state sales to the other state.
Lee Evans, an auditor with New Jersey's Division of Taxation, said that since the agreement was signed, New Jersey tax officials have collected about $39 million in taxes on sales that were reported to the division.
"You can't go after every sweater or record album," he said. "But when somebody's buying a big-ticket item like furniture or jewelry or art, it makes sense to go after it."
As for collecting outstanding taxes on unreported sales in other states, however, officials have found only frustration.
"We've been beating our brains in for years trying to get this money," said Robert Thompson, assistant director of audit activity in the Division of Taxation. "We've just been underwhelmed with our success."

HEADLINE: Children on Life-Support Systems Increasing

BYLINE: By MARY L. RAFFALLI

 BODY:
YUWANNA remembers the moments after her son, David, was born. He is her third child. She has two daughters.
"I said, 'Wow! I have a son,' " she recalled. "But looking at his face, he looked different. I knew something was wrong. At that moment, my expectations, my whole world collapsed. I went into a little cocoon and I wanted him to go back into my uterus and never come out. 
 "All the happiness of birth died, and my expectations for him died also."
David has severe cardiac and respiratory anomalies in addition to Down syndrome. When he was 3 months old, he had open heart-surgery to repair a ventricular septal defect, a hole in the wall of his heart.
He has a tracheostomy tube inserted through his throat to support his breathing.
At his home in Nassau County he is attached to a cardiac monitor that sounds an alarm if his heart rate is too fast or too slow.
David is one of a growing number of Long Island children on life support systems, and as the caseload increases the legal, social, medical and ethical issues surrounding the problem are intensifying. Hospitals and families are dealing not only with the academic issues but also with the realities of maintaining many critically ill children.
According to the State Health Department, the number of children younger than 1 year treated in Long Island hospitals for conditions that require life support increased 48 percent from 1987 to last year. The state's rate increased 22 percent.
Experts said the difference did not stem from different birthrates or documented differences in children's health. Physicians in New York City and on the Island said medical centers on the Island attributed the difference to improved pediatric and neonatal critical care.
Increasingly parents are taking their critically ill children to medical centers on the Island rather than the city, doctors said.
Some legal and medical experts attribute the increase in children using life-support procedures to doctors' growing unwillingness to withhold or withdraw treatment because they fear legal and social problems.
"If you err toward overtreatment, you're safe," said Peter Williams, a lawyer in the department of community affairs and preventive medicine at the SUNY Stony Brook Medical Center. "Physicians today have an obsession with malpractice or with being the test case. If they treat a kid as if he's the 1 case in 100,000 cases that is going to be a miracle, 99,900 cases will be treated inappropriately."
Through new diagnostic and therapeutic technology, medical centers are managing critically ill children more aggressively, and many severely ill infants are surviving with conditions that can be supported with advanced technologies.
"Amid technology, physicians find that they can do something, but not everything, for the child," the Rev. Robert Smith, a Roman Catholic chaplain at the Stony Brook Medical Center, said. "What should he do if he can assist the lungs with a machine, but he can't change the whole condition of the child?"
Father Smith is on the Governor's panel on life and the law. Removing or withholding life support can contravene the role and perception of doctors' curing illnesses and saving lives.
The director of bioethics and social policy at Schneider Children's Hospital, Dr. Robert Cassidy, said:
"If I go in there and pull that tube out, and the child gasps and gasps and dies, I could only have a sense of connectiveness between what I've done and what happens to the child. If I go in there and hook the tube up, then I'm just doing what doctors are supposed to do."
Dr. Andrew Steele, a neonatologist at Schneider, a unit of the Long Island Jewish Medical Center, said, "What has evolved in our society is an idea that you should not die in a hospital unless somebody pounds on your chest and tries to breathe for you."
 Physicians said their roles were being divided among lawyers, ethicists and judges. "People with a political agenda, economic agenda, philosopical agenda or simply inexperience are out there waiting to second-guess the physicians," said Dr. Cassidy.
 "Physicians are in an atmosphere of suspicion and hostility, which is unfortunate," Father Smith said. "But no physician will tell you that it is good medicine to make a decision based on the possibility that he might be sued."
One court case concerning infants, that of Baby Jane Doe, began in Stony Brook in 1983 and ended up in State Supreme Court. The court ruled that the parents could choose to withhold certain surgical procedures.
There have been no court cases on infants' treatment. "No court cases," Dr. Cassidy said. "No Federal vigilantes' coming over the hill, pounding on the doors of the neonatal unit."
The chairman of the bioethics committee at Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx, Dr. Alan Fleischman, said: "The problem is doctors are moderately paranoid and are reading facts incorrectly and reading the law inappropriately. There have been no cases to support the paranoia."
In July, the Supreme Court of the United States rendered a decision on the case of Nancy Cruzan, who is permanently unconscious. Although her family would like to withdraw her life support, the High Court ruled that proof was needed to show that the patient would want the support removed.
 
Limits in Cruzan Decision

Many physicians extrapolate from decisions on adults' cases to approach pediatric situations.
The executive director of the governor's panel, Tracy Miller, said the Cruzan decision and the panel's reports did "not offer any new laws or guidelines for newborns, only for competent adults."
"Nancy Cruzan has virtually nothing to do with New York State or with infants," Dr. Fleischman said. "It may be more prudent to treat from the potential-lawsuit perspective, but it may frequently be unethical as well."
 State law sets out rules on do-not-resuscitate, or D.N.R., orders for newborns and children, but they apply just to very specific circumstances.
"Most states have adopted legislation that allows parents and health-care workers to decide when treatment is inappropriate," Mr. Williams said. "D.N.R. covers cardiopulmonary resuscitation, not the 9,000 other situations that can come up."
 
'Miracles With These Kids'

Molly was born 13 weeks prematurely and remained in the intensive-care unit of Winthrop Hospital in Mineola for four and a half months. She had repeated seizures, was attached to a ventilator and a feeding tube.
Molly and her mother, Maggie, flew to Memphis, to a doctor who "had done miracles with these kids, too bad not mine," the mother said.
Molly is 3. She is microcephalic, with a brain significantly smaller than normal, and is wheelchair-bound. Intravenous tubes deliver nutrients and medications directly to her bloodstream. She lives at home with her mother, her twin brother and her younger sister.
"I've had a number of chances to let Molly slip away, but it would over my dead body," Maggie said. "Her life is as valuable to me as my two other children."
Doctors usually confer with parents over the child's treatment. There is controversy over what is considered "futile" treatment, not just between parents and doctors, but also among doctors.
Doctors agree that futile care should not be provided, but the question of what may be unnecessary for newborns is still difficult to determine.
The brain is very "flexible" in children younger than 2. Until at least that age, neurologists cannot be certain that an infant who may appear to be permanently unconscious will remain unconscious.
 "When the brain is so very young and immature and sustains insult," said the chief of pediatric neurology at Schneider, Dr. Lydia Eviatar, "the response initially may seem to be total devastation with no recovery. And yet we have seen children who qualify for the diagnosis of vegetative state, and six months, a year, sometimes two years later, they start showing signs of awareness."
Twenty years ago decisions to withhold or withdraw treatment were made between the physician and the family.
"Now we have too much treatment for too many," Dr. Cassidy said. "But maybe we need that to avoid too little treatment for too many."
 
Communication With Parents

An accident at birth deprived Angela of oxygen. By the time the doctors revived her, they did not know the severity of the damage. Angela was in a nonrehabilitative nonresponsive state.
Her father, Robert, said: "The ironic part is that there is a communication between the parents and the child. Yet everyone is so quick to question the ethics of it."
Eventually, a child who is technology dependent does not necessarily need to be in a hospital. Typically, parents have two basic options. One is to take the child home with them. In those cases, the parents learn how to work with the child and often obtain home nursing care.
"We took him home, because that's where we feel our son belongs," Yuwanna said about David. "But before he came home, it was very hard to decide, especially with other children. Now there are people in the house every single day. You can never just leave the house a mess or stay in bed. You always have the feeling that somebody is looking over your shoulder."
Maggie, who took her daughter home, said: "There is tremendous prejudice against these kids. I hate it when I go to temple and I see people avert their eyes or get upset that Molly is there. I've lost all my friends. But I wouldn't do anything differently. Molly is very happy when she's not in the hospital. She's beautiful."
 
One Center in Albany

The second choice is to place the child in a chronic-care center that does not provide hospital-style intense management. Parents on Long Island may not be able to find a chronic-care center.
When Angela was ready to leave the hospital, Robert looked for a long-term center. The only one in the state for a nonrehabilitative infant like Angela was in Albany, but it had a three-and-a-half-to-five-year waiting list.
Finally, Robert placed Angela in a center in New Britain, Conn. He and his wife, Angie, traveled five hours each week to visit their daughter. Angela died two months ago.
"Families need more facilities, especially downstate," said Phyllis Eckert, a senior social worker and supervisor in maternal and child health at North Shore University Hospital, who worked with Angela's family. "We are seeing more and more technology-dependent children, and there must be many more facilities made available to them."
 
'Lives Are Changed Forever'

 "What society has to realize is that these children are not being killed or dying, because they haven't provided places for them to go," Dr. Fleischman said. "They're taking up i.c.u. beds, acute-care beds, which is not what they need and which costs society more money anyway."
"I don't know anyone in the support group who would not want their child to live," Maggie said. "Robert and Angie haven't been freed since Angela died. They're still in pain. Their lives are changed forever.
 "When you're doing things out of love, you're very blind. I would almost love to still be able to go all the way to Connecticut just to visit her."

HEADLINE: Campus Life: Fairfield;
Program Eases Student Transition To College Life

DATELINE: FAIRFIELD, Conn.

 BODY:
To ease the transition from high school to college, Fairfield University has established a Freshman Experience Program. Unlike many such efforts at other colleges, its administrator says, the program tries to ease students through nonacademic problems in their college life.
"The program is directed toward the social development of the student," said Gwen Vendley, the program's director. "During the second semester it challenges the student to look beyond himself to the community" through outreach projects. 
 The program, which is voluntary, consists of weekly workshops to help freshmen adjust tolife at the Jesuit college. Drug abuse, stress, relationships and time management are among the topics covered. The core groups formed at the workshops act as support groups and provide a forum for the freshmen's concerns.
"Students typically feel lost and overwhelmed when they go to college," Mrs. Vendley said. "They imagine that everyone else is better prepared than they are and they feel isolated."
 
 'A Safety Net'
 Each group is led by two volunteers -- a student and either a faculty member or an administrator.
With 50 to 75 percent of the freshman class participating, there are now about 12 students in each of 38 groups, Mrs. Vendley said.
"The beauty of the program is that it doesn't try to be dominating or tell the students what to do, but it is a safety net and support group," said James D. Fitzpatrick, assistant dean of university activities and one of the volunteer leaders, or facilitators.
"I think it's really good to get to know the people in your group and to have a facilitator who pays attention to you and is concerned about you," said Patricia Sullivan, a freshman from Whitestone, Queens, who is majoring in psychology.
 
'It Was a Waste of Time'
 "We have a great time," said Kevin Talz, a junior from Chicago, a psychology and economics major and a freshman facilitator. "I love preparing for the class."
But not all groups have been as successful. "It was a waste of time," said Brooke Duschock, a freshman from South River, N.J., majoring in biology. "Our resident adviser on the floor will have meetings if we need to know something, and we can ask her questions when we have a problem."
David Lynch, a freshman from Burlington, Conn., majoring in chemistry, said the workshops did not help him, since "if you have a problem you can talk to friends or counselors."
"We don't need a group to tell us what to talk about," said Steven Gonzalez, a freshman biology major from East Northport, L.I.
"I'm not sure that it's needed to the extent that they are trying to push it with meetings once a week," said Jacqueline Carelli of Brookfield, Conn., a sophomore majoring in psychology and a freshman facilitator.
 
Housing Was Restructured
 Mrs. Vendley said she hoped that in the future the program would be designed so that the student facilitators and the freshmen would receive college credits.
The new program has also caused the university to restructure its housing plan, establishing freshman floors and adding a dining hall for freshmen.
The university's recent purchase of three buildings from the Sisters of Notre Dame on the campus provided the building for the freshman dining hall. An old chapel was renovated into the dining hall and the other buildings became offices and residences.
The administration originally proposed freshmen-only residence halls when the new program started, but many students protested. They asserted that one of Fairfield's attractions was the mixture of students. The administration compromised with freshmen wings and halls.
Mrs. Vendley said she planned to expand the number of facilitators to incorporate freshmen faculty advisers into the program and to include an additional student facilitator. She also hopes to make the meetings mandatory for all freshmen.

HEADLINE: Campus Life: U. Mass.;
Tutoring Program Is Intended to Cut Housing Costs

DATELINE: AMHERST, Mass.

 BODY:
Students at the Uni versity of Massachusetts at Amherst can ease their financial burdens while easing fellow students' academic burdens through a new tutoring program starting next spring.
The program, created by the office of academic support and housing services, is aimed at helping students offset the $400 fee increase set for next semester while providing tutoring to students, said Ann G. Quinley, dean of academic support services. 
 Tutors will be chosen from juniors and seniors majoring in English, mathematics, accounting, economics and computer science. Applicants must maintain 3.0 grade point averages.
Each student will be paid $450 for working five and half hours a week for 12 weeks. The student can spend the money toward the $907 semester charge for a double room in a residence hall, but that is not required.
 
 60 Applications Received
 Ms. Quinley said her office had received about 60 applications as of Friday. About 50 students living on campus and 50 living off campus will be selected. Students living off campus will have to return to the dormitories to participate.
Some juniors and seniors move off campus between first and second semesters each year, leaving residence hall vacancies that the administration hopes the program will fill, said Joseph Zannini, director of housing services.
"It is not necessarily economically advantageous to students to move back to the dormitories," Mr. Zannini said. "Through the tutorial program, the administration can pay for some of the students' bills, provide a service and bring more juniors and seniors back into the dorms."
Ms. Quinley added: "We're relying on the increased occupancy in the dormitories to pay for the program."
Students will be notified of whether they have been selected by Dec. 17 so they can inform their landlords, Ms. Quinley said.
Tutorials will take place in residence halls and multicultural centers. Freshmen and sophomores will be matched with tutors the second week of the spring semester, which starts Jan. 31.

HEADLINE: Social Events

BYLINE: By Thomas W. Ennis

 BODY:

For the Costume Institute
Dec. 3 -- The annual benefit for the Costume Institute at the Metropolitan Museum of Art will begin with cocktails at 7:30 P.M. in the museum's new Carroll and Milton Petrie Sculpture Court, to be followed by dinner at the Temple of Dendur at 9. Tickets, $900 or $125 for a reception and dancing at 9:30, from (212) 570-3948.
 
 Remembering Satchmo
Dec. 3 -- The Newport Jazz Festival All-Stars, Carrie Smith and other jazz performers will gather at St. Peter's Lutheran Church, Lexington Avenue and 54th Street, at a benefit for the Center for Children and Families, formerly the Queensboro Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children. The event, which also includes a dinner and reception after the 7:30 P.M. performance, will be a tribute to the late Louis (Satchmo) Armstrong. Tickets, $175 for the performance, dinner and reception or $75 for the performance only, from (718) 526-0722.
 
Aid for Children's Theater
Dec. 3 -- A fund-raising cocktail party for TADA -- the Theater and Dance Alliance, a children's theater company -- will start at 6:30 P.M. at 12 West 17th Street. There will be a preview of the latest TADA musical, "The Gift of Winter." Tickets, $25, at the door or from (212) 627-1732.
 
YIVO's 65th Birthday
Dec. 3 -- A benefit dinner at 7:30 P.M. at the Manhattan Center, 311 West 34th Street, will observe the 65th anniversary of the YIVO Institute for Jewish Research. Samuel Pisar, a lawyer, author and economic adviser, will be the guest of honor. There will be entertainment by Mandy Patinkin, Tovah Feldshuh and Alexander Schneider. Tickets, $500 and $750 ($175 for people under the age of 35), from (212) 535-6700.
 
Briefly Noted:
Dec. 4 -- A baby shower from 6:30 to 8 P.M., at Grace Episcopal Church, Hicks and Joralemon Streets in Brooklyn Heights, is to benefit the Interfaith Medical Center in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section. The center cares for abandoned and crack-addicted babies. A holiday tea will be served, and Tom Chapin, a folk and rock singer, will entertain. No admission charge, but guests are asked to make a donation or to bring blankets and clothing for the babies. Information: (718) 624-7765.
Dec. 4 -- Oscar de la Renta, in association with Saks Fifth Avenue, will present his Spring 1991 collection at a lunch at noon at the Waldorf-Astoria, a benefit for the Mount Sinai Medical Center's Department of Obstetrics, Gynecology and Reproductive Science. Tickets, $200, from (212) 241-4993.
Dec. 4 -- Lauren Bacall, the author John Irving and the artist John Davis will receive Lifetime Achievement in the Arts awards from the Guild Hall Academy of the Arts in East Hampton, L.I., at a dinner benefit for the Guild Hall at the Plaza. The party will start with cocktails at 7:30 P.M. Tickets, $300, from (516) 324-0806.
Dec. 4 -- The Advertising Club's holiday party at 6 P.M. at the Plaza will be a benefit for its scholarship fund. There will be a buffet dinner, open bar, entertainment and an auction. Tickets, $75, from (212) 935-8080.
Dec. 5 -- The community programs of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine will benefit from a dinner and a night of music at the cathedral. Billy Joel is to be the guest of honor in recognition of his philanthropies, and such well-known chefs as Jonathan Waxman and Larry Forgione will prepare the dinner. Cocktails at 7:30 P.M. Tickets, $250, from (212) 316-7483.
Dec. 5 -- The Marine Corps Scholarship Foundation is to benefit from an exhibition of works by Victor H. Runnels, a Sioux Indian artist, at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and 67th Street. Buffet supper at 6 P.M. Tickets, $55, from (212) 371-9155.
Dec. 5 -- The Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater will open its four-week season at the City Center, 131 West 55th Street, with benefit premieres of Lar Lubovitch's "North Star" and Kris World's "Read Matthew 11:28." The 7:30 P.M. performance will be followed by a dinner and dance at the New York Hilton at 9:30. Black tie. Tickets, $350 and $500, from (212) 767-0590.
Dec. 5 -- Educational programs of the Jewish Guild for the Blind are to benefit from a cocktail party and dance at the Harmonie Club, 4 East 60th Street. The party will begin at 8 P.M. Tickets, $125, at the door or from (212) 769-6239.
Dec. 5 -- The Cystic Fibrosis Foundation is to benefit from a cocktail party and dance at the New York Hilton. HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Consumers Aren't Buying The Bad News

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
As measured by the University of Michigan, consumer confidence actually rose in November. Not, to be sure, by nearly as much as it dropped the previous month, but nonetheless it was an increase. And the stock market was up nicely for the month, even before peace hopes on Friday propelled the Dow to a weekly gain of 32.42, to 2,559.65.
For the month, the Dow was up 4.8 percent, and smaller stocks did much better. The Nasdaq composite rose 8.8 percent. The mutual fund companies find it hard to believe just how much money is pouring into their stock funds. 
 The public's apparent optimism, or at least lack of pessimism, may reflect the fact that life looks a lot less grim on many Main Streets than it does on Wall Street. The word from Christmas shoppers in parts of the Midwest is that the malls are jammed.
A partial explanation for the good cheer is that the unemployment rate has not yet zoomed upward, and most Americans don't know people who are losing jobs. A Conference Board survey finds that the majority of Americans still tell pollsters that jobs are available, not scarce.
Another reason for consumers to be happy, while businesses are not, is that much of the economic pain so far has been borne by corporate America, as pressures have piled up to keep them from passing on cost increases. The Commerce Department says that inventory profits -- mostly for the oil companies -- sent overall corporate profits zooming in the third quarter. But economic profits, after adjusting for inventory gains, showed a sharp 9.6 percent decline.
Tom Doerflinger, who watches profits for Paine Webber, argues that the factors depressing earnings are not likely to reverse themselves. "The main point is that the bad news on earnings is still ahead of us, and expectations are too high," he said. "The worst is yet to come."
If this recession turns out to be mild and short, that forecast could be wrong. Over the short run, a Middle East war, or lack of one, could have a profound impact on that prospect, and it is reasonable that Wall Street hangs on every rumor of talks or attacks.
But over a longer term, the trade talks now nearing conclusion in Brussels may be a lot more important. Free trade can produce a more prosperous world, but it has few friends when economies are slowing around the globe, and the best bet is that the talks will fail.
If so, rounds of trade retaliation, like Europe's decision last week to slap a tariff on sales of Monsanto's Nutrasweet, may become the order of the day. Those are battles in which individual companies and interests win -- the European competitor of Monsanto, for example -- but the world economy loses.
Messrs. Smoot and Hawley made it into the economic hall of shame with their bill to raise tariffs in the Depression. If trade wars get going again, the results could be the same, and the current optimism will be long forgotten.

HEADLINE: Wall Street;
Taking the Measure of Recession '90

BYLINE: By Diana B. Henriques

 BODY:
TO many Wall Street sages, the most dangerous phrase in the language is: "It's different this time." The economic landscape is littered with corporate corpses whose last words were, "Sure, junk bonds haven't had a good name, but it's different this time." Or, "A debt-heavy balance sheet used to be dangerous, but it's less risky now."
Of course, some things really do change -- and change so profoundly, with such intriguing implications for the market, that Wall Street ignores the alteration at its own risk. One such change has been occurring over the past four years, according to a forthcoming study by Mickey Levy, chief economist at CRT Government Securities in New York, an affiliate of the Chicago Research and Trading Group. And this change, a sharp shift in how and where America makes its money, suggests to Mr. Levy that Wall Street needs to re-examine some of its assumptions about what the coming recession will look like, and which stocks will perform best while it lasts. 
 The markets have been preoccupied with the overall state of the economy for months, and last week that concern developed into obsessionary overdrive. President Bush, still loath to say the R-word, conceded a "serious slowdown" has occurred. Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, spoke out loud of "a meaningful downturn." And the Commerce Department reported that its index of leading economic indicators fell in October for the fourth month in a row, signaling to many that the recession is here.
Like most private economists, Mr. Levy expects a recession. But he does not think it will bear much resemblance to other recent downturns. Typically, the postwar downturns have been "V-shaped recessions," Mr. Levy said, with the Fed slamming on the brakes to tame an overheated economy and then hitting the gas pedal just as abruptly after the recession develops. "Thus, the entrance into and exit from recent recessions were quite dramatic," Mr. Levy said. "But this time is distinctively different."
Ah, the fateful phrase. But Mr. Levy is not deterred: "Look, it is simply common experience. We may all look back from some point in the future and say, 'Gee, 1990 -- the gross national product was growing, but it still felt like a recession. The Fed tightened gradually, and we have had this gradual slowdown.' " Indeed, the gradual onset of this recession distinguishes it from every other postwar downturn except for 1969, according to Mr. Levy. "And 1969 is not really comparable because you had the Vietnam War build-up, with defense spending as a much higher percent of G.N.P. than today, despite the situation in the Middle East."
Similarly, barring any aggressive stimulation from the Fed, the rebound from this recession is likely to be more anemic than in the past, and to come only after some protracted period of "flatness," Mr. Levy said.
What does this matter of timing mean to Wall Street? Well, the abrupt nature of past recessions helped dictate which industries felt the most pain, in Mr. Levy's view. Any sudden plunge into recession will typically leave manufacturers with unsold products in the warehouse. They cope with this inventory backlog by quickly scaling back production, producing layoffs and reduced business for their suppliers and distributors. That is one reason why service firms, unburdened by unsold inventory, have tended to outperform manufacturers during past recessions.
But this time around, manufacturers have not accumulated the inventories that haunted them in the past -- perhaps because of changed production practices that emphasize lower inventories, or perhaps just because the gradual slowdown gave companies the chance to adjust more gracefully.
At the same time, the weaker dollar has produced a dramatic but little-appreciated boom in exports, which have grown from less than 11 percent of G.N.P. in 1986 to nearly 15 percent this year. Further, there has been a sharp rise in the share of G.N.P. made up of spending on durable goods, which economists define as products with a life of at least three years and which shoppers define as big-ticket items -- cars, say, or sectional sofas. Both developments benefit manufacturers more than their service-sector brethren.
Since each percentage-point share of the G.N.P. is worth about $41.5 billion, these shifts represent the movement of a gigantic amount of money from one corner of the economy to another, and from one set of corporations to another. Consequently, Mr. Levy argues, the nation's manufacturing sector simply may not experience the levels of recessionary pain this time around that it has felt in the past.
 The other side of this encouraging coin, unfortunately, may be that those who work in the traditionally "recession-proof" regions of the nation's economy -- its banks and financial service companies, its real estate firms and its department stores -- are likely to suffer in this recession as never before in postwar history.
Here, too, the changing mix of the nation's economic production is significant. As exports have grown in economic importance, spending on nondurable goods -- the stuff that department store sales are made of -- has shrunk as a share of G.N.P., as has spending on residential property.
The service-sector equivalent of a warehouse full of unsold goods is an office full of idle people, Mr. Levy points out. "Thus, somewhat analogous to the liquidation of excessive inventories in the manufacturing industries in prior recessions," he explained, "this economic correction will involve the liquidation of excesses of human capital in these major service-producing industries."
The silver lining in all this, Mr. Levy adds, is that "a slow and gradual recession is much healthier over the long run." It permits the core rate of inflation to come down, and puts the subsequent recovery on a stronger footing. But if Mr. Levy's analysis is right, the path to that recovery winds through some unfamiliar terrain, and some people will not survive the trip.
