LENGTH: 2617 words

HEADLINE: It's Glam! It's Fab! It's a Rave!

BYLINE: By WOODY HOCHSWENDER

 BODY:
Gene and Robert Pressman are like brothers from different planets.
Gene, long haired and laid back, preferring jeans and blazer to a suit, went to film school and worked as a go-fer in Hollywood before bringing women's fashion to the family business, Barneys New York. Robert, at 36, is three years' Gene's junior; he is close cropped and buttoned down, has an M.B.A. and runs the financial side of the company. In an era of retail retrenchment, it may be just this mix -- innovative fashion merchandiser and sober financier -- coupled with rich Japanese backers that will make Barneys fly as other retailers flounder. While in malls and on Main Street fashion industry executives are struggling just to survive, the Pressmans have been thinking: the world. 
 With help from Japan's sixth-largest retailing operation, the Isetan Company, Barneys has embarked on a remarkable expansion program, opening a chain of satellite stores in shopping malls from Long Island to California, Texas to Tokyo. On Nov. 16, it announced plans to open a 230,000-square-foot store on Madison Avenue at 61st Street, the largest new specialty store in Manhattan in decades and the first uptown foray for Barneys.
Retail analysts consider the expansion every bit as daring as the decision by Gene and Robert's father, Fred Pressman, in the 1960's, considered questionable at the time, to move Barneys from a men's-wear discounter to a high-end fashion store. The idea now is to take Barneys' peculiar mix of traditional and avant-garde clothes to suburban malls coast to coast -- well beyond the drumbeat of their well-honed advertising campaigns, to boldly go where Jean Paul Gaultier and Hickey-Freeman have never gone together before. Eventually, the Pressmans envision a national apparel chain of at least 25 stores, maybe 100. There are now 10.
 
Staking Out the Territory
 It is certainly a major change in direction for Barneys, which had remained in a single location at Seventh Avenue and 17th Street for 65 years. Superficially, the timing, with apparel sales sluggish and signs of recession everywhere, could not have been worse. Conceivably, a severe economic downturn could cause the Pressmans to cut back plans. But the Pressmans say they are not worried. "There is a market-share thing here," said Robert recently. "If you are expanding and others are retracting, when times get better you've got that share." Or as Gene, who handles marketing and merchandising, put it: "We got a lot going on here, and it's, like, worldwide."
Whether they can extend their success to such far-flung cities as Seattle and Tokyo may depend on their ability to adapt in each market, and, more important, to manage the various balls they are juggling. "The question I have to ask is: Do they know how to manage this new concept?" said Kurt Barnard, a retail analyst and publisher of the Retail Marketing Report. "They're creating something new, but can we assume they can master that business?"
Certainly, Barneys' moves reflect the robust opportunism of this generation of Pressmans, who developed a women's fashion image for Barneys even as others in the industry scoffed. But it is also reflects the conservative, deleveraging mood of the 90's. While many of America's most prestigious stores sag under huge debt, Barneys is financing its expansion largely with cash -- its own and Isetan's.
Most of all, the expansion points to the importance of having a partner that shares a commitment to long-term retailing goals -- and has very deep pockets.
"Isetan is a fourth-generation family-run business," said Robert Pressman, executive vice president of Barneys and grandson of the founder, Barney Pressman. "It's not like going to a venture capitalist. Isetan doesn't expect to get back money overnight."
The start-up investment by Barneys and Isetan is about $250 million, with Isetan putting up more than half -- how much more Barneys executives would not say.
As a privately held company, Barneys has formerly declined to disclose sales figures. But executives provided figures showing that Barneys has nearly doubled sales since 1986, when its women's store opened.
 
Pursuing Volume
 A Barneys men's clothing store opened in the Wall Street area in 1988 -- with no involvement from Isetan -- has not met expectations. Barneys executives said layoffs in the financial services industry had affected sales, but they expect that eventually it will be profitable. Total sales for all stores in 1989 were $130 million, according to Barneys figures, with sales of $160 million projected for this year. By comparison, Isetan estimates sales from its own operations will be $4 billion this year.
With sales of the new Madison Avenue store projected to exceed $150 million in the year it opens, 1992 -- plus additional volume from scheduled satellite store openings both here and in Japan -- Barneys' yearly volume could easily more than double again, to about $400 million.
However, a long and deep recession will certainly affect sales at a premium retailer like Barneys, no matter how much capital they have. "The burden of risk may be with the Japanese, but that does not guarantee success," Mr. Barnard said. "Barneys is trying to become a destination store of preference among the elite. But when people are spending more conservatively, they tend to revert to established store loyalties."
Clearly, Barneys New York has come a long way from the 1940's -- from the radio days of "Calling all men" (short men, tall men, stout men!), when it sold bargain men's clothing. For years, it remained a cautious, family-run company staying close to its humble retailing roots: In 1923, as family lore has it, Barney Pressman pawned his wife's engagment ring (her idea, the story goes) to raise $500 to cover rent and to stock men's suits.
But with its entry into the women's fashion business and its hard-won expertise at promoting itself and its products, Barneys has become a fashion mecca. While traditional retailers deck their holiday windows with toy trains and quaint movable figurines of Christmases past, Barneys displays life-size figures of Mikhail Gorbachev, Lawrence Taylor, Ivana Trump and Madonna in ironically glamorous contexts.
 
Strange Beauties
 Its Tammy Bakker window this season, for example, shows the fallen evangelist's wife standing before a Christmas tree made out of a giant mascara brush. Another window portrays Karl Lagerfeld, the designer who updated Chanel, in a totally quilted room, including a quilted fireplace with quilted flames -- a visual allusion to the signature Chanel quilted handbags. On the wall is a quotation: "I don't like standard beauty. There is no beauty without strangeness."
Those sophisticated images are aimed at maturing baby boomers, those who have grown up hip and rebellious but now have the money to buy Chanel (or at least appreciate witty visual allusion to Chanel's signature quilted handbags). With competitors in disarray, the Pressmans are on the prowl. "In a weak retail environment, that's the time to take a shot," said Robert Pressman.
At Madison Avenue and 61st Street, Barneys will be in position to take advantage of weakness at nearby Bloomingdale's, whose parent company, Federated/Allied Stores, entered into a Chapter 11 bankruptcy last year. It can also challenge other stores like Bergdorf Goodman and Saks Fifth Avenue for the tourist trade. It is at the gateway to a golden strip of Madison Avenue designer boutiques, leading up to the Ralph Lauren store at 72d Street.
The 11-floor store, purchased outright for more than $100 million, cash, abuts the Pierre Hotel and the swank Metropolitan Club. This prime spot was achieved through a real estate co-venture of Barneys and Isetan in which each retains a 50 percent share in the building. But therein lies a tale.
How did a relatively small company -- compared to the large specialty store chains like Saks and Neiman Marcus -- come up with the kind of cash for a global expansion?
 
Just Family
 "In 1986, we hired Goldman, Sachs as an adviser and sat down as a family to try and figure out how to grow and still sleep at night," Robert Pressman said. (With almost 1,500 employees, Barneys is nevertheless a family business. Fred remains president of Barneys New York, although Robert and Gene are leading the expansion. Fred's wife, Phyllis, is vice president and general merchandise manager. Their daughter, Nancy Pressman-Dressler, is general merchandise manager of the main store's Co/Op section. Bonnie Pressman, Gene's wife, is general merchandise manager for women's accessories, cosmetics and shoes. Holly Pressman, Robert's wife, is director of corporate gifts and investments.)
On the advice of Goldman, Barneys entered into joint ventures with Isetan, which was eager to import the hip display and merchandising skills that Barneys is known for.
In Japan, there are few such mid-sized specialty stores -- on a scale somewhere between a boutique and a department store -- but there is a strong consumer appetite for sophisticated, fashionable "special" store products. And Barneys is nothing if not special, from the majolica china in its Chelsea Passage department to the clothes by Romeo Gigli, Yohji Yamamoto and Issey Miyake, which sometimes seem to require a set of instructions on how to put them on.
The deal was structured so that Isetan and Barneys each has an equity stake in ventures set up on the other's turf. Isetan became a minority partner in Barneys America, the company established to open the smaller satellite stores (7,000 to 30,000 square feet) in the United States. So far, the verdict remains out on the stores, which are in Chestnut Hill, Mass.; Short Hills, N.J.; Manhasset, L.I.; Westport, Conn.; Costa Mesa, Calif.; Seattle and Dallas.
"We took the viewpoint that we would do the opposite of what everybody else has done," Robert Pressman said. "We don't make interest payments, and we're not dependent on banks. We do not have to run fall sales in August."
Even though Isetan holds only a minority interest in the satellite stores, it is kicking in a majority of the cash for building them.
Barneys became a minority partner in Barneys Japan, set up with Isetan to open the Asian stores, including a 30,000-square-foot Barneys that opened in Tokyo Nov. 3, and two more slated for Japan.
Through Barneys Inc., formed in 1923, Barneys and Isetan will open larger American stores, along the lines of the Seventh Avenue flagship. These will include the Madison Avenue store and a 110,000-square-foot Beverly Hills store, expected to open on Wilshire Boulevard in 1993. Barneys Inc. will own and run both, leasing the property from the joint venture set up with Isetan. Contrary to some industry reports, Isetan holds no equity interest in Barneys Inc., Barneys executives said.
On the face of it, it would appear that Barneys and Isetan would each have invested about $50 million in the $100 million Madison Avenue deal. But Barneys could have put up less, Robert Pressman said, without elaborating. Isetan executives declined to be interviewed. Payments to the real estate partnership will be tied to sales performance. Robert Pressman said future rent payments by Barneys Inc. might not be split equally by the partners. In other words, he said, Isetan could receive more -- as Isetan may have invested more. "It's incredibly complicated," he said.
Barneys executives expect new-store profits to finance the expansion. "In the good old days, retailers made enough money internally to pay for expansion," Robert Pressman said. Now, that's not so.
 
 
CASHING IN ON THE GREAT REAL ESTATE BLUES
 In leasing its new properties, especially for the smaller satellite stores, Barneys says that it has benefited from a softness in the real estate market nationwide -- a softness accelerated by the wave of retail bankruptcies in the last three years.
"People who own real estate, particularly new shopping centers, are more flexible," said Gene Pressman, co-president of Barneys America, established to open the satellite stores. "Things have definitely changed in the last 18 months. There aren't a lot of takers out there."
Mall owners in two of the satellite store locations -- Costa Mesa, Calif., and Manhasset, L.I. -- would not provide details, but said they gave Barneys favorable terms. Typically, such leases are long term and geared to sales volume.
In Manhasset, Barneys opened a year ago in the Americana shopping center, about 20 miles from its Manhattan flagship store. It is directly across Northern Bouleward from the red-brick shell of Bonwit Teller. A block away stands ivy-covered, empty B. Altman. Both fell victim to the bankruptcy proceedings at their parent company, the Hooker Corporation. Still, Barneys is far from alone. In the same block are Polo/Ralph Lauren, Sonia Rykiel, Anne Klein, Giorgio Armani, Liz Claiborne and Hermes -- high focus, high fashion.
Barneys' smallish satellites "make sense," said Frank Castagna, founder and owner of the Americana center. "To take big stores and try to ship them all over the country doesn't work. We found that out after the Campeau bankruptcy, when Bloomingdale's released its numbers: The New York store was great but the rest of the country was not outstanding. It's very hard to adapt a big unit to different lifestyles."
With that in mind, Barneys has confined its plans for larger stores -- more than 30,000 square feet -- to major cities including Chicago, Los Angeles and New York. The Chicago store is scheduled to open on fashionable Oak Street late next year.
The newest Barneys satellite is in Dallas -- a 30,000-square-foot store that opened on Aug. 26, within days of the closing of Bloomingdale's troubled Dallas unit. Barneys also plans a satellite store in Tower City, a development in downtown Cleveland, next spring.
"The offers from mall owners are endless," said Gene Pressman. "But we don't want to be all over the place. Our product is not as commercial as the Limited or the Gap."
 
RETHINKING THE MIX
WITH seven satellite stores open, some brand new, the verdict is still out on the Barneys expansion. But Barneys has already begun to tinker with the merchandising mix.
When the first six stores opened in the last two years, they were stocked primarily with women's clothing, in a mix loosely based on the hip, moderately priced styles sold in the Co/Op department, a youth-oriented section of the 17th Street store. About 20 percent of the women's clothing was designer level -- Jean Paul Gaultier, Comme des Garcons, Sybilla and the classic Hermes.
In a radical departure from the flagship store's traditional emphasis, men's wear was scarce. And it was confined to sportswear -- no suits.
But this is being rethought.
"After we opened," said Gene Pressman, "we found the men's business was doing way above the $600-a-foot average." Barneys average, $600-per-square-foot annual sales volume, is about double the typical mall store performance. So men's suits and dress shirts are in -- at all the satellites.
In the remerchandizing, European men's suits by Giorgio Armani, Ermenegildo Zegna and Hugo Boss are sold with Barneys-label suits and clothing by leading women's designers. In Manhasset, L.I., where women wear Azzedine Alaia to the supermarket, the strategy seems to make special sense.
"They're on target in terms of revenue and profits," said Mark Green, Barneys' adviser at Goldman, Sachs, who receives aggregate sales figures from the satellite stores. "I don't know if every store is meeting its projections or not, but they're doing well."

HEADLINE: FORUM;
Israel's Latest Push to Attract Investors

BYLINE: By Joel Kurtzman

 BODY:
Israel has undertaken an investment initiative designed to lure high-tech American and European companies to invest in its economy. The program was developed by Moshe Nissim, Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Industry and Trade. Mr. Nissim discussed the initiatives and the state of Israel's economy with Joel Kurtzman of The New York Times. 
 Q. The intifada continues in Israel while the Middle East is generally tense after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. Is this the right time to try to lure new foreign investment?
Mr. Nissim: Why not? Let me tell you about the intifada. It hurt our economy in 1988 only. Since then, we haven't seen any special damage to our economy. The purchases of our products from people coming in from the territories is down somewhat. But as far as the security issue goes, the damage to Israel is only psychological.
In the region, yes, we have problems with all of our neighbors except Egypt. But these security problems have not damaged the image of the Israel as a country of high-level industry. Motorola, Intel, National Semiconductor, they have all established enterprises in Israel and succeeded.
Q. But doesn't tension from the gulf crisis spill over into Israel?
Mr. Nissim: I think only in tourism. Everyone knows that this crisis will find its end. I don't know how or how long it will take, but it will not take years -- and I don't want to interfere in it. But we will see the end of this crisis.
Tourism was down before, around the time of the U.S. raid on Libya. That was when President Reagan recommended that Americans not come to the Middle East. It was also down during the first year of the intifada. But in 1989, we had more tourists than in 1988 or 1987 or even 1986. It was booming in the first part of this year as well. Only now is it down because of the gulf crisis.
But in reality, our security problems don't create any more risks than there are in other countries around the world. They will not damage the prospects for investing in Israel.
Q. You recently outlined a new series of incentives for investing in Israel. Why?
Mr. Nissim: I submitted to the Government a new plan hoping to accelerate the growth of our economy. The goal is to create a lot of new jobs. You know why? Because within the next three years we'll absorb a million Jews from the Soviet Union. Our population will increase by 25 percent, more or less. That is something quite unusual.
Q. Does the plan focus on selling state-owned companies?
Mr. Nissim: Privatization is only one component. There are a lot of separate components. We are trying to create the conditions for growth. We are trying to encourage investments -- local and foreign. We have to double and triple investment. We have to increase our business-sector output by 12 percent a year. We have to double exports within four years. If not, we will not have new jobs for the immigrants. This is our main task. We want to accomplish it by encouraging investments. How? The Government will participate with the investor to offset the risk. The investor has to put in one-third of the investment and the Government will give a state guarantee for two-thirds. The investor has to go to the bank to get a loan, of which two-thirds will be guaranteed. In different parts of the country the incentives vary. In the north and south we give guarantees and 10 years of exemption from income tax and company tax.
Q. Israel is famous for its slow and cumbersome bureaucracy. How are you going to deal with that?
Mr. Nissim: Everyone talks about the bureaucracy. This is what we've done. The company has to make an application to the Israel Investment Center in our ministry. We will make a decision within 12 working days, not more. We will examine the record of the investor and the business plan, all within 12 days. We'll give the decision without bureaucracy. If it takes longer than 12 days, then the answer is an automatic "yes." We want to cut -- no, crush -- the bureaucracy.
Q. A lot of countries are competing for a limited amount of foreign investment. Why should a company invest in Israel?
Mr. Nissim: We offer grants and we have state guarantees. We offer an exemption from taxes. We offer a free-trade area and a very high level of facilities -- banks, communications, infrastructure. But there is something else. Highly skilled manpower as a proportion of the total work force. In the 1990's, 33.5 percent of our work force will be highly skilled versus 16 percent in the U.S. Twenty-two percent of the new immigrants from the Soviet Union are engineers; engineers will make up 6 percent of our work force in the 1990's versus 1.6 for the U.S. It is a higher percentage than in Denmark, Germany, Ireland and Japan.
Q. There has been opposition to foreign investment within Israel, hasn't there? Privatizing the national airline, El Al, has been a subject of controversy.
Mr. Nissim: El Al is not a company that is easy to privatize because it has some legal problems. The company is under receivership. It's a very good company, but because of strikes 10 or 12 years ago, it was put under the receiver. It will be privatized, but not tomorrow.
Q. There has also been controversy over the foreign purchase of the state-owned Israel Chemical Industry.
Mr. Nissim: Correct. But I am in favor to privatizing it. We have some things to do there too. My idea is to sell shares on the stock exchanges in New York and in Tel Aviv. In the first stage, we'll sell 12.5 percent in New York and 12.5 in Tel Aviv.
We want to deregulate our economy. You can see it in our plan. We deregulated control of foreign currency. I opened the market in a lot of areas. Our plan is to gradually open all of our industries and all sectors of our economy -- textiles, food chemicals and electronics -- everything will be open.

HEADLINE: Railroads Meet Steep Grades in Trying to Haul Trash

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

 BODY:
SEVERAL years ago, some railroad executives and consultants began referring to the garbage mountains accumulating in the nation's cities as "urban ore."
The railroads envisioned a tantalizing new opportunity in hauling the wastes hundreds or even thousands of miles to incinerators, recycling plants and remote high-tech disposal sites dubbed megafills. They foresaw a $1 billion market by the turn of the century, because thousands of older landfills in populous regions were nearing capacity or facing closure due to environmental problems. In addition, they expected revenues and even higher profit margins from hauling lesser amounts of hazardous waste, including contaminated soil. 
 So far, though, the new business is inching ahead at most railroads with all the speed of an iron-ore train huffing up a steep grade.
"It's developed more slowly than anyone anticipated," said Roderick Willey, a consultant with Waste Placement Professionals Inc. in Dayton, Ohio. Indeed, most analysts say there is little chance that such business will have a measurable impact on earnings in the next few years.
The delay has not caused railroad executives to give up on the market, or even to stop making ambitious plans. Two railroads, for example, are involved in separate plans to haul hundreds of millions of tons of waste out of the Los Angeles area over the next century. Others are pursuing ventures to haul hazardous waste in Oklahoma and municipal wastes in Washington State.
Yet, for now, even the biggest waste hauler, Conrail, has only a modest operation: its tonnages are small and the business is scarcely more mature than operations at other railroads that are hauling wastes sporadically and searching for dependable markets.
Nationwide, railroads are unlikely to capture more than 15 percent of the garbage-hauling market -- about 30 million tons -- before the latter part of the decade, according to Dean Wise, a transportation expert at the consulting firm of Temple, Barker & Sloane in Lexington, Mass.
One problem is that railroads have needed time to figure out the best types of equipment to handle different types of waste. Some railroad executives say they are still getting to know the marketplace, having had few previous contacts with waste-collection companies, municipal sanitation departments and other customers they need to wean from truckers.
Moreover, truckers have been able to carry all kinds of consumer goods -- even food -- in one direction and wastes on their return trip, a cost-cutting strategy known as backhauling that has allowed them to offer unbeatable prices to waste generators in many urban areas. Railroads have not had the right blend of equipment and customers to offer similar deals. Congress passed legislation early this year calling for restrictions on backhauling by trucks transporting food and agricultural products, but regulations implementing the limits are not expected until next year at the earliest.
BUT the biggest problem has been the lack of disposal sites approved by state and Federal regulators that are easily accessible to rail lines.
"The lack of environmentally sound destinations has really held us back," said Steve Watson, assistant vice president in charge of hazardous and solid waste at the CSX Corporation, which has its railroad operations based in Baltimore.
That problem will probably not be cured quickly, given the opposition in most areas to any new development that smacks of waste handling or disposal. Railroad executives say there are already cases in which local groups have blocked railroads from building "transfer stations" where wastes can be loaded on to trains. In other cases, protesters have pressured regulators or disposal-site owners to reduce or even block importation of out-of-state garbage.
The Supreme Court has ruled that outright bans on such imports are illegal. But strict licensing requirements and a variety of fee structures have proven to be equally imposing hurdles in many cases.
"This is a challenge like nothing I've ever seen before," said Barry Vann, director of environmental logistics and marketing for the Burlington Northern Railroad Company, based in Fort Worth. "Economics don't determine whether you will make any money. It's all relationships with states and local communities."
Just last month, a ballot initiative in South Dakota forced developers to suspend construction of a megafill that would have received wastes hauled from out of state on a Burlington Northern line.
Despite such obstacles, long-distance rail transportation of wastes is growing and should accelerate as the decade progresses.
"We have reached the stage where we carry something every day," said Ellison Wefel, manager of the solid-waste business group at Conrail, which was formed in 1976 to take over the freight operations of the bankrupt Penn Central and five smaller Northeast railroads. "The grand numbers some people envisioned are still somewhere down the road, but we are optimistic we'll get there."
Conrail serves the Northeast and portions of the Midwest, where waste-disposal problems are especially pressing and the cost of local disposal can reach $150 a ton or more, more than 10 times that of some areas in the West.
Last year, Conrail was paid about $4 million to ship municipal wastes and incinerator ash and $5.7 million to ship contaminated soils and hazardous waste. The waste material was taken to disposal sites in Conrail's region or to other railroads that carried it as far as Florida or states west of the Mississippi.
Conrail expects its solid-waste revenues to reach $40 million to $50 million by 1994. It anticipates that hazardous-waste revenues will grow 10 to 15 percent annually, to as much as $11.5 million, over the same period. Such sums pale beside the company's total revenues -- $3.4 billion last year -- but the company sees long-range potential for further growth.
"IT'S all new business, so it's very important to Conrail," said Wayne Michel, the company's director of asset management. Smaller regional railroads, notably the Long Island Rail Road, feed substantial amounts of the waste into the Conrail system for shipment.
Conrail has moved further into the waste business through its stake in the Concord Resources Group, a year-old Pittsburgh-based joint venture with the OHM Corporation, an environmental concern best known for cleanups of hazardous waste. Concord is seeking a permit to build a hazardous-waste disposal site next to Conrail tracks in western Pennsylvania and hopes to open a string of solid-waste disposal sites in rural sections of the 17 states Conrail serves. Conrail has invested $5 million in Concord and lent it $100 million.
The Atchison, Topeka & Santa Fe Railway Company has more focused -- but no less ambitious -- plans for its joint venture with Waste Management Inc., the nation's largest solid-waste disposal company. The two companies have pledged to invest $85 million in a proposal to ship up to 200 million tons of waste from the Los Angeles area over the next century to a megafill on the railroad's property 225 miles to the east in the Mojave Desert. Dubbed Rail-Cycle, the project includes recycling programs and up to six processing centers in the Los Angeles region.
"We hope to handle about half the Los Angeles basin's solid waste, but it would be worth our while if we get half that," said Delbert M. Miller, the railroad's spokesman for the project. At its projected disposal cost of $41.50 a ton in 1989 dollars, the project could bring in as much as $8.3 billion.
A JOINT venture involving the Southern Pacific Railroad, Western Waste Industries and the Mine Reclamation Corporation to transport similar amounts of garbage from the Los Angeles region to abandoned iron ore mines south of the Rail-Cycle site fell apart earlier this year. (Western Waste is a Los Angeles-based waste-disposal company; Mine Reclamation is a privately held startup venture based in Norwalk, Calif.)
Mine Reclamation hopes to go ahead with the project and Southern Pacific remains the logical choice to haul the waste because its tracks run by the mines, according to Gary Korvall, a Mine Reclamation spokesman. With the Los Angeles region generating up to 80,000 tons of solid waste a day, Mr. Korvall said, there is ample room for both projects.
Waste Management, meanwhile, is working with another railroad, the Union Pacific, on a more modest program that is scheduled to start hauling waste from Seattle to Waste Management's disposal site in eastern Washington next year.
Since 1988, the Union Pacific, which is based in Omaha, and Uspci Inc. (formerly United States Pollution Control Inc.), a leading hazardous-waste disposal company based in Topeka, Kan., have both been owned by the Union Pacific Corporation of Allentown, Pa. Internal committees have been asked to explore potential synergies.
But Uspci has operated independently since it was acquired and continues to work with other railroads carrying a growing share of the wastes that reach its disposal sites, said Ken Jackson, vice president for business development. For instance, the company is working on a joint venture with Burlington Northern to build a transfer station in Avard, Okla., where hazardous wastes brought by rail from distant places could be unloaded for a short truck trip to Uspci's site in Fairview.
With the megafill project in South Dakota on hold, Mr. Vann at Burlington Northern is more eager than ever to push ahead at Avard. "People see a large, growing market," he said, "but no one ever thought it would be easy to cash in on."
 
 
JUST WHOSE BACKYARD IS IT?
 Burlington Northern got an expensive lesson in how strong the "not in my backyard" factor can be during last month's elections.
A group of developers operating under the name South Dakota Disposal Systems Inc. had persuaded the community of Edgemont, S.D., and the South Dakota Board of Minerals and Environment to license development of a 1,200-acre megafill that would take solid wastes from around the state and, by means of the Burlington Northern line that ran by the site, vast amounts of out-of-state waste from sources as far away as New York. Megafills are designed to minimize leakage and other problems associated with older landfills.
But an environmental group based 90 miles away in Rapid City placed an initiative on the ballot requiring that all megafills be approved by the State Legislature.
The megafill's backers and the railroad spent more than $1.5 million opposing the measure, compared with about $25,000 by the environmental group, but lost, getting only 47 percent of the vote. South Dakota Disposal Systems was forced to suspend construction. Opponents have pledged to force a statewide referendum on the issue if the legislature approves the megafill this winter.
"I'm skeptical about the prospects for this business unless we can win some battles like the one in South Dakota," said Barry Vann, Burlington Northern's director of environmental logistics and marketing. He said it was especially discouraging because Edgemont voters once again endorsed the plans in the election only to be outvoted by the rest of the state.
To combat the "Nimby" factor, railroads have begun to argue that long-distance garbage shipments not only make economic sense but also are environmentally preferable. They claim that it is riskier to dump wastes at sea or bury them in states in which populations are denser, water tables higher and rainfall more plentiful.
Kim Marie Kiepke, the Rapid City environmentalist who led the initiative fight, said such claims may be true but are beside the point if the nation needs to work far harder to avoid burying wastes anywhere.
"In return for today's solution, we are getting tomorrow's problem," she said. "We are arguing that to the extent we and the other Northern Plains states provide easy dumping sites, we are undermining recycling efforts everywhere."

HEADLINE: So Many Taxes, So Few Services

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I was depressed to read the article by Stuart Meyers, "A Company Gives Up on New York" (Forum, Nov. 4). But I was even more depressed to read the ad hominem attacks written in response. The question is not whether Mr. Meyers should have purchased insurance. The question is why insurance rates are so high given the amount spent on the criminal justice system. And given the increases in water charges in the last decade, why can't the city provide pipes that don't rupture? Not one writer responded to the real problem: Why can't this city provide services commensurate with the amount spent on services? Unless it does, people will continue to vote with their feet to the detriment of the city, the state and this country.
 
PHIL GOODMAN
New York, Nov. 26

HEADLINE: NEW YORK WEIGHS MORE TENNIS SPACE

BYLINE: By JOSEPH P. FRIED

 BODY:
New York City officials say they will consider leasing additional land in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park to the United States Tennis Association so it can build a bigger and better complex there for the United States Open.
That position heartens those who fear that the tournament might be moved out of the city if the association -- whose current lease on its 17-acre park site expires in 1994 -- cannot have a larger and more efficient National Tennis Center. 
 But it distresses some civic leaders in Queens and parks advocates, who oppose what they term the city's propensity to give up pieces of the three-mile-long park -- the city's largest after Pelham Bay Park in the Bronx and one of its most heavily used -- for commercial ventures or other non-park uses. They are already upset by a city plan to build a seven-acre 40-million-gallon underground sewage tank in the park just several hundred yards from the center.
 
'The Answer Is Yes'
 Mayor David N. Dinkins, an avid tennis player who attended some matches at the Open this year, has expressed concern that the tournament's departure would cost the city's economy more than $100 million a year in what those attending the annual two-week late-summer event spend for hotels, restaurants and other services.
"The question is do we want the United States Tennis Association to say in New York, and the answer is yes," Betsy Gotbaum, the city's Parks and Recreation Commissioner, said recently. "If the condition of their staying is they want some more land, the answer is yes."
Mrs. Gotbaum said in an interview that expansion of the tennis center could take place on land outside the park, just north of the center, but also that it could take place on parkland.
She and other administration officials said talks with the association had just begun and any agreements were a "long way" off. The tennis group has not even indicated yet how much additional space it might need or what the size or design of an expanded center might be, they said.
But Mrs. Gotbaum said that aside from wanting more seats, the associaton wanted to do away with the tight spaces between stands that made it difficult for the crowds to move around.
 
Critics Vow Court Fight
 The current center is at the northern end of the park, just south of the subway yards and Long Island Rail Road tracks, which separate it from Shea Stadium. The center comprises the 20,000-seat Louis Armstrong Stadium; a 6,000-seat adjunct and 25 additional courts, some indoors and some outdoors, which members of the public pay to use when the Open is not taking place.
Mrs. Gotbaum acknowledged potential opposition to allotting more of the park to the Tennis Association, and that the association would have to "mitigate" the loss of parkland. The association might have to buy nearby land that could be added to the park, or to provide community recreational operations within an expanded center.
Critics of granting additional parkland to the Tennis Center vowed to fight any such move in court.
Patricia Dolan, the first vice president of the United Civic Council of Queens, made up of 35 civic groups in the borough, said, "We are absolutely appalled at what the Parks Department is considering doing." She said parkland was a "public trust and not to be looked upon as something to trade."
Benjamin M. Haber, a lawyer and president of the Civic Association of Kew Gardens Hills, an area east of the park, pointed to the role of Sid Davidoff, a politically connected lawyer and lobbyist who represented the race promoters and who is now negotiating on behalf of the Tennis Association. Mr. Davidoff is a tennis partner of Mayor Dinkins and raised a large amount of money for his mayoral campaign.
But a spokeswoman for Mr. Dinkins, Catie Marshall, said Mr. Davidoff's ties with the Mayor "have nothing to do with anything."
"The U.S. Tennis Association brings in enormous revenues to the city," she said, "and for that reason alone we would deal seriously with them, whoever is negotiating."
Mr. Davidoff said he had been retained because "I know the park pretty well; I know Queens, and I know tennis."
He said the Tennis Association's board preferred to keep the Open in New York and that "they want to stay in Flushing Meadows" because of its convenience to major highways, the subway and the Long Island Rail Road. But the association "has indicated it needs an expanded and better facility," he said.

HEADLINE: NO MOVES ON RICE BY JAPAN ARE SEEN

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Dec. 1

 BODY:
Japanese negotiators departed Friday for a crucial round of trade talks in Brussels next week amid signs that they were no more prepared than in the past to ease the nation's ban on rice imports.
While not eager to admit it openly, officials acknowledge that the stalemate between the United States and the European Community over American demands to reduce protection of farm products had eased the pressure on Japan to make concessions. 
 They also said they did not expect the deadlock to be broken in Brussels.
"The E.C. will not make major concessions during the Brussels meeting," said a Japanese official. "Such a deep gulf cannot be bridged in five days."
Japan and the United States have had a series of trade disputes in recent years -- over supercomputers, telecommunications equipment, wood products and other matters -- that have been addressed in talks between the countries. Washington relegated the rice issue to the multilateral talks, being conducted by the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the world body that oversees trade.
 
Pressure on Rice Import Ban
 For years, Japan has been under pressure to ease its ban on rice imports, which it argues is necessary for food security. Instead, Japan proposes reducing some farm subsidies in return for a promise that its own rice market remain completely protected.
The United States has rejected the Japanese position, and Vice President Dan Quayle carried a sharp message to Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu when he attended the enthronement of Emperor Akihito three weeks ago.
Japan is also under pressure to ease barriers on other fronts. Japan has tariffs on dairy products, starches, tomato products and certain types of vegetables, all products over which Tokyo has been slow to make concessions.
The Japanese strategy appears to be to wait until the American dispute with the European Community has been resolved, and then to decide itself whether to make concessions on rice.
 
How Tokyo Is Perceived
 How much of a concession is made is likely to depend on whether Tokyo is perceived as a stumbling block to successful completion of the talks.
Officials here acknowledge that Japan is deeply divided and hampered by weak leadership under Mr. Kaifu, who has a small political base and is viewed by Japanese as less powerful than others behind the scenes.
Rice farmers are a powerful constituency of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party, not simply because 90 percent are part-time farmers employed in other professions, but because rice-growing is a key to the health of fertilizers, chemicals and other agriculture-related industries.
Moreover, the Ministry of Agriculture continues to issue warnings about the possible disastrous consequences of easing the rice import ban. It argues that such a step would throw entire communities into a recession.
 
Another View in Japan
 On the other hand, officials at other powerful ministries, including Finance, Foreign Affairs, and International Trade and Industry, say they recognize that Japan cannot afford to be seen as the stumbling block at the GATT talks.
Japanese officials reason that should GATT fail, there would simply be pressure from the United States on rice.
A broader concern among Japanese officials is that the talks' failure might lead to greater barriers to Japanese exports in Europe and elsewhere. Japan also shares the United States position that GATT is needed to eliminate protection in the developing world of telecommunication, insurance, banking and other services.

HEADLINE: Officials in Cuba Seem to Be on the Defensive

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HAVANA, Nov. 26

 BODY:
Senior Government and Communist Party officials in Havana often begin discussions with foreigners these days on a wry, almost plaintive note, before reverting to their customarily combative defense of their Revolution.
"So, have you too come to say that we are doomed?" one official after another asked of a recent visitor, recounting the increasingly pessimistic assessments made by academics, diplomats and journalists from both friendly and antagonistic countries, of the country's ability to resolve itsgrave economic and social problems while, almost alone in the world, it clings to Communism. 
 "People look at us and say, 'the water is up to your neck,' " said Julio A. Garcia Oliveras, a Central Committee member, of Cuba's sudden loss of most of its traditional economic partners since the fall of Communism in Eastern Europe.
Even as they issue such defiant proclamations, the country's leadership shows increasing signs of anxious searching, as it seeks to both retain popular support and reorganize its economy in a world where international underpinnings for both arequickly dissolving.
As Communist-style rule has lost much appeal in the world, Cuban officials, while clinging to the label, have increasingly sought to emphasize two other central tenets of their ideology: a high-pitched nationalism that celebrates the authenticity of the country's revolution and faithfulfulness to the person of President Fidel Castro.
Revolution and national independence are "insolubly linked," Mr. Castro has said in recent speeches, which have dwelt lengthily on Cuba's identity.
The Cuban leadership, meanwhile, has ceaselessly wielded the threat of a United States invasion to drum up support, loudly amplifying the supposed menace with the United States interventions in Grenada and Panama.
Officials commonly predict that if American soldiers do not fight in the Persian Gulf, a thirst for blood will push President Bush to attack Cuba.
Internally, as it prepares for a crucial fourth congress of the Communist Party to be held sometime early next year, Cuban leadership is seeking to project a more benign image.
In a wide-ranging interview, Cuba's first vice president, Carlos Rafael Rodriguez, a gray-bearded 77-year old, who diplomats say has long been entrusted with Mr. Castro's most sensitive missions, spoke of the "mistake" of Stalinism, confessing that the leadership had committed many errors, including what he called intolerance. The Cuban Communist Party, he said, wasbeing streamlined to ease communication between the leadership and the people.
 
If Lenin Had Lived Longer
 "Our first conclusion is that a revolution, to keep moving forward, must be authentic, not imposed" Mr. Rodriguez said, explaining the fall of Communism in Eastern Europe. "In the Soviet Union, with all of its problems, Socialism is holding up better. I think if Lenin had lived a few more years, we would have a different situation."
"One of the fundamental characteristics of our revolution is the direct link between the leadership, headed by Fidel, and the people," he added. "You really need to go out into the streets with him to see it, to give yourself an idea of the degree of identification between the people and Fidel,"Told that many Cubans had expressed weariness with Mr. Castro's leadership during street conversations with a visitor, Mr. Rodriguez said: "We have the support of 80 or 90 percent of the population. The others are either strongly against us or are equivocal."
Cuban human rights advocates dispute this figure, saying popular support for the Government is closer to 20 percent or less, and falling in the face of growing economic hardship.
"Up until the end with Ceausescu, you could see vast halls of people applauding on cue," said Gustavo Arcos Bergnes, one of Cuba's leading human rights advocates, of the Romanian dictator who was overthrown last year. "These say all sorts of things, but they don't even believe them themselves anymore.

HEADLINE: Can Japanese Import Save an Oyster Industry?

 BODY:
New Jersey environmental officials, hoping to buoy a sinking oyster industry, are considering introducing a new species -- the Japanese oyster -- into the Delaware Bay.
The idea has been proposed by scientists from the state and the Rutgers University Shellfish Research Laboratory in Bivalve, N.J. But it has been strongly opposed by environmentalists and neighboring states, who warn that the species from the Far East could irrevocably alter the bay's ecosystem, as well as those of estuaries all along the Atlantic seaboard. 
 The scientists, however, say the Japanese oyster, or Crassostrea gigas,could prove resistant to two parasites that have mysteriously decimated the native Eastern oyster and the industries it has nurtured in New Jersey since the colonial era.
One parasite, called MSX, has ravaged the Eastern oyster from the Carolinas to New England since it was discovered in 1957. Another, called Dermo, was once confined to the Gulf of Mexico but has recently spread as far north as the Delaware Bay. Neither is a threat to people.
"At some point people will realize they will have to look for alternatives," said Dr. Standish K. Allen, a Rutgers researcher who wants to test whetherthe Japanese oyster can adapt to the Atlantic seaboard. "Almost anything is better than nothing."
But some environmentalists say that introducing the Japanese oyster is short-sighted and that efforts should rather be spent protecting the diminishing populations of Eastern oysters.
"What happens if they introduce them and in five years they succumb to these same diseases and have crowded out native oysters, and we have no oysters left?" said Peter Defur, who studies oysters for the Environmental Defense Fund in Richmond.
In New Jersey, oyster boats landed 7.2 million pounds of oyster meat in1950, but in 1980 they hauled in only 756,546 pounds. For three years, from 1987 to 1989, New Jersey closed the beds altogether.
If introduced, the Japanese oyster would transform the industry. Instead of planting and then harvesting oysters from the sea bottom, oystermen would grow the Japanese oysters on trays.
Robert L. Morgan, owner of the Port Norris Oyster Company, said he is "very much opposed to that." But he acknowledged that the industry is desperate for a solution.
The hearty Japanese oyster, which is abundant along the Far Eastern Pacific Rim, has been introduced in other regions, including the Pacific Northwest. While it has revived some oyster industries, it has also disrupted native populations.
This year, Dr. Allen sought thestate's permission to put several thousand Japanese oysters at seven sites on Delaware Bay to test the species' adaptability to baywaters.
But the test was put off when neighboring states, including Delaware, objected, saying it did not do enough to prevent the oysters from escaping.
 
Unanswered Questions
 "There are all kinds of questions, both ecological and economic, that have not been answered," including whether the Japanese oyster will co-exist with or wipe out the Eastern oyster, said Jack G. Travelstead of the Virginia Marine Resources Commission. In May, the commission refused to approve a similar plan by the Virginia Institute of Marine Sciences at the College of William and Mary.
The Atlantic States Marine FisheriesCommission, an advisory body, refused to endorse New Jersey's experiment and on Nov. 14 recommended that tests on the Japanese oyster be restricted to the laboratory until more is known about its impact on the environment.
"The Catch-22 is that you can't release gigas until you know its ecological impacts, but you can't know its ecological impacts without releasing it into the environment, at least on a scientific basis," Dr. Allen said.
Despite the commission's resolution, which is not legally binding, New Jersey officials said they are still considering Dr. Allen's proposal.
"We're still going to do it eventually," said Bruce A. Halgren, director of the Marine Fisheries Administration. "It's part of our mandate to pursue avenues of potential restoration of the oyster industry."

HEADLINE: Speedometers to Be Used to Raise Subway Speeds

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
A subway rider can go from Bowling Green to Bloomingdale's in about 16 minutes, or nearly half the time the 4.8-mile trip would take in a taxi fighting midday traffic in Manhattan, the New York City Transit Authority boasts in a recent radio commercial.
Riding the subway trains around town should get even faster, transit officials say, under a plan to speed them up by installing speedometers in them, beginning in the spring. By knowing precisely how fast they are going, train operators, or motormen, will be less wary of exceeding subway speed limits, the officials say. 
 "We are not trying to get our drivers to operate unsafely or to drive like bats out of hell," said Termaine Garden, a Transit Authority spokesman, "but we are trying to get them to go closer to the maximum safe speed."
Motormen now rely on instinct and experience to judge how fast they should go, and that usually means they veer toward caution, particularly if they are wary of poor track conditions, transit officials say. A recent survey by the management consultant firm of McKinsey & Company found that 80 percent of subway trains travel at speeds below the safety limit of 50 miles an hour. While the exact speed of the trains varies throughout the route depending on the turns, condition, and grading of the track, most trains travel an average of 40 to 45 miles an hour.
 
'Extremely Cautious'
 For the last 20 years, motormen have been required to go slower because of the poor condition of subway cars and tracks. "The old track and cars posed operating dangers, so we had to be extremely cautious," said Andrew Bata, the Authority's director of rapid transit service planning.
But since the Transit Authority began its $12 billion capital program in 1982, he said, 493 miles of subway track have been replaced, 1,175 new subway cars have been purchased and 4,181 old cars have been overhauled, making it safe to speed up again.
"It's like driving a car," Mr. Bata said. "When you see a road full of dips and potholes, you go slower until the road is repaved."
But some motormen doubt whether speedometers would make any difference in how fast they go, and some are concerned that higher speeds would only add to the stress of their jobs and reduce their control over the trains.
 
Trains Will Be Staggered
 "Speedometers would be great as long as they don't use them to make us go faster and faster," said Louis Aponte, 32, who has been a motorman for four years. "These trains do not stop on a dime, and the motormen who have less experience will probably have difficulty controlling the trains if they are asked to go faster."
Increasing the speed of the trains, even by a small percentage, would mean passengers would arrive at their destinations sooner, if only by a few minutes, transit officials say. But higher speeds would not mean that trains would arrive at a given station more frequently. Rather, trains will be staggered at greater distances from one another, meaning fewer trains and motormen will be needed to meet current timetables. That will save millions of dollars in maintenance and operating costs, the Transit Authority says.
Transit officials estimate that reducing the average time it takes a subway train to complete its run by 5 percent could save the Authority about $15 million a year. Such a reduction in travel time would allow the Authority to eliminate a total of 300 subway cars from the system. Each subway car costs about $50,000 a year to maintain.
Hit hard by a weak regional economy, declining mass-transit subsidies from New York State and shrinking ridership, the transit agency is scrambling to find ways to cut costs to offset a swelling deficit that is estimated at $272 million for fiscal 1991. A report by McKinsey & Company said that the Transit Authority could save about $80 million a year by installing the speedometers, increasing the number of express trains and those that skip every other station, revising speed limits, reducing the time the trains remain in stations, increasing maintenance productivity, and running shorter trains during off-peak hours.
 
'More Work for the Same Pay'
 The agency is considering all those measures. Though running the trains faster will require more electricity, the Transit Authority says the extra cost will be minimal and offset by the other savings.
But most motormen interviewed recently said that the new speedometers would make their jobs more difficult.
Norman Smith, a 30-year-old motorman who operates a No. 2 train on the IRT line, said: "What they are doing is increasing the pressure on us and asking us to do more work for the same pay. It's not easy being locked in that small cab for hour after hour and now they want to drive us even harder."
Harry Slade, 46, who has been a motorman with the Authority for 22 years, said, "We've been doing fine without the speedometers all these years so why do we need them now." And Mr. Slade said, "you always seem to go at just about the right speed -- it comes naturally."
 
'Very Good Judges of Speed'
 Mr. Slade said that instead of spending time and money installing speedometers, the Transit Authority should concentrate on repairing and maintaining the track signals that tell motormen how to proceed.
Louis Brusati, a Transit Authority yard master, who supervises and trains motormen, said that most of the agency's 3,036 motormen were "very good judges of speed" and that installing speedometers on trains would "probably not make a big difference in run times."
But Mr. Brusati said that the speedometers would make the subway system safer because motormen would rely on them when they encounter difficult turns and track grading where they are required to slow down.
To further increase subway efficiency, the Transit Authority is revising the posted safety speed limits in certain parts of the system. For example, since the early 1900's the Authority has required trains to travel at no more than 35 miles an hour when going through an underwater tunnel. "This rule was made so long ago that we don't even know how they came up with 35 as the magic number," Mr. Bata said. "But if we can increase the speed, we eliminate a lot of the delays and congestion we experience on many of our lines where there is only one underwater tube."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Speedometers are being installed in subway trains in a plan to speed them up. Motormen now rely on instinct and experience to judge speed. (Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Japanese See Opportunities In U.S. Sludge

 BODY:
A Japanese conglomerate has made an unusual offer to Monticello, N.Y: give us your sludge and used tires, and we will dispose of them at no cost.
World Envirotech, an American subsidiary of the Kubota Corporation of Japan is hoping that officials from American cities will beat a path to Monticello's sludge in search of technology that the company says can turn even the most toxic sludge and tires into a harmless lava-like material. 
 The disposal of sewage sludge -- the waste product left after sewage treatment -- is becoming a critical question for municipalities around the country, and in particular in the New York area, where a Federal law that takes effect in 1991 will bar the dumping of sludge in the ocean.
And as environmental choices are becoming more difficult and costly here, industry analysts say, Japanese businesses are taking an increasingly aggressive approach to marketing waste treatment technologies in America. The ribbon-cutting of the $5 million plant in the shell of an old incinerator in the Sullivan County village in September, for which waste-treatment experts flew in from around the world, is an example, they say.
"It's a marketing thing for them," said Bob Reimers, a professor of environmental sciences at Tulane University, who is sponsoring a conference on sludge management this winter. "They want to see what the operation costs are like in America. We do the same thing in Japan."
 
Burn, Bury or Purify
 Local governments now have three basic choices for disposing of sludge, which is composed mostly of water with some organic materials and some poisonous heavy metals.
They can burn it, and hope to deal with the more modest problem of how to dispose of the ashes, which are often toxic; they can dump it directly into a landfill, and deal with the problem of finding enough land to fill, or they can purify it and try to find farmers who will want to use it as fertilizer.
Composting -- using sludge as a fertilizer -- is the technique environmentalists prefer. Monticello, like many municipalities, has stored its sewage sludge in a landfill.
The Kubota method, which involves exposing the sludge to very high temperatures, is most similar to incineration. But instead of burning the sludge to produce ashes, it melts it, producing a gritty substance that resembles shards of crushed black glass. The used tires are burned to raise the temperature of the flames in the furnace to about 2,500 degrees Fahrenheit.
 
Six Plants in Japan
 The shards can be used as a substitute for fine aggregate, a material used in road construction, officials say. But the economics of the process -- finding a market for the shards -- poses as big a question as the technology does.
World Envirotech plans to give Monticello the aggregate produced by the plant in its first six or seven years, which the village will use to line pipes, said David A. Greenhut, the vice president of World Envirotech.
The sludge-melting technique that Kubota licensed to World Envirotech was first introduced in Japan in 1975. There are now six Kubota plants in operation in Japan, making the company one of the country's largest waste management companies.
Japan has a head start in many environmental technologies because the island is so densely populated that it was forced long ago to find alternatives to dumping sludge, said Barry Mannis, an environmental services analyst at Morgan Stanley. Those Japanese businesses are expected to find more customers as the costs of dumping in landfills rises around the United States.
The Monticello plant has received all the necessary permits to operate, but construction delays have pushed back an opening date to early next year.
 
'Let's Wait and See'
 The state officials who approved the plant said they thought the technology held great potential, but wanted to wait until they had seen it in operation before calling it the sludge solution.
The Monticello plant will treat 25 tons of sludge a day and give off no smoke or odor, officials say. Even so, that capacity dwarfs the village's sludge treatment needs. The company hopes that one revenue source for the plant would other communities' bringing sludge to Monticello for treatment.
Even though Kobuta officials promise to avoid the pollution risks of incineration, dumping or burying sludge, environmentalists said in interviews that they disapproved of the approach.
Sludge is most useful as a fertilizer, said Sarah Clark, a staff scientist at the Environmental Defense Fund, and any other use for sludge squanders that potential.
Monticello's Mayor, John Diuguid, who is also a lawyer, said the agreement with World Envirotech would allow the town to buy the plant after 10 years at a 10 to 20 percent discount. Also, he said he thought having a state-of-the-art sludge treatment plant would attract developers to Sullivan County.

HEADLINE: Philadelphia Journal;
Amid Sea of Bad News, An Accent on the Good

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 1

 BODY:
With the city now in its fourth month of fiscal and political paralysis and the prospects of insolvency very real, the Convention and Visitors Bureau has begun a campaign to promote civic pride.
But the bright side of things has tough competition. For example, the Christmas tree in front of City Hall did not light up the first time that Mayor W. Wilson Goode dramatically threw the switch this week. And T. Milton Street, assistant budget director of the Traffic Court, publicly refused to pay $2,600 he owed in parking violations and then had a shouting match with a Traffic Court judge and took over her bench and chair for five hours one day last week. 
 In addition, municipal services are slowly deteriorating, with the city running out of no-parking signs and with contractors walking off jobs, leaving block-long streets unpaved.
Although those are the types of occurrences that make Philadelphia Philadelphia these days, the visitors bureau has its sights on more positive events. For instance, two luxury hotels, including a Ritz-Carlton, and scores of accompanying shops, including a jewel box from Tiffany & Company, opened their finely finished doors for business two weeks ago.
These new buildings and shops are some of the stars of a videotape, "Visions of the 90's," being produced by the bureau for distribution to major employers and civic organizations in the Philadelphia region.
"We're doing a Philadelphia Pride campaign, not a glitz piece, but an educational piece, based on bricks and mortar," said Thomas O. Muldoon, the bureau's president.
The show will not sidestep the city's fiscal problems, but will put them in perspective, he said, adding, "We want to create more faith in the city's future, because if there is a question in people's mind about the city's economic viability, it can become a self-fulfilling prophecy."
All of the projects now opening their doors were conceived in the warmer economic climate of the mid- to late-1980's, but business executives say there is still very good money to be made here. "Philadelphia ranks in the top 10 cities in the United States as far as strong demographics for our type of customer," said Brian E. Ohl, a senior vice president at Tiffany's. "Look at all the great things happening in Philadelphia. Look at the new mall. Look at all the new office buildings. Look at all the new stores."
Julien J. Studley, a national real estate consultant who has taken a look at the city, agrees.
"The secret story of Philadelphia is that it has a certain degree of prosperity greater than any other city in the Northeast," said Mr. Studley, president of Julien J. Studley Inc., a New York-based company with offices in Philadelphia and 14 other cities. "It's got a very diversified economy, and it's attractive because nearly everything costs less there."
The brick-and-mortar star of "Visions of the 90's" is Liberty Place, a pair of 61-story office buildings that add an Art Deco flourish to the skyline. Developed by Rouse & Associates and designed by Helmut Jahn, the $700-million project was the first to be allowed to rise above the statue of William Penn atop City Hall. Liberty Place includes an office tower, the 290-room Ritz-Carlton and 80 shops and restaurants off a street-level, glass-enclosed rotunda.
Some co-stars of the videotape are the $26-million Omni Hotel, a 155-room luxury hotel that also opened this month on Independence Mall, a dozen new shops at the renovated Bellevue Hotel and a new terminal at Philadelphia International Airport that is scheduled to open early next year. A convention center, now a six-square-block hole in the ground, is scheduled for completion in 1993, and an associated hotel, a 1,200-room Marriott, is scheduled to open in 1994.
These and other healthy new projects, when packaged into a 15- or 20-minute videotape, could well shore up people's confidence in the city's economy. But whether it will resusitate civic pride remains to be seen.
"It's not that my pride in the city isn't re-invigorated by these new shops and buildings," said Ruth Anne Gage, echoing the comments of several Philadelphians interviewed the other day as they shopped and strolled around the new shops and buildings.
"But these things are happening in spite of what's happening in city government," said Ms. Gage, a 29-year-old retailing executive. "One-hundred and fifty years ago, the city leaders were corrupt and the city was full of patronage. I don't think that has changed very much."

HEADLINE: Bush to Press Trade on South American Trip

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1

 BODY:
President Bush leaves on a weeklong tour of South America on Sunday intended to further his efforts to create a hemispheric free-trade zone and demonstrate interest in a continent long forsaken by United States Presidents.
Administration officials said they did not expect any major agreements to come out of Mr. Bush's trip to Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Uruguay and Venezuela. But they said that along with economic matters a broad range of items would be discussed, including protection of the Amazon jungle, nuclear nonproliferation and the continuing instability in Central America. 
 A senior State Department official said that, in a time when oil-fueled inflation, debts and economic austerity programs threaten to weaken the authority of democratically elected Governments, especially in Chile, Argentina and Brazil, "we want to give these guys a shot in the arm."
 
'You Can't Walk Away From It'
 A second senior official noted that Mr. Bush was the first American President "to look south of Panama" since Richard M. Nixon, and that he would work hard to rekindle relations withArgentina, Brazil and Chile that cooled during years of military rule. "He has the vision that Latin America is too important to let it be poisoned. You can't walk away from it."
Aside from parades and other pageantry designed to spotlight Mr. Bush's excellent rapport with several Latin leaders, the focus of the trip will be on promoting Mr. Bush's Enterprise for the Americas Initiative.
The initiative envisions an eventual free-trade zone from the North Pole to Tierra del Fuego. It calls for negotiations to reduce $7 billion of the region's $12 billion debt to the United States Government, and includes $300 millionin fresh aid to be provided by the United States and other international donors to encourage Latin financial and economic reforms. The program also permits countries, particularly Amazonian nations like Brazil, to make debt interest payments to a fund for environmental-protection projects.
 
Ties Into Brady Plan
 The Enterprise for the Americas Initiative fits neatly with the Brady Plan, an Administration proposal that developing debtor countries sell state-owned industries and cut spending while commercial banks forgive some debts and lower interest payments on others. So far, Costa Rica and Mexico have reached agreements with their creditors under the Brady Plan, and Uruguay and Venezuela expect to complete arrangements soon. Mr. Bush is expected to encourage Presidents Fernando Collor de Mello of Brazil and Carlos Saul Menem of Argentina to press on with their economic reform programs of privatization and cutting deficits so they may work out arrangements under the Brady Plan with their creditors as well.
Latin American leaders pledged in telephone interviews to give Mr. Bush a warn welcome.
"He understands and respects us," said President Luis Alberto Lacalle of Uruguay. "He knows where we are on the map, and we like that."
President Carlos Andres Perez of Venezuela said, "There is no doubt that the Enterprise for the Americas is the most advanced proposal the United States has ever proposed for Latin America. It's a revolutionary, historical reaching out."Such comments underscore the fact that Mr. Bush is the beneficiary of a new Latin American intellectual trend away from anti-United States political ideology and populist economic thinking that fueled growing debts with Government subsidies and bureaucracy in the 1970's and 80's.
Sol M. Linowitz, a former United States representative to the Organization of American States and negotiator of the Panama Canal treaties, predicted that Mr. Bush would receive plenty of abrazos, or embraces, during this trip.
"But behind the abrazos," he said, "there are real concerns. The hard truth is that the practice of democracy in many of these countries is floundering."
