HEADLINE: As Alertness Outlives Vigor, New Kinds of Care for the Old

BYLINE: By TAMAR LEWIN

 BODY:
The morning Peggy Scotch was to leave her daughter's house and move into the two-room suite where she plans to spend the rest of her life, she fumbled the battery from her hearing aid, dropped it on the floor and began to weep.
For the past week, Mrs. Scotch, who is 85, widowed and arthritic, had been determinedly upbeat about her move, declaring herself delighted with the decor and service at the New Jersey retirement complex she had chosen. 
 But the broken hearing aid was the last straw, crystalizing fears she had been trying to suppress. "I was far away from the people who fix my earphone," she said. "I thought I should have my head examined for making this move. I was scared in a way I've never been scared. It was such an unknown quantity, and I didn't know anyone there."
Such moves, and such fears, have become more common as older Americans, unable to manage housekeeping on their own, but not ready for a nursing home, turn increasingly to complexes offering a new way of life to the old and infirm, with private rooms or suites, three restaurant-style meals a day, activities, maid service and access to nursing care for those whose health declines.
 
The Sadder Stage
 While many of these continuing-care communities promote their elegant lobbies and good food, to people like Mrs. Scotch they represent a second, sadder stage of retirement after failing health prevents them from enjoying the active retirement life they chose when they first stopped working.
Mrs. Scotch and her husband, Maurice, who together practiced law in Union Township, N.J., retired 20 years ago to the poolside warmth of Florida. But when her husband died two years ago, Mrs. Scotch's children began pleading with her to move back north. This fall, after a broken leg left her dependent on a walker, Mrs. Scotch gave in to their wishes and decided to move to The Atrium in Allendale.
Also living there is Rose Edelman, who led a lively retirement in Puerto Rico until her husband, Hyman, suffered a stroke and needed nursing care. Mr. Edelman lives in the nursing home part of the complex, while Mrs. Edelman lives in a suite at the other end of the building.
"I haven't come to terms with living like this yet," said Mrs. Edelman, who has Parkinson's disease. "I hope I do. I'm more reconciled than I was, but I still do wake up in the middle of the night wondering what I'm doing here. Yet I can't think of a nicer place to end up. It's right for me now, because I have nowhere else to go, and I can be close to my husband here."
 
 Levels of Care Depend on Health
 The Allendale complex, like most others, offers three levels of care. They are "independent living," where Mrs. Scotch and Mrs. Edelman live, which costs about $2,000 a month for a studio; "assisted living," for those who need help dressing or getting out of bed, which costs $2,400, and the nursing home, for those who become incontinent or demented or, like Mr. Edelman, need rehabilitation from a health crisis, which costs $3,000.
Continuing-care complexes attract the more elderly people; nationwide, the average age of new residents is 79. Most residents are women, most are widowed, and most have never before made a move without their spouses. And like Mrs. Scotch and Mrs. Edelman, most have adult children who worried about their parents' living arrangements, and helped select the new residence.
"After Dad died, it was really hard for us not to be close enough to be of any real help to Mom," said Mrs. Scotch's daughter, Barbara Schreiber, who wearied of traveling to Florida every few months. "So we mentioned, for the 48th time, or was it the 73d, that maybe she should think about moving back north."
Mrs. Schreiber and her brother, who lives in Vermont, left the decision to their mother. But in some cases, admissions directors at the complexes say, children become so upset about their parent's isolation or reclusiveness that they almost bully the parent into moving.
"The hardest transitions tend to be people who believe that families should always live together, that their children have dumped them here and they don't really belong," said Barbara McVeigh, who handles admissions at The Atrium. "Even in the best of circumstances, it usually takes a couple weeks before people begin to feel comfortable. Most of them eventually come to feel that this is the right place for them."
But even those who are happiest to move may have mixed feelings about living so closely with strangers, relinquishing responsibility, however onerous, for running a household and coming to terms with an old age in which they feel diminished by dependency.
"Sometimes I wonder what I'm doing here, surrounded by so many people who are old and sick, but then I remember that I'm not so young and I'm not so well, and I know of no viable alternative," said Mrs. Scotch. "I couldn't market and cook and clean by myself. The only possibility would be having a full-time housekeeper on top of me all day long in an apartment, and that would be very lonely and sad. I don't want to be a burden on my children."
Experts say continuing-care complexes will never attract the majority of older people. In a study by the American Association of Retired Persons, 86 percent of people 55 and over said they wanted to to stay in their own homes in old age. And even most people 85 and over -- a particularly fast-growing segment of the population -- still do live in their own homes, often getting intensive home care to cope with their frailty and health problems.
 
Coming Back North, This Time to Stay
 Mrs. Scotch came north in October to visit her daughter in New City, N.Y., and find a retirement home nearby. There were not many alternatives, since some institutions exclude people with walkers and others have long waiting lists. Mrs. Scotch's daughter and son-in-law had already visited The Atrium, and when Mrs. Scotch saw it, she decided immediately that it was what she wanted.
"It has a beauty parlor, and a bank branch and it is all in very good taste," she said."I decided on the spur of a spur of a moment. I didn't look at the nursing home part, and that was not part of my decision, but I guess in the back of my mind I thought it was a good thing to have there under the same roof."
Still, Mrs. Scotch awoke at 4 A.M. the day she was to move in, and calmed herself by doing crossword puzzles. Her daughter and son-in-law drove her to The Atrium at 10:30. All three were heartened when another resident, carrying a crossword puzzle book, greeted Mrs. Scotch, telling her she was going to love the place.
But the best surprise came a day later, when Mrs. Scotch walked into the dining room and saw Syd Zuckerman, a woman with whom she had been friendly in Florida 15 years earlier, when both still had their husbands. It was a great joy to both, especially since neither had found a soulmate at their assigned dining tables. After a few days, hey were able to arrange to sit together at meals.
"We could talk all day just catching up," said Mrs. Scotch, a tiny woman with the white curls and warm smiles of a storybook grandmother and a thoroughly modern intelligence.
Social contact at meals is a big draw of continuing-care complexes, especially for those with limited mobility. And even complexes where residents have their own kitchens usually require that some meals each day be taken in the communal dining room.
But unwanted social contact can be trying, forcing interaction with those who are slightly senile, overly talkative, querulous or simply incompatible. A tablemate who hums, curses or complains -- or repeatedly appears at the door uninvited -- can become almost unbearable.
"It's like an army barrack or college dormitory, where the constant interaction with people whom you did not select can be like a pressure sore," said Rose Dobrof, executive director of Hunter College's Brookdale Center on Aging. "Because of the constant proximity, some people are afraid to make close friendships, for fear that it won't work out, and they'll be stuck."
That worry has made Mrs. Scotch cautious: "I would love to find another kindred spirit, but I don't want to be impetuous," she said. "I don't want to start a friendship, make a mistake, and not be able to get out gracefully. So I'm trying to make haste slowly."
 
New Friendships In a New World
 Mrs. Scotch said she was looking forward to going on the daily outings but could not do so until her leg healed. But she does go to the word-game session. She singled out a candidate for friendship when there was talk of starting a book group, and she noticed that one of the women from the word games seemed interested.
Among the widows, there is surprisingly little conversation about husbands, a great deal about long-dead parents and even more about children: "Something happens, and all the children have all of a sudden become saints," said Mrs. Edelman, dryly. "I guess that's old age."
Each retirement community is a self-contained world, with some residents who build new friendships, some who rarely leave their rooms, and others who alienate everyone by constant boasting about their past. Most residents leave the premises only for rare visits to a relative's home or group outings to a shopping mall or museum.
Such outings can be a real relief for older people who were almost shut-ins on their own. Mrs. Scotch, for example, never drove, and her husband, who had heart disease, stopped driving two years before his death. Sometimes, she said, friends hesitated to invite her out because of the difficulty of the travel arrangements.
For many older residents, there is great relief in having a call bell in the bathroom, a nurse on the premises, a hot meal in the dining room and a maid. But there is also a bittersweet loss of control over basic daily chores.
"I was a good cook, and I still look at recipes, and then I think, what am I doing, I'm not going to be cooking any more," said Mrs. Scotch.
 
Praying the Money Doesn't Die First
 Rarely discussed, but often present, is a fear of outliving one's money, a fear that is likely to intensify as the industry switches increasingly to pay-as-you-go complexes like The Atrium, and away from nonprofit communities charging a large entry fee to cushion future costs. While all the complexes screen applicants' health and finances, it is unclear what will happen when their projections are wrong and residents live longer, and need more care, than their resources can cover.
At the family-owned Allendale complex, Ms. McVeigh said, the owners have absorbed the costs rather than turning a resident out, in the few cases where the question arose. But directors of most nonprofit complexes express skepticism that in difficult economic times, complexes run by large corporations for profit will make the same decision.
Even for the most affluent elderly, it is hard to adjust to a future less full than the past.
"I used to go walking at night in the first snow, and the stars would come out, and I would say to my husband that it's just like diamonds; I never thought I'd be left a widow," Mrs. Scotch said. "Sometimes you feel as if you're not whole, because you are so dependent on other people. But I'm not in a hovel, I'm not beholden to anybody, and I think I've made the right choice moving here."

HEADLINE: Unemployment Insurance Aiding Fewer

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1

 BODY:
The unemployment insurance system, the main Government program meant to ease the pain of recession, is much less effective than it used to be, largely because the Federal Government and the states have let it wither rather than raise taxes to sustain it.
As a consequence, barely one-third of the jobless are now receiving unemployment checks. Experts say that proportion will not rise much even if the country enters a severe and prolonged recession, a prospect many economists and politicians believe is not beyond possibility. 
At the depth of the recession in 1975, more than three-quarters of the people out of work received unemployment benefits from the Government. In the last recession, in 1982, about half got benefits.
"When this recession hits," said Representative Thomas J. Downey, "unemployment insurance is not going to be the effective tool it could and should be. A lot of innocent people are going to be hurt because of our inaction." Mr. Downey, a Democrat from Long Island, is acting chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee's Human Resources Subcommittee, which has jurisdiction over unemployment compensation.
Sentiment against higher taxes is so strong in Washington and across the country that chances are slim the system will be made more generous. Many states may actually tighten eligibility requirements or lower payments next year if the demand for benefits rises.
That could make economic conditions worse, many economists believe. Providing billions of dollars in additional unemployment payments is one way the Government can put money in people's pockets during bad times, slowing the decline in consumption and hastening a recovery.
 
A Cushion for the Jobless
 The unemployment compensation system was established in 1935 by the same law that created the Social Security system. The theory behind unemployment insurance was the same then as now: to provide a temporary cushion for people out of work and to act countercyclically against the economy by making more money available for consumption when unemployment rates were high.
From the beginning, Social Security was administered nationally and paid for by a Federal tax. The unemployment system, by contrast, was delegated to the states, which, within broad Federal guidelines, were given the right to set their own eligibility and benefit standards and to set the level of the tax they imposed on businesses to raise the money.
As the law stands now, all states must require employers to impose a tax of at least eight-tenths of 1 percent on each employee's first $7,000 of pay. But beyond that, the states are free to go in different directions.
Most states base the tax rate on each business's record of laying off workers. Employers that lay off a large percentage of workers and, thus, have many claiming benefits pay a higher tax, and those whose employees make few claims pay the minimum. In three states, Kentucky, Tennessee and Michigan, the rate can be as high as 4.6 percent for employers with the worst records of layoffs. In New York, no employer pays more than 1 percent.
In 36 states, but not New York, the wage base on which the tax is paid is higher than $7,000. The average nationally is about $8,500. But a few go much higher, up to $21,300 in Alaska.
 
Worker Benefits Vary
 How much and how long workers are paid also vary considerably. Most states tie benefits to the amount of wages last earned and the length of time worked for the last employer. Longtime employees can generally get 26 weeks of benefits. In 1989, the average weekly payment was $152; the maximum was $408, in Massachusetts.
But the size of the benefits is not what concerns the critics. As a rule, benefit levels have kept up with inflation over the years, averaging about 35 percent of what workers were earning at their last jobs. What the critics find worrisome is that with each passing year, fewer workers are eligible for any benefits.
That has occurred for two main reasons, said Wayne Vroman, an economist at the Urban Institute, a private research center in Washington. Mr. Vroman, who is working on a study for the Labor Department, has done more analyses of this subject recently than any other economist.
First, he said, most states have tightened eligibility requirements in recent years, requiring workers, for example, to work longer and earn more before they qualify and generally denying benefits altogether to those who were not laid off but quit their jobs voluntarily.
The states did this mostly to avoid raising the taxes they charge employers. Businesses argue, and many politicians agree, that a lower unemployment insurance tax improves the business climate of a state and makes it more attractive to companies that might wish to come there.
 
Changes in Work Force
 The second main reason for the decline in eligibility is that the nature of the work force has changed markedly in the last two decades. Fewer people are in manufacturing jobs, and many more are in services. Service industry employees tend to earn less and change jobs more frequently. Many, especially women, have taken time off from steady work or are part-timers who have not worked enough hours or earned enough pay to qualify under the more stringent rules.
In addition, service workers are less likely to be unionized, and that has made employers bolder in challenging claims in an effort to keep their layoff record cleaner.
"It is almost unheard of for General Motors or Ford to file a challenge, but the fast-food chains do it all the time," said Walter S. Corson, an economist at Mathematica Policy Research, who has also studied the system's shortcomings for the Labor Department.
During recessions, the proportion of the unemployed entitled to benefits tends to be higher than it is during good times. But Mr. Vroman has found in his studies that even if the unemployment rate, 5.7 percent last month, rose as high as 9 percent, indicating a serious recession indeed, only 36 percent to 38 percent of those out of work would be eligible for unemployment checks.
 
Situation May Worsen
 The budget rules that Congress approved last month could worsen the situation. In past recessions, laws were enacted that extended the duration of unemployment benefits from 26 weeks to 52 weeks, with the Federal Government picking up most of the additional cost. The new budget rules require any increase in benefits to be accompanied by a spending cut or a rise in taxes that balances out the cost of the benefits. Those are steps President Bush and Congress are not likely to take.
Michael J. Boskin, chairman of Mr. Bush's Council of Economic Advisers, said in an interview that the Administration had no plans to extend unemployment payments, although he said he could not completely rule it out if a deep recession developed.
In each of the last two years, when the unemployment rate was low, Representative Downey proposed legislation that would raise the minimum wage base to $10,000 nationally from $7,000. He argued that when the economy was healthy, states should beef up their benefit funds, which in many cases are in shaky financial condition. But he faced solid opposition from Republicans and Southern Democrats and never had the votes to get his bill out of the Ways and Means Committee.
Opponents contended that higher taxes hurt business and that better benefits merely encouraged people to remain unemployed.
Mr. Downey said he intended to offer his bill again next year, but he said he had no confidence it would be enacted.
"It's a classic economic march of folly," Mr. Downey said. "We knew what was wrong going into this recession, but now we're going to be completely unprepared."

HEADLINE: CALIFORNIA PANEL BACKS PAY RAISES

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Dec. 1

 BODY:
A citizens' commission rejected protests on Friday and unanimously approved a 40 percent increase in the governor's salary, to $120,000 annually, as well as a rise in state lawmakers' base pay to $52,500.
The panel, the California Citizen's Compensation Commission, was created in an initiative approved by the voters on June 5. The initiative, a political ethics measure, also banned the acceptence of speaking fees.
The commission's decision is final and is not subject to approval by the Legislature or the Governor, but the panel is required to conduct regular reviews of lawmakers' pay.
The new salaries take effect Monday. The commission had tentatively approved the proposal earlier this year.
Besides the governor, those scheduled to receive pay increases are the lieutenant governor, attorney general, secretary of state, treasurer, controller and the 120 members of the Assembly and Senate.
 
Protests From Public
 Friday's ratification of the measure was accompanied by boos, hisses and shrieks of protest from taxpayers who jammed the chamber and urged the commission to cut or eliminate elected officials' raises.
More than 200 people attended the meeting, most of them criticizing the new salaries. The critics contended that a worsening economy and state budget problems, including a potential $4.3 billion shortage over two years, required pay cuts, not increases.
There was some support for the pay scale, from lobbyists, a former legislative fiscal adviser and the citizens' group Common Cause, among others, who said elected officials' pay should be commensurate with their responsilities.
 
Governor's Pension Increased
 The measure provides a $21,000 raise -- from $50,000 a year to $71,000 -- in the pension of Gov. George Deukmejian, who is retiring after two terms and will leave office by Jan. 7. The legislative leaders of both houses, including the Assembly Speaker, Willie Brown, and Senate President Pro Tem David Roberti, will get raises to $63,000 a year from $40,816.
Claude Brinegar, a vice president of the Union Oil Company who is the commission's chairman, said the salary levels were decided regardless of the "popularity or unpopularity of the current incumbents." The goal of the commission, he said, was to "set salaries to attract a good range of candidates."
But opponents described the Legislature -- and the commission -- as corrupt and angrily denounced the revised salary schedule.
"How can you give elected officials a $3,000-a-month raise and $1,000 raise for legislators" while asking welfare recipients "to do without a $17 a month cost-of-living adjustment?" asked Harvey Rosenfield, the head of Voter Revolt.
The commission's decision culminated a three-month survey of salary levels of comparable jobs in other states and pay in private industry.

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
Bush's Overture to Iraq Is Welcomed by Both Egypt and the P.L.O.

BYLINE: By By ALAN COWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAIRO, Dec. 1

 BODY:
From divergent perspectives within the Arab world, both Egypt and the Palestine Liberation Organization today welcomed the Bush Administration's overture toward Iraq, casting it as a chance to obtain peace.
President Bush's offer of talks with Iraq in Baghdad and Washington sent tremors through the region's diplomacy as the Arab world contemplated an outcome of the crisis short of a war that Arab leaders say publicly they do not want. 
 The foreign ministers of Egypt, Syria and Saudi Arabia, anti-Iraqis who were supposed to meet here today to discuss the Persian Gulf crisis, postponed the encounter until Monday. And Libya, which earlier this week said it had lost interest in the crisis, sent an envoy to Syria to discuss the issue.
The Saudi Press Agency said that President Bush telephoned King Fahd and the exiled Kuwaiti leader, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, on Friday night and that President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt also called the Saudi ruler. Western diplomats here said the American invitation to Iraq was not discussed in detail when President Bush visited Saudi Arabia and Egypt last month.
 
'A Last Chance'
 Egypt, America's leading Arab ally, has sent forces to join the United States-led military buildup in Saudi Arabia, as has Syria, offering the force an Arab profile supposed to legitimize it in regional politics.
President Bush's invitation "represents a last chance to resolve the crisis through peaceful means, as Egyptian diplomacy has sought to do since the start," Deputy Foreign Minister Butros Ghali said in Cairo.
At the Tunis headquarters of the Palestine Liberation Organization, the welcome was shaded with concerns that the Palestinian issue be placed on the agenda of United States-Iraqi contacts, as Baghdad insists it should.
"The U.S. President's decision is a step in the right direction," said Yasir Abed Rabbo, a P.L.O. spokesman. "We hope the agenda will include all regional issues, including rapid holding of an international peace conference and international protection for our people under occupation."
"This could be a turning point in the history of the region and could also be the step which precedes war," he said. "That depends on how the U.S. side responds to a comprehensive solution for all regional crises."
While Egypt has led Arab support of American diplomacy in the region, the Palestine Liberation Organization has tilted openly toward Iraq, seeing President Saddam Hussein as its newest champion.
In Taif, Saudi Arabia, where Kuwait maintains a government-in-exile, a Kuwaiti spokesman said Sheik Jaber held "identical" views with President Bush on the crisis.
But Western and Arab diplomats here said the exiled Kuwaitis could come to view the contact between Washington and Baghdad with some trepidation because their position as the only players without control of their own country was inherently vulnerable.
Both the United States and its Arab allies insist on Iraq's unconditional withdrawal from Kuwait and the restoration of what they call its "legitimate" government.
 
Saudis Cancel Egyptian Debt
 Saudi Arabia sought to cement the anti-Iraq alliance further today with a formal announcement that it had canceled Egypt's debt, estimated by Western economists at $4 billion.
The United States has canceled an Egyptian military debt of $7 billion and other gulf nations have forgiven debts of about $3 billion in return for Egypt's commitment of 15,000 soldiers to the multinational force.

HEADLINE: Help for Salvadorans, With a Catch

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 1

 BODY:
For those daring enough to grasp it, the United States is offering a hand of welcome, though an ambiguous one, to hundreds of thousands of illegal immigrants from El Salvador.
The broad immigration law signed Thursday by President Bush offers among its provisions an 18-month "safe haven" to Salvadorans who have illegally entered the United States. But to qualify for safety, they must make their presence known to the Government, and at the end of the 18 months they return to their former status, illegal alien.
Those who register by July will win the right to live and work in the United States, with all the benefits of legal residents. But after 18 months, with their names and addresses in the hands of the authorities, they become subject to possible deportation.
The safe-haven provision represents a victory for immigrants' rights advocates, who have sought protection for El Salvadorans fleeing the military and political strife in their country, said Guillermo Rodenzo, executive director of El Rescate, a private legal and social services group in Los Angeles. But he said, "It is not clear whether the implementation of the legislation will have a negative or positive impact on the Salvadoran community."
 
Confronting a Quandary
 The law presents groups like his with a quandary. "We'd like to say: 'This is great. Do register and don't worry,' " Mr. Rodenzo said. "But we just can't do that because we don't think it is that wonderful."
But Frank Sherry, an immigration advocate in Washington, said, "The fear that people live with on a daily basis is so overwhelming and debilitating that the opportunity to live free and work safely for 18 months or more is a benefit that may be worth the risk."
Duke Austin, a spokesman for the Immigration and Naturalization Service in Washington, noted that the safe-haven provision was intended only to meet what was seen as an immediate need, a humanitarian gesture to provide a respite for people fleeing war.
"There has never been anything said about granting them permanent residence," he said.
Indeed, the provision includes language making it difficult for a person who accepts safe-haven status to apply to stay permanently.
A paradox at the heart of the provision is that the United States is offering a haven for refugees fleeing a Government and a military that Washington supports and helps to finance.
The safe-haven provision is one of several innovations in the immigration law, which also raises quotas for highly skilled immigrants, enlarges the number of Europeans and Africans to be admitted, and ends certain barriers, including those blocking Communists, homosexuals and people with AIDS.
 
Rule Could Be Extended
 The attorney general is empowered to extend the safe haven longer than 18 months, or allow it to lapse. If the time is extended, it is unclear whether immigrants who had chosen to remain underground could then apply.
One of the El Salvadoran immigrants who now faces the decision is Andres Candido, a 51-year-old farmer who said he fled El Salvador two years ago to escape retribution for anti-government activities.
He has turned for counsel to Madeline Janis, executive director of the Central American Refugee Center in Los Angeles. At seminars for El Salvadoran immigrants, her group is urging them to think before registering.
"The military killed some of my brothers because they were with me in a cooperative," Mr. Candido said. "My family and I spent eight years in hiding, moving from place to place, and we were running out of places to hide."
In America, he said, he has found political freedom but economic hardship. Apart from six months' work as a security guard, Mr. Candido has been unemployed and needs relatives' help to support his wife and two daughters.
 
After 18 Months, What?
 "We all want work permits," he said of his fellow immigrants, "but we would like to know what the Government is going to do after 18 months. If they are going to deport us, then maybe it is better for us to remain as we are and not turn ourselves in."
But he added, "I think there are people who will apply out of desperation."
Ms. Janis said 400,000 to 500,000 El Salvadoran immigrants live in Los Angeles, most of them without legal status. They represent perhaps half of all Salvadorans in the United States.
The Salvadorans are only part of a huge wave of Mexican and Central American immigrants who have entered the country illegally in recent years, but they have been singled out for safe haven because of the fighting in their country.
"There are people who are fleeing the general conditions and are in danger of the general violence, and there are people who are a little more active in politics and perhaps labor issues," said Nils Frenzen, a lawyer with a private legal assistance group, Public Counsel, adding, "Everyone in El Salvador is in some degree of danger."
Nevertheless, the United States rejects all but about 2 percent of El Salvadoran applications for political asylum, say immigrant-rights advocates.
 
An Underground Society
 The result is a large underground society here of people who share low-cost housing and work illegally at low-paying jobs, with little prospect of achieving legal residence.
"I think many will participate simply because it will allow them for 18 months and perhaps longer to leave their house every day without having to look both ways for the immigration agent," said Mr. Sherry, executive director of the National Immigration, Refugee and Citizenship Forum, a coalition of groups in Washington.
"It will allow them to stand up to their boss who has been refusing to pay overtime or making them work in poor conditions, to stand up to the landlord who used to threaten to turn them in while gouging them with the rent, to go to their child's school and talk to the teachers without the fear of being reported," he said.
Dr. Rodenzo at El Rescate, a physician who fled the war in El Salvador in 1980, said that for people who live with hardship, immediate needs can outweight longterm risks.
"Life has been very hard for them and people think, 'What do I do right now in order to survive?' " he said. "The consequences of 18 months are very far away."

Mr. Candido said he fled El Savador two years ago to escape retribution from the military. (Bart Bartholomew for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Stirrings of Hope in Redeeming Chesapeake Bay

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 28

 BODY:
After a decade-long struggle against pollution and overfishing in the Chesapeake Bay and its tributaries, environmentalists and government officials say they are seeing the first signs of progress. But they warn that unless new steps are taken, including far-reaching controls on development and the pollution it produces, the fight could be lost.
The progress is scattered -- a clear stream here, a new bed of clams there, a sewage pipe through which nothing now flows. Like canaries in a mineshaft, "the fish and the shellfish and the bottom grasses are sending out a few good signals," said Ann P. Swanson, executive director of the Chesapeake Bay Commission, a multistate panel that monitors the effort to save the 200-mile-long estuary.
"But we're still a long way from winning the battle," she went on, "and we could still lose it if we don't do even more, especially in controlling and guiding future growth."
 
Action in Maryland
 Once one of the world's richest sources of seafood, and still a playground for the mid-Atlantic region, Chesapeake Bay is deeply scarred by decades of pollution. Though environmental laws have blocked many sources of pollution, experts say unchecked growth could undo much of that progress. The populations in many metropolitan regions in the bay have increased by as much as 50 percent over the last quarter century.
One crucial state, Maryland, is pressing to control growth. It has established a 1,000-foot zone along its bay shore in which development, particularly housing subdivisions, is severely restricted. And this week, a state study commission recommended that the Legislature pass laws restricting growth around the bay mainly to areas already built up.
The commission said too many farms and forests had been bulldozed to create sprawling subdivisions, with the uncovered raw soil often eroding into nearby streams that lead to the bay. The commission said such erosion had produced much of the silt that is choking parts of the bay, and added that runoff from new roads and the newly fertilized lawns of subdivisions had further polluted the bay.
The commission's proposal to stop suburban sprawl set off a debate among planners, developers and Marylanders who still cling to the American dream of a home on a spacious lot. But commission members said land use was growing twice as fast as population. "Everyone is going to have to modify, to some extent, their style of living," said Walter A. Frey 3d, a business executive on the panel.
The progress up to now has been accomplished mainly through widespread construction of modern sewage plants and the regulation of waste flowing into the 150 rivers and streams that feed the bay. There has been a major reduction of fertilizer runoff from the farms in the bay watershed, especially those concentrated along the banks of the Susquehanna River in Pennsylvania. And restrictions have been placed on seafood that can be taken from the bay, on the amount of wetlands that can be destroyed or disturbed and on the use of pesticides.
The move to control growth represents a new direction in the effort to save the bay. It could involve people who live miles away from the shores of the estuary whose immense drainage basin stretches from Cooperstown, N.Y., to Lynchburg, Va.
"It's the next logical step, but it's also a tricky approach because you have to find some way to protect the economic interests of those in rural areas whose land can no longer be developed," said W. Tayloe Murphy Jr., a Virginia lawmaker who serves on the Chesapeake Bay Commission.
 
Life on the Bottom Again
 One of the most striking signs of progress in the fight to save the Chesapeake can be found on the bay's bottom. Some sections that pollution had denuded of almost all life are now lush with underwater grass, a critical part of the bay's life chain that provides food for some of the bays creatures and also helps cleanse and rejuvenate its waters.
Elsewhere, signs of progress include summer swimmers in the Potomac River, a major tributary that was dangerously toxic before the imposition of strict pollution controls, including the construction of some of the most modern sewage treatment plants anywhere.
On the bottom of Baltimore harbor, once considered dead because of all the industrial pollution that had been poured into it over the years, there are newfound beds of clams and the stirrings of mud worms.
All across the bay's watershed, the amount of phosphorus flowing into streams and the bay has been sharply reduced in the last decade, as much as 50 percent, by new sewage treatment methods, the elimination of phosphates from household detergents and the imposition of erosion controls. Phosphorus is one of the nutrients on which choking rafts of algae feed, keeping sunlight from reaching the bay's life-giving grasses and depleting life-supporting oxygen.
Striped bass, shad, ospreys, peregrine falcons and bald eagles are beginning to make a comeback, as is the Chesapeake oyster, once the bay's greatest seafood resource, along with the blue crab.
Among these varied creatures of land and sea, only the crab has been able, year in and year out, to hold its own against pollution, pesticides, disease, waterside condominiums, overfishing and serendipitous Mother Nature. But this year enough striped bass, called rockfish by many residents of the bay area, showed up to permit a fishing season, the first in the better part of a decade.
Environmentalists credit newly clean spawning areas and closed seasons for the resurgence of the fish. Still, after just a few days, the 1990 season had to be ended, so intense was the angling.
"That was a sign of just how fragile our progress is in cleaning up the Chesapeake," said William C. Baker, the president of the Chesapeake Bay Foundation, a citizens' group that monitors the bay's quality and promotes its conservation.
"We're still a long way from the days when we could pull in millions of pounds of rock and shad," he said. "In fact, we may never get back to that or to the kind of bay that Captain John Smith found in the early 1600's when he said there were so many fish he could catch them with the frying pan. Our realistic hope is that we can return to a bay in which species aren't endangered and pollution and human pressure are managable."
The continued fragility of the bay is especially evident in the amount of bottom grasses. While new grasses are beginning to spring up in some places, three-fourths of the areas where grass was once plentiful remain bare.
 
Few Simple Answers
 While oysters appear to be making a comeback this year after several exceptionally barren years, the catch is drastically down from the past -- only a tenth of what it was at the turn of the century. That sharp reduction is attributed not just to pollution and over-harvesting but largely to naturally occurring, cyclical diseases.
"In figuring out what is happening in the bay and who and what is to blame, there are seldom many simple answers," Mr. Baker said. "For instance, while pollution causes serious oxygen depletion in the bay's waters, we also know that such depletion occurs naturally."
He also pointed out that just when pollution experts thought they had figured out how to handle the problem of phosphorous and nitrogen entering the bay from waste and fertilizer runoff they discovered that acid rain was also bringing nitrogen in the bay. That discovery helped lead to the new growth approach for saving the bay.
"In this fight," Mr. Baker said, "knowledge is often progress."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Waterman tonging for oysters at Kent Narrows, Md. Once one of the richest sources of seafood in the world, Chesapeake Bay is deeply scarred by decades of pollution. In a effort to reverse the damage, Maryland has severely restricted development within 1,000 feet of the bay shore. (Marty Katz for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
U.S. Rebuffs Iraq on Palestinian Talks

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1

 BODY:
Neither President Bush nor Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d responded publicly today to Iraq's acceptance of Mr. Bush's offer of talks on the gulf crisis.
But Administration officials rebuffed the Iraqi government's suggestion that any direct talks between Iraq and the United States on Kuwait should deal with the issue of a Palestinian homeland. 
 In its statement, Iraq welcomed the chance for the two countries to have "a serious and deep dialogue," but did not make its acceptance of Mr. Bush's offer conditional on discussion of the Palestinian issue. But the statement also said that "Palestine and the other occupied Arab territories will remain before our eyes and at the forefront of the issues that we will discuss in any dialogue."
In making his offer, Mr. Bush said that Mr. Baker would be willing "to discuss all aspects of the gulf crisis" on his visit to Baghdad.
"Palestine is not an issue on the table," Vice President Quayle said on Cable News Network today. "There is no linkage."
 
Hussein Linked the Issues
 Roman Popadiuk, a White House spokesman, seconded Mr. Quayle when he said, "Our position all along is that there is no linkage of the Gulf crisis to other issues, including the Middle East."
President Saddam Hussein of Iraq has said many times that he will leave Kuwait only if the Israelis leave the West Bank and the Gaza Strip, captured in the 1967 Arab-Israeli war.
While the President and his advisers have publicly refused to link the fates of Kuwait and Palestine, what appeared to be a carrot on linkage was inserted into a speech Mr. Bush gave at the United Nations on Oct. 1, when the President suggested that diplomatic opportunities would exist in the Middle East after Iraq made an unconditional withdrawal from Kuwait.
The President met today at Camp David with his top advisers, including the Joint Chiefs of Staff and their chairman, Gen. Colin Powell; the national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft; Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney and Mr. Baker. The group reviewed military options in the gulf even as they waited for an official response to the President's offer to send Mr. Baker to Baghdad to hold direct talks on Kuwait with Mr. Hussein.
 
Seen as a Last Resort
 The offer, which Mr. Bush first made during a White House address and news conference on Friday, was conveyed formally today by Joseph Wilson, deputy chief of mission in Baghdad, to Nizar Hamdoon, an Iraqi Deputy Foreign Minister. It is seen as a last resort for a peaceful solution, since a resolution adopted by the United Nations Security Council on Thursday gives Iraq until Jan. 15 to pull out of Kuwait or face possible military action.
Because the invitation was delivered late in the day in Baghdad, no formal response was expected until Sunday. But the 10-man Revolutionary Command Council chaired by President Hussein did issue a statement to the press, in response to Mr. Bush's press conference, saying that it would accept the offer from "the arrogant" Mr. Bush for an emergency meeting in Baghdad, as well as an invitation for the Iraqi Foreign Minister, Tariq Aziz, to meet with Mr. Bush in Washington.
Mr. Quayle said today that the point of the direct talks is not to negotiate, but to persuade Mr. Hussein that this is his last chance to comply with the United Nations resolution before force is used. Mr. Bush said on Friday that Mr. Baker was not making "a trip of concession" but that he would be willing "to discuss all aspects of the gulf crisis." Middle East experts say it is inevitable that trade-offs would be broached -- by the Iraqis if not by the United States.
In the C.N.N. interview, Vice President Quayle was asked why the President had changed from the patient approach of economic sanctions to the aggressive approach of a military deadline.
"Okay," Mr. Quayle replied. "Patience means, in essence, that we're not going to do anything for 18 months. Well, what about the hostages in Iraq? Are we prepared to let them stay there for another 18 months?"
At the beginning of his Administration, Mr. Bush promised that he would never personalize American hostages held in the Middle East, because it would likely increase their value as objects of ransom. But he and his top advisers have consistently tried to personalize the fate of the hostages in Iraq recently as a way of building up American support for possible military action.
 
Relieved Reactions
 The President's offer to "go the extra mile for peace," an effort to persuade a skeptical American public that he is not rushing into an unpopular war, has once more quelled the rising voices for a special session of Congress to debate the Administration's policy.
It triggered a wave of relieved reactions this weekend from Congress, allies and from the Arab world.
William Broomfield, a Republican lawmaker from Michigan who is the senior Republican on the House Foreign Affairs Committee, said that the proposed diplomatic talks would offer "wiggle room" for Mr. Hussein to save face. "Anything the President can do to keep the focus of the crisis on diplomacy and not on war is all to the good," Mr. Broomfield said.
State Department officials said that they had received calls from the Ambassadors of Egypt, Kuwait, Saudi Arabia and other key Arab states saying they were pleased and relieved about Mr. Bush's approach.
 
Kissinger Dissents
 One of the few voices of dissent was Henry Kissinger, the former Secretary of State who said on ABC-TV's "Nightline" on Friday that the President's action filled him with "foreboding."
"I feel extremely lonely," Mr. Kissinger said. "I have not been this worried in decades."
Mr. Kissinger argued that "the arrival of an American Secretary of State in a country that is holding a thousand hostages, a country that has been compared to Nazi Germany and been threatened with war crimes trials" would create an atmosphere that would favor Mr. Hussein.
He suggested that the military option and the United States bargaining position would erode if Mr. Hussein was allowed to narrow the issue so that he would leave Kuwait and take only two disputed islands and some northern oil fields.

HEADLINE: A Weak Case for War in the Gulf

 BODY:
In bits and sound bites, interviews and briefings, the Bush Administration has finally explained why it abruptly shifted three weeks ago from Desert Shield to Desert Sword. Until then, the purpose of the troops in Saudi Arabia was defensive. Now officials are starting to make the case for changing to the possibility of offense. The case they present is unpersuasive.
The Security Council has now authorized force to evict Iraq from Kuwait, but many nations do not share Mr. Bush's enthusiasm for an early showdown. Few are willing to commit their own troops in force. 
 Far more important, growing numbers of Americans question the President's haste. At Senate hearings last week, some of the country's most knowledgeable strategic authorities challenged the Administration's policies.
Here are some of the most frequent Administration arguments, and some reasons why they seem inadequate.
The coalition won't survive much delay. Tensions between Arab states and Israel could erupt at any time, the argument goes, and conservative Arab states may be destabilized by the long-term garrisoning of U.S. troops.
These are legitimate concerns. But so far, the glue of self-interest has held fast, even during the crisis over Temple Mount. War, with its likely high toll of Arab civilian casualties, would test allied unity far more severely than patient pressure. And King Fahd made plain last week that he considered the foreign military forces supporting Saudi Arabia "a blessing from God."
Time is on Saddam Hussein's side. The U.S. deployment is set to peak early next year. From then on, morale and logistics problems will mount. After February, summer heat will start returning to the Saudi desert. Meanwhile, every day Iraqi forces are entrenching their positions, and dismantling Kuwait.
True enough. But the logistical and morale problems are self-inflicted, and would be eased by a return to the smaller scale of Desert Shield. Experts doubt that a war begun after Jan. 15 could be concluded before the onset of hotter weather. And a calendar-driven timetable could bias tactics toward massive air strikes, producing horrific civilian casualties but still requiring ground combat later.
What's more, the Administration argument ignores the sapping of Iraq's fighting strength through the cumulative impact of sanctions.
Iraq's abuse of hostages is intolerable. Saddam Hussein has manipulated the hostage and embassy issue, and President Bush's gut feelings are real. But Mr. Bush sensibly proclaimed at the start of the Kuwait crisis that concern for the hostages could not be allowed to overturn sound policy judgments. That's still the wisest position.
Iraq must be stopped from going nuclear. Four months ago, the Bush Administration insisted that Iraq's nuclear program posed no imminent danger. But in an ex poll facto judgment, after surveys showed Americans viewing a nuclear threat as the only plausible reason for war, the White House has been sounding nuclear alarms. Expert opinion still holds that Iraq is years away from a deliverable nuclear weapon. And diplomacy, not military pre-emption, remains the most effective response to potential nuclear threats.
High oil prices will wreck the world economy. The embargo against Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil will shave one or two percentage points off world growth rates in the short term. But as former Energy Secretary James Schlesinger noted at Senate hearings last week, most of this price has already been paid. The world oil market, Mr. Schlesinger reported, "has now been brought into balance . . . without Iraqi and Kuwaiti crude."
America, as President Bush noted Friday, has vital interests at stake in the gulf. Chief among these are preventing a single dictator from gaining decisive control over world oil supplies, and assuring that naked aggression reaps no rewards. Both of these interests are fully served by the original operation Desert Shield. Iraq has been deterred from moving against Saudi Arabia, and suffers economic punishment rather than reward for grabbing Kuwaiti oil fields.
With vital interests on the line, fighting may eventually become necessary. In that case, heavy costs will have to be borne, and Americans will bear them. But honest and informed citizens remain skeptical that that threshold has yet been crossed, or even approached.

HEADLINE: Bush Has Made the Right Moves, So Far

BYLINE: By Caspar W. Weinberger; Caspar W. Weinberger was Ronald Reagan's Secretary of Defense.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
I believe President Bush is doing what has to be done in the Persian Gulf and is doing it very well. That was clearly the majority view of the nation immediately after Saddam Hussein's conquest of Kuwait, but since then there has been disarray and confusion.
In sending James Baker to Baghdad and inviting Iraq's Foreign Minister to Washington, Mr. Bush has struck the right note. It is well that he warned Mr. Hussein not to misread our motives. The trips must not be viewed as involving standard negotiations in which both sides give a little to achieve an agreement. The only peace acceptable is a peace under which Mr. Hussein gives up what he has stolen, makes reparations for his theft and is left without the ability to steal again. 
 Before Mr. Bush's announcement, he had encountered increasing opposition and questions, claims that our goals are not clear, contentions that Kuwait and Saudi Arabia are not worthy of being defended, and cries for a negotiated peace. There have even been demonstrations by a few moth-eaten relics of the Vietnam peace movement, which despite their small size have been given undue prominence on TV news.
There are Americans who not only support our being in the gulf but want us to attack immediately. There are still others who think the embargo will not work but content themselves with saying that and with professing "profound pessimism" or some equally helpful analysis.
There really is and should be no confusion about why Mr. Bush sent the troops to the gulf. We are there to prevent a particularly brutal aggression that, if successful, would have badly crippled a large part of the world and left us subject to continual blackmail by one of the world's most miserable leaders. President Bush's Thanksgiving speech to our troops in Saudi Arabia made that crystal clear.
That we have not always acted with such dispatch and effectiveness every time some aggression has occurred is beside the point, and hardly an argument for not trying to establish the rule of law globally now.
To say we are in the gulf only because of oil is to trivialize the great role we are playing. Of course oil is important to our civilization -- just how important we'd easily know if Saddam Hussein had been allowed to carry out his plan to march through Saudi Arabia and take the United Arab Emirates, thereby securing control of at least 70 percent of the world's known oil reserves.
The troops know why they are in the gulf even if many opponents profess to be "unclear" and "puzzled." The troops appreciate that aggressors cannot be allowed to keep what they steal. By protecting the world from continual blackmail and relieving it of the incalculable cost of clawing Mr. Hussein out of Saudi Arabia and the emirates, we achieve complementary goals: preventing aggression from succeeding and from undermining the quality of life Americans and millions of others enjoy.
As for the specious argument that we should not oppose Iraqi aggression because Kuwait and Saudi Arabia are not as pure as some would like, let's remember when we heard a similar argument: "We should not support the Shah of Iran because his Government has done repressive things." But that overlooked the alternative: the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeni. So, are we going to let Mr. Hussein keep Kuwait because Kuwait is not everything its critic want?
What is this negotiated peace so many want? Some advocates tip their hands when they talk of Iraq's "historical claims" to Kuwait. But no one can contend that Kuwait invaded Iraq. If some country's claims on another justify a brutal invasion, freedom and the rule of law are dead. What kind of negotiated settlement can we reach with a mass murderer who suppressed Iraqi Kurds seeking some small measure of freedom? What would be the terms of such a compromise or negotiations?
Would we let him keep half of Kuwait? Or "to save Saddam's face," which seems to be the goal of some who talk compromise, would we let him retire gracefully from Kuwait, welcome his generosity, express gratitude for the return of hostages -- and watch him repeat the whole murderous scenario when he chooses?
None of this is to say that we should commit our forces to combat now. I believe the economic sanctions, enforced by a tight air and sea blockade and supported by some 21 other countries, including every major Arab country, is succeeding. It will bring Iraq to its knees if we and our allies have the patience to keep it tightly in place, and the willingness to wait until its full effect is felt.
Of course we must keep our own military strength, joined by more than 130,000 allied troops, in place and ready to be used if necessary. The objections to President Bush's recent strengthening of our force make little sense: If we are in the gulf because we have to be, every military consideration dictates that we should be there with overwhelming power.
I do object, however, to the policy of no rotation for our troops. It would help morale if they were rotated home after some months' service in the harsh desert. This could be done without any loss in strength, and without sending any signal to Saddam Hussein other than that we have the best interests of our troops in mind.
I hope this great opportunity to enforce the rule of law globally is not watered down, compromised and weakened. We must preserve the military option. But let us see if patience and strength will give us victory without committing troops to combat.

HEADLINE: The Region: Recession;
It Took Time, But New York Yields to Laws Of Gravity

BYLINE: By RICHARD LEVINE

 BODY:
PERHAPS inevitably, what started as a "BMW recession" is filtering down to those who also travel by bus and subway.
Since June, New York City has been shedding about 7,000 jobs a month -- construction jobs, clerical jobs, retailing jobs, manufacturing jobs, financial-industry jobs, white-collar jobs, blue-collar jobs, managerial jobs, selling jobs, assembly-line jobs. 
 With less than four weeks until Christmas, there seem to be more vacant stores in Manhattan than at any time in years. City Hall, which went on a hiring spree in the 1980's, is talking about layoffs. Law firms and advertising agencies are pinched. Suddenly, it's easy to get a cab.
"Economically," said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional commissioner of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics, "we're in the soup."
All this now seems a natural consequence of the stock market's freefall three years ago, an event that essentially ended the 1980's a few years early. But while Wall Street, which had propelled the city's boom, began shrinking soon after the plunge, the rest of the city's economy was surprisingly unaffected, at least at first. And if there were fewer wealthy young traders, and fewer pricey restaurants for them to swagger into, well, that did not seem such a terrible price to pay for the excesses of the decade.
There was a "puritanical backlash," said Matthew P. Drennan, an economics professor at New York University, whose prediction that the city would lose 30,000 jobs by the end of 1988 is only now coming true. "A gloating about what happened to Leona Helmsley and Milken and Trump."
 
Falling Off a Cliff
 What happened to the city next? Mr. Ehrenhalt likened it to a cartoon character who runs right off a cliff and, oblivious to the lack of support, hangs in space, feet churning and face smiling. Then he looks down. Then he falls.
For a few years after the stock market's plunge, the city's economy hung there, with employment holding steady at around 3.6 million. Then it fell. And now it is falling faster.
By last year, the ripples had reached the real estate industry and were being felt in the boroughs outside of Manhattan and in the suburbs. State and local governments, struggling with drooping revenues, began raising taxes, pulling more money out of an already faltering economy.
Then, this year the national economy weakened. The effect on the city was akin to that of a large wave on an uncertain swimmer. The demand dropped for the goods New York produces for the rest of the country -- the services of advertising agencies, architects, engineers, accountants, lawyers, finance experts and consultants of various sorts. Consumers turned wary and retail sales in the city sagged. Dry cleaners and other neighborhood businesses suffered, too.
The savings and loan scandal, though caused by institutions in other regions, made New York lenders more cautious, inflicting more pain on small businesses, which often are underfinanced.
The construction industry, which flourished during the last decade even as factory jobs continued to disappear, tailed off, but only after a few too many skyscrapers were erected. Carpenters and other people in the trades who went from office building to office building, sometimes commuting in from the suburbs, were faced with choices like finishing basements or tending bar.
The rise in oil prices in a region that consumes energy without producing it further tightened discretionary income. And on top of all this, the city endured a wave of violence over the summer that was well chronicled across the country, making it harder for New York to attract visitors and businesses.
"This is the price you pay for being a world media capital," said Ronald K. Shelp, president of the New York Chamber of Commerce and Industry and the New York City Partnership. "Black eyes take a while to go away."
In retrospect, it seems clear that some of what is being felt now can be attributed to structural changes that occurred even as the city prospered. With computers replacing clerks and cash machines replacing tellers, for example, banking employment peaked in 1982. Suburban malls and catalogue outlets were siphoning off city business even before some New York department stores began to struggle under the weight of corporate debt that was a legacy of the junk-bond and leveraged-buyout carnival of the 80's.
But downturns can have benefits, even in the short term. Apartment rents, long a barometer of a housing shortage that came to be regarded as permanent, are falling in much of New York for the first time since the 1930's. There is greater choice of office space now and it's cheaper, too, which might encourage companies to stay or expand. According to the brokerage firm of Cushman & Wakefield, vacancy rates in the heart of the financial district have hit 23 percent for primary office buildings and 30.3 percent for secondary buildings.
The city's retooled economy is now strong in what Mr. Ehrenhalt calls information and knowledge-based industries -- from law firms to sophisticated business consulting -- which are the ones with the best prospects for growth in the 1990's. The question is, will advances in telecommunications render face-to-face meetings obsolete, reducing the need to do business in New York, which is still more expensive than elsewhere in the country.
Last month, after state and city officials offered about $150 million in incentives, the directors of four of the commodity exchanges located in the city recommended that their new headquarters be built in Lower Manhattan rather than New Jersey. Several other financial institutions, though, including the Morgan Stanley Group, are considering moving not just back-office clerks but also executives out of the city.
In the late 60's and 70's, New York endured the loss of 600,000 jobs and the near bankruptcy of its municipal government and, astonishingly, emerged to enjoy its most prosperous decade since World War II. Economists point to that experience as evidence of the city's resilience, if not its luck. What happened in the 70's was a catastrophe, they say. This is a cycle.
Rosemary Scanlon, chief economist of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, believes there could be a turn in New York's fortunes by the mid-1991. She can even envision one sooner, if Iraq withdraws from Kuwait, the price of oil drops, interest rates fall and the national economy, which pushed New York down, raises it back up.
"I don't think the sky is falling," said Professor Drennan. He, too, sees a turnaround, but not until 1992.

HEADLINE: The Region;
Another Dinkins Test: The Bond Market

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL

 BODY:
SINCE even before David N. Dinkins was elected Mayor, the municipal bond market has, like a Greek chorus, shadowed him across the public arena, sometimes heckling him, sometimes cheering him on. And now that he is wrestling with the worst fiscal problems in a decade, his administration's efforts to calm the concerns of the institutions and individuals who invest in New York City's bonds have moved to center stage at City Hall.
Next week, after an intensive marketing campaign in which the city feted investors at a two-day conference, the city is offering nearly $1.2 billion in long-term bonds -- the first such sale since the city's fiscal picture darkened in October, as tax revenues fell and the Mayor warned of layoffs. 
 Underwriters say the city faces the immediate prospects of significantly higher interest costs -- the city expects next year's payments to reach $2.7 billion, up from $1.8 billion this year -- as well as the likelihood of higher costs in future sales.
The relationship between the city, the largest borrower in the municipal market, and the investors who buy its bonds has become closely intertwined over the last year, beginning in the closing weeks of the 1989 mayoral campaign.
"The market for city debt has become sensitive to the local economy and just plain change in the last year or so in a way that was not true before," said Mark Page, a deputy city budget director.
This relationship became starkly clear in October, after the administration sent some confusing signals about its mastery of city finances. In the course of a single week, Mr. Dinkins agreed to a 5.5 percent increase in teachers' pay, announced plans to hire thousands of police officers and warned of the possibility of 15,000 layoffs. Worried bondholders quickly dumped large blocks of bonds. Prices fell and the yields on bonds ---- yield is the overall return on investment received by the buyer ---- rose sharply.
And while most New Yorkers never buy a municipal bond, these changes in the market matter. The more the city spends on debt service the less it can spend on city services.
During the last years of the Koch administration, after the city shook off the lingering effects of the fiscal crisis, city bonds were in high demand and sold at lower interest rates than other similar bonds.
But in the closing weeks of last year's mayoral campaign, yields on a benchmark 25-year bond rose, from 7.45 percent in September to 7.9 percent in late October, and rose again in December, just before Mr. Dinkins was sworn in. Yields reached 8.35 percent last April, as Mr. Dinkins grappled with his budget -- and the state, which provides $5 billion in aid to the city, failed to pass its budget on time.
 Rates dropped in July, after the City Council approved Mr. Dinkins's first balanced budget. In October, they reached 8.6 percent, and have remained high since.
One way of measuring the changes in city bonds is to compare their yields with those of other bonds. Through most of September 1989, the Bond Buyer's weekly index of 20 representative municipal bonds showed that city bonds were trading with a yield of a quarter of a percentage point above the index. By mid-October, the difference rose to seven-tenths of a point and to eight-tenths by January. In November, the spread was more than 1.25.
Some investors said the decline in the city's bonds was due to fears about social change under a mayor committed to giving more political power to minorities. Others said any new mayor, particularly one elected on a liberal platform, would have to demonstrate fiscal responsibility.
According to many city officials, investors and traders, the city's financial picture had been quietly deteriorating long before Mr. Dinkins appeared on the scene. And at the same time, the city pressed ahead with plans to sell more and more bonds -- $57 billion over the next 10 years -- raising questions about the city's ability to find buyers. As long as Mayor Edward I. Koch and Controller Harrison J. Goldin were in office, the market took little notice. Investors were familiar with their style and confident in them.
Darcy Bradbury, the Deputy Comptroller for Finance, said she viewed the changes in the market as a straw poll on the city's financial management.
"It will take time for investors to get comfortable with the new administration," she said, "because the old administration was in for 12 years. That was a long time."
 
Investors' Alert
 She attributed the beginning of the decline in city bonds to a full-page editorial in Barron's that appeared a few weeks before the election and called attention to the city's ever-growing payroll, revenue shortfalls and increased long-term borrowing needs. It questioned whether Mr. Dinkins or his Republican opponent, Rudolph W. Giuliani, was up to the job.
 Support for the notion that the city's problems predated Mr. Dinkins comes from James F. Lynch, a money manager and editor of the Lynch Municipal Bond Advisory in Santa Fe, N. M., who has been urging investors to sell their New York City bonds since 1987 and who now warns that "the crisis is coming."
 "The politicians played games when they had all of the money that was generated from the tremendous economic growth in the 1980's," Mr. Lynch said. "Everybody was fat, dumb and lazy in giving the store away. Dinkins can't walk away from it. He has been in city government all of his life."
 The Dinkins administration views its problem in the credit market as one of symbol as much as substance. In one of his first budget decisions as Mayor, Mr. Dinkins delayed the hiring of a new class of police recruits, signaling that he intended to act responsibly. He has warned that creating a "leaner, more efficient" government requires "tough choices."
But one city underwriter said the Mayor's confusing signals in October were so damanging because they undermined his past efforts to reassure investors.
When asked at a news conference last week why city bond yields had risen so much since he took office, Mr. Dinkins said that municipal finance was "an inexact science."
"It is very subjective," he said. "It is predicated to a large degree on what people feel."

HEADLINE: The Region;
Weicker Is King of An Uncharted Mountain

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON

DATELINE: HARTFORD

 BODY:
LOOKING for patterns in the careers of those few independent governors elected in this nation over the last century is like studying a pile of pick-up sticks. By their nature, people who have the ego and drive to surmount an entrenched two-party system are, well, independent and don't lend themselves to patterns.
James Bernard Longley, elected Governor of Maine in 1974, was an insurance man who apparently found politics and most politicians distasteful. By contrast, Walter J. Hickel, elected Governor of Alaska last month as an independent, is a career Republican who served as Governor in the 1960's before becoming Secretary of the Interior under President Nixon. He intends to rule as a Republican once again with the support of his party. The only independent before Mr. Longley, William Langer of North Dakota, served only two years before leaving office in 1938 for an unsuccessful independent run for the United States Senate. 
 Connecticut's experiment in nonparty government, which begins next month with the inauguration of Lowell P. Weicker Jr. as Governor, is like none of those others. Mr. Weicker, a 59-year-old former United States Senator who will be the first independent Governor here since 1858, thrived for 30 years as a Republican politician who routinely crossed party lines and openly antagonized leaders of his own party. Some people here still recall how even as a young lawmaker from Greenwich Mr. Weicker turned his back on fellow Republicans to work with a Democratic Governor as House liaison on transportation issues.
This year, however, he told voters that he had given up entirely on party politics and would run for Governor as an independent.
Running under the banner of A Connecticut Party, a name he plucked from thin air earlier this year to meet the legal requirement of getting on the ballot, Mr. Weicker beat his nearest rival, the Republican Party's nominee, Representative John G. Rowland, by 32,736 votes out of 1.1 million cast. He buried the Democratic Party's nominee, Representative Bruce A. Morrison, with a victory margin of nearly 224,000 votes.
Now Mr. Weicker faces the problem of turning his lone-wolf victory at the polls into a functioning state administration. Among the questions he faces: How will an independent get legislation through a Democratic-controlled General Assembly? Would he return to the Republican fold? Would he make a deal with the Democrats and try to use that party as his base to support legislation? With a sinking economy and a floundering state budget, would the legislative session spiral into chaos?
One month after the election, most of those questions are still echoing, but there have been signals. Within days of the election, Mr. Weicker turned in his membership card in the Republican Party, then immediately appointed two Republicans, Thomas J. D'Amore Jr. and Stanley A. Twardy Jr., a United States Attorney appointed by President Reagan, to be his closest advisers. He then named a Democrat who had also sought the governor's chair, William J. Cibes Jr., to be the state's next budget chief.
"It's opened up tremendous horizons," said Jonathan Pelto, the political director for the state Democratic Party, referring to the first wave of appointments, specifically that of Mr. Cibes, the former co-chairman of the Assembly's Finance, Revenue and Bonding Committee. Mr. Pelto said that while many Democrats are leery about Mr. Weicker, he believes the possibility of genuine "coalitional government" has become tangible.
 
Personal Popularity

 
 Politicians and academics who have studied the dynamic of relations between chief executives and legislatures say that in the months and years to come, several other factors will affect Mr. Weicker's ability to rule. If he can sustain a high personal popularity, lawmakers may be cowed into cooperating lest voters later retaliate.
And the issue of popularity will probably to a great degree hinge on how and when Mr. Weicker presents his proposals to resolve the state's yawning budget gap and how he addresses the still-simmering resentments over his election.
Over the next 18 months, Connecticut is expected to face a shortfall in state revenue of about $2 billion in an annual budget of just over $7 billion, with most of the gap resulting from plummeting sales-tax collections and corporate-profits taxes. Mr. Weicker has warned that solutions will be neither popular nor painless, and many lawmakers have interpreted the appointment of Mr. Cibes -- a supporter for the idea of a state income tax -- as a sign that the long-avoided wage tax may be at hand. Connecticut is among 10 states that have no income tax.
 
Tactics on Taxes
 One tactical possibility mentioned by Democrats is that Mr. Weicker would present a straw budget this February deliberately loaded with unpopular or unworkable measures. Lawmakers could then work out their resentments and publicly denounce the plan, allowing a compromise to be worked out behind the scenes that would include an income tax. A bleaker interpretation has Assembly leaders left on their own to fashion a solution from the wreckage and face the wrath of an angry electorate.
An even more Byzantine scenario, according to Mr. Pelto, involves Mr. Weicker leading the Assembly on to solve this year's budget gap through the sale of short-term bonds, thus intentionally postponing the final budget reckoning until 1992, an election year for legislators but not for the Governor. Then, in the predicted surge of voter anger over taxes, Mr. Weicker's fledgling party could storm the Assembly, running Connecticut Party candidates against the weakened Democratic and Republican incumbents.
Mr. Weicker, who takes office on Jan. 9, isn't tipping his hand and declined to be interviewed for this article. But those who know the Governor-elect's history say the fear of such intrigue is exaggerated.
"My fear is that he won't like the job," said Leo V. Donohue, a 66-year-old auditor of public accounts, who is a veteran of more than 30 years at the capitol and remembers Mr. Weicker's early days. Mr. Donohue said there was no mistaking Mr. Weicker's self-possessed style as a legislator, but that this time around he won't be able to go it alone. "He's going to be dealing with a lot of people who also have egos," he said.

CORRECTION-DATE: December 9, 1990, Sunday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about Governor-elect Lowell P. Weicker Jr. of Connecticut omitted the name of one independent elected to a governorship in this century. Julius L. Meier served as Governor of Oregon from 1931 to 1935.
