HEADLINE: Office Parties: They're Still Given, But the Ostentation Level Is Down

BYLINE: By LENA WILLIAMS

 BODY:
To party or not to party? That is the question many company executives are asking themselves this year. Whether to forgo the office Christmas party in light of budget cuts, layoffs and gloomy economic forecasts or to celebrate having survived a year of outrageous fortune.
"By this time last year, I had corporate party invitations for every night of the week in December," said Kurt P. Ross, president of K. P. Ross Inc., a public-relations concern for real-estate and investment clients. 
 By Friday he had received only one invitation.
Not every business is doing without. The Bureau of National Affairs, a nonprofit information service in Washington, reported that of 504 employers it surveyed, 61 percent would sponsor holiday parties this year, the same proportion as in 1989.
Seventy-four percent of the 217 New York City businesses surveyed by the New York Chamber of Commerce and Industry said they planned to have Christmas parties; 68 percent of them said the company would pick up the tab.
And BDO Seidman, a leading accounting and consulting concern, said that 79 percent of 1,650 business owners it surveyed provide office parties and 69 percent distribute bonuses to celebrate the holidays.
 
A New Spirit of Frugality
 But where, in years past, the motto seemed to be the bigger and more lavish the better, 1990 seems to have ushered in a spirit of frugality and cost-consciousness.
"The big corporations and even the smaller ones are asking themselves, 'How can we let people go during the year, then throw $10,000 to $20,000 on a Christmas party," said Nicholas Baxter, a Manhattan caterer who says his holiday business is doing well. "Some won't have a party at all. Then there are those who say, 'Why should we suffer?' So they have a party, but do it cheaper."
Many businesses are having their parties in the office or at the home of a senior officer. In some cases employees are chipping in. In others sit-down dinners have given way to buffets, and instead of filet mignon and shrimp on silver platters, there will be cold cuts on stainless steel.
"We're not exactly at the point of paper plates yet," said John Dawson, owner of Tri-State Party Rentals in Mount Vernon, N.Y. "Clients still want the party to look nice."
Sharon Destefano, a spokeswoman for the law firm of Jacoby & Meyers, said, "We've decided to arrange six smaller, more intimate gatherings in local restaurants, as opposed to the big Saturday night extravagant shindig we use to host."
Some businesses are so wary of how people might react to their employees kicking up their heels when others are having to bite the bullet that they are keeping their party plans secret.
A spokesman at Prudential-Bache Securities said the company would have no comment about its holiday party plans. A corporate communications director at a Manhattan marketing concern said he could lose his job if information about the concern's lavish party appeared in the public prints.
Adam Weiss, vice president and director of banquets for Bridgewaters, a 23,000-square-foot banquet center at 11 Fulton Street, said: "We've had three clients who prefaced their bookings with us on the basis that we keep the information confidential. Our clients are very sensitive. They want to keep their employees happy, but they don't want to set off any negative impressions." Bridgewaters is booked from Dec. 3 through Dec. 21.
 
But for Some, Open Jollity
 But there are those who, having looked at the bottom line and seen black, want to see jolly old red for the holidays.
Ron Bruder, president of the Brookhill Group, a real-estate developer and an adviser to troubled properties, gave a small party last year for his staff and a few clients in his conference room. This year he has doubled it, sending invitations to almost 200 people -- including Mr. Ross -- and is holding the Dec. 11 affair at Colors, a restaurant on Park Avenue.
"I think it's important to do this to show that there are still successful people in the real-estate business, and the office party is an important symbol at Christmas," he said.
The Caroline Jones Advertising Agency is taking a similarly upbeat attitude. Ms. Jones said the agency, which is celebrating its third year, is thankful to be alive and well. To show the agency's appreciation of its staff, clients and friends, Ms. Jones has rented Rex, a restaurant on the Avenue of the Americas, and invited clients from Bankers Trust, the Ministry of Tourism for the Bahamas, Western Union and Prudential-Bache, along with friends like O. J. Simpson, for "dancing, prancing and vixening."
David Bricker, a psychologist with a Wall Street practice, said: "Nobody's called to ask my advice, but were they to, I would say it's a good idea to have a holiday office party, especially if they had one in the past.
"You might cut back and not do something too garish, like taking people to the '21' Club or hiring Frank Sinatra to sing. But just because you have layoffs doesn't mean you start selling the artworks on the wall."

HEADLINE: Poles Move Forward, Nervously

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Will Poles Scuttle Economic Plan?" (news article, Nov. 28), you quote me as saying that Poland's election results were "tragic." This remark, taken out of context, might be seriously misunderstood.
What was tragic about the results was that an unknown Polish emigre, Stanislaw Tyminski, could overtake Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki through a campaign of demagoguery and outright lies. Mr. Tyminski's hot rhetoric that Poles were becoming the "white slaves of Europe" and that the Mazowiecki government had committed "high treason" by selling state enterprises cheaply to foreigners (while the privatization program -- based mainly on Polish ownership -- had not yet begun), played well in Poland's impoverished rural regions.
But as you make clear, the prospect of Lech Walesa as president is anything but tragic. A Walesa presidency offers an excellent chance for continuation of the economic reforms, because Mr. Walesa will be a highly persuasive advocate for them. As Mr. Walesa has been saying for weeks, and as he reiterated boldly at a Nov. 27 press conference following the election results, he will continue the Leczek Balcerowicz plan of rapid economic reform. It is even likely that Mr. Balcerowicz himself would be asked to continue at the economic helm in a Walesa Government.
It has been evident for months in Poland that the highest costs of reforms have not been the actual results (because the costs have been balanced by major advances), but rather the profound anxieties that have been raised among the population about the future.
Poles are living in a time of rapid change, and they often have grave doubts about their ability to remain afloat in the new market economy that is arising in their country.
Thus fears of future unemployment or collapsing living standards are grossly exaggerated (as with the widespread estimate that the unemployment rate would reach 20 percent this year, when it is 5.5 percent, less than in the United States).
To paraphrase Franklin Roosevelt, the main thing the Poles have to fear is fear itself. It is in confronting such fears that Lech Walesa will likely prove again to be a political genius. He mobilized Polish society to confront Communism against extraordinary odds. Mr. Walesa is now likely to do the same thing with regard to economic reform and the reintegration of Poland into the mainstream of Europe.
 
JEFFREY D. SACHS
Cambridge, Mass., Nov. 28, 1990
 
The writer is the Galen L. Stone Professor of Economics at Harvard and an adviser on Poland's program of economic reforms.
