The New York Times

PUB-DATE: December 2, 1990

SECTION: Section 6; Page 52; Column 3; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 5676 words

HEADLINE: Betting on the Planet

BYLINE: BY John Tierney; John Tierney is a reporter for The New York Times. He is writing a book on environmental crises.

 BODY:
In 1980 an ecologist and an economist chose a refreshingly unacademic way to resolve their differences. They bet $1,000. Specifically, the bet was over the future price of five metals, but at stake was much more -- a view of the planet's ultimate limits, a vision of humanity's destiny. It was a bet between the Cassandra and the Dr. Pangloss of our era.
They lead two intellectual schools -- sometimes called the Malthusians and the Cornucopians, sometimes simply the doomsters and the boomsters -- that use the latest in computer-generated graphs and foundation-generated funds to debate whether the world is getting better or going to the dogs. The argument has generally been as fruitless as it is old, since the two sides never seem to be looking at the same part of the world at the same time. Dr. Pangloss sees farm silos brimming with record harvests; Cassandra sees topsoil eroding and pesticide seeping into ground water. Dr. Pangloss sees people living longer; Cassandra sees rain forests being decimated. But in 1980 these opponents managed to agree on one way to chart and test the global future. They promised to abide by the results exactly 10 years later -- in October 1990 -- and to pay up out of their own pockets. 
 The bettors, who have never met in all the years they have been excoriating each other, are both 58-year-old professors who grew up in the Newark suburbs. The ecologist, Paul R. Ehrlich, has been one of the world's better-known scientists since publishing "The Population Bomb" in 1968. More than three million copies were sold, and he became perhaps the only author ever interviewed for an hour on "The Tonight Show." When he is not teaching at Stanford University or studying butterflies in the Rockies, Ehrlich can generally be found on a plane on his way to give a lecture, collect an award or appear in an occasional spot on the "Today" show. This summer he won a five-year MacArthur Foundation grant for $345,000, and in September he went to Stockholm to share half of the $240,000 Crafoord Prize, the ecologist's version of the Nobel. His many personal successes haven't changed his position in the debate over humanity's fate. He is the pessimist.
The economist, Julian L. Simon of the University of Maryland, often speaks of himself as an outcast, which isn't quite true. His books carry jacket blurbs from Nobel laureate economists, and his views have helped shape policy in Washington for the past decade. But Simon has certainly never enjoyed Ehrlich's academic success or popular appeal. On the first Earth Day in 1970, while Ehrlich was in the national news helping to launch the environmental movement, Simon sat in a college auditorium listening as a zoologist, to great applause, denounced him as a reactionary whose work "lacks scholarship or substance." Simon took revenge, first by throwing a drink in his critic's face at a faculty party and then by becoming the scourge of the environmental movement. When he unveiled his happy vision of beneficent technology and human progress in Science magazine in 1980, it attracted one of the largest batches of angry letters in the journal's history.
In some ways, Simon goes beyond Dr. Pangloss, the tutor in "Candide" who insists that "All is for the best in this best of possible worlds." Simon believes that today's world is merely the best so far. Tomorrow's will be better still, because it will have more people producing more bright ideas. He argues that population growth constitutes not a crisis but, in the long run, a boon that will ultimately mean a cleaner environment, a healthier humanity and more abundant supplies of food and raw materials for everyone. And this progress can go on indefinitely because -- "incredible as it may seem at first," he wrote in his 1980 article -- the planet's resources are actually not finite. Simon also found room in the article to criticize, among others, Ehrlich, Barry Commoner, Newsweek, the National Wildlife Federation and the secretary general of the United Nations. It was titled "Resources, Population, Environment: An Oversupply of False Bad News."
An irate Ehrlich wondered how the article had passed peer review at America's leading scientific journal. "Could the editors have found someone to review Simon's manuscript who had to take off his shoes to count to 20?" Ehrlich asked in a rebuttal written with his wife, Anne, also an ecologist at Stanford. They provided the simple arithmetic: the planet's resources had to be divided among a population that was then growing at the unprecedented rate of 75 million people a year. The Ehrlichs called Simon the leader of a "space-age cargo cult" of economists convinced that new resources would miraculously fall from the heavens. For years the Ehrlichs had been trying to explain the ecological concept of "carrying capacity" to these economists. They had been warning that population growth was outstripping the earth's supplies of food, fresh water and minerals. But they couldn't get the economists to listen.
"To explain to one of them the inevitability of no growth in the material sector, or . . . that
commodities must become expensive," the Ehrlichs wrote, "would be like attempting to explain odd-day-even-day gas distribution to a cranberry."
Ehrlich decided to put his money where his mouth was by responding to an open challenge issued by Simon to all Malthusians. Simon offered to let anyone pick any natural resource -- grain, oil, coal, timber, metals -- and any future date. If the resource really were to become scarcer as the world's population grew, then its price should rise. Simon wanted to bet that the price would instead decline by the appointed date. Ehrlich derisively announced that he would "accept Simon's astonishing offer before other greedy people jump in." He then formed a consortium with John Harte and John P. Holdren, colleagues at the University of California at Berkeley specializing in energy and resource questions.
In October 1980 the Ehrlich group bet $1,000 on five metals -- chrome, copper, nickel, tin and tungsten -- in quantities that each cost $200 in the current market. A futures contract was drawn up obligating Simon to sell Ehrlich, Harte and Holdren these same quantities of the metals 10 years later, but at 1980 prices. If the 1990 combined prices turned out to be higher than $1,000, Simon would pay them the difference in cash. If prices fell, they would pay him. The contract was signed, and Ehrlich and Simon went on attacking each other throughout the 1980's. During that decade the world's population grew by more than 800 million, the greatest increase in history, and the store of metals buried in the earth's crust did not get any larger.

Population, when unchecked, increases in a geometrical ratio. Subsistence increases only in an arithmetical ratio. -- Thomas Robert Malthus, 1798.

Population Outgrows Food, Scientists Warn the World -- Front-page headline in The New York Times, Sept. 15, 1948, over an article about the "dark outlook for the human race" due to "overpopulation and the dwindling of natural resources."

No Room in the Lifeboats -- Headline in The New York Times Magazine, April 16, 1978, over an article warning that "the cost of natural resources is going up" as increasing population ushers in the "Age of Scarcity."

The earth has limited resources, and if we don't recycle them we use them up. -- Meredith Baxter-Birney, who played the mother on the "Family Ties" television show, in a recent Greenpeace public-service message showing the family sorting garbage in the living room.

IT IS SUCH AN OBVIOUS proposition in a finite world: things run out. It must have occurred to Homo habilis while searching for rocks to make the first tools 2.5 million years ago. Aristotle and Plato shared the same concerns as the "Family Ties" cast. The American Indians put it nicely in a proverb that has been adopted as a slogan by today's environmentalists: "We do not inherit the earth from our parents. We borrow it from our children." The idea shapes our personal actions when we bundle newspapers to avoid running out of wood for paper and land for garbage dumps. It affects our national policies when we send soldiers into the Persian Gulf to prevent Saddam Hussein from getting a "stranglehold" on the dwindling supplies of oil. It is the fear Paul Ehrlich raised in 1974: "What will we do when the pumps run dry?"
The counterargument is not nearly as intuitively convincing. It has generally consisted of a simple question: Why haven't things run out yet? The ones asking this question now tend to be economists, which is a switch, since their predecessors were the ones who initiated the modern preoccupation with resource scarcity. Economics was first called "the dismal science" in the last century because of Malthus's predictions of mass starvation. He had many successors, the most eloquent of whom perhaps was a British economist named William Stanley Jevons.
In 1865 Jevons published "The Coal Question: An Inquiry Concerning the Progress of the Nation, and the Probable Exhaustion of Our Coal Mines." In most ways, it was quite similar to the books that appeared during the energy crisis of the 1970's. There were graphs showing parabolic curves of population and coal consumption shooting upwards, and charts showing estimates of woefully inadequate coal reserves. "The conclusion is inevitable," Jevons wrote, "that our present happy progressive condition is a thing of limited duration."
Unlike the prophets a century later, though, Jevons was not sure that the answer was mandatory conservation. At first glance, he wrote, there seemed to be a clear case for the Government's limiting industry's profligate energy use. "To disperse so lavishly the cream of our mineral wealth is to be spendthrifts of our capital -- to part with that which will never come back." He warned that this might lead to the sudden collapse of British civilization. Yet he noted that much of that civilization, such as "our rich literature and philosophy," might never have existed without "the lavish expenditure of our material energy" that "redeemed us from dullness and degradation a century ago." To reduce coal consumption might only bring back stagnation, he cautioned, and he ended his book with a sentence in italics: "We have to make the momentous choice between brief greatness and longer continued mediocrity."
There were many other sightings of the end of the lode. An energy crisis arose in the middle of the 19th century, when the dwindling supply of whales drove up the cost of lighting homes with oil lamps and tallow candles. In 1905 President Theodore Roosevelt warned of an American "timber famine," a concern that prompted a proposal to ban Christmas trees. In 1926 the Federal Oil Conservation Board announced that the United States had a seven-year supply of petroleum left.
Naturalists gradually replaced economists as the chief doomsayers. They dominated the conservation movement early this century, and in 1948 two of them -- Fairfield Osborn, the president of the New York Zoological Society, and an ornithologist named William Vogt -- started a national debate by publishing popular books: "Our Plundered Planet" and "Road to Survival" respectively. Both men warned of overpopulation, dwindling resources and future famines. Vogt's book lamented the loss of "such irreplaceable capital goods as soils and minerals." Vogt was especially worried about one of the metals that turned up decades later in the Ehrlich-Simon bet, warning that "we might go to war to ensure access to tin sources." The world's supply of agricultural land, he wrote, was "shrinking fast" and "every year producing less food." America's recent bumper crops were "accidents of favorable weather." Since the United States was already overpopulated, "a fall in living standards is unavoidable." And if humanity did not follow Vogt's "Road to Survival" -- conservation and population control -- there was the alternate route presented in the book's last sentence: "Like Gadarene swine, we shall rush down a war-torn slope to a barbarian existence in the blackened rubble."
Both books made an impression on the teen-age Paul Ehrlich. He was already a naturalist himself, thanks to a mentor at the American Museum of Natural History in New York who encouraged him to study butterflies and publish papers while he was still a high-school student in New Jersey. Ehrlich went on to study zoology at the University of Pennsylvania. He married Anne in 1954 while in graduate school at the University of Kansas, and they put their Malthusian principles into practice by limiting themselves to one child. Ehrlich had a vasectomy in 1963, shortly after getting tenure at Stanford.
In the mid-60's, Ehrlich started giving public lectures about the population problem. One caught the attention of David Brower, then executive director of the Sierra Club, who led him to Ballantine Books. Rushing to publish his message in time for the 1968 Presidential election, Ehrlich produced what may be the all-time ecological best seller, "The Population Bomb."
It was "The Tonight Show" that made him and his book famous. As Ehrlich remembers it, Joan Rivers went on first, telling jokes about her honeymoon night ("I said, 'Turn off the lights . . . turn off the lights . . . shut the car door.' "). Then there was a starlet whose one-word answers made things so awkward that Ehrlich was rushed on early to rescue Johnny Carson.
"I went on and did basically a monologue," Ehrlich recalls. "I'd talk until the commercial, and during the break I'd feed Johnny a question, and then I'd answer it until the next commercial. I got the highest compliment after the show, when I was walking behind Johnny and Ed McMahon up the stairs, and I heard Johnny say, 'Boy, Paul really saved the show.' "
"The Tonight Show" got more than 5,000 letters about Ehrlich's appearance, the first of many on the program. Ehrlich has been deluged ever since with requests for lectures, interviews and opinions. He is a rare hybrid: the academic who keeps his professional reputation intact while pleasing the masses. Scientists praise his papers on butterflies and textbooks on ecology; talk-show hosts tout his popular books and love his affably blunt style. He has never been one to mince words or hedge predictions.
"The Population Bomb" began: "The battle to feed all of humanity is over. In the 1970's the world will undergo famines -- hundreds of millions of people are going to starve to death." Ehrlich wrote that "nothing can prevent a substantial increase in the world death rate" and that America's "vast agricultural surpluses are gone."
Six years later, in a book he wrote with his wife, "The End of Affluence," he raised the death toll. The book told of a "nutritional disaster that seems likely to overtake humanity in the 1970's (or, at the latest, the 1980's). Due to a combination of ignorance, greed and callousness, a situation has been created that could lead to a billion or more people starving to death." The book predicted that "before 1985 mankind will enter a genuine age of scarcity" in which "the accessible supplies of many key minerals will be nearing depletion." Shortages would be felt in America as well as the rest of the world. "One general prediction can be made with confidence: the cost of feeding yourself and your family will continue to increase. There may be minor fluctuations in food prices, but the overall trend will be up."
Ehrlich was right about one thing: the world's population did grow. It is now 5.3 billion, 1.8 billion larger than when he published "The Population Bomb." Yet somehow the average person is healthier, wealthier and better fed than in 1968. The predicted rise in the world death rate has yet to materialize -- infant mortality has declined and life expectancy has increased, most dramatically in the third world. There have been famines in countries afflicted by war, drought and disastrous agricultural policies, but the number of people affected by famines has been declining steadily during the past three decades. In fact, the number is much lower than it was during the same decades of the last century, even though the world's population is much larger. Experts argue about how much hunger remains in the world, but they generally agree that the average person in the third world is better nourished today than in 1968. Food production has increased faster than population since the publication of "The Population Bomb," just as it has since the books of Vogt, Osborn and Malthus.
Perhaps the best way to see what has happened to food prices -- and to get a glimpse of the Malthusian mind-set -- is to consider a graph from Lester R. Brown, another widely quoted doomster. Brown has long been the chief source for Ehrlich and other ecologists on trends in agriculture -- "the best person in the country on the subject" in Ehrlich's words. Brown is the president of the Worldwatch Institute in Washington, which makes news each year with what it calls the world's most widely used public-policy document, its "State of the World" report. This year's report includes a graph, below, of grain prices that is interesting for a couple of reasons:
 
[GRAPH: "World Wheat and Rice Prices, 1950-89]
 
Consider, first of all, how it compares with Brown's predictions of a decade ago. He was pessimistic then for the same reasons that Ehrlich, Vogt and Osborn had been: rising population, vanishing topsoil, the growing dependence on "non-sustainable" uses of irrigation, fertilizer, pesticides. "The period of global food security is over," Brown wrote in 1981. "As the demand for food continues to press against the supply, inevitably real food prices will rise. The question no longer seems to be whether they will rise but how much." But as the graph shows, grain prices promptly fell and reached historic lows during the 1980's, continuing a long-term decline that dates back to the days of Vogt and Osborn (and Malthus, too, if you extended the graph).
Now consider how Brown analyzes this data. In a chapter titled "The Illusion of Progress" in this year's report, he focuses not on the long-term trend but on the blips in the graph in 1988 and 1989 -- when prices rose because of factors like drought and a United States Government program that took farmland out of production. Looking ahead to the 1990's, Brown writes, "The first concrete economic indication of broad-based environmental deterioration now seems likely to be rising grain prices."
We are barely into the 1990's, but so far Brown's poor track record is intact. Grain prices have plummeted since he published his prediction at the start of the year. The blips in the late 1980's caused farmers to do what they always do when prices rise: plant more crops. The price of wheat has fallen by more than 40 percent in the past year, and if you plotted it on that graph, it would be at yet another all-time low. Once again Malthus's day of reckoning will have to be rescheduled.

JULIAN SIMON REMEMBERS his first glimpse of Paul Ehrlich as being one of the more frustrating moments of his life. It was during the Earth Day furor two decades ago. Simon was sitting at home in Urbana, Ill., Ehrlich was on "The Tonight Show" and Johnny Carson was enthralled.
"Carson, the most unimpressable of people, had this look of stupefied admiration," Simon recalls. "He'd throw out a question about population growth and Ehrlich would start out by saying, 'Well, it's really very simple, Johnny.' Now the one thing I knew in those days about population was that nothing about it is simple. But what could I do? Go talk to five people? Here was a guy reaching a vast audience, leading this juggernaut of environmentalist hysteria, and I felt utterly helpless."
At this point, Simon was still in the early stages of Cornucopianism. He had started out as a Malthusian. After studying psychology at Harvard University and receiving a doctorate in business economics from the University of Chicago, he joined the faculty at the University of Illinois in 1963. He was an expert in mail-order marketing -- his book on the topic sold 200,000 copies, more than any he has written since -- and was looking for something else to do when he heard the grim predictions about overpopulation. In the late 1960's he began publishing papers on using marketing tools and economic incentives to persuade women to have fewer babies. But then he came across work by economists showing that countries with rapid population growth were not suffering more than other countries. In fact, many were doing better. He also came across a book, "Scarcity and Growth," published in 1963 with the help of Resources for the Future, a conservation group dominated by economists.
The book was a revelation to him: it provided the empirical foundations of Cornucopianism. The authors, Harold J. Barnett and Chandler Morse, tracked the price of natural resources back to 1870 and found that the price of virtually everything had fallen. The average worker today could buy more coal with an hour's pay than he could when "The Coal Question" was published in the last century, just as he could buy more metals and more food. Things were actually getting less scarce as population grew.
The evidence inspired the boomster view of history, which was then refined by Simon and others, like Charles Maurice and Charles W. Smithson. These economists, then at Texas A & M University, looked back at 10,000 years of resource crises and saw a pattern: things did sometimes become scarce, but people responded with innovations. They found new supplies or practiced conservation. They managed to recycle without the benefit of government policies or moral exhortations from Greenpeace. Stone Age tribes in areas short of flint learned to resharpen their tools instead of discarding them as tribes did in flint-rich areas.
Often the temporary scarcity led to a much better substitute. The Greeks' great transition from the Bronze Age to the Iron Age 3,000 years ago, according to Maurice and Smithson, was inspired by a disruption of trade due to wars in the eastern Mediterranean. The disruption produced a shortage of the tin needed to make bronze, and the Greeks responded to the bronze crisis by starting to use iron. Similarly, timber shortages in 16th-century Britain ushered in the age of coal; the scarcity of whale oil around 1850 led to the first oil well in 1859. Temporary shortages do occur, but Cornucopians argue that as long as government doesn't interfere -- by mandating conservation or setting the sort of price controls that produced America's gas lines of the 1970's -- people will find alternatives that turn out to be better.
"Natural resources are not finite. Yes, you read correctly," Simon wrote in his 1981 manifesto, "The Ultimate Resource." The title referred to human ingenuity, which Simon believed could go on indefinitely expanding the planet's carrying capacity. This idea marked the crucial difference between Simon and Ehrlich, and between economists and ecologists: the view of the world not as an closed ecosystem but as an flexible marketplace. The concept of carrying capacity might make sense in discussing Ehrlich's butterflies or Vogt's "Gadarene swine," but Simon rejected animal analogies. He liked to quote the 19th-century economist Henry George: "Both the jayhawk and the man eat chickens, but the more jayhawks, the fewer chickens, while the more men, the more chickens."
Of course, men can also produce more pollution than jayhawks, and Simon conceded that the marketplace did need some regulation. But he insisted that environmental crises were being exaggerated. He and another leading boomster, Herman Kahn, edited a book in 1984, "The Resourceful Earth," rebutting the gloomy forecasts of the Government's "Global 2000 Report" prepared under President Carter. Their book was replete with graphs showing that, by most measures, America's air and water had been getting cleaner for decades, thanks partly to greater affluence (richer societies can afford to pay for pollution controls like sewage treatment) and partly to the progress of technology (the pollution from cars today in New York City is nothing compared to the soot from coal-burning furnaces and the solid waste from horses at the turn of the century). Simon asserted that innovations would take care of new forms of pollution, and he set about disputing the various alarming estimates of tropical deforestation, species extinction, eroding topsoil, paved-over farmland and declining fisheries.
"As soon as one predicted disaster doesn't occur, the doomsayers skip to another," Simon complains. "There's nothing wrong with worrying about new problems -- we need problems so we can come up with solutions that leave us better off than if they'd never come up in the first place. But why don't the doomsayers see that, in the aggregate, things are getting better? Why do they always think we're at a turning point -- or at the end of the road? They deny our creative powers for solutions. It's only because we used those powers so well in the past that we can afford to worry about things like losing species and wetlands. Until we got so rich and healthy and productive at agriculture, a wetland was a swamp with malarial mosquitoes that you had to drain so you could have cropland to feed your family."
Simon's fiercest battle has been against Paul Ehrlich's idea that the world has too many people. The two have never debated directly -- Ehrlich has always refused, saying that Simon is a "fringe character" -- but they have lambasted each other in scholarly journal articles with titles like "An Economist in Wonderland" and "Paul Ehrlich Saying It Is So Doesn't Make It So." Simon acknowledges that rising population causes short-term problems, because it means more children to feed and raise. But he maintains that there are long-term benefits when those children become productive, resourceful adults. He has supported making abortion and family-planning services available to women to give them more freedom, but he has vehemently opposed programs that tell people how many children to have. He attacked Ehrlich for suggesting that governments should consider using coercion to limit family size and for endorsing the startling idea that the United States should consider cutting off food aid to countries that refuse to control population growth.
Among academics, Simon seems to be gaining in the debate. Many scientists are still uncomfortable with his sweeping optimism about the future -- there is no guarantee, after all, that past trends will continue -- and most population experts are not sure that the current rate of population growth in the third world is going to bring the long-term benefits predicted by Simon. But the consensus has been shifting against Ehrlich's idea of population growth as the great evil. Simon's work helped prompt the National Academy of Sciences to prepare a 1986 report, which noted that there was no clear evidence that population growth makes countries poorer. It concluded that slower population growth would probably benefit third world countries, but argued that other factors, like a country's economic structure and political institutions, were much more important to social well-being. The report opposed the notion of using government coercion to control family size. It noted that most experts expected the world food situation to continue improving, and it concluded that, for the foreseeable future, "the scarcity of exhaustible resources is at most a minor constraint on economic growth."
But Simon is still far behind when it comes to winning over the general public. This past Earth Day he did not fare much better than he did in 1970. Ehrlich was still the one all over national television. In the weeks leading up to Earth Day in April, Ehrlich did spots for the "Today" show and appeared on other programs promoting his new book, "The Population Explosion," which declares that "the population bomb has detonated." At the big Earth Day rally in Washington, Ehrlich was one of the many Malthusians warning that this was humanity's last chance to save the planet. It was a scene to make Cornucopians wonder if the ancient Greeks who described Cassandra's curse -- fated to be always right but never heeded -- had gotten it precisely backward. The crowd of more than 200,000 applauded heartily after Ehrlich told them that population growth could produce a world in which their grandchildren would endure food riots in the streets of America.
Ehrlich did not mention Simon by name, although he did refer to him at another event that Earth Day weekend, a symposium of ecologists inside the domed auditorium of the Smithsonian's National Museum of Natural History. The symposium was devoted to the question of natural resources -- "Population and Scarcity: The Forgotten Dimensions" -- and Ehrlich talked about humanity squandering irreplaceable capital. He praised a colleague who had advocated the idea of governments' stopping economic growth by setting quotas on the amount of resources that could be used each year. Ehrlich criticized the shortsightedness of economists, and he got a laugh when he alluded to Simon's book: "The ultimate resource -- the one thing we'll never run out of is imbeciles."
That same day Simon spoke only a block away in a small, low-ceilinged conference room at another Earth Day symposium. It was sponsored by the Competitive Enterprise Institute, a group that explores free-market solutions to environmental problems. In an intense, quiet voice, Simon declared that the Malthusians "must either turn a blind eye to the scientifc evidence or be blatantly dishonest intellectually." He spoke of population growth representing "a victory over death," because it was due to the doubling of life expectancy since the Industrial Revolution. "This is an incredible gain. Human history has never shown any achievement to hold a candle to that. You'd expect lovers of human life to be jumping with joy at this incredible success. Instead, across the street we've got them lamenting that there are so many people alive."
He seemed a little disappointed that there were only 16 people in the audience to celebrate his message. "Well, there may be more of them over there," Simon said, gesturing toward the place where Ehrlich was speaking, "but we're happier."

The bet was settled this fall without ceremony. Ehrlich did not even bother to write a letter. He simply mailed Simon a sheet of calculations about metal prices -- along with a check for $576.07. Simon wrote back a thank-you note, adding that he would be willing to raise the wager to as much as $20,000, pinned to any other resources and to any other year in the future.
Each of the five metals chosen by Ehrlich's group, when adjusted for inflation since 1980, had declined in price. The drop was so sharp, in fact, that Simon would have come out slightly ahead overall even without the inflation adjustment called for in the bet. Prices fell for the same Cornucopian reasons they had fallen in previous decades -- entrepreneurship and continuing technological improvements. Prospectors found new lodes, such as the nickel mines around the world that ended a Canadian company's near monopoly of the market. Thanks to computers, new machines and new chemical processes, there were more efficient ways to extract and refine the ores for chrome and the other metals.
For many uses, the metals were replaced by cheaper materials, notably plastics, which became less expensive as the price of oil declined (even during this year's crisis in the Persian Gulf, the real cost of oil remained lower than in 1980). Telephone calls went through satellites and fiber-optic lines instead of copper wires. Ceramics replaced tungsten in cutting tools. Cans were made of aluminum instead of tin, and Vogt's fears about America going to war over tin remained unrealized. The most newsworthy event in the 1980's concerning that metal was the collapse of the international tin cartel, which gave up trying to set prices in 1985 when the market became inundated with excess supplies.
Is there a lesson here for the future?
"Absolutely not," said Ehrlich in an interview. Nevertheless, he has no plans to take up Simon's new offer: "The bet doesn't mean anything. Julian Simon is like the guy who jumps off the Empire State Building and says how great things are going so far as he passes the 10th floor. I still think the price of those metals will go up eventually, but that's a minor point. The resource that worries me the most is the declining capacity of our planet to buffer itself against human impacts. Look at the new problems that have come up: the ozone hole, acid rain, global warming. It's true that we've kept up food production -- I underestimated how badly we'd keep on depleting our topsoil and ground water -- but I have no doubt that sometime in the next century food will be scarce enough that prices are really going to be high even in the United States. If we get climate change and let the ecological systems keep running downhill, we could have a gigantic population crash."
Simon was not surprised to hear about Ehrlich's reaction. "Paul Ehrlich has never been able to learn from past experience," he said, then launched into the Cornucopian line on the greenhouse crisis -- how, even in the unlikely event that doomsayers are right about global warming, humanity will find some way to avert climate change or adapt, and everyone will emerge the better for it. But Simon did not get far into his argument before another cheery thought occurred to him. He stopped and smiled.
"So Ehrlich is talking about a population crash," he said. "That sounds like an even better way to make money. I'll give him heavy odds on that one."

SECTION: Section 2; Page 35; Column 1; Arts & Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 1814 words

HEADLINE: TELEVISION;
Now, a Look at the Life Style of Robin Leach

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS

 BODY:
You are Robin Leach. That Robin Leach. You are the star of "Lifestyles of the Rich and Famous" and "Runaway With the Rich and Famous." You are launching "Preview: First Look at the New," a $30 million, five-day-a-week television extravaganza. You've traveled 400,000 miles this year to exotic locales. And yes: You are the on-screen voice of Spuds MacKenzie.
Yet dark clouds have shadowed your paradise. You are savaged by critics. You are parodied. By children, even. You are continually amazed at the remarkable number of misconceptions that keep cropping up about your life, your person and your art. What do you do? You pause between continent-spanning flights. You grant an interview. You speak frankly. And you set to rest once and forever 13 myths about the ever-growing Legend of Leach: 
 1. Robin Leach Is Rich and Famous: "Actually, I'm infamous," said the 49-year-old Mr. Leach, sipping decaf coffee from a not very rich or famous Styrofoam cup. He was seated not on the Orient Express but on a conference chair in one of his two offices in midtown Manhattan. "And I'm not rich. Everyone thinks I make what Oprah does or Cosby, but I don't, because we're in syndication. I made my first million by the time I was 31 and promptly lost it when I got divorced." How close is he now to his 10th million? "Nowhere near," he said in the famous harsh, manic voice.
He added, with more modulation: "I don't want to be rich -- in the definition we have of rich." He meant that the cutoff point for inclusion on "Lifestyles" is $50 million. "I just want to be comfortable."
2. Robin Leach Has Hot-and-Cold Running Servants: "I have no servants," he said. "I do have a cleaning lady, like everyone else." He sighed. "I have no limo. In cities, I usually hail a taxi like everyone else. My car at home is a Ford Mustang. I have a one-bedroom apartment in Manhattan, which is really a glorified closet for changing clothes." He owns a three-bedroom house in Connecticut -- "no fence, no guard, no barking dog" -- and a two-bedroom house in Los Angeles.
3. Robin Leach Is Robin Leach: "I've become Robin Leach the cartoon character in front of the camera," he said. The cartoon character is a 5-foot-11-inch, lower-middle-class Englishman with protruding ears and sufficient girth who breathlessly intones his lines in glass-cutting vowels on international television. "I am the most unlikely star in the world," Mr. Leach said happily.
"But the cartoon character, that's not who Robin Leach is," he added. "Robin Leach is a guy who, when he has the time, goes quietly to his house in Connecticut and sits looking into the fire with a good glass of red wine in his hand." Mr. Leach said his steady date these days is the actress Judith Ledford; he has three grown children from his first marriage.
"And when I wake up in the morning," he continued, "I wink at myself because I like me -- I know who I am. And when it's time to send the cartoon character off, I just send him on his way."
4. Robin Leach Is on Every Single Television Station Every Hour of Every Day: "It just seems that way," he said. Especially in New York and Los Angeles, where weekends are Robin Leach television festivals. Leach-lovers can view three of his shows and three repeats on three different networks in Los Angeles, and three shows and one repeat on three different channels in New York, where, as in many other cities, Mr. Leach's shows are broadcast seven days a week.
Truly, a gradual process of worldwide Leachification is occurring: in addition to the 168 stations in America that carry his programs, his shows are now broadcast in 22 overseas markets. "Lifestyles of the Rich and Famous," Mr. Leach's weekly hourlong show celebrating millionaires, celebrities and industrialists, is in its eighth year and has been renewed for next season; according to A.C. Nielsen, it has 4.4 million viewers. (In the New York City area, "Lifestyles" is on WABC-TV on Sunday nights at 8.) "Runaway With the Rich and Famous," which takes celebrities and their video cameras on jaunts to exotic foreign climes and/or locales, is in its fifth season, has 3.5 million viewers a week and has also been renewed for next year. (In New York, "Runaway" is on WABC-TV on Sunday mornings at 9:30.) Mr. Leach is executive producer, and on-air talent, for both shows; he is managing editor and on-camera reporter for "Preview: First Look at the New," the latest Leach project. The half-hour, five-day-a-week "strip," as it's called in the biz, began in September and has 2.1 million viewers. (In New York, "Preview" is on WNBC-TV weekdays at 9 A.M.)
 The impression of Leachian ubiquity is further enhanced by all those commercials. Mr. Leach has been the voice of Spuds MacKenzie -- the piratical Bud Light party pooch -- and he has hawked the California Lottery and Honda automobiles. If you remember, Robin Leach is the man who said, "I'll take the red one."
What makes Robin run? Is it the desire for fame? Is it greed? "It's enthusiasm," he said. "I thrive on it. And I really do have a lot of fun."
5. Robin Leach Is Daunted by Fears of a Recession: "I think the 90's will be a much more interesting era for us," he said. "It won't hurt 'Lifestyles' -- there's more fascination with a Gatsby in a depression, when no one's rich, than in a time when everyone's rich."
A recession "certainly isn't a bad time for television, when people have less income to spend on entertainment. It means that more people will be staying at home."
In a depression is it possible that Mr. Leach will run out of millionaires for "Lifestyles"? "Even now, two new people become millionaires every day," he said. "In our first eight years, we've been able to do stories on only 2,000 millionaires. We've hardly scratched the surface."
And if he's wrong? "Well, then we have two choices. We can do 'Lifestyles of the Formerly Rich and Famous,' " he said, "or we can do 'Lifestyles of the Poor and Unknown.' "
6. Robin Leach's New Show Is a Knock-Off of "Entertainment Tonight": "Cynics say that 'Preview' is 'Entertainment Tomorrow,' but they are two different shows," said Mr. Leach, who developed the new show with his longtime partner, Al Masini. Mr. Masini is the producer who came up with the concept for "Entertainment Tonight," and he also came up with Robin Leach: Mr. Leach was the only performer on the pilot of "Entertainment Tonight" to make it to the debut, and he stayed with the show for three years.
"Preview" is "the first look at everything that is new," said Mr. Leach. The show is a gee-whiz preview of movies, TV, recordings, fashion, medical breakthroughs, hotels, restaurants and life styles that often has the feel of a video press release.
7. Robin Leach Will Interview Just Any Millionaire: "We were offered the Duvaliers and the Marcoses," he said. "We turned them down cold. We felt their wealth was based on exploiting people in horrible ways."
8. Robin Leach Is Interested Primarily in Gossip: "It's not a fascination with gossip but with people," he said. "All my life I've been doing people-motivated journalism. It comes from the curiosity I have about what makes other people tick."
9. Robin Leach Has a Cockney Accent: His accent isn't true Cockney but a hybrid with "a bit of Manchester," he said. Mr. Leach said he spent two years in that city after spending his first 16-and-a-half years in Harrow, 18 miles from London. "Mine is a strange accent that has a harsh tone on some consonants," he said. Sometimes it sounds almost Australian.
The cartoon-character Robin Leach talks in a voice "that Rich Little said is just south of Howard Cosell in terms of arrogance, and just north of the adenoids," said Mr. Leach. "Unlike the politician, who's usually brought babies to kiss, I can't tell you how many parents ask me to listen to their 7-year-olds' bad Robin Leach imitations."
10. Robin Leach Broadcasts Trash TV: "Compared to 'Geraldo,' we look like Masterpiece Theater," said Mr. Leach. "We do sizzle, but we don't do sensation. None of our shows is trash TV. We offer the best in infotainment. You'd never catch us doing a show about nuns who become transvestites, or vice versa. You'll never see me in a dress like Phil Donahue."
Couldn't the content of Mr. Leach's shows have more calories? "We are what we are," he said. "People criticize us for being empty TV without substance, but that's what TV is. TV is the click of life. You know, the remote box." He pretended to be a viewer holding a remote-control, changing channels. "You have to grab the viewer's attention or -- click!"
For years, critics have denigrated Mr. Leach's shows, deploring his breezy pseudo-reportorial style that seems to have been inspired not by news but by hotel, resort and entertainment tie-ins, and disparaging his glorification of conspicuous consumption. " 'Lifestyles' is seen to be about money, but that's not true," he responded. "The audience sees it as fun and entertaining. The audience also learns something -- that capitalism, though not perfect, is the best system. The Russians are learning that now. We say it's O.K. to better your life. We say that the American dream is still alive and well."
Isn't all this fascination with the wealthy somewhat twisted? "I think it's eminently healthy," he said. "The American capitalist system offers the chance at the best of what there is. And 'Lifestyles' keeps banging home the values of the good life. The idea is, work hard and you'll be rewarded."
11. Robin Leach Sees Himself Primarily as a Performer: "I am a businessman who, every once in awhile, stands in front of the camera and screeches his screech," Mr. Leach said. "We are very, very serious about what we do. TV is an art, but it's not brain surgery. It's a business.
"We aim for the mass market and put it in a package," he said, adding that the package was first wrapped in the world of the tabloids. "I believe in talking in 96-point," he said referring to the screaming headlines of Fleet Street, where he once worked. "I write short sentences. No sentence shall be more than 10 words long. No word shall have more than seven letters. I love cliches. I love alliteration. On television, you can wrap your tongue around cliches and aggressive verbs."
12. Robin Leach Can Keep Working 18-Hour Days Forever: "I suppose that, after 10 years of 'Lifestyles,' I'll have to limp into the sunset like Chester," he said. "Then I'll be 50, and look it. My hairline has been going backwards, and my waistline has been going forwards. The question is, at age 50, will audiences want to see this slightly balding, overweight Englishman, crumpled in a chair?"
13. Robin Leach Will One Day Be Absent From Television: " 'Lifestyles' and 'Runaway' have a very long shelf life," he said. "They'll run forever. They'll still be running when I'm dead."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mr. Leach being filmed on Times Square in a segment for his new weekday series, "Preview: First Look at the New"--"I am the most unlikely star in the world." (Neal Boenzi/The New York Times )

SECTION: Section 6; Part 2; Page 16; Column 1; Business World Magazine

LENGTH: 4217 words

HEADLINE: Cable Television;
Television's Real-Life Cable Baron

BYLINE: BY L. J. DAVIS; L. J. Davis, a frequent contributor to this magazine,
received research assistance for this article from Robert G. Woletz.

 BODY:
ASK THE AVERAGE COUCH POTATO about cable television, and he may tell you about MTV or the Home Shopping Network or complain about soaring rates and companies that seldom answer the phone. Odds are, the name John C. Malone will never come up in the more than 50 million households to which, directly or indirectly, he provides cable TV.
 In fact, John Malone, C.E.O. of Tele-Communications Incorporated, is perhaps the most powerful man in the television business and, indisputably, one of the most feared. It is Malone, for example, who once threatened to yank the popular sports network ESPN from T.C.I.'s many cable systems if a new rate structure were not negotiated by midnight of the day in question. 
John Malone's opinion and attitude is surmised at, guessed at, speculated at in every sports-rights negotiation, in every conversation investment bankers might have about the formation of a new cable service," says a ranking network executive who is familiar with Malone's business practices. "Although John is a likable man, when you're negotiating with him, he will let you see his fangs. His power is real. And some of his rhetoric about the people he competes with, his rhetoric about the networks, certainly suggests that he considers himself intellectually superior to all of us. With some reason, I think, by the way."
 In his south-Denver office on a late-September morning, the 49-year-old Malone, the guiding spirit of the largest cable television company on the surface of the planet, looks hardly the consummate villain his numerous enemies describe. He is intense and handsome, clearly comfortable in his tweed trousers and green sweater-shirt -- and, surprisingly, trim. (The suits he wears, when protocol dictates, appear to have been tailored for an oil drum.) Nor does the T.C.I. headquarters, in a sleek new office tower across the street from a luxury hotel but otherwise surrounded by a sea of vacant lots, give hint to the awesome media empire Malone has assembled. As the result of a long series of shrewd, if often fiendishly complex, acquisitions, T.C.I. has a hand in piping a cable television signal to more than 11 million households in 48 states -- or roughly one-fifth of the American cable-viewing populace.
 Malone's company does much more than simply run a coaxial cable into those homes; it wields enormous influence over the programming that travels through that cable. T.C.I. holds equity stakes in 9 of the top 20 "basic" cable networks, the largest of which, the Cable News Network, reaches 55.3 million households.
 Malone's cable systems own the electric plumbing that delivers the television signals to his subscribers' homes. The programming networks, by contrast, create many of the shows that the signal carries. T.C.I.'s interest in both parts of the business, its vertical integration, gives Malone three bites of the apple. He receives the subscriber fees paid monthly to his cable systems, and his largest programming investments yield income from both advertising and the fees paid by other systems to carry the shows.
 T.C.I., in short, is an incredible money machine with an annual operating cash flow projected at $1.4 billion this year, more than any other company in the American television industry. And John Malone, the machine's chief engineer, makes no apologies for his success.
 "I think there's no question that I have the cable industry tattooed on one of my rear-end cheeks, and T.C.I. on the other," he says. "But I don't think I've been ruthless in anything. I don't think I've driven anybody out of business."
 If Malone sounds defensive, he has good reason. In an office down the hall, an aide monitors the nonprofit, public-affairs cable channel C-Span, which T.C.I. helped create. (Unique among television executives, Malone keeps no TV set in his office.) On this autumn day, C-Span is covering proceedings in the United States Senate -- activity of vital importance to T.C.I.'s future.
 The House had already passed, and the Senate was now considering, legislation that would effectively reregulate an industry that in the 1980's had won almost complete freedom from Government supervision and control. "What the cable industry can do and how it does it," says Malone, "is largely a function of what the Government permits it to do."
 As events subsequently transpired, the bill was stalled by Senator Timothy E. Wirth, the Colorado Democrat who has collected 19 percent of his campaign contributions over the last year and a half from cable executives and 33 percent of his PAC money from the cable industry itself -- including $10,000 received in April from Malone's T.C.I.
 But the reprieve, in all likelihood, will be only temporary. Most cable industry experts expect a new bill to emerge next year, one that might go even further in curtailing cable companies' power.
 If Malone feels that such legislative efforts are aimed directly at him, he has a certain amount of justification. "There's a joke going around Washington," says John Tinker, a New York-based Morgan Stanley & Company investment banker who specializes in cable television. "If you have a gun with two bullets, and you have Abu Nidal, Saddam Hussein and John Malone in a room, who would you shoot? The answer is John Malone -- twice, to make sure he's dead."
IN 1952, A FORMER OKLAHOMA cottonseed salesman and part-time rancher named Bob Magness sold his cattle, mortgaged his house and founded the company that would become Tele-Communications Inc.
 In that golden video era of "The George Gobel Show" and "Tom Corbett, Space Cadet," cable TV -- often called "community antenna television" -- was almost exclusively a means of carrying the broadcast networks to distant farms, homesteads and villages where the over-the-air signal was either weak or nonexistent.
 Stringing the lines himself from utility pole to utility pole, Magness completed cabling his first town, Memphis, Tex., in 1956. He proceeded to Montana and then, in 1965, moved his company, Community Television, to Denver. At that point he owned 17 cable systems with nearly 37,000 subscribers and a microwave-transmission business, which, like cable, primarily carried broadcast signals to distant locations.
 Magness renamed his operations Tele-Communications Inc. in 1968 and took it public in 1970. He did not entirely relinquish control, however. To this day, he and Malone, through their majority ownership of the company's Class B stock, account for 41 percent of the voting rights in T.C.I.
 From the earliest days, Magness operated according to two principles: "Keep It Simple" and "Pay Interest, Not Taxes." The latter credo, based on his belief that the most effective way to accumulate assets is to borrow copiously while reporting very little profit, would find a receptive ear in the man who would eventually succeed Magness. In 1973, with T.C.I. falling deeply into trouble, Magness hired that person, 32-year-old John Malone, as president.
FOR A MAN SO YOUNG, Malone had already enjoyed an impressive career. Born in 1941 in Milford, Conn., John Charles Custer Malone graduated from Yale in 1963, with a double major in electrical engineering and economics, then joined AT&T as an economic planner. Malone went on to take an M.S. in operations research from Johns Hopkins in 1964 and a Ph.D. from the same university in industrial engineering five years later.
 He became a management consultant at McKinsey & Company in 1968, and two years later moved to the General Instrument Corporation, soon rising to president of its Jerrold cable-equipment division. At Jerrold, a key supplier to cable-systems operators, Malone's star burned with sufficient brightness to attract the attention of Warner Communications' chairman, Steven J. Ross. In 1972, Ross asked him to head up Warner's fledgling cable operation.
 Malone turned him down. "Some of the senior management were very good friends of mine, but their continued involvement would probably have been inconsistent with my coming in, if you know what I mean," he says. Unwilling to dismiss friends and eager to remove his family from the hectic New York metropolitan scene, Malone accepted Magness' invitation to work for him in Denver.
 "The early years of me and T.C.I. were really a workout," says Malone. "T.C.I. was struggling. It was overextended. But I liked the entrepreneurship. I liked the people. I wanted a career."
 As recently as 1972, T.C.I.'s stock had traded at $37. But it had tanked, and, after the stock market turned downward in 1974, it could be purchased for less than a dollar. Wall Street was effectively cut off as a source of new funds. Meanwhile, turmoil in the cable industry had shut off the credit markets.
 At that point, T.C.I.'s money-losing microwave subsidiary was one of the nation's largest microwave common carriers. And the cable subsidiary became the second-largest cable company the next year. Malone, however, was running a company whose long-term debt reached $122 million in 1976, serviced by an operating cash flow of only $19 million. Meeting this challenge was the making of John Malone.
 Although his financial achievements would become the envy of the industry, the man who slowly turned T.C.I. into the most powerful force in the cable industry remained virtually unknown to the public -- with some significant exceptions. In the 1970's and early 80's, Malone and T.C.I. became all too familiar to the residents of a handful of small municipalities.
 Too often, T.C.I.'s signal was poor, and its repairmen frequently failed to keep their appointments. In handling such complaints the company established a reputation for treating customers with utter disdain. A partial bill of particulars:
 * In 1973, rate negotiations stalled with local regulators in Vail, Colo., the local T.C.I. system shut off all programming for a weekend and ran nothing but the names and home phone numbers of the mayor and city manager. The harried local government gave in.
 * In 1981, T.C.I. withheld fees and vowed to go completely dark in Jefferson City, Mo., if the city failed to renew its franchise, while a T.C.I. employee -- "who turned out to have a psychological problem," says Malone -- threatened harm to the city's media consultant. Again, a beleaguered local government renewed the franchise -- although in a subsequent lawsuit, T.C.I. was fined $10.8 million in actual damages and $25 million in punitive damages.
 * In 1983, the small city of Kearney, Neb., also dissatisfied with poor service and rising rates, tried to give Malone some competition in the form of a rival system built by the regional telephone company. T.C.I. slashed fees and added channels until the enemy was driven from the field.
 "That's the dark side, if you will, of T.C.I.," says Richard J. MacDonald, a media analyst with New York-based MacDonald Grippo Riely, discussing the strong-arm days. But, he quickly adds, such methods were not confined to T.C.I. at a time when munici pal governments were the primary regulators of cable television.
IT WAS PROGRAMMERS -- Time Inc.'s Home Box Office and a Georgia entrepreneur, Ted Turner -- that propelled the cable industry into the great leap forward that made much of Malone's true and lasting power possible. HBO began broadcasting via satellite in 1975. The following year, Turner took the signal of his Atlanta television station, WTBS, and similarly beamed it skyward. HBO's movies and Turner's "superstation" were now available to every cable operator in the land.
 Satellites spawned a new generation of cable networks, created by programmers who put together video offerings and lined up advertisers to help pay for them. A single program could be sold simultaneously to any cable operator with the necessary "earth station" to receive the signal.
 "Malone understood the nature of the business sooner, quicker and more profoundly than any of the others did," says MacDonald. "He realized that large size meant lower costs. The bigger he was, the better the deals he could cut with his suppliers, which in turn boosted his cash flow. Everyone else in the industry stood around worrying about what Wall Street would think about their earnings. But Malone quickly realized that the debt market was awash with cheap money, and he went after it."
 Malone seemed to have a divining rod for money. In 1978, he pledged to give HBO access to his 660,000 subscribers in exchange for free satellite earth stations. That same year, Malone persuaded a group of institutional investors -- including the Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association, along with Equitable Life -- to lend T.C.I. $70.5 million. The largest cable loan in history to that point, the deal was made possible by the company's improved operating cash flow, by then $31.5 million and growing. In the early 80's, Malone gave the proliferating programming networks access to his cable systems in exchange for advance royalties -- obtaining, in effect, tens of millions of dollars in interest-free loans.
 But if Malone was bold and inventive in raising his money, he was cautious when it came to investing it. "We took a conservative strategy," he says, "of building the company up in little bites rather than great big swallows."
 Many little bites. By mid-1989, after 16 years with T.C.I., Malone had done an incredible 482 deals, on average one every two weeks. By the latter part of the 80's, the bites had become great big swallows. At least three acquisition deals -- Heritage Communications, United Artists Communications and Storer Communications -- ran more than $1 billion each.
THROUGH THE Early 1980's cable companies faced a bewildering maze of jurisdictions -- municipal, state and Federal -- responsible for regulating systems and dictating the fees the operators could charge subscribers. To placate these regulators, cable companies often made extravagant and sometimes impossible promises: limitless public-access channels and, perhaps more tempting, channels devoted solely to coverage of the mayor and city council.
 The cities, in turn, saw an opportunity to generate nontax revenue. Though Federally limited to charging the cable companies 3 percent of gross receipts, many municipalities charged as much as 5 percent. At the same time, many local officials, eager to please the voters with inexpensive cable television, placed artificially low ceilings on monthly cable fees.
 Congress, determined to streamline the regulatory system, passed the Cable Communications Policy Act of 1984. The law transferred primary oversight of cable rates from the cities to the Federal Communications Commission, where the Reagan-era commissioners interpreted their new powers in a way that effectively deregulated cable television.
 Among other measures, the agency eliminated rate regulation wherever a cable company operated in a competitive environment -- defined as the presence of at least three over-the-air broadcast signals in the cable operator's service area; most major markets, in other words.
 Even though they were no longer required to, virtually all cable systems continued to carry the major broadcast networks and important independent stations -- just as they had always done, at absolutely no cost to themselves. Meanwhile, the new-found ability to charge the subscribers any price the marketwould bear meant that a well-managed cable company now had ample funds to expand its system to carry the many new types of programs that had been created especially for the cable industry.
 By the end of the decade, most cable systems offered some three dozen channels to compete with the single channel each major broadcast network could provide. The fractionalized video marketplace seriously eroded the broadcasters' share of the audience.
 It was in this dramatically altered environment that John Malone consolidated his power.
IN 1987, MALONE led a consortium of cable holding companies, including Time Inc., that invested $568 million in Turner Broadcasting to save it from the disastrous consequences of Ted Turner's purchase of the MGM/UA film library. Suddenly, T.C.I. held 22 percent of Turner Broadcasting, including the all-news channel CNN, and Malone sat on Turner's board.
 Over the years, T.C.I. has also acquired other programmers, including 60 percent of the Prime Network group of regional sports channels; 50 percent of American Movie Classics; 49 percent of the Discovery Channel, and 20 percent of Black Entertainment Television.
 In Malone's view, there had been sound and even benign reasons for these investments. "We kept Turner in business," he says. "And without us, the little guys don't have a chance. The guys at the Discovery Channel ran around looking for someone who could help them. They ended up here."
 But Malone did not hesitate to throw his weight around. During rate negotiations, for example, Malone once threatened to use Turner Broadcasting to compete with ESPN for sports programming, and subsequently threatened to compete with Turner's CNN by forming a joint news venture with NBC. In both cases, he backed off after securing favorable terms.
 Lately, however, there are signs that the tables could turn. Consumers now demand that their cable systems carry such popular services as ESPN, MTV and the Turner networks. Whereas the programmers once paid the cable companies to transmit their services, the most popular ones now charge the cable operators -- and even indulge in blackmail of their own.
 Last New Year's Eve, Peter R. Barton, T.C.I.'s senior vice president for programming, stopped by his office to pick up some papers. On his desk was a telegram from ESPN. As of 12:01 A.M., New Year's Day, T.C.I. was to cease carrying ESPN everywhere in the country -- unless Malone's company agreed to a huge rate increase. T.C.I. had no choice. It paid, and passed the increase along to its subscribers.
 As the year wore on, the credit markets fell into a steep decline; the savings and loan crisis and the growing disarray in commercial banking had caught up to cable. During the 80's, fueled in no small part by Malone's shopping spree, the per-subscriber market price of a cable system had risen from $998 in 1983 to $2,328 in 1989.
 But with Federal bank examiners now looking with great disfavor on leveraged transactions, the money spigot was shut off. Malone had anticipated this situation by arranging for nearly a billion dollars' worth of credit, but he is no longer in a mood to deal.cw0
 "The Government is fishing for tuna and catching porpoises," he says. "Federal examiners are running around in a panic. You can't do an acquisition or a refinancing in the media industry today in the United States." Other types of deals were still possible, however, as Malone demonstrated in September, when he agreed to carry Fox Broadcasting -- the "fourth network" -- on all his systems. In essence, the deal makes T.C.I. the first formal network-broadcast affiliate in cable history.
 But by early November, Malone's attempt to buy 50 percent of Viacom International's pay-TV programming networks -- Showtime and The Movie Channel -- had been inexplicably stalled for months at the Federal Trade Commission. Malone was giving serious consideration to withdrawing his offer.
 He was also conspicuously absent as a bidder for the 20 percent share of ESPN that RJR Nabisco had placed on the block, and which the Hearst Corporation bought last month. "I can't understand why anybody would want to own 20 percent of a controlled company," Malone says of ESPN, the other 80 percent of which is owned by Capital Cities/ABC. "The other reason is that Tom Murphy [the chairman of Capital Cities/ABC] said we weren't an acceptable bidder."
CONGRESSMEN MAY have difficulty counting money, but they can count voters with astonishing accuracy. And while cable deregulation had been a boon for Malone and the industry, it had been decidedly less popular with the citizenry. "I'm hearing from the people," says Senator John C. Danforth, the Missouri Republican and ranking minority member of the Senate Commerce Committee.
 The General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress, has found that, since deregulation, the nation's 9,000 cable systems have raised rates for basic, bare-bones cable service an average of 43 percent. The average, though, masks the extremes, such as in Denver, where T.C.I. is a partner in the system. Between 1986 and 1989, the fee for basic service increased sevenfold in the Mile High City.
 "People think they're being gouged," says Danforth. "They think that service is deteriorating. They think the cable companies are monopolies." During the 1989-90 Congressional session, the impulse to reregulate cable became, for Malone and his industry colleagues, a dangerously nonpartisan issue. In June, the Senate Commerce Committee approved a bill that would have given the F.C.C. power to regulate basic cable rates and monitor prices for so-called premium services. In September, the full House passed its own, similar version of the legislation. In a transparent move, Malone and other cable operators responded by creating a new service tier, called "enhanced basic," that would place certain channels -- such as MTV and ESPN, traditionally part of the basic package -- beyond the reach of the House bill.
 Although adamantly opposed to the very idea of legislation, Malone portrays himself as a cable industry statesman. As a member of the executive committee for the politically powerful lobbying group, the National Cable Television Association, he says, "I've consistently voted with the N.C.T.A. majority in its attempts to accept a reasonable bill. But we have been skeptical from the beginning." Even so, "at the last minute, we encouraged Tim Wirth to try and negotiate a resolution."
 When the bill reached the Senate floor, Wirth criticized the legislation as going "far beyond" a simple redressing of consumer complaints. His opposition effectively stalled the bill. Subsequently, however, Wirth reached an eleventh-hour compromise with Senator Albert Gore Jr., the Tennessee Democrat whose constituents were particularly outraged over sudden rate hikes by their system operator, U.S. Cable.
 The sticking point between the two Senators had been a provision restricting the ability of cable companies to block the sale of programming to satellite broadcasters and microwave-transmission companies; Gore favored this provision, but it was intolerable to Wirth's constituent, John Malone. Wirth and Gore agreed that cable companies could retain exclusive rights to programming, so long as they did not "unreasonably" impede competition.
 In the end, opposition from the White House, which wanted no reregulation whatever, combined with the all-consuming budget crisis to prevent a cable bill from being passed -- this year.
 With the industry's legislative future in doubt, it is perhaps no coincidence that Malone recently, if belatedly, discovered the virtues of customer service. Telephones will be answered, T.C.I. has announced; repairmen will keep their appointments. And the company has begun replacing its coaxial-cable trunk lines with optical fiber, which will improve the signal and allow for a substantial increase in the number of channels.
 In October, T.C.I. also began running corporate-image TV spots on its cable systems and on broadcast stations in the company's biggest markets. The warm-and-fuzzy ads are in the tradition of the "morning in America" spots that were so effective for President Reagan during his 1984 campaign -- and, in fact, were produced by the same ad agency, Hal Riney & Partners.
The T.C.I. ads interweave traditional family values with a cable-is-good-for-America theme. In one spot, as the screen shows a child on a tricycle, then a young woman in her wedding gown, the announcer intones a subliminal anti-reregulation theme: "We all grow up -- never fast enough for some, and yet altogether too fast for others."
 Malone's board in October approved his idea to spin off T.C.I.'s minority investments in cable systems and programming -- except for Turner Broadcasting and the Discovery Channel -- into a new company to be called the Liberty Media Corporation. If and when the plan is implemented, T.C.I. would still largely control Liberty and its assets, which analysts have valued as high as $3 billion. Moreover, T.C.I. could always buy it back if the atmosphere improved.
 It "would be logical to assume," says Malone, that he hoped the spinoff would make the F.T.C. see the proposed Showtime transaction in a more favorable light. It might also serve to make T.C.I. look less monolithic in the eyes of key Congressmen.
 But on Capitol Hill, where lawmakers will return next month, Malone's antagonists remain grim and unforgiving. "In January, this thing is going to come back on T.C.I. and its pals with a vengeance," says Roy Neel, chief of staff to Senator Gore. "They have done everything in their power to stifle and kill competition. Next year, it will catch up with them. This arrogant chicken is about to come home to roost."

HEADLINE: Commercial Brokers Striving to Survive

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER

 BODY:
HOW do brokerages survive in a sagging market for commercial real estate? In the present downturn, some of the largest offices in the county have closed, including all those of Coldwell Banker and the Helmsley Companies. But other brokers, if not prospering, are at least coping, often by learning new strategies to take advantage of the opportunities that do exist.
 "We're in for hard times that are bound to get even worse, because we haven't hit the bottom yet," said Carl Austin, head of Austin Corporate Properties in Tarrytown, the commercial brokerage concern he founded 25 years ago. "The market may not recover for another four or five years." 
 In the county, Mr. Austin said, overbuilding has produced so much office space that there has to be a psychological adjustment to bridge the gap between what owners are asking and what buyers or renters are willing to pay. "And that won't come until the banks start foreclosing," he said. "Bank foreclosures act as a catalyst, and the smart money then will be able to cash in on some tremendous opportunities that are out there."
But the opportunity has to be created, Mr. Austin emphasized. "I compare the market to a mountain that has to be scaled, right now. In the 80's, it was an easy staircase up to the top. Now we have to carve out niches and gain footholds. It's not an impossible procedure. It can be done."
 
County Regarded Favorably
 Normal leasing activity has fallen off, with vacancy rates in Westchester at more than 20 percent for the second year. "Significant lease commitments have been made, however," Mr. Austin said, "and will continue to come -- primarily from relocating companies in New York City who are looking at Westchester more favorably because of economic conditions in the city.
He said his firm was also looking for new areas of business. "We're taking a look at the retail industry, for instance, in which we haven't been active since the 70's, when we were the brokers in the sale of land to Bergdorf Goodman. Just recently, we completed a deal for the sale of a two-acre parcel of land that will be incorporated into the Nordstrum Fashion Mall in White Plains."
More joint ventures and more consulting work are all part of doing business in the 90's, Mr. Austin said. "The ability to adjust to the times is absolutely critical," he said.
"This market has forced us to develop different aspects of our business, which I expect will stand us in good stead when the upturn comes. For instance, we've been making studies of the development potential of properties for several corporations, and the blueprint for activity will already be laid."
Although 11,000 real estate agents in the state have given up their licenses, and many commercial brokerages have left the field, others have changed direction and stayed in the industry.
Take Harold Wagner, for example. Mr. Wagner, a former head of a commercial brokerage company in White Plains, saw the handwriting on the wall right after the stock market plunge of October 1987, when, he said, he felt it was time to "become a player instead of a coach."
"I decided to close my brokerage company that employed eight brokers and to become a real estate consultant to corporations," said Mr. Wagner, who heads the Wagner Group in Bedford Hills. "And what has happened is that as companies downsize, one of the first things they let go is their in-house real estate departments. So in essence I fill that gap. I become the company's real estate department, either on a fee arrangement or a commission."
 
Opportunities for Mavericks
 Mr. Wagner said the soft commercial real estate market was full of opportunities for a "maverick like me."
Mr. Wagner, who took charge of the relocation of the Municipal Bond Insurance Association from its rented offices in White Plains to its new corporate headquarters building in Armonk, said:
"M.B.I.A. had a great opportunity to buy a 100,000-square-foot building in Armonk, ideal for its corporate headquarters. But the problem was it also had five years remaining on its lease in White Plains. And some creative financing had to come into play. So as a precondition of the deal, we made the owner of the Armonk property, who was anxious to sell, take over M.B.I.A.'s remaining lease in White Plains, which he agreed to do. Subsequently he was able to sublet the space. It just shows that he, too, had to be adaptable to make the deal."
Mr. Wagner said he was financially better off now than when he was running a commercial brokerage office. "In a way I'm lucky because I have always been intuitive," he said. "I knew it was time for change. New York City and Westchester have always been pretty well insulated from severe busts, but the S.&L. disaster is broader and deeper than anything that caused the other recessions."
 
Leaving the Helmsley Office
 Jack Pancaldo, head of First Corporation Property Consultants in Purchase, said he also felt intuitive.
"I had been a vice president and the manager of the Helmsley commercial real estate office in White Plains since 1976," Mr. Pancaldo said. "But in January of this year, I had a strong hunch it was time to leave. When I had an opportunity to become a broker/consultant, I took it.
"What happened was that in August, Helmsley closed all its commercial real estate offices and when I left there was no inkling of that. Now, most of the brokers who worked with me at Helmsley are with me again."
 
'It's Not All Black'
 Real estate in the 1990's, Mr. Pancaldo predicted, will require managing brokers to work much more closely with tenants.
"It's not all black," he said. "There are good deals around. A lot of New York companies are taking advantage of them and leaving the city. I know of 18 active transactions in Westchester that involve New York City companies. We're involved in 12 of them, and we're the exclusive agents for 4 of those."
Mr. Pancaldo stressed, however, that "people who are going bottom fishing, looking for absolute bargains, aren't going to find them. No owner is going to make a deal that loses him money."
Speaking about the number of projects now in default in Rockland and Fairfield Counties, John Rostenberg, a principal in Rostenberg/ Doern, a commercial brokerage house with offices in Purchase and Stanford, said: "Developers are walking away from projects in both places. That hasn't happened yet in Westchester."
Mr. Rostenberg also predicted that conditions would get worse before they get better. "We've been in business for 25 years and seen recessions come and go," he said. "Westchester/ Fairfield, with its diverse types of tenants, has pretty well escaped from serious recessions before. But this one, which involves the monetary system, is deeper. It's a time of change.
"A year ago, I predicted one-third of the brokers in Westchester would be gone by year's end. And I was right. I believe the same thing will happen this year, bringing the total number of brokers gone from the market to 60 percent."
Yet, there is business for the brokers who understand the market, Mr. Rostenberg emphasized. "We've noticed that a lot of firms are taking advantage of the times and moving from B space to A space," he said. "And there are leases coming from smaller companies that don't make big news. Tenants are more demanding and owners expect more from brokers in this climate."
Brokers who want to do business in the 1990's, he said, are going to have to work hard. "For one thing, they'll have to screen the financial profiles of prospective tenants very carefully, because the worst thing that can happen to a landlord is to have a tenant default on a lease."
 
Views of Tenants and Owners
 Mr. Rostenberg's office is handling the leasing of 10 Bank Street, the newest office complex in downtown White Plains, as well as the Center at Purchase, and Saxon Woods Office Park.
"Even though rents have come down, it takes longer to find tenants," he said. "But owners are very aggressive. In the better buildings, the trend is to write leases with staggered rentals and automatic step-ups in rent."
But the slump in the economy means that the price of housing and labor and the cost of relocating employees have gone down. "It's made Westchester look even more attractive to companies thinking of leaving New York City," Mr. Rostenberg said. "And that's the good news."
