SECTION: Section 6; Part 2; Page 8; Column 1; Business World Magazine

LENGTH: 1680 words

HEADLINE: Quarter Notes;
THE NEXT OIL SURPRISE

BYLINE: BY DANIEL YERGIN; Daniel Yergin is the author of "The Prize: The Epic Quest for Oil, Money and Power," which will be published this month by Simon & Schuster. He is the president of Cambridge Energy Research Associates, an international consulting firm.

 BODY:
THE SUDDEN JUMP IN OIL PRICES IN THE aftermath of the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait is the most recent of a series of surprises that has, since the early 1970's, shaken not only the world oil market, but the world economy and world politics as well. Each time, after the fact, the evidence has been reviewed and sifted, leaving little doubt that the surprise should not have been so much of a surprise.
Half a year before the October 1973 Yom Kippur War, which led to the Arab oil embargo and the quadrupling of oil prices, Egypt's president, Anwar el-Sadat, was talking aloud about using the "oil weapon" -- this at a time when the oil market was already tightening, eroding the surplus supplies that buffer the market against serious disruption. Early this year, six months before the invasion of Kuwait, the public rhetoric of Iraq's president, Saddam Hussein, was becoming increasingly belligerent in tone -- even while the oil market was once again tightening rather rapidly.
Where is the brew of political and economic forces that could produce the next oil surprise? Most eyes are still focused on the Middle East, yet there are good reasons to look elsewhere -- toward the Soviet Union, or whatever that huge land mass will be called a few years from now. What kind of surprise is it likely to be? Will it contribute to a new crisis -- or actually help avert one? 
 Though the fact is little recognized, the Soviet Union is the world's largest oil producer, last year churning out more than twice as much as Saudi Arabia. Moreover, the Soviets are second only to the Saudis as oil exporters. Since the days of the czars, Russia's petroleum industry has had a far-reaching impact on the global economy. And that history holds clues to what may happen in the next decade.
Back in the 1870's, the world oil industry was dominated by one company, John D. Rockefeller's Standard Oil Company of Ohio, and virtually all of the world's supply came not just from one country, the United States, but from a corner of a single state, Pennsylvania. Then the Russian Imperial Government changed the game.
Centuries before, Marco Polo had reported signs of oil in the Caucasus near the port of Baku on the Caspian Sea. In the early 19th century, a tiny, Government-run oil operation developed there, depending not on wells but on hand-dug pits. When the czarist regime eliminated the oil monopoly at the beginning of the 1870's, opening the door to private enterprise, it ignited a burst of investment and development, and there emerged a large, dynamic industry led by the Nobel and Rothschild families. Standard Oil's grip on the world market was broken, never to be regained, and by 1898 Russian oil production actually exceeded that of the United States. Therein lies one clue to the future.
Another clue is to be found in the Russian Revolution of 1905, which in the oil region primarily took the form of an ethnic civil war. The Moslem Tatars -- today generally known as Azerbaijanis -- rose up in rebellion, slaughtering Christian Armenians and setting the oil fields ablaze. The upheaval in the Caucasus constituted the world's first major political interruption of the oil supply, long before anyone had ever heard of an "oil weapon," and it threw the global market into turmoil.
Yet a third clue to the future of the Soviet oil industry arises from the 1920's. The new Bolshevik Government, desperate for hard currency, glutted the world market with Russian oil, driving down the price. That inspired the oil tycoons of the day to meet in August 1928 at Achnacarry Castle in Scotland, where they set about creating a worldwide cartel to manage prices and supply. This arrangement -- openly called the As-Is system -- lasted until World War II, and for a time even the Soviets participated.

IN THE LATE 1950's, THE SOVIET UNION, desperate once again for hard currency, launched another, even larger oil export campaign, part of what became known as the Soviet Economic Offensive. Allen W. Dulles, the Director of Central Intelligence, warned President Eisenhower, "The free world faces a quite dangerous situation in the Soviet capacity to dislocate established markets." Senator Kenneth B. Keating, the New York Republican, went even further, declaring: "Khrushchev has threatened to bury us on more than one occasion. It is now become increasingly evident that he would also like to drown us in a sea of oil if we let him get away with it."
In the Soviets' drive to win customers, they took to selling oil at enormous discount. In response, Standard Oil of New Jersey made what turned out to be the most famous oil price cut in history, a 7 percent reduction that amounted to 14 cents a barrel. The oil exporting countries were so furious that they came together in Baghdad in September 1960 and formed the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.
The record of past Soviet oil surprises offers some clues to what form the next surprise might take. So does the particular nature of that nation's petroleum industry today.
The Soviet Union's exports of oil and natural gas provide more than 60 percent of its hard-currency earnings, which in turn make it possible to buy the food and technology that keep the beleaguered country afloat. But the Soviet oil industry is in the grip of its own crisis, brought on by inefficiency and low productivity, poor organization and technological backwardness, wasteful expenditure and environmental neglect. "Energy policy has been the single most disruptive factor in Soviet industry since the mid-1970's and one of the leading proximate causes of the downturn and stagnation of Soviet economic growth," according to Thane Gustafson in "Crisis Amid Plenty," his most recent book on the industry. "For the reformers under Mikhail Gorbachev, no other issue of economic policy is so great an obstacle to their plans."
In the late 1970's, to take advantage of higher world oil prices, the Kremlin dramatically increased investment in oil production, actually starving other essential parts of the economy.
On one level, the spurt of investment worked: production continued to climb. But that success came at great cost in terms of wasteful expenditure and distortion of overall investment. And over the last two years, as the Government curtailed its investment in oil production, the effects have been dire. Production has plummeted by almost a million barrels a day since 1988, an 8 percent decline. The Soviet Union has been able to maintain its exports to the hard-currency West only because it has cut supplies to Eastern Europe -- and because the deeply depressed Soviet economy is using less oil.
Yet even that level of production will be hard to sustain. The Soviet oil industry is suffering from the same internal disorder and, indeed, demoralization that afflict the society as a whole. In western Siberia, where two-thirds of Soviet oil is now produced, massive unrest among oil workers, including the threat of a general strike, jeopardizes the operations of the petroleum industry. Moreover, the uncertainty over who currently controls oil resources -- Moscow or the would-be independent republics -- adds to the chaos.
Ethnic conflict represents another threat to oil production. Last year, a civil war between Azerbaijanis and Armenians led to bloody violence that was startlingly similar to that of 1905 -- except it was acted out with automatic weapons, not single-action rifles. Azerbaijan is not, as it was in those days, a center for oil production. It is, however, the main service and supply center for the nation's oil fields.
Two months ago, Moscow ordered an emergency allocation of $1 billion in hard currency to try to stem the production decline and reduce industry unrest. Still, based upon current trends, Soviet production could easily fall by another 1 million to 1.5 million barrels a day by mid-decade. And unless the oil requirements of the Soviet domestic economy are miraculously trimmed, that shortfall in production will come out of Soviet exports. If that reduction in world supply occurs at the wrong time, it could send prices spiraling upward again, renewing pressure on an already strained global market.
In other words, the next oil surprise could be a repeat of the past, complete with soaring gasoline prices and long lines at the gas pumps -- and with the Soviet Union playing the role previously reserved for the Middle East.

YET EVENTS COULD move in quite a different direction. Back in the 19th century, the breaking of the czarist Government's monopoly in the oil region and the introduction of Western capital and technology led to the development of the modern oil industry. Today, the Communist Government's monopoly is being broken, and the industry is once again eager to attract Western money and know-how.
Many Western companies are already actively seeking exploration and production opportunities, though they find themselves hindered by the political conflicts, confusions and uncertainties that characterize the entire Soviet system today. In some cases, even when the companies receive approvals from Moscow and the individual republics, they still run into environmental opposition from local groups. Yet the companies seem determined to drive ahead, convinced that the various governments in the Soviet Union will eventually remove most obstacles to foreign participation.
So the next Soviet oil surprise might be a sharp drop in production and exports in the next few years -- or, later in the decade, a sharp rise in production and exports. Perhaps both scenarios will take place -- yet another surprise! If the political situation there stabilizes, and Western companies are permitted to operate on a large scale, the Soviet Union could be an even more significant player in the global oil market by the end of the 90's.
In the West, a resurgence of oil exports from a one-time enemy would most likely be accorded a warm welcome -- not least because the increased exports would lessen the world's overdependence on the Middle East.

HEADLINE: Calhoun County Goes Global

BYLINE: BY JON BOWERMASTER; Jon Bowermaster is the co-author, with Will Steger, of "Saving the Earth: A Citizen's Guide to Environmental Action."

 BODY:
FROM HIS THIRD-FLOOR OFFICE, Mike Clayborne looks out over the verdant hills of Calhoun County, Ala., through the haze of a steamy spring afternoon. While the view is distinctly Southern, the conversation is purely global. Now in his second year as president of the local Chamber of Commerce, in Anniston, Clayborne is describing how his community is participating in the world marketplace: competing for branch plants from Southeast Asia, marketing a variety of services across Europe and Asia, selling Alabama-made goods to markets from Norway to Saudi Arabia.
On the credenza behind him sits a small black flag holder, with miniatures of the Stars and Stripes and the Alabama state flag protruding at angles from each side. Between them is the flag of South Korea. While Clayborne holds forth about the county's latest trade mission (to Japan) and the Memphis public relations firm that was recently hired to help promote Calhoun County worldwide, I ask if that little Korean flag is aimed at a particularly ripe prospect. He smiles and reaches into his desk drawer and comes out with a fistful of miniature flags -- from Great Britain, Japan, Finland, Hungary, Yugoslavia, Taiwan and a couple of countries he can't identify. "These are key economic development weapons today," he says, brandishing the flags that he picked up for a dollar apiece at a variety store in Gatlinburg, Tenn. 
 "We feel the world's economy is a two-way street," Clayborne says with a determined grimace, "and that there's plenty of room for all of us. If these little flags help one iota, the symbolism is worth every penny."

IT IS HARDLY A SECRET THAT THE WORLD ECONOMY HAS become one big, evolving, complex international bazaar. Chopsticks are made in Minnesota for export to Japan. Schwinn bicycles are made in Hungary; so are G.E. light bulbs and Levi's
jeans. Silos made in North Dakota are cut in half and shipped to Norway as warehouses. Chicken feet -- once the refuse of Virginia poultry fanciers -- are sent to Hong Kong, to be made into soup. In Japan, Mazda manufactures the Ford Probe, partly owned by Ford. It's sold as an American car. "There is no longer such a thing as an 'American economy,' " insists Robert B. Reich, an economist and Harvard professor.
As a result of all this global economic shrinking and booming, industrial development has taken on new twists in places like Calhoun County, Ala. Until recently a slick economic development presentation consisted of sending out a couple of officials with a slide projector to show pictures of vacant industrial land. Today those officials are as likely to be courting new businesses in Cairo as in Chicago.
It used to be that to woo new business to town, Calhoun's leaders would gather prospective investors over tables full of barbecued pork, char-grilled catfish, fried chicken, corn on the cob, coleslaw, fries and an array of spicy sauces at Betty's Bar-B-Q or the Goal Post. They would boast about the county's cheap wages and lack of unions. Today those pitches are more likely to take place over kimchi at one of several local Oriental restaurants.
Yet Calhoun County, Ala., couldn't be more red, white and blue. Giant American flags decorate the water towers across the county; three more hang, hugely, from the rafters of the Quintard Mall. Most offices and front porches boast the Stars and Stripes, and not just on holidays.
The 158-year-old county is wedged into a narrow sluice cut through the foothills of the Appalachians in eastern Alabama; Atlanta lies 90 miles to the east, Birmingham 60 to the west. Between are long stretches of blacktop lined by little but scrub pine, sandy soil and smaller, quieter towns. The biggest employer in the county is the Federal Government: the Army's Fort McClellan pumps more than $300 million a year into the local community, the Anniston Army Depot an additional $260 million. The county's economy has been steeped in small manufacturing since the 1870's: pig iron, textiles and cast-iron pipe have been its backbone. Bass fishing is the biggest participant sport, football and stock-car racing the activities most favored by spectators. There are no liquor sales on Sunday, no parking meters on the wide cement streets of Anniston, the county seat, (population 35,000). This is no new-age suburb -- no "penturbia" nor "micropolitan" -- but small-town America in the deep South.
Despite the pervasive aura of Americana -- from the strip malls to the Stars and Bars -- around every corner in this rural county lie hints of an encroaching world. Five of its bigger manufacturing plants -- employing 10 percent of its work force -- are foreign-owned. Of the top 25 businesses in the county, 20 face stiff foreign competition. Three hundred jobs at Magic Chef are threatened by South Korea's entry into the microwave-oven market. Nearly a third of the local Monsanto plant's output was shut down after the financial instability that ensued from Tiananmen Square. A yellow, red and blue billboard on Highway 21 advertises "Full Gospel Korean Church." The local daily paper has recently hired its own foreign correspondent. At a Hardee's one early recent morning, conversation among several retirees revolved around the best way to pick huckleberries (seated, with a constant eye out for rattlesnakes) and the recent economic turmoil in Georgia. Soviet Georgia.
You might expect the long tentacles of the international economy to have infiltrated New York, Los Angeles and Miami. Yet there may be no better place to illustrate just how drastically the world economy has shrunk in recent years than in rural Alabama. In fact, virtually every town and county in the nation has stepped -- some boldly, some with hesitance -- into this changing marketplace. Many say just in time. From 1984 through March 1989, Japan invested $72 billion in the United States. Between 1987 and 1989, United States imports to Mexico increased by 70 percent, to $24.9 billion. In 1989 the United States sent $79 billion worth of goods to Canada. In Europe, 12 countries are working to create the world's largest common market, with 325 million consumers and a combined gross national product of nearly $5 trillion. Like everybody else, folks in Calhoun County want a piece of the action.
Competing in this new world mart is arduous, especially in Alabama. Most foreign investors know all about California and New York. Many think Atlanta is a state. But when it comes to Alabama, they generally think first of George Wallace, not exactly a selling point. The state ranks near the bottom in many categories deemed necessary to lure investment -- safe environment, good education, sound economy. Yet despite such apparent roadblocks to economic growth, Alabama has more than 190 foreign-based manufacturing investments from 22 nations, and finances three overseas development offices, in Tokyo, Seoul, and Eschborn, Germany.

BEYOND THE BORDERS of Calhoun County there is a feeling that it may soon be too late for some American industries to jump into the increasingly crowded global marketplace. As a result, some experts insist, American industry -- and government -- must make this new game a priority. Yet the question persists in many quarters: Is this a good thing? The answer is: It is unavoidable and inevitable.
"New technologies of worldwide communication and transportation have redrawn the playing field," Robert Reich says. "American industries no longer compete against Japanese or European industries. Rather, a company with headquarters in the United States, production facilities in Taiwan, and a marketing force spread across many nations competes with another, similarly ecumenical company."
Reich says places like Calhoun County are ripe for inclusion in this marketplace if they act now. "The new economy operates on a smaller scale and is far better suited to rural environments," he insists, but cautions that rural America must shift its dependence from productions of low-value, high-volume products like grain and simple manufactured goods to high-tech manufacturing services.
Others believe that sending local chamber representatives out after foreign investment is a boondoggle that brings little improvement to local economies. Carol Conway, deputy director of the Southern Growth Policies Board, says Calhoun's leaders should leave such tasks up to people with more experience: there are now a multitude of state and Federal agencies that specialize in working with foreign investors. "Even if they do get face to face with a potential foreign client, are they up on global policy enough to not insult their audience?" Conway wonders. "Do they understand foreign protocol? Not even a lot of state international development offices are as knowledgeable as they should be."
There are also pros and cons to the methods used to attract foreign investment, whether it be the sale of an existing business or a new branch operation. "The pros are -- especially with the Japanese -- you are bound to have fresh investment, not just mergers and acquisitions," Conway says. "It also gives an international flavor to the community, which we desperately need. The cons are dependent upon how you attract them, what you're promising them. If you're promising tax breaks that last for years and years, that's hardly the best use of public funds."
Reich says: "The mistake often made by local chambers of commerce and state governors when drumming up business is that they focus only on the number of jobs, not the quality of jobs. Attracting Volkswagen or Honda to set up a facility nearby employing 5,000 routine assembly-line jobs at a cost of $5 million in tax abatements may not be a great accomplishment.
"Ultimately for a British, Dutch or Japanese company to come into town isn't necessarily better or worse than a California or Massachusetts company. If they bring good jobs, build up the ability of the work force, this type of 'foreign' investment is probably a big plus. But if jobs are unskilled or routine, and fail to add new skills, the investment may ultimately cause small towns to suffer in the long run." Another generation of assembly-line workers is not what we need.
Not everyone in Alabama thinks jumping into the global marketplace is a good idea. June Collier, president and chairman of National Industries, a $124-million-a-year auto parts company based in the state capital, Montgomery, is a loud critic of United States companies who allow themselves to be bought by foreigners: "The first thing I would advise these 'leaders' is that they are derelict in their duty if they don't realize they are selling out our country." Once foreign companies have bought American businesses, Collier insists, they'll start using economic leverage to control politics and government. She would like to see a law that aims at shutting down foreign investment in the United States. "If you're not a citizen of this country," she says, "you should not be able to buy anything you can't take home with you."
Harvard's Reich maintains that Collier is out of step: "Whether she realizes it or not, we are all part of a global economy. Money is now international. It can be passed by a flick of a button from nation to nation. To try to put barriers across borders is as foolish as it fruitless."

BLUE MOUNTAIN (population 250) sits smack in the heart of Calhoun County. Its frame houses are crumbling and peeling; their predominantly black residents are old, veterans of decades of factory and field work.
The focal point of the tiny village is Blue Mountain Industries, a 93-year-old manufacturer of yarn, twine, rope and other textiles. Its sprawling red-brick plant has tin roofs and metal awnings. The whir of machinery drifts from inside the plant, through large windows open to the spring breeze. Behind, in an overgrown field, are two horseshoe pitches, a long-abandoned backstop and rickety bleachers. In front, an American flag waves against a bright blue sky.
The absentee owner of Blue Mountain Industries is Hanson Trust Ltd., a $12.5 billion British conglomerate that bought the mill in 1975 (the company's third foreign owner). Hanson owns many businesses in many countries -- Blue Mountain is just one in its portfolio. But according to Blue Mountain's president, Al Rothwell, who has been with the company since the 1950's, it makes little difference to Calhoun County who owns the company, as long as it stays profitable. The pluses of foreign ownership? "You never have a cash crunch; there are plenty of dollars in hard times," he told The Anniston Star, the local newspaper. The downside? "When you're with a conglomerate, everything's for sale."
Blue Mountain Industries is just one of five foreign-owned manufacturers in Calhoun County. Defense Research Inc., a small-weapons-component maker, was sold to a West German defense contractor in May 1989. Jenkins Manufacturing Company, which sells wood and steel doors, has been owned by a British hardware manufacturer since 1987. Three Southern Ready-Mix plants are owned by a leading Finnish construction-materials maker. Southern Tool Inc., employer of 410, is owned by a $350-million-a-year British-based company, Triplex Lloyd.
County leaders expect that more home-grown manufacturers will sell out to foreign companies in the next few years, keeping pace with a national trend: the Bureau of Economic Analysis in Washington reports that in 1988, 24,460 non-bank companies in the United States were partly owned by foreign investors. The reasons for selling are varied but simple: sales bring expansion capital, openings to new markets and provide a base for further investment.
H. M. (Mack) Burt Jr. is chairman and chief executive officer of Southern Tool. A native of nearby Talladega, he has been with the company since 1968, and rose through the ranks until he was made a group vice president in 1979, charged with overseeing the Calhoun County factory, three plants in Atlanta and one in Scotland. In 1983 he put together a leveraged buyout of the precision castings maker. A year ago he closed the deal that sold the company to the British. Today a Union Jack flies briskly in the breeze in front of his factory.
Why did he sell and run the risk of raising local ire from businessmen who would prefer to see industry in town remain home-grown? "In late 1987 I could see that we were reaching the end of our ability to finance our own growth," says Burt, relaxing in a leather chair in his company's Oxford, Ala., headquarters. "Receivables and inventory were both up and cash had disappeared. But I could see there was still room to grow. We had to either borrow more money -- which venture capitalists are against -- or find another investor. And this one was not to be a financial play, but a strategic one."
With the help of a regional brokerage firm, Burt began looking for a buyer. "We had been approached by companies, most from the United States, but the chemistry just wasn't there. Then Triplex Lloyd surfaced. They wanted to establish a presence in the U.S., and they wanted a base company to build from." Burt checked them out, while they pored over his books. The deal was signed in July 1989. They have already assigned him the task of searching out more American businesses to buy, while the sale has opened doors for Southern Tool across Europe and given Burt $2 million or $3 million to invest in expansion.
Burt and Southern Tool are emblematic of one kind of cross-border investment -- selling existing businesses -- that has become prevalent across the United States. But many local governments are still making efforts to entice foreign investors to build new plants and branch operations in their town. Perhaps the most inventive -- some would say outlandish -- toolCalhoun County leaders are using to attract such investment is a planned Japanese school. Spearheading that effort is A. W. Bolt, a lawyer who attended Jacksonville State and has practiced in town since 1977.
Silver-haired and patrician, Bolt gets red-faced with frustration when talking about the forces that have compelled the town to go to such economic-development lengths. "We're just trying to play the game according to the rules that others have made," Bolt says. "If American industry continues to have the philosophy of 'Let's don't make it, let's just sell it,' and continues to try to make the easy buck on the sell -- if foreign countries are the only people who've got the guts and the know-how and the capital to manufacture, then they may be our ultimate saviors. So far we've found foreign investors to be right good citizens and we're glad they're here."
The Japanese school had its origins in one of the Chamber of Commerce missions to the Far East. "We found," Bolt says, "that one concern of Japanese businesses was that the executives they would send to America would bring their families, and their children's education would suffer by comparison to their peers back home. They were concerned they would be out of sync with language, math and the discipline the Japanese use in their educational system."
Based on those concerns, other communities in the United States have started "Saturday schools" -- classes intended to keep young Japanese students on a par with their competition back home. As an enticement to potential Japanese investors, a group of Calhoun County leaders raised $20,000, secured space at Jacksonville State, purchased textbooks and lined up a teacher. Now all they need are students. Clayborne, the chamber president, insists a Japanese company is one of his most desired goals -- nearly 6,000 Alabamians already work for Japanese-owned businesses, but none yet in his backyard.
While attempts to attract foreign investment get a lot of attention, many of Calhoun County's businesses have already plunged deeply into the changing marketplace. Ribbon, pool tables, twine, ball bearings, pumps, auto carpets, lumber, jet engine components, lamps, children's clothing -- all are made in Calhoun County and sold overseas from Scotland to Saudi Arabia. Steve Lopiano at Samson Cordage Works sells braided rope in Japan. Jim Ulrey at Southern Metal Processing licenses his company's technology across Europe. Roy Hathorn, chairman of R & J Machinery in Anniston, has sold his foundry equipment in 16 different countries since 1961, and is in the process of importing Chinese-made tractors for sale in the United States and elsewhere. "International sales could easily be 100 percent of our business one day," he says.
Trying to educate the local community about the changing world around it is the responsibility in part of The Anniston Star, published and edited by H. Brandt Ayers. His grandfather was an early publisher of the county's first paper, The Daily Hot Blast, which was founded in 1883; the paper's motto was: "Three essentials of a good home -- 1. Pure Air; 2. Good water; 3. A salubrious climate." Ayers knows that if his hometown is to prosper, that motto must be stretched to include "international understanding."
Ayers has been involved in foreign affairs all his life. His grandfather sold the paper to become the first Southern Baptist missionary to China. When his father, Col. Harry Ayers, returned to Anniston and bought the paper back, his own worldly philosophy was wrapped up in the warning he gave his two children over the nightly dinner table: "He who fails to take heed of problems far away will soon find trouble near at hand."
As a result of that early indoctrination, The Star includes an abundance of foreign coverage. Recently, Ayers hired a reporter to work half time covering local business, and the other half traveling the world reporting economic and social stories from a Calhoun County perspective. "It's a world that's gotten very, very small," he says, "and if we're going to try and deal with it, we've got to know the competition. What they're thinking, what their lives are like. What we want our guy to send back are Ernie Pyle-like stories. I want him to go to Korea, to a microwave plant, and ask them if they give a damn about Magic Chef in Anniston. I want him to give us a glimpse of that worker's life, so that we can better understand the competition. We can't wait to get that news from other news organizations, it'll be too late."

CALHOUN COUNTY recently had good economic news -- namely, that Defense Secretary Dick Cheney's proposal to shut down 35 military bases (one of which was Fort McClellan) has been shelved. People are also less concerned about the possibility of layoffs at the county's biggest employer, the Anniston Army Depot. The future of the nation's only Army base for rebuilding tanks has brightened considerably since troops and tanks were sent to Saudi Arabia.
Yet, if in years to come, defense budgets are slashed, the price of peace could still cost Calhoun County jobs. Elmer Wheatley, economic development guru of the Anniston Chamber, insists that now is the time to diversify the local economy by whatever means necessary. He is convinced that foreign investment is the county's ultimate economic savior, and that ultimately what is good for the businessman's pocket will prove good for the community at large. Wheatley points out his window where a pair of window washers dangle three stories above the sidewalk. "See these guys? They don't care who owns the businesses, as long as they get their paycheck every week, can stop at the Quik Mart on their way home and get a six-pack and watch the Atlanta Braves win a couple times a week on the tube."
For all the fast-coming economic changes, Calhoun County's leaders insist they are optimistic about the future. "There are only two basic human tendencies, fight or flight," A. W. Bolt says. "I think communities are much the same way. Most people in this community love it here. They're going to stay and fight."
And if in the next decade 50 percent or more of the local populace is employed by companies with foreign flags flying proudly in front of their Alabama plants, will Calhoun County have won the fight? "Probably," Bolt says with a frown. "Probably."

HEADLINE: Make Fuel Efficiency Our Gulf Strategy

BYLINE: By Amory B. Lovins and L. Hunter Lovins; Amory B. Lovins and L. Hunter Lovins are director of research and executive director of the Rocky Mountain Institute, an energy policy organization.

DATELINE: SNOWMASS, Colo.

 BODY:
Are we putting our kids in tanks because we didn't put them in efficient cars? Yes: We wouldn't have needed any oil from the Persian Gulf after 1985 if we'd simply kept on saving oil at the rate we did from 1977 through 1985.
Even now we could still roll back the oil dependence that perpetually holds our foreign policy hostage and distorts other U.S. priorities in the Middle East. Just by aiming at greater efficiency, we could eliminate all gulf imports by using only an eighth less oil. 
 A great place to start would be personal vehicles. Improving America's 19-mile-per-gallon household vehicle fleet by three miles per gallon could replace U.S. imports of oil from Iraq and Kuwait. Another nine miles per gallon would end the need for any oil from the Persian Gulf and, according to the Department of Energy, would cut the cost of driving to well below pre-crisis levels without sacrificing performance.
The Reagan Administration doubled 1985 oil imports from the gulf when it rolled back efficiency standards. Today's new cars average 29 miles per gallon; the fleet, only 20. Yet 10 manufacturers have built and tested attractive, low-pollution prototype cars that get 67 to 138 miles per gallon. Better design and stronger materials make some of these safer than today's cars, as well as more nimble and peppy.
And efficiency needn't mean smallness: only 4 percent of past car-efficiency gains came from downsizing. Some of the prototype cars comfortably hold four or five passengers, and two of them are said to cost nothing extra to build.
Many other oil savings can help. Boeing's new 777 jet will use about half the fuel per seat of a 727. Technical refinements can save most of the fuel used by heavy trucks, buses, ships and industry. Insulation, draftproofing and simple hot-water savings can displace most of the oil used in buildings. Superwindows that retain heat in winter and reject it in summer could save each year up to twice as much fuel as we get from Alaska.
In all, we know how to run the present U.S. economy on one-fifth the oil we are now using and the cost of saving each barrel would be less than $5. Even achieving just 15 percent of that potential oil savings would displace all the oil we've been importing from the gulf. Doing that requires only a small additional step. Since 1973, we've reduced our oil use per dollar of gross national product four and a half times as much as we'd need to reduce it today in order to eliminate all gulf imports.
How can we promote fuel efficiency? Higher gasoline taxes are a weak incentive to buy an efficient car, because gasoline costs four times less than the non-fuel costs of owning and running a car. And, since the often higher purchase price of an efficient car about cancels out the lower gasoline bills, the total cost per mile for 20- and 60- mile-per-gallon cars is about the same.
But the 40-mile-per-gallon difference represents more than twice America's imports from the gulf. If the security and environmental costs of inefficient cars had to be paid up front, buyers would choose more wisely. The best way is "feebates." When you register a new car, you pay a fee or get a rebate, depending on its efficiency. The fees would pay for the rebates.
Rebates for efficient cars should be based on the difference in efficiency between your new car and the old one -- which you'd scrap -- thus getting the most inefficient, dirtiest cars off the road first. That's good for Detroit, for the poor, for the environment and for displacing gulf oil sooner.
The California legislature recently approved car feebates by a margin of 7 to 1; Connecticut, Iowa and Massachusetts are weighing them. Feebates are also being considered for new buildings in California, Massachusetts and the four northwestern states and could be applied to trucks, aircraft, appliances and other energy-consuming goods. Unlike miles-per-gallon standards, feebates reward maximum performance and encourage businesses to bring superefficient models to market.
Energy efficiency is also the key to the decades-long transition to nondepleting, uninterruptible energy sources. Government studies confirm that sun, wind, water, geothermal heat and farm and forestry wastes can cost-effectively provide, within 40 years, half as much energy as America uses today. Efficiency would raise that share and buy the time needed for graceful conversion.
The military alternative to energy efficiency isn't cheap. Gulf jitters have added more than $40 billion a year to U.S. oil imports. Counting military costs, gulf oil now costs in excess of $100 a barrel.
The roughly $20 billion net cost of U.S. forces in the gulf just from August through December 1990, if spent instead on efficient use of oil, could displace all the oil now imported from the gulf. It could also create jobs and wealth, improve America's trade balance, stretch domestic reserves, clean urban air, cut acid rain and global warming and help the poor at home and abroad.
In 1989, the Pentagon used about 38 percent as much oil as the U.S. imported from Saudi Arabia, and estimated that its consumption could readily double or triple in a war. An M-1 tank gets 0.56 miles per gallon. An oil-fired aircraft carrier gets 17 feet per gallon. And no good outcome, in dollars, oil or blood, is in sight.
But from inside an efficient car, the gulf looks very different. From inside enough of them, its oil becomes irrelevant. National security, peacetime jobs in a competitive economy and the environment demand immediate mobilization -- not of tanks but of efficient cars, not of B-52s but of 777's, not of naval guns but of caulk guns.

HEADLINE: Doubts About Magnetic Train Mount

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your "Sakaigawa Journal" on Japan's planned 27-mile test track for superconductive magnetically levitated trains (Nov. 8) is a good description of the maglev project but fails to take account of its dangers and rising public resistance to it.
The highly respected Japan Environment Monitor (partly funded by the Toyota Foundation) notes that "while proponents of the maglev see this super express traveling at 350 m.p.h. aiding a booming economy with speed and convenience, they do not see the energy waste, environmental destruction and possible damage from nonionizing radiation." 
 Prof. Kawabata Toshio, the first to do research leading to the maglev and known as the father of the maglev, is now firmly against it. His chief criticism is its enormous waste of energy in a period of declining energy resources. Japan's railway system acknowledges that the maglev will consume at least three times as much power per passenger as the old bullet train (shinkansen); some critics say up to 40 times.
Unlike conventional trains, the maglev will carry little or no freight. Standing room will be far more limited because there are dangers involved in standing in the aisles at 350 miles per hour.
Dr. Nakahara Hideomi, a geneticist at Yamanashi Medical University, believes there is a problem "that affects everyone -- possible gene damage from electromagnetic radiation resulting in cancer and birth defects. They must clearly show that the radiation will not affect our genes or the fetus of a pregnant woman."
Grass-roots opposition began in Yamanashi Prefecture, where the experimental line will be built. The main opposition group is the Blue Sky Society led by Ueno Sakaru. It is coalescing with movements opposing nuclear power and dams. A national rally was held in Tokyo in October.
The Germans are working on a similar maglev. The United States, given its attitude toward mass transportation, has no plans now for such a project. It is important that Americans should be aware of the potential dangers that may arise if the United States undertakes a magnet-type train.
 
MARJORIE HOPE YOUNG
JAMES YOUNG
Wilmington, Ohio, Nov. 12, 1990

HEADLINE: Ex-Vernon Owner Testifies

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: DALLAS, Dec. 2

 BODY:
The former owner of the Vernon Savings Association, Don R. Dixon, has testified at his bank fraud trial that the savings institution courted risky commercial loans to help it out of a financial slump.
Mr. Dixon, who is 50 years old, said on Friday that economic reasons were also behind Vernon's decision to seek new financial markets in California, where prosecutors contend that the institution's money was used to pay for two beach houses and prostitutes. 
 Mr. Dixon was indicted on 38 counts of conspiracy, misapplication of funds, making false statements and other crimes. If convicted on all counts, he could be sentenced to as long as 190 years in prison and fined as much as $9.5 million.
Federal regulators say Vernon's failure in 1987 cost taxpayers an estimated $1.3 billion.
Under questioning by his lawyer, Bill Ravkind, Mr. Dixon testified that he knew after acquiring Vernon in 1982 that he would have to go after risky commercial loans instead of safer investments to help the institution survive.
"Vernon financially was in the hole," Mr. Dixon said. "We were perfectly aware that to get out of the hole, we had to make those high-yield loans."
During Mr. Dixon's trial, which has lasted six weeks, prosecution witnesses have accused him of using money from Vernon for prostitutes, political contributions and the lease of a $2 million house in Solana Beach, Calif.
Mr. Dixon is scheduled to resume his testimony on Monday. Lawyers said closing arguments could take place late this week.

HEADLINE: Jobless Rate Rise Predicted

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The nation's unemployment rate could rise past 6 percent next year, the White House's chief economist said Friday.
Joblessness is not, however, likely to reach "anything as massive" as what occurred in previous recessions, said Michael Boskin, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers.
"Unemployment could rise to the low- to mid-sixes next year," he said in a speech to the Japan Society.
The nation's unemployment rate stood at 5.7 percent in both October and September of this year. In 1982, during the last recession, it peaked at 10.8 percent.
Mr. Boskin declined to comment on November employment figures, which are scheduled to be released next Friday.
He said the economy was currently under strain because of higher oil prices as well as more restrictive bank lending. Oil prices should decline in the second half of 1991, he said.

HEADLINE: Profit Decline Projected For Chemical Industry

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
Hard hit by the cost increases brought about by the crisis in the Middle East and by overcapacity at home, the American chemical industry will see its after-tax profits fall this year for the first time since 1985, the industry's trade association has reported.
The report, released over the weekend by the Chemical Manufacturers Association, forecast that after-tax profits this year would total between $19 billion and $22.5 billion, down from $24.8 billion last year. The chemical industry has been one of the most profitable in the recent years and has seen robust growth in earnings in each of the last five years. Industry profits have climbed steadily from $9.5 billion in 1985. 
 But higher crude oil prices in the second half of this year have begun to affect prices for products that are important components in making chemicals, and chemical manufacturers have not been able to pass along all of those higher costs to their customers.
The association, which compiled its information in part from a survey of its members, predicted that sales for the industry would rise 3 percent this year, to $263 billion, and that continued high exports would contribute to that increase. The association represents about 90 percent of the nation's chemical manufacturers.
"This is a period of profitless prosperity in the chemical industry," said Anantha K. S. Raman, president of Anantha Raman & Company, an investment firm based in Parsippany, N.J., that specializes in the chemical industry. "Demand is very strong and people are buying hand over fist. On the other hand, there is the assumption on the part of buyers that the economy has slowed and that the buyer is in control and not the seller."
Allen J. Lenz, chief economist with the Washington-based trade association, said, "It's safe to say that there will be instances where we won't be able to pass cost increases on."
Higher costs have been a particular problem for chemical manufacturers since the invasion of Kuwait by Iraq on Aug. 2. For example, the price of naphtha, a product that comes out of refineries and is used in making propylene, ethylene and benzene, has soared from $160 a metric ton before the invasion to $320 a metric ton. And there have been similar increases in the spot prices of other products like benzene, a key ingredient of plastic packaging, and xylene, a chemical used as an octane enhancer and an important ingredient in making plastic bottles.
The report forecasts the operating rates in the nation's chemical plants will average 81.7 percent of capacity this year, down from 83.4 percent in 1989. The report says members of the association forecast that operating rates will fall to an average of 80.7 percent next year.
 
Increase in Capital Spending
 Still, the report stated that chemical manufacturers planned to increase their capital spending by 13 percent, from $20.8 billion in 1990. The 1990 figure was up slightly from last year's level. Also, research and development spending is projected to reach a record $12.7 billion in 1990, up from 11.7 billion last year.
"The chemical industry has been heavily buffeted this year by downward economic pressures at home and unexpected raw material increases brought on by the Iraqi invasion," Mr. Lenz said. "Still, the industry has shown itself to be remarkably resilient in 1990, and this bodes well for the future."
Employment in the chemical industry posted a small gain this year, with an average 1.08 million jobs, up slightly from 1.07 million last year.

HEADLINE: A.T.&T. Strained by a Success

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

 BODY:
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company's Universal card has been a bigger success than the company ever anticipated -- and that is exactly the problem.
Consumer demand for the card was so heavy after its introduction in March that A.T.& T. was unprepared to handle the millions of applications. The result was delays, billing errors and other problems that irritated some customers and led some to cancel their cards. 
 The company says the problems have been solved -- partly because it has reduced advertising and let demand drop. But the card remains a big success, with 4.1 million accounts opened in just eight months. Only Citibank, Chase Manhattan, Bank of America and First Chicago have more bank credit card accounts in use.
Analysts attribute the fast start largely to A.T.& T.'s guarantee that it will never charge an annual fee to anyone who applies for the card in 1990 and uses it at least once a year. Tomorrow, the company plans to announce whether it will extend that offer. Credit card industry experts expect a short extension, possibly combined with a slight tightening of rules, such as requiring that cards issued after Dec. 31 be used twice a year to avoid fees.
The Universal card is a Mastercard or Visa credit card combined with an A.T.& T. Calling Card. Consumers can use it to buy merchandise and make long-distance telephone calls at a 10 percent discount off A.T.& T.'s regular rates. Merchandise charges may be paid off in monthly installments, at an annual interest rate now at 18.9 percent, roughly the industry average. All telephone charges are required to be paid in full each month.
A.T.& T.'s growth has not gone unchallenged. Its rivals from both the charge-card and long-distance industries have scrambled to come up with countermeasures and form new marketing alliances. On Friday, Visa U.S.A., a trade group of banks that oversees the Visa credit card program, announced that it was temporarily banning financial institutions owned by nonbanking companies from setting up Visa card programs.
The president of A.T.& T.'s Universal card unit said in a recent interview that he has been seriously considering buying or setting up a special credit card bank to run the Universal program. Friday's ban, which will last until June 4, 1991, could represent a considerable obstacle.
 
Ran Out of Blanks
 Some snags were inevitable in starting an entirely new business and quickly setting up such a large organization, said David Robertson, a vice president of the Nilson Report, a credit card newsletter based in Santa Monica, Calif. "Once this initial 'getting out of the gate' process is over, they'll settle down," he said.
But along the way, A.T.& T. ran out of blank cards in August. As a result, customers who applied for the card in July had to wait up to a month for delivery, twice as long as the company's goal of just 15 days.
An unanticipated flood of applications in June and July also forced the company to hire hundreds of new employees, some of whom had little or no experience handling orders over the phone. What followed, said Paul Kahn, the president of A.T.& T.'s Universal card unit, was a surge in errors. For example, some customers who asked for the premium or "gold" version of the Universal Visa card were sent the regular Mastercard version. Then they were mistakenly told to cancel the card and fill out a new application.
A.T.& T. sharply reduced advertising for the card in the summer, when fewer people are watching television, he said, and used the resulting lull to fix shortcomings in the application and credit-checking procedures.
 
Depressed Earnings
 Paradoxically, A.T.& T.'s success has depressed the company's second- and third-quarter earnings. Consumers have charged more than $2 billion worth of purchases to the Universal card, and with new charges coming in much faster than consumers pay their bills, A.T.& T. has had to pay out the difference.
In the long run, the rapid expansion may mean that A.T.& T. will develop a large, stable portfolio of interest-paying customers sooner than if it acquired customers at a more sedate pace. Robert E. Allen, the chairman of A.T.& T., predicted on Oct. 30 at a meeting of Wall Street analysts that the card might become profitable within two years, the low end of the company's initial estimate of two to five years.
But the unexpected popularity of the card helped to derail A.T.& T.'s plans for 10 to 12 percent growth in earnings this year, and the company's stock has slid sharply since management acknowledged the slower earnings growth in late June.
The success has also provoked regulatory and legal challenges by other Visa and Mastercard issuers. And one of A.T.& T.'s strong initial marketing edges, the combination of a credit card and a discount-calling card, has faded quickly.
Several dozen card issuers, including Citibank on June 26 and the American Express Company on Oct. 29, announced alliances with the MCI Communications Corporation and U S Sprint to allow their credit cards to be used for calls. On Nov. 15, U S Sprint and Visa International, an association of national Visa groups like Visa U.S.A, announced an agreement to allow holders of Visa cards issued abroad to use them for phone calls in the United States.
 
Increased Work Force
 To cope with the increased business, A.T.& T.'s Universal card unit , based in Jacksonville, Fla., ballooned this year to 2,200 employees, from 200 on March 1.
One of A.T.& T.'s big problems has been keeping straight which customers asked for which of the four versions of the Universal card.
"I originally applied for the A.T.& T. Universal Visa gold card," said Joy R. Van Elderen, a book researcher in Washington. "I was sent a regular Mastercard, then I was sent a regular Visa card, and finally a Visa gold."
Universal card representatives required Ms. Van Elderen to fill out separate applications over the phone for all three cards, and separately cancel each of the first two cards.
Inquiries to credit bureaus about card applications remain on a person's credit record for two years, and can make it hard to obtain other cards, said Elgie Holstein, the president of Bank Card Holders of America, a consumer group based in Herndon, Va.
 
Interest Charges
 Sharon J. Kalin, a Wall Street arbitrager, had no problem getting her Universal card. But A.T.& T. never deposited one payment check, and was late depositing another check, charging her interest both times on amounts she had paid.
Ms. Kalin complained repeatedly and ended up dropping the card, although the company gave her credit for the interest both times. "I took it because it looked like a good deal," she said. "But I had a perfect credit rating, and now it was beginning to make my credit rating look funny because of late payments."
Mr. Kahn said such problems were rare. A.T.& T. hired its Universal card executives, including him, from the top credit card issuers, he said. "We do a better job than any of the banks that any of us came from."
When A.T.& T. surveyed some of its customers in September, it found that 52 percent rated the application process better than expected and none rated it worse, said Bruce E. Reid, a company spokesman. And 93 percent of those surveyed rated service for the Universal card as good or excellent, he said.
The popularity of the Universal card has also irritated established issuers of credit cards, who object to A.T.& T.'s complex arrangements to sponsor the card.
The cards are issued by the Universal Bank in Columbus, Ga., a three-employee subsidiary of the Synovus Financial Corporation. The bills are processed by Total System Services Inc., another Synovus subsidiary. The bank was set up last spring only to handle the Universal card, and at the end of each day sells all card charges to A.T.& T.
 
Banks Urge Legal Reviews
 Several big banks have urged four state and Federal agencies to review the legality of A.T.& T.'s arrangements, particularly whether A.T.& T. controls Universal Bank without having to obey banking laws and regulations.
The Visa group introduced new rules on Oct. 9 to prevent other industrial companies from making similar arrangements and said it would consider retroactively applying the rules to the Universal card. Friday's ban prevents companies from going around the rules by buying a bank or savings institution.
The Federal Reserve will probably make a decision within three or four months, while it may take six months to a year for the Federal Communications Commission to act, Mr. Kahn said. The Georgia Banking Department has dropped its investigation without taking action, but the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation is still reviewing the matter.
A.T.& T. has said that these complaints have no merit but that it is prepared, if necessary, to buy a special credit card bank to issue the Universal card, which would eliminate most grounds for the criticisms. The banking laws in Delaware, Ohio, Nevada and South Dakota would lend themselves to such a move, Mr. Kahn said. He added that A.T.& T. had no particular bank in mind and might charter a new one. But Friday's ban by Visa could block these plans.
Bank credit card executives also say that A.T.& T. cannot make money on the card without an annual fee. But Mr. Kahn said the banks' credit card profit margins had been so large with fees that A.T.& T. can do without them and still make money.

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
Ex-Defense Secretaries Advise Patience in Gulf

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 30

 BODY:
Most former Defense Secretaries counsel patience in resorting to military force against Iraq, saying that the United States should give economic sanctions more time to work.
The views of the former Pentagon chiefs were expressed in recent interviews and at a conference here at the Southern Center for International Studies. 
 The advocacy of restraint by most of the former Secretaries was generally consistent with the views of two former Chairmen of the Joint Chiefs of Staff who testified on Capitol Hill on Wednesday that they think economic sanctions against Iraq should be given a year or more to work.
"I would continue with diplomatic and economic sanctions for some time," said former Defense Secretary Harold Brown, who served in the Carter Administration.
 
 McNamara's Position
 Robert S. McNamara, Defense Secretary during the Kennedy and Johnson Administrations, emphatically urged that sanctions be given 12 to 18 months to work, saying, "We have not by any means proven that they will not achieve their objective."
Critics of the Administration say there is no sense in risking American casualties if economic sanctions will work over time, and argue that the measures have not yet been fully tested. But supporters of the Administration say that further delay in taking military action will only enable Iraq to strengthen its hold on Kuwait and add that the prolonged presence of American troops in Saudi Arabia risks destablizing that desert kingdom and the fraying of the multinational coalition.
Wishing to avoid the appearance of undercutting the Bush Administration's campaign to press President Saddam Hussein to withdraw his forces from Kuwait, all of the former Defense Secretaries agreed that the United States needed to retain a credible threat of using force against Iraq.
Even so, some former Defense Secretaries from Republican as well as Democratic Administration were generally cautious about using force.
"War probably would create more problems than it would solve," said Frank C. Carlucci, Defense Secretary at the end of the Reagan Administration.
Mr. Carlucci also said it would be difficult to keep American troops in Saudi Arabia for a long period.
 
 Weinberger Favors Sanctions

Caspar W. Weinberger, who ran the Pentagon for most of the Reagan Administration, did not attend the conference. But he said in a recent interview that he thought sanctions would probably be effective in persuading Iraq to withdraw its forces from Kuwait if given time to work.
"If we apply the sanctions longer, we may well be able to accomplish what we want," Mr. Weinberger said. "I understand people get impatient and all, but I do not believe in rushing in and attacking early."
Mr. Weinberger also said that he believed Iraq was "some years away" from developing nuclear weapons, a threat that has been cited by some Bush Administration officials as possible ground for a strike against Iraq.
Elliot L. Richardson, who served briefly as Defense Secretary in the Nixon Administration, argued that American troops would not be misused by a long deployment on the Arabian Peninsula. "We ought not to assume that they are unable to display patience," Mr. Richardson said.
 
 Rumsfeld Sees Merit in Attack
 Of the former Pentagon chiefs, only Donald Rumsfeld, who served at the Pentagon in the Ford Administration and was a longtime political mentor of the present Defense Secretary, Dick Cheney, stressed the merits of an attack on Iraq.
Mr. Rumsfeld said that American air superiority could be used to destroy Iraqi nuclear and chemical weapons plants, decisively resolving Western and Saudi worries about those weapon programs.
"I am not the slightest bit uncomfortable with military action" to destroy such installations, he said.
But Mr. Rumsfeld also said that he was "not terribly enamored" of suggestions that the United States launch a ground attack to pry the Iraqis out of Kuwait, and added that the Bush Administration had put too many troops in Saudi Arabia to maintain a long-term presence there at that level.
Melvin R. Laird, a Defense Secretary during the Nixon Administration who has been advising the Bush Administration on the gulf crisis, said that it would be a mistake to signal Mr. Hussein that the United States would rely entirely on sanctions during the next several months and would be unlikely to use force during that period.
"The important thing here is that we have until the 15th of January to get down to some very serious business with Saddam Hussein," Mr. Laird said. "It would be a very grave error to send a direct message about what we will or will not do."
 
 Support for Cheney

Mr. Laird said that "we have one Secretary of Defense at a time," adding that he would support the testimony that Defense Secretary Cheney gives on Monday to the Senate Armed Services Committee.
James R. Schlesinger, Defense Secretary in the Nixon and Ford Administrations, has previously urged that sanctions be given a year or more to work and repeated those points today.
Mr. Schlesinger said he approved of the United Nations Security Council resolution authorizing the use of force as a means of keeping up the pressure on Iraq. But he added, referring to military force, that "there is no necessity to use it or to say now that we will use it."
Clark M. Clifford, Defense Secretary at the end of the Johnson Administration, was not at the conference and has not responded to recent requests for comment.

HEADLINE: Israelis Go On Strike to Fight a Tax to Absorb Emigres

BYLINE: By JOEL R. BRINKLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Dec. 2

 BODY:
Israel's national trade union all but shut the nation down today with a general strike protesting the Government's plan to tax Israelis to pay for the absorption of Soviet immigrants.
The Histadrut union, which represents workers in virtually all areas of public and private enterprise, shut down radio, television, air traffic, telecommunications, Government offices, banks, most schools, postal and port services. It put a number of other fields, including health services, on holiday schedules. 
 Ignoring a court order last week requiring many Histadrut workers to remain on the job, the union threatened to continue the strike indefinitely, until the Government reversed or modified its decision last week to raise taxes, lower the minimum wage and carry out other economic steps to pay for the resettlement of immigrants.
"The Government is exploiting the situation in the country to cause damage in matters vital to the workers that have nothing to do with the objective of absorbing immigrants," the Histadrut said last week.
 
Shift to the Taxpayer
 "We are ready to continue striking tomorrow and the day after that," Chaim Haberfield, the trade union chairman, warned today.
Until this year, the Government relied almost exclusively on donations from abroad, chiefly from the United States, to pay for resettlement costs. American Jews were repeatedly solicited to contribute hundreds of millions of dollars.
The immigrants are now arriving in such large numbers that even the foreign contributions are insufficient. Jewish fund-raisers abroad said they realized they could return to the well only so many times.
Still, Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said last week that when he meets with President Bush this month in Washington, he will ask for hundreds of millions of dollars in American loan guarantees, apart from the $400 million already provided.
Today the Israeli Government said that 30,000 immigrants arrived in November, 28,000 of them from the Soviet Union. The precise number is not known because the Absorption Ministry, which gathers the figures, is on strike.
 
Big Increase From October
 A total of about 30,000 would represent an increase of more than 40 percent over the 21,163 who arrived in October, which was a record number.
So far, 165,000 immigrants have arrived this year. And it now seems clear that the total for 1990 will be higher than for any year except 1949, the newly founded state's first full year, when 239,576 immigrants and refugees poured in.
Thousands of the immigrants lived in tents that year. Despite a year's warning, Israel has been so slow to build housing for this wave of immigrants that thousands of them may have to live in tents or similar temporary housing starting early next year.
No matter where they live, newcomers in 1991 will receive fewer benefits than the immigrants who are arriving now. Because the Government is running out of money, it has cut the amount of money and services that immigrants receive upon arriving, in some cases sharply.
But the strike today is a response to new economic steps affecting workers, not immigrants.
 
20 Percent Wage Cut
 As part of a package worked out last week for the 1991 national budget, the Government agreed to cut the minimum wage by 20 percent for the employee's first six months of work, from $521 a month to $417. The Government also proposed to place a 20 percent tax on certain types of interest earned by pension funds. Those are the provisions that most irked the workers' union.
The Government has also proposed a 5 percent surcharge on income taxes for all Israelis. With a top rate of 52 percent, Israeli taxes are already among the highest in the world.
The Government also plans to raise the national sales tax, applicable to nearly all purchases, from 16 percent to 18 percent.
Although the strike virtually closed the country down, it was peaceful and relatively quiet. Israeli strikers seldom organize pickets or hold large-scale public demonstrations. Strikers are more likely to stay home, or to go to the beach if the weather is warm.
Since a member of nearly every Israeli family belongs to the Histadrut, there is seldom much public complaint about the inconvenience caused by a strike, and that was again the case today.
 
Peres Sides With Workers
 The Labor Party leader Shimon Peres sided with the workers today and said the Government had been insensitive to their concerns.
"I think the Government behaved foolishly because the Histadrut is not against immigration and not against absorption," he said. The union has close ties with the Labor Party.
Politicians across the spectrum realize that Soviet immigration will be a potent issue in the next election.
More than 200,000 new Soviet immigrant voters will clearly have an impact on the nation's politics. And the wave of immigration is so important to most Israelis that successful integration of the newcomers will probably be viewed as the most important test of the current Government's success or failure.
Union officials have said repeatedly that they, too, are happy that so many Soviet Jews are choosing to move here. At the same time, they say they do not want to suffer economically as a result of the influx of newcomers.
Government officials were angered by the strike. Economic Minister David Magen said, "All those who heard the declarations of the Histadrut leaders could not but conclude that this strike is against the immigration."
 
Sharansky's Warning
 But Natan Sharansky, who has come to be viewed as a spokesman for the Soviet immigrants, warned that regardless of the reluctance of workers to pay for the absorption of immigrants, Israel had better find a way to come up with more jobs and housing.
Private organizations monitoring the immigrants' progress have determined that of the 3,000 Soviet scientists who have arrived so far this year, only 160 have found jobs. Mr. Sharansky said he was worried that many of the others would give up on Israel and emigrate to the United States.
And as for those who stay, Mr. Sharansky said, "I am worried that in half a year, there will be half a million immigrants in the streets or in tents, and then we will really have a civil war here."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Drop in Global Interest Rates Seen

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Global interest rates are likely to slide in coming months if war does not break out in the Middle East.
"Right now the United States is sort of out in front of the rest of the world," said Gary Schlossberg, a vice president and senior economist at the Wells Fargo Bank in San Francisco. "But we are probably going to see some decline in global interest rates. That is one reason why some of us feel the decline in the dollar is about over, because interest rate differentials will start to narrow." 
 Early in the year the promise of German unification, a stronger and more unified European Community and political problems in Japan helped to push foreign interest rates sharply above those in the United States. The increase intensified the struggle for investment capital.
 
Competition Still Intense
 Competition for capital is just as intense, but interest rates are expected to drop because of the general economic slowdown. Yet a number of credit market analysts and economists said that for the first time since World War II a downturn in the United States was not likely to mean that the rest of the world will fall into a recession.
Recessions were under way in Australia, Britain and Canada before the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait in August sent oil prices skyrocketing. The oil shock almost certainly added the United States to the list, economists said.
Unless oil prices remain high for a protracted period of time, a possibilty if a Mideast war breaks out, some analysts say the downturn will be contained.
 
Impact Viewed as Minimal
 "The Anglo-Saxon countries don't account for as much of global output as they did even 10 years ago, so that minimizes the impact," said Robert Hormats, vice chairman of Goldman, Sachs International. "But the oil crisis, which comes at a time of an international capital shortage and more stringent lending requirements at banks around the world all work in the direction of a general global slowdown in growth."
Mr. Hormats predicted that trade would be a less important mechanism for spreading recessions in the 1990's than it has been in the past. Countries that are relatively energy efficient and have strong balance sheets will be the ones whose economies will slow but not stop. "If you are energy inefficient and overleveraged, you are doubly hurt," he said. "The United States falls into both those categories."
Of the industrialized countries, Japan and Germany appear best able to prevent a slowdown from turning into a recession. But growth in these countries will be crimped.
 
Japanese Slowing Forecast
 In a new forecast, analysts at Salomon Brothers projected last week that growth in Japan will slow to just over 3 percent next year, from 6.1 percent in 1990. And a slowdown in its principal trading partners will blunt the economic stimulus of unification and bring German growth down to about 3 percent next year from just over 4 percent in 1990, the Salomon analysts said. In anticipation of slower growth, Japanese interest rates are starting to fall.
By comparison, from the fourth quarter of 1990 to the fourth quarter of 1991, output in the United States is projected by Salomon to decline by 1.5 percent, the worst performance among leading Western economies.
"The 1991 economic outlook for the Group of Seven industrialized countries is the weakest since the early 1980's, but we don't think there will be a worldwide recession," said Anita Lauria, an economist at Salomon. "But if the average world oil price next year is higher than the $28 per barrel we currently assume, there will be a lot more pain in a lot of corners of the world."
Closer to home, those looking for additional signs of economic weakness in the American economy will probably find them in reports to be released this week, analysts said. If those forecasts are borne out, further declines in interest rates are almost certain to follow.
"The economic numbers will reinforce the concept that rates will come down," said Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at the Chase Manhattan Bank. "November is shaping up as being equally as weak as October was."
 
Jobless Data on Friday
 A snapshot of how the manufacturing sector fared last month is expected today, when the nation's purchasing managers release their survey. But truly substantive information will not be available until Friday, when November employment data are scheduled to be issued by the Labor Department.
Mr. Fine and other analysts predicted that the report will probably remove any residual doubt that the economy is sliding into a recession.
Propelled by additional layoffs in goods-producing industries like autos, nonfarm payroll employment fell sharply last month, analysts agree. The only question is by how much.
As of late last week, optimists were projecting a decline of 50,000, while pessimists were expecting a decline of 150,000. Analysts said the report would also show that the unemployment rate, which stood at 5.7 percent in October, probably shot up last month, perhaps to as high as 6 percent.
Those sorts of numbers would probably persuade the Federal Reserve to push for another quarter-point reduction in the overnight Federal funds rate, which the central bank only recently lowered to 7 1/2 percent, analysts said.
"We feel the numbers will be weak enough to encourage the Fed to ease one more time before the year is out," Wells Fargo's Mr. Schlossberg said.

HEADLINE: Brooklyn Bishop Sends Diocese A Pastoral Letter Against Racism

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
In his first pastoral letter to Roman Catholic congregations in Brooklyn and Queens -- the setting for some of the worst racial incidents in New York City -- Bishop Thomas V. Daily called for a fight against racism.
"If God is our Father, we must be related to one another as brother and sister," said Bishop Daily, in the first such letter he has issued to the diocese, which covers Brooklyn and Queens, since his installment in April. "Race, creed, color, sex, national origin, language, culture or condition in life are irrelevant." 
 Bishop Daily called upon educators, politicians, business leaders, police officers and journalists to fight racism and the attitudes and institutions that perpetuate it. He also implored city residents to rid themselves of the tendency to stereotype and to make judgments about people based on physical characteristics and economic status.
He alluded to several racially motivated crimes in the diocese that have grabbed national headlines in the last few years.
 
 'The Right to Travel Safely'
 In August of last year, a group of white youths swinging baseball bats and yelling racial epithets attacked three black teen-agers in Bensonhurst. In the incident, one of the blacks, 16-year-old Yusuf K. Hawkins, was killed. And in 1986, Michael Griffith, 23, a black man who was trying to escape an attack by several white youths, ran in front of a car on a highway in Howard Beach, Queens, and was killed.
"Every citizen should have the right to travel safely into and through any neighborhood, unmolested by insult or physical assault," Bishop Daily wrote. "When a black man is attacked in a white neighborhood, racism is often the root cause."
The pastoral letter also drew attention to anti-Semitism, quoting from a declaration issued after the second Vatican Council that said the Catholic Church rejected any discrimination and harassment based on religion. Last year three Jewish students were attacked outside a Brooklyn College fraternity house by several white men who pummeled them with feet, fists and beer bottles.
Although he is not the first bishop to issue such a letter focusing on racism, Bishop Daily indicated that he has placed paramount importance on the issue by making his comments in a pastoral letter. Pastoral letters, which are not binding on Catholics, place special emphasis on issues and set guidelines for church policy and for training seminarians and children who attend Catholic schools.
In an interview on Saturday, the Bishop noted that people of almost 100 different nationalities speaking roughly 70 languages lived in his diocese. He said that such diversity, concentrated in the dense urban environment of Queens and Brooklyn, could heighten racial tensions.
