HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL REPORT;
Top Official at GATT Faces a Round in Crisis

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GENEVA, Nov. 29

 BODY:
With the shadow of failure hanging over the global trade talks that begin in Brussels on Monday, Arthur Dunkel, the Director General of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, is all too aware that he can neither take sides nor impose solutions. "All I can do is to put them at a table and make them negotiate," he said.
After four years of the current round of trade talks, real negotiations -- in the sense of tit-for-tat concessions between major trading blocs on issues like agriculture, services and textiles -- have been left to the final hour. 
 "The round is in crisis, and the negotiators have to get out of this crisis in the first hours and days in Brussels," he warned. "If governments are not prepared from the very start of the conference to abandon well-known positions, then the conference will be a missed opportunity."
 
Cannot Decide Who Wins
 Mr. Dunkel, 58 years old, feels he has done all he can so far. He sees himself as manager of "a system of rules" who cannot decide who wins. Unlike the heads of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, he is a man "with totally empty pockets," he says, lacking the clout of a checkbook to make his views known.
His words nonetheless carry the weight of experience. Born in Lisbon and fluent in five languages, he spent 25 years as a Swiss Government official working on trade questions, including the Tokyo Round of trade negotiations that ended in 1980. And since then, as head of GATT, he has been preparing for this current round, known as the Uruguay Round because it began in that nation.
He is not a man given to hyperbole. Many governments are warning darkly of the dangers of protectionist trade wars if the Uruguay Round ends in failure, but the tall chain-smoking civil servant talks of "a slow erosion" of economic confidence and security -- "with occasional explosions" -- as a more likely consequence.
 
Taking a Broader View
 While attention has been focused on the deadlock over farm subsidies between the United States, which wants such programs cut sharply, and the 12-nation European Community, Mr. Dunkel looks further afield, underlining the political risks of failure to Latin American and Eastern European countries that are for the first time opening their economies to market forces.
"Those who have taught them the virtues of the market economy have a special responsibility now," he said in an interview in his office overlooking Lake Geneva. "Take the Poles. They abolished all agricultural subsidies. Now they look at the rest of the world and wonder, are we foolish?"
Yet, after 10 years in the job, Mr. Dunkel is not allowing himself to be pessimistic. "I knew it would be difficult," he said, "and it's more difficult than I expected one year ago. But if we can get agreements on agriculture, services and textiles, the rest will fall into place."
 
Effect of Deadline Pressure
 He hopes deadline pressure can help. Washington and other major capitals recognize that they have five days in which to achieve a political breakthrough.
"It's easier for a politician to go home after giving up an entrenched position if he can explain that, otherwise, he would have blown up the whole thing," Mr. Dunkel said.
One of Mr. Dunkel's weapons is his "green room," a conference room with green wallpaper where negotiators are frequently sequestered until they settle trade disputes. "He sits at the top of the table and fills the room with smoke until they agree," one Latin American ambassador to GATT recalled.
 
'Force of Personality'
 In general, delegates speak warmly of Mr. Dunkel as a personable civil servant and good negotiator who occasionally adopts the tone of a university professor. "His power comes more from force of personality and his ability to master details than from his office," one Western ambassador said. "And also, of course, we all need him."
Mr. Dunkel was reminded of the limits on his power only days ago, when he was reprimanded by the European Community simply for preparing a series of questions to be taken up by ministers from the 107 participating countries in Brussels.
"I have to take calculated risks because one of my roles is to help bring people together," he explained with a shrug. "You take risks when you think you can help the process. I was asked to put key questions on agriculture. I did it, and apparently I'm under strong attack from one of the sides."
To Mr. Dunkel, however, the many issues in dispute are closely interrelated, as ministers prepare to link concessions in one area to gains in another. "It's now a question of governments balancing off different pressure groups and defining their national interest," he said.
"That's the game," he went on. "How can some developing country come here seeking market openings in textiles and return home to say they got nothing on textiles but have reduced protectionism for local pharmaceutical companies? It's all a question of linkage now."
Mr. Dunkel is also looking beyond the Uruguay Round to two new subjects. "One is trade policies in the context of protection of the environment," he said. "The other is private restrictive business practices that fall outside traditional government control."
 
Leaving Post at End of 1992
 Those talks, however, may not take place on Mr. Dunkel's watch. He steps down from his post at the end of 1992, and he is already planning to see whether, as a business executive, he can apply some of the lessons he has been offering governments over the last decade.
"I come from a family of traders," he said, recalling that his father was a textiles designer who moved to Portugal in the 1930's to escape recession in Switzerland. "I spent a lot of my youth discussing business at the family table. But then I got caught up in government."
After 1992, though, he said he would end his career of public service. "Then I will go out into the real world," he added with a laugh.

HEADLINE: A.T.& T. Might Shift Cable Ships Abroad

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

 BODY:
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company is considering a plan to operate two new undersea cable-laying ships under foreign flags.
That would enable the company to employ foreign seamen at a fraction of the wages, perhaps one-tenth, of what an American crew could command. 
 "The primary reason if we did go this route is economics," said Michael D. Miller, a spokesman for A.T.& T., which has more stockholders among the American public than any other company. "With the present union setup on the ships, we are paying a substantial premium. We feel we could economize with a nonunion crew."
One of the two ships is scheduled to be christened next Monday in Singapore, and a decision is expected by next month, when the vessel is scheduled to go into service.
"You're talking about a lot of American jobs here," said an A.T.& T. employee who serves aboard the Long Lines, the company's main cable-laying vessel. "It has got a lot of us worried here."
The employee insisted on anonymity, saying he might be disciplined if he were identified. He said he thought A.T.& T. might register the ships in Greece.
Mr. Miller said no final decision had been made on whether to register the ships abroad or what crew to employ. He declined to comment on whether Greek registry was being considered.
The ship to be christened next Monday is the Global Link. The Global Sentinel is to be christened later. Both ships were completed in Singapore.
A.T.& T.'s consideration of foreign registration reflects a broad trend in American shipping.
The number of active deep-draft vessels flying the American flag has fallen to 379, from 770 in 1970. Besides the higher wages received by American crews, a variety of taxes, laws and more stringent safety rules that require additional safety equipment have prompted many companies to register ships abroad.
One result is that American-flag ships are in short supply for mobilization during crises, like the one in the Persian Gulf. The Defense Department has mobilized more than a dozen commercial vessels to ferry goods to American forces stationed in Saudi Arabia.
A.T.& T.'s cable-laying ships hold laboratories and rooms full of communications gear and are among the most technologically advanced vessels afloat. The company said it expected little difficulty in hiring foreign workers who could operate such equipment.
One A.T.& T. vessel, the Long Lines, was built in West Germany and has a crew four times as large as that on a supertanker. The big crew is needed to allow sailors and officers to maneuver the vessel carefully as it lays cables across undersea canyons and mountains. The crew also recovers and repairs broken cables at sea.
"It's a skilled job, and it's the type of job we'd like to have permanent crews on," said Edward B. Kelly, a vice president of the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association, which represents low-ranking officers aboard the Long Lines.
A.T.& T. has no plans to register the Long Lines abroad, Mr. Miller said. The union contracts for the vessel do not expire for two years.
The Long Lines has a crew of 70 and is based in Baltimore. A.T.& T.'s other cable-laying ship, the much smaller Charles L. Brown, was built in Naples, has a crew of 40 and is based in Honolulu. No foreigners serve aboard either vessel.
As demand increases for international telephone circuits, competition in the cable-laying business is increasing and more companies are building ships.
"We want to be a worldwide competitor in cable provision," Mr. Miller said. "Obviously we're concerned about the jobs on those ships, but behind those jobs are 2,000 jobs at Bell Labs and elsewhere that depend on our winning those cable contracts."
The result is more bidding for cable-laying contracts. A.T.& T. recently lost out on a $140 million contract from the United States Navy to construct a 500-mile underseas cable between Japan and Okinawa.
The contract went to STC P.L.C., a British company, which operates a cable factory in Portland, Ore. STC plans to load its vessel in Portland for shipment across the Pacific.
A.T.& T. sued the Navy, contending that the contract had violated a Federal law that required all American military cargoes to be carried in American-flag vessels.
The suit was filed in the Federal District Court in Alexandria, Va. The court ruled that the trans-Pacific shipment was not a big enough part of the contract to justify overturning the award to STC.
A.T.& T.'s two maritime unions, the Marine Engineers and the Seafarers International Union, with two trade associations of American shipping companies, joined A.T.& T. in the original suit and are appealing the ruling.
A.T.& T. has refused to join the appeal.
"Since they no longer have to be American-flag to get American contracts, why stick with American flags and American crews?" said J. Dinsmore Murphy, a lawyer representing the unions and the trade groups.
 
Negotiating With Unions
 A.T.& T. is negotiating contracts with the unions for its new ships, the Global Link and the Global Sentinel. Mr. Miller said the company's consideration of foreign registration was prompted by concern about the growing fleets of foreign cable-laying ships.
"This is a competitiveness issue, not a union issue," he added.

HEADLINE: Way Cleared On Alaskan Oil Project

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, Dec. 2

 BODY:
Production at a large Alaskan oilfield, discovered in 1989 two miles north of the vast reserves of Prudhoe Bay, is expected to begin within two years now that oil producers and the Federal Government say they have resolved an environmental dispute that had stalled the project.
The agreement was announced late Friday by the Army Corps of Engineers, ARCO, BP Exploration and Exxon. The Corps of Engineers was the main opponent of the project. It was not clear today whether other challenges might be brought during further licensing steps that might be required. 
 It was the second time in a week that big oil companies said they planned to pump more oil from large fields where production was blocked by disputes over environmental worries. The Chevron Corporation said Tuesday that it anticipated that a group of 18 oil companies it heads will produce as much as 20,000 barrels a day from the Point Arguello field, off the California coast near Santa Barbara, by next summer.
Negotiations in both cases were mediated by high-ranking officials at the Energy Department. The Administration has sought to increase domestic oil output because imports of 200,000 barrels a day of Kuwaiti oil were halted after the invasion by Iraq on Aug. 2.
Officials at the Army Corps of Engineers and at the Environmental Protection Agency held up production in the Point McIntyre field because they considered existing gravel causeways that extend from land into the shallow waters of the Beaufort Sea a threat to fish that migrate in those coastal waters.
A commercial fishery situated more than 100 miles west of the causeways relies on the Arctic char, broad whitefish, least cisco and Arctic cisco for its operations. The view of Federal officials was that the causeways appeared to raise salt concentrations and the temperature of the water to levels in some areas near the coast that would be harmful to the fish.
 
Oil Companies' Argument
 The oil companies disagreed, saying years of study at their expense had not indicated any bad effects from the causeways. "It has been and continues to be our position that variations caused by natural factors, like wind and current, far exceed any variations that you could attribute to the causeways," said Paul Laird, a spokesman in Anchorage for BP Exploration, a unit of the British Petroleum Company.
ARCO, B.P. and Exxon agreed to spend $50 million to clear several water passages in the gravel roadbeds first built for exploration drilling at the Point McIntyre field as well as at the nearby Endicott field.
The roadbeds extend 2.5 miles to the Point McIntyre field, and 5 miles to Endicott. The oil companies agreed to add a total of 650 feet of clearance for water at several locations in the causeways. The Endicott causeway was built initially with 700 feet of openings; the Point McIntyre causeway contains a 52-foot breach.
Brian Davies, a vice president for development at B.P., said the settlement announced Friday enabled the oil companies to move ahead with production and "avoids years of dispute and possible litigation."
 
Called a Reasonable Conclusion
 Col. William W. Kakel, Alaska district engineer for the Army Corps of Engineers, said the pact was a reasonable conclusion to the disagreement. He added that the agreement "recognizes that environmental quality and economic reality are both important in North Slope oil and gas decisions."
The oil companies own rights to an estimated 300 million barrels in the Point McIntyre field. Production from Point McIntyre and from the nearby Lisburne field could reach 100,000 barrels a day by 1994, said Al Greenstein, a spokesman at ARCO's headquarters in Los Angeles.
Output at the Lisburne field, already in production, is 40,000 barrels a day. The combined output of Lisburne and Point McIntyre will exceed 60,000 barrels when output from Point McIntyre begins by late summer in 1992, Mr. Greenstein said. An expansion set for the summer of 1993 should increase output in the combined project to between 80,000 and 100,000 barrels a day, he said.
Oil produced from the fields will flow through the Trans-Alaska Pipeline to the tanker port at Valdez, Alaska, with most of the output then shipped by tanker to West Coast refineries.
 
Pipeline Found Sound
ANCHORAGE, Dec. 2 (AP) -- The company that oversees the Trans-Alaska Pipeline said today that it had completed an investigation of reported corrosion and found the 800-mile pipeline to be sound. State and Federal regulators who supervised the monthlong inquiry by the Alyeska Pipeline Service Company said they had not decided whether to allow the company to increase pressure in the line. Oil producers want to increase the amount of crude pumped through the line, which links the North Slope with Valdez, to about 2.1 million barrels a day, from 2.06 million.

HEADLINE: New Aggressiveness at Times Mirror

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN

 BODY:
When Thomas Plate left New York Newsday last year to become editorial page editor of The Los Angeles Times, the meeting to announce his arrival turned into a fiasco. A member of The Times's editorial staff abruptly stood up, asked, "Is this a meeting or an announcement?" and then embarked on a fiery 15-minute diatribe against the appointment of somebody from outside the paper.
This unusual outburst, which stunned the editors and executives present, reflected uneasiness about change at the Times Mirror Company, the diversified media giant that owns The Los Angeles Times and Newsday on Long Island. It is a company unused to upheaval. Indeed, The Times was once dubbed "the velvet coffin" because of its reputation for stability and paternalism. 
 But the velvet has recently turned to something more like sackcloth. David Laventhol, who was editor and then chairman at Newsday for a total of 18 years before becoming the publisher and chief executive of The Los Angeles Times last year, is a man who hides a tough business sense and a taste for challenges beneath a mild and amiable manner. In his appointment of Mr. Plate, and in other changes reflecting a more aggressive attitude, Mr. Laventhol is now making his presence felt throughout a company that had revenues of $3.5 billion last year. Mr. Laventhol, who is also, president of Times Mirror, is widely viewed as likely to become the company's next chief executive.
The changes at Times Mirror amount to what David Shaw, The Times's media reporter, called "the completion of a move from a family-run enterprise to more of a corporate, bottom-line business." They come at a time when tremendous opportunities and serious difficulties have abruptly arisen for Times Mirror on both the East and West Coasts.
On the one hand, the strike at The Daily News in New York has given an extraordinary boost to New York Newsday, which Mr. Laventhol started five years ago, and has brought it within sight of profitability. The publisher of Newsday, Robert M. Johnson, said its New York City edition was selling about 120,000 more copies during the week, bringing its circulation to 340,000, and 225,000 more copies on Sunday, putting that circulation at 373,000. New York Newsday has gained about 120 new advertisers since the strike began five and a half weeks ago.
Over all, Newsday now has a weekday circulation of about 870,000 and accounts for about 12 percent of Times Mirror's revenue. A paper strong in both New York City and its Long Island suburbs would be very attractive to advertisers, so this growth -- if it lasts -- is an important breakthrough.
"Suddenly, there is the possibility that Newsday could become an East Coast cash cow for them," said John Morton, a newspaper industry analyst at Lynch, Jones & Ryan.
On the other hand, Times Mirror is being severely hurt by the advertising slump that has affected its Eastern papers, which include The Baltimore Sun and The Hartford Courant, and has just hit the flagship paper, The Los Angeles Times.
Operating profits in the company's newspaper division, which account for close to 60 percent of the revenues, plunged 61.2 percent in the first nine months of 1990. Although the company's other activities -- which include a book publishing division, cable and broadcast television operations and specialty magazines -- have generally fared better, overall net income was down 40 percent, to $134.9 million, in the same period.
 
'Worst of Both Worlds'
 "They are getting the worst of both worlds," said Ed Atorino, an analyst at Salomon Brothers. "There's been a severe slump on the East Coast, and the West is moving into recession."
This trend is not likely to change soon. "I do not see any immediate turnaround," said Robert F. Erburu, the 60-year-old chief executive of Times Mirror. "I guess most people would hope for a bottoming-out and some recovery beginning in the second half of 1991."
In a joint interview with Mr. Erburu at Times Mirror's headquarters in Los Angeles, Mr. Laventhol said: "The whole company is focused on the question of costs right now. We want to be more efficient and more productive. It's a good issue to look at, both now and for the longer term."
The "long term" is a favorite expression of Mr. Laventhol, 57, an utterly unpretentious former reporter and founding editor of The Washington Post's Style section. He combines a belief that "God is in the details," as one collegue put it, with an ability not to get bogged down in them. He asks his staff, for example, whether The Times has enough boxes on Los Angeles's new Metro Rail transit system, while pursuing a plan for the paper in 2005.
 
'Long-Term Opportunity'
 Mr. Laventhol said a conviction that there was "a long-term opportunity" for Newsday to be the strongest paper in Brooklyn and Queens led him to get Times Mirror behind a New York City edition in 1986. He felt the paper could offer more serious and in-depth coverage of local news and sports than The Daily News.
At the time, The Daily News was dominant in Brooklyn and Queens, but its circulation was declining.
Newsday, meanwhile, was dominant on the rest of Long Island, but looking for ways to grow. "We saw an opportunity in New York if we could cover New York better than anybody else," Mr. Laventhol said.
New York Newsday -- once called "the tabloid in a tutu" because of its format and serious content -- grew steadily, from a circulation of about 87,000 in 1986 to 221,660 in September of this year.
But that was still far short of the break-even point, which Mr. Laventhol estimates at "between 300,000 and 400,000" and Mr. Johnson, the Newsday publisher, at "around 300,000." Although Times Mirror does not disclose the finances of its individual papers, analysts believe that New York Newsday has so far lost in excess of $100 million.
But as a result of the Daily News strike, Mr. Johnson believes New York Newsday can be profitable next year. He is convinced that even if The News survives, New York Newsday can hold at least half of its new readers and that "the longer the strike goes on, the more we'll get."
The strike has helped New York Newsday exactly where it wanted to grow. Circulation in Queens is up to 170,000, from 120,000 two months ago, Mr. Johnson said, and up to 90,000, from 50,000, in Brooklyn.
Both Mr. Johnson and New York Newsday's editor, Don Forst, contend it will now be very difficult for The News to recover, and they say The New York Times will become the main competitor if The News closes. "We aim to get younger New York Times readers," Mr. Forst said, adding that New York Newsday would not become more sensational to compete with The New York Post.
Still, one media analyst who insisted on anonymity said New York Newsday still had much to prove because, even at a price of 25 cents compared with 40 cents for The Post, it appears to have gained fewer readers. The Post claims its circulation is up by more than 200,000.
Moreover, the analyst pointed out that Newsday had not yet raised its ad rates in the New York edition, so that, for the moment, "the more copies they sell, the more they lose."
Mr. Laventhol takes a prudent view, describing the New York situation as too volatile for firm predictions. But although he and Mr. Erburu stressed that "the context of change here is evolutionary," Mr. Laventhol's actions in his 14 months as publisher of The Los Angeles Times suggest that Times Mirror will move aggressively to capitalize on New York Newsday's gains.
 
Buying and Selling Properties
 It is not that Times Mirror was inactive in the 1980's. Indeed, it sold some businesses, including its newsprint operation, for about $1 billion, and acquired new ones, including The Baltimore Sun and magazines like Field & Stream, for $1.5 billion.
But Times Mirror officials agree that the pace of change has accelerated since Mr. Laventhol's arrival. Indeed, the very presence as heir apparent of Mr. Laventhol, an Easterner in a corporation long dominated by Westerners, is widely regarded as confirmation of a new era -- one in which the Chandler family, which still owns the largest single stake of Times Mirror stock, has retired from active management.
Under Mr. Laventhol and the editor of two years, C. Shelby Coffey 3d, The Los Angeles Times has changed the format of its editorial page, introduced a "faster format," started a weekly showcase for its foreign correspondents, become more competitive in its reporting and changed the editors of most sections.
Like Mr. Laventhol, Mr. Coffey is a relative outsider to The Times. He previously was editor of The Dallas Times Herald when Times Mirror owned the paper.
The Times has also moved forcefully to counter the growth of strong suburban papers in neighboring Orange and Ventura Counties. Indeed, it is locked in an all-out war with The Orange County Register, which still outsells The Times in Orange County by a solid margin.
"The corporate culture is change," said John Lindsay, the editor of The Times's Calendar section, which covers arts and entertainment. "Whether you like it or not, that is absolutely it."
 
Circulation of 1.2 Million
 In the last year, The Los Angeles Times surpassed The Daily News as the nation's largest metropolitan newspaper. The Times's circulation has grown to 1.2 million a day. More than 100,000 of that gain came after The Los Angeles Herald Examiner closed in November 1989.
Mr. Erburu said the company aimed to become even stronger in the 1990's. "I would be surprised if Times Mirror does not acquire other papers in the next decade," he said.
Analysts like the company's new aggressiveness. "They will come back very strongly when the economy comes back," Mr. Atorino predicted. They also like Mr. Laventhol, who "knows the newspaper business better than anyone else they've had running it," Mr. Morton said.
Asked about his plans, Mr. Laventhol said, "We want to hook the Los Angeles Times up with Newsday in St. Louis!" Then, with his shy smile, he added, "That's a joke, of course."
It may be a joke, but Times Mirror's new-found restlessness and ambition clearly are not.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

BUSY TIMES FOR A.T.&T.
A.T.& T. offered to buy NCR for $6 billion, in a renewed effort to become a power in computers. The offer amounts to $90 a share, 60 percent above the closing price of NCR stock on Friday. The premium was seen as a sign that A.T.& T. hopes to persuade stockholders to accept, after failing to sway NCR's board. [Page A1.]
A.T.& T. is considering a plan to operate two new undersea cable-laying ships under foreign flags, enabling the company to employ foreign seamen at a fraction of American wages. [D1.]
The Universal card has been a bigger success than A.T.& T. ever anticipated, and that has caused some problems. [D1.]
 
INTERNATIONAL
Canada, Japan, Sweden and Switzerland will propose rules to broaden world trade in international banking and other financial services when world trade talks open in Brussels today. [A1.] With the shadow of failure hanging over the talks, Arthur Dunkel, the Director General of GATT, is aware that he can neither take sides nor impose solutions. [D10.]
Eight months after Brazil's President jolted the economy with a radical plan that cut inflation to single digits, the rate has crept up, a trade surplus has vanished and the economy has shrunk. [D1.]
Kohl's coalition claimed the reward for his stewardship of German unity, winning the first all-German election in 58 years. [A1.]
The Brussels stock exchange building was gutted by fire, casting doubt on changes scheduled for Jan. 1. [D10.]
 
THE ECONOMY
Production at a large Alaska oilfield is expected to begin within two years. An environmental agreement was announced by the Army Corps of Engineers, ARCO, BP Exploration and Exxon. [D1.] Radium from the earth's crust has been brought to the surface in decades of oil drilling, causing widespread radioactive contamination of oilfields. [A1.]
Dismissals at Paine Webber will involve about 18 percent of the firm's investment bankers, Wall Street executives said. [D1.]
After-tax profits of the chemical industry will fall this year for the first time since 1985, a trade association says. [D5.]
Officers and board members were well aware that Freedom National Bank had been severely troubled for years. [A1.]
 
THE MEDIA BUSINESS
A company unused to upheaval, Times Mirror is being shaken by aggressive change at a time when tremendous opportunities and serious difficulties have arisen on the East and West Coasts. [D1.]
Matsushita is becoming the publisher of Tom Clancy, the techno-thriller writer, who is a best-selling author in both Japan and the U.S. Many other foreign authors also sell well in Japan. [D8.]
A team of young editors is feverishly preparing for the Feb. 26 debut of Allure, Conde Nast's newest women's magazine. [D8.]
A pipe bomb ready for detonation was found on a ramp used by delivery trucks at a Daily News plant, the police said. [B3.]
The changing economics of network television are leading to unusual developments. Almost anything that does not cost a lot of money is liable to get on the air. Bill Carter: Television. [D8.]
"Snipers" slap up posters with messages throughout New York City. The practitioners often create political ads that include striking copy. Advertising. [D9.]

Global interest rates are likely to slide in coming months if war does not break out in the Middle East. Credit Markets. [D7.]

HEADLINE: Political Memo;
Democrats, Albeit Late, Ponder Presidential Bid

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2

 BODY:
With the 1990 midterm elections finally over, Democrats with Presidential ambitions are entering a season of decision.
It is already a remarkably late-starting campaign, given the norms of modern politics. By this time in 1982, Gary Hart was making the case for his "new ideas," while Walter F. Mondale was trying to pick up support from Senator Edward M. Kennedy, who had already withdrawn from the race for the 1984 Democratic nomination. By this time in 1986, Representative Richard A. Gephardt and former Gov. Bruce Babbitt were already fixtures in Iowa. 
 But in December 1990, not a single paid worker for a Democratic Presidential campaign plods the streets of Des Moines, says a somewhat mystified Iowa Democratic Party. Elsewhere in political circles, there are quiet whispers in the clubby world of fund-raisers and nervous rumors in the ranks of consultants, but little real action and perhaps even less real information.
As one prominent Democrat groused about Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's plans, "What I'm hearing is he's absolutely running or he's absolutely not running."
 
Time to Decide
 Over the next two to three months, to the relief of political aficionados and probably the dismay of everyone else, this eerie calm will end as potential candidates finally make up their minds. The dance is beginning. The hopefuls are showing some leg.
Senator Al Gore of Tennessee, who was resoundingly re-elected to a second Senate term last month, said last week: "I said throughout the campaign, when asked, that I wasn't even going to think about it until the campaign was over with. Now that it is over with, I'm going to follow through, sit down and think about it."
Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas, whose interest in the Presidency seemed lukewarm to many Democrats recently, reignited speculation a few weeks ago when he said, "The 1992 Democratic Presidential nomination is a lot more attractive than it was eight months ago."
Mr. Bentsen, who was apparently referring to President Bush's recent political problems and accompanying plunge in public opinion polls, plans a series of major economic speeches when Congress returns next month.
"He's weighing in his own mind, first and foremost, his chances should he decide to explore this further, and whether or not he wants to make the total commitment that he sees something like this requiring," said a friend of the 69-year-old Mr. Bentsen, the 1988 Democratic candidate for Vice President.
 
Nunn Well Positioned
 Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia, who sets hearts fluttering in the party's Southern-conservative wing, is well positioned as chairman of the Armed Services Committee to be a leading Democratic voice in the Persian Gulf crisis.
And Mr. Gephardt, the House majority leader, emerged strengthened from the recent budget talks, with some of his partisans urging him to consider a race in 1992, even though he promised not to do that when he ran for majority leader in 1989.
Governor Cuomo's unimpressive re-election and his state's budget woes have prompted some reassessment of his strengths, but he is still widely considered the heavy of the field.
Others who usually get mentioned whenever two or more Democrats are gathered together include Gov. L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia, who has maintained a notable national travel schedule; the Rev. Jesse Jackson, automatically considered a factor in Democratic campaigns; Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, although he says he intends to serve out his new term as Governor; Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey, although Democrats are still buzzing about his political near-death experience in last month's election, and Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska. The list could go on.
Deciding whether to run for President is never easy, but there are a number of factors that make it particularly difficult this time around and are slowing the process.
"Essentially, people are making decisions that could involve putting together a $100 million-plus operation, involving maybe 25,000 people, which has a substantial impact on their lives, other people's lives and potentially the country," said Paul Tully, the political director of the Democratic National Committee.
"It is irresponsible to make that decision without being aware of the terrain you're operating on," Mr. Tully added. "Is there going to be a war or is there not going to be a war? That's not a small side issue."
Combined with the uncertainty over the economy, the Persian Gulf crisis makes it hard to assess Mr. Bush's vulnerability in 1992. "Bush could either be politically enshrined or politically deceased based on a couple of events," said Harrison Hickman, a Democratic poll taker.
Democrats know how quickly a President's fortunes can change. President Reagan looked very different in 1984 than he did just after the 1982 midterm elections, when Republicans lost 26 seats in the House and were buffeted by recession.
Beyond complicating the decisions, the Persian Gulf crisis has generally had a chilling effect on Presidential maneuvering: "There's a genuine concern that you not engage the President in partisan bickering while he's trying to manage a crisis," said Thomas E. Donilon, a Democratic lawyer involved in several Presidential campaigns.
Each of the hopefuls has his or her own career arc to consider. For example, Mr. Gephardt and Mr. Gore ran unsuccessfully for the Democratic nomination in 1988 and need to be careful about when they take their next shot. A tested candidate is one thing, a perennial also-ran another.
Moreover, Mr. Gephardt, who as majority leader is the House's No. 2 Democrat, is on the ladder to the Speaker's job. Should he jeopardize that in a attempt to unseat an incumbent President? For now, he is pledging his commitment to his current job.
 
The Cuomo Factor
 There are other variables in the race, like the Cuomo factor. "Will he be in or not in? If he's in, what's the best type of candidacy to push off him with?" as one Democratic strategist put it.
Because of his name recognition, fund-raising ability and political base, Governor Cuomo has longer to make his decision than some of the other candidates, in the view of many Democrats, making the Cuomo factor all the more unpredictable.
In general, presidential hopefuls have felt less pressure to jump into early. Several of the most prominent, including Mr. Gore, Mr. Cuomo and Mr. Bradley, had re-election campaigns to occupy them in 1990. As long as they were tied up, others felt free to wait.
Mr. Gore also said there was a "kind of psychological arms control agreement" among potential candidates. "I think there's a feeling on the part of many potential candidates that the race last time really was too long and everybody pays a very high price politically, not to mention personally, in a two-year campaign," he said.
There could be another interpretation for the quiet in the Presidential wing of the Democratic Party: It has yet to find the idea, the issue or the message strong enough to propel candidates onto the field.
For all of that, the hopefuls are beginning to stir. "The fact of the matter is, the nomination is too big a prize and there will be people grabbing for it before long," said Geoffrey Garin, a Democratic poll taker.
Campaign 1990 is over. Campaign 1992, perforce, must begin.

LENGTH: 2619 words

HEADLINE: Failed Dreams - The Collapse of a Harlem Bank;
Freedom Bank's Demise: A Trail Of Risky Loans and Fast Growth

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
Earl Dicks remembers the day back in 1964 when he and several co-workers at a Harlem building-supply company scraped up what money they could and bought shares in a new bank opening on 125th Street. Civil rights fervor was coursing through the nation, and Freedom National Bank promised to do what establishment banks had not: to finance the economic aspirations of the nation's pre-eminent black neighborhood.
Three weeks ago, a team of Federal agents strode into the bank, plastered the automatic teller machine with masking tape and padlocked Freedom's doors forever. After a quarter-century of some success and much more struggle, the bank had failed. 
 "You have to remember, this was a bank that had so much promise," Mr. Dicks said a few days later as he stood on 125th Street, a witness to the end of the first black-owned bank in New York and one of the largest minority banks in the nation. "We really wanted it to work, and now it's gone."
While Freedom's depositors and some elected officials complained of the haste with which the Federal Government acted to shut down the bank on Nov. 9, the bank's officers and board members were well aware that it had been severely troubled for years. Freedom National Bank went under because of financial disorder -- imprudent lending practices, good investments spoiled by poor management and sloppy record-keeping that obscured those problems.
 
Short on Economic Resources
 The problems were compounded by Freedom's raison d'etre: to provide money to a community short on economic resources. Its mission was to lend to businesses, homeowners and other consumers in neighborhoods underserved by larger banks. But the neighborhoods Freedom served, and thus the bank's potential borrowers, often did not have enough of the resources and experience that make people good credit risks.
"I tried to balance loans with the community -- often time-consuming loans that weren't really that profitable -- with loans to major corporations," said Sharnia Buford, Freedom's president from 1979 until 1987. "In the minority community, most often we didn't have certified financial statements and other means of checking creditworthiness, so we did a great deal of lending with our hearts, which is risky."
The history of Freedom is also a cautionary tale of an incautious era. Most of the loans that later bankrupted Freedom were made between 1985 and 1987, as shifting alliances ultimately produced a majority on the board that favored fast growth.
Freedom's fall is also a story of the constant tension between the bank's risky mission and its bottom line, of how the battle between an old guard of Harlem business leaders and a new guard of Wall Street professionals toppled that uneasy balance and of 1980's financial ambitions faltering as the decade's boom ended.
"I hate to use a cliche, but when downtown catches a cold, Harlem gets pneumonia," said the Rev. Wyatt Tee Walker of the Canaan Baptist Church, who headed Freedom's board from 1982 to 1985 and served for more than a decade as a director.
 
Bad Loans and Mismanagement
 Federal regulators will only say the bank failed because of "bad loans" and "mismanagement." But through interviews with former bank officials and a review of Federal bank examiners' reports, there emerges a detailed account of the bank's snowballing decline. These are some of the bank regulators' findings:
*Before the bank was closed, it reported that more than 11 percent of its loan portfolio was either in default or far behind in payment, twice the city average. Many of those loans were made without adequate collateral, regulators said. And though most of Freedom's loans did go to minority entrepreneurs in New York, Federal regulators say that as a small community bank, it made an unusual number of loans outside its lending area.
*A small number of unsound investments cost the bank almost $1 million, and its high-quality investments lost money because the bank did not adjust to swings in the stock market after the Wall Street collapse of 1987.
*Poor record-keeping let bank employees conceal mistakes. And Federal bank examiners found a variety of unorthodox procedures, like approving overdrafts on checking accounts so otherwise bankrupt customers could make loan payments.
*Though the bank's board was so involved in day-to-day management that it wanted approval of pamphlets and forms inserted in customers' bank statements, it waited until the final months before the bank's failure to try to save it.
Freedom's last chairman, Isaiah E. Robinson, says that "the board did everything it could to save that bank."
"We had problems, but we were not the only bank with problems," he added, "and it seemed discriminatory to us that the regulators moved so fast to close us down."
Last Thursday, under pressure from New York State officials, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation agreed to pay 50 cents on every uninsured dollar to depositors whose accounts totaled more than the insured limit of $100,000. Many of these are nonprofit community development groups, and they still must struggle to maintain their services on unexpectedly reduced budgets.
In Washington, Federal banking officials are sorting through Freedom's records. In New York, business leaders, civil rights groups, ministers and politicians are trying to raise money to establish a new bank. Out on 125th Street, former customers are trying to decide where to put their money now.
Mr. Dicks never made much on his handful of shares, and stood to lose very little. Neither did most of the hundreds of others waiting in that long cold line to withdraw their money; only deposits above $100,000 were at risk. But for Mr. Dicks and the others, Freedom's failure was the passing of a neighborhood dream of economic independence.
"It has been here so long that it's just hard to believe it's gone forever," said Essie Farrington, treasurer of People Who Care, a community group with a small account at Freedom. "I grew up with Freedom National Bank and it's sort of like losing a friend."
 
Goals and Setbacks
'Bank of Last Resort' For Many in Harlem
 Founded by a group of black and Jewish entrepreneurs led by Jackie Robinson, Freedom made loans that other commercial banks avoided. "In many cases," Isaiah Robinson said, "Freedom was the bank of last resort."
While fulfilling that role, Freedom frequently ran into trouble. By 1974, more than $2 million of its $19 million loan portfolio needed to be written off as losses. A consortium of major banks came up with $3.7 million for Freedom -- investments now unlikely to pay off -- and in the early 1980's Freedom was turning a small profit.
But the bank was soon in dire straits again. Its deterioration, bank regulators and people involved with the bank say, began as many contemporary financial disasters did -- with a divisive takeover attempt.
 
Downtown Fever
 Freedom caught downtown fever about 1982, when Travers J. Bell Jr., the head of the only black-owned brokerage on the New York Stock Exchange, accumulated about 17 percent of Freedom's stock and sought control.
"There was this tension among board members over the Bell assault on Freedom," Dr. Walker recalled. "There were those who were resistant to the Bell group, and there were those who favored the Bell group, and there were those sitting on the fence, and in trying to sort the allegiances, we got distracted from running the bank."
Although the takeover attempt failed, Dan Bell Group, Mr. Bell's holding company, gained three seats on the board. For the first time, outsiders had a hand in running the bank, and they began pushing their growth strategy of more aggressive investments and loans and acquisition of smaller banks.
For more than two years, the Bell group jockeyed with board members backing the bank's president, Mr. Buford, a slow-speaking Texan known as Tab. He favored slow growth, balancing community loans with loans and services for major corporations like Heublein and Philip Morris.
"Since I got there in 1977, the bank had grown from $35 million in assets to $125 million, and we had established another branch," in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, said Mr. Buford, who now owns a Westchester banking and management consulting firm. "I've always said, 'If it ain't broke, don't fix it.' They said different."
In 1988, fresh from a highly touted four-year tenure as Boston's city treasurer, George A. Russell Jr. arrived at Freedom to further this growth. Mr. Bell, who recruited Mr. Russell and had championed the bank's growth, died five days after the new bank president's arrival. But instead of expanding the bank into a $500 million institution to finance minority businesses throughout the New York area, Mr. Russell spent his years as president dealing with the consequences of what Federal regulators called "highly questionable credit underwriting practices."
"I found myself really having to go in and clean up one big mess," he said recently.
Bank examiners' reports describe several loans that were unsecured or granted with little regard for customers' creditworthiness. Freedom lost $806,000 on a loan to the Argrett Enterprises Corporation, a concrete contractor, that was secured against a condominium contract, instead of completed work, the standard way of securing a loan.
An unsecured 1985 loan to the Western Oil and Refining Company of Arizona was not repaid and cost Freedom $293,000. The company's last financial statements were dated September 1985, even though banks are supposed to keep current financial statements.
"Most of these inferior credits were originated under prior management," an examiner from the Federal Comptroller of the Currency's office said in 1989. "This legacy of the past has clearly had a catastrophic impact upon the bank's earnings and capital and jeopardized its very survival."
 
Losses or Potential Losses
 In 1988, the Comptroller's office reported that $7.3 million of Freedom's loans -- more than 7 percent of its portfolio, well above average -- was either in losses or potential losses. About 20 percent of banks Freedom's size had similar losses. In 1989, that loan percentage had risen to what Federal regulators called "an astonishingly high" 9.21 percent.
While by far the largest part of the bank's troubled assets were problem loans, Freedom was also losing money on investments.
When Mr. Russell arrived in 1988, about $60 million, almost 60 percent, of the bank's assets were investments, with most of the rest in loans. It was "more of an investment bank than a commercial bank," he said.
But, he said, no one was tracking the turbulent financial markets to take advantage of their swings. From 1987 to 1990, the difference between what the bank had paid and the investments' market value resulted in an average annual loss of more than $2 million.
 
Some Substandard Investments
 Nearly all the investments were in high-quality securities, but bank examiners in 1988 classified more than $500,000 of them as substandard. Mr. Russell said the bank sold $492,000 of M Corp securities for 24 cents on the dollar, resulting in a $372,268 loss. In 1988, Freedom had taken a $419,000 loss on First Republic Bank holding company notes, sold for 16 cents on the dollar, he said.
The Harlem bank's balance sheets and earnings reports obscured the troubled loan portfolio and poorly managed investments.
In 1988, regulators identified $2 million in problem loans that were not in the bank's reports to the Comptroller's office. Over all, $6.8 million in commercial loans lacked current credit information, the examiner wrote.
One case highlighted by the regulators involved the Johfra Construction Company, a Brooklyn company that was lent $350,000 in 1985. When the owner failed to make the interest payments, his loan officer approved a checking overdraft that added $71,000 to the total owed to the bank. The bank finally charged off $421,000 as a loss.
 
Battling for Bank's Survival
'All Sorts of Problems' In the Last Three Years
 The last three years were a perpetual battle to stay alive.
Mr. Buford resigned in a power struggle with the board in January 1987, some months after a management study by Arthur D. Little concluded that excessive influence by the board over daily operations hampered the bank's performance.
Mr. Russell recalls one board meeting at which instead of discussing ways to attract new capital, directors bickered with management about a standard form used to confirm that customers held accounts.
"We had all sorts of problems, problems that threatened the very existence of the bank, and they were arguing about when we should send out a routine piece of paper work," he said.
Reports show that since at least 1988, Federal regulators had repeatedly demanded that the board find new capital. As loan losses increased from 9.21 percent of assets in 1989 to 11.1 percent in 1990, capital shrank and the need to increase it became more urgent.
In 1988, the regulators prescribed harsh medicine, demanding that the board increase capital, write off bad loans and build up its reserve against loan defaults. But even as the board failed to attract new money, the need to build its defenses reduced its capital pool and its ability to make money through new loans.
"It was circular," Mr. Russell said. "The higher the bank's potential loan losses got, the more capital we had to set aside for reserves and the less capacity we had to lend."
 
Investors to the Rescue
 That fall, Mr. Russell proposed a plan to save the bank. It was approved by the board, Mr. Russell said, and the bank's two major stockholders -- the Harlem Commonwealth Council and the Washington-based Opportunity Funding Corporation, two nonprofit development groups that together controlled just under half the stock -- agreed to put up $1 million each.
But, Mr. Robinson, the bank's last chairman, said, the two groups were hamstrung by Federal laws requiring those holding a majority stake in a bank to divest themselves of other interests.
In late 1989, Federal examiners again downgraded their assessment, warning, "Failure to achieve this objective within a reasonable time period may directly jeopardize this bank's prospects for survival." The board began working to find new investors; it also issued new stock, but the offering did not sell well.
 
Several Plans Dismissed
 After Federal regulators dismissed several recapitalization plans that would have involved Federal assistance, the board approved a merger with the Boston Bank of Commerce, Mr. Robinson said. On Nov. 7, the board and the Boston bank presented the plan to the Comptroller's office, which asked for time to review it.
"Nothing was said to us that day or the next that indicated they were not going to accept that offer," he said. "At least somebody could have said to us, 'Friday is the deadline.' "
Ronald A. Homer, chairman and chief executive of the Boston Bank of Commerce, said regulators informed his bank late that Thursday night that they were unsure that the bank had enough time to raise the money for a merger.
Mr. Russell quickly got in touch with more than 15 potential investors, from the Tisch family to Bill Cosby. But, he said, "the climate, because the S.& L. crisis was so bad, was such that nobody was rushing to buy a bank."
On Nov. 9, the F.D.I.C. closed Freedom forever.
Perhaps Wilbert A. Tatum, publisher of The New York Amsterdam News, expressed the sentiment in Harlem best. "No matter how badly managed it may have been," he said, "it was ours and it was all we had."

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
Baker Cites 2 Aims: Kuwait and Captives

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2

 BODY:
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said today that the United States would not attack Iraq if President Saddam Hussein withdrew his forces from Kuwait and freed the hostages it holds.
In one sense, Mr. Baker was doing no more than restating the United States intention to enforce the United Nations Security Council resolutions, which are limited to ending Iraq's occuption of Kuwait, restoring the legitimate Government of Kuwait and gaining the release of the hostages. 
 But in recent weeks Administration officials have cited a reason to consider military action that goes beyond the United Nations resolutions: Iraq's continuing efforts to develop nuclear, chemical and biological weapons.
While the Administration has never threatened to attack Iraq even after it evacuated Kuwait, some officials have pointed out that such a course has not been explicitly ruled out either.
 
 Bush's Rationale
 President Bush, for example, during his Thanksgiving visit to American troops, cited Iraq's drive to develop nuclear weapons as part of the rationale for considering offensive action. President Hussein has "never possessed a weapon he did not use," Mr. Bush warned.
And in his press conference on Friday, the President again cited Iraq's nuclear capabilities as one of several reasons why the United States has sent troops to the Persian Gulf.
"Imgaine his ability to blackmail his neighbors should he possess a nuclear device," Mr. Bush said on Friday.
Since highlighting the nuclear issue, the Administration had not said authoritatively whether, presuming Iraq withdrew from Kuwait, the United States would rule out attacks on Iraq like the sort that Israel launched to disable Iraqi's Osirak nuclear reactor.
And the Administration's repeated reference to Iraqi nuclear capabilities, as well as President Bush's strong denuciations of President Hussein, has led some lawmakers, such as Representative Lee H. Hamilton of Indiana, the second-ranking Democrat on the House Foreigh Affairs Committee, to argue that Mr. Hussein is likely to be uncertain whether the ultimate objectives of the United States go beyond liberating Kuwait to include "the removal of Saddam Hussein from power or the removal of the exotic weapons" in Iraq's arsenal.
Baker Discusses Trip
Mr. Hamilton had urged that the United States open talks with Iraq to clarify its objectives, a step President Bush announced on Friday.
Discussing his upcoming mission to Baghdad, Mr. Baker said in an interview on the NBC News program "Meet the Press" that no military action would be taken if Iraq fully complied with the United Nations resolutions.
"There's never been any suggestion that force would be used if the U.N. resolutions were fully complied with," Mr. Baker said, without specifically addressing the recent comments on Iraq's nuclear program by President Bush, Vice President Quayle and the national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft.
"And, if fact, if they were fully complied with, the resolution recently passed by the United Nations would not be self-executing and wouldn't come into force," Mr. Baker asserted, referring to the Security Council resolution on Thursday authorizing the use of military action against Iraq.
"That would give some assurance, it seems to me, that if he complied with the resolutions, his reward for that would not be a military attack by the United States," he said.
 
 Other Issues Left Open
 Mr. Baker said Iraq's compliance with the United Nations resolution was not negotiable, but he was careful to leave open the possibilty of substantive discussions on other issues, such as how to assure stability in the Persian Gulf.
"We will not be negotiating backwards from those United Nations resolutions," Mr. Baker said. "So there won't be a negotiation in that sense."
"The President said we could talk about aspects of the gulf crisism" he said. "Now what the President means by that is political, economic and military." He did not elaborate.
 
 Iraq Test-Fires Missiles
 Mr. Baker's comments came as Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said Iraq has test fired Scud surface-to-surface missiles, in a move that some Administration officials take as a demonstration by Iraq of its military abilities.
An Administration official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said the Iraqis test-fired two Scud missiles over a distance of about 200 miles. The missiles were launched inside and landed inside Iraq, and they flew on a southeast to northwest trajectory.
Missles would be launched on an east to west trajectory if Iraq launched an attack on Israel or Sryia. But one senior Administration official said that the trajectory chosen may have represented an effort by Iraq to fire the missiles away from American forces in Saudi Arabia and into an unpopulated area.
Mr. Cheney said on the ABC News program "This Week" that it was the first time the missiles have been flight-tested since April. Mr. Cheney added that the missiles have a range of 360 to 400 miles, depending on which variant is used, and that they are accurate enough to hit cities but not accurate enough to hit more specific targets.
Iraq has previously armed the missiles with high explosives, but American and Israeli officials assume for the purposes of military planning that Iraq may be able to arm them with poison gas.
 
 Several Questions Raised
 Mr. Bush's decision to open talks with Iraq and Mr. Baker's clarification today of American objectives raised several key questions.
If Iraqi forces leave Kuwait and a settlement is reached, how will the United States slow down the Iraqi nuclear program and reduce Iraq's other military abilities, such as its ballistic missiles, that threaten the area?
Would the current blockade against Iraq's oil exports be maintained to deprive Baghdad of revenues needed to maintain its weapons programs?
Would some American forces continue to be based in the Persian Gulf as a military counterweight to Iraq? Where would they be deployed and at what strength?
Iraq's Ambassador to the United States, Abdul Amir al-Anbari, said today that American efforts to disable Iraq's military were unacceptable.
 
 Further Sanctions Seen

Mr. Cheney -- who is scheduled to testify with Gen. Colin L. Powell, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, before the Senate Armed Services Committee on Monday -- said some form of international sanctions would still be needed to prevent Iraq from acquiring dangerous military technologies, but he was not specific on how they would work.
In other developments, Mr. Bush's statement that he would invite ambassadors from several of the nations in the multinational coalition against Iraq to take part in the Baghdad talks appears to have been dropped in light of Iraq's statements that it would invite "countries and parties that are connected with unresolved disputes and issues," an apparent reference to the Palestine Liberation Organization.
Mr. Scowcroft said today that "perhaps the best thing to do is to make the talks bilateral on both ends so that we don't get to haggling about the shape of the table."
He also said on the CBS News program "Face the Nation" that Iraqis have continued to supply some provisions to the American Embassy in Kuwait, which is running short of food. The Iraqi move appears to reflect concern that the United States might use its concern over a shortage of food at the embassy, which Mr. Bush has pledged to keep open, as a rationale to intervene militarily.

HEADLINE: Holding Recession at Bay

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, admitted to Congress last week that the nation's economy is shrinking. One day later the Government reported that its index of future economic activity had fallen for the fourth consecutive month. That's compelling, though not foolproof, evidence that the economy is headed for recession.
To many private economists Mr. Greenspan's admission is belated, a sign perhaps that the Fed has relied too long on outdated statistics that fail to capture the relevant indicators of recession in today's economy. Worse yet, his admission was unaccompanied by a stated resolve to turn the economy around with a modest easing of interest rates to spur economic activity. Mr. Greenspan's position is that there is little the Fed can do to offset the impact of the crisis in the Persian Gulf and other recessionary forces. 
There's an important middle ground in this debate. No one would want the Fed to engage in an inflationary increase in the money supply. But the Fed could modestly nudge interest rates lower and reign in overzealous bank regulators who are inadvertently contributing to a credit crunch. This might not be enough to keep the economy growing. But it's the only relief in sight.
Mr. Greenspan has received high marks for his stewardship of the Fed by liberal and conservative economists alike. He's kept monetary policy loose enough to permit modest growth for the past several years, but not so loose that inflation spiraled. That's not been easy, especially in the wake of stock market crashes and oil shocks.
But the Fed chairman is getting somewhat lower marks for current policy. He's kept the money supply growing near the bottom of the Fed's targeted range, allowing only a minor fall in interest rates. Perhaps that's because, as Prof. Jeremy Siegel of the Wharton Business School suggests, the Fed's forecasting tools are outdated. Past recessions have started in goods markets, like autos and steel, where forecasting measures have been developed to track changes in production and inventories. But this recession is different. It has begun primarily in the service sector, for which economists have not yet developed useful indices of future activity.
Many economists are now calling for the Fed to become more aggressive. That would not necessarily require a change in Fed policy, just an increase in money supply growth rates toward the top of the targeted range. Some estimate that would be enough to lower interest rates by about one percentage point.
The advice is sound. Inflation, once the temporary impact of higher energy prices is excluded, is in check. The Fed has room to loosen credit without worry.
The Fed could also deal with the problem of "credit crunch." Banks aren't lending the funds they already have on hand. A shaky real estate and business climate has sobered loan officers. But part of the problem, at least judging from anecdotal evidence, lies with bank regulators who are scaring lenders away from all but their blue-chip customers. Here, Mr. Greenspan could exert moral suasion to get the loan officers back on track.
There is no cause for panic or hysteria. The economy is limping, but not lame. The unemployment rate is still an enviable 5.7 percent and, with wages rising slowly, shows no signs of exploding. Yet the risk of serious recession now outweighs the risk of serious inflation. That should embolden the normally cautious Fed to act a bit less cautiously.

HEADLINE: Consumers Borrow Less

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3

 BODY:
Consumers were scaling back borrowing in the July-September quarter as the economy appeared to be headed toward a recession, a banking group said Monday.
The percentage of consumer loans 30 or more days delinquent was a seasonally adjusted 2.56 percent at the end of the third quarter, virtually unchanged from the 2.55 percent rate at the end of the April-June period, the American Bankers Association said. 
 The rate was 2.46 percent at the end of the first quarter and 2.64 percent at the end of the fourth quarter of 1989.
"Consumers are well aware of the slowing economy and are making efforts to consolidate and repay debts, rather than take on new ones," said Robert H. Dugger, chief economist of the trade group.
Government data show consumers are taking fewer loans, he said, while anecdotal evidence from bankers indicates financially strong households may be taking out less expensive and longer-term home equity loans to pay off other consumer loans and reduce their monthly payments.
Mr. Dugger said he expected the number of consumers behind on loan payments to be higher when figures are reported for the final three months of this year.
Michael K. Evans, a Washington economist and consultant, said consumer loan delinquencies generally did not rise significantly until well into a recession.
The lack of movement in the national delinquency rate masks sharp variations among regions. Consumers were hit hardest in the Northeast and least in the West and Midwest.

HEADLINE: Business and Health;
The Squeeze On Drugstores

BYLINE: By Milt Freudenheim

 BODY:
ALTHOUGH few doctors make house calls, many drugstores still deliver prescriptions to the homes of elderly customers. Scrambling to retain customer loyalty in the highly competitive retail pharmacy business, many drugstores specialize in advice and services. Eighty-five percent have also purchased computer systems that cost $10,000 and up, and some even have satellite links to keep supplies and insurers' payments flowing.
The McKesson Corporation's PCS pharmacy card unit, for example, operates a national electronic claims-processing network. An identification card with a magnetic stripe is passed like a credit card through a $200 device, which quickly tells the druggist what the customer's health plan pays for. The bill goes electronically to a data processing center in Scottsdale, Ariz., which pays the pharmacies every two weeks. 
 Prompt payment is vital to the nation's 55,000 pharmacies, for their pretax profit margins have fallen to 3 percent from 5.5 percent in the 1960's. Pharmacists are being squeezed by insurers, which increasingly insist on price discounts. Insurer guidelines on prescribing drugs are followed by about 22 percent of all office-based doctors, and the number is growing, said John Schaetzl, vice president of Scott-Levin Associates, a consulting firm in Newtown, Pa., that surveys physicians.
As retailing categories overlap and blur, retail druggists have had to compete with big discount chains like K Mart and Wal-Mart Stores, each with 1,000 or more pharmacies; mail-order pharmacy services, and supermarket chains, which are accustomed to even lower profit margins, based onmoving products off the shelf faster than drugstores do. And in the front of their stores, the druggists compete with the health and beauty aids sections of groceries, convenience stores, variety stores and specialty discount stores.
But the pharmacy business can also be difficult for such competitors. Joseph Thomas 3d, an economist at Purdue University, said the expenses in operating a pharmacy "are very different from operating a grocery." He added, "You need pharmacists, people with knowledge and time, willing to answer questions about over-the-counter products." A sign in the West Main Pharmacy, an independent store in Penns Grove, N.J., says, "Please ask our pharmacists questions before you purchase over-the-counter drugs."
"We foresee gross margins in the pharmacy business continuing to drop," said David D. Bernauer, vice president and treasurer of the Walgreen Company, which is based in Deerfield, Ill. "The bottom line to the whole thing is: Who can most efficiently distribute that prescription to the customer?" Walgreen stores, which deal with 800 insurance plans, are linked by satellite to a computer center in Mount Prospect, Ill. "In five seconds, we check the patient's eligibility and other parameters like which drugs are covered, the number of days' supply, whether generics are mandatory," he said. "The system greatly reduces the percentage of rejects and dishonored claims and the cost of shipping paperwork." Sales at Walgreen's 1,575 stores are growing by 20 percent annually, reflecting rising drug prices and the addition of 110 stores this year, Mr. Bernauer said.
To compete with the chains, independents like the West Main Pharmacy work on customer service. "We can't always match the dollar figure," said Louis A. Mitchell, the owner, who is in the store daily from 9 A.M. to 9 P.M. "My main concern is that the patient has to be satisfied that what they are doing is based on good sound advice."
Don Moore, an independent pharmacist who is president of the Moore Drugstore in Kokomo, Ind., maintains a staff nurse for consultations.
"All retail drugstores, whether they are independent or chains, are being squeezed much more today," said David Malmberg, vice president for strategic planning with McKesson's wholesale unit, the nation's largest drug wholesaler.
Insurers that pay most of the cost of drugs directly to the store may account for 75 percent of the prescription business by the end of the decade, said Robert J. Mandelbaum, a pharmacist who is a vice president of the 1,136-store Revco chain, based in Twinsburg, Ohio. Revco is adding patient counseling areas to its stores.
Some druggists are developing niche markets like joint ventures with hospitals to supply equipment for home health care. And Fay's, based in Liverpool, N.Y., which has 185 drugstores, is opening free-standing operations just to supply nursing homes. "They are a large growth end of our prescription business," said Henry A. Panasci, Fay's chairman.

HEADLINE: VIETNAM PUBLISHES PLAN FOR ECONOMY

BYLINE: REUTERS

DATELINE: HANOI, Vietnam, Dec. 3

 BODY:
Vietnam has devised a new plan to end decades of poverty that is intended to double the nation's income by the year 2000, cut inflation to single digits and increase export values five times.
Officials said the ruling Communist Party hoped the economic blueprint and a political platform, which were published on Friday, would give Vietnam's aging socialist system a facelift but maintain the state's grip on society. 
 "Until now we are still among the poorest countries of the world," was the beginning of the plan, published in three leading state newspapers.
The draft was approved by Communist leaders last week and will be debated nationwide before being submitted to a full congress in May, officials said.
 
Uneven Economic Growth
 Vietnam's economy, ravaged by poor state management and war with the United States and others, has grown unevenly since limited economic reforms were instituted three years ago. Moves to increase rice production and end inflation last year proved short-lived.
The plan -- called the Draft Strategy of Socio-Economic Stabilization and Development Up to the Year 2000 -- blamed many of the problems of the last few decades on Communist dogmatism. It listed three main goals: making people richer, introducing a multi-faceted economy and creating a more open economic system.
Among the Government's goals are doubling the country's per-capita income, which was given as between $200 and $210, and raising rice production by 50 percent, to 30 million tons. Electricity output would triple under the plan and inflation, hovering around 50 percent after reaching nearly 1,000 percent in 1988, would be less than 10 percent by 1995, the newspapers said.
The draft plan set as a goal a fivefold increase for the value of exports by the year 2000. In 1988, Vietnam's exports were worth $1.07 billion.
 
Hard-Liners Giving Way
 Diplomats said the targets were ambitious but not unattainable.
In recent years, hard-line Communist officials who dealt with economic planning have given way to educated technocrats, and party ideologues have stressed the value of basic market forces.
But Vietnam, denied aid and Western investment because of its 1978 invasion of Cambodia, has yet to secure investor confidence or enough capital to dent shortages in basic infrastructure and industry.
It has also failed to address short-term problems that have aroused fears of a Soviet-style crisis in basic foods.
Severe cuts in aid from the Soviet Union, its chief ally, have distorted the limited reforms that have been undertaken. Many civil servants have not been paid for five months. Hopes for a bumper rice crop this year are being threatened by a fertilizer shortage.

HEADLINE: Neediest Cases Fund Helps a Divorced Father

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ

 BODY:
It is the type of story that movies are based on. A divorced man is frustrated in his efforts to raise his four daughters. A young housekeeper arrives, dissipates the atmosphere of chaos, charms the girls and teaches him to be the perfect father.
The real-life version is set in the streets of the Bedford-Stuyvesant neighborhood of Brooklyn, and the co-producers are the Brooklyn Bureau of Community Service and The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. 
 Jeffery A., a 37-year-old unemployed man, lives in a third-floor walk-up apartment with exposed nails, chipped paint and holes in the ceiling. The lobby smells of urine. Four men have been shot on this block in the last year. His daughters occasionally find crack vials and hypodermic needles in the halls.
But these problems are nothing, Jeffery said yesterday, compared with the difficulty of dressing, feeding, bathing and disciplining four daughters who are 10 years old or younger. "Chaos" is the word he used to describe it.
 
Awarded Custody
 In 1988, Jeffery was awarded custody of his four girls after his wife, from whom he was separated, was diagnosed as mentally ill. After a year, social workers visited and saw a loving, devoted father struggling to get by. His daughters had uncombed, matted hair. The youngest, then 2 1/2 years old, needed to be toilet-trained. The clutter in the apartment made it a fire trap.
Through the assistance of the Brooklyn Bureau of Community Service, Jeffery was assigned a homemaker who comes to his apartment five days a week to help organize the housekeeping and child care. Money from the Neediest Cases Fund helps to pay for this service.
Jeffery's family is one of hundreds that the fund has assisted. All the money that is raised goes to the Brooklyn Bureau of Community Service and six other charities that use it to help the sick and the needy. Along with providing the poor with food, shelter, clothing and other services, the Neediest Cases Fund helps about 120 families to receive regular homemaker visits from the Brooklyn agency.
 
Trouble With Braids
 Yesterday morning, Jeffery sat with his youngest daughter, Erin, now almost 4, perched on his knee. Her hair was in neat cornrows with a top knot and braided pigtails, held in place by two heart-shaped white barrettes.
"There are a lot of things I can do around this house, but these braids aren't one of them," he said. "My hands just can't do that. I can comb out and take care of my oldest's, but Erin's hair is too short for my fingers."
The homemaker, Sharon Taylor, 22, does Erin's braids, and many other household chores. When Miss Taylor arrived yesterday morning, she immediately started sweeping the apartment. Erin followed her as she went from room to room.
This is Miss Taylor's fourth -- and favorite -- placement as a homemaker. In past jobs, she has been threatened by a mother with a knife and had children scream and hit her, she said. It is unusual to be working for a single father since most of the homemakers' cases involve single mothers, but it has worked out well.
Miss Taylor has also taught Jeffery how to do better at many chores -- like planning his children's meals and buying in bulk. (There are 15 boxes of cereal in the kitchen.) And the girls' clothing is no longer in piles on the floor but organized in an old dresser and in garbage bags.
Jeffery is almost ready to survive on his own, Miss Taylor said. "All he needs to learn now is braids, and he's got it all down," she said. In the next year, her services will be phased out, and he will be on his own again -- and better prepared.
