HEADLINE: New York Adopts Rules to Spread Projects Fairly

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
The New York City Planning Commission adopted final guidelines yesterday aimed at distributing city projects, from homeless shelters to libraries and from jails to parks, more evenly among both rich and poor communities.
Required under the new City Charter, the guidelines are the first such municipal rules in the nation. They are intended, in part, to end the city's practice of placing a disproportionate share of programs for the homeless, the mentally ill and drug abusers in the poorest neighborhoods. 
 Such programs have often beenplaced wherever there was available low-cost city-owned land or buildings, and under the new guidelines that will undoubtedly still happen. But now economic considerations are to be among a variety of other considerations the Planning Commission will have to take into account.
The guidelines, which take effect immediately, apply to the opening, closing and major expansions or reductions of a city project from landfills to police stations.
"Certainly the commission is going to be sensitive to the costs to the city," said its chairman, Richard L. Shaffer. "But the financial cost is only one kindof cost. There are other kinds of costs as well."
He also said: "I think what this will do is insure an open process with full information. My hope is that that will bring some more rationality to the process."
 
 7 Hearings Lead to Changes
 After seven public hearings since Mayor David N. Dinkins first proposed the guidelines last summer, the commission revised them in a number of ways.
One of the biggest changes was to minimize strict numerical calculations in determining whether the addition ofa particular residential project -- like a 100-bed shelter -- to a neighborhood would push that area over the citywide average for such programs.
Under the original proposals, if a project pushed a community over the threshold, the city could proceed only after making a number of public findings, including certifying that the site was the only feasible one.
Now, the commission still has to take such comparative ratios into account, but need not make such highly specific explanations for exceeding them.
The final guidelines also specify that the city must take into account existing private, state and Federal programs as part of the base of projects in a neighborhood when making decisions about where to place new projects of its own. The guidelines now define a significant expansion or reduction of a program asa change of 25 percent, rather than 50 percent.
And the revised guidelines also require the commission to consider the compatibility of any new project with existing ones, and the extent to which a neighborhood's character would be hurt by a concentration of programs.
Joseph Rose, director of the Citizens Housing and Planning Council, a nonprofit research group, said the rules were a fine start at adressing complex issues. But he said the real test would come when the Planning Commission tried to apply them to individual projects.
"The particular cases are going to be very tough," he said.

COMPANY: NEW YORK RESTAURANT GROUP INC (91%); FEDERAL PROGRAMS (52%);

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Jumps and Gold Falls After Reports of Joint Steps

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar closed sharply higher yesterday, lifted by reports that the leading industrial nations will step in to halt the currency's recent slide.
In response to the dollar's advance, gold prices tumbled more than $6 an ounce in New York. 
 Analysts said the dollar was lifted by reports that the Group of Seven industrial nations would meet in January to discuss actions to stabilize the currency.
Those seven nations -- the United States, Britain, France, Germany, Japan, Italy and Canada -- have said little as the dollar plunged in recent months. That reticence contributed to the currency's slide as traders took the lack of public statements as a sign that the Group of Seven wanted a lower dollar, so speculation that the group was about to take a stand sent the dollar higher.
Barbara Clay, a spokeswoman for the Treasury Department, declined to comment yesterday on the speculation.
Kevin Lawrie, senior foreign exchange manager at the Bank of Boston, said the Persian Gulf crisis continued to affect dollar trading, with rumors alternately prompting buying and selling. The dollar is seen as a relatively safe investment in times of international strife.
"We're all looking over our shoulder," he said. "It's very volatile and confusing."
Overseas traders said the dollar was also supported by the Treasury's twice-a-year report to Congress on international economic and exchange-rate policy. The report stressed the Government's desire to see improvement in the trade deficit through fundamental economic factors rather than through a weak dollar.
The dollar surged against the British pound, which fell to $1.9180 in New York, from $1.9430 late Friday. Earlier in London, the pound fell to $1.9205, from $1.9400 late Friday.
The dollar also jumped against the Japanese yen. In New York, the dollar closed at 134.74 yen, up from 132.50 late Friday. In Tokyo trading overnight, the dollar rose 0.25 yen to close at 133.00 yen, and it was quoted later in London at 134.35 yen.
Against the German currency, the dollar rose to 1.51395 marks, from 1.5020 on Friday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with the late Friday prices, included: 1.2935 Swiss francs, up from 1.2770; 5.1135 French francs, up from 5.0580; 1,138.00 Italian lire, up from 1,125.25, and 1.16625 Canadian dollars, up from 1.16475.
Gold prices fell as the dollar rose, amid some optimism that the Persian Gulf crisis might be peacefully resolved.
In New York, an ounce of gold closed at $376.60 on the Commodity Exchange, down $6.70. The Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $375.50, down $6.50.
Silver prices rose. In New York, silver gained 1.6 cents to close at $4.138 an ounce on the Comex. Silver had risen earlier to a late bid price in London of $4.16, from $4.11 on Friday.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Rise in Slow Trading

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities rose in sluggish trading yesterday, pushed higher by a round of foreign buying during overnight trading.
The gains, which amounted to as much as 3/4 point for some securities, were not sustained after trading shifted to the United States, even though a survey of the nation's purchasing managers showed that conditions in the manufacturing sector deteriorated in November. 
 Most economists had been expecting that the monthly Purchasing Managers Index would show a decline, but the drop, to the lowest point since November 1982, when the economy was in recession, exceeded expectations.
The index surveys manufacturers' plans to purchase raw materials for their products. A drop in the index indicates lower production plans. The recessionary implications could be expected to cause fixed-income securities prices to rise, as investors buy bonds to lock in current rates.
"The number was a great one for the market, but we couldn't hold the highs," one trader of government bonds said. "There was no retail follow-through on a very, very bullish number."
 
 Too Much Bullish Sentiment?
 Ward McCarthy, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates, a Princeton, N.J., research firm, said that "given the lack of reaction to the purchasing managers' report, you have to wonder if, for the short term, there isn't too much bullish sentiment already built into prices."
Mr. McCarthy and other market participants said that a rise in oil prices and remarks by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney might have dampened enthusiasm to buy Treasury securities.
Mr. Cheney told Congress yesterday that he was skeptical that negotiations with Iraq would lead to a solution to the gulf crisis. He added that military force rather than economic sanctions was the only sure way of forcing Iraq to end its occupation of Kuwait.
"If you could pinpoint one event that took the starch out of the market, it was Cheney's remarks," Mr. McCarthy said.
Nevertheless, prices closed higher on the day.
 
 30-Year Bonds Up 3/8
 In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds of 2020 were offered late yesterday at a price of 104 1/4, up 3/8 point, to yield 8.35 percent, compared with 8.39 percent late Friday.
Among note issues, the 8 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 101 14/ 32, up 10/32, to yield 8.36 percent. And the 7 7/8 percent five-year notes were offered at 99 30/32, up 1/8 point, to yield 7.88 percent.
At the Treasury's weekly auction of three-month and six-month bills, the three-month bills were sold at an average discount rate of 7.06 percent, up from the average 7.02 percent rate at last week's sale.
Six-month bills were sold at an average discount rate of 6.96 percent, unchanged from the auction a week ago.
 
 Ford Motor Offers Notes
 In the market for investment-grade corporate bonds, the Ford Motor Credit Company offered $300 million of three-year notes through an underwriting syndicate led by the First Boston Corporation.
The 9 1/8 percent notes, which mature Dec. 15, 1995, were priced at $99.78, to yield 9.18 percent, 1.3 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7 3/4 percent three-year notes at the time of pricing.
The notes, which are noncallable for life, are rated AA-3 by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and AA- by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
The decline in interest rates made November a good month for all investors in fixed-income securities, including the high-yield "junk bond" market.
 
 Positive Returns
 Last month, an index of 344 securities compiled by First Boston posted a positive return of 2.01 percent, the first positive month since July. By comparison, 10-year Treasury notes posted a positive return of 2.88 percent, First Boston said.
Yields on the bonds included in the index declined to 18.74 percent, from 19.12 percent in October.
Prices of most high-yield issues were little changed in light trading yesterday, dealers said.
In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds, prices of most issues were unchanged.
Meanwhile, participants in the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds said that prices of most widely quoted issues rose by 1/8 point to 1/4 point.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Shakeout Begins Among British Sunday Papers

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN

 BODY:
A shrinking British newspaper market has claimed its first victim, The Sunday Correspondent, and some in the industry believe the Sunday market for serious papers is still too crowded for all to survive through the current advertising recession.
The Correspondent, in which the Tribune Company of Chicago held a 17.5 percent stake, was closed last week just 14 months after its debut. The paper represented Tribune's attempt to get a toehold in the European market. A Tribune spokeswoman, Martha Lindeman, said the company had invested "between $7 million and $10 million" in the venture. 
 The closing comes at a time of extreme flux in the British newspaper market. Several papers are losing money. Meanwhile, media companies from Spain and Italy are investing in British newspapers in preparation for the creation of a single European market in 1992.
 
 Tribune's Problems
 The Correspondent was started as a serious, balanced, full-sized paper. In September, it became a tabloid in a bid to raise its slumping circulation.
Ms. Lindeman denied that the decision to close The Correspondent was related to Tribune's problems at The Daily News in New York, where analysts believe the company is losing $15 million to $20 million a month because of a strike that has cut The News's circulation in half. "We were just one of many stockholders in The Correspondent, and The Daily News was not a factor," she said.
But Peter Shott, the chief executive of Sunday Newspaper Publishing P.L.C., which published The Correspondent, said he had extensive talks with Scott C. Smith, Tribune's chief financial officer, during last-ditch efforts to save the paper. Mr Shott said the essential message from Chicago was that "we have enough on our plates with The Daily News and the general recessionary climate in the newspaper business." Mr. Smith declined to comment.
When it closed, The Correspondent had a circulation of 207,000, far short of the 400,000 that management said was needed to break even. Even the 207,000 figure was not accepted by Britain's Audit Bureau of Circulations, because it included promotional sales. The last audited circulation figure, for August, was 149,241.
 
 $60 Million Invested
 Other shareholders in the paper included The Guardian and Manchester Evening News P.L.C. with about 10 percent, Robert Maxwell's Mirror Group with about 15 percent, two Middle Eastern investors with about 17 percent each, and investment firms with a total of about 12 percent.
Mr. Shott said that about $60 million had been invested in The Correspondent and that 200 jobs were lost when the paper closed.
When The Correspondent was started last year, the British newspaper market was still riding a wave of innovation and optimism that began in 1986, when Rupert Murdoch overcame fierce union resistance and succeeded in introducing new technology at The Times and his other papers. Costs tumbled, and new newspapers like The Independent flourished.
But toward the end of last year, a steep advertising recession began and readership started to slip. Moreover, The Correspondent's debut was followed last January by the introduction of The Independent on Sunday, giving readers a choice of five serious Sunday papers. Analysts believe that only the runaway market leader, The Sunday Times, is profitable. The other two papers are The Observer and The Sunday Telegraph.
 
 'Beginning of a Severe Downturn'
 "It was very unfortunate that two new Sunday papers were launched at the beginning of a severe downturn," said Carla Tammenoms Bakker, European media analyst for Morgan Stanley & Company. "It would have been a miracle if all had survived."
Even without The Correspondent, "things are so bad at the moment that it would be foolhardy to rule out more casualties," said Stephen Fay, the deputy editor of The Independent on Sunday.
Henry Porter, an associate editor of The Independent on Sunday, said that although it expected to gain 25,000 to 30,000 readers from The Correspondent's collapse, the paper would still be more than 60,000 short of the roughly 470,000 circulation needed to break even.
Start-up costs at The Independent on Sunday have strained the finances of its parent company. For the year ended Sept. 30, Newspaper Publishing P.L.C. posted a pretax loss of close to $8 million.
 
 Stakes in The Independent
 Last month, the company said El Pais, a newspaper in Barcelona, Spain, and La Repubblica, based in Rome, were each acquiring a 14.9 percent stake in The Independent and The Independent on Sunday for a total of $86 million.
Mr. Shott said the last attempt to save The Correspondent involved an effort to merge it with Today, a money-losing tabloid owned by Mr. Murdoch's News Corporation. But The Correspondent was unable to raise $40 million in new equity needed for the venture.
Ms. Tammenoms Bakker of Morgan Stanley predicted that "newspaper advertising will be weak through most of next year," suggesting that the problems of British papers are far from over.

HEADLINE: At Trade Talks, Fear of Collapse

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, Dec. 3

 BODY:
At the end of the first day of a pivotal week of talks to liberalize world trade, fears grew that a continuing stalemate in negotiations on farm trade could lead to a collapse of the negotiations.
After two hours of talks on agricultural trade ended tonight, officials from the United States and several other farm-exporting countries voiced dismay about the European Community's failure to make concessions to reduce protection to farmers. 
 With officials from more than 100 nations meeting here today, numerous ministers said that to conclude in an agreement before Friday's deadline, progress had to be made in the next day or two on the central issue: reducing subsidies to farmers.
The United States and 13 other farm-exporting nations have proposed slashing farm subsidies by 75 percent over the next 10 years, while the European Community has proposed cuts of 30 percent. Canada, Australia, Argentina, Brazil and the United States have criticized the community for opposing greater cuts, and ministers grew worried tonight after European officials did not make a more liberal offer.
After tonight's talks on farm trade, Donald F. Mazankowski who is Canada's Farm Minister and its Deputy Prime Minister, said that unless there were some substantial indications of change from the European Community, "there is not much point in continuing the discussions."
Clayton K. Yeutter, the American Agriculture Secretary, added that "there was essentially zero support for the European Community position" at the meeting, the first session in which agriculture was discussed.
A four-year round of talks aimed at liberalizing world trade rules is scheduled to end with five days of this week's talks in Brussels. The goal of the negotiations is to promote economic growth by setting new, more liberal rules for the world's $4 billion in trade and for the first time including agriculture, textiles, financial services and intellectual property under the trade rules.
The talks are sponsored by the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the Geneva-based organization, and are called the Uruguay Round because they began in that country in 1986.
Early today, European Community officials had sought to put the United States on the defensive by asserting that Washington was demanding unrealistically large cuts in aid to farmers. They also sought to go on the offensive by calling Washington protectionist for having proposed that several key sectors -- shipping, aviation and telecommunications -- be excluded from international trade rules.
 
Protest by Farmers
 Community officials seemed heartened that 25,000 European farmers gathered in Brussels today for a raucous protest against further cuts in farm aid. They pointed to the rally as evidence of how difficult it would be for them to agree to the cuts in farm aid that the United States and other nations are demanding.
Daniel Gremillet, a dairy farmer from the Lorraine region in France, said: "The American proposals are unrealistic. They would crush us." He and other farmers said that if approved, the American proposals would drive half of Europe's farmers out of business in the next 10 years.
Frans Andriessen, the community's Trade Commissioner, said that if the 12-nation community was to make further concessions on farm trade, then other nations, especially the United States, must make concessions, too.
"How can you expect me to make new proposals on agriculture, when we don't get anything in return?" Mr. Andriessen said.
Many officials here expressed profound uncertainty over whether this week's talks would result in an agreement.
"I am cautiously optimistic because everyone is saying what a catastrophe would be if the talks fall apart," said Willy de Clerq, the chairman of the European Parliament's delegation.
 
 Talk of a Bluff
 Nonetheless, the threat of collapse hung over the conference. This afternoon Australia's Trade Minister, Neal Blewett, said there was no point continuing the talks if the European Community did not come forward with a broader offer to cut farm protecton by Tuesday night.
He said he hoped European Community officials would not succumb to the pressures of the protesting farmers. "I'm disappointed that European leaders have not prepared their farmers for change," he said.
Some Europeans said that Australia's implied threats to walk out of the talks was a bluff to put more pressure on the community to make concessions.
To break the deadlock in agriculture, Washington wants the European Community to agree to reduce protection in three areas: internal supports, import barriers and export subsidies. The community has agreed to cut internal subsidies, but the United States and other farm-exporting countries say it has been vague about reducing protection in the other two areas.
In another area, reducing trade barriers in services, European officials criticized Washington for blocking progress. Peter Lilley, Britain's Minister for Trade and Industry, said the United States had originally pushed to include services in the Uruguay Round. Now, he said, "there seems to be a reluctance in the United States to go the whole hog."
European officials said American officials had bowed to domestic corporate pressures and were seeking to exclude shipping, aviation and telecommunications from new trade rules. Washington has also been criticized for proposing that most-favored-nation status not be granted to all nations in services, with American officials saying that only when a nation has an open market should it be granted that status. Under that status, if a country gives preferential trade treatment to one nation, then all nations should receive that treatment.

GRAPHIC: Photo: European farmers protesting proposed cuts in agriculture support subsidies scuffled with the Belgian riot police during the opening day of talks by the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade in Brussels. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Economic Index Hits 8-Year Low

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
Hit hard by lower production and a decline in new orders, the nation's manufacturing economy slowed in November to the lowest level since the recession of the early 1980's, a survey of purchasing managers has found.
The National Association of Purchasing Management said yesterday that its index of economic activity fell to 41.3 percent, the weakest showing since November 1982, when the index stood at 39.2 percent. In October, the index was at 43.3 percent. 
 Economists said the report underscored their feeling that the nation's economy was heading into recession. The Commerce Department said on Friday that the Government index of the leading economic indicators fell in October, for the fourth consecutive month, by 1.2 percent. And Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, told Congress on Wednesday that economic activity had been contracting since last month.
 
 Wide Range of Industries
 The purchasing managers' report is considered an important economic indicator because it is based on a survey of managers from a wide range of the nation's industrial companies. It is also the first important indicator released each month.
The report for last month also stated that the December index, if unchanged from the November level, would mean that growth in the gross national product for the entire year would be nine-tenths of a percent and that G.N.P. would decline in the fourth quarter by about six-tenths of a percent.
In contrast, G.N.P. rose by 2.9 percent in 1989, and by five-tenths of a percent in the fourth quarter of last year.
 
 Weakness in New Orders
 "The negative growth in the United States economy, registered in October for the first time in 10 years, has deepened in November," said Robert J. Bretz, chairman of the purchasing managers' business survey committee and director of materials management at Pitney Bowes Inc. "With the engine of the economy, new orders, at its lowest point in over eight years, it appears likely the negative trend will continue for some time."
The weakness in new orders reported by the purchasing managers was cited by economists as the greatest indicator of troubles in manufacturing. The index of new orders dropped to 39.4 percent in November, from 43.8 percent in October. The November level is the lowest since May 1982, when the index stood at 38.1 percent.
"The economic decline will not bottom until this index stops falling," the report said.
Neal Soss, chief economist at the First Boston Corporation, said: "The industrial sector has been in recession for some time and there is nothing that suggests an early rebound. New orders are weak and inventories are already low, which suggests that you won't get the rebound that sometimes comes when there is too little inventory."
Production fell in November for the fourth consecutive month, with the association's production index falling to 41.8 percent, from 43 percent in October. "Considering that the new-orders index is the weakest in over eight years, it is unrealistic to expect a reverse soon," the report said.
 
 Prices Rise Again
 Prices that manufacturers pay for goods rose in November for the sixth consecutive month, but the rate of increase dropped from that of October. The report said that despite increases in the costs of raw material to manufacturers, customers had resisted price increases. The report said that inflation as a result of the crisis in the Persian Gulf had probably peaked and that price increases would largely subside in the next year or so.
The level of exports continued to increase in November, with the association's index of new export orders rising to 55 percent, from 51 percent in October.
The level of imports declined in November for the seventh consecutive month, with the imports index dropping to 42 percent, from 46.5 percent in October.
Prices of several items were said to be higher in November, including chemicals and other items that contain crude oil or derivatives. Other items that were higher priced included solvents, sulfur, ammonia and caustic soda, which is heavily used in making paper.

HEADLINE: As Airlines Stumble, Rivals Circle

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES

 BODY:
If the combination of high jet-fuel prices and low-paying passengers persists through the winter, the unrelenting consolidation in the airline industry that pushed Continental Airlines into bankruptcy will claim other weakened carriers, several analysts said yesterday.
"It's a Darwinian situation," said Timothy Pettee, transportation analyst at Alliance Capital Management, a money management firm in New York. "The strong shall survive and the strong will pick off what's left of the weak airlines. There will be more bankruptcies." 
 With operations hurt by jet-fuel prices that have doubled since summer, and an economy that appears to be growing weaker by the month, the nation's airlines expect total losses of at least $1 billion in this quarter alone, industry experts say. They add that losses will possibly be that high in the first quarter of next year.
 
 Costly 2-for-1 Programs
 Adding to their problems, the airlines began a costly wave of two-for-one fare promotions last month, when they could ill afford them.
Analysts said the airlines that outlast the industry's latest turmoil will probably be those holding at least 10 percent of the market for domestic air travel, which include American, United, Delta and Northwest. Others with smaller market share, like Pan Am and Trans World Airlines, are candidates to join Continental in bankruptcy, or to sell most assets to larger rivals.
Indeed, Wall Street saw the Continental bankruptcy as good news for the strongest carriers. The shares of AMR, the parent of American Airlines, rose $1.25, to $48.50. The stock of UAL, the parent of United, moved up $1.875, to $99.375, and shares of Delta Air Lines rose $1.75, to $58.50.
Kevin C. Murphy, an analyst at Morgan Stanley & Company, said one reason airlines suffered low profits in the 1980's, compared with other domestic industries, was that most operated with more aircraft than passenger demand could support. Before Congress deregulated the industry in 1978, routes and prices were controlled by the Government.
 
A Better Return Ahead
 "This is the last stage of the post-deregulation era," Mr. Murphy said. "With the move toward fewer carriers and higher fares, it will mean you have a better rate of return for investors, creditors will be able to get paid, and employees will have more job stability."
Some analysts said airline stocks rose because the big carriers were likely to chip away at Continental's share by adding competing flights on its most profitable routes. They expressed doubt that Continental would emerge from bankruptcy as a potent, if smaller, carrier.
Continental was particularly vulnerable because of the interest costs for its huge debts. It had been flirting with bankruptcy for months.
 
 2 Others in Deep Trouble
 Pan Am and T.W.A., two others that were considered weak long before the current troubles began, could be pushed over the brink, the analysts said. Both have pared operations in recent months.
T.W.A. laid off 950 of its 33,000 employees in the last two months, and reduced daily flights 14 percent. Its St. Louis hub, for instance, will have 247 departures by the middle of this month, compared with 302 a year ago.
Pan Am dismissed 2,500 of its 29,000 workers in the last two months. Last month, it announced a deal with United to sell its London routes and one aircraft, and said it would work with United on marketing programs.
Northwest, facing a $1 billion increase in jet-fuel costs for 1991, if prices stay above $1 a gallon, said it had cut $200 million from its 1991 budget by eliminating flights.
Reeling from both the self-inflicted wounds and those caused by outside forces, many industry executives want the Bush Administration to pressure the oil industry to ease prices for jet fuel, much as the President asked oil companies for restraint on gasoline prices after the Kuwait invasion in August.
Lee Howard, head of Airline Economics, a consulting firm in Washington, said jet-fuel costs now represent about 25 percent of an airlines' operating expenses, compared with an average of 15 percent in 1989.
In a statement today, Robert J. Aaronson, president of the Air Transport Association, the industry's chief lobbying arm, sharply criticized the Government for not responding to airlines' concerns. He said the airlines' financial condition was vital to the national economy and the Administration should give "special attention" to its growing losses.
"Unless something is done to stabilize jet fuel prices, it is only a matter of time before other airlines will be forced to take drastic measures," Mr. Aaronson said.

HEADLINE: Consumer Group Questions Milk Hormone's Safety

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3

 BODY:
Consumers Union, the publisher of Consumer Reports, today questioned the safety of an genetically engineered growth hormone that is used to increase milk production in dairy cows, and urged the Food and Drug Administration to immediately halt sales of milk in which traces of the drug are found.
Spokesmen for the manufacturers say the experimental hormone, which increases milk production in cows by 10 to 25 percent, is being tested in more than 100 herds around the country. In 1985 the F.D.A. declared that the hormone was safe, and milk from the experimental herds has been sold in commercial markets ever since. 
 The growth hormone has never been shown to be a hazard, and the questions raised today were meant as a caution before the drug is widespread in the nation's milk supply.
"This is a very powerful growth hormone and the Government has not looked at all the potential health effects," said Dr. Michael K. Hansen, a biologist at the Consumer Policy Institute, the research division of the 54-year-old consumer group and the author of the report criticizing the drug. "They are playing roulette with the nation's milk drinkers."
But a physician for Eli Lilly, one of the manufacturers of the hormone, bovine somatotropin, said today that the issues raised by Consumers Union had been thoroughly reviewed by the F.D.A. in a paper published in August in the weekly journal Science, and the drug was found to be safe.
"In the several years since scientists gained the knowledge to synthesize bovine somatotropin, opponents of this and other modern technologies have tried to frighten the public into believing a litany of unsupported statements," said Dr. John H. Holcombe, q clinical research physician at Eli Lillyin Indianapolis. "You can be assured that milk from BST-supplemented cows is safe for humans, young and old."
The Consumer Union's report, which is based on an analysis of publicly available studies, comes two days before the National Institutes of Health plans to hold a national conference in Bethesda, Md., on the drug's safety.
Bovine growth hormone is the first economically important product of genetic engineering to emerge from the agricultural biotechnology industry. Since the late 1970's, Lilly and three other chemical and drug companies -- the American Cyanamid Company, the Monsanto Company and the Upjohn Company -- have spent more than $500 million on its development, hoping to exploit a worldwide market estimated at more than $1 billion annually. The drug's success or failure is seen by many industrial analysts as an important indicator of the public's willingness to accept genetically engineered products in food.
 
Higher Growth Rates Found
 Dr. Hansen said a study by Monsanto showed that rats fed high concentrations of insulin-like growth factor exhibited higher growth rates. He said such effects indicated that the same could happen in people, particularly children, who are fed hormone-treated milk, and urged the F.D.A. to study the issue more thoroughly.
But Dr. William H. Daughaday, a professor emeritus of medicine at Washington University in St. Louis, said today that the amount of extra insulin-like growth factor in the milk of cows treated with the gene-altered hormone was trivial compared with the levels already in human blood.
Normally, adults and children have 200 micrograms per liter of insulin-like growth factor in their blood, said Dr. Daughaday, who has studied the effects of hormones on people and animals under a research contract from Monsanto. Milk from cows treated with bovine growth hormone has an average of 20 micrograms per liter. Moreover, because it is a protein, much of the insulin-like growth factor would be broken down during digestion, which would further reduce concentrations of the substance in a person's blood.

HEADLINE: Riverboat Gambling Gets a Chance in Mississippi

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: VICKSBURG, Miss., Dec. 1

 BODY:
Mississippians are flirting with legalized casino gambling on riverboats to spur economic development. And as might be expected in this Bible Belt state, the voters' decisions have been mixed.
Voters in the area around Greenville in western Mississippi defeated a gambling proposal two weeks ago. But down river in Natchez, voters approved one last week. 
 Referendums will be held Tuesday in Hancock, Harrison and Jackson counties on the Gulf Coast. Many observers predicted that gambling would be approved in Harrison County, which includes tourist-oriented Biloxi and Gulfport, and defeated in the other counties.
"We're fledglings in the gaming area and we are just trying to find our way," said Charles A. Marx, chairman of the Mississippi tax commission, which will regulate gaming until the state establishes a permanent commission.
 
Authorized by Legislation
 Legislation passed this year authorizes 11 counties on the Mississippi River and three on the Gulf of Mexico to have riverboat gambling on cruise vessels setting sail from those counties or on outfitted barges tied up at the docks.
On Dec. 11, voters in Vicksburg and surrounding Warren County will decide whether to burnish their antebellum cast and Civil War-era attractions with Las Vegas-type glitz along the riverfront. The debate has elements that were crucial to gambling's defeat in Greenville as well as elements which contributed to its success in Natchez. Most observers expect the vote here to be close.
The law requires a referendum in counties where operators submit proposals for gambling and opponents gather petitions with at least 1,500 valid signatures within 60 days. If a proposal is unopposed, the person making it undergoes a background check.
So far, Mr. Marx said, there have been unchallenged proposals in only two counties, Tunica and DeSoto, which are just below Memphis.
 
A Paradox in Mississippi
 The Mississippi bill passed as other states, like Iowa and Illinois, have approved riverboat gambling. In those states, too, the purpose was to spur economic development in river towns that once thrived as centers of manufacturing, agriculture or commerce.
The riverboat gambling bill passed in Mississippi even as lawmakers were emotionally debating both the constitutionality and the morality of statewide legalization of video-poker machines, lotteries and Bingo.
Wilson Golden, a state Democratic committeeman and a lawyer for some of the gambling interests, said the gambling measure may have passed because "the riverboat gambling idea seemed to confine the sin, because it was for 14 other counties and not everybody's county." In addition, he and others said, the referendum clause seemed to guarantee that local standards of morality would triumph.
The Rev. Paul Jones, executive director of the Mississippi Baptist Convention, which has been a leader in opposing gambling in eight counties, said, "The gambling proponents are starting to see that it is difficult to get statewide support for any form of gambling in the South." Mr. Jones said Texas and Tennessee had in recent years adopted local-option measures for parimutuel betting after it was clear that statewide approval was unlikely.
 
Friendly Persuasion
 In the Vicksburg Veterans of Foreign Wars hall, about 100 people picked over a Friday lunch of chicken-neck bones, black-eyed peas and turnip greens as William M. Dougall, the chief executive officer of the Aladdin Hotel and Casino in Las Vegas, told the group what his company hoped to do in the city.
Mr. Dougall's company negotiated with the city and got tentative approval to invest up to $25 million to develop a fixed gambling barge and a touring gambling riverboat. "We hope to make this more of a tourist destination than a gambling destination," he said.
He said gambling would provide up to 1,500 new jobs with an estimated $13 million annual payroll, contribute $3 million a year to city and county government, pay $4 million in various state taxes and spend another $16 million locally for goods and services.
Jimmy Heidel, chairman of the Warren County Chamber of Commerce and the county port commission, said that Vicksburg had an unemployment rate of 7.7 percent and that gambling could spur economic growth.
 
Emphasizing 'Development'
 Trying to tap in to this fear of economic stagnation but aware of the religious feelings in the community, proponents of gambling urge people to vote yes on "riverfront development" and only secondarily mention gambling.
That approach angers Charlie Caldwell, an engineer with the Army Corps of Engineers who heads SIGNET, the major opposition group here. The acronym stands for "Standing in the Gap Network" and uses a phrase from the Old Testament.
"It's deceptive to talk about riverfront development without talking about gambling," Mr. Caldwell said. Proponents do not deal with the possible increase in crime and other physical and social costs, he said.
Vicksburg officials, including Mayor Robert Walker, have remained neutral. In Greenville, officials also stayed out of the fray. Harold Duke, the organizer of the local pro-gambling campaign, cited that as a reason the measure failed, by fewer than 250 votes out of nearly 13,000 cast two weeks ago.
But in Natchez, said Mr. Golden, who ran the campaign for gambling proponents, there were strong endorsements from local officials. There, as in Vicksburg, he said, the campaign emphasized riverfront development and rarely mentioned riverboat gambling.
Mr. Golden also credited the narrow victory of the gambling proponents in Natchez with a strong effort to get out the black vote. But Mr. Caldwell said that the Vicksburg debate is not racial and that SIGNET had black members. Among them is Max Tyler, also an engineer with the Army Corps, who said, "This is a united front."

Dougall, chief executive officer of theLas Vegas-based Aladdin Hotel and Casino, are hoping voters will approve a riverboat gambling referendum in the coming election in Vicksburg. (Hubert Worley Jr. for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: First Executive Refinancing

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 3

 BODY:
The First Executive Corporation said today that it planned to refinance $275 million of bank debt, putting off large payments to lenders for several years to protect its capital base. Under the plan, dividend payments to common and preferred stockholders would be stopped.
First Executive, an insurance holding company based in Los Angeles, had been considering such a restructuring for several months to postpone making the first of three large payment to lenders next year. Payments were coming due of $46.5 million on March 31, $184.5 million in 1993 and $44 million in 1995. 
 While First Executive maintains that it could have made the $46.5 million payment due next March, a restructuring would prevent a further drain on company finances.
Under the preliminary agreement, the company will make a $30 million payment to borrowers participating in the restructuring. Then about $245 million in new notes at a higher interest rate will be issued, coming due in equal installments in 1996, 1997 and 1998.
First Executive also said it had told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it might restructure its preferred stock obligations. The company said there was no guarantee either restructuring would be consummated.
First Executive has been hurt badly by losses of hundreds of millions of dollars caused by the declining value of the company's "junk bond" portfolio.
The well-publicized problems caused concern among policy holders and for a time surrenders of policies were well above normal levels, though the company says that is no longer the case. In the wake of the crisis, the company's ability to borrow large sums has been shut off.
Regulators in California, who are conducting a special review of First Executive's insurance activities, have prevented the company from transferring large amounts of money from its California subsidiary to the parent company.

HEADLINE: Continental's Risks in a Chapter 11 Filing

BYLINE: By ERIC WEINER

 BODY:
The words "Chapter 11" have never helped a company's public image. The question facing executives of Continental Airlines is just how serious the damage will be.
In filing for bankruptcy protection yesterday, Continental has taken great pains to reassure its customers and travel agents that it will be business as usual for the nation's fifth-largest airline. While many travelers say they will indeed continue to fly the carrier, some remember Continental's bankruptcy filing eight years ago, when some flights were canceled and some passengers were left with worthless tickets. 
 One travel agent said yesterday that he had temporarily stopped booking tickets on Continental.
 
 A 'Dangerous' Move
 "In this environment, it's dangerous to go into Chapter 11," said Raymond Neidl, an analyst with Dillon, Read & Company. "Other airlines will pounce on you and try to steal customers and scare travel agents."
Hollis H. Harris, Continental's chairman, said yesterday that the airline would continue to fly its normal schedule, would honor its contracts with travel agents and other airlines and would refund money to any customer who wanted it.
"The travel agent and consumer can book Continental Airlines with absolute confidence," said Ned Walker, a Continental spokesman. He said that of the airline's approximately 1,400 scheduled flights yesterday, not one was canceled because of Continental's financial condition. Of 4,600 calls to its reservations line surveyed by the company, only nine cancellations were reported, which was a lower rate than average, Mr. Walker said.
But the real test of consumer confidence, industry analysts said yesterday, will come early next year, when demand for travel historically falls off. By filing for bankruptcy protection in the midst of the busy holiday travel period, Continental has cushioned itself against, or at least delayed, any consumer backlash.
"They picked a good time," said John Pritchard, a New York lawyer specializing in bankruptcy law. "No judge is going to want to strand these people." A bankruptcy judge has broad powers in deciding how a company would operate and could, as a last resort, call for liquidation.
With flights already booked through the end of the month, most Continental ticket holders have few options.
Ron Smith, the executive vice president of the American Society of Travel Agents, said the trade group was telling its members to book customers on Continental. "We're telling people to hang loose and keep booking them," he said.
To some, the stigma of Chapter 11 may not be as strong as it once was. "The public is more callous about these things," said Russ Thayer, the senior vice president of Airline Economics, a consulting firm in Washington, noting that at least three well-publicized airline bankruptcy filings have occurred in the last decade. In only some of the cases did the airlines stop flying altogether.
Travelers flying Continental from Newark International Airport yesterday had mixed reactions to -- and varying degrees of understanding about -- the filing. "I hope it doesn't go through for at least five days because that's when our flight home is," said Leo Bergeron of San Francisco.
Others showed greater loyalty. "It's a temporary setback," said Gene Carter of Columbia, S.C. "It's a great airline."
But some travel agents are suggesting that their clients not fly Continental, at least for now. "We are suggesting alternative airlines until the smoke clears," said David Perelman, the owner of the D.M.S. Travel Group in New York. "In the past, the passenger and travel agent have been left holding the bag," he said.
In recent years, the travel industry has been seeking greater protection for itself and its clients, should an airline stop flying. The industry has been pushing for a small "default" fee to be collected on each ticket, with the amassed funds to be used to reimburse passengers and travel agents should a carrier stop flying.
The law currently affords passengers little protection. "Passsengers are unsecured creditors who go to the end of the line," said Cornish Hitchcock, legal director of the Aviation Consumer Action Project, a group based in Washington.
 
 'Put Me on Someone Else'
 Other travel agents said they were informing passengers of Continental's financial situation when making reservations. Thomas Nulty, the president of Associated Travel in Santa Clara, Calif., said that after being told of the filing, "every single person said put me on someone else."
Most of Continental's 37,000 employees learned of the filing from the news media. One pilot, who spoke on the condition that he not be identified, said he was not concerned about his job security, but he added, "It's aggravating to have it hanging over our heads all the time."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Filing for bankruptcy will give Continental Airlines a reprieve from paying its debts, and the carrier says it can keep up its regular flights. Passengers at Newark International Airport line up at the ticket counter. (Marilynn K. Yee/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
Excerpts From Gulf Testimony

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from testimony to the Senate Armed Services Committee today by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and Gen. Colin L. Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, as provided by the Federal News Service, a transcription service:
MR. CHENEY: Let me say just a word about sanctions. . . . We think we've shut down much of the flow of goods into Iraq from outside. We don't think it is totally successful but, clearly, he cannot get anything through the Persian Gulf or through the Red Sea. A little bit of air traffic going in, and there's some smuggling. . . . But, basically, in terms of major international commerce, we think we've been able to pretty well dry that up. 
 The question that comes up with respect to sanctions, though, is -- I think it is important for us to focus upon what our objective is and, of course, that's the goal of getting Saddam Hussein out of Kuwait. So, when you talk about sanctions and sanctions working, I think it has to be with that caveat that sanctions working doesn't mean just destruction of the Iraqi economy, it means getting Saddam Hussein out of Kuwait. That's our goal; that's our objective; that's why the sanctions have been employed.
In terms of trying to assess whether or not that will happen, we have to look at several things; we have to look at circumstances inside Iraq. . . . Iraq has been through an eight-year war with Iran. They clearly have the capacity to hunker down, if you will, and operate on a subsistence basis. It's been suggested that if you compare the pain -- the economic pain that he feels now -- with the pain that the population felt during the Iraq-Iran War, that today the pain is not as significant as it was then. Because, of course, then, not only were they faced with the burden of the war, they were also faced with the propositions of casualties and attacks on Iraqi territory.
 
 Iraqi Food Resources
We think we clearly have been successful in closing off the flow of spare parts and military supplies from the Soviet Union and France, which previously were his major suppliers. But, with respect to food and agriculture, the picture is somewhat murkier.
. . .Iraq is not a desolate country by any means. In the valley of the Tigris and the Euphrates, there's a lot of good farmland there. And there are three occasions in the last 25 years when they've been able to double from one year to the next the total amount of cereal production, for example, in country. . . .
Another key element from the standpoint of the sanctions that we have to keep in mind, I think, is that sanctions do not impose pain just on Iraq. They impose pain on everybody who used to do business with Iraq. So, to say that we're going to shut off the flow of commerce to Iraq, it is important for us to remind ourselves that commerce is a two-way street and that when you close the pipeline from Iraq across Turkey, Turkey loses the value and the benefits and the earnings of having operated that pipeline, a significant loss to a nation that obviously is very important to us and a key partner in the coalition.
There are other problems that I think have to be kept in mind as we contemplate what the right course of action might be. While we wait for sanctions to work, Saddam Hussein continues to obliterate any trace of Kuwait and her people. While we wait, he continues to dig in in Kuwait, to send more forces south, to deploy and mobilize additional manpower, to dig more formidable fortifications, so that it's possible that at some point the military effort that might be required to get him out will be more difficult in the future than it is today.
While we continue to wait, he also continues, obviously, his efforts to improve his weapons arsenal, continues to work to see if he can acquire more weapons of mass destruction. And while we wait, he continues to hold hundreds of Americans hostage.
 
 Basic Propositions
So the questions, it seems to me, Mr. Chairman, that have been asked by this committee and that you've addressed over the last few days, are vital ones. But the notion that we can in fact wait a year or two, as some have suggested, that we can wait indefinitely for him to withdraw, comes back again to a couple of very basic, fundamental propositions.
Can we make the judgment that sanctions will achieve the desired result of forcing him out of Kuwait? I don't know. I don't think we can make that judgment. They might, but then again there's a lot of evidence that they won't.
Will the coalition hold? Will this relatively fragile, complex enterprise that we've organized internationally produce the kind of ongoing support, international effort, for the next year or two, that it has for the last four months?
Will the economic pain be greater for Saddam Hussein than it will be for members of the coalition, or for some of our other friends around the world? Will we be in a better position ourselves, as a coalition and as a nation, to use military force in the future than we are now?
. . .If Saddam wins, if he keeps Kuwait, if the coalition falls apart, if economic sanctions don't work, if we don't use military force, if that's the only way to achieve our objective to force him out, then we've got a hell of a problem because of course he will, given his current location and his ability to dominate the gulf, constitute a significant threat to the world economy.
 
Threat to U.S. Allies
He clearly will constitute and does today, a significant threat to our friends in the region, especially to those Arab governments who have had the courage to stand by us to try to stop Saddam Hussein. He clearly represents a threat to Saudi Arabia, to the gulf state governments and, I would argue as well, to President Mubarak's Government in Egypt. . . .
He clearly constitutes a significant threat to Israel. And the United States has long-standing, indeed, commitments and an important strategic relationship with the State of Israel. . . .
My own personal view is that it's far better for us to deal with him now while the coalition is intact, while we have the United Nations behind us, while we have some 26 other nations assembled with military forces in the gulf, than it will be for us to deal with him 5 or 10 years from now when the members of the coalition have gone their disparate ways and when Saddam has become an even better armed and more threatening regional superpower than he is at present.
SENATOR NUNN: Thank you very much, Mr. Secretary.
General Powell?
GENERAL POWELL: . . .What I would like to do in my oral statement is to build on Secretary Cheney's comments and provide you some insight into our military planning, why we recommended what we did, and the underlying military rationale for our deployments and our campaign planning.
. . .The mission is not to punish, the mission is not to retaliate, the mission is not to see if Saddam Hussein will change his mind. The mission is to take action to achieve our political objective if Saddam Hussein does not change his mind.
Many experts, amateurs and others in this town believe that this can be accomplished by such things as surgical air strikes or perhaps a sustained air strike. And there are a variety of other nice, tidy, alleged low-cost, incremental, may-work options that are floated around with great regularity all over this town.
 
 Hussein Can't Control
The fundamental fatal flaw in all such strategies is that it leaves the initiative in Saddam Hussein's hands. He makes the decision as to whether or not he will or will not withdraw. He decides whether he has been punished enough so that it is now necessary for him to reverse his direction and take a new political tack.
Those strategies may work, but they also may not. The initiative is left in Saddam Hussein's hands. These strategies are not decisive; they are not success-oriented. Saddam Hussein has demonstrated for 10 years his willingness and his ability to absorb punishment and to callously expend Iraqi lives and to care not a whit about what happens to the citizens of his country.
Another flaw in such strategies is that it allows Iraq to concentrate essentially on one threat -- as you pull apart these alternative strategies, an air threat. I know the deserts of Kuwait and Iraq are quite different from the triple-canopy jungles of Vietnam or the forests of Germany, and I have no question about the competence and ability of our United States Air Force to inflict terrible punishment.
But one can hunker down, one can dig in, one can disperse to try to ride out such a single-dimension attack. Recognizing that such attack will do grievous damage to the defenders after such a strategy has been executed, the decision is still in the hands of the defender to decide whether or not he has had enough punishment. Such strategies are designed to hope to win, they are not designed to win.
General Schwarzkopf, the Joint Chiefs of Staff and I believe strongly that if the armed forces of the United States are asked to go into combat to achieve a decisive political objective, we must implement a decisive military strategy that seizes the initiative -- one that is designed to win.
 
 Move It or Lose It
The second factor in our consideration is the enemy. We do not overestimate or underestimate the capability of the Iraqi armed forces. We have studied them very closely; we understand their strengths, we understand their vulnerabilities. We must have a military strategy, and I believe we will have a military strategy, that uses our strengths against their vulnerabilities, avoids their strengths and protects us against attacks directed against our vulnerabilities.
Based on our analysis of the mission, the enemy and other factors, we recommended and the President approved a force buildup capable of accomplishing the mission which seizes the initiative and which forces the Iraqis to consider the consequences of a combined overwhelming air-land-sea campaign against a powerful coalition force. The question they will have to consider is, do they move it, or do they lose it?
We don't want a war; we aren't looking for one. The President doesn't want one. The Secretary doesn't want one. No one in uniform wants one. No American wants one. And certainly, no loved one waiting at home wants one. War is a terrible thing with unpredictable consequences, but my job, and the job of the Joint Chiefs of Staff and the commanders involved in this operation, is to make sure that if it is necessary to go to war, we go to war to win. That is the surest way to achieve our objectives and to minimize casualties.

HEADLINE: Argentine Army Revolt Is Crushed Days Before Planned Bush Arrival

BYLINE: By SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 3

 BODY:
Several hundred army dissidents rebelled early today and captured the Argentine Army headquarters and four other installations, creating battlegrounds in an area that President Bush is scheduled to visit on Wednesday.
But loyalist troops, acting on President Carlos Saul Menem's demand for a complete rebel surrender, moved quickly and forcefully to retake the installations and declared tonight that the mutiny had been put down. 
The defeat of the rebels seemed to assure that Mr. Bush would go ahead with his visit, spreading the message of a "new dawn in the New World" that he proclaimed in Brazil today. [Page A14.]
 
'There Is a Surrender'
 "There is a surrender -- it is over," a lieutenant colonel told journalists tonight outside the Libertador Building, the army headquarters, which sits on a small plaza opposite the rear of Casa Rosada, the presidential palace. The army said that it had retaken al of the sites captured by the mutineers and that most of the rebels -- thought to number about 300 -- had been taken prisoner in a succession of operations that lasted some 12 hours.
At about the same time, President Menem told reporters in the palace that "the painted-faces are finished." The dissidents' camouflage-painted faces have become symbols of the four rebellions they have staged in the six years since Argentina returned to civilian government.
The army headquarters fell after nearly two hours of intense firing between loyal troops and those inside the immense structure as four warplanes swooped overhead. Threats to bomb the headquarters were not carried out.
 
Bullets Riddle Vehicles
 Automatic weapons firereverberated through the capital during most of the day, causing pandemonium in rush-hour traffic. Cars and buses in the combat area were riddled with bullets. Many people, unable to believe the extent of the danger on a pleasant, sunny day, gathered on street corners and in plazas as snipers exchanged fire and troops moved into place to retake the 15-story army headquarters.
Late this morning, the army command announced the first of the recaptures, saying it had retaken a battalion headquarters in the suburb of Palomar, and in midafternoon navy rebels surrendered at the coast guard headquarters just two blocks north of Casa Rosada.
Then loyalists in tanks recaptured a regimental headquarters in the Palermo neighborhood, an area of luxury apartment buildings where the United States Embassy is located, and a tank factory taken by the rebels in Boulogne, a suburb northwest of the city. The army said the rebels in the tank factory were attacked from the air. Both actions dragged out for most of the afternoon.
Loyalist forces also cut a highway leading toward the city from the northern province of Entre Rios, from which a rebel column was reported trying to advance in armored vehicles. In early evening, air force planes reportedly bombed the column as it tried to advance at the town of Gualeguaychu, 150 miles north of Buenos Aires. Other provinces were reported calm.
 
At Least 13 Reported Dead
 In late afternoon, the authorities moved journalists away from the Gothic-style army headquarters, with the announced intention of bombing it. Loyalist troops in full battle gear took positions at the rear of the presidential palace and behind trees and other places of cover in the plaza separating the army building from the Casa Rosada as planes roared overhead.
During the day, at least seven loyalist soldiers, one rebel and five civilians were killed, the Government news agency Telam reported. A colonel of unknown affiliation was reported found dead in a tank outside the factory at Boulogne. The army said the five civilians were killed when a tank collided with a public bus outside the tank factory. At least six loyalist soldiers, about a dozen civilians, four of them journalists, and an unknown number of rebels were wounded.
The uprising was the first during the 16-month administration of Mr. Menem, and could not have come at a more difficult time for him. He has been counting on the Bush visit to give a symbolic shot in the arm to his program of privatizing state-owned companies, encouraging foreign investment and finding a place of respect for Argentina.
The Economy Minister, German Gonzalez, said the rebellion raised questions about whether Argentina was mature enough to live in democracy and expressed fear that would-be foreign investors would rethink their plans.
But the United States Ambassador, Terence Todman, tried to allay such doubts even before the uprising was crushed, assuring authorities "in the most firm manner" that President Bush intends to go ahead with his plans to visit Argentina as part of his tour of five South American countries that began Sunday.
 
Martial Law Decree Signed
 The army said the mutineers took over the five sites in a coordinated action beginning at 3:30 this morning. President Menem arrived at the presidential palace from his suburban residence by helicopter at 5 A.M. and remained in his offices throughout the day. Before 7 A.M. he signed a martial law decree. Otherwise, he treated the event like an internal army problem, leaving it to the army Chief of Staff, Gen. Martin Bonnet, to issue the ultimatums and communiques.
Spokesmen for the rebels said that this uprising, like the three previous rebellions, was not intended to overthrow the Government but to force changes in the army command and win better treatment for the military.
But unlike the previous rebellions, which were drawn out and almost bloodless because the loyalist troops felt sympathy for the rebels, both sides in this rebellion showed much more determination to fight things out. The fact that the rebels killed three men at the regimental headquarters in the Palermo neighborhood apparently helped to polarize the situation.
The President apparently also had more active support from the air force and navy than in previous uprisings. None of their men were involved in the rebellion, which was an army affair aside from the participation of some dismissed port police officers in the capture of one building at the coast guard headquarters.
 
Loyal to Jailed Colonel
 Although the leader of today's action was identified by army intelligence only as a Colonel Baraldini, Miguel Angel Toma, chairman of the defense committee of the Chamber of Deputies, said the rebels were loyal to Col. Mohamed Ali Seineldin, who led one of the three previous rebellions.
Colonel Seineldin is now serving 60 days' detention in San Martin de los Andes, a remote mountain town, because of statements he made a few weeks ago about unrest in the army. Because of his popularity with some of the troops, Colonel Seineldin was not cashiered after the last rebellion, two years ago, but was stripped of all responsibility.
Some rebels interviewed by radio stations said one of their goals was for Colonel Seineldin to replace General Bonnet as army chief.
The three previous rebellions occurred during the Government of Raul Alfonsin, leader of the party called the Radical Civic Union, and had the dual purpose of blocking trials of military officers for human rights abuses committed during the so-called dirty war against leftist subversion during the mid-1970's and of winning better salaries and other treatment for the armed forces.
Under the pressure of the successive rebellions, the Alfonsin Government negotiated and gradually gave in to the demands to halt the efforts to prosecute members of the armed forces. The top military commanders and two former Presidents have continued to serve sentences they received before the uprisings.
Mr. Menem, a member of the Justicialist Party founded by Argentina's longtime leader, Juan D. Peron, has promised to pardon the imprisoned officers before the end of the year.
Their continued detention does not appear to have been an issue with the army dissidents who mutinied today. Their primary concern now is a perceived lack of financial and other support.

HEADLINE: CONTINENTAL FILES FOR BANKRUPTCY

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
Continental Airlines filed for protection from its creditors under bankruptcy laws yesterday, attributing the step to the jump in fuel prices and the cost of interest on its huge debts.
The airline, the nation's fifth largest, has been flirting with bankruptcy for months. Since the crisis in the Persian Gulf sent fuel costs sharply higher, Continental's $2.2 billion in debt -- a legacy of a high-growth strategy in the 1980's under its former chairman, Frank Lorenzo -- suddenly loomed as a far greater burden. 
 Eastern Airlines, also acquired by Mr. Lorenzo under that strategy, filed for reorganization under the bankruptcy laws in March 1989. It is now operating under the direction of a trustee.
Continental's bankruptcy filing will give the airline a reprieve from paying its debts so that it can continue its regular flights as it tries to work out a way to pay its bills and return to financial health. In the filing, Continental said that it had $138 million in cash.
Continental executives stressed that the airline planned to continue its flights as usual. They said that frequent-flier programs would continue as before and noted that Judge Helen S. Balick, who is handling the filing in the United States Bankruptcy Court in Delaware, had permitted Continental to keep paying its work force of 37,000 and to pay for ticket refunds to any customers who wanted them.
In addition, other airlines were ordered to continue to honor their operating agreements with Continental. These agreements are crucial to the airline's survival because they enable Continental customers to check through their baggage if they are connecting with another carrier and to have their tickets honored by a connecting airline.
"The consumer should not notice any change in operations," said Hollis L. Harris, the line's president, chairman and chief executive.
Many anxious Continental ticket holders called the airline and travel agents asking if they should change their bookings to another carrier. So far, at least, most were apparently reassured by Continental's intention to keep operating normally. Richard Lisser, a vice president of Continental at Newark International Airport, said he had not seen any increase in cancellations because of the filing.
The problems of Continental, which is a unit of Continental Airlines Holdings Inc., are particularly severe, but its bankruptcy filing underlines the financial pinch being felt throughout the United States airline industry. Most major carriers are suffering under the pressure of higher fuel costs and competition for passengers as the economy weakens.
One airline consulting firm, Airline Economics Inc., has estimated that the industry as a whole will have an operating loss of about $1.5 billion this year compared with an operating profit of $1.4 billion last year. Almost all of the loss came in the second half of the year, as fuel prices soared.
 
88 American Cities Served
 Continental serves 88 American cities and 55 international destinations with 338 aircraft. It is a major carrier along the East Coast with one of its main hubs at Newark International Airport, where it has 305 daily flights and employs about 6,000 workers. The carrier also has a strong route system with other major hubs in Houston and Denver, and it is building up a fourth hub in Cleveland.
Industry analysts were guarded in their assessment of Continental's chances of being able to use the protection afforded under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy laws to work its way back to financial health. They noted that the airline had a valuable route system and had considerably improved its performance in the last few years.
Still, the twin burdens of higher fuel costs and stiff debt payments make its future uncertain. During the first nine months of this year, Continental Airlines Holdings, the airline's parent company, lost $97 million, compared with a loss of $522.8 million for the period last year.
 
'Step in Right Direction'
 The bankruptcy filing "is a step in the right direction," said Kevin Murphy, an airline analyst for Morgan Stanley & Company, "but they are a long way from the road of recovery."
Since Iraq invaded Kuwait in early August, the price of jet fuel has roughly doubled to about $1 a gallon. The increase is greater than the rise in oil prices largely because much of the refining capacity was in Kuwait.
At Continental, fuel accounts for an estimated 25 percent of the airline's operating costs. During the last four months, the airline says it will pay about $230 million extra for fuel because of the price runup since the start of the Persian Gulf crisis.
Given the big increase in fuel costs, the airline must renegotiate its schedule of debt payments with its creditors. At $2.2 billion, Continental's debts are roughly twice that of each of the three largest United States carriers, American, United and Delta. Continental's interest costs alone total about $300 million a year.
 
Debt Is Called Key
 "The key is their debt," said Raymond E. Neidl, the airline analyst for Dillon, Read & Company. "If they get the cooperation of the creditors for their long-term viability they can come out of this."
The creditors will have to be persuaded, analysts note, that they have a better chance of recovering what is owed them by supporting a long-range plan to keep the airline going rather than pushing for liquidation.
Moreover, the continuing difficulties of Eastern Airlines since it filed for bankruptcy protection in 1989 raises questions about Continental's chances of success, analysts say. But they note that there are major differences between the carriers. Continental has not been locked in a bitter strike with its employees. Instead, in recent interviews, Continental employees said that they had confidence in the current management and believed that it was making an effort to expand the airline.
 
Not a Surprise
 The bankruptcy filing was not a surprise. The airline had prepared to file late in October, but its board decided to try to avoid the drastic step.
Mr. Hollis and his managers tried to raise cash by seeking to sell Continental's international routes and other assets. The airline was able to reach an agreement to sell its Seattle-Tacoma-to-Tokyo route to American Airlines for $150 million. The deal must be approved by the Department of Transporation and the Japanese Government before it can be completed. Approval in Washington for the sale is expected to be expedited because of Continental's cash problems.
But a bigger deal to sell the airline's Pacific routes to Delta Air Lines fell through last week. Then, Delta learned that the bankruptcy court handling Eastern's own attempt to return to financial health, begun in 1989, had allowed Martin R. Shugrue, its trustee, to spend $135 million in an attempt to make Eastern profitable.
 
Reasons Not Spelled Out
 Delta abandoned its talks with Continental without detailing the reasons. However, analysts say that Delta did not want to pay heavily for new routes at a time when Eastern, a major competitor, would have additional funds to compete for business by offering low fares.
This is the second use of a bankruptcy filing by Continental. Under Mr. Lorenzo, the airline went into court-protected bankruptcy in the fall of 1983, starting a period of bitter confrontation between Mr. Lorenzo and the workers over cuts in manning and pay.
Recently, Continental has been praised for shedding its reputation for unreliable service and was winning back business passengers.
The complaint rate of the carrier has declined sharply and its on-time performance has improved. For example, Continental's complaint rate as compiled by the Department of Transporation has fallen from 38.6 per 100,000 customers in August 1987 to 1.71 last August.
 
$14 a Share Paid by S.A.S.
 One of the big losers from Continental's financial troubles, at least on paper, is the Scandinavian Airlines System, which bought a 16.8 percent interest in Continental last September. S.A.S. paid $14 a share for 2.25 million shares of Continental for a total of $31.5 million in September. Shares of Continental dropped severely yesterday, down $1.375 and closing at $2 a share in trading on the American Stock Exchange. That would put S.A.S.'s holding at a worth now of $4.5 million.
But S.A.S. executives expressed confidence yesterday that Continental could work out of its difficulties and said that Continental was generating increased traffic for S.A.S. by feeding passengers at Newark into the Scandinavian carrier's international flights.
Jan Carlzon, the president of S.A.S., said there would be no interruption of service by the two carriers. "As Continental now enters negotiations with its creditors , the company's management will get breathing space to solve its problems,"he said.
