HEADLINE: Bush Begins His Latin Tour in Brazil Amid Worry Over Argentina Strife

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRASILIA, Dec. 3

 BODY:
President Bush began a six-day trip through Latin America intended to show support for strapped democracies today, telling Brazil's Congress that it is time "to end the false distinctions between the first world and third world that have too long limited political and economic relations in the Americas."
But even as Mr. Bush spoke of helping Latin America enjoy a "new dawn in the New World," a coup attempt in Argentina overshadowed the beginning of the trip, causing White House advisers to worry that President Bush might have to cancel his visit to Argentina. But they insisted all day that the Argentine President, Carlos Saul Menem, would bring things under control and that the trip was on. 
 After his talks in Brazil with President Fernando Collor de Mello, Mr. Bush is scheduled to go to Uruguay, Argentina, Chile and Venezuela, before returning to Washington on Saturday night.
 
Supercomputer Sale Approved
 The biggest substantive development in the day of meetings in Brazil was Mr. Bush's announcement that he would permit the sale of a high-performance supercomputer to Brazil's state aircraft company, Embraer.
Critics have said that Brazil should be denied such sensitive technology because it can be used to design advanced nuclear weapons. Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger said that Brazilian officials renewed promises today to use the technology under safeguards.
The computer at issue is manufactured by IBM. Information on the cost was not immediately available. Mr. Eagleburger said it was of "relatively high quality but not at the top of the line."
Last week, Mr. Collor cleared away many American worries about his nation's nuclear program by agreeing with President Menem of Argentina to forego the development of nuclear weapons and to place their nuclear installations under bilateral safeguards.
 
Technology Transfers Speeded
 As a result of Brazil's willingness to institute safeguards, the United States and Brazil agreed to set up a bilateral commission to speed the transfer of technology.
Much of the day was taken up with the developments surrounding the coup. The Presidential spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said that it "seems likely" that the military uprising was meant to embarrass President Menem before Mr. Bush's visit.
"The President wants to express his confidence in President Menem and his support for democracy in Argentina," Mr. Fitzwater said. "We intend to proceed on our original schedule."
Mr. Eagleburger was asked this evening in a press briefing whether the uprising underscored the fact that even in the region's democratically elected leaderships, officers in the military still hold positions of authority and are prone to use force when they feel threatened.
"It certainly demonstrates that the military, on occasion, or small portions of the military on occasion are prepared to use force, yes," he replied. But he warned reporters not to take the incident "out of perspective."
"As far as we know, this is a small group of officers," he said. "My argument would be that, fundamentally, democracy in Argentina is working and that this will, when this is over, demonstrate that the roots of democracy in Argentina are fairly deep."
 
Seeking Hemispheric Unity
 Despite the tensions over the Persian Gulf, President Bush decided to make this trip because he wanted to promote unity in the Western Hemisphere during a year when a great deal of attention has gone to the fledgling democracies in Eastern Europe.
Speaking to the joint session of the Brazilian Congress, Mr. Bush inserted a few critical comments about the Iraqi President into his remarks.
He said that he had been told by President Collor that "the brutality and aggression of Saddam Hussein" had cost Brazil $5 billion in higher oil prices "for your economy, struggling to move forward."
Ronan Tito, the Senate leader, welcomed the American President by noting that "we have had a long, difficult change" moving away from "the military and authoritarian regimes which have been the scourge of our region since the Cuban Revolution."
 
Foreign Debt Cited
 Mr. Tito urged Mr. Bush to renegotiate Brazil's foreign debt, which now totals $115 billion. "We are inviting our creditors to become our partners in development and growth, not our partners in poverty," he said.
The lawmakers who spoke before Mr. Bush offered veiled criticisms of the Administration's "demeaning" conditions for renegotiating the region's debt and trading techonology, and about stereotypes in America about Latin America.
Ricardo Fiuza, a Brazilian legislator, asked that the region not be viewed "only as debtors, as producers of drugs and exporters of immigrants," but as partners in commercial enterprises. Before traveling here, Mr. Bush had warned in a press interview that talks on Brazil's $115 billion foreign debt would not be a "central" issue.
The United States is Brazil's largest trading partner, investor and creditor. Brazil is $8 billion in arrears on payment of its private debt and talks in New York have stalled. Nicholas Brady, the Treasury Secretary, discussed the debt issue with Zelia Cardoso de Mello, Brazil's economy minister.
 
Emphasizing Free Trade
 "We recognize that the North American Government cannot lobby private banks," Foreign Minister Francisco Rezek said today of the debt talks. "But it is not in the interest of the creditor country that the debtor cannot recuperate its economic vitality."
Another major American-Brazilian issue is trade. In June, Brazil abolished a list of prohibited imports and set a four-year schedule for reducing tariffs; it also announced plans to open up its computer industry to foreign investment and imports and agreed to discuss joining multilateral trade agreements that regulate services, investment and intellectual property. In return, the United States dropped Brazil from a watch list of major trading violators.
In his public addresses to Brazilian legislators and businessmen, Mr. Bush advocated his plan to create a hemispheric free-trade zone from Alaska to Tierra del Fuego.
Known as the Enterprise for the Americas Initiative, the plan calls for free trade, easier access of foreign investments and reduction of Latin American countries' debts to the United States Government.
American officials have also expressed concern that deforestation in the Amazon contributes to a global warming process known as the greenhouse effect.
Brazil has ended Government subsidies that encouraged ranchers to cut down the rain forest and started a campaign against using fire to clear forest. In return, Brazil wants the United States to cut carbon dioxide emissions and to give financial aid for Amazon conservation projects.
The last American Presidential visit was in 1982, when Ronald Reagan offended many Brazilians with a dinner toast in which he referred to Brazil as Bolivia.
The reception for Mr. Bush was oddly subdued. No crowds lined the street. The modernistic chamber of the Brazilian Senate was only partly filled and many seats on the main floor and in the balcony were empty.

HEADLINE: Brussels Talks Not the Only Trade Game Around

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, Dec. 3

 BODY:
This week's conference involving more than 100 countries may be the biggest trade game in the world, but it is not the only one.
The United States, Canada and Mexico have just concluded important talks in this city on coming negotiations to shape a North American common market. And President Bush is visiting Latin America to promote trade agreements. 
 To many people here for the conference sponsored by the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the most ambitious effort ever to liberalize trade, the timing of these events is more than coincidental.
Should the conference collapse because of the huge differences separating its participants, the United States wants to emphasize that it has alternatives to the global, multilateral process.
"Let's face it," said an American negotiator who spoke on the condition that he not be identified, "there are other avenues that we can take -- bilateral arrangements not only with Latin America but countries of the Pacific basin. It's chiefly developing countries that will be hurt by a collapse here."
Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher put it more succinctly in a conversation with several American reporters today: "We could be O.K. either way. The U.S. always could make regional or other agreements. In all truth, we're doing this now."
The United States has been able to use this situation as a means of strengthening its bargaining hand, especially in the battle with the European Community over trying to cut billions of dollars in agricultural subsidies.
For example, it now has many developing countries as allies in the farm conflict, putting further pressure on the 12-nation community to cut its subsidies.
When senior officials met tonight to try to break the farm deadlock, the Europeans found themselves completely isolated. Most delegates say a failure to reach agreement on agriculture in the next 48 hours could mean collapse of the conference.
With the expansion of the European Community in recent years, along with growing interest in regional trading arrangements in the Western hemisphere, most analysts think the world is headed toward a system of preferential trading blocs. The question, most analysts say, is whether they will be benign or belligerent.
"If we have a strong multilateral system, they can be benign," said C. Michael Aho of the Council on Foreign Relations, one of the American observers at this conference.
 
 Impact on Poorest Countries
 Belligerent blocs would fight trade wars that could curb global trade flows. This could be especially harmful to the poorest countries not associated with any of the blocs because they could find themselves frozen out of the mainstream of world trade.
The multilateral system under the 43-year-old GATT permits the creation of geographical trading arrangements, like the European Community or the Free Trade Area between the United States and Canada, provided they do not erect barriers against other nations. Under the Enterprise for the Americas program that President Bush announced last June, the United States offers both to write free trade agreements and provide debt relief for countries that pursue market-oriented economic restructuring, as is the case now with most countries in the region.
Hector Gros Espiell, the Foreign Minister of Uruguay and president of the GATT Trade Negotiating Committee, told reporters the trading arrangements the Bush Administration contemplates with the Latin American countries "are not incompatable with the GATT and will reinforce multilateral trade."
Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, heads the American negotiating team here. She met yesterday with her Mexican and Canadian counterparts -- John C. Crosbie, Canada's Minister for International Trade, and Jaime Serra Puche, Mexico's Trade Minister -- on the projected North American common market.
The issue was Canada's participation in the negotiations the United States is preparing on the establishment of a free trade area with Mexico, following the arrangement Washington concluded with Ottawa in 1989.
Canada wants to join the talks, but some American officials and lawmakers are worried that Canadian participation could complicate and delay the projected agreement with Mexico.

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
CHENEY SEES NEED TO ACT MILITARILY AGAINST THE IRAQIS

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3

 BODY:
Defense Secretary Dick Cheney told Congress today that military action rather than economic sanctions was the only sure way of forcing Iraqi troops to leave Kuwait.
Mr. Cheney rebutted suggestions from leading Democrats and many former military officials that the United States wait a year or more to see if economic sanctions work. He told the Senate Armed Services Committee that delaying military action that long would further damage the world economy, allow Iraq to stiffen its defenses and risk the erosion of the international effort to compel President Saddam Hussein of Iraq to remove his forces. 
 "There is no guarantee that sanctions will force him out of Kuwait," Mr. Cheney said, adding that the United States does not have "an indefinite period of time to wait for sanctions to produce the desired result."
 
'He Can Ride Them Out'
 "Given the nature of the regime, given Saddam Hussein's brutality to his own people, his very tight control of that society, his ability to allocate resources for the military, their ability to produce their own food basically inside, he can ride them out," Mr. Cheney said, referring to sanctions. [Excerpts, page A12.]
Mr. Cheney's remarks seemed intended not only to defend the Administration's decision to get a United Nations Security Council resolution authorizing the use of force after Jan. 15, but also to step up pressure on the Iraqi Government. Many Administration officials contend that calls for a longer period for the sanctions to work have sent the wrong signal to Mr. Hussein.
The Defense Secretary's arguments prompted a quick rejoinder from Senator Sam Nunn, the committee chairman, who challenged Mr. Cheney's assertions that Washington could not afford to give sanctions time to work.
 
Nunn Wants Time
 "If we have a war, we're never going to know whether they would have worked, would we?" Mr. Nunn, a Georgia Democrat, said. "The way you find out if sanctions are going to work is to give them enough time to work."
Mr. Nunn's comments echoed testimony to the committee last week by two former Chairmen of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Adm. William J. Crowe and Gen. David Jones, who urged the Administration to postpone military action against Iraq and give economic sanctions a year or more to work. In interviews and at a conference in Alabama, most former Defense Secretaries have also urged patience.
In his appearance today, Mr. Cheney also asserted that President Bush had the authority to order an attack on Iraq without Congressional approval, in remarks that were criticized by Senator Edward M. Kennedy and other Democrats.
"I'm concerned that we don't have a consensus here in this country that would support a war," said Senator Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia, a member of the panel and President pro tem of the Senate.
As Mr. Cheney outlined the rationale for possible early military action, Gen. Colin L. Powell, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, described war plans for the Persian Gulf, saying American forces were preparing for a combined air, ground and sea attack seeking to win a quick victory, rather than wage an escalating air campaign against Iraq.
Mr. Cheney and General Powell repeatedly told the panel that Mr. Bush had not yet decided to order an attack on Iraq. To some extent, their remarks were intended to keep the pressure on Mr. Hussein as Washington prepares for talks with Baghdad.
Iraq's Foreign Minister, Tariq Aziz, is expected to visit Washington next week for talks with Mr. Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3rd, and Mr. Baker is likely to go to Iraq sometime before Jan. 15 to meet with Mr. Hussein. The talks were proposed last week by Mr. Bush after the United Nations Security Council approved a resolution authorizing the use of force against Iraq after Jan. 15 if it does not withdraw from Kuwait by then.
 
Appeals to Congress and Public
 But as thousands of American reinforcements head toward the gulf, the top Pentagon officials were addressing Congress and the American public, as well as Iraq, in making the case for possible early military action should the diplomatic effort fail.
While most of these arguments have been made by other officials in recent weeks, Mr. Cheney's presentation, buttressed by General Powell, was the most systematic effort by the Administration to lay the groundwork for possible military action against Iraq early next year.
The Defense Secretary maintained that Iraq was likely to cope with the sanctions by increasing its agricultural production and holding military activity to a minimum to curtail the demand for spare parts.
He also argued that the economic sanctions were hurting American allies like Turkey, which has lost revenues by closing its oil pipeline with Iraq, as well as other countries that are hard hit by the increase in oil prices.
As Washington waited for the sanctions to work, Iraq would continue to destroy what was left of Kuwait, strengthen its defensive fortifications there and mobilize additional troops, Mr. Cheney said.
In addition, he argued, the "relatively fragile" multinational coalition might falter if military action was deferred."
"It is far better for us to deal with him now than it will be for us to deal with him 5 or 10 years from now, when the members of the coalition have gone their disparate ways and when Saddam has become an even better armed and more threatening regional superpower than he is at present," Mr. Cheney argued.
 
Shift Since October
 His statements against waiting for economic sanctions to work ran counter to arguments he made in mid-October, when the Administration appeared to be relying on the sanctions. Mr. Cheney said at a news conference then with Defense Secretary Tom King of Britain that the sanctions and the embargo were beginning to have an effect,
"I would think if I were in his place tonight, I would be concerned that over the next few months he will see the erosion of his political base within Iraq, the erosion of his economy within Iraq and the erosion of the capability of the enormous military machine he's deployed in Kuwait and against Saudi Arabia," Mr. Cheney said at the time.
Though Mr. Cheney was not asked about those comments today, he said he had modified his thinking on the utlity of sanctions because of Iraq's decision to call off gasoline rationing and new Administration analyses about Iraq's ability to increase farm production and to mobilize additional troops.
The Secretary's argument for early military action were skeptically received by Democrats on the panel.
Senator John Glenn, the Ohio Democrat, said the argument about the weakness of the coalition was a "Chicken Little approach to our policy: the sky is falling and the only option is war."
And Senator Nunn disputed Mr. Cheney's argument that the United States should force a resolution of the gulf crisis to alleviate the economic hardships experienced by Eastern European and other nations hit hardest by rising oil prices. Instead of staging an attack, Washington should ask Saudi Arabia to contribute its "windfall profits" from increased oil production and rising prices to such hard-hit nations, Mr. Nunn said. He cited figures indicating that Saudi Arabia's oil revenues have shot up $30 billion because of the gulf crisis.
 
Rebuts Other Experts
 As Mr. Cheney outlined the rationale for early military action, General Powell sought to rebut experts -- including Senator Nunn, former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger and others -- who say the United States should rely largely on air power in any attack, instead of waging a ground campaign, which critics fear could involve many casualties.
General Powell argued that reliance on air power might not decisively defeat Iraq, would not allow the United States to maintain the military initiative and would allow Iraqi forces to concentrate on a single American threat, air power.
"I have no question about the competence and ability of our United States Air Force to inflict terrible punishment," General Powell said. "One can hunker down, one can dig in, one can disperse to try to ride out such a single-dimension attack.
"Recognizing that such attack will do grievous damage to the defenders after such a strategy has been executed, the decision is still in the hands of the defender to decide whether or not he has had enough punishment. Such strategies are designed to hope to win; they are not designed to win."
In contrast to the critics, General Powell said the American military was planning a "combined overwhelming air, land, sea campaign."
But Senator Glenn, a former pilot, questioned General Powell's military approach, saying the United States should apply the embargo for an extended period to deprive the Iraqi military of needed supplies. If war comes, the United States should then rely on an extended air compaign, Senator Glenn said, so casualities can be held down.
"I don't have much doubt that sometime we may have to wind up in combat over there, but let's do it embargoing him to as weak a position as possible," Senator Glenn said. "I don't see why we want to rush that schedule and not let these steps take their normal course of events, to make certain that we keep casualties as low as possible."

HEADLINE: 200 Contract Words Stall News Talks

BYLINE: By DAVID E. PITT

 BODY:
Forty days after the start of a bitterly divisive walkout, The Daily News and its unions still insist that they are willing to negotiate new contracts to replace the ones that expired last spring.
But despite some 200 bargaining sessions since January -- nearly a dozen of them since the strike began on Oct. 25 -- both sides remain oceans apart over management's demands for up to $70 million in labor cuts, including elimination of what it sees as needless overtime, rampant labor abuses and outdated work rules, like one that requires up to 700 drivers when The News says far fewer are needed. 
 Yesterday, leaders of the 700-member local of the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers of New York and Vicinity -- the first of nine unions to strike after The News replaced 60 drivers over a seemingly minor labor dispute -- showed up for their second negotiating session since the strike began.
There was no immediate word on the outcome of talks, held in lower Manhattan under the eye of a Federal mediator. But union officials said beforehand that they were not optimistic.
 
$150 Million Damage Suit
 In the last week, the negotiating atmosphere -- already poisoned by a vicious circle of public charges and countercharges -- grew worse after The News filed a $150 million damage suit in Federal court accusing labor leaders of racketeering. The suit repeated charges of a union-led conspiracy to terrorize news vendors, despite the findings of police investigators that no such conspiracy existed.
But the chief sticking point in the talks, labor leaders say, remains the same one that has bedeviled the negotiations for nearly a year: The News's insistence that new contracts include a paragraph of slightly more than 200 words titled "Management Rights."
The publisher, James Hoge, describes the paragraph as no more than contractual language expressing the fundamental right of any business to control itself. A spokesman, John T. Sloan, added, "That clause is found in 90 percent of all contracts in the newspaper industry today."
But union leaders say that if they were to agree to the broadly worded provision, they would be granting The News the right to modify or eliminate every agreement that the unions have won over decades of collective bargaining. It is thus not surprising, they say, that the phrase is repeated like a mantra by The News's chief negotiator, Robert Ballow, a Nashville lawyer reviled by organized labor for his success in breaking newspaper unions.
"I ask him, 'Tell me what you need for relief,' " Michael J. Alvino, the drivers' union president, complained over the summer. "And he always says, 'Give us management rights and we'll tell you.' "
The management rights clause, included in copies of proposed contracts delivered to union leaders last January, begins: "The union recognizes that any and all rights concerned with the management of the business and the direction of the work force are exclusively those of the Publisher."
It ends by saying that management may "take any other measures which the Publisher deems necessary for the orderly, efficient and profitable operation of its business."
Under Federal law, management and unions are required to bargain collectively -- and in good faith -- even in the event of a strike.
But union leaders complain that their acceptance of the management rights clause would would give The News virtual fiat to modify any contract. Moreover, they assert that Mr. Ballow (pronounced buh-loo) -- who has been in charge of the negotiations since they began -- has made management rights a nonnegotiable item.
Repeated efforts to reach Mr. Ballow for comment were unsuccessful. But Mr. Sloan denied the accusations.
Management rights, he said, would be subject to negotiation. He added that if after accepting management rights, a union were to object to any contract provision pertaining to hours, wages or working conditions, "then they are welcome to submit their own language" for further negotiation.
 
Strikers Demand Old Jobs Back
 The unions counter that several other major problems are standing in the way of a settlement, including what to do about the nonunion substitutes. The unions have insisted that all strikers must be given their jobs back.
But by far the biggest stumbling block, said George E. McDonald, president of the Allied Printing Trades Council, is labor's belief that The News has never had the slightest intention of negotiating new contracts.
The chief exhibit in the unions' evidence is a deposition from Vincent Tese, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's Commissioner of Economic Development, who swore in May that Mr. Hoge had visited him on April 17 and "made it clear that management was looking to achieve significant changes in the contracts and that the unions would never agree to the changes."
Mr. Hoge denies the accusation, saying Mr. Tese's statement is "riddled with errors."
A News spokesman added that Mr. Hoge remained hopeful about talks.

HEADLINE: Dow, Retaining Momentum, Rises by 5.94

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Building on Friday's gain, stock prices continued to advance yesterday, propelled in part by A.T.& T.'s $6 billion proposal to buy NCR, the computer giant once known as the National Cash Register Company.
High-tech stocks were especially strong following the offer. 
 NCR soared 24 3/4, to 81 1/2, with 8.5 million shares changing hands. A.T.& T. fell 2, to 30 1/8, on 5 million shares, as traders bought NCR and sold A.T.& T. in a standard Wall Street strategy to hedge their bets in case the deal eventually collapsed.
Airline stocks gained after Continental Airlines' said it had filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection.
And retail stocks strengthened after Joseph H. Ellis, retailing analyst for Goldman, Sachs, mentioned several on Friday on the television program "Wall Street Week."
Changing directions drastically several times during the day, the Dow Jones industrial average jumped 16 points at the opening and then fell back by the same amount. By 2:30, the Dow was ahead again 15, only to slide 18 within an hour.
The Dow recovered somewhat in the final half-hour, ending the day at 2,565.59, up 5.94. Trading volume fell to 177 million shares, from 192.4 million on Friday.
"What we're seeing is a buildup of investor conviction," said Eugene E. Peroni, chief technical analyst for the investment firm Janney Montgomery Scott in Philadelphia, adding that "the market handled itself well last week, despite all the economic ambiguities and military uncertainties."
"It was largely tied into the price of oil," said Edgar Wachenheim 3d, chairman of Greenhaven Associates, a Manhattan investment manager. Crude oil, which plunged $4.06 a barrel on Friday, rose only 30 cents yesterday, to $29.25.
Program trading was also strong, tending toward selling. Birinyi Associates, which monitors such activity, said three selling waves took nearly 14 points off the Dow.
Among the high-tech issues, Digital Equipment rose 2 3/4, to 54 1/2; Apple Computer 1 3/8, to 38 1/8; Microsoft 1 5/8, to 73 7/8; Cray Research 1 7/8, to 31 3/8; Motorola 1 1/2, to 52, and Compaq Computer 1 3/8, to 54 1/2.
In the airline group, Continental fell 1 3/8, to 2 1/8, but Delta rose 1 3/4, to 58 1/2; UAL 1 7/8, to 99 3/8; Southwest Airlines 1 3/8, to 18 7/8, and AMR 1 1/4, to 48 1/2,
Among the retail sector mentioned by Mr. Ellis, the Goldman, Sachs analyst, Home Depot rose 2, to 37 3/4; the Limited 1 1/2, to 17 1/4; Wal-Mart 3/4, to 30 7/8 and Toys "R" Us 1 1/8, to 24 3/8.
 
 Stocks Drop in Tokyo
 TOKYO, Tuesday, Dec. 4 (REUTERS) -- Stock prices were sharply lower today, with the Nikkei index of 225 issues closing below 22,000 for the first time since Oct. 1. The Nikkei ended 863.38 points lower, or 3.8 percent, at 21,862.61. Brokers reported that heavy index selling, amid thin overall trading, depressed a market that was already suffering from the effects of a weaker yen.

HEADLINE: FREER TRADE TIES TO MOSCOW BACKED

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3

 BODY:
The National Conference on Soviet Jewry, a confederation of more than 300 Jewish organizations, announced today that it would support President Bush should he decide to waive trade restrictions against the Soviet Union that are tied to the free emigration of Soviet Jews.
The organization released a statement noting that 180,000 Soviet Jews have left or are about to leave the Soviet Union this year, compared with 70,000 in 1989. 
 "We expect that the President will confirm that he has the assurances for the waiver required" the organization said, referring to conditions for easing trade with Moscow that are contained in the Jackson-Vanik ammendment.
 
'Goal of Freer Emigration'
 Martin A. Wenick, executive director of the group, said that "if by waiving Jackson-Vanik, it will contribute to the goal of freer emigration, then the President ought to do it."
The amendment, an irritant in United States-Soviet relations since it was enacted in 1974, linked most-favored-nation tariff treatment for Communist countries directly to their emigration policies. The provision was approved principally to encourage Moscow to rescind laws that prohibited millions of Soviet Jews from leaving the country.
The Soviet Union has yet to change its basic emigration laws, but it has significantly altered the ways the laws are applied, thus expediting the departure of many of the Soviet Jews who sought to leave.
A senior State Department official said the Jewish group's decision would make it politically easier for the Administration to issue a waiver of Jackson-Vanik as well as to provide credits for purchases of American grain to forestall possible food shortages in the Soviet Union this winter.
 
'Economic Migration' Feared
 The official said the Administration's "old position" of insisting that emigration laws be changed "is beginning to haunt us" now that fears are growing that a sweeping emigration revision might send millions of unwelcome "economic migrants" into Eastern Europe, swamping the attempts to transform centralized economies into ones that embrace free markets.
Mr. Bush said on Friday he was asking his principal advisers for recommendations on a possible Jackson-Vanik waiver to be delivered this week. Senior officials in the Agriculture and State Departments, as well as American farmer groups, have already endorsed a reversal.
Administration officials said they believe that Mr. Bush would like to waive the amendment as a way to show his support for President Mikhail S. Gorbachev at a time of growing economic and nationalistic pressures in the Soviet Union.
 
'Sustained High Levels'
 The National Conference on Soviet Jewry statement said that "truly free emigration does not yet exist in the Soviet Union." But it noted that its re-examination of the issue comes "against the backdrop of almost two years of sustained high levels of Jewish emigration from the Soviet Union."
The group's statement was far more sympathetic in its assessment of the Soviet position than other groups pressing for freer Soviet emigration.
In a letter to Mr. Bush sent last week, the Union of Councils for Soviet Jews argued that a waiver of Jackson-Vanik would signify "that we are letting the U.S.S.R. off the hook" for continued human rights abuses.
"The agreements of the Helsinki Process, requiring freedom of emigration, no less than the strictures of Jackson-Vanik, compel the conclusion that this is the moment to press, not release, the leverage," it said.

HEADLINE: A Lilliputian Paris of the 40's Opens at Met Museum

BYLINE: By ANNE-MARIE SCHIRO

 BODY:
Don't be surprised if next fall's fashion collections have a strong air of the 1940's. Designers who visit this year's Costume Institute exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, which had a gala preview last night, could be influenced by the full skirts, wasp waists, gently tailored suits and feminine evening dresses. Some women were already in the mood. Donna Karan, Kimberly Farkas and Marina Schiano wore fairy-tale ballgowns reminiscent of the 40's. They laughed as they jumped over rain puddles and hitched up their skirts in a dash up the museums steps. "Everything in fashion has its relevance," Ms. Karan said as she headed into the show. 
 The exhibition, "Theatre de la Mode," comprises 150 miniature mannequins in French haute couture styles from spring 1946 with strong harbingers of the New Look of 1947. The mannequins are displayed in sets that were originally designed by leading artists and designers of the era and have been recreated for the show, which ran in Paris from May to September of this year.
 
A Memory of 1946
 Bill Blass saw the exhibition in 1946 at the Whitelaw Reid mansion on Madison Avenue. "I had just come out of the Army," he said, "and I remember it well. Those clothes are still totally contemporary."
"Especially the Jacques Fath," said Pat Buckley, chairman of the evening. "He did my trousseau."
Among the other couturiers represented in the Met show are Lucien Lelong (whose designer at the time was a man named Christian Dior), Nina Ricci, Molyneux, Maggy Rouff, Jeanne Lanvin, Schiaparelli, Marcel Rochas, Robert Piguet, Balenciaga and Pierre Balmain. There are tiny handbags by Hermes, platform-soled pumps and ankle-strap shoes.
"Oh, those divine little shoes," murmured Mary McFadden, who had also seen the exhibition before. "But not in the 40's," she said, laughing and leaning on the arm of her husband, Kohle Yohannan. "We saw it in Paris last summer."
Those who paid $900 each to see the show last night included Ivana Trump, Sonia Braga, David Bowie, Valentino Garavani, Blaine and Robert Trump, Nancy and Henry Kissinger, Kelly and Calvin Klein, Carolyne Roehm and Henry Kravis. And Isabella Rossellini, daughter of one of the premiere movie stars of the 40's.
When the war ended in 1945, France was in economic ruin, said Katell le Bourhis, associate curator of the museum's Costume Institute. "The only industry that could be revived very quickly was couture because it didn't need factories," she said. "It depended on creativity and skills, and the skills were still there."
So the French fashion industry, contrived a traveling exhibition in miniature to show the world that Paris was still the capital of fashion. In addition to the publicity value, the exhibition was intended to entice wealthy women to order clothes from the miniature samples.
The first show, in Paris in March 1945, and an updated version in 1946 traveled to London, Leeds (origin of many couture fabrics), Stockholm, Copenhagen, Barcelona, Vienna, New York and San Francisco. Admission was charged to help French war relief.
The original 15 sets, designed by the likes of Jean Cocteau and Christian Berard, were lost. But the dolls ended up at the Maryhill Museum in Goldendale, Wash. They were returned to Paris for restoration in 1984.
 There are vestiges of the tailored suits and shoulder bags of the war years in the mannequins on exhibit, alongside full-skirted dresses based on couture styles of the late 1930's. Even an amateur can see how the full-skirted dresses with belted waistlines evolved into Dior's New Look.
The beaded and bejeweled evening dresses with their sweeping long skirts make dramatic tableaux, especially in a three-dimensional theater set by Berard with red drapes, a crystal chandelier and box seats on two sides of the stage. The evening dresses are almost timeless; the day clothes really tell the story of the fashion of the day.
 
Mannequins Strolling
 Among the sets displaying daytime suits and dresses are scenes of mannequins window-shopping in the Place Vendome and strolling outside the Palais Royal. A setting of the Ile de la Cite has mannequins modeling the couture equivalent of sportswear, including a pants costume with a bright green hacking jacket over a matching vest by Freddy Sport.
The only set that relates to the war itself is Cocteau's surrealistic bombed-out maid's room with a witch in a gray tulle Balmain dress flying from the rafters.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
McGee Signed by Giants; Expos Retain Martinez

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ROSEMONT, Ill., Dec. 3

 BODY:
The collusion settlement between baseball's owners and the players may not be ready for ratification at their respective meetings this week, but it nevertheless had a profound impact today on the San Francisco Giants and the Montreal Expos.
Reacting to the impending "free-look" free agency that will be part of the settlement, the Expos kept Dennis Martinez, their No. 1 pitcher, by signing him to a three-year, $9.5 million contract. The Giants, however, decided to let Brett Butler, their center fielder and leadoff hitter, leave them, and instead signed Willie McGee, a free agent, to a four-year contract for $13 million. 
 In other free-agent signings, Terry Pendleton, the St. Louis Cardinals' former third baseman who this year batted a career-low .230, joined the Atlanta Braves with a four-year, $10.2 million contract, and Kevin Gross, a pitcher with an 80-90 career record who hasn't had a winning season since 1985, became a member of the Los Angeles Dodgers' starting rotation with a three-year, $6.4 million contract.
 
Rosen Explains His Motives
 Al Rosen, the Giants' general manager, explained his stunning announcement here at baseball's winter meetings by saying he did not want to sign Butler to the four-year, $15 million contract the player wanted to remain with the team. If he remained, Butler would waive his right to leave as one of 16 players who will become free agents as soon as there is agreement on the settlement of the collusion case, in which an arbitrator ruled the owners colluded to hold down free-agent salaries.
Kevin Mitchell and Will Clark each have four-year, $15 million contracts with the Giants. Rosen had offered Butler $10 million for four years, the same deal he gave Bud Black, a free-agent pitcher with a career 83-82 record. The general manager did not attempt to negotiate from the respective proposals.
"I felt the asking price was more than we could meet and I didn't want to leave here without a center fielder," Rosen said.
McGee, 32 years old, won the National League batting championship this year with a .335 average even though he finished the season with Oakland of the American League. Butler, who batted .309, scored 108 runs and had 51 stolen bases this season, has two years left at $1.35 million a year on his existing contract.
Richard Moss, Butler's agent, said that Rosen told him the Giants would be willing to release Butler as soon as the collusion settlement is ratified so he could begin talking to other clubs immediately.
 
A Number of Possibilities
 "Brett is interested in the possibility of a number of clubs," Moss said. "What we discussed with the Giants was in the context of the Giants, and that does not mean we will insist on those figures with other clubs."
The Expos took the opposite approach to the Giants. They wanted to make sure they did not lose Martinez.
"The Player Relations Committee recently had a briefing on the settlement, and after hearing what they said, we had the strong feeling that he would be a second-look free agent," Dave Dombrowski, the Expos' general manager, said. "There's no question about it. We dealt with him as if he were a free agent."
Fifteen other players, including Jack Clark, Jack Morris and Butler, will become free agents as soon as the settlement talks are completed. One lawyer involved in the talks said today that the two sides were exchanging drafts but that some issues remained to be resolved and it was possible that an agreement would not be ready for Wednesday, when the owners hold their final meeting of the annual winter meetings here.
Martinez, 35 years old, had a 10-11 record this year, but the Expos' made him baseball's fifth highest-paid pitcher. With an average annual value of $3,166,667, he only ranks behind Dave Stewart, Nolan Ryan, Mark Davis and Mark Langston.
 
55-41 Record With Expos
 Martinez, who has compiled a 55-41 record in five years with Montreal, was the 21st player and McGee the 22d to sign a contract worth $3 million or more, an economic category of players that did not exist 54 weeks ago. He had a contract calling for a $1.6 million salary for next season, but the Expos tore that up and gave him the new deal.
"We were very concerned we would lose him," Dombrowksi said. "We didn't feel we could go into the season losing our No. 1 pitcher. To compete, we needed to sign him."
In another free-agent matter, Bill Goodstein, Dave Righetti's agent, checked in today, seeking to continue his talks with the Yankees.
"We haven't made a proposal," Gene Michael, the general manager of the Yankees, said, "because we can't get the number of years straightened out. If we get that straightened out, I think we'll work it out."
Goodstein declined to identify other teams interested in Righetti, but a friend of Righetti said Minnesota and California are two.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Union-Management Plan To Help Young Players

BYLINE: By CLAIRE SMITH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ROSEMONT, Ill., Dec. 3

 BODY:
A long-sought thaw in baseball's labor relations appeared closer to coming to fruition today as a first-ever joint venture between management and the Major League Baseball Players Association was outlined here at the winter meetings.
The new program, revealed by Commissioner Fay Vincent in his annual state-of-the-game address, is one designed to better prepare young players for the pressures of the big leagues. The plan, along with the imminent naming of a joint committee to study the economics of the game, was portrayed by Vincent as yet another example of efforts "to establish some common ground" between players and management. 
 Vincent, whose speech was delivered in written form because he is continuing to recover from pneumonia at his home in Greenwich, Conn., also referred to an arbitrator's recent settlement in a case that ruled baseball's owners colluded in trying to lower payments to free agents. He said both the owners and the players were days away from deciding whether to approve the $280 million settlement.
"Should it be approved," Vincent said, "then finally we can put this episode behind us for good, and move forward."
 
Concept Developed by N.B.A.
 Donald Fehr, executive director of the players union, acknowledged on-going attempts to improve the relationship between players and management.
"The fact is, if the relationship improves, it hinges almost entirely on whether the collusion settlement goes through and whether the free-agent market continues to show signs that it is operating and well," Fehr said by telephone from Orlando, Fla., where the union's representatives are about to begin their own meetings. "If the relationship does improve, everybody has to be encouraged. It doesn't mean you agree on everything; if it could avoid unnecessary squabbling, that could be a step in the right direction."
Fehr has been invited to join in the leadership for the joint venture. He will propose the idea to his union this week.
"This is a concept that was developed by the N.B.A. and it's our understanding that it's been reasonably successful over there," Fehr said.
 
Common Ground
 The very idea that such an effort is being made may be as important as the program itself, said the program's architect, Steve Greenberg, the deputy commissioner, who is designing what is tentatively called the Player Personnel Development Committee.
"The key thing is that we are doing something constructive with the union," Greenberg said. "The common ground between the union and the clubs is much greater than one might think."
Officials hope to have the committee in place by February.
 
Little Progress
 Also today, baseball released hiring statistics in its annual equal-opportunity employment report, and major league officials admitted that the numbers were flat.
In 1990, there were 305 Asian, black and Hispanic front-office employees, compared with 273 the year before and 142 in 1988. The percentage remained at 15 percent, the same as 1989.
As for on-field positions, Asian, black and Hispanic managers, trainers, scouts, coaches and instructors numbered 324 this year as opposed to 313 in 1989 and 199 in 1988. The percentage remained at 20 for a second consecutive year, however.
Greenberg said: "The numbers are flat, but I take that as not really a negative sign, because our office has not been as active in this area as we have wanted to be and have vowed to be because of the number of activities that have kept us very busy during the commissioner's first year in office. But we have reaffirmed our push in this area and I would expect to see an up tick in the numbers a year from now."

HEADLINE: U.S. Pushes for Lead Over Japan With Chips Etched by X-Rays

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD

 BODY:
ENGINEERS have switched on an innovative machine that could help the United States win a clear lead in the international race to pack more circuits onto computer chips, seizing the initiative back from Japanese manufacturers.
The device, at the Brookhaven National Laboratory on Long Island, is the nation's first compact synchrotron, a small, ring-shaped particle accelerator that emits X-rays to etch exceptionally fine lines on the slivers of silicon that lie at the heart of most complex electronic devices. The $32 million machine is a mere 13 feet long and 7 feet wide, a far cry from giant particle accelerators from which it descends. Small size means its offspring could easily fit into chip factories. The machine began its first phase of operation in October. 
 "It's got the possibility of being a winning ticket," said Dr. Gwyn P. Williams, a Brookhaven physicist who believes the United States leads Japan in perfecting the X-ray technology. "We could capture some huge percentage of the world market."
Japan's share of the world chip market soared in the 1980's, even as America's dropped. Between 1980 and 1990, the United States semiconductor industry saw its market share fall to under 40 percent from 60 percent. Worse, the American share in chip-making equipment also fell dramatically, leaving the industry increasingly dependent on foreign suppliers.
Today the Japanese have an X-ray effort larger than that of the United States. But experts here are eager to push ahead, noting that technological shifts are often the time when market leadership can be wrested away by bold entrants. The Brookhaven machine, financed by the Defense Department, is a prototype meant to help American manufacturers master the field of X-ray lithography in the mid to late 1990's. The X-ray process can easily etch circuit lines of about 0.1 micron (one-thousandth the width of a human hair), which in theory would allow the equivalent of four billion transistors to be crammed onto a computer chip. In comparison, the standard etching process today works at around 1 micron (one-hundredth the width of a human hair) to make computer memory chips equivalent to one million transistors.
X-ray lithography is not the only aspirant for the task of etching finer lines. Scientists around the world are racing to invent new ways to cut tiny circuits as traditional techniques using visible light reach their limit. Candidates for the next generation of chip-making machines include electron beams, ion beams and X-rays produced by a variety of devices, including particle accelerators and lasers.
X-rays are seen as a top choice for advancing the field, with some experts saying their production by accelerators is crucial to the international chip race. "If we don't develop it we'll lose the lead for sure," said Dr. Franco Cerrina, director of the Center for X-ray Lithography at the University of Wisconsin.
The Brookhaven machine and complementary X-ray devices at Wisconsin and other academic research centers are important examples of how Congress is quietly putting money into high-technology research, largely over the objections of free marketers in the Bush Administration who would leave the job to industry. For the fiscal year 1990, Congress put some $30 million into the work. For the fiscal year 1991, which began on Oct. 1, it doubled the figure. The X-ray work is administered by the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency.
Today ordinary light is the main tool in making chips. The light passes through a "mask" much like a photographic negative and then onto the surface of a silicon wafer coated with photosensitive chemicals. This process is known as lithography. The end result is an etched chip. Over the years, etched lines have become increasingly fine and circuits more complex, vastly increasing the power of computer chips and the electronic devices they drive.
The natural limit to that process is now on the horizon. The consensus among experts is that light will work down to about 0.3 microns, a micron being a millionth of a meter. Below that, light waves are too large to render sharp images.
X-rays are a leading candidate for the next step in chip making because of their exceedingly short wavelengths. A crucial question is how to generate them. Medical X-rays are too strong, penetrating most matter. In contrast, "soft" or low-energy X-rays interact well with chip-making materials. But the best way to make them in the needed quantities has been with huge, costly, unwieldy particle accelerators known as synchrotrons.
These machines push electrons to nearly the speed of light. As the electrons zip around the large circular rings, they shed enormous numbers of soft X-rays in a process known as synchrotron radiation. Today the world's largest synchrotron center is at Brookhaven. Its two main rings are 50 feet and 180 feet in diameter. The International Business Machines Corporation, considered the world leader in X-ray lithography for chip making, has done much work on the rings at the Brookhaven National Laboratory.
Synchrotrons were pioneered in the United States. But their adaptation for chip making, a matter of shrinking their size, has been led by the Japanese, who in an aggressive program have built at least three very small synchrotrons for X-ray lithography and more than a half dozen larger ones.
"It's the same old story," said Rick Cole, a Wisconsin X-ray lithography expert. "The U.S. develops the technology and then Japan takes it and beats us at our own game."
The key to shrinking a synchrotron is to use superconducting magnets, which when cooled to near absolute zero become much more powerful than ordinary ones. Magnets of greater strength allow a small ring to considerably boost its energy, giving a richer shower of X-rays.
Though ahead in making small synchrotrons, Japan is seen as trailing the United States in the art of actually using the machines to etch experimental chips. Moreover, some American experts say the sheer size of the Japanese synchrotron push is actually diluting the effort.
 
I.B.M. Leading Way
 "They're overinvesting," said Philip Webre, an analyst at the Congressional Budget Office who recently wrote an X-ray lithography report. "Realistically, there are only a handful of teams that can handle the research job."
In the United States, the industrial leader in the push to make smaller synchrotrons is I.B.M. It has designed and ordered from Oxford Instruments Group in England a superconducting synchrotron about 20 feet long and 7 feet wide, which it hopes to have running next year at its research center in East Fishkill, N.Y. Teaming with I.B.M. to explore the process is Motorola Inc., the chip maker. I.B.M. has calculated that a single synchrotron would be powerful enough to annually make nearly six times the amount of computer memory used worldwide last year.
Dr. Daniel J. Fleming, director of the research center, said I.B.M. already has used X-ray lithography to make experimental chips with line widths of 0.5 microns and has demonstrated the technology down to 0.25 microns. The new synchrotron made by Oxford Instruments, he said, will be a production device to etch wafers.
A step beyond the I.B.M. effort is Brookhaven's new machine, which is smaller and more powerful. At the moment, its magnets operate at room temperature. But Brookhaven scientists are preparing superconducting ones, which, when installed in 1992 or 1993, will considerably boost the machine's output. It is to generate a current of 0.5 amperes, a measure of electron flow through the ring. That level, which is quite large for a small synchrotron, is considered good enough for highly advanced chip manufacturing. In contrast, the I.B.M. machine is to have a lower power level of 0.135 amperes.
The wavelength goal for both the I.B.M. and Brookhaven machines is about 0.001 microns -- far smaller than the finest circuit lines now foreseen as feasible by computer chip makers.
"Contrary to what people think, these machines are not easy to build," said Dr. Richard N. Heese, head of the Brookhaven project. For one thing, the synchrotron's small size means the difficult job of creating a strong magnetic prison to guide speeding electrons must be accomplished in a smaller space, around a "short radius of curvature," Dr. Heese said. For another, the whole system must withstand the intense pressures generated by super-strong superconducting magnets, which can exert 200 tons of force.
"You have to do so many things in a small space," said Dr. Heese.
 
The Matter of Money
 At Wisconsin, scientists are pursuing complementary work aimed at perfecting ways to handle the X-rays for chip making. Since X-rays are impossible to manipulate with ordinary lenses, many new kinds of equipment are being created. The problem of making "masks" that can withstand a barrage of X-rays has been largely solved, said Dr. Cerrina, head of the Wisconsin center. The greatest challenge today, he added, is to draw circuit patterns on these masks with extreme accuracy.
"Precision is the problem," Dr. Cerrina said.
Perhaps the main hurdle for the field is not technical but financial. Chip factories based around X-ray synchrotrons are estimated to cost in the neighborhood of $500 million or more. I.B.M. estimates that by the time it starts full-scale production with X-ray lithography in the mid-1990's, it will have invested $1 billion.
Because of these high costs, many American chip makers are sitting on the sidelines, waiting to see if the work pans out.
"There's always a period of euphoria with these technologies," said Dr. Fleming of I.B.M. "With X-ray lithography in the last three years, people went from complete ignorance to a euphoric peak, to realizing that you can't buy it off the shelf, that it takes a lot of work, and that it's expensive. Besides which, now is not the best of economic times. People are trying to understand the cost."
Many scientists in the field say the Japanese are showing little or no hesitancy in pursuing the idea, no matter how expensive, and that it is in America's best interest to do likewise.
"We're in an interesting situation," said Dr. Williams of Brookhaven, who was the lead author of a report saying the United States has a one- to two-year lead over the rest of the world in most aspects of synchrotron X-ray lithography.
"It's a pity more people aren't putting their money on it," he said. "It's disappointing to people who would like the U.S. to maintain its competitive edge."

HEADLINE: TOPICS OF THE TIMES;
For Whom the Tolls Toll

 BODY:
Commuters won't like it. And with their states facing budget deficits that require many other painful steps, the timing isn't great. But Gov. Jim Florio of New Jersey and Gov. Mario Cuomo of New York can no longer deny the need for a $1 toll increase on bridges and tunnels run by the Port Authority.
A plan submitted by the agency's new director, Stanley Brezenoff, would increase round-trip tolls from $3 to $4 early next year on four bridges and two tunnels. Commuters who buy monthly passes would pay $72 for a 20-trip package, up from the present $40. The $1 fare on PATH trains would rise to $1.25.
A similar proposal by Mr. Brezenoff's predecessor died last spring after a chilly response from the two Governors, who share veto power over any toll increase. About $100 million in essential capital improvements had to be postponed. Further delay could risk the region's long-term economic health.
The interstate transportation network operates at a heavy deficit, and revenues from the region's airports and from the World Trade Center, also operated by the Port Authority, can no longer provide big subsidies. Those facilities urgently require major renovations themselves.
The Automobile Club of New York complains about charging automobile commuters more to cover PATH's operating losses. But the proposed $4 toll is still a relative bargain; the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority charges $5 round-trip on its crossings. Moreover, drivers clearly benefit when commuters are diverted from congested roadways and onto mass transit.
The task may be politically difficult. But it shouldn't be too much to ask Mr. Florio and Mr. Cuomo to face up to reasonable toll and fare increases needed to rehabilitate the region's infrastructure.

HEADLINE: Left Behind in Germany

 BODY:
The latest milestone of German unity has brought results that are simultaneously obvious, surprising and deceptive.
The governing right-center coalition was surely expected to win the first all-German elections since 1933. The surprise came in the size of the losses suffered by the opposition parties. How could the left lose, given the addition of all those former East German Communists to the electorate? 
 The answer, and the deceptive aspect of the returns, is that the right and center ate the left's lunch. Now the winners will have to pay for their campaign promises and Americans will have to recognize that, if only for reasons of domestic politics, Germany will have to find its own way.
 To former East Germans, Chancellor Helmut Kohl and his coalition partner, Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher, promised economic deliverance. Millions responded enthusiastically to their message of hope, rather than to that of the Social Democrats, who played to blue-collar resentment of welfare for the east.
Mr. Genscher's Free Democrats won 11 percent of the vote, up from 9 percent in 1987, and Mr. Kohl's Christian Democrats held their 44 percent. The Social Democrats slipped to 33.5 percent. The western Greens plunged to 5 percent, below the level needed to qualify for Parliament.
Now, however, the coalition will have to make good on the promised deliverance. German reports estimate that 1,000 former East Germans a week are still moving west, in search of jobs and prosperity. The victors did little in the campaign to prepare the German people for the cost of deliverance. The Government will almost certainly have to scale back spending on defense if it is to provide the necessary social welfare for 16 million Germans in the east.
The opposition can learn to make promises too, and to avoid being outbid Mr. Kohl and Mr. Genscher may try to change the political agenda. Just as they rightly insisted that German unification was for Germans to decide, they could begin now to reassert sovereignty over reducing foreign nuclear weapons and loosening Germany's military integration with NATO.
The United States can help manage this transition. Getting on with negotiations to eliminate short-range nuclear arms would probably relieve hasty pressure to remove all nuclear weapons. Cutting U.S. troop levels substantially would make it easier for a modest force to remain.
A sovereign Germany cannot be expected to follow Washington on security issues as faithfully as before. But that is no reason for Americans to be alarmed. They know what a united Germany is discovering: Politics is promises and promises have their price.

HEADLINE: ON MY MIND;
A Week in Jerusalem

BYLINE: By A. M. Rosenthal

DATELINE: JERUSALEM

 BODY:
For seven days, I have been talking with a full range of top-rank Israeli civilian and military leaders. This is an attempt to distill the essence of what they said about two war-or-peace crises central to this country's existence.
One is relatively new -- the situation in the Persian Gulf. The other has dominated life in the Middle East for almost a half-century and is at least as important and dangerous as ever -- the struggle between Israel and those Arab nations that in heart and action still resent and challenge Israel's existence among them. 
 Since I wanted as much candor as possible, the understanding was that the Israeli leaders would not be quoted by name. I did not attempt to get a "consensus" from men of different responsibilities and duties, but I think most of them would agree with most of what follows.
On Saddam Hussein: if the United States and its Western allies want to keep the Arab Middle East, its oil riches and its political destiny out of the hands of Saddam Hussein it will have to fight him, now or later.
The Israelis think he is strong but beatable now, but will be stronger later. Examining the economic planning of Iraq known to them and the profile of his entire political life, they believe he will keep using the oil billions of the future for two military objectives: development of his chemical weapons and the achievement of nuclear weapon power.
The major concern is his approaching ability to parcel out nuclear weapons among extremist allies, which would make international supervision an evil joke. The estimate for this is three to five years.
This is a long way from saying that the Israelis "want" war. As a matter of fact, a few days in Israel would convince anybody but a fool or an incurable Israel-hater that the last thing in the world that this country "wants" is war. The whole picture of an Israel macho-mad for war in the gulf or anyplace else becomes an absurdity. It would be comical if it were not so often painted with ugly motivation.
This country has lived through one war after another with Arab nations, who lost everything but their hatred. The U.S. likes to pretend Israel has no role in the Persian Gulf crisis, but Israelis are entirely intelligent enough to know that in case of a gulf war they would have to expect an Iraqi attack on Israel.
The only thing that could prevent it is Saddam Hussein's understanding of Israel's ability and readiness to retaliate with enormous power. They remind him of this fact in a variety of ways without having to send their Foreign Minister to Baghdad.
But nonetheless they know he may not go down without trying to change the war into an Arab crusade against Israel. They are not trying to push the United States into a war, which they could never do. In any case, that is now the full-time pursuit of Washington's new allies such as Saudi Arabia, Egypt, Kuwait and Syria, which have at least as much to fear from Saddam Hussein as does Israel. But Israelis add up the cost of fighting now or fighting later, and they come to their own conclusions -- without any pleasure either way.
Some of the most informed men with whom I talked have strong professional respect for the maneuvering talents of both Saddam Hussein and George Bush. They do not expect the Iraqi to collapse in terror when Secretary of State James Baker looks him straight in the eye.
They think that instead he will begin unwrapping his proposal for a "compromise" under which he would withdraw from most of Kuwait -- except for this oilfield and that gulf island.
They do not know what Mr. Bush will do after the pressures mount on him to accept. But they think Mr. Bush knows that air attacks in strength could cripple Iraq and lessen -- although not eliminate -- the need and cost for ground combat.
On the Israel-Arab confrontation, they know a one-word answer: Sadat. Anwar el-Sadat moved for peace between Israel and Egypt and the Israelis rushed toward it, willing to pay the price -- the land of Sinai, so dear to both nations.
They do not see another Sadat now. But they think that whatever happens in the gulf, the monarchies and despotisms will eventually begin to fall apart. Fanatic fundamentalism may be the major result. But perhaps one day change in the Arab world will bring forward another leader ready to risk peace. Until then, Israel must swim in hostile seas.
In the seven days of talk, there was not a moment of bluster, drama or pretense. There seemed too much at stake for anything but calm.

HEADLINE: Budget-Deficit Plan Closes Gap in Albany Without Gimmicks

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Before the Nov. 6 elections, I announced that New York faced a significant budget deficit this year that we needed to overcome without raising taxes or borrowing. I was pleased at that time to hear a chorus of state legislative candidates ratify both the problem and the solution. Now I have given the Legislature a proposal to reduce spending this year by $1 billion through recurring cuts in local aid, social services and the state's work force. This plan will close the budget gap and without gimmicks.
It does not do it without pain. I have worked hard, however, to see that the pain is shared in proportion to the ability to make sacrifices. Cuts in education aid, for example, reflect a school district's wealth. I have minimized the need for employee layoffs through furloughs, attrition and voluntary retirement. This means, regrettably, that a rejection of my proposal for furloughs would force thousands of people out of work.
The deficit equals only about 2 percent of the state budget. Many states around the country and, of course, the Federal Government face greater imbalances.
Even with the cuts I have proposed, budget growth in such areas as education and mental health during my first two terms as Governor will have exceeded 90 percent, or three times the rate of inflation. It will be difficult to argue, in light of that growth, that any of the proposed cuts is intolerably deep or that they will leave local governments with no choice but to raise their taxes.
Our deficit-reduction plan is designed not to weaken our government, but to insure that we preserve government's capacity to meet its obligations over the long term.
Indeed, this period of revenue shortfalls presents an opportunity for re-examination and reform that can make our government more efficient than ever. I look forward to the analysis and recommendations of the Legislature and timely enactment of a plan that will balance this year's budget and prevent future deficits.
I ask for your help, especially in pointing out that it is not enough to reject the reductions; whatever is rejected must be replaced with an alternative cut. We can't pretend we can make the problem disappear because the solution is inconvenient or even painful.
 
MARIO M. CUOMO
Governor
Albany, Nov. 19, 1990

HEADLINE: Stangl Is Said To Be Choice For M.T.A.

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Dec. 3

 BODY:
The president of the Metro-North Commuter Railroad, Peter E. Stangl, is the leading contender to fill the vacancy at the top of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, Cuomo administration officials said today.
He would replace Robert R. Kiley, who announced his resignation as M.T.A. chairman early last week. 
 The M.T.A. chairman, one of the state's most powerful non-elected officials, oversees a far-flung transportation network that includes New York City's subway and bus lines, two commuter rail lines, seven bridges and two tunnels. Each day, roughly six million New Yorkers rely on the M.T.A. and its subsidiaries -- Metro-North, the Long Island Railroad, the New York City Transit Authority and the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority -- to get from place to place.
Mr. Stangl, 49 years old, has been president and general manager of Metro-North since 1983. In recent months, he has been credited with increasing ridership on the commuter line at a time when the number of riders on the M.T.A.'s other rail lines has been dropping.
 
Job Offer in a Few Days
 Cuomo administration officials, noting that standard background checks, which are conducted by the state police, had not been completed, stressed today that Mr. Stangl had not yet been formally offered the M.T.A. chairmanship. But they said that unless the background checks uncovered damaging information, they expected Mr. Stangl to be offered the job within the next few days.
The nomination would be subject to approval by the State Senate.
"It's safe to say that he's the leading candidate," one administration official said.
Mr. Stangl was out of town today and could not be reached for comment.
Mr. Kiley is widely credited with having lifted the sagging image of New York City's subway and commuter lines during his seven years in office, and his successor will inherit a rail system in which more than 90 percent of the cars have been rebuilt or replaced. But revenues and ridership have flagged in the last year, and the system will need a large infusion of new funds to continue its rebuilding efforts beyond next year.
All three rail lines -- the L.I.R.R., Metro-North, and the New York City subway system -- are currently considering fare increases and service cuts to close growing budget deficits.
Since January, when fares were last increased, ridership on both the L.I.R.R. and the city subways has dropped by about 4 percent, according to figures provided by the M.T.A. But during the same period, ridership on Metro-North trains has, in contrast, increased about 1.5 percent.
"Assuming Stangl does get the job, we hope he will do for the subways what he's done for Metro-North," said Gene Russianoff, a staff lawyer for the Straphangers Campaign, a transit advocacy group.
Probably the most daunting task facing the new M.T.A. chairman is securing new financing for the authority's ambitious capital improvement program.
 
Seeking $12 Billion More
 Money for the current phase of the program -- $8.6 billion -- is scheduled to run out at the end of 1991. M.T.A. officials have already said they plan to seek an additional $12 billion from the State Legislature to carry the program through 1996, but the state's own budget problems are likely to complicate this effort.
Several officials today described Mr. Stangl, who holds a bachelor's degree and a master's degree in economics from the University of Connecticut, as well suited to confront the interlocking financial and transportation issues facing the M.T.A. From 1972 to 1973, Mr. Stangl served as a budget administrator for the New York City Transporation Administration, and before that as a program planner for transportation at the city's budget office.
Members of the Straphangers Campaign said that they expected Mr. Stangl, whom they described as talkative and expansive, to be a more outgoing and accessible M.T.A. chairman than Mr. Kiley, who maintained an unusually low profile for such a high-ranking public official.
"This is good, because the key job is going to be getting the $12 billion," Mr. Russianoff said. "And you don't do that by being a shrinking violet."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Syndication Trek: Journey Continues

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
SEVEN years after President Reagan parried their last lobbying assault, the television networks are again preparing for war with Hollywood over the right to market programs after they have been shown in primetime. Why, the networks ask, should the Japanese, Australian and Italian carpetbaggers who have snapped up Universal/MCA (Matsushita), MGM/UA (Pathe), Columbia (Sony) and 20th Century Fox (News Corporation) have freedom to syndicate programming that is denied to NBC, ABC and CBS?
Why, indeed. Alfred C. Sykes, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, favors repeal of the regulatory limits the commission imposed in 1970. And now that the Gipper has hung up his shoulder pads, Hollywood can no longer count on help from higher places. 
 The demise of the syndication rule would not upset Peter Pitsch, a former F.C.C. staff member who consults in Washington. Like many economists, he has never been persuaded that the studios needed protection from network avarice. But Mr. Pitsch is more puzzled than elated by the latest turn of events. In his view, there is less at stake here than meets the eye.
The studios assert that the rule is a matter of economic life and death. Payments for prime time, they note, do not cover the full cost of production. Thus, if Big Peacock and the other network bullies were allowed to grab syndication rights, the studios might never make a profit.
Independent television stations, which compete with network affiliates, stand with Hollywood: the networks, they fear, would warehouse reruns to bolster the audience for their own new shows.Mr. Pitsch does not share their alarm. The three networks might have once had the leverage to play rough with the studios because they were the only program buyers in town. But today, he notes, they face competition from cable, as well as from independent stations that buy original programming direct from studios. And it is almost inconceivable that a network would withhold popular (but perishable) programs from syndicated reruns when it would have to divide the resulting gain in audience share with a dozen or more rivals.
In any case, Mr. Pitsch points out, the syndication rule never really protected sellers from network power. Taking one item of value -- syndication rights -- off the bargaining table could not prevent the networks from using their leverage to exact other valuable concessions, notably cuts in the portion of production costs that would be covered by payments for prime-time viewing.
By the same token it is not obvious why the networks are so eager to go into the business: In a competitive market, the studios would not part with syndication rights for less than their worth.Lawrence Summers, a Harvard economist who consults for the networks, argues that the inability of the networks to pay up front for syndication rights forces independent producers unable to bear the risk of deficit financing to share their best ideas with big studios. The net effect, he suggests, is to raise the cost of the programming and reduce its diversity.
That argument is plausible. But Mr. Pitsch wonders why there is insufficient competition among the eight major studios to drive out excess profits. And he is perplexed by the support by independent producers for the syndication rule, which, by Mr. Summers's logic, hardly serves their interests.
The best explanation Mr. Pitsch can conjure runs something like this. If networks could contractually share in syndication rights, they would have an incentive to enhance syndication value in ways that could not be pinned down in contracts with producers. They might, for example, keep a slipping show on the air for an extra 13 weeks to improve its prospects for syndication later on.
That might increase the total value of syndicated shows -- part of which would presumably trickle down to producers. But it would also increase the number of shows competing for air time in syndication, increasing competition among syndicators and driving down studio profits.
This does not explain why independent stations also oppose the move by the networks into the syndication business. But it at least offers a rational peg for the networks and the studios to hang their hats on.
It is also possible that the fight is an artifact of the unusual culture of the business. In the feudal economy of mass entertainment, where everyone from stagehands to the owners of broadcast licenses is perpetually manuevering for a larger slice of what is widely seen as a fixed pie, it is only natural to assume that the gain of the networks must be someone else's loss. Only natural -- but in this case, probably wrong.
