HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
British Say Allies Must Erase Doubts

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Dec. 4

 BODY:
Britain's new Prime Minister, John Major, repeated his Government's strong support today for international demands that Iraq pull out of Kuwait by Jan. 15. But members of his Government warned that if Iraq balks, the allies must leave no doubt about their willingness to use military force.
One high-ranking Government official, referring to growing opposition in Congress to the use of force, said the United States would have to "fish or cut bait" soon after the United Nations deadline in mid-January. 
 "We want to see a peaceful solution in the gulf," Mr. Major told a group of Conservative Party supporters today. But he said that President Saddam Hussein of Iraq would have to pull his forces out of Kuwait unconditionally if he wanted to avoid an attack.
"It is in his hands," Mr. Major said.
 
'Short and Sharp' War
 His Defense Minister, Tom King, told the House of Commons today that if war did break out, it would be "short and sharp and quick." He said Britain and the United States were sending reinforcements to the Persian Gulf to insure "that the casualties on the allied side could be kept to a minimum."
Mr. King announced that Britain was sending 14,000 more troops to the gulf on Nov. 22, the day that Margaret Thatcher announced that she would resign as Prime Minister. The deployment will bring the total number of British troops there to more than 30,000, amounting to a tenth of Britain's total active duty force, by the end of next month. The United States expects to have more than 400,000 troops in the area by then.
Brig. Patrick Cordingley, commander of the British Seventh Armored Brigade in Saudi Arabia, said last week that a war would be "particularly unpleasant" if it came.
"There are going to be a lot of casualties and inevitably one has to be prepared for unpleasant things to unfold," press accounts quoted him as saying. The reports said his chief of staff had estimated that casualties could run to 15 percent of the total force.
 
Limited Time Frame
 No official here would speculate on when the forces allied against Iraq would be most likely to strike. But several said that if fighting did not begin by the end of March or early April, when hot weather returns to the Arabian desert, it would be difficult to sustain such huge deployments.
Before the Chairman of the United States Joint Chiefs of Staff, Gen. Colin L. Powell, arrived here today for consultations, a senior official in the British Government said the vast allied force would suffer humiliation tantamount to defeat if President Saddam Hussein of Iraq refused to leave by mid-January and the force did not act.
"It would soon be time to fish or cut bait, as you say," the official said. "Would you not agree that if this huge force assembled in Saudi Arabia were to go home a few months later without having achieved the objective of forcing Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait, that it would have suffered defeat?"
General Powell met with Mr. Major, Mr. King, and British military officials here today, the United States Embassy said. It declined to reveal the substance of the discussions.
British officials profess to be unconcerned about polls showing an erosion in support among the American public for military action in the gulf. Nor do they acknowledge any worry about warnings against war from influential senators like Sam Nunn, Democrat of Georgia, who has said that an attack on the Iraqis would be "unwise."
 
Nervously Watching U.S.
 But the British Government is clearly somewhat nervous about what its principal ally is going to do. Mrs. Thatcher was initially skeptical about the need for a United Nations resolution authorizing the use of force if Iraq did not pull out, but went along with it when the United States asked for Britain's backing. Under Mr. Major, Britain voted for the measure last week in the Security Council.
A Foreign Office minister, Douglas Hogg, told the House of Commons on Monday that the British Government had been notified of President Bush's decision to send Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d to Baghdad to press for an Iraqi withdrawal before Mr. Bush announced the mission on Friday.
Mr. Major said today: "We fully support President Bush when he says that he is prepared to travel the extra mile to achieve such a solution. So are we. But there can be no question of negotiations, concessions, partial solutions or linkage to other issues."
His office said today that Mr. Major would be traveling to the gulf in the near future to visit British troops there.
 
Britons Support Policy
 British public opinion remains solidly behind Government policy on the gulf crisis. Its decisions have also been supported by the leaders of the two main parties in the opposition, Neil Kinnock of the Labor Party and Paddy Ashdown of the Liberal Democrats. Both men been kept closely informed by the Government.
"We've had a long history of involvement in the region, we're familiar with most of it, and people here are outraged at Iraq's treatment of the British hostages," a Government official said.
A Gallup poll of 977 adults conducted between Nov. 21 and 27 and published in The Daily Telegraph today showed that 57 percent would prefer a successful blockade over military action to force Iraqi troops to leave Kuwait. But it said that 63 percent would support military action against Iraq if the economic blockade failed.
The results were not significantly different from those of a similar poll in mid-September, when 61 percent said they would support the use of force against Iraq if sanctions failed, the Telegraph said.

HEADLINE: China Ready to Try (and Forget) Dissidents

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WUHAN, China

 BODY:
Perhaps what is most remarkable about Zhu Jianbin is not that he has spent the last nine years in prison for trying to promote democracy, but that he has been so totally forgotten in the labyrinth of the Chinese penal system.
Mr. Zhu is evidence that repression sometimes works, for the authorities have locked him up without attracting any significant criticism or tarnishing their image. 
 His very existence has been virtually obliterated, for most democracy advocates here and abroad have neverheard of him, and even in this city where he worked and dreamed of democracy, people shake their heads and say they have never heard his name.
The Chinese leaders appear ready to go ahead soon with criminal trials of some major figures in the 1989 democracy movement, and the Government may well believe -- based on the evidence of Mr. Zhu and countless others -- that the harm to its image will be slight and transitory.
Beijing may well believe that such a temporary setback is an acceptable price for making an example of some activists and frightening the rest intosubmission.
Hundreds, and perhaps thousands, of people remain in Chinese prisons and labor camps for their involvement in the 1989 democracy movement. Last week, the Government formally charged two editors of an economics journal, Wang Juntao and Chen Ziming, with counterrevolutionary crimes because of their participation in the movement. They and others are expected to face trial soon, and perhaps prison sentences of up to 15 years.
The result has been a flurry of foreign indignation -- just as there was a burst of outrage a decade ago when China imprisoned the leaders of the1978-79 Democracy Spring movement. But that outrage gradually dissipated, and only Wei Jingsheng is much remembered now, in China or abroad. Mr. Wei, an electrician and essayist, is now in the 12th year of his 15-year prison sentence. He is said to be in solitary confinement, with even the guards ordered not to speak with him.
Mr. Zhu's case never attracted much attention, partly because he lived and worked here in Wuhan, where there are no resident diplomats or foreign journalists. Mr. Zhu, who is now 35 years old, was a worker at a big steel mill in Wuhan and an editor of a journal about democracy, "The Bell Tolls."
"We've been sending letters, but we've never heard anything," said Barbara Krasnoff, a member of an Amnesty International group in New York that has "adopted" Mr. Zhu as apolitical prisoner. "We never found out if he has any family."
"It's very hard not to lose interest in a case," Ms. Krasnoff added in a telephone interview. "We're human and if you don't hear anything from somebody for so many years he becomes almost fictional. Every once in a while we have to take out his picture and remember that this is a real person."
The way in which Mr. Zhu has been forgotten, except to the Amnesty group, raises larger questions about the democracy movement in China. Nelson Mandela managed to inspire many South Africans while he was in prison, and in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union dissidents kept alive the memories of many who were in labor camps.
But Chinese intellectuals say that the tendency here has been to forget thosewho are locked away. Many of the students involved in the 1989 Tiananmen movement had never heard of the leaders of the Democracy Spring Movement a decade earlier -- names of men like Xu Wenli and Wang Xizhe, who are serving 15- and 14-year prison sentences, respectively.
Fang Lizhi, the Chinese dissident now living in England, wrote in an essay this year about "The Chinese Amnesia" -- the tendency for society to forget and ignore past repression -- as a factor inhibiting the emergence of greater democracy in China.
While Professor Fang argued that the Communist "Technique of Forgetting History" was losing its effect with regard to the 1989 crackdown, there is no sign of greater interest in those who remain in prison for their efforts a decade ago to promote democracy.

HEADLINE: Leverage on Pretoria: Mandela's Group Turns to a Mass Protest Campaign

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG, Dec. 4

 BODY:
As it maneuvers for advantage before negotiations proposed by President F. W. de Klerk on the nation's future, the African National Congress has replaced its former at least rhetorical commitment to armed struggle against white minority rule with a strategy of coordinated protest marches, strikes, consumer boycotts and work stayaways.
Though protests against apartheid are not new and Mr. de Klerk has tolerated peaceful dissent since taking office, mass action, as the Congress's current policy is called, has become a key point of contention, delaying talks between black and white leaders on a new national constitution. 
 From the perspective of the African National Congress, giving up mass action as a tactic would mean going into negotiations with far less political clout. For Mr. de Klerk, mass action complicates negotiations because his white electorate would see any concessions to the Congress as coerced.
 
A Victory for Hard-Liners?
 Some analysts like Ronnie Bethlehem, an economist who has studied revolutionary change, speculate that the Congress's call for mass action signals a victory for its hard-line strategists, who did not want to give up the guerrilla option, over its pragmatists, who view negotiations as the best route to a post-apartheid society.
"It is a victory which could assist strategists and racial ideologists against pragmatists on the Government's side also," Mr. Bethlehem wrote in the financial newspaper Business Day.
At a politically charged funeral here on Sunday for a man shot by the police at a unapproved march here on Nov. 17, Nelson Mandela declared that the African National Congress would not give up mass action.
"We will not trade off our mass struggle for negotiations," said Mr. Mandela, who is deputy president of the Congress. He called for more demonstrations, even if the authorities refused permission, as happened on Nov. 17.
 
The Remnants of Apartheid
 The civil disobedience campaign has sought out flaws in Mr. de Klerk's policies of change. As Mr. Mandela keeps pointing out, he and other blacks still cannot vote and many other structures set up to enforce apartheid remain in place.
The African National Congress suspended its armed struggle, adopted in 1961 after nearly half a century of non-violence, at the last full round of talks with the Government on Aug. 6. In military terms, the guerrilla warfare achieved little because of a ruthlessly efficient counter-insurgency and had grown quiescent months before its suspension.
The international isolation of South Africa began to unravel after Mr. de Klerk declared the African National Congress and other liberation movements legal, freed Mr. Mandela and began dismantling apartheid. Though he has far to go, Mr. de Klerk has been warmly received in Washington and other Western European and African capitals.
 
New Attitude in East Europe
 Eastern European countries that championed the African National Congress with money, weapons and political support have also shifted interest to Mr. de Klerk's Government. Poland, Hungary and Czechoslovakia have established informal diplomatic links and last week a Soviet delegation visited Pretoria for talks. The Soviet Union, which awarded Mr. Mandela the Lenin Peace Prize while he was in prison, has yet to arrange for him to collect it.
Economic sanctions are also starting to slip, raising the prospect that by the time the Congress consents to their removal, they may be ineffective. Though the case for sanctions could be reviewed at the Congress consultative conference opening here on Dec. 14, Mr. Mandela told foreign correspondents on Nov. 15 that "we have no plans to call on countries and the world to review sanctions."
At home, the African National Congress has failed to translate widespread admiration for Mr. Mandela into equivalent grass roots support. Only one in 250 South Africans has joined the Congress, though many more endorse its aims. The Congress has admitted signing up 150,000 members out of a total population of 37.5 million inhabitants, only 5 million of whom are white.
There are reasons for the lackluster showing. The Congress's claim to lead was hurt by its inability to stop factional violence exploding around Johannesburg in August and September. And the poverty, illiteracy and backwardness afflicting many blacks is so severe that a recent survey of farm laborers in the rural Eastern Cape reported that only 60 percent had heard of the African National Congress and only 30 percent of Mr. Mandela.
 
Tactics of the 1950's
 Because it cannot afford to lose credibility before it feels ready to negotiate with the Government, the African National Congress has reverted to the kind of tactics it used before the adoption of armed struggle, like the campaigns of the 1950's to defy restrictive pass laws and other apartheid legislation.
Mr. Mandela has likened mass action to demonstrations by Americans against the war in Vietnam or by Western Europeans against the deployment of nuclear weapons.
"We have reached the position where we are precisely because of mass action," Mr. Mandela told journalists on Nov. 10.
Last month, Mr. de Klerk accused the African National Congress of "a clearly defined strategy of intimidation and undermining of local authorities, regional and self-governing states." He called it a form of violence that the African National Congress pledged to stop when it suspended the armed struggle on Aug. 6 and urged that it express dissatisfaction through the channels created in their ongoing contacts.
 
'Peaceful Search for Solutions'
 "I expect from them an unqualified stand against everything that is not conducive to the peaceful search for solutions," Mr. de Klerk said. At a private meeting last Tuesday, President de Klerk and Mr. Mandela failed to resolve their differences over mass action.
The mass action campaign has set complex goals, like the nonracial election of a constituent assembly and interim government during negotiations and the collapse of black township councils created by Pretoria, both of which the Government opposes.
The New Nation, a weekly newspaper that reflects the views of the African National Congress, insisted recently that mass action was essential to maintain pressure on the Government.
"It is asking too much that, having abandoned the armed struggle to help facilitate the process of negotiations, the A.N.C. must now be expected to give up its sole legal and legitimate means of organizing?" The New Nation said.
 
Congress's Motives Assailed
 The Citizen, a daily tabloid that supports the Government, accused tbe African National Congress in an editorial this week of being motivated by self-interest.
"Mass protests, marches, stayaways and boycotts, which President F. W. de Klerk says can lead to violence and are therefore unacceptable, are not simple expressions of mass feeling; they are organized to disrupt life as well as to demonstrate the A.N.C.'s strength so that blacks are convinced of the A.N.C.'s invincibility," The Citizen said.
Because mass action needs community mobilization, participation tends to be enforced by unemployed youths who have intimidated those who want to go to work or shop. When rival black political groupings oppose such tactics, factional violence can result.
"There can be no denying that there have been instances of A.N.C. supporters displaying intolerant behavior and at times even employing strong-arm methods to bully political rivals into silence," Mr. Mandela said Friday in Cape Town.
"We want to take this opportunity to denounce in the strongest terms any such tactics as completely contrary to A.N.C. policy."
He promised that those guilty of intimidation would be punished.

HEADLINE: Day by Day Economics As Seen in Reading, Pa.

SERIES: Downturn of a City: First visit of a periodic series.

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: READING, Pa., Dec. 2

 BODY:
Here in this row-house industrial city 50 miles northwest of Philadelphia, evidence of economic malaise abounds, from the closing of Georgia-Pacific's fine-paper plant to a subtle shift in demand toward the cheaper brands of the Bachman Company's snack foods.
Throughout the nation, from automobile factories to dairy farms, businesses and workers are hearing talk of recession and fearing its consequences on their lives. No one place is a perfect microcosm of the United States. But the Reading area reflects both the weaknesses and the partly offsetting strengths of the economically floundering mid-Atlantic region. While its large manufacturing base tends to reflect contraction quickly, Reading's economy as a whole is diverse, and occasional visits here may provide a look at how one city deals with difficult economic times.
 
Drop in an Important Gauge
 Some analysts think recession has already put its clammy grip on Reading and the rest of Berks County. One important gauge is a drop in the amount of electricity used by industry. This proxy for industrial output has trailed 1989 levels in three of the last four months. And the unemployment rate, though below the national average, has climbed one and a half percentage points since September 1989. 
 The immediate concern is not whether proud Reading, its namesake railroad a Monopoly board fixture, will reverse the decades-long eclipse it shares with many former industrial powerhouses. The question is how this area, the early home to Daniel Boone, Abraham Lincoln's ancestors and John Updike, will weather an incipient, possibly severe, cyclical downturn in the American economy at large.
Scores of interviews here recently found a general sense of apprehension combined with a belief -- in many cases probably only a hope -- that a likely slide will be neither deep nor lengthy. At the same time, many companies here continue to grow, even thrive. These seem to underscore the country's economic resiliency and the intricate ways people and businesses adapt to circumstances.
Yet the fundamental message these days is clearly downbeat. Most manufacturers cite flat to shrinking orders. Shoppers at the city's renowned outlet malls talk about buying less. Workers throughout the county ponder closings, announced or actual, of Sonoco Fibre Drum's plant here in town, the Caloric Corporation's appliance plant in nearby Topton and Adidas's shoe plant in Kutztown, which failed despite the efforts of Dae Yang Inc., a Korean company.
"I personally think we're in a recession now," said Ezekiel S. Ketchum, the president of Meridian Bancorp Inc., which is based in Reading and commands 36 percent of the Berks County banking market, giving it an exceptional vantage point on the local economy.
Meridian, an $11.8 billion regional institution, is suffering from serious deterioration in its loan portfolio. The bank announced in September that it was making a special $75 million addition to bad-debt reserves, part of a plan that also includes selling its credit-card, indirect auto-loan and title-insurance businesses.
 
Long-Gone Glory
 Its glory days are long gone. The Reading Railroad, once, briefly, the biggest anywhere, went bankrupt and was folded into Conrail. Yet in the city, long a world-class producer of such disparate goods as textiles and cigar boxes, manufacturing still plays a substantial role. More than 32 percent of the county's non-farm jobs are in factories, well above rates of 22 percent statewide and 19 percent nationally.
Such businesses, with high fixed costs and stocks of materials and the purchase of their products generally deferrable, are particularly susceptible to downturns. They also face intense world competition that in many industrial spheres has induced excess capacity.
Mainly reflecting the loss of factory jobs, Reading's unemployment rate climbed to 4.7 percent in September, the latest month for which data are available. This is a percentage point below the current national rate but, consistent with the national trend, Reading is now suffering from a paucity in new service jobs as well.
Automobiles and trucks is one area of overcapacity. The current slump in sales, though not as bad as had been feared after oil prices soared when Iraq invaded Kuwait, is putting pressure on at least two Reading businesses -- the Dana Corporation's Parish frame division and the Carpenter Technology Corporation, formerly Carpenter Steel.
"It looks to me like the recession has hit the county," said Richard Harman, Dana's division controller, He declined to talk specifically about Dana other than to note that the company, based in Toledo, Ohio, laid off 60 of its 2,400 Reading workers in October and to hint that rumors around town of large additional layoffs may prove well founded.
 
Demand for Replacement Parts
 Carpenter produces specialty steels, and its 2,700 employees make up the county's third-biggest work force after an A.T.&T. semiconductor plant and the Reading Hospital. Its chairman, Paul R. Roedel, said orders by automotive and military customers were slipping but were being made up elsewhere. He said orders were relatively strong for products used in power generation, chemical processing and oil-drilling equipment, with a special Cartech drill collar in particular demand.
But analysts here also note that a weak market for new cars implies better demand for the area's substantial production of replacement parts, like Exide batteries.
In fact, throughout the county one hears about strengths offsetting weaknesses, particularly in the recession-resistant candy and snack-food industry where Luden's Inc. (5th Avenue bars as well as cough drops) and Bachman (best known for pretzels) have many smaller competitors.
Bachman's chief, Joseph F. Welch, said unit sales continue to run about 5 percent ahead of 1989 levels despite a decision to cut the company's promotion budget. But he has noticed that the company's premium brands of popcorn and tortilla chips have faded as consumers here and elsewhere seek to economize.
Such trading down is clearly evident in the city's half-dozen outlet malls where legions of bargain-seekers, many on bus excursions from out of state, spend close to $1 billion a year.
 
The Draw of the Malls
 "They're buying the basics; they're buying quality," said Jay R. Titsworth, president of VF Factory Outlet, noting that the malls this year are attracting an increasing number of local residents. Area shoppers had spurned these malls, partly in reaction to congestion brought by the tourist hordes.
While some financially pinched shoppers no doubt have raised their outlet spending this year, the outlets over all are not benefiting from a rise in bargain hunters in hard times. Some recent weekends have produced declines. "In other years it's always been increases," said Mr. Titsworth. Bus arrivals to the city are reported down by 10 percent since August.
Soft sales probably prompted the VF apparel outlet to join the other stores in accepting credit cards. Until this year, VF, the area's biggest outlet, had declined to accept the cards, in the mistaken belief that they took more transaction time at the checkout counter than checks.
Yet for each negative in the Reading-area economy -- subdued consumers, cutback-minded executives and a real estate slump symbolized by the for-sale sign that has long hung on the Abraham Lincoln Hotel, site of John Philip Sousa's death -- there seems to be a counterweight.
The fruit-juice plant in Fleetwood, the town that gave its name to a line of Cadillacs, closed in February. But it is now being prepared by its new California owners, Sunsweet Growers, Inc., for reopening. Instead of Red Cheek apple juice, its traditional mainstay, the plant will produce Sunsweet prune juice.
 
No One Really Knows
 As for real estate, Aetna insurance has recently completed two new buildings, one in the suburbs and one downtown. Other major projects in the area include a Sam's discount store, a major addition to the county courthouse, a huge Ames Department Stores distribution center and, just over the county line, a new Pepperidge Farm bakery.
There are also companies like Arrow International Inc., a one-time moribund knitting-needle unit bought by local interests in 1975 and turned into world-class producer of catheters and other precision medical equipment now employing 1,200 people. Aided by a weak dollar, Arrow's export business is booming, and Marlin Miller Jr., Arrow's president, is constantly fending off potential acquisitors and underwriters.
The counterweights, which include measures taken by individual companies to produce more competitively and market more imaginatively, lead some to doubt that the Reading area -- or the national economy for that matter -- is in for sharp or prolonged economic contraction.
"Manufacturing there is going to get hit," said Richard M. Stein, an economist for Corestates Financial Corporation, a Philadelphia-based institution. "But I think they'll be able to skirt recession."
But no one really knows, and the usual uncertainty has been compounded by military confrontation in the Persian Gulf.
A restaurateur, Dan Gallagher, seemed to capture the city's mood when asked to explain why two dozen applicants sought an assistant chef job at his struggling Penn Street establishment in October, four times as many as when the job was advertised earlier in the year.
"It's the premonition of what's to come," he said.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Fed Move and Iraq Report Cause Sharp Drop in Dollar

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell sharply against other major currencies yesterday, hit hard by the Federal Reserve's decision to relax its reserve requirements for banks and by a news report that Iraq may be willing to withdraw from Kuwait.
Gold prices were mixed, falling overseas and then rising in New York. 
 The dollar first slumped after the Fed announced its bank reserves decision, an unusual move aimed at stimulating the deteriorating economy by easing a shortage of credit.
The central bank said its action, the first change in reserve requirements since 1983, was taken in part for technical reasons but also to encourage banks to increase lending.
Ideally, if banks have more money to lend, interest rates would fall, although some private economists questioned whether that would in fact be the result of the Fed move. But the foreign exchange markets, taking no chances, sold the dollar.
The dollar draws support from higher interest rates, which make United States investments more attractive. When rates fall, the dollar tends to follow suit.
The dollar fell further shortly before the close of trading, after a British news report said Iraq might be ready to withdraw from most of Kuwait as long as it was allowed to keep the disputed Rumailah oilfield.
The report raised the prospects for a peaceful end to the Middle East crisis. The dollar, seen as a relatively safe investment in times of international strife, has advanced as tensions increased in recent months and dropped as they were defused.
The British pound rose against the dollar yesterday. In New York, sterling closed at $1.92925, up from $1.9180 late Monday. In London earlier, the pound rose to $1.9255, from $1.9205 late Monday.
The dollar fell to 133.30 Japanese yen in New York, from 134.74 late Monday. In Tokyo overnight, the dollar rose 1.35 yen to a closing 134.35 yen, and it was later quoted in London at 134.00 yen.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Monday's late quotes, included: 1.5030 German marks, down from 1.51395; 1.2825 Swiss francs, down from 1.2935; 5.0825 French francs, down from 5.1135; 1,129.25 Italian lire, down from 1,138.00, and 1.16325 Canadian dollars, down from 1.16625.
Gold advanced in New York, climbing $2.30 on the Commodity Exchange to close at $378.90 a troy ounce. The Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $376.25, up 75 cents.
Silver prices advanced. The metal rose 1.3 cents on the Commodity Exchange, closing at $4.151 a troy ounce. Earlier, silver rose in London to a late bid price of $4.18 a troy ounce from Monday's $4.16.

HEADLINE: WORLD BANK LENDS CHINA $114 MILLION

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4

 BODY:
The World Bank today approved the first loan to China since the student uprising last year that goes beyond the confines of meeting basic human needs.
The approval of the $114.3 million loan marked the first time in more than a year that the Bush Administration did not object to other than humanitarian assistance to China. 
 The World Bank's approval of the loan for technological improvements in rural industry had been expected for weeks, but it was uncertain whether the United States would vote against it. Such a move would have been largely symbolic, because both the European Community and Japan have resumed normal economic relations with China and both supported the loan.
 
Bush Met With Beijing Aide
 The decision comes less than a week after President Bush met last Friday for the first time since the crackdown with the Chinese Foreign Minister, Qian Qichen. The meeting occurred a day after China abstained, rather than opposed, a vote by the United Nations Security Council authorizing the use of force to expel Iraq from Kuwait.
While the World Bank is owned by 155 member Governments, an American has headed it since it was founded in 1945 and the United States has a 20 percent vote on all major issues. The bank makes loans and helps countries in other ways to strengthen broad economic sectors by building such projects as dams, fertilizer plants, irrigation works, ports and highways.
Before the military crackdown on the democracy movement in June 1989, China had been receiving World Bank loans of more than $2 billion annually. Largely at the insistence of the United States all loans were initially blocked to China as part of a sanctions package.
 
Hostility on Capitol Hill
 Since then, World Bank loans to China had shrunk to $650 million, primarily in the form of rural credits and assistance to small cooperative business enterprises in towns and villages.
The American position against non-humanitarian aid reflected opposition from Capitol Hill, where many lawmakers had been hostile to Beijing. But that opposition has been steadily softening since Iraq took over Kuwait in August and the Bush Administration began reaching out to a wide range of allies and other nations for support in challenging the invasion.
The package approved today consists of a $50 million loan and $64.3 million in credit.
Attila Karaosmaonoglu, the World Bank's vice president for Asian Affairs, said that other loans by the bank toChina were being prepared.

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
Mubarak Urges Alliance With Syrians and Saudis

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAIRO, Dec. 4

 BODY:
President Hosni Mubarak today urged the creation of a new Arab alliance grouping Egypt, Syria and Saudi Arabia as "a foundation to serve the Arab people," as Arab nations drew diplomatic lines in response to Washington's latest initiative on the Persian Gulf crisis.
The United States has proposed talks with Iraq to urge it to pull out of Kuwait by Jan. 15 or face war with the United States and its allies gathered in Saudi Arabia. 
 King Hussein of Jordan and Vice President Ali Salem al-Beedh of Yemen, whose countries have both shown sympathy toward Iraq, flew to Baghdad today to meet President Saddam Hussein. At the same time, President Mubarak, the leading Arab supporter of United States regional diplomacy and one of Iraq's most powerful Arab adversaries, was host at a meeting here of the Foreign Ministers of his own country, Syria and Saudi Arabia.
Cooperation between the three, he said, should "transcend any specific situation to become part of a long-term policy to build a foundation to serve the Arab people."
 
No Immediate Response
 The suggestion, which drew no immediate public response from Damascus or Riyadh, reflected widespread Arab concerns that, however the gulf crisis is resolved, it will leave the Arab world questing for a new order to maintain collective security.
Egyptian officials said Cairo also urged "raising the level of military coordination and cooperation in the field of defense" between the three countries.
Egypt and Syria have both either sent or pledged to send thousands of troops backed by tanks to support the American-dominated military buildup in Saudi Arabia, thereby offering an Arab presence to soften the political impact of foreign troops being stationed in an Arab country that houses the holiest shrines of Islam.
"We believe that our positions are united with regard to this crisis," said Syria's Foreign Minister, Farouk al-Sharaa, after a meeting with President Mubarak. "Dangerous developments" in the region could not be halted, he said, "unless Arab and international resolutions are implemented" obliging Iraq to leave Kuwait unconditionally and restore the country to its rulers.
 
Suggestion Reflects Breech
 Mr. Mubarak's suggestion of a three-way alliance reflected Cairo's breach with its previous partners in the defunct Arab Cooperation Council -- Iraq, Jordan and Yemen -- with whom it had formed a regional grouping supposed to promote stability and economic cooperation.
The grouping worried both Syria and Saudi Arabia because it was seen as a cloak for Iraqi designs on regional hegemony.
After the invasion on Aug. 2, Egypt led Arab condemnation of Iraq, while Jordan and Yemen both maintained contact with Baghdad and opposed the United States military buildup in Saudi Arabia, arguing that the Arab world should find its own solution to the crisis.
Saudi Arabia is already the dominant member of the Gulf Cooperation Council, a six-nation grouping formed initially by the gulf oil nations, including Kuwait, to oppose Iran in its eight-year war with Iraq.
 
Assumptions Stripped Away
 The Egyptian suggestion for a new alliance, an Arab diplomat said, showed concerns that the Iraqi invasion had stripped away many of the assumptions on which the Arab world previously did business. "The aftermath of the invasion of Kuwait could be as destabilizing, or more so, than the invasion itself," the diplomat said.
In coming weeks, the Syrian Foreign Minister said, "the decisions that will be taken will be fateful for our three countries and the Arab world."
Since the crisis, he and his Egyptian counterparts have met with unusual regularity in the diplomatic turmoil caused by the Iraqi invasion. All three have said publicly that they support President Bush's invitation to Iraq to open discussions. But other Syrian and Arab officials have registered concern that the contacts between the United States and Iraq be restricted to the issue of forcing Iraq out of Kuwait, and should not lead to a negotiation or concessions.
The information ministers of Egypt, Saudi Arabi and Syria have also been meeting here for the past two days seeking ways to prevent Iraqi propaganda from igniting popular support for President Hussein in their own countries.
 
Maneuver to Avert War
 In today's diplomatic flurry, the trip to Baghdad by King Hussein and Vice President al-Beedh of Yemen suggested that the Jordanian King might once again be seeking some opening for maneuver to avert war, Western diplomats here said. While supporting most of the international economic sanctions against Iraq, Jordan has kept open the lines to its powerful eastern neighbor and has said its policy is to promote a peaceful resolution of the crisis.
The Western diplomats noted that King Hussein's visit coincided with news reports that he has decided to send his Ambassador back to Riyadh. The diplomat, Nasser al-Batainah, was recalled in September as relations between Jordan and Saudi Arabia soured after the invasion of Kuwait.

HEADLINE: Late-Month Vehicle Sales Off 20.5%

BYLINE: By PAUL C. JUDGE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Dec. 4

 BODY:
Sales of cars and light trucks tumbled 20.5 percent in late November, deflating hopes that moderately strong demand earlier in the month would continue despite a weakening economy.
Seasonally adjusted, cars sold at an annual rate of 5.3 million late last month, the lowest rate for a 10-day period since early October 1982, when the economy was struggling out of a recession. 
 Analysts said today that the poor sales rate reflected flagging consumer demand more accurately than the data of the last few months, when deliveries to corporate and rental fleets made vehicle sales look abnormally high. Manufacturers do not differentiate in their sales reports between retail and fleet sales.
 
Prolonged Slump Seen
 "This is probably the pure underlying market that represents the private demand," said Maryann N. Keller, an analyst with Furman, Selz, Mager, Dietz & Birney Inc. in New York. Ms. Keller and other analysts said the late-November results could mark the beginning of a prolonged slump for the industry, lasting well into the spring.
Mark Brobeck, the general manager of Ricart Ford in Columbus, Ohio, said salesroom traffic was down 30 percent last month. "A lot of people seemed to be putting off the purchase decision," he said. "They talk about the economy in general; they don't know what will happen, and they don't want to get into a four- or five-year loan. It seems more people are buying on need than on impulse."
One bright spot, Mr. Brobeck said, was the strong demand for smaller, fuel-efficient cars, including the Ford Motor Company's Escort subcompact, which posted an overall gain of 18.6 percent in November, compared with last November's sales. Used cars sales have been steady, he said.
"I'm worried," said Jim Hoffer, the manager of Jordan Motors, a Ford dealership near Indianapolis. "Everybody is scared to death we are going to war, and they aren't in any mood to spend their money on cars or trucks." Car The 10 domestic makers said today that they sold 153,314 cars in the Nov. 21-30 period, a decline of 15.2 percent from the same period last year, when demand was also weak.
The seasonally adjusted annual sales rate of 5.3 million cars in the period lagged behind the sluggish rate of 6 million in late November of last year, and well behind the pace of 6.3 million for the entire month.
The sales rate for the last 60 days totaled 6.6 million; so far this year, cars have sold at an annual rate of 6.9 million.
The sales of pickup trucks, mini-vans and four-wheel-drive vehicles fell 28.8 percent in late November, to 82,453, continuing a three-month slide that analysts have tied to the lower fuel-efficiency of light trucks.
For all of November, car sales fell only 1.5 percent, to 668,008, reflecting fleet deliveries that propped up sales during the first half of the month. Sales of imported cars fell 10.3 percent in November, while those of Japanese cars produced in American factories -- transplants -- rose 19 percent. The Big Three's combined car sales were off six-tenths of a percent. The sales of light trucks declined 7 percent in the month.
The Big Three auto makers posted sales declines in late November, which had been foreshadowed by sweeping plant shutdowns announced by the General Motors Corporation, Ford and the Chrysler Corporation in recent weeks. The shutdowns will idle more than a third of the Big Three's 72 assembly plants in the United States and Canada, causing widespread layoffs among hourly workers.
If the car companies adhere to the latest production schedules, they will manufacture 2.3 million vehicles in the United States in the fourth quarter, 17 percent below their plans at the beginning of the period. Based on the slump in sales and the sharp production cuts now occurring as a result, several analysts predict that the Big Three will lose money in the fourth quarter.
General Motors said it sold 64,792 cars in late November, a decline of 17.3 percent The company's Saturn division, reporting its first sales results, said it sold 641 cars in November. A Saturn spokesman said most new cars were going to dealerships in the Southwest, the West Coast, and Florida -- "heavy import areas we wanted to hit first," he said.
 
Ford's Car Sales Off 3.3%
 Ford's November car sales fell 3.3 percent, to 128,346. Those of its light trucks were down 5.4 percent.
Chrysler sold 61,667 domestically produced cars last month, down 3 percent. Those of the company's light trucks, including mini-vans and Jeeps, plunged 18.9 percent, to 58,536.
Chrysler plans to stop reporting its sales results every 10 days and report figures only for the end of the month beginning in January, because of what it regards as adverse publicity arising from unfavorable comparisons with Japanese auto makers, who report their overall sales at the end of each month.

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
House Democrats Caution Bush on War

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4

 BODY:
House Democrats adopted a nonbinding policy statement late today declaring that President Bush should not initiate any offensive military action in the Persian Gulf without the formal approval of Congress unless American lives were in immediate danger.
The resolution, adopted on a 177-37 vote after two hours of closed-door debate by the House Democratic Caucus, reflected the views that Democratic leaders in both the House and Senate have repeatedly expressed since Mr. Bush ordered more American troops to the Gulf last month. But it is the most explicit and formal statement to date of the Democratic position. 
 It also comes as concerns increase among lawmakers and outside experts about the Bush Administration's apparent impatience with reliance on economic sanctions to force the withdrawal of Iraqi forces from Kuwait. Before approving the resolution, House Democrats agreed to accept modifying language that would also put them on record in support of the President's actions to defend Saudi Arabia and his efforts to use diplomatic initiatives and the economic sanctions to resolve the crisis.
 
Court Clash on War Powers
 The action today came as 54 Democratic members of Congress and the Bush Administration clashed in Federal Court over whether the President can wage war against Iraq without first getting explicit authority from Congress.
The confrontation, which involves questions of constitutional law dating back to the founding of the nation, came as the result f a suit brought by the lawmakers asking a judge to block Mr. Bush from going to war unless Congress first votes its approval.
Noting that no court had ever issued such an injunction, Judge Harold H. Greene said he would study the case and rule sometime in the future.
"The question before this court is straightforward," said Jules Lobel, a University of Pittsburgh law professor who argued the case for the lawmakers. "Can the President initiate a war against Iraq for the purpose of getting it out of Kuwait without the consent of Congress? The President says he can but the Constitution says he can't."
At issue is Article I, Section 8 of the Constitution, which vests Congress with the sole authority to declare war. The question of how much of a role Congress should play in the use of combat troops abroad has vexed policymakers since the founding of the nation.
 
The Government's Stand
 Stuart M. Gerson, the assistant attorney general who argued the case for the Government, said Presidents have often sent troops into combat without a Congressional declaration of war.
Judge Greene interrupted Mr. Gerson's argument to ask when the declaration of war clause could be used.
"So when does it apply?" Judge Greene asked.
Mr. Gerson said, in effect, that the declaration of war power was optional, that it allowed Congress to take the initiative to start a war if it chose to do so, but did not limit a President from sending troops into combat.
Mr. Gerson also argued that the Constitution did not say when Congress had to declare war. "It doesn't have to be in advance of hostilities," he said, "it could be after."
Mr. Lobel, who was accompanied by four members of Congress at the counsel table, argued that it was useless for Congress to have the ability to declare war once a President has already sent troops into combat. Everyone knows, he said, that Congress has no choice but to support troops once they are engaged in combat.
The power to declare war, he said, "is before it begins, not while it's going on."
 
No 'Indefinite Threat'
 The buildup in the Gulf, he argued, provided Judge Greene with the clearest case in history for requiring the President to seek explicit approval from Congress. Noting the troop deployment and statements from Administration officials that they were running out of patience with the Iraqi President, Saddam Hussein, he said: "We're talking about the threat of war in six weeks. We're not talking about some indefinite threat."
In October, before Congress adjourned for the year, both the House and Senate overwhelmingly approved resolutions supporting President Bush's initial deployment of American troops to the Gulf.
But the resolutions were deliberately ambiguous about continued support if the President took military action without exlicit approval from Congress. The Senate measure for example, included language approved by the White House that tied future decisions to "United States constitutional and statutory processes," a statement vague enough to be open to different interpretations by the Administration and lawmakers.
 
Cheney Stirs the Pot
 The original House measure sidestepped the question of how or when force should be used. At the time those measures were passed, and in the weeks since, a number of liberal Democrats argued that Congress was too vague and had left the door open for the President to make a military move.
The action by the House Democrats today appears to have been prompted in part by statements on Monday by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney that the President has the authority to order an attack on Iraq without Congressional approval. Although lawmakers have generally given President Bush high marks for his willingness to consult with Congress on the Gulf crisis, they have failed to win either a public or private commitment from him that he would seek a formal declaration of war prior to committing American troops to military action.
The touchy issue was also raised today as the Senate Foreign Relations Committee opened a series of hearings on Gulf policy. When Democratic senators asked former Defense Secretary Robert McNamara whether he shared Mr. Cheney's view that Mr. Bush did not need approval from Congress, Mr. McNamara pointed to the bitter lessons of Vietnam.
"I do not believe the President should, and I do not believe he will initiate action without the approval of the American people expressed by the approval of Congress," he said.
Mr. McNamara, who was President Lyndon B. Johnson's Defense Secretary during the height of the Vietnam War, told the committee that the Bush Administration should continue to rely on economic sanctions for perhaps as long as 18 months as the means to dislodge Iraq from Kuwait. Democratic senators on the panel shared that assessment.
 
'Toughness in Patience'
 "Sometimes there is more toughness in patience than in lashing out," said Senator Paul Simon, an Illinois Democrat. "This is such a time." Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, a New York Democrat, said, "We have time, I don't see any hurry." .
But Senator Rudy Boschwitz, a Minnesota Republican who lost his re-election bid and will not be returning to Washington when the new Congress convenes on Jan. 3, said he shared Mr. Cheney's conclusion that giving the sanctions more time to work also amounted to a decrease in pressure on Iraq that would allow President Hussein to marshall his resources and build military strength.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Japanese Bullish On U.S. Stocks

BYLINE: By Kurt Eichenwald

 BODY:
AS gloom is spreading among American investors about the state of the domestic economy and equity markets, one big group of investors is being told to buy American: the Japanese.
In a report being discussed with its large institutional clients today, Nomura Securities International, the world's largest securities firm, is saying that it views American companies as a better investment for the next five years than Japanese companies. 
 That viewpoint is based on several factors, including Nomura's conclusion that a number of Japanese industries have reached the peak of their rapid growth and should grow only at a stable pace over the next five years.
In the extensive report Nomura says the American marketplace is significantly undervalued, in part because of the troubles in the Middle East. And, contrary to popular conceptions, the Japanese securities firm says American corporate expenditures on research and development, as a percentage of sales, have kept even with or ahead of their Japanese counterparts' expenditures. The report, which was written in Japanese, was discussed by executives of the firm.
The report comes at a critical tie for the domestic securities industry. As the Tokyo stock market has fallen in 1990, the net investment by Japanese investors in United States securities has been falling, cutting back an important source of capital and liquidity for the marketplace. Through September, Japanese investors were net sellers of $144 million of American securities.
Executives with Nomura Research InstituteAmerica, the division that put the report together, said the recommendations were among the strongest they have ever made to Japanese institutional investors to purchase American securities.
One reason the Japanese have been pulling back on their investments, is concern about the disparate rate of growth in the real gross national product -- 2.5 percent in the United States through the 1980's and 4.1 percent in Japan, executives with Nomura said.
"We hope the Japanese clients will understand the actual truth about the United States," said Koichiro Aoyama, the chairman and chief executive of the research institute. "Corporate profit growth has nothing to do with G.N.P. growth."
Makoto Hiranuma, the senior analyst who worked on the report, added: "Usually, Japanese clients see only the inflation rate and the real G.N.P. rate, and forget to look at the companies themselves. There is an excellent opportunity for long-term investment in United States stocks."
According to the Nomura report, 13 corporate sectors stand to have earnings growth over the next five years of 13 percent in the United States, compared with an estimated earnings growth of 6.4 percent in Japan.
That difference assumes a 3 percent annual depreciation for currency fluctuations, which the firm foresees largely because of the differing inflation rates in the United States and Japan.
The largest percentage difference in earnings isexpected in the airline industry, where Nomura sees earnings growth of 47.8 percent in the next five years in the United States and only 5.4 percent in Japan. The only industry sector where the firm sees less earnings growth in the United States than in Japan is the utilities industry -- 1.9 percent in the next five years in America compared with 11.7 percent in Japan.
The overall conclusion, Mr. Hiranuma said, is simple. "The typical company in the United States should grow faster than their Japanese counterparts during the 1990's."
Among the companies that Nomura expects to experience strong growth over the coming years are Compaq Computer, Toys "R" Us, Wal-Mart and Procter & Gamble.
The report also concludes that much of the American market is extremely undervalued. In an analysis of the Standard & Poor's 400 industrial company stocks, Nomura concluded that as of Nov. 30 they were undervalued by a total of 29 percent. Much of that undervaluing, Mr. Hiranuma said, is the result of Middle East concerns. "After the Mideast crisis ends, there is nothing to stop the market from reaching its value," he said.
The report, which will also be shown to Japanese corporate clients, also has some strong suggestions for the future of management strategies in Japan. For example, the report says that strategic alliances with foreign companies will be very important for Japan during the 1990's to maintain competitiveness.
In addition, the report cautions that Japanese international companies must adopt local management cultures, so that American divisions are managed by Americans and European divisions by Europeans. In addition, they must establish local research and development divisions that would share information.
"Think global, manage local is a good phrase, I think," Mr. Hiranuma said.

HEADLINE: U.S. Center to Help Parents Choose Children's Schools

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4

 BODY:
Education Secretary Lauro F. Cavazos said today that his department would establish a research center to help give parents the power to determine what schools their children attend.
Although the Bush Administration has spoken approvingly of the movement toward parental choice in education, often called simply "choice," the new Center for Choice in Education is its first concrete action in support of the idea. 
 The center, which will soon be opened in the department's offices and run by department employees, will provide a toll-free telephone number, (800) 442-PICK, to answer questions about school choice; create a bank of experts who can provide help and information to educators and parents, and offer workshops and seminars for administrators, school trustees, teachers, legislators and parents.
 
Empowering the Poor
 Parental choice is based on the idea that if people can choose freely among schools, the competition will force schools to shape up or shut down. Proponents of the policy, which has been adopted in a half a dozen states in various forms, say it leads to better schools. Opponents reply that free-market principles will not eliminate underfinanced, inferior schools, and that those schools will simply become repositories for children who are poor or disabled, or whose parents may not be able to make informed choices.
Mr. Cavazos said the new center fitted into the philosophy of empowering people, particularly the poor, through programs based on market forces, individualism and decentralization. The idea is favored by many in the Administration, notably Housing Secretary Jack F. Kemp. "The American economy and our democracy are products of empowerment," Mr. Cavazos said, "and this approach can revitalize our schools as well."
One widely publicized choice program, intended to serve low-income families in inner-city Milwaukee, goes a step further than others because it provides state financing for children to attend private schools. It has been operating since September, though on Nov. 14 a Wisconsin appeals court struck down the law authorizing it. The Legislature is revising the law to satisfy the judges.
Mr. Cavazos said the Administration took no position on using public funds to finance private schools, and added that budget constraints would make it impossible for the Federal Government to provide vouchers or direct support for such programs. But he said President Bush supported the Milwaukee choice program.
Supporters and critics were quick to respond to the department's action today.
Bella Rosenberg of the American Federation of Teachers said choice alone would not fix America's schools. "The notion that choice automatically, like a magician pulling a rabbit out of a hat, is going to lead to quality schools, is a joke, " she said. "I don't know whether to call it pathetic or an example of an Administration in Fantasyland as the Christmas season approaches."
Burton Yale Pines, a senior vice president at the Heritage Foundation, a nonprofit conservative research organization, praised the department for embracing the "fundamental populism of the Reagan world view," though he added that the Bush Administration had been pushed "kicking and screaming" into embracing empowerment.
Other researchers criticized the creation of the new center, in part because the Federal Government withdrew its financing for two established research centers -- one devoted to elementary and middle schools, at Johns Hopkins University, the other to secondary schools, at the University of of Wisconsin.

GRAPHIC: Photo: "The American economy and our democracy are products of empowerment, and this approach can revitalize our schools as well," said Education Secretary Lauro F. Cavazos of a plan to give parents more power to determine the schools their children attend. (The New York Times)

HEADLINE: FEDERAL RESERVE ACTS TO INCREASE LENDING BY BANKS

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4

 BODY:
In an unusual step to improve bank profits and stimulate the economy, the Federal Reserve announced today that banks would no longer have to keep a portion of certain types of deposits in reserve in cash or interest-free accounts.
With the American economy weakening, the move seemed to be a response by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve Board's chairman, to mounting pressure from the White House to do something to turn the flagging economy around. If banks increase their lending, businesses and consumers will have more money to invest and spend to generate economic growth. 
 Mr. Greenspan has also been pressed by bankers to take some step to make lending easier. Many bankers have complained that Federal regulators have overreacted to the loan problems of some banks by twisting the screws so tight that banks in general could not conduct business normally.
 
'Contractionary Influence'
 The Federal Reserve said in its announcement that the action on reserve requirements was taken because tightened lending standards by banks had become "a contractionary influence on the economy."
The Federal Reserve has been increasingly concerned in recent months about the tightening of bank credit, a development Mr. Greenspan called a "credit crunch" in Congressional testimony last week. The chairman said this was a contributing factor to the shrinking of the economy since October, although he added that it was a less important element than higher oil prices and the general uneasiness over the possibility of a Persian Gulf war.
In the financial markets, the value of the dollar declined somewhat and bond prices rallied. The market reaction was based on the reasoning that if it becomes easier for banks to lend money, interest rates should fall.
 
Commercial Rates Cited
 A Federal Reserve Board official said another reason for the move was to help correct an anomalous situation this year that has made bank certificates of deposit unattractive to institutional investors at the end of the year, a circumstance that the board believes has led commercial interest rates to be higher than warranted.
The change, effective later this month, will increase bank profits by about $1 billion a year, the bulk of it going to a relatively few large banks.
 This is the first time the reserve rules have been changed since 1983. The rules require banks, savings and loan institutions and other depository institutions to hold a portion of their deposits in cash or in interest-free balances at regional Federal Reserve Banks.
The central bank said it was eliminating the 3 percent reserve requirement on certificates of deposit held by corporations with maturities of less than 18 months and on the small amount of Eurocurrency liabilities, which are dollar-denominated certificates of deposit purchased abroad. The requirement will be reduced to 1.5 percent on Dec. 17 and eliminated altogether on Dec. 27.
Personal deposits like checking accounts and certificates held by individuals make up the bulk of bank deposits, and the reserve requirement on these, 12 percent in most instances, will remain unaltered.
 
 Funds Rate Reduced
 Typically, when the Federal Reserve wants banks to increase lending, it reduces the Federal funds rate, the rate banks charge for overnight loans, or the discount rate, the rate the Federal Reserve charges for direct loans to banks. In normal times, banks react to those changes by charging their customers lower rates. That in turn leads the customers to borrow more readily and spend more, giving the economy a boost.
But the Federal funds rate has been lowered by three-quarters of a percentage point in three steps since July. Still, the prime rate, the benchmark for many bank loans, has not fallen, and banks have cut back on their lending. Mr. Greenspan is clearly hoping that an increase in bank profits will prove to be a stronger inducement for a reduction in commercial rates.
Bankers and economists generally welcomed the move today but said they were skeptical it would have much effect on bank lending or on the economy in general. They observed that the additional funds that would be available to banks for lending would be more than offset by the higher deposit insurance premiums banks must begin paying on Jan. 1.
"This may have a minimal short-run economic effect," said Jerry L. Jordan, senior vice president of First Interstate Bancorp in Los Angeles. "But no one," he added, "would say that this will lead to a lot more bank lending or solve banks' problems."
To the extent banks are reluctant to lend, it is almost entirely because of the deteriorating economy, he said.
James E. Annable, chief economist of the First National Bank of Chicago, agreed with that analysis. "Yeah, it makes some difference," he said of the change. "But it's not that much. It puts a small Band-Aid on a large problem."
Reserve requirements were established in Revolutionary times when the Government first began chartering banks and have been in force in one form or another ever since. The purpose was to make banks keep a cushion as protection against a run or other short-term liquidity problem.
But almost all economists today believe they are an anachronism that has been kept on the books largely for political reasons. Bert Ely, a banking consultant in Virginia, expressed the prevailing view. He observed that the establishment of the Federal Reserve early in this century as the lender of last resort lessened the need for such a safety valve, and said the capacity of banks in recent years to borrow from other banks and raise money in various other segments of the financial markets made the required reserves unnecessary.
 
Tighter Credit Standards
 The announcement today stated: "The board took action at this time in response to mounting evidence that commercial banks have been tightening their standards of creditworthiness and the terms and conditions for many types of loans. While much of this tightening has been welcome from a safety and soundness standpoint, it has in recent months begun to exert a contractionary influence on the economy."
The action today was the kind of incremental step that Mr. Greenspan favors rather than the bold move many in the Bush Administration and Congress believe is now necessary.
With the budget deficit preventing tax and spending policy from being used to redirect the course of the economy, the burden is entirely on Mr. Greenspan's shoulders. Until now, the chairman has received high marks in political circles for keeping the economy on a steady course.
But if the economy slides into a serious recession, he will surely be blamed for being timid, and that could douse his chances for reappointment when his four-year term expires in August.
The view within the Bush Administration, for example, is that short-term interest rates should now be driven down by a percentage point or more to give the economy a jolt, but Mr. Greenspan is reluctant to make any move that might be inflationary.
A Federal Reserve official said the central bank hoped the change would ease an unusual development this year that threatens to keep interest rates unusually high at the end of this year.
Because banks are perceived nowadays as bad risks, many institutional investors that must make public their portfolios as of Dec. 31, particularly money market mutual funds, do not want to show bank certificates as among their holdings. "They want the stuff they print at the end of the year to look wonderful, first class, no risk at all," said Mr. Annable of the First National Bank of Chicago.
As a result, interest rates on certificates of deposits have risen recently. That in turn has forced the banks to keep their commercial interest rates high at the very time the Federal Reserve is trying to drive interest rates down.

HEADLINE: New York Sues Fast-Food Outlets on Fifth Ave. Over Signs

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
Tired of seeing the once-subdued storefronts of Fifth Avenue disappearing under a blanket of gaudy plastic banners advertising $2.99 chicken fajitas, New York City has sued Irving and Murray Riese, among others, to get the illegal signs removed from three locations.
The Riese brothers run 178 fast-food outlets in New York, often in clusters that include Roy Rogers, Pizza Hut, Del Taco and Houlihan's restaurants. The three in question are all on Fifth Avenue -- No. 479, at 41st Street; No. 560, at 46th Street, and No. 604, between 48th and 49th Streets. 
 Often, Riese Organization restaurants are festooned with large banners, like those on a scaffold over the sidewalk in front of No. 604 or the pink-and-white sign draped haphazardly over a marble pilaster at No. 560.
But in the case of the special Fifth Avenue zoning subdistrict in which those three restaurants operate, the Zoning Resolution prohibits the display of banners or pennants from building exteriors.
"The continued maintenance of this public nuisance deprives the public of its right to economic and esthetic stability in one of the city's premier districts," the lawsuits declared.
 
Devising 'Another Way'
 Late yesterday afternoon, less than a day after legal papers were served, the chief operating officer of the Riese Organization, Vincent McCann, said: "If we shouldn't do it, we shouldn't do it. We'll have to devise another way."
"With the banners, I know we probably overstepped our bounds," Mr. McCann said. "I've instructed the removal of the banners."
Repeated earlier efforts to get the Riese brothers to comply with the restriction -- by request and legal summons -- were unavailing, said city officials and the president of the Fifth Avenue Association, whose 900 members include stores, banks and real-estate concerns.
The suit was undertaken by the Office of Midtown Enforcement, which coordinates law- and code-enforcement measures from 30th Street to 60th Street, between the East and Hudson Rivers.
 
'Ample Opportunity to Comply'
 "A lot of stores were violating the Zoning Resolution and a lot of violations and summonses were issued along there," said William H. Daly, director of the enforcement bureau."We've given these places ample opportunity to comply. The most egregious among those who haven't complied are these three."
"It's not targeted against the Riese brothers," Mr. Daly said. "It turns out that our code-enforcement people informed us that these three were the worst offenders as far as a failure to comply and also with respect to the number and size of signs. We may, indeed, bring more lawsuits along Fifth Avenue. These were the first -- the first and the worst."
Mr. McCann said that the Riese Organization did not "feel singled out," but that the lawsuits "seem like an overreaction."
In an affidavit supporting the city, Thomas Cusick, the president of the Fifth Avenue Association, said that the Riese Organization was the only company on the avenue that "completely ignored" notices from the association that they were violating the regulations.
 
Charges of Defective Locks
 In addition, he said, legal notices were "routinely ignored by the Riese Organization," which played "a game of 'cat and mouse' with the inspectors by removing the banners when a summons is issued, then waiting a respectable period and ultimately restoring the banner."
City officials also charged that the second, third and fourth floors of the restaurant at No. 604 were being used without the necessary public-assembly permit or certificate of occupancy and that the exits in the restaurant at No. 479 were locked or defective.
Mr. McCann said that he had only seen the suit involving No. 560 by yesterday afternoon and that he did not know about the other issues.
In their court papers, city officials seemed to acknowledge that signs might not be everyone's idea of a civic crisis.
"Although the harm engendered by the display of unlawful advertising banners and signs is different from the harm engendered by massage parlors, houses of prostitution or drug dens, it is nonetheless palpable and real," the suit said. "The defendants' intentional flouting of the Zoning Resolution will encourage further disregard for such laws."

HEADLINE: MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Macy's Ad Assails Financial Rumors

BYLINE: By ISADORE BARMASH

 BODY:
Frustrated by the continuing speculation about the financial stability of R.H. Macy & Company, Edward S. Finkelstein, its chairman and chief executive, took a full-page advertisement in a leading retailing trade paper yesterday to respond to "unfounded rumors and misinformation, which serve no one."
In the advertisement, which appeared in Women's Wear Daily at a reported price of about $15,000, Mr. Finkelstein leveled an attack on what close associates say is a pet peeve -- the growing conviction among suppliers and creditors that Macy's future is staked to sales performance this Christmas. 
 "No 'miracles on 34th Street' are required this Christmas," he stated in the advertisement, a reference to the holiday movie that is centered on Macy's flagship store on 34th Street in Manhattan. "The season will not make or break Macy's. We expect it to be slow and we are prepared for it."
The ad, which some in the industry say only lends credence to the rumors, was in the form of a letter from Macy's and signed by Mr. Finkelstein. It begins, "Dear Friends: It has become fashionable of late for uninformed outsiders to speculate about Macy's status and future."
The letter was also distributed to Macy's employees earlier this week, a company spokesman said.
Mr. Finkelstein declared in the ad, "We have $650 million less in inventory this Christmas season than last, so there is no need to resort to last year's level of markdowns, regardless of what others may do."
He added: "Our gross margins this Christmas quarter will be superior to last year's. We are focusing on profitability, not volume, and are committed to preserving traditional gross margins."
Mr. Finkelstein is said by people close to Macy's to have been especially irritated by recent news reports about the sharp increase in its losses, which rose to $66 million in the first fiscal quarter, ended Oct. 31, and by other articles suggesting that Macy's may face what Federated Stores confronted last January: a bankruptcy filing.
Last Thursday the Standard & Poor's Corporation said it was reviewing for a possible downgrading the speculative-grade rating for Macy's subordinated debt. The rating agency said the action reflected Macy's continuing weak retail sales in the context of the company's highly leveraged capital structure. Macy's is about $5 billion in debt from a 1986 leveraged buyout led by Mr. Finkelstein and a 1988 acquisition of the Bullock's and I. Magnin retail chains in California.
In the advertisement, Mr. Finkelstein tried to address the ramifications of some of these issues. "Macy's has ample liquidity to meet all of its obligations under any economic scenario we can foresee," he said. "In fact, even after making our $68 million debt principal payment later this month, we will be cash positive and have $475 million of excess bank borrowing capacity."
The advertisement drew mixed reactions.
"It's certainly a gamble that by running the ad he is reinforcing the rumors," said Bud Konheim, president of Nicole Miller Inc., a dress and sportswear maker. "It's obvious that Mr. Finkelstein is frustrated because no one is telling the story the way he wants it to be told. He probably feels embattled on several fronts. He used to make himself available to the media, but now he has other people doing it for him. But, in my opinion, he is doing well coping with all his problems."
Others doubted that the advertisement made a convincing case. "It's a bold move for Macy's to make considering that neither they nor anyone else knows that the retail business will be better in 1991 than it was in 1990," said David Rachman, professor of marketing at Baruch College in New York. "Ed Finkelstein must also be feeling pressure from suppliers. But if I were doing this, I would have my favorite banker also writing a statement in the ad or appearing with me on the six o'clock news."
He said the advertisement might have been a ploy to buy time. "I suspect that he may be in the midst of making a major or otherwise important deal and ran the ad to buck up the morale of factors and creditors until the deal takes place," Professor Rachman said.
In the ad, Mr. Finkelstein also stated: "Any comparison between Macy's and the situation in which Campeau Corporation (now Federated) found itself last winter is simply wrong. Campeau didn't have ample cash to meet its obligations -- we do; Campeau had huge, ballooning debt and interest payments to meet in a very short time frame -- we don't; and Campeau wasn't run by merchants who have seen hard times before and know how to plan for them -- we are."
Federated Stores, which owns Bloomingdale's and Abraham & Straus, declined to comment.

HEADLINE: Sales of New Homes Lowest in Eight Years

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4

 BODY:
Sales of new homes dropped by 3.5 percent in October to the lowest level in eight years, the Government reported today. But analysts said the free fall might be bottoming out and sales should begin rebounding by spring.
"Sales should be leveling off at this number in the fourth quarter and the first quarter of next year," assuming mortgage rates continue to fall and the gulf crisis is resolved, said David G. Seiders, an economist at the National Association of Home Builders. 
 Mark Obrinsky, an economist at the Federal National Mortgage Association, suggested that sales might zig-zag for several months, "but assuming no blowup in the Middle East," he said, "I expect to see a more sustained pickup by the spring of 1991."
 
Annual Rate of 491,000
 Sales totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 491,000, the Commerce Department and the Housing and Urban Development Department said in a joint news release. That was the lowest since 480,000 new homes were sold in October 1982, a month before the 1981-82 recession ended.
So far this year, the sales of new homes are off 15.8 percent from the 1989 period.
Sales fell by 4 percent in September and 2 percent in August. The September figure was revised upward from a 6 percent decline in the initial estimate by the departments, but the October total was worse than the 1.8 percent drop first reported.
Mr. Obrinsky said the main reason for the decline "is great consumer uncertainty and generally negative buying sentiment."
At the October sales pace, it would take 8.4 months to exhaust the inventory of unsold homes, up from 8.3 months in September. There was a seven-month supply of unsold homes in October 1989.
The median price of a new home in October was $121,800, up from $112,900 in September but down from $123,000 a year ago. The median means that half of the homes cost more, half less.
Mr. Seiders of the home-builder group attributed the price increase to a hefty 47.4 percent gain in sales in the Northeast, which has the highest housing costs in the nation. Sales there were at an annual rate of 84,000 units after falling 12.9 percent the previous month.
Sales in all other regions fell, including a drop of 18.2 percent in the West, to 112,000 units. That was the lowest since 106,000 homes were sold in September 1982.
In the Midwest, sales were off 11.7 percent, to 83,000 units, the lowest since 74,000 homes were sold in August 1986. Sales dropped 4.1 percent in the South, to 212,000 units.
