HEADLINE: BUSH, IN URUGUAY, VOWS OIL PRICE AID

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Dec. 4

 BODY:
President Bush, on the second stop of his Latin American tour, gave a strong pledge today to relieve the economic burden that small countries face from rising oil prices in connection with the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait.
Mr. Bush warned: "I can make clear that this is not going to go on forever. And it is not going to go on forever." 
 The coup attempt in Argentina on Monday and the situation in the Persian Gulf overshadowed the President's visit to Uruguay today.
Asked about the uprising in Argentina, Mr. Bush said he was looking forward to his visit to Buenos Aires on Wednesday. "I think that the incidents yesterday were aimed not at the Government, but it was a military-versus-military controversy," he said.
And when asked whether he thought democracies in South America were stable, he replied, "Yes I do."
 
Focus on Economic Issues
 The President spoke with reporters after meeting with President Luis Alberto Lacalle for talks that focused on trade and economic issues.
Secretary of the Treasury Nicholas F. Brady, who was accompanying the President on this trip, said today that Mr. Bush felt "very badly" that other events had distracted attention from his messages on free markets and blossoming democracy.
"We're missing a big opportunity to see how the President really feels" on the General Agreement on Tariff and Trade and the Enterprise for the Americas Initiative, Mr. Brady said.
There was no question that Mr. Bush's message of "a new dawn for the New World," the stated theme of his South American visit, was diminished by Urugayans' expressed concerns about the situation in the gulf.
 
Warning From Uruguayan
 Gonzalo Aguirre, Uruguay's Vice President and President of the Senate. introduced Mr. Bush for his speech to a session of the Uruguayan Congress with a strong warning to behave with "infinite patience" and take the paths of "persuasion and dissuasion" in the gulf.
"The use of force is equivalent and tantamount to war, and war is tantamount to destruction, desolation and death," Mr. Aguirre said. "If the decision is for war, perhaps we will not justify it, but we will certainly understand it."
When it was Mr. Bush's turn to speak, he defended his bellicose turn in recent weeks.
"What the world faces in the Persian Gulf, believe me, is fundamental," he said. "We will not, we must not, reward a nation that would wipe another country off the face of the earth. We will not reward a nation that has literally -- and the tales are agonizing -- has literally raped and terrorized its smaller neighbor."
 
Cheney's Assessment Backed
 At a news conference, Mr. Bush backed Defense Secretary Dick Cheney's assessment that economic sanctions will not work and that military force should be used to force Iraq out of Kuwait.
Although Mr. Cheney's arguments before the Senate Armed Services Committee on Monday were swiftly challenged by the committee chairman, Senator Sam Nunn, and other Democrats, Mr. Bush said he was so pleased with the Defense Secretary's words that he had sent him a warm message.
Mr. Cheney's testimony, and the President's remarks today at the joint news conference with President Lacalle, may have been designed less to signal imminent war than to increase the pressure on President Saddam Hussein of Iraq by persuading him that war is near.
"I am convinced that Saddam Hussein, up until now at least, has not gotten the message," Mr. Bush said. "And the United Nations resolution speaks for itself. To me, it was loud and clear. But I don't think Saddam Hussein yet understands that. And therefore, the best hope for peace is for him to understand that and all means, all means, necessary to fulfill these resolutions will be used against him."
 
Some Boycott Speech
 About a dozen lawmakers in the leftist coalition of the Uruguayan Congress boycotted Mr. Bush's speech, and a score more left afterward without clapping or joining in the polite standing ovation for the President.
Outside the Congress, several hundred people demonstrated, chanting in Spanish that Mr. Bush was a "murderer." Thousands more residents of Montevideo lined the streets of his motorcade, some curious to see the President and others waving crosses and flags with skull and crossbones in protest.
Mr. Bush is on a six-day Latin American trip to promote free trade, democracy and growth in the Western Hemisphere, trying to give the countries here some attention in a year when the focus has been on Eastern Europe.
"The Western Hemisphere can take pride in having launched this worldwide transformation from dictatorship to democracy," he said at the Legislative Palace.
He praised President Lacalle for being the first leader to call him when he announced his Enterprise for the Americas Initiative, a plan to open up trade and investment possibilities in the region.
 
Flexible on Trade Issue
 At his news conference, Mr. Bush said he was flexible on the issue of reducing farm subsidies on the trade negotiations on the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. The negotiations on the world trade regulations followed by some 100 nations are now in a stalemate in Brussels.
He said the United States and Uruguay were in agreement that something must be done about the European Community's unwillingness to make concessions to reduce protection for its farmers.
The American and Uruguyan Presidents agreed that the agriculture issue must be addressed, but said they were not locked into a specific figure for reduction of the subsidies.
"We are taking a pragmatic view toward the negotiation," Mr. Lacalle said. "We are saying agriculture must be inside. I'm not telling you what kind of percentage I'm prepared to accept, but it must be in the package, and it cannot be the percentage that has been officially offered up to now."

HEADLINE: Debt and Democracy

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 4

 BODY:
President Bush has started his five-nation tour of South America speaking of democracy. His Latin hosts, all democratically elected presidents, are talking of debt.
 "To fulfill the New World's destiny, all of the Americas and the Caribbean must embark on a venture for the coming century: to create the first fully democratic hemisphere in the history of mankind," Mr. Bush said on Monday as he began the first tour of South America by an American president in eight years. 
 Later in the day, Brazil's president, Fernando Collor de Mello, touched on his major preoccupation: the nation's $115 billion foreign debt.
"We are not talking of a banking problem, but a question that involves 150 million people and one of the largest and most important countries of the world," the Brazilian said at a dinner for Mr. Bush. "My government cannot demand more sacrifices if it is not convinced that these efforts will be the price for a consistent, balanced and feasable solution."
 
Linking Debt and Democracy
 To some, the missed dialogue reflected two hemispheres permanently out of synchronization. Leaving winter behind, the American president arrived as South America started its summer.
To others, Mr. Bush's reluctance to confront the debt issue reflected new economic realities in the United States. The developed world's most indebted nation can ill afford to bail out the developing world's most indebted nation.
But many Latin Americans argue that debt and the future of democracy will be inextricably intertwined in the 1990's.
"The foreign debt problem has created hurdles for democratization," Paulo Nogueira Batista Junior, a Sao Paulo economist, said today.
The countries on Mr. Bush's route -- Brazil, Uruguay, Argentina, Chile and Venezuela -- collectively owe $250 billion to foreign creditors. With the exception of Venezuela, virtually all of the debt was run up by military dictators during the 1970's and early 1980's. When civilians started reasserting control in the mid-1980's, they inherited staggering debt obligations.
 
An Orthodox Way Out
 "Brazil's military Governments had ample credit -- the civilian Governments have had none," Mr. Batista said referring to the virtual halt of new commercial bank loans to Brazil after the debt crisis broke in 1983.
Heavy debt service payments -- the Brazilians calculate that they paid $60 billion in the 1980's -- helped depress growth to the extent that the 1980's were widely dubbed Latin America's "lost decade."
Seeking to restore their finances, the region's nations are now trying an orthodox way out --slashing Government spending, encouraging foreign investment and opening domestic monopolies to international competition.
Chile made the painful transition under the closed system of a military dictatorship. But the other countries are going through the turmoil as fledgling democracies.
 
Widespread Reactions
 Behind the braggadocio of the military revolt in Argentina on Monday was widespread discontent over military salaries that have fallen far behind inflation. In Brazil, where inflation is 17 percent a month, military and civilian workers are demanding that they receive raises before New York banks receive interest payments. In Venezuela last year, about 300 people died in rioting when an austerity plan went into effect.
But in an interview with South American journalists in Washington on Friday, Mr. Bush said of the debt problem, "While I will want to discuss this issue with President Collor, I do not see it as central to my discussions in Brazil."
To the disappointment of many Brazilians, the American officials visting Brasilia took the position that renegotiating Brazil's $60 billion foreign debt is a private affair between Brazil and the banks.
Mr. Bush preferred to talk of his Enterprise for the Americas initiative, which envisions a free trade and free investment zone extending from Alaska to Argentina. Under the intiative, the United States would forgive a portion of $12 billion in debt owed by Latin American nations to the United States Government. In addition, he called for reducing commercial debt service by channeling payments into local environmental projects.
 
Twisted Arms, Empty Sleeves
 "In the Mexico negotiations we twisted a lot of arms that turned out to be empty sleeves," one American official said, seeking to minimize the participation of the United States Treasury in a commercial debt reduction package for Mexico last year.
But in a move that visiting Americans did not trumpet in Brasilia, the United States, Europe and Japan acted last week to cut off all new loans from the Inter-American Bank to Brazil until the Collor Government makes significant progress with its commercial creditors.
Indeed, the deadlocked Brazil negotiations reflect the anguish that surrounds the debt issue in South America. Brazil has not paid interest on its commercial debt in 15 months, racking up $8 billion in arrears.
"When I saw President Collor in New York in September, he told me he wanted to get an agreement by the end of the year, but progress has been glacial," William R. Rhodes, a senior executive of the Citicorp group and chairman of Brazil's bank advisory board said in a telephone interview today from New York. At risk, two American economists in Brasilia said today, are access to short-term credit lines and continued foreign investment.
The Brazilians say they are holding out for a long-term renegotiation that will reduce annual service payments to a level that will allow resumption of economic growth in the 1990's.
"Portugal, Spain and Greece returned to democracy under prosperity," Fernando Henrique Cardoso, a Sao Paulo senator, said in an interview today. "Latin America is trying to establish democracy without prosperity."

HEADLINE: Nation's Image Worries Argentines

BYLINE: By SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 4

 BODY:
As the last of the Argentine Army rebels were being loaded onto trucks after giving up Monday, a nearby group of civilians began to chant, "Paredon! Paredon!" meaning that they should be lined up before a wall and shot.
Such disgust with the fourth army rebellion in less than four years was almost generalized across Argentine society today as people endorsed the tough handling of the uprising by President Carlos Saul Menem and fretted about how the revolt might damage Argentina's standing with the world. 
 "My husband, after he heard about the rebellion yesterday, woke me up saying we were a fourth-class republic -- worse than a banana republic," said a woman crossing the Plaza de Mayo in front of the presidential palace. It was a comparison that could not be resisted by many commentators.
With President Bush scheduled to arrive Wednesday on the first visit by an American President since Eisenhower, the Menem Government has been eager to show a nation leaving behind the political and military antics of the past and worthy of mature trade and investment relations with the leading nations of the world.
 
Menem Cites Determination
 While some Government officials worried that the rebellion would represent a step backward from that goal, Mr. Menem said Argentina would emerge "fortified at the international level" because of the determination with which he crushed the rebels.
Determination was also used to put things back to normal this morning. Banks, the exchange markets and the domestic airport were functioning on schedule after being closed Monday, and traffic flowed freely.
The Interior Ministry said 21 people -- five of them civilians, the rest loyalist and rebel soldiers -- were killed in the long day of fighting that ensued after about 300 men occupied the army headquarters, three other army installations and a small building of the coast guard headquarters before dawn Monday. There was also fighting in the northern province of Entre Rios as loyalist troops attacked a rebel tank column moving toward the capital.
Unlike what occurred in the three military uprisings faced by Mr. Menem's predecessor, Raul Alfonsin, this time the bulk of the army and the leadership demonstrated what appeared to be strong loyalty to the Government by quickly using firepower against their rebellious comrades.
The newspaper La Nacion reported that the army chief of staff, Lieut. Gen. Martin Bonnet, told his generals Monday that he wanted the rebels to give up "in their underwear, with their hands behind their neck, and barefoot."
 
No Deals Seen
 In the past, loyalist troops had waffled and delayed and fired hardly a shot as politicians negotiated. To all appearances, there were no deals this time.
It was also notable that the civilian population showed no sympathy for the rebel demands. In the previous uprisings, a key demand was the halting of efforts to prosecute military men for political killings committed during the so-called dirty war against leftists in the mid-1970's. That demand found many civilian sympathizers from the political right and center-right.
But Mr. Alfonsin subsequently halted such trials and he and Mr. Menem pardoned or amnestied most of those accused, so that was no longer an issue.
The rebel demands this time were largely related to the impoverished state of the armed forces and the status of the dissidents within the ranks. They demanded, for example, that General Bonnet be replaced as chief of staff by Col. Mohamed Ali Seineldin, who led the last uprising two years ago and is now under 60 days' detention for recent public criticism of the Government.
 
Death Penalty Hinted
 Mr. Menem ordered summary proceedings against the rebels and hinted that he might permit the death penalty for the leaders, but other Government officials privately played down that possibility.
Foreign Minister Domingo Cavallo, arriving today from Brussels, said events such as those on Monday "always have a negative effect" on international public opinion but said the Government's rapid reaction had served to "mitigate" that effect.
Argentina, which is emerging from a long period of economic isolation and of cool relations with the United States, is looking to the Bush visit to help in its efforts to rebuild and restructure the economy with foreign investments and loans.
Mr. Menem would like to use what will be his fourth face-to-face meeting with Mr. Bush to seek better terms for Argentina's nearly $65 billion foreign debt and open new markets for Argentine agricultural exports. Although Argentina is siding with the United States in efforts to persuade the European Common Market countries to lower their agricultural subsidies -- the demand the Bush Administration makes for lowering United States subsidies -- there is still fear among producers and exporters here that the United States will never go far in reducing its own subsidies.
While the debt, most of which is with private banks, and the hope of increased foreign investment are not in the power of Mr. Bush to resolve, Mr. Menem is a man who believes that most things can be worked out by direct dealings among friends.
Like most Latin American leaders today, he wants to be friends with Mr. Bush.

HEADLINE: Alliance on Subsidies Pleases U.S.

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, Dec. 4

 BODY:
In trying to force the European governments to cut the generous subsidies paid to their farmers, the United States is allied with the 70 developing nations represented at this week's trade talks.
Among the industrial nations, the Europeans give farmers by far the largest subsidies. The International Monetary Fund estimates that halting the industrial world's farm subsidies could raise third world farm exports by $50 billion a year. 
 American officials are delighted that many third world nations have made reducing farm subsidies their principal goal in the trade negotiations. Brazil, Argentina, Chile and several other third world nations have been at Washington's side in putting pressure on the European Community to slash farm subsidies.
But that support has its price. The developing nations have stressed that without a liberalization of farm trade, they will resist dropping barriers to protect their nascent service industries, which might be hurt by efficient competitors from industrialized countries.
"Without a significant result in reducing agricultural protection, our country cannot accept the other results of this round of talks," said Domingo F. Cavallo, Argentina's Foreign Minister.
 
Rejoicing Over Fiber Accord
 On the one hand, third world ministers are eager for the industrial world to agree to slash protection in trade in textiles and farm products. Asian, African and Latin American officials say protection in these two areas robs them of vital export markets and slows their economic growth.
At the same time, officials from many developing nations are uneasy about proposals to liberalize trade in services and curb government subsidies to industry. They fear, for example, that if Western or Japanese banks and insurers gain the right to operate freely in their countries, that could hold back development of their small financial services sectors.
Officials of third world nations are rejoicing that negotiators are near agreement on phasing out the multi-fiber accord, which rich nations long used to restrict imports of third-world apparel.
They are also optimistic about winning far lower tariffs on tropical products like bananas, peanuts and cocoa. Lower tariffs should help raise trade in third world farm commodities battered by low prices.
Many officials of developing countries are less than enthusiastic about liberalizing trade in services. Fearing that Western corporations may completely dominate their service sectors, they are asking that along with liberalizaton, the industrialized world provide aid to help develop the third world's service sector.
There is also ambivalence about the West's push to win more protection for intellectual property, including patents and copyrights. Some third world officials fear that this could slow much-needed innovation and the development of small business. One Indian official said that granting patents to Western pharmaceutical companies could aggravate problems in his nation where cheap medicine is needed.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
With Oil High, How About Wood?

BYLINE: By SALLY JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BURLINGTON, Vt., Dec. 4

 BODY:
With oil prices hovering near $30 a barrel, advocates of wood energy are calling on the Government to forge a national energy policy that would make wood once again an economically attractive fuel for generating electricity.
Improved technologies and environmental benefits should rekindle interest in wood and other vegetable fuels called biomass, advocates say. In Vermont, which has gone from 20 percent forest to 80 percent in the last century. some developers are taking a serious look at new wood-burning projects. 
 Environmentally, wood is attractive for several reasons. It has no sulfur, so burning it does not contribute to acid rain, said Robert Kennel, a vice president of Hadson Power Systems, who is in charge of developing wood and coal plants for the Southern California-based company.
Barry Commoner, a leading environmental expert, said that theoretically wood even could be preferable to fossil fuels. "Coal, oil or natural gas would contribute to the global warming effect," he said, "A tree would not," because it would be releasing carbon dioxide that was taken out of the atmosphere when it grew, whereas the other fuels represent much older carbon.
Professor Commoner, who is director of the Center for the Biology of Natural Systems at Queens College of the City University of New York, also said that emissions from wood-fueled power plants, like those from any other power plants, could be controlled through the use of electrostatic preciitators or scrubbers.
"The only way I know that the environmental issue has arisen from wood-burning," he said, was when people in Vermont and New Hampshire used wood-burning stoves and furnaces. Unlike a power plant, they do not have emission controls, so smoke accumulates.
Another advantage to the plants being tried in Vermont and California is that they use only waste wood from industry and agriculture, solving a waste-disposal problem, not cutting down trees to burn. Despite the environmenal advantages, the economic advantages are less clear-cut.
"Rising oil prices should have a positive effect on getting people and institutions thinking about alternative energy," Mr. Kennel said.
"The concern is that no one knows how long oil prices will stay high," he said. "The only thing that's going to get wood energy back into the picture is a solidly thought-out national energy policy, something we've never had in this country."
Wood burning, once promising, had a boom period in the 1980's, only to slow to a near-standstill by the end of the decade after the 1986 tax law curbed tax credits for alternative energy, along with many other tax breaks.
The most promising technologies would both reduce capital costs and increase the efficiency of biomass plants, said David Rinebolt, director of research for the National Wood Energy Association, a trade association of developers of wood projects.
Whole-tree burning allows trees to be burned in 20-foot sections, eliminating the need for processing the wood into chips and thereby cutting costs.
A technology called gasification involves "cooking," or heating, the wood in an oxygen-restricted environment and separating it into volatile gases, charcoal and tars. The gases can be fed directly into the turbines that generate electricity, eliminating the need for steam power.
Vermont has proposed using the gasification process with a highly efficient gas turbine engine, developed by General Electric for use in jets.
The Vermont Department of Public Service has won a commitment from the Federal Government of close to $1 million to pay for a feasibility study for a 20-megawatt wood-gasification power plant in Bennington, near the New York State line.
"Southwestern Vermont has the most underutilized forest, so the forestry people like it," said George Sterzinger, commissioner of the department. "We like it because it is one of the cleanest ways to generate electricity without a net addition of carbon dioxide to the environment."
In addition, the state signed an agreement with Brazil last May to explore the applications of the gasification technology for agricultural waste, specifically sugar cane.
"This project would have both local economic and global environmental benefits," Mr. Sterzinger said. "It potentially leverages a small amount of Federal money to attract a large amount of private money. Everybody's just been waiting to see if somebody else could make it work."
But others remain unconvinced that technology alone will bring wood back into play. Mr. Kennel argues that only national policy can do that.
Vermont was a pioneer in using wood as a fuel to generate electricity for commercial sale. The McNeil Generating Station, owned by the Burlington Electric Department, went into commercial operation in 1984. It used wood, taken from nearby forests, that was chipped for burning.
At 50 megawatts, it is the largest wood-fired plant in the country, capable of serving 100,000 to 150,000 people. There was trouble from the start, however, leading some detractors to write it off as a failure. But to backers of wood burning, McNeil became an object lesson for future plants.
The McNeil station, conceived in the years after the oil embargo when oil prices were high and Congress was enthusiastic about renewable energy sources, was built in a populated area.
Wood was plentiful, but there was poor road access. And by the time the plant, which was expensive to run, started up, oil prices had dropped. Also, it was noisy and dirty, angering its neighbors just outside the city.
"I have to say the Burlington Electric Department showed some pizazz in attempting McNeil," said Mr. Kennel, whose company, Hadson Power Systems, has developed eight wood-burning plants. "It is certainly the granddaddy of wood plants. What we all learned from it is that 50 megawatts is too big. We also learned that a location with good road access is critical."
Despite McNeil's problems, national interest in wood burning, spurred by Federal tax policy, grew quickly. In 1986 alone, 1,839 megawatts of electricity from wood-burning generators went into operation, more than half the 3,054 megawatts of power introduced from 1980 to 1985.
Over all, Mr. Kennel estimated, there are 1,000 wood-fired plants in the country, typically ranging from 10 to 25 megawatts. A 20-megawatt plant burns 600 tons of wood a day and can serve 50,000 people, but only a third of the plants offer electricity for sale. The rest are owned and operated by the forest-products industry for its own use.
Wood energy has been tried principally in New England and California, where it has been seen as an alternative to failed nuclear plants.
But in 1989 Mr. Rinebolt of the wood energy association said that without the tax credits only 614 megawatts of wood-fueled electricity were brought into operation. This year, he expects the number to be even smaller: 250 to 300 megawatts; plants are under development in Vermont, Connecticut, Maine and Michigan.
Mr. Rinebolt said, "Coal projects are getting bid in at 3.5 cents per kilowatt-hour, while wood is at 5 cents."

HEADLINE: Puerto Ricans' Alienation Is Cited in Miami Rampage

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, Dec. 4

 BODY:
A rampage on Monday night in which hundreds of youths looted stores and set fires was touched off in part by a sense of alienation and powerlessness among Miami's tiny Puerto Rican population, neighborhood residents and leaders of Puerto Rican organizations said today.
"We want the people to know that we exist," said Clemente Montalvo, who has lived in Miami's predominantly Puerto Rican neighborhood, Wynwood, all his life. 
 The disturbance in Wynwood, small compared with outbreaks of ethnic violence in recent years here, came hours after a Federal jury acquitted six members of a police drug squad of conspiracy in the beating death of a Puerto Rican drug dealer, Leonardo Mercado. The jury deadlocked 11 to 1 for acquittal on the more serious charge of violating Mr. Mercado's civil rights by killing him,
 
'Cubans Get Everything'
 "It's not just because of the Mercado trial," Mr. Montalvo said. "Cubans get everything; we get nothing. When the Cubans jump, they get what they want."
During the rampage, several youths clutched Puerto Rican flags, and shouts of "Viva Puerto Rico!" mixed with chants of "Cano!" which was Mr. Mercado's nickname.
Puerto Ricans said today that their lack of status here was reflected in such things as the absence of Puerto Rican music on Spanish-language radio stations and the dearth of Puerto Ricans in powerful positions in local government and business.
"I dare you to find in the city of Miami a Puerto Rican in a position of authority," said Emilio Lopez, president of the Borinquen Health Care Center in Wynwood. "If he is, he is so entangled with the establishment that he won't do anything for his people."
In fact, Maurice Ferre, a former Mayor, was born in Puerto Rico.
The police and some Wynwood residents attributed the rampage to neighborhood toughs whose sole motive was to cause trouble and steal. "All these criminals saw this demonstration taking place and they started taking advantage of it," said Sgt. David Rivero, spokesman for the Miami Police Department. "You had hoods, dope dealers, alcoholics, dope users who decided to have a good time."
Numbering about 12,300 people, or about 4 percent of the city's population, Miami's Puerto Rican residents have for years quietly existed on the fringe of the political and commercial establishment. In a city often defined by its ethnic crosscurrents, the Puerto Ricans have largely been missing from the spotlight that shines on Cubans, blacks and non-Hispanic whites.
"The perception here is that when you speak about Hispanics, you only speak about Cubans," Mr. Lopez said. "When you speak about the poor, you speak about blacks."
Monday's disturbance grew out of a demonstration by friends and relatives of Mr. Mercado in a neighborhood park.
 For nearly three hours Monday night, hundreds of youths roamed with impunity through Wynwood, pelting passing cars and buses with stones, overturning vehicles, setting three buildings ablaze, igniting fires in trash bins and looting stores. More than 300 police officers, many in riot gear, finally moved in around 9 P.M. and began to quell the melee.
Fire officials set a preliminary estimate of the damage at $2.5 million. Other than two news photographers who were roughed up, there were no reports of injuries. At least 15 people were arrested.
Several Wynwood residents and merchants criticized the police for responding too slowly to the violence. The police acknowledged today that they had not expected the traditionally tranquil Puerto Rican community to become violent. As a result, they said, there was only a normal complement of officers on duty when the trouble began around 6 P.M., several hours after the verdict was announced.
 
Police on Guard Again
 It took the police about three hours to muster riot squads. Mr. Rivero, the police spokesman, said that any police presence in Wynwood before the arrival of the riot squads could easily have resulted in more people being hurt, as outnumbered officers without tear gas or riot gear might have had to resort to firing their weapons to protect themselves.
Since two of the six officers in the Mercado case were Hispanic, three were black and one was white, the disturbance is not being interpreted in strictly racial terms. The resentment expressed today by several Wynwood residents was against the police, not against a particular racial group.
Police were on guard tonight for further outbreaks of violence. Several Wynwood residents have expressed outrage not only at the verdict but also at Chief Perry Anderson's stated intention to reinstate the six police officers involved in the Mercado case.
The rampage has focused the city's attention on Wynwood, an area of grinding poverty where the windows on most of the one-story and two-story bungalows are covered by iron bars and where concertina wire tops fences around the parking lots of the few businesses. Miami officials say Wynwood is one of the city's poorest communities, though data on unemployment and income are from the 1980 census and are considered outdated.
"They're destitute, and they don't get much that help from society or government," said Mayor Xavier Suarez, who promised to divert more city resources to Wynwood. "We're a little embarrassed by that."
"It's a sad situation that this had to happen," said William Rios, executive director of the Wynwood Community Economic Development Corporation, a non-profit company that seeks to lure busineses to the area through tax incentives.
"It's going to be difficult for me to promote businesses in this area," he said. "But at least the community is getting recognition of its needs. Before, people didn't really know where Wynwood was. They didn't know there was a Puerto Rican community."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Miami firefighters examining a gutted building yesterday in the predominantly Puerto Rican Wynwood section, after a disturbance Monday night in which hundreds of youths looted stores and set fires. (Agence France-Presse)
 
Map: Map of Miami showing the area of disturbance.

HEADLINE: Oil Rallies, Then Slips a Bit After Close on Iraqi Report

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Oil prices climbed more than $1.50 a barrel on the futures market yesterday, but then lost a large part of that gain in after-hours trading when a news report indicated that Iraq might leave Kuwait.
The benchmark grade of crude oil settled at $30.66 a barrel, up $1.51, at the New York Mercantile Exchange on contracts for January delivery. Later contract months all settled higher, mostly by more than $1 a barrel. 
 But soon after the Mercantile Exchange had closed for the day, oil traders were jolted by a British television news report indicating that Iraq might have a plan for pulling its army out of Kuwait.
Sky television news said Iraq might be ready to withdraw from most of Kuwait if it is allowed to keep the disputed Rumaila oilfield and if it received a guarantee that Western forces would not attack. A State Department official said the United States was unaware of any such Iraqi position.
Prices for petroleum at loading platforms and docks, commonly called the cash or spot market, tumbled by more than $1 a barrel minutes after the Mercantile Exchange closed, traders said. The cash market ordinarily follows the behavior of prices in the futures market at the exchange.
"That's a lot," said Thomas P. Blakeslee, an energy analyst with the Pegasus Econometric Group in Hoboken, N.J. "They usually don't move as dramatically as on the futures market."
In early afternoon trading on the exchange, oil prices had fallen on a report indicating that Kuwait might be willing to negotiate on the future of some of its islands if Iraq withdrew its troops, which invaded the country on Aug. 2.
 
'A Very Bullish Event'
 "But it did not continue to sell off; in fact it snapped back up," said Brian Tagler, a broker with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. "Everybody interpreted that as as a very bullish event, the fact that the market did not collapse."
Crude oil futures shot up nearly $2 above their lows for the day, puzzling many traders.
Futures prices for refined petroleum products moved pretty much in tandem with crude prices yesterday.
Home heating oil rose 2.23 cents, to 86.90 cents a gallon, on contracts for delivery in January. Unleaded gasoline for January delivery rose 2.40 cents, to 75.92 cents a gallon.
Natural gas prices, which are not directly affected by the potential for a Middle East war, fell 3.5 cents, to $2.44 per 1,000 cubic feet, on contracts for delivery in January.
Later yesterday, the American Petroleum Institute reported that the nation's supply of crude oil fell last week to 335.5 million barrels from 337.1 million a week earlier and 351.9 million a year earlier.
The stockpile of gasoline was at 221.1 million barrels, up from 218.3 million a week earlier but down from 223.1 million a year earlier, the institute said in its weekly report. The stockpile of distillates, which include home heating oil, totaled 132.9 million barrels, down from 134.8 million a week earlier but up from 121.5 million a year earlier, the institute said.

HEADLINE: Miscalculations Put a Tight Lid On '92 Budget

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4

 BODY:
Bush Administration officials said today that they had discovered that less money would be available for new domestic spending in the 1992 fiscal year than White House and Congressional budget negotiators had expected.
The discovery reflects the fact that new budget procedures and spending limits were set in an atmosphere of confusion at the end of October. The negotiators were juggling large sums of money, and budget officials said there was apparently a miscalculation, the reason for which is not yet clear. Another factor is that Congress was at the same time adding money to the Federal budget for the 1991 fiscal year, which began Oct. 1.
 
Assigning the Blame
 As a result, there is less room for growth in the next fiscal year than the negotiators thought they were allowing. In fact, Administration officials said today that spending limits set in the new budget law were slightly lower than the amount needed to continue the services at existing levels, and hardly any money would be available for new domestic initiatives. 
 So far, there has been no finger-pointing, but budget officials and Congressional aides said that could come later.
The finding that the budget agreement's limits on domestic spending are tighter than people realized came to light in a memorandum sent to Cabinet officers by President Bush's budget director, Richard G. Darman. In responding to their budget requests for 1992, he said they had not caught up with "the new world of firm, fixed (and lower!) domestic discretionary spending caps," or limits.
He also scolded them, saying that they had submitted excessive budget requests for 1992. He said the Cabinet officers had displayed "near-universal expectations" that cuts would come in someone else's programs.
Mr. Darman and Congressional leaders set the domestic spending cap at $191.3 billion for 1992. They thought they were allowing a cushion for new spending, because the 1992 limit was nearly $30 billion more than the amount spent in 1990. But a late burst of appropriations pushed the 1991 spending close enough to the limit to eat up most of the cushion.
 
A Shocking Surprise
 In addition, Presidential appointees at several Cabinet departments said they had been told by Mr. Darman's staff that there had been "a miscalculation" or "a technical error" in computing the new limits for domestic spending.
"I have every reason to believe that this came as a surprise to Darman," said a senior official at one of the bigger Federal agencies. He spoke on condition of anonymity.
When White House and Congressional negotiators set the statutory limits on domestic spending for the next fiscal year, they envisioned small increases, in addition to increases to make up for inflation, in education, housing, law enforcement, environmental protection, scientific research and other national needs.
The chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee, Robert C. Byrd, Democrat of West Virginia, said at the time that domestic spending programs, which he called the "little runt pig" of the budget, had been starved for 10 years and would now get their "fair share" of Federal funds.
The budget bill signed by Mr. Bush on Nov. 5 established new budget procedures, including separate limits on "discretionary spending" for domestic, military and international programs. There is no evidence of a similar problem of miscalculations for military and international programs.
Congress sets the level of discretionary spending by passing appropriation bills each year. Discretionary spending differs from spending on benefits like Social Security, paid automatically to people who are eligible.
In his memorandum to the heads of Federal departments and agencies, Mr. Darman said he had "received and reviewed all agencies' budget requests for domestic discretionary programs" in the next fiscal year. "Unfortunately," he said, "the total requested for fiscal year '92 exceeds the legally binding cap by over $20 billion," or more than 10 percent.
"The excessive agency requests (in aggregate) would seem to have resulted" from "near-universal expectations that somehow cuts in someone else's area would be used as offsets" against increases in programs cherished by each Cabinet Secretary, Mr. Darman wrote.
Officials at the Office of Management and Budget and the Congressional Budget Office said Congress had already approved policy changes that would push Federal domestic spending above the new ceiling.
 
'A Big Windfall'
 A White House official said the 1992 budget would be tighter than Mr. Darman and Mr. Byrd initially assumed, in part because Congress approved "a big windfall" in domestic spending for the 1991 fiscal year just before adjourning.
As a result, he said, there will be substantial increases built into the budget for 1992, and those increases will eat up virtually all the funds available under the spending limit for domestic programs. The spending levels approved by Congress in one year are used as a starting point in preparing and analyzing budget requests for the next year.
"There was a one-year orgy, and now the chickens are coming home to roost," a White House official said, noting the increases in 1991 appropriations for many domestic programs.
Congress provided $182 billion in the 1991 appropriations bill for the Departments of Labor, Education, and Health and Human Services, up 14 percent from 1990. Spending for Federal highway projects will be allowed to rise more than 18 percent, to $14.5 billion in 1991. Congress approved a 9 percent increase in appropriations for energy and water projects, to $20 billion in 1991.
As a result of such increases in the current fiscal year, the White House and Congress will have little opportunity to spend money in creative new ways next year. They are already near the 1992 spending limits for domestic programs.
"We thought we would be in the land of milk and honey, with plenty of money to spread around in fiscal 1992," said the budget officer of a Cabinet department with many popular domestic programs. "But there was evidently a miscalculation of the spending caps. When the Administration and Congress were discussing those limits for 1992, they didn't know exactly what the 1991 appropriations would be."
Mr. Darman warned Cabinet officers to get ready for a new climate of fiscal austerity. The President's 1992 budget, which is to be submitted to Congress in two months, "will have to be far below agency requests, in aggregate," he said in his memorandum. "We must obey the legal limits on domestic discretionary spending."
Under the new budget law, there would be automatic across-the-board cuts in scores of domestic programs if the spending levels approved by Congress exceeded the statutory limit for domestic discretionary programs.

HEADLINE: State Arts Cutbacks Leave Trail of Inequity Among Applicants

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN

 BODY:
In October, the Metropolitan Museum of Art received a check for $618,000 authorized by the New York State Council on the Arts to cover general operating expenses.
A few days later, the Museum of Modern Art was notified that its State Arts Council grant of $584,240 had been suspended by the state's emergency deficit-reduction plan. 
 Such inequities are now commonplace among state arts organizations as a result of cutbacks ordered by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.
The Governor's package of proposed budget cuts -- a plan to reduce spending in order to help resolve the expected deficit in fiscal 1990-91 -- is expected to be acted on by the State Legislature next week before lawmakers adjourn for the holiday, even though the plan is now stalled by legislative wrangling in Albany.
 
A $1 Billion Cut
 In October, Mr. Cuomo proposed a plan to cut $1 billion from the state budget, and simultaneously ordered the suspension of a wide range of expenditures including grants to 567 arts groups.
While some institutions were staggered by the suspension, others were left unscathed, because the State Arts Council goes through five grants cycles each year. For convenience in processing, the 5,000 to 6,000 applications received annually are arbitrarily assigned for consideration to council meetings in February, June, August, October and December, and grants are dispensed five times a year.
The Governor's order became effective Oct. 30, so all groups in the summer cycle -- which included all of the local arts councils throughout the state, as well as the Metropolitan Museum and other institutions -- received their checks.
Those in the winter cycle, including the Modern, also received letters announcing their grants. But just before they were to receive their contracts, they got a second letter from the State Arts Council, dated Nov. 15, informing them that their grants had been suspended and might be permanently reduced.
 
Fewer Private Donations
 The suspension and potential cuts come at a particularly onerous time, many arts administrators have pointed out. Declining corporate profits and the threat of a recession have significantly reduced support for their institutions from the private sector.
The Arts Council remains hopeful that cuts will not be as deep as they appear to be. The Governor's order in October suspended $9.8 million in grants, but he has recommended to the Legislature that cuts in the Arts Council budget be held to $3.6 million.
"The arts groups will definitely get something back," said Tim Mulligan, a spokesman for the State Arts Council, "but everybody's going to have to take the medicine."
"We are hoping the Legislature will approve the Governor's package next week," said Diane M. Martuscello, the executive director of the Alliance of New York State Arts Councils, the central lobbying organization for state arts groups. "If it falls over to January, then we would be in the position of competing with ourselves, because January is when we try to talk to legislators about the 1991 budget. It would be like trying to read two chapters of a book at once."
"Compared to the cuts for mental health and education, the arts are not doing that badly," Ms. Martuscello said. "But arts organizations have no fat in their budgets. Many upstate organizations are not able to pay health benefits for their staff. So when you run like that, any cut hurts."
 
Across the Board
 The proposed cuts have gone out helter-skelter across the arts, striking the well-endowed and poor alike. Among the potential losers are The New York Shakespeare Festival ($308,500), the Roundabout Theater ($96,000), the American Spanish Dance Theater of Manhattan ($4,700) and the Albany Institute of History and Art ($37,000).
Hardest hit of all, thus far, is the Saratoga County Historical Society in Ballston Spa, N.Y., which has notified three of its four full-time staff members that they will be laid off by January because the organization's $56,400 in grants have been suspended. "The existence of the organization is threatened," said David Mitchell, director of the society.
The position of some arts groups has been made especially difficult because they signed contracts with performers after receiving the grant announcements. For example, Julianne Ramos, the executive director of the Rockland Center for the Arts in West Nyack, N.Y., said she must honor about $26,000 in contracts with performers signed just before she learned that her application for a $20,000 grant had been suspended.
"We have to replace whatever money we don't get from the state," Ms. Ramos said. "That's extremely difficult to do in the middle of the season. Everything has already been printed for those programs, so it would be difficult if not impossible to give any new sponsor proper credit."
She said she had "absolutely cleaned out" the center's bank account and could not rule out layoffs.

HEADLINE: Subtract Missiles, Add Food

 BODY:
It's within President Bush's grasp to build a foundation for friendly relations with Moscow for years. But first he must complete two major pieces of unfinished business when he meets Mikhail Gorbachev in Moscow next month.
 One is an agreement reducing nuclear arsenals by a third. The other is emergency food aid for the Soviet people. Both items will be on Secretary of State James Baker's agenda when he meets with the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard Shevardnadze, in Houston next week. 
 An arms accord will surely cause rejoicing in Washington and Moscow. But the reduction won't mean as much for anxious Soviet citizens preoccupied with their inability to get food. Emergency aid won't solve Moscow's shortages. But it will help prevent panic and buy time to reform the economy. It will show that Mr. Gorbachev can deliver and that Americans care. That could be as important as any cut in nuclear arms.
 Three small but sticky issues have to be resolved before the two sides can sign a strategic arms reduction treaty. One is the SS-18, a Soviet heavy missile that can be armed with 10 warheads and may have the accuracy to destroy U.S. missiles in their silos. The Soviets have agreed to cut the number of SS-18's in half, to 154.
 But critics of the treaty want the Soviets to agree not to upgrade the remaining SS-18's, or eliminate them altogether. The critics are too late; the Soviets have already fielded a new, more accurate version of the SS-18. But as soon as this treaty is signed, the two sides can move to negotiate further cuts.
bombers, has an obvious solution to anyone with a head for simple arithmetic. The Soviets are willing to limit their force to 600; the U.S. wants it reduced to 400. (Hint: Try 500.)
 The third issue seems well on the way to sensible resolution. Washington wants nothing to interfere with future sales of nuclear arms and technology to its allies. Moscow fears that more such deals will allow the U.S. to circumvent treaty limits. For now, Washington and Moscow seem prepared to agree to disagree on the issue.
 If an arms accord is one reassuring step Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev can take toward better relations, another would be a prompt decision by Washington to send emergency aid.
 Mr. Bush seems prepared to ship pharmaceuticals. But he seems strangely stubborn about food aid. America was willing to sell millions of tons of grain to the Soviet Union in Leonid Brezhnev's time. Why not give some now to the Soviet people of the Gorbachev era?
 Sure, Soviet farms produce enough to feed the Soviet population, though it doesn't always get to market. Sure, Mr. Bush is right to insist on reforms. And sure, fears of famine are exaggerated. But there are real shortages in some cities, and, a New York Times survey reports today, they are worsening. Suppliers, anticipating higher prices, withhold goods. Local authorities, expecting shortages, do too. Panicky shoppers, seeing little on the shelves, grab all they can.
 The certain knowledge that supplies are on the way could calm the hoarders and get the Soviet people through the winter.

HEADLINE: Lessons Unlearned

 BODY:
To The Living Section:
My husband and I and thousands like us could be called "coppies" -- caring older people -- and we have mixed emotions about the feelings and attitudes of the big-spending yuppies now affected by the recession. 
 For the past 60 years, our lives have been influenced by a serious Depression, disrupted by a long war, buffeted by two other wars, shaken by a change in morals and standards and disturbed by the ceaseless and pernicious materialism and selfishness touted by the media and advertising.
Through it all, we worked very hard, saved as much as we could and paid our way, step by step. We took care of our parents, sent our children to college, lived through strikes, layoffs, recessions. We paid our taxes, without benefit of tax shelters, contributed to good causes and did without when we had to. Many of us, because of our thrift, were also there to help our children when they needed us. And we never cried, "Foul!"
We knew that whatever goes up comes down, that one should live within one's means, that all of us have a responsibility for those less fortunate than ourselves, that there is no free lunch.
For most of us, our prudent ways mean that between savings, Social Security and small pensions, we are not a burden on our children. We even can help them weather this economic storm. But please, no tears for those who mocked our values. It is time to treat us with honor and respect and maybe to learn something from our life experiences.
 
NAOMI ZIEPH KATCHER
New York, N.Y.

HEADLINE: Two Different Worlds

 BODY:
To The Living Section:
Regarding your feature on fallen yuppies ["Young, Successful but Between Jobs," Nov. 7] and the wave of prosperity they rode on during the high-rolling 80's, I can only ask: Were we living the same 80's? 
 Where did you find these people?
I am of the same age and of a parallel work history as many of the people you profiled, having graduated from college in 1982 and having been employed in several sectors of the economy that performed well during the 80's, including the insurance industry and Wall Street. I can assure you, times have never been high-rolling.
When we left school, most of us made between $12,000 and $18,000 a year. Most of us, and all of the women I know, had difficulty passing this entry-level threshold.
The reasons: in the early 80's the last major recession was on, and jobs were very hard to come by. Most of us were forced to take low-paying positions, not very often in the fields of our choice. In the mid-1980's when the so-called boom came, it's true that corporate America was doing well. On paper. Stock prices and earnings were soaring. How did the companies achieve this? Largely through streamlining, belt-tightening, mergers and acquisitions. This translated into budget-cutting and salary restrictions.
When it came time for raises and promotions, corporate policies were always cited. Over and over again, I heard the same story: that I should have been there 5 or 10 years ago, when annual raises were 9 to 12 percent and promotions for the deserving were routine.
Over the course of the 80's, such policies translated not only into frozen paychecks but an overall sense of hopelessness and depression, a perception of a lack of opportunities. What I saw were people delaying marriage, reluctantly living with their parents until the age of 28 or 30 in order to save a down payment for a co-op, single people of 32 sharing their one-bedroom apartments with strangers and enduring the discomforts of roommate living, something they thought they'd leave behind soon after their college days.
The only people I know who had lavish weddings or managed to save money for a house or a co-op while paying rent were those whose parents were liberally supplementing their incomes, just as they had relieved them of the burden of paying for their educations. This is not the case for most working people my age.
Perhaps the secret ingredient in the downfall of the yuppies you profiled is the parent factor. Perhaps the money pipeline from home, the executive-fathers who are finally losing their jobs in the current fallout, are the real reason for the drastic life-style changes you highlighted.
For the rest of us, adolescence has long been over.
 
CHRISTINA GOMBAR
New York, N.Y.

HEADLINE: WASHINGTON AT WORK;
Snubbed, Hamstrung, but Ever So Diplomatic: He's Castro's Invisible Man

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4

 BODY:
Jose Antonio Arbesu is Fidel's man in Washington.
In a capital where politics and society mix as easily as wine spritzers, Mr. Arbesu, the Chief of the Cuban Interests Section, is so discreet he is the invisible diplomat. He will not identify his friends, nor the members of Congress and academics he meets. To do so, he said, would violate their confidence. He won't give out the address of his upscale Chevy Chase, Md., home because, as he put it, "some citizens of the neighborhood might be angered by my presence." 
 "Fortunately nobody recognizes me," the representative of President Castro said, pursing his lips into a self-contented grin. "I am a nonperson. I am the man who never was."
This invisibility follows him everywhere. Here he is, at the height of his career and professional powers, and he has no diplomacy to do. The United States is waiting for the successor to President Castro before the two nations start talking. "Sometimes I wonder what he does with his time," said one of the few Administration official who has met with Mr. Arbesu. Only middle-level officials meet with him and then only occasionally and on narrow consular and migration matters.
 
Some Unwanted Advice
 To make matters worse, wherever he goes, Mr. Arbesu said, Americans tell him what Cuba ought to be doing. "Everyone wants to give me advice," he said. "People say at parties and meetings, even in my own house, 'Why don't you do what they are doing in the Soviet Union?' One thing is to disagree, another is to patronize."
"When people ask me, 'Has socialism functioned well?' I ask them, 'Has capitalism functioned well?' "
Mr. Arbesu takes the indignities in stride. He predicts that despite growing shortages, rationing and decreased Soviet economic and political support, the Cuban revolution will survive after one or two difficult years.
"The fact that the cold war is over does not mean it has ended for everybody," he said. "It has not ended for us." His low standing in Washington, he added, is connected to the United States obsession with Cuba, which he said only a person trained as a historian or as a psychiatrist could explain.
The 50-year-old son of a middle-class Havana lawyer, Mr. Arbesu is a graceful and intelligent man who knows how to disarm with a professorial style, a kindly smile and a dry wit. "I came prepared for what I couldn't do," he said matter of factly, sitting in a parlor of his mission decorated with French Empire style furniture, ruffled curtains and portraits of Mr. Castro posing with champion boxers and a women's basketball team.
 
A Cloak Over the Past
 Before coming to Washington, he was the second-ranking official in the Americas Department in Havana, the Cuban Communist Party's bureau that handled relations with Latin American guerrilla groups and Communist parties. While he served there, the department clandestinely armed rebels throughout much of Central America and in Colombia and Chile, and he himself reportedly traveled to Panama in 1988 to advise Gen. ManuelAntonio Noriega on ways to resist United States efforts to depose him.
Mr. Arbesu, who has also represented his country in Indonesia, Egypt and Algeria, in secret talks with the Carter Administration, and in negotiations that brought about the independence of Namibia, won't comment on charges of Americas Department arms trafficking. He says little more about his current diplomatic activities, except to say that he is busy from 8:30 A.M. until well into the night nearly every day, dispelling the "misinformation" about his country prevailing in Washington in meetings with journalists and people from universities and other institutions that mold opinion here. "I'll explain my country's positions to whoever will listen to me," he said.
Few influential people do. Bush Administration officials almost totally snub him and members of Congress who met with him in efforts to improve relations when he first arrived in May 1989 are concentrating on more pressing international issues. Most on Capitol Hill are waiting for the Cuban regime to follow Eastern Europe's example and collapse.
"The highest level official who receives me here is a Deputy Assistant Secretary of State," Mr. Arbesu said, referring to Michael G. Kozak. "I never get access to higher levels."
"That's the way it is," he said, noting that United States diplomats in Havana can speak to anyone they like, including Mr. Castro, but adding, "I don't take it personally."
(A rare moment came on Nov. 25 when Under Secretary of State Robert M. Kimmitt called him in to consult on the Persian Gulf crisis and the position Cuba would take on the Iraq resolution as a member of the United Nations Security Council. Neither Cuban nor United States officials would comment on the meeting except to say bilateral matters were not discussed.)
 
Balanced, Low Key, Patient
 Wayne Smith, a former Chief of the United States Interests Section in Havana who sees Mr. Arbesu on occasion, said the Cuban diplomat "came at the worst possible time."
"Still," Mr. Smith said, "he's always been very balanced, very low key and very patient."
According to Mr. Arbusu, relations between Cuba and the United States are even worse under the Bush Administration than they were under President Reagan, even though Cuba has gone a long way to improve relations by withdrawing most of its military forces from Angola and Ethiopia. He said Washington always "moves back the goal posts."
"They believe the problems between our countries were invented by a group of people in 1959 in Cuba, but the problems began much much before that," he said. "It used to be that the concern was that Cuba was a threat to the security of the United States because of its relationship with the Soviet Union. But the relationship between the United States and the Soviet Union has changed tremendously in the last couple of years."
Despite proclamations that the cold war has ended, the Bush Administration has refused to lift the 30-year-old economic embargo or restrictions on Americans who wish to travel to Cuba on vacation. Indeed, Mr. Bush has stepped up the pressure by opening Television Marti, a network intended to bring anti-Castro news and public affairs programming into Cuban homes.
 
A Prescription for the U.S.
 Mr. Arbesu says the United States needs to end transmissions of Radio Marti and Television Marti, drop the economic embargo, and eventually withdraw from its naval base at Guantanamo Bay before relations can become fully normal. But he says those basic issues are never fully addressed in his irregular discussions with State Department officials.
Even the bronze plaque outside the gate of the Interests Section, the Cuban Embassy in Batista's day, is a time warp.
Like his official vita, it says that he and his mission are attached to the embassy of the Czechslovak Socialist Republic. Not only is Czechslovakia not socialist anymore, but Prague has cut its lines of credit to its former Soviet bloc ally and is now a leader in the international campaign to censure Cuba for its poor human rights record.
Mr. Arbesu shrugged, saying that because the United States and Cuba did not have formal relations his embassy was still technically attached to the Czechoslovak Embassy, just as the United States Interests Section in Havana is technically attached to the Swiss Embassy.
 
'You Learn to Be Patient
 Despite the limitations of his diplomatic role here, Mr. Arbesu said he liked his job. "It's a challenge, and anything that is a challenge I like. After working on the United States for 17 years, you learn to be patient. If not, I better change my work."
Still, life could be easier. Mr. Arbesu said he misses his three grown children, two by his first wife, whom he divorced, and one by his current wife, Julia, who works in the Interests Section as a personal aide. All three children live in Cuba and reunions are infrequent. He and Julia find Washington's violence and poverty shocking, he said, and he complained a bit about the State Department rules that mean he must report when and where he travels far outside Washington's metropolitan area (while acknowledging that United States diplomats in Cuba have to undergo similar inconveniences).
But Mr. Arbesu said that he and his wife appreciated Washington's Southern charm, beautiful parks and museums, and the manageable traffic, which he noted beats the driving conditions in Havana.
"I have been interested in American culture since I was four years old, when I became acquainted with Mickey Mouse and Donald Duck," he said, displaying the affinity for things American typical of many Cubans' love-hate relation with this country. "And of course, there were the movies -- the westerns, the adventure films and the musicals. And the literature, of course -- Hemingway most of all."
Mr. Arbesu, who is an accomplished deep-sea angler, said his favorite literary character was Santiago, the fisherman hero in Ernest Hemingway's novella "The Old Man and the Sea."
"He caught the biggest marlin in the world, only to see it eaten by the sharks," he said. "All Hemingway's characters are losers in one way or another. But these are people who fight. I hope I will be a winner. At least I am not a marlin."
 
Jose Antonio Arbesu Fraga
 
Born: June 21, 1940
 
Hometown: Havana
 
Education: Master's degree in political science, University of Havana.
 
Career Highlights: 1960, joined the Cuban Foreign Ministry; 1960-61, attache to the Cuban Embassy in Indonesia; 1961-64, Department Chief and Assistant Director for North Africa and Middle East, Cuban Foreign Ministry; 1964-66, counselor to the Cuban Embassy in the United Arab Republic (the short-lived merger of Egypt and Syria); 1967-70, counselor to the Cuban Embassy in Algeria; since 1975 has held senior positions in the Americas Department of the Cuban Communist Party Central Committee; 1989, appointed Chief of the Cuban Interests Section in the United States with the rank of counselor.
 
Interests: Deep-sea fishing; reading history and fiction.

HEADLINE: MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Saatchi Says Hard Times Will Stay With It a While

BYLINE: By Steven Prokesch

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
FOR Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C., the future looks even bleaker than the recent past.
The advertising giant yesterday reported a loss for the year ended Sept. 30 that was much greater than the loss in the previous year. And Saatchi executives stunned the financial community with an unusually grim forecast for next year. 
 Neil R. Blackley, an analyst at James Capel & Company in London, said the executives told analysts at a meeting yesterday that they expected their clients in the United States to cut their advertising spending by 8 to 10 percent next year. As a result, the executives expect Saatchi's American ad billings to be flat next year, excluding the operations of McCaffrey & McCall, an agency that Saatchi is in the process of selling to McCaffrey's management.
Saatchi's flagship advertising agencies are Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Worldwide and Backer Spielvogel Bates Worldwide.
Mr. Blackley said Saatchi expected ad spending by clients in Britain and Australia to be flat or slightly down in 1991 and to be up about 6 percent on the European Continent.
The forecast for American operations was much worse than many analysts' predictions. Other big ad agencies have been predicting advertising spending would be up 4 or 5 percent in the United States next year.
"They are talking very, very bearishly indeed," Mr. Blackley said of the Saatchi executives. "The outlook is a lot worse than previously thought."
Mr. Blackley has slashed his forecast for Saatchi's pretax earnings in the 15 months ended Dec. 31, 1991, to 24 million, or $46.1 million, from 50 million, or $96.1 million.
The major clients of Saatchi & Saatchi's agencies include Johnson & Johnson, Mars, Procter & Gamble, Metropolitan Life, British Airways, Visa International and Toyota's American operations.
Saatchi said yesterday that in the year that ended Sept. 30, it had a loss of 98.2 million, or $184 million, after taxes, extraordinary items and preferred dividends. That compared with a loss of 58.5 million the previous year.
Pretax earnings before extraordinary items were 35.8 million, or $67.1 million, on revenues of 808.1 million, or $1.51 billion. That was down 41.6 percent from the 61.3 million earned the previous year on revenues of 973.5 million, but it was in line with analysts' expectations.
The company said it expected its operating margins, or pretax profits as a percent of revenues, to sink below 7 percent next year from 8.1 percent. "That's worse than in the recession in the early 1980's," Mr. Blackley said.
On the London Stock Exchange, the price of Saatchi's shares fell 8 percent, losing 3 pence, or 5.8 cents, to close at 34 pence, or 65.4 cents. Another advertising giant, the WPP Group, which is the world's largest marketing-services company, saw its shares fall yesterday by 3 pence, to 94 pence, or $1.807. The stock of heavily indebted WPP has tumbled recently amid worries about its ability to weather the industry's tough times.
In the last year, Saatchi & Saatchi has sold most of its consulting operations, and write-offs related to that were the cause of much of the loss reported yesterday. It has also trimmed 500 jobs, and executives said more cuts might be made. Saatchi also said yesterday that dividend payments, which were suspended in June, would not be restored now.
"We are continuing to reduce our costs," Maurice Saatchi, the company's chairman, said in a statement. "Our cost-control procedures should additionally enable us to react more quickly to changes in revenue expectations, which is particularly important in current economic conditions." He added that "1991 will be a difficult year for the group."
Saatchi, which had previously been criticized for not having good cost controls, recruited Robert Louis-Dreyfus last year to be its chief executive and address the problem. Mr. Louis-Dreyfus, who had been head of IMS International Inc., the American market-research company, brought along Charles Scott, an associate from IMS, to be the chief financial officer at Saatchi.
Since March, Mr. Scott has reduced Saatchi's short-term debt by 29.6 percent, to 195 million, or $374.9 million at today's exchange rate. He is in the process of trying to refinance 211 million, or $405.6 million, in convertible bonds due July 1993.
There have been rumors in the trade press that the company has been negotiating with Electra, a British venture capital firm, about injecting equity into the company. Saatchi would neither confirm nor deny those rumors yesterday.
But Mr. Saatchi said in the statement that the company intended "to make proposals to the group's bankers and shareholders to strengthen the balance sheet and to insure that the business is adequately and appropriately financed.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Next year "will be a difficult year for the group," said Maurice Saatchi, the chairman of Saatchi & Saatchi. (Ashley Ashwood/Financial Times)

HEADLINE: Factory Orders Up by 2.8% On Transportation Strength

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5

 BODY:
Factory orders for manufactured goods bounced up 2.8 percent in October, the Government reported today, but analysts attributed the jump mostly to the transportation sector and the higher cost of oil.
"The October numbers are about as good as the factory orders are going to look for a while," said Robert Brusca, an economist at the Nikko Securities Company International in New York. He, like many analysts, contends the economy is in a recession. 
 Cynthia Latta, an economist with DRI-McGraw-Hill in Lexington, Mass., said: "The strength was mostly in aircraft and in nondurable price increases. I don't see any reason to become particularly hopeful on the basis of this report."
 
Revising the Numbers
 Excluding transportation, October orders were up just nine-tenths of 1 percent.
The Commerce Department said orders for both durable and nondurable goods totaled a seasonally adjusted $250.7 billion after a revised decline of two-tenths of 1 percent the previous month. The revision showed September orders even weaker than the gain of one-tenth of 1 percent initially reported.
Transportation orders jumped 14.8 percent, to $37.9 billion, reflecting gains in both the aircraft and automobile industries. But aircraft orders tend to be volatile, and analysts noted that car production was falling at the end of November.
Factory orders are a significant barometer of manufacturing. A decrease may indicate a slump in that sector and future job layoffs.
Durable goods, products like autos that are expected to last more than three years, were up 3.9 percent, to $129.8 billion, after dropping 1.6 percent in September and nine-tenths of 1 percent in August.
 
 Report Called 'Bleak'
 But Mr. Brusca said the October total was below the $131.7 billion level reached last December. "The orders situation is really pretty bleak," he said.
The National Association of Purchasing Management said on Monday that its index of new manufacturing orders dropped to 39.4 percent in November, the lowest since a 38.1 percent reading in May 1982 during the last recession.
The association said that in its survey of purchasing managers 43 percent reported their companies had fewer new orders in November, 18 percent said their orders increased and 39 percent said they were unchanged from October.

HEADLINE: STANDOFF IN THE GULF;
SAUDIS PROMISING CAIRO $1.5 BILLION

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAIRO, Dec. 5

 BODY:
Saudi Arabia promised Egypt $1.5 billion to offset losses from the Persian Gulf crisis today as Cairo prepared to commit more troops and armor to join the American-led military buildup confronting Iraqi troops occupying Kuwait.
The Egyptian troops, forming an armored division equipped with tanks supplied by the United States, will be deployed alongside other Arab forces, including other Egyptians and Syrians, on the western flank of the buildup along Saudi Arabia's border with Kuwait, diplomats said. 
 Egypt, a leading Arab opponent of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2, has already sent several thousand commandos and a mechanized division to the gulf. But Egyptian officials have said the crisis will cost it between $4.5 billion and $10 billion.
After two days of discussions here with Egyptian and Syrian officials, the visiting Saudi Foreign Minister, Prince Saud al-Faisal, said his country would give Egypt $1 billion in grants and $500 million to finance development projects.
 
Increasing Oil Production
 The announcement reflected the way the Saudis are diverting some of its gains from increased oil production and prices to bankroll America's Arab allies against Iraq. Saudi Arabia has increased oil production to meet the shortfall in world markets caused by the invasion of Kuwait, while the crisis has driven up prices. It has thus increased its oil revenues by several billion dollars a year, according to Egyptian estimates.
Saudi Arabia is reported by diplomats in Damascus to have given "substantial" aid, possibly $1 billion, to Syria in return for the Syrian commitment of an armored division of 15,000 men and 300 tanks to the anti-Iraq buildup.
The latest announcement of Saudi aid to Egypt coincides, diplomats said, with the final stage of preparations for the deployment of an armored division that will reinforce Cairo's position as the biggest Arab contributor to the massing of forces in Saudi Arabia.
Since concluding its peace treaty with Israel in 1979, Egypt has received billions of dollars worth of American military aid, and large amounts of heavy military equipment, including tanks and armored personnel carriers. Diplomats who spoke on condition of anonymity said the Egyptian armored division would leave soon for Saudi Arabia.
 
Economic Losses for Cairo
 Cairo's close association with the policy aims of both the United States and the so-called moderate Arab camp it leads has brought economic windfalls to offset the country's losses both from its profound economic malaise and from the gulf crisis.
According to official estimates, Egypt's revenues from tourism are down 65 percent, revenues from Suez Canal traffic are down 20 percent, and remittances from one million Egyptian workers in Iraq and Kuwait are down by half. The combined loss of revenue is estimated at $4.5 billion.

HEADLINE: Curb Sought On Investing

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Banks, savings and loan associations and credit unions could effectively be barred from investing in certain mortgage-backed securities considered high risk by Federal regulators, according to a draft proposal obtained yesterday.
The move, which has been expected for some months, could force the banks, savings and loans and credit unions either to sell the securities or to price them at the present market value, which could take a big bite out of their balance sheets. 
 A board of Federal regulators -- the Federal Financial Institutions Examination Council -- is to meet tomorrow to consider adopting the proposed policy. The council consists of the Federal Reserve, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, Office of Thrift Supervision, Comptroller of the Currency and National Credit Union Administration.
Prices of some of the securities, held by banks and savings institutions for investment, have already been under pressure because of fears of just such restrictions.
According to the draft proposal, stripped mortgage-backed securities and certain types of collateralized mortgage obligation installments "are not suitable investments for the vast majority of depository institutions."
In a stripped security, principal and interest payments are divided into different securities. Considered very volatile, a stripped security moves sharply higher or lower as interest rates and the economy change.
A collateralized mortgage obligation is a bond that represents a bundle of home mortgages. The types of C.M.O.'s considered high-risk include those with a higher share of prepayment or interest rate risk than the underlying mortgages, the draft said.
