HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Trading in Dollar Is Mixed On Gulf and Economic News

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar turned in a mixed performance yesterday as foreign exchange traders watched the Middle East situation and the United States economy.
"The markets are still very nervous about peace, war, peace, war," and the dollar has fluctuated accordingly, said Robert Ryan, corporate foreign exchange manager with the Bank of New York Company.
 
Gains in Europe
 The dollar advanced against most major currrencies in Europe after Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d reiterated demands for Iraq's withdrawal from Kuwait. 
 Mr. Baker told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee that the United States would strike "suddenly, massively and decisively" if military force was needed to remove Iraqi troops from Kuwait.
The dollar has gained in recent weeks amid signs that Middle East tensions were increasing. But it has also fallen as those tensions seemed to ease or as the markets had second thoughts about the seriousness of the situation.
The dollar generally advances during international turmoil because investors view it as a safe currency. But the dollar was held down yesterday by the faltering United States economy and the belief that American interest rates would fall.
A Federal Reserve survey released yesterday showed the economy in all regions of the United States was either declining or growing sluggishly at the end of November.
Traders believe the Fed will be forced to lower interest rates. That would be a negative for the dollar, which like all currencies is supported by higher rates.
In New York trading, the dollar advanced against the British pound and the Japanese yen.
Sterling fell to $1.9260 in New York, from $1.92925 late Tuesday. In earlier London trading, the pound fell to $1.9225, from $1.9350.The pound is also facing the prospects of lower interest rates.
The dollar rose to 133.63 yen in New York, from 133.30 late Tuesday. In Tokyo overnight, the dollar fell 0.93 yen, to 133.42, and it was quoted later in London at a higher rate of 133.95 yen.
Japan, which imports nearly all its oil, would be particularly vulnerable should war break out in the Middle East.
The dollar fell, however, against the German currency, closing at 1.49925 marks, from 1.5030 late Tuesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's prices, included: 1.2795 Swiss francs, down from 1.2825; 5.0770 French francs, down from 5.0825; 1,127.685 Italian lire, down from 1,129.25, and 1.16295 Canadian dollars, down from 1.16325.

HEADLINE: STANDOFF IN THE GULF;
Political Cost of Victory Questioned

 BODY:
The Bush Administration's decision to open talks with Baghdad follows a chorus of warnings about the potentially high political cost of a military victory over Iraq.
In recent weeks, some who had privately counseled the Administration against precipitous military action -- military and Middle East analysts, Foreign Service officers in the field and some Arab offiicials -- have expressed their concerns publicly. 
 There are few who doubt that if there is war in the Persian Gulf, the United States and its allies can "turn Baghdad into a parking lot," as an American diplomat in the Middle East recently put it. But many analysts are increasingly concerned about the probable effect of such a victory on longer-term American interests in the region.
William Crowe, a former Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, warned last week that "many Arabs would deeply resent a campaign that would necessarily kill large numbers of their Muslim brothers and force them to choose sides between Arab nations and the West."
 
Losing 'Even if We Win'
 "Even if we win," he concluded in testimony before a Senate committee, "we lose ground in the Arab world and generally injure our ability to deal in the future with the labyrinth of the Middle East."
His words have been echoed in many Arab capitals, even in Cairo, whose Government supports American policy and has sent 20,000 troops to join the multinational force in Saudi Arabia.
"Who can live with 100,000 Iraqi deaths in the Arab world?" asked Taseen Bashir, a former Egyptian official, articulating what other officials have said in private. "Of course, Saddam Hussein is a terrible man who did an unacceptable thing that must and will be reversed, probably through sanctions within 9 to 12 months. But what's the rush?"
Mr. Bashir said few Egyptians, irrespective of political orientation, "want a war in which Egyptians will kill Arabs with the Americans."
For Egypt, a war would mean Egyptians killing Egyptians, since some of the one million Egyptians living in Iraq are serving in the Iraqi armed forces. But Mr. Bashir and others argued that Egyptians would accept war if they were persuaded that diplomatic and economic sanctions had failed.
 
Feeling of Humiliation
 Another factor that would dilute the political value of an American military victory, Arab analysts maintain, is the Arab world's strong feeling of humiliation at the hands of the West. Nowhere is this more potent than in Algeria.
"We are a wounded people," said Sid Ahmed Ghozali, Algeria's Foreign Minister. "We lived under French domination for 130 years. Every 20 or 30 years or so, there was an uprising. When Algeria had only 10 million people, France had a million soldiers here. By the time we got our independence, one in six Algerians had died fighting."
"So how do you think Algerians will react to thousands of Iraqi deaths once again at the hands of the West, this time the Americans aided by the French and a few Arabs for window dressing?" he asked.
This attitude is shared in other Arab countries, especially those that have suffered defeats in wars with Israel, which is seen as America's proxy.
 
Damage to New Democracies
 A new Arab humiliation would not only promote political instability by strengthening extremist, anti-Western forces, many of them religious, but also jeopardize the nascent democratic movements in Jordan, Algeria, Yemen, and Tunisia, officials in those countries predicted in recent interviews.
The largely Palestinian majority in Jordan might rise up against the King they now claim to support, an official said. All agreed that a war would probably make the Palestinians, among the most Westernized of Arabs, even more deeply anti-American.
"You can flatten Iraq," said Mohammed Milhem, a Palestine Liberation Organization official in Amman, Jordan. "But no American plane will be safe in the sky, and you will need five bodyguards for every American in the Mideast."
Those who see war ultimately as the only means of prying Mr. Hussein out of Kuwait recalled that many of the same bleak predictions about the consequences of using force were made before the United States bombed Libya in 1986 in retaliation for terrorism. But other than the requisite condemnations from the Arab League and many Arab capitals, the raid had few adverse consequences for Washington.
But Arab critics of United States policy counter that Libya is not Iraq, and that Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the quixotic Libyan leader whom few Arabs fear or respect, is not Saddam Hussein. The bombing of Libya did not split the Arab world, but the gulf crisis has already divided the Arabs and shattered the Arab League. A war seen as premature or unnecessary would further polarize the Arab states.
Bernard Lewis, a leading Western scholar of Islam, stressed that limiting what he termed "psychic damage" to the Arabs should war come depended in part on changing the image of the impending conflict.
 
Iraqi Emigres Cited
 "Where is the Iraqi opposition, and why haven't the United States and its allies been more active in encouraging the one million Iraqi emigres to play a role?" Mr. Lewis asked.
He asserted that the political effect of a war would be quite different if the conflict was not seen as "America versus Iraq, but as Iraqis attempting to liberate their country by getting rid of Saddam Hussein."
A second way of diminishing the perception among Arabs that the crisis is a conflict between Iraq and the United States, he said, is to insist on maximum visibility for the Arabs allied with the United States. "And all talk of Americans staying on in the region should be avoided," Mr. Lewis said.

HEADLINE: STANDOFF IN THE GULF;
Turkish Leader Sees Chance To Avert War Against Iraq

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 5

 BODY:
President Turgut Ozal of Turkey said tonight that as a result of the United Nations Security Council resolution authorizing the use of force against Iraq, there was a "big chance" now of averting a Persian Gulf war.
Mr. Ozal, whose country was an early and vital participant in the embargo against neighboring Iraq, also argued that economic sanctions were working, at least to the extent that they may "soften" Baghdad's military capacity in the event of a war. 
 But he implied in an interview that he was not fully persuaded that sanctions alone would force President Saddam Hussein to withdraw his troops from Kuwait, and said the anti-Iraq coalition had to stand firm. Turkey, for its part, was ready to take any necessary steps to protect its borders, he said.
"I think if President Saddam Hussein has logic, even a little logic, he should pull out of Kuwait," Mr. Ozal said, speaking in English. But he added: "That does not mean there will be no war. The other side has to be very straight: there will be a war if he does not pull out of Kuwait."
 
Intense Public Debate
 What Turkey's own next steps against Iraq might be has been a subject of intense public debate, with Mr. Ozal standing squarely in the middle.
On Monday, he was reported by a leading newspaper to have told aides that Turkey should sent a symbolic military force to Saudi Arabia, and, if war does break out, allow the United States to use an important NATO air base in southern Turkey. Washington reportedly has encouraged new Turkish measures to apply additional pressure on Iraq.
A close associate of Mr. Ozal confirmed that the news article had accurately reflected the Turkish leader's basic thinking. In addition, a senior official said the Americans undoubtedly would be given access to the air base, known as Incirlik, and that the only question was whether it would be for limited logistical operations or full-fledged strikes against Iraq.
"Incirlik will be used: that is clear," the official said. "One must be a realist."
 
A Considerable Stir
 The news report, however, touched off a considerable press stir in Turkey, where many people say they have already done more than enough by shutting down Iraqi oil pipelines that run across southern Turkey, by enforcing the economic embargo and by bolstering troop strength on the border with Iraq.
Mr. Ozal has personally come under attack from domestic critics who charged him with exceeding his constitutional authority and with being overeager to increase Turkey's military role. The dispute took on a new dimension this week when the chief of the Turkish armed forces suddenly resigned in what appeared to be a multilayered protest that included unhappiness over the direction of the country's gulf policy.
In the interview tonight, Mr. Ozal took a very cautious stand. Insisting that his position had been misrepresented by the Turkish press, he said no decision had been reached about what Turkey might do next. He also asserted that the Government was not hampered by internal dissent, that he had acted so far within constitutional limits and that his country had made "a very substantial contribution" that should be appreciated by its coalition partners.
 
More Strength on Border
 "I think the Government has the possibility of sending troops, but as far as I know it is not decided," he said. But he continued: "I think also that no troops are going to be sent because what is the benefit if you send a small detachment?"
Instead, he argued that it made more sense to augment Turkey's military presence on its own border with Iraq. Turkish troop strength there has been increased in recent months by about 50 percent, to 100,000, but Mr. Ozal said it was not clear that this number would be further increased.
The Turks face serious choices in figuring out how involved they should become in the next phase of the crisis. On the one hand, it is axiomatic here that no good can come from an entanglement in Arab disputes. The military and Foreign Ministry bureaucracies have been particularly cautious, and some news commentators interpret the resignation of the armed forces chief as a warning from the entire army leadership against going too far.
But on the other hand, some officials worry that a peaceful solution could leave Mr. Hussein in power, and that would leave them with a next-door neighbor of proven danger. So while Turkey may not want to join a war, they argue, it might need someone else to fight a war to rid them of this menace.
"Let's suppose Saddam withdraws from Kuwait," one official said. "That's the worst scenario for us."
 
'Let Them Worry'
 "We have no problem with the Iraqi people," he added. "But we would not like to see Saddam come out of this with any benefits, or that he remain in power, or that he remain on this earth, to be blunt about it."
Mr. Ozal, however, argued in the interview that any future danger from Mr. Hussein would threaten the gulf oil states and industrialized nations even more than Turkey. "Let them worry, not only us," he said.
But he also said Turkey had a stake in any post-crisis settlement, and its main interest was that Iraq's borders remain intact.
"There should be no change in geography," he said. "There should be no separate state in any part of Iraq." This was an apparent reference to suggestions that had been raised that Kurdish zones in northern Iraq be turned into a separate state. Any creation of a Kurdish state would be strongly resisted by Turkey, which has a sizable Kurdish population of its own in the country's southeast.

HEADLINE: Change of Administrations Unsettles Hartford Appointees

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Dec. 5

 BODY:
For hundreds of men and women who shaped the 10-year administration of Gov. William A. O'Neill as commissioners, agency heads and executive assistants, the end of power that will come with his retirement next month is shaping up to be neither clean nor painless.
With Mr. O'Neill's long years in office ending on a pronounced sour note for the state's economy, the white-collar jobs in insurance and banking that might have beckoned these appointees in better times must now be sought out and sometimes fought over. 
 And with an unpredictable, independent governor-elect, Lowell P. Weicker Jr., taking office on a pledge to create a hybrid government of Republicans, Democrats and non-political experts chosen on merit alone, some people are not sure that the party is over.
Mr. Weicker, a former Republican, was forced under state law to gave up his party membership after his election last month as a third-party candidate. He has already appointed one Democrat, and a close O'Neill associate at that, William J. Cibes Jr., to be his budget director. He has said he might appoint more Democrats and reappoint some now in office.
 
So Many Unknowns
 The result is a recipe for anxiety: Do you stay in place, trying to look indispensable, and hope for reappointment? Do you leap for what jobs in industry can be had and thus get an edge? Or do you transfer to the Civil Service, and thus stay in government by abandoning the ladder of executive promotions that can lead to the top?
"I don't think anybody approaches this with great ease," said John E. Saunders, a deputy commissioner at the State Labor Department.
Mr. Saunders, a 45-year-old former director of the Hartford Urban League, is one of those who hopes to hang onto his job. He has sent his resume to Mr. Weicker's transition team. But like most remaining O'Neill officials, Mr. Saunders is keeping his options open, and his mouth closed about them.
"In more secure times, people would be more willing to talk about it," he said. But with so much economic and political uncertainty, "you do try and keep the options you've explored fairly close to the vest."
 Some officials have already abandoned ship. Mr. O'Neill's Commissioner of Economic Development, Stephen B. Heintz, left in October to become deputy director of an Eastern European democracy training group based in Prague. The Governor's press secretary, Jon Sandberg, left for a corporate public-relations job.
Others are said to be close to taking new jobs, but with so many unknowns about what Mr. Weicker may or may not do, few want to appear committed to leaving.
A spokeswoman for Mr. Weicker, Avice A. Meehan, said that an initial pool of "more than 100" appointments would be made over the next few months, but Mr. Weicker has declined to even talk about how many current O'Neill officials might be retained.
Over the four-year term, Ms. Meehan said, about 2,000 appointees are expected to be named to the state's various boards, commissions and departments. More than 1,200 resumes have been received since Mr. Weicker's election.
Part of the tone of Connecticut's change in government results from the fact that Mr. O'Neill made that many appointments and more in his two-and-a-half terms, and thus has thousands of people who linked their lives and careers in some way to his.
Sworn in as chief executive after Gov. Ella T. Grasso resigned in ill-health in 1980, Mr. O'Neill was elected in 1982, then re-elected in 1986. He decided this spring not to run again. As governor, he appointed or reappointed every sitting judge in the state. Since all judges serve eight-year terms, Mr. O'Neill's bench will linger long into the 1990's.
He was also credited -- after a series of scandals early in his administration -- with seeking out professionals for some appointments that in past administrations might have been awarded on the basis of loyalty. The Commissioner of Correction, for example, Larry R. Meachum, was hired after a nationwide search in 1987 to run the state's expanding prison system.
There is also simple longevity: The Democrats have controlled the governor's office for 36 of the last 40 years, including the 16 years since the election of Mrs. Grasso. By the time Mr. O'Neill leaves office, he will be the longest serving governor since Jonathan Trumbull 2d, who left office in 1809. The passing of Mr. O'Neill's generation of politicians is the end of a group of Democrats who rose to power in the 1950's and 1960's.
 
'A Great Deal of Uncertainty'
 For those caught between administrations and eras, there has been some help. Mr. O'Neill's chief of staff, David J. McQuade, has coordinated transfers into other branches of government for secretaries and clerks on the Governor's staff. The Department of Administrative Services conducted a series of "career transition" seminars aimed at improving appointees' job-search skills. But not everyone is eager to look like a job hunter.
"There's great uncertainty now as to who is going to go and who is going to stay, and some people are reluctant to declare that they may be in the job market," said J. Robert Tank, vice president of Lee Hecht Harrison Inc., a job placement firm that coordinated the seminars. "They haven't availed themselves of this help."
Even for those trying to transfer to the Civil Service, the confidence level is not high.
William K. Seymour, an executive assistant in the Department of Administrative Services, turned in his competitive examination to become a civil service press spokesman -- technically, a senior information-services officer -- on Nov. 9 and is still awaiting word. He said he had no guarantee that a decision would be made on the examination before the Department's Commissioner, Stephen J. Negri, leaves office.
 
Still Is Eager to Serve
 Another former appointee trying to make the transition, Matthew J. Broder, said his Civil Service examination would not even be submitted until this Friday. Mr. Broder, a former public affairs officer in the governor's office, transferred this spring to the Department of Economic Development as director of the international division on a temporary basis. Because of personnel department timetables, however, a Weicker appointee will undoubtedly make the final judgment on whether he gets to keep the job, Mr. Broder said.
As for Mr. O'Neill, a 60-year-old former tavern owner who sold the family bar several years ago, the Governor said he would be eager to serve in some appointed volunteer or advisory position, "if called upon" by Mr. Weicker, but that his years of elective office were behind him. Hobbies will mostly have to be developed. "I used to fish a little," Mr. O'Neill said.
Howard G. Rifkin, a soft-spoken lawyer who has worked for Mr. O'Neill since the first days of the administration, said he would probably land on his feet. But he said that two of the three job possibilities before him involve a cut in pay from the $81,000 he receives as legal counsel to the Governor, and none of them is a sure bet. He also recently turned 40.
"I get to have a mid-life crisis in a depressed economy," he said.

HEADLINE: Fed Survey Says Slump Has Spread

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5

 BODY:
Business activity "appears to have declined recently" in much of the country, according to a Federal Reserve survey released today. That is a marked erosion from mid-October, when most of the central bank's 12 districts were still reporting an expansion, albeit a slow one.
The new findings, based heavily on anecdotal information collected through Thanksgiving, were consistent with a wide array of statistics published in recent weeks that many regard as conclusively demonstrating the onset of a recession. Reports on industrial output, construction, employment and sales of cars and homes have all brought negative news. 
 At the same time, today's report, known as the beige book, did include spotty signs of strength, particularly for exports and agriculture. It was also reassuring in its finding that the sharp increases in oil prices since August were having only a minimal impact on inflation.
"None of the districts report significant wage pressures," said the survey, written this time by the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis. "Several districts report expectations of discounting by retailers this Chistmas season in the face of weak demand."
Subdued inflation, many analysts maintain, could enable the Fed's Open Market Committee to decide at its Dec. 17-18 meeting that it can afford to take further steps to ease monetary policy in an effort to counter the downturn. Some, in fact, say the Fed, which eased credit on Tuesday by cutting some bank-reserve requirements, could move again even sooner than midmonth, if the job figures to be released on Friday are sufficiently worrisome.
The expectation is that the unemployment rate, now standing at 5.7 percent, will approach 6 percent in the report for November.
"Business conditions are somewhat mixed in different parts of the country but on balance display a weaker pattern," today's survey said in summary. "In many of the Federal Reserve districts, economic activity appears to have declined recently, while it has remained sluggish or grown slowly in the rest."
 
Sales Are Sluggish
 Retail sales, it added, have fallen below year-earlier levels, after adjusting for inflation, in nearly all districts, and manufacturing conditions "have weakened in most."
Sales of durable goods, particularly automobiles, have been hard hit, though the Dallas district reported that auto sales were "rebounding" after several weak months and that department store sales were rising "mildly."
Even within individual districts the findings were not uniformly negative. In Philadelphia, for example, industrial activity continued to decline in November and the general outlook among manufacturers was "dim" but expectations about the severity of the downturn "appeared to be diminishing a bit," the Fed reported. Some companies, in fact, indicated that business was improving last month "in contrast to early fall when there were virtually no manufacturers experiencing improvement."
 
 Mixed Report on New York
 Conditions in the New York district were described as "soft to mixed" with merchants "rather pessimistic" about holiday sales. But a pickup in office leasing in Manhattan brought down the primary vacancy rate.
Most respondents in the Cleveland district, where manufacturing has been relatively strong, said their region was not currently in recession, and one supplier to the heavy-duty truck industry said conditions have improved in recent months.
Exports, aided by the weak dollar, were particularly robust in the Richmond district, with timber from West Virginia a standout.
Business activity in the San Francisco district was described as sluggish, with the Pacific Northwest posting relatively strong retail trade.

HEADLINE: U.S. Acts to Assure Safety of Alaska Pipeline

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ANCHORAGE, Dec. 5

 BODY:
Concerned about continuing discoveries of corrosion problems along the Alaska pipeline, the United States Department of Transportation has formed an umbrella group of state and Federal regulators to review and coordinate pipeline safety efforts and "avoid potential disaster," a department statement said Tuesday.
The department realized such a step was needed after the disastrous Exxon Valdez oil spill in March 1989, said Russell A. Rockwell, a Transportaion Department spokesman. The timing of the announcement was not related to recent allegations of shoddy inspections of the pipeline or the discovery last month of a leaky seal that was to keep moisture off the pipeline surface, Mr. Rockwell said. But, he added, "The project will focus on corrosion that has been found on the Trans-Alaska system."
 
Focus to Be Corrosion
 In a telephone interview today, he said, "It will look at other things as well, but the primary focus is the pipeline corrosion." 
 The Alyeska Pipeline Service Company, operator of the pipeline that carries a quarter of the oil produced in the United States, has come under criticism over the past several years for not taking steps earlier to slow the spread of external rust and internal corrosion that has been building since the pipeline's completion in 1977. Plans to increase pressure in the line to bring more oil to the port of Valdez to be shipped to refineries have been put on hold because of fears that the line was too damaged to handle the load.
Last year, Alyeska, owned by seven producers of North Slope oil, embarked on a five-year $800 million program to repair rusted sections and intensify its inspections.
 
 Repair Plan With Problems
 But that program itself has been troubled.
The latest problem was the surprise discovery of moisture inside a steel sleeve covering a section of line that was repaired this summer. The discovery came after nine sections of the pipeline were unearthed to investigate allegations that a contractor testing for rust had used poorly trained workers.
The moisture in the repair sleeve at Atigun Pass is a new safety concern for the agencies monitoring pipeline operations, said David Vickery, a spokesman for the Federal Bureau of Land Management.
The water could exacerbate corrosion problems, Mr. Vickery said, and is one reason why officials are not allowing greater pipeline pressures to meet the increased demand for oil.
The joint Federal-state panel was formed to "avoid potential disaster" that could occur if the rust-weakened pipeline burst, according the statement prepared by Travis P. Dungan, head of the Transportation Department's Research and Special Programs Administration.
In addition to rust and corrosion, the group will examine how well the pipeline operators are protecting the environment, and whether plans are adequate in the event of a spill.
Mr. Rockwell said the review panel would have an indefinite life and be charged with coordinating the Federal and state agencies with oversight over the pipeline, though it will not investigate the Federal and state regulators' performance. "We think we've done a more than adequate job," Mr. Rockewell said.
 
 Increase in Pressure Sought
 To make up for the reduction in oil supplies as a result of the Middle East crisis, Alyeska is seeking permission from state and Federal regulators to increase pipeline pressure so that the daily output could maintained at 2.1 million barrels daily without the use of expensive compounds that must be put in the oil to reduce friction. Alyeska is presently pumping that amount but says it is not economical because of the cost of the friction-reducing compounds.
"We would not be inclined to give our approval to that request, certainly not till we have a couple weeks to go over the data," Mr. Vickery said.
 
 Eight Miles of New Pipe
 Marnie Isaacs, a spokeswoman for Alyeska, said engineers did not believe the moisture problem was serious because the water was not free-flowing. In any event, she said the suspect repair sleeve, along with 41 others, would be replaced next year when eight and a half miles of new pipe is laid in the Atigun Pass area in the most extensive reconstruction of the line since its opening.
At 4,740 feet, Atigun Pass in the Brooks Range is the highest point of the line and the location of the pipe's highest internal pressure, the work of Pump Station 4 as it boosts heated crude over the top. It is also one of the most severely corroded section of the pipeline, though officials say there is no immediate danger of the pipeline bursting.
When short sections of the pipeline are repaired, the steel sleeves covering the weakened pipe are usually welded shut at both ends. However, the eight-foot and longer structural sleeves used at Atigun Pass were not sealed with welds because engineers feared the rigidity of the longer lengths could cause the pipeline to buckle. A sealing compound was used instead to block water.
But the seal in one of the sleeves was broken, perhaps by a rock, and officials wonder how many more buried sleeves might be wet, Ms. Isaacs said.
The moisture inside the sleeve was accidently discovered when officials reinspected 19 sections of the pipeline that had been tested for rust last summer by Thorpe Technical Services of Anchorage.
The investigation was prompted by allegations of a former Thorpe employee, Edward Thompson, that his co-workers were not properly trained in the equipment and methods to discover rust spots and cracks. Mr. Thompson also said that on-the-job drug and alcohol use was common among his fellow workers.
Dale Thorpe, the president of the company, denied the allegations and has threatened to sue Mr. Thompson.

HEADLINE: STANDOFF IN THE GULF;
Excerpts From Remarks by Webster and Baker on Embargo's Drain on Iraq

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from remarks by William H. Webster, Director of Central Intelligence, before the House Armed Services Committee today, and from Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d's appearance before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today, as recorded by The New York Times:
 
WEBSTER STATEMENT
 Despite mounting disruptions and hardships resulting from sanctions, Saddam apparently believes that he can outlast international resolve to maintain sanctions. We see no indication that Saddam is concerned at this point that domestic discontent is growing to levels that may threaten his regime or that problems resulting from the sanctions are causing him to rethink his policy on Kuwait. The Iraqi people have experienced considerable deprivation in the past. Given the brutal nature of the Iraqi security services, the population is not likely to oppose Saddam openly. Our judgment has been, and continues to be, that there is no assurance or guarantee that economic hardships will compel Saddam to change his policies or lead to internal unrest that would threaten his regime. . . . 
 The blockade and embargo have worked more effectively than Saddam probably expected. More than 90 percent of imports and 97 percent of exports have been shut off. Although there is smuggling across Iraq's borders, it is extremely small relative to Iraq's precrisis trade. Iraqi efforts to break sanctions have thus far been largely unsuccessful. . . .
Industry appears to be the hardest-hit sector so far. Many firms are finding it difficult to cope with the departure of foreign workers and with the cutoff of imported industrial inputs -- which comprised nearly 60 percent of Iraq's total imports prior to the invasion. These shortages have either shut down or severely curtailed production by a variety of industries, including many light industrial and assembly plants as well as the country's only tire-manufacturing plant.
Despite these shutdowns, the most vital industries -- including electric power generation and refining -- do not yet appear threatened. We believe they will be able to function for some time because domestic consumption has been reduced, because Iraqi and Kuwaiti facilities have been cannibalized and because some stockpiles and surpluses already existed.
The cutoff of Iraq's oil exports and the success of sanctions also have choked off Baghdad's financial resources. This too has been more effective and more complete than Saddam probably expected. In fact, we believe that a lack of foreign exchange will, in time, be Iraq's greatest economic difficulty. The embargo has deprived Baghdad of roughly $1.5 billion of foreign-exchange earnings monthly. . . .
 
Iraqi Food and Economy
 We believe Baghdad's actions to forestall shortages of food stocks, including rationing, encouraging smuggling and promoting agricultural production are adequate for the next several months. The full harvest of fruits and vegetables is injecting new supplies into the market, and will provide a psychological as well as tangible respite from mounting pressures. The Iraqi population in general has access to sufficient staple foods. Other food stocks still not rationed also remain available. However, the variety is diminishing and prices are sharply inflated. For example, sugar purchased on the open market at the official exchange rate went from $32 per 50 kilogram bag in August, to $580 per bag last month.
But these hardships are easier for Iraqis to endure than the combination of economic distress, high casualty rates and repeated missile and air attacks that Iraqis lived with during the eight-year Iran-Iraq war. During this war, incidentally, there was not a single significant public disturbance, even though casualties hit 2.3 percent of the total Iraqi population -- about the same as the percentage of U.S. casualties during the Civil War.
Looking ahead, the economic picture changes somewhat. We expect Baghdad's foreign-exchange reserves to become extremely tight, leaving it little cash left with which to entice potential sanctions-busters. At current rates of depletion, we estimate Iraq will have nearly depleted its available foreign-exchange reserves by next spring. Able to obtain even fewer key imports, Iraq's economic problems will begin to multiply as Baghdad is forced to gradually shut down growing numbers of facilities in order to keep critical activities functioning as long as possible. Economic conditions will be noticeably worse and Baghdad will find allocating scarce resources a significantly more difficult task.
Probably only energy-related and some military industries will still be functioning by next spring. This will almost certainly be the case by next summer. . . .
 
Effects on Military
 By next spring Iraqis will have made major changes in their diets. . . . But we expect that Baghdad will be able to maintain grain consumption, mainly wheat, barley, and rice, at about two-thirds of last year's level until the next harvest in May.
Although sanctions are hurting Iraq's civilian economy, they are affecting the Iraqi military only at the margins. Iraq's fairly static defensive posture will reduce wear and tear on the military equipment and as a result, extend the life of its inventory of spare parts and maintenance items. Under noncombat conditions, Iraq ground and air forces can probably maintain near-current levels of readiness for as long as nine months.
We expect the Iraqi Air Force to feel the effects of sanctions more quickly and to a greater degree than the Iraqi ground forces because of its greater reliance on high technology and foreign equipment and technicians. Major repairs to sophisticated aircraft like the F-1 will be achieved with significant difficulty, if at all, because of the exodus of foreign technicians. Iraqi technicians, however, should be able to maintain current levels of aircraft sorties for three to six months.
The Iraqi ground forces are more immune to sanctions. Before the invasion, Baghdad maintained large inventories of basic military supplies, such as ammunition, and supplies probably remain adequate.
 
BAKER QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS
 SENATOR JOSEPH R. BIDEN Jr.: The Administration appears -- not appears, in my view has -- shifted to a new policy based on the premises -- the premise that sanctions will not work and that an early resort to offensive action may be necessary.
In essence, Mr. Secretary, I'd like to hear you explain why you've abandoned what you told this committee just three months ago. You said that the sanctions policy is, quote, the only peaceful path to meeting the objective set by the President. You continued by stating, quote, What we ask most of the American people is to stand firm, be patient and remain united, end of quote.
My question today is, Mr. Secretary, can you provide this committee with a compelling case that the international coalition will not hold? . . .
BAKER: I don't think that there are -- there are reservations with respect to some of the forces of nations that have symbolic presences in the gulf -- ships and that sort of thing. But for the most part, those that are on the ground, Senator Biden, are quite prepared if the -- if the option of force is resorted to, to move to the same degree and extent that the United States is -- the majority of them.
One of the most important questions that will arise in this whole -- in all of these hearings -- Armed Services and Foreign Relations -- as indicated by the statement the committee made when they called the hearings. And the question was: What is -- essentially, what is the workability of economic sanctions? . . . Clearly, everyone I know would prefer to see sanctions work. There is no one that I know that wants to see a resort to the force option. As I've said before, though, and as I said in the statement, I've said it a number of times in the past and I reiterated it today in the formal statement, nobody can every tell you that sanctions alone will force Saddam Hussein out of Kuwait.
And, Senator, I have to tell you I am personally very pessimistic that they will. This pessimism, I would also share with you, is shared by our recent intelligence estimates.
The four months of experience we have is not particularly encouraging. I've already said we know he's willing to starve his army. We've made the point in the past that Iraq has the capability of improving its agricultural production significantly. And you made the very valid point just now, Senator, that yes, indeed, there are some exemptions in the UN resolutions that permit the importation of food for humanitarian purposes. So I grant you that that is a consideration as well.
It's just our view that he is not going to retreat just because we've cut off his oil exports or just because we have cut off his financial exchange. His whole history as a dictator makes it clear that he is not uncomfortable in imposing extraordinary sacrifices on the people of Iraq.
Q. Would you answer the question? Who in the coalition will not hold? . . .
A. I'm not going to predict weakness on the part of our coalition partners in an open session, Senator.
 
Withdrawal and Defeat
SENATOR PAUL S. SARBANES: I do not agree with your statement on page seven that this is not a new strategy, but rather a continuation and reinforcement of the strategy we have been pursuing. I think two days after the election, the Administrationundertook a new strategy. And I asked you, how long after you had an offensive force in the area, perceived to be capable of mounting an offensive attack, could you go without using it. . . . Would you not agree that if this huge force assembled in Saudi Arabia were to go home a few months later without having achieved the objective of forcing Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait, that it would have suffered defeat?
There was a story in the paper yesterday that Saddam Hussein was closed off and he never got conflicting advice. And it's been suggested, in fact, that if you go out to see him, that's one of the things that will be accomplished. But I'm increasingly concerned that perhaps something of the same sort is taking place within our own Administration.
A. Let me say, Senator, that right out my windowat the State Department I look every day at Arlington National Cemetery, and I understand very, very well what's at stake here, and I think the President of the United States understands very, very well. And that's why we have gone about it in a way that I think the term persevere would apply to. We have not been precipitous. We have not been reckless. Indeed, we have solicited. In terms of consultation, there's been more consultation on this issue I think than ever before on anything that I'm aware of. As far as the Congress is concerned, the President has met seven times; I have been up here 11; the Secretary of Defense has been up here 12. This is a very serious matter.
 
Reasoning and Waiting
SENATOR JOHN KERRY: . . . I think that we're missing a point of what is
dividing the country and what is so much at issue here. You talked today about endless sanctions, and Secretary Cheney keeps using the concept that we can't allow sanctions to go on forever. And you've talked about misinterpreting our resolve. And it seems to me that -- I haven't heard anybody talking about endless sanctions. You put it this morning in the context of, Let me express my pessimism, versus your optimism. I don't think it's a question of pessimism versus optimism in the application of sanctions. I think it's a question of how reasonable people make a judgment.
What I fear is that while you talk about the cost of waiting, as Secretary McNamara yesterday talked about the cost of not waiting, and that the cost of one week of war may be far, far greater than the cost of several more months of exhausting the possibilities so that Americans will come together united and say, We did everything and now we have no other choice.
 A. I have alluded to the intelligence assessments that we have, I have mentioned the fact - if I haven't, I want to - that we follow these sanctions very closely, interagency and with other governments. We follow them through the intelligence community, we follow them through our presence of other countries in Baghdad . . . But if you delay too long, the costs of dealing with the problem could be much greater later.
 
An Oil Field's Role
 SENATOR FRANK H. MURKOWSKI: If there is any other way out, if Saddam Hussein clearly considers alternatives, then, of course, the question of what has been thrown out from time to time as, perhaps, an alternative consideration . . . It continues to come up in considering, you know, the alternative of warfare.
 A. Senator, I don't want silence to go - to be interpreted as assent here, so I have to respond to that by saying we have to be - we have to be very careful --
 MURKOWSKI: I understand that.
 BAKER: When we're dealing with as important an issue and principle as we are here that we do not - do not lend credence to the suggestion that somehow an aggressor can be rewarded --
MURKOWSKI: I understand.
 BAKER: For his aggression.
 MURKOWSKI: But by the same --
 BAKER: We're talking about a new world order that would operate on a different principle, entirely.
 MURKOWSKI: We're also talking about an alternative of warfare that could be very devastating and we both share in that concern --
 BAKER: Yes, sir.

HEADLINE: Court Extends 'Family' Rule To Rent-Stabilized Units

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI

 BODY:
A landmark ruling that protects the remaining member of an unmarried couple from being evicted from a rent-controlled apartment if one partner dies or moves was extended by a New York State appeals court on Tuesday to cover all of the one million rent-stabilized apartments in the state.
"It's a huge victory for over one million rent-regulated tenants across the state," said Alan Hamerman, a spokesman for the State Commissioner of Housing and Community Renewal, Angelo J. Aponte. 
 The rules will insure, for the first time, Mr. Hamerman continued, that elderly people, gay couples and others sharing apartments "receive the full blanket of protection as set forth in the rent laws."
 
'A More Realistic' View
 The unanimous ruling by four judges in the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court -- First Department, which covers Manhattan and the Bronx, overturned an injunction issued by a court in Albany in November 1989. The lower court had barred the state housing agency from putting into effect new regulations extending what is known as the Braschi decision from rent-controlled to rent-stabilized apartments. The injunction had been sought by the Rent Stabilization Association, an organization representing landlords.
In the Braschi case -- brought by the surviving member of a gay couple in Manhattan -- the state's highest court, the Court of Appeals, said in July 1989: "We conclude that the term family," as used in laws governing the state's estimated 160,000 rent-controlled apartments, "should not be rigidly restricted to those people who have formalized their relationship by obtaining, for instance, a marriage certificate or an adoption order."
"In the context of eviction," the ruling added, "a more realistic, and certainly equally valid, view of a family includes two adult lifetime partners whose relationship is long term and characterized by an emotional and financial commitment and interdependence." Gay-rights advocates have hailed that decision as a step toward legalization of their relationships.
 
An Appeal Is Planned
 In its ruling on Tuesday, the Appellate Division said, "Since the new regulations incorporate the Braschi definition of 'family' into the existing scheme, they do not conflict with Real Property Law."
It also said, "By responding to the continuing shortage of low- and middle-income housing units available, the rise in instances of individuals 'doubling up' and tenants being forced into a homeless situation due to unaffordable rents, the regulations clearly comport with the broad mandate provided the Division of Housing and Community Renewal by the Legislature to 'protect tenants and the public interest.' "
William Rubenstein, director of the American Civil Liberties Union's lesbian and gay-rights project, which was a party to the case, said: "These state regulations are really the first we know of in the country in which a statewide authority has defined family in a such broad, meaningful and realistic manner, including the recognition of lesbian and gay families. The fact that these regulations have withstood judicial scrutiny is an important milestone."
The president of the Rent Stabilization Association, John Gilbert, said he was "disappointed but not surprised" by the ruling.
"We will appeal," Mr. Gilbert said.
But the state's highest court does not necessarily have to hear an appeal. Mr. Gilbert, however, said he thought it would. "The Court of Appeals has always held sacred the fact that a lease is a contract," he said. "In Braschi, it was a rent-controlled situation, and there was no lease. But this is a rent-stabilized situation, and you've got a lease between two people."

HEADLINE: STANDOFF IN THE GULF;
The Collapse Of a Coalition

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5

 BODY:
The bipartisan coalition in support of President Bush's policy in the Persian Gulf, which developed cracks last week with the defection of an influential Democratic Senator, Sam Nunn of Georgia, fell apart today on Capitol Hill, live on television in full view of the nation and the world.
Prominent Democrats of today, led by the senior members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, joined prominent Democrats of the past, including a noted hawk and a noted dove, in attacking the Bush Administration for what they termed an indecent rush toward war against Iraq and in asserting that woefully inadequate thought had been given to the consequences of such a war. 
 All said they spoke out of concern for the national interest, insisting that policy, not politics, was the motivation. But senior Administration officials, betraying for the first time something of a bunker mentality, suggested that the criticism had grown out of partisanship; one ranking policy maker said the day's events had showed that the Democrats "have decided this is the issue that will break Bush's Presidency."
If Mr. Bush is engaged in a game of what John Foster Dulles used to call "brinkmanship," hoping that by making war seem inevitable he will force President Saddam Hussein of Iraq to pull back and make it unnecessary, the Democrats' tough new stance may hinder him greatly by making his threats less credible.
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d came close to saying as much when he called on the Democrats on the committee to help persuade the Iraqi leader that "the alternative to peaceful compliance is to be forced to comply." Given an opening by a friendly Republican question, he commented rather wistfully that he wished he could persaude Congress to back the Administration as fully as the United Nations had done.
 
More Support Abroad
 Mr. Bush clearly faces a Herculean repair job if he is to arrive at Jan. 15 with anything approaching a national consensus behind him. That is the day after which the United Nations Security Council has authorized member nations to use force if Iraqi troops remain in Kuwait.
For the first time in recent history, an American Administration has more comprehensive support abroad for a major foreign-policy position than it has at home. And for the first time in recent history, public and political opinion in the United States is split on the eve of a possible war -- not halfway through it, as was the case in Vietnam, or toward its end, as in Korea.
The day's proceedings before the Foreign Relations Committee, a piece of political theater full of the urgency lent by high political stakes, marked a turning point of considerable importance. Democratic doubts and suspicions, suppressed or ignored for months, suddenly coalesced.
In the process, Mr. Baker, who has grown accustomed in his many years in Washington to being treated as something of an icon, was roughed up pretty badly. Again and again, Democrats accused him of ignoring expert opinions on sanctions and other subjects, of failing to justify the Administration's impatience and of failing to get American allies to commit enough troops or money to the common cause.
Many in the packed conference room recalled the hearings during the Vietnam War, held by this same committee under the chairmanship of Senator J. William Fulbright of Arkansas, that did much to fuel the antiwar movement. George McGovern, the Democratic nominee who tried and failed to ride that movement into the White House in 1972, was one of those who testified today; so was Zbigniew Brzezinski, a prominent participant in the last American military adventure in the gulf, the futile attempt to rescue American hostages from Iran.
 
Undesirable Side Effects
 Mr. Brzezinski echoed other critics, including former cabinet members and retired senior military officers, in arguing that economic sanctions had not been given a fair chance to work. But he also introduced a new note to the debate, suggesting that all sorts of undesirable and unanticipated side effects might arise from a war, including Iranian dominance in the gulf, Syrian leadership of the Arab world, overthrow of Arab governments friendly to the United States, military involvement of the United States in the region for decades and temptation for Israel to use its military force more freely.
In response to Senators' questions, he urged Mr. Bush and Mr. Baker to emulate Dwight D. Eisenhower in his measured response to Beijing in the Quemoy and Matsu crisis and John F. Kennedy in his measured response to Moscow in the Cuban missile crisis. In a direct reproach to the President's language, Mr. Brzezinski added, "To speak of Saddam Hussein as a Hitler is to trivialize Hitler and to elevate Saddam."
Offstage, other lines of potential attack were becoming visible as Democrats tried to exploit weaknesses in the Administration's position.
Representative Dan Rostenkowski, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, suggested that a surtax might be needed to pay for a war in the gulf or even for the protracted deployment of hundreds of thousands of American troops in Saudi Arabia. Such a surtax would surely be highly unwelcome to the Administration.
"We really haven't focused on the cost of the Persian Gulf," the Illinois Democrat told reporters at a breakfast meeting. "People are not really aware of it. When that surfaces, there is going to have to be some response from Congress and the President."
On Tuesday, in another sign of the growing partisan polarization in the House, Democrats there overwhelmingly adopted a nonbinding resolution that said Mr. Bush should order no attack without the approval of Congress. It was passed by a vote of 177 to 37 in a closed-door caucus.
The Democrats' tactical position is made easier by the contradictions in statements about the gulf crisis made by top Administration officials.
On Oct. 16 in London, for example, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said, "The sanctions and the embargo are beginning to have an impact" and predicted that over the next few months the measures would erode Mr. Hussein's political base as well as the Iraqi economy and military capacity.
On Capitol Hill on Monday, however, Mr. Cheney said it was unlikely the sanctions would ever work, either by restricting food supplies enough or by crippling the Iraqi military.
Now the Administration must decide how to fight back -- either directly, perhaps by suggesting that the Democrats' conduct is vaguely unpatriotic, or indirectly, perhaps by urging Jewish groups and others with an interest in an aggressive United States policy to bring pressure on key Democratic critics like Senators Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware and Paul S. Sarbanes of Maryland.
More likely, the President will leave the infighting to surrogates, like Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina.
Mr. Bush himself may well try to appeal over the heads of Congress to the American people, who appear, at least from the evidence of opinion polls, to have grave doubts of their own, and whom he has never found it as easy to sway as Ronald Reagan did.

HEADLINE: Cash Offer By A.T.&T. After Rebuff

BYLINE: By EBEN SHAPIRO

 BODY:
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced a $90-a-share, $6 billion hostile cash tender offer for the NCR Corporation yesterday after NCR's board rejected A.T.& T.'s all-stock bid for the same amount.
NCR said that it would be prepared to negotiate if A.T.& T. offered $125 a share, or $8.5 billion. But an A.T.& T. spokesman, Walter Murphy, said, "We view that price as outrageous and totally unjustified."
Analysts said that while it was unlikely that NCR would sell for so much, the company was, in effect, placing itself up for sale by setting a price.
 
 'A Bargaining Point'
 "I would characterize $125 a share as simply a bargaining point," said Jack Grubman, analyst with Paine Webber Inc. "The notion of remaining independent has gone by the wayside," he said. 
 Mr. Grubman and other analysts said that they expected A.T.& T. eventually to acquire NCR at a somewhat higher price than $90 a share.
The hostile bid was made after a 50-minute meeting between NCR's chairman, Charles E. Exley Jr., and A.T.& T.'s chairman, Robert E. Allen. The meeting, which was requested by Mr. Exley, took place in the offices of NCR's law firm, Weil, Gotshal & Manges.
A.T.& T. moved quickly to make its cash bid after the stock offer was rejected. It lined up as advisers Morgan Stanley & Company, the Wall Street investment house; Martin Lipton of the law firm Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz, who made his name in takeover defenses, and Sidley & Austin, the Chicago-based law firm. The company is expected to challenge NCR's shareholder rights plan and to begin a proxy fight to replace members of the board.
 
 Resignation Threatened
 Mr. Exley of NCR has threatened to quit if A.T.& T. acquires the company.
Yesterday morning, in a conference call with analysts, Robert M. Kavner, a top executive of A.T.& T., said the company was determined to press its bid despite Mr. Exley's pledge to resign. Analysts said that Mr. Kavner hoped that Mr. Exley would remain with the company, but Mr. Kavner said that while A.T.& T. needed the senior engineering staff of NCR, it could afford to lose some executives.
In a letter to Mr. Allen rejecting A.T.& T.'s stock offer, Mr. Exley wrote, "We will not jeopardize the imprtant values we are creating at NCR and sacrifice a successful American computer company in order to bail out A.T.& T.'s failed strategy." He also called the takeover attempt "a desperate attempt to salvage A.T.& T.'s disastrous foray into the computer business." A.T.& T. has had consistent losses with its computer business since entering the field in 1984.
Despite such language, analysts viewed NCR's response as an attempt to get A.T.& T. to raise its bid. Mr. Grubman of Paine Webber said that A.T.& T. could pay up to $110 a share for NCR, with the deal still making economic sense.
In announcing the tender offer, Mr. Allen questioned NCR's ability to go it alone. "We are entering an era in which the survival of stand-alone computer companies will be sorely challenged, particarly from abroad," he said.
In a separate letter to Mr. Exley, the A.T.& T. chairman wrote: "All we have is a difference of opinion on price. We should let your shareholders decide."
The tender offer will expire at midnight, Jan. 4, 1991, unless it is extended. A.T.& T. is not expected to have trouble obtaining financing.
A.T.& T. was the most active issue on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, with more than 5 million shares changing hands. The stock closed down 25 cents, at $30.125 a share. More than 2.4 million NCR shares were traded, and it closed up $3.125 a share, to $86.625.
 
 Bruising Fight Ahead
 With yesterday's announcement, A.T.& T. and NCR began to brace for what promises to be a bruising takeover fight similar to those of the 1980's.
Several Wall Street investment banking firms were said to be trying to join the battle as advisers. For example, Goldman, Sachs & Company, was said by Wall Street executives to be preparing a presentation for the NCR board.
"If there is an investment bank that is not trying to get hired by someone here, they're asleep," One investment banker said.
Investment bankers believe that the two companies will have to hire additional firms because of the size and complexity of the potential deal. Few large deals during the 1980's were run by a single firm, and Dillon, Read & Company, the mid-sized firm that is advising the NCR directors, is not known as a defensive powerhouse in the takeover business.
At the same time, A.T.& T. was said to be in contact with a number of other companies to block any attempt by NCR to find a "white knight" that would acquire the company in a friendly transaction.
"They are attempting to chill other bidders," one person involved in the situation said. "Very few people are willing to take on A.T.& T, particularly a non-U.S. company."
 
 Array of Defenses
 Even if no other bidders come into the process, however, A.T.& T. would have to overcome an array of NCR anti-takeover defenses.
Yesterday, the NCR board authorized several steps that Wall Street executives said were intended to give it more negotiating power.
First, the company lowered the threshold at which parts of its poison pill would come into play. That is a provision designed to fend off unwanted suitors. Now, if a hostile suitor acquired 15 percent of the company, elements of the poison pill would become effective, compared with the prior level of 20 percent.
In addition, NCR opted out of an anti-takeover protection provided to the company under Maryland state law, where it is incorporated.
While the protection at first appears to benefit the company, it includes a provision that would have allowed the shareholders to remove the board of directors if 80 percent of the shareholders approved of a takeover bid. By opting out of the protection, NCR also prevented its shareholders from voting its board out under the 80 percent rule.

HEADLINE: Nynex Units Allow Hookup

 BODY:
The New York Telephone Company and the New England Telephone and Telegraph Company announced this week that they would allow private urban telephone systems to connect their equipment directly to the local phone network.
Metropolitan Fiber Systems Inc., a privately held company based in Chicago, announced yesterday that it had reached a connection agreement with New York Telephone. Metropolitan Fiber said last week that it had completed construction of an urban fiber-optic system in lower Manhattan. 
 Urban fiber-optic systems provide big companies with low-cost, high-capacity telephone cables to nearby businesses and to the nearest switching centers of long-distance carriers. The new systems compete with local phone companies, which have traditionally offered this service.
By allowing the fiber-optic system vendors to plug their equipment directly into local phone company switching equipment, New York Telephone and New England Telephone will allow these vendors to offer local phone calls more cheaply and efficiently.
The move by the two subsidiaries of the Nynex Corporation "ends a long, disputatious history of several years" of clashes with the fiber-optic system companies, said Eli M. Noam, a Columbia University economist.

HEADLINE: Mixed Results for Test of Oil Reserve Sales

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
The last deliveries of oil sold from the nation's Strategic Petroleum Reserve were made on Sunday, according to the Energy Department.
The relatively small sale went fairly smoothly, but it did uncover some problems that might hamper bigger efforts to tap the reserve. The financial picture was mixed; the Government may have turned a profit, but it depends on the accounting method used. 
 President Bush announced the sale on Sept. 26 in an unsuccessful effort to scare speculators and drive down the price of oil. The sale involved 4.125 million barrels, delivered over several weeks. The White House described the sale as a test, and it was a modest exercise for a reserve system that is supposed to be able to deliver as much as 3.5 million barrels a day in a full-scale emergency.
Establishing the buyers' credit was one source of potential delays. Government officials said the Energy Department required bidders to submit letters of credit from their banks, to assure that the buyers could pay for the oil. But without a standard form, each letter had to be analyzed carefully by Government lawyers.
Another possible problem involved the Federal law that requires the use of American-flag ships when oil is shipped from the reserve by tanker. Oil companies try to avoid American ships, because they are more expensive and sometimes are not available. Of the 26 deliveries in the test, 21 were made by pipeline and 5 by barge, but none by tanker. In a large sale, tankers would be needed.
There also appeared to be something of a mismatch between what was offered for sale and what the oil companies wanted to buy. The Government accepted bids on all 2.2 million barrels of low-sulfur oil that were offered. But with high-sulfur oil, only 1.925 million of the 2.8 million barrels offered were sold because some bids were judged to be less than 90 percent of fair market value.
The average sale price was $31.80 a barrel. Whether that was good for the taxpayers depends on which of the 585 million barrels were sold.
The last oil bought, just before the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait by Iraq, cost about $16 a barrel.
The first barrels bought, in the late 1970's, were even cheaper, about $14.45 each. But the Government has paid 12 years of interest on the money it borrowed to buy that oil. Assuming an average interest rate of 9 percent, the price of those barrels rises above $40. With maintenance expenses, the total would be about $46 a barrel.
The cost could be even higher if the oil is assumed to be barrels bought for more than $36 in the early 1980's.
John W. Bartholomew, director of the Strategic Petroleum Reserve, does not any use any of those accounting systems; the law that established the reserve, he noted, states that the money from sales is to be used to buy replacement crude. On a replacement-cost basis, the sale was probably profitable, since analysts expect oil to drop to the low $20's, if not lower, when the gulf crisis ends. Mr. Bartholomew added that the reserve was not regarded as a vehicle for making money through speculation.

HEADLINE: Energy Strategists Review U.S. Reliance on Oil Imports

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5

 BODY:
Administration officials, racing to submit the elements of a long-awaited national energy strategy to the President this month, are giving renewed attention to the nation's high dependence on imported oil, officials in the Energy Department and in industry say.
With no change in current trends, projections show the United States would import 80 percent of its oil by 2030, up from the 50 percent level that was reached during some months of this year. As the nation approached 50 percent dependence in 1977, President Jimmy Carter pledged that imports would never climb that high again. 
 Oil now accounts for 40 percent of the nation's total energy use and that is expected to decline by only four percentage points, to 36 percent, during the next four decades.
 
New Sense of Urgency
 Energy Department officials have long been concerned about oil dependence, but for others involved in the review of national energy strategy that was begun in July 1989 the oil-import issue has taken on extra urgency in light of the Persian Gulf crisis.
"There are people who have looked at this in the Administration and called it to our attention," said W. Henson Moore, the Deputy Energy Secretary. "That's the factor that slaps you across the face."
He declined, however, to say what, if any, options might be added to the list of 60 to 65 now being prepared for presentation to President Bush at a meeting with his economic advisers, probably on Dec. 18.
The President, who was once in the oil business, is to select various options and offer these, presumably in January, as his Administration's energy program.
Since the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, analysts working on the project have added at least one new set of projections based on big gyrations in oil prices, but they have decided not to accelerate the timetable for completion of the study.
Energy Department officials most closely involved with the project have cast their net widely for ideas, conducting nearly a score of public hearings around the country and processing thousands of pages of comments.
Early drafts of the option list have aroused heavy criticism from various quarters, particularly environmentalists and those favoring alternative forms of energy like solar power. But objections have also come from the nuclear power industry, the coal industry and the Edison Electric Institute, the trade association representing investor-owned utilities.

HEADLINE: Oil Prices Fall $3.37 a Barrel As Gulf War Worries Fade

BYLINE: By Keith BRADSHER

 BODY:
Crude oil prices fell more than $3 a barrel yesterday in futures trading, while wholesale gasoline prices fell below 70 cents a gallon for the first time since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2.
The sharp decline in oil prices came after reports that Iraq was willing to discuss a negotiated withdrawal from Kuwait. 
 The move in oil helped push prices on the stock market sharply higher yesterday in the heaviest trading since mid-October. [Page D8.]
Crude for January delivery dropped $3.37, or 11 percent, to $27.29 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The January gasoline contract fell 7.08 cents, to 68.84 cents a gallon. Heating oil for October delivery dipped 5.76 cents, to 81.14 cents a gallon.
Traders attributed the heavy selling to increased optimism about the chances of a peaceful settlement in the Persian Gulf. The State Department said yesterday that the United States and Iraq had agreed to talks, although no date had been set. "There is the perception that this crisis will be resolved by means other than military," said Nauman Barakat, a senior energy trader at Merrill Lynch.
A week ago, there were twice as many traders expecting a war as were expecting a peaceful solution, Mr. Barakat said, adding that now the ratio has been reversed.
"The war premium is out," said John H. Kingston, the managing editor of Platt's Oilgram Price Report, a daily newsletter.
The slump in energy prices is likely to continue because the market has broken through several important price levels watched by traders and because some traders are becoming desperate to sell on any sign of strength in the market, said Michael Wilner, the president of Hilltop Trading Company in New York.
After the close of trading in New York, the spot, or cash, price for crude in informal deals fell a further 15 to 30 cents a barrel in light trading, traders and analysts said. Only a small fraction of the oil consumed each year in the United States is traded on the Merc, but the prices that result from trading there tend to determine spot prices nationwide.
 
Some Earlier Worries

Wholesale gasoline and heating oil prices both rose above $1 a gallon in September, when traders worried that war in the Persian Gulf was imminent and that a significant portion of the world's oil production capacity might be destroyed.
But the warm autumn weather, the end of the summer driving season and expanded refining prompted by the high prices have resulted in large stockpiles and reduced demand for refined products, particularly gasoline. The American Petroleum Institute said late Tuesday that refineries operated at 88 percent of capacity last week, up from 83 percent the week before.
"We haven't seen that type of increase in a long time," said Thomas P. Blakeslee, an analyst at Pegasus Econometric Group Inc., a consulting firm in Hoboken, N.J.
Oil companies and speculators have accumulated huge supplies of gasoline in Texas and are vulnerable to a stiff annual tax that most Texas municipalities assess on refined product inventories on Dec. 31. Storage sites elsewhere are in short supply.
"A lot of these companies are looking at chartering barges, taking it out in international waters, and bringing it back afterwards," Mr. Kingston said.
