HEADLINE: STANDOFF IN THE GULF;
HEAD OF C.I.A. SEES IRAQIS WEAKENING IN 3 TO 9 MONTHS

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5

 BODY:
The Director of Central Intelligence told Congress today that Iraq's military could maintain its current combat readiness for no more than nine months if economic sanctions continued to hold, and that the ability of the Iraqi Air Force to fly regular missions could decline within three months.
In testimony to the House Armed Services Committee, the C.I.A. director, William H. Webster, predicted that mounting shortages caused by the sanctions were likely to shut down all but Iraq's energy-related and military industries by spring, and "almost certainly" by next summer. 
 Mr. Webster hewed to the Bush Administration line that sanctions would not cause Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait, but his cautiously phrased remarks nonetheless forecast some deterioration in the Iraqi military in less than a year.
 
Nine-Month Effect Seen
 "Under noncombat conditions, Iraq ground and air forces can probably maintain near-current levels of readiness for as long as nine months," he said. "We expect the Iraqi Air Force to feel the effects of sanctions more quickly and to a greater degree than the Iraqi ground forces because of its greater reliance on high technology and foreign equipment and technicians."
Mr. Webster testified as Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, appearing before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, reiterated the Administration position that there is no certainty that sanctions will produce an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait. [Excerpts from the two sessions, page A16.]
Testifying before the House panel, Mr. Webster said, "There is no assurance or guarantee that economic hardships will compel Saddam to change his policies or lead to internal unrest that would threaten his regime."
 
A Different View
 But he appeared to part company with the Administration on the questions of whether and when the sanctions might erode Iraq's military forces -- and by extension, whether waiting longer for the embargo to work might weaken the Iraqi military to the point where it would pose less of a threat to American forces in a war.
On Monday, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney told the Senate Armed Services Committee that a prolonged embargo might only give Iraq's military time to harden its defensive positions in Kuwait and southern Iraq.
Mr. Baker, who drew a barrage of criticism from Democratic members of the Foreign Relations Committee, said the United States would strike "suddenly, massively and decisively" if it chooses to use military force.
At times the Democrats argued with Mr. Baker, and at times Democrats and Republicans openly jousted with each other, ignoring the Secretary of State sitting in the witness chair. The Democrats almost unanimously lined up in favor of giving sanctions more time to bring pressure on Iraq and weaken its army, while the Republicans almost unanimously supported Mr. Baker's argument that only a credible threat of imminent war could convince President Saddam Hussein to peacefully withdraw from Kuwait.
Mr. Baker said his proposed trip to Baghdad this month or in early January was not an opening for negotiations.
 The State Department reported today that Iraq had formally accepted President Bush's offer to hold talks in Washington this month with the Iraqi Foreign Minister, Tariq Aziz, and to send Mr. Baker to Baghdad. Iraq had indicated its acceptance over the weekend. The department said the dates and other details were under discussion with Iraq.
At American urging, the United Nations Security Council last week gave Iraq until Jan. 15 to leave Kuwait or face the prospect of being forced out militarily. Mr. Hussein dismissed the threat and promised to exact extensive casualties from American troops if war breaks out.
Mr. Webster neither agreed nor differed with the Administration's arguments for military force. But his remarks, the Administration's most detailed public assessment of the embargo to date, nevertheless depicted an Iraq whose industry and military are inexorably withering as foreign exchange, food stocks and key manufacturing supplies dry up.
He said that the trade embargo continued to deprive Iraq of more than 90 percent of the goods and services it formerly imported from abroad, and that exports, including oil, had been virtually shut off.
 
Reserves Sufficient Now
 Warehoused goods and other reserves are forestalling serious hardship now, but Mr. Webster said sanctions should begin to significantly hobble Iraq's economy within a few months in these ways:
*Unable to earn money through exports, Iraq should deplete its foreign reserves by the spring, "leaving it little cash left with which to entice potential sanctions-busters" who smuggle goods over rural borders, Mr. Webster said.
*Economic problems will noticeably worsen by spring as Baghdad shifts more and more of its dwindling resources to the military and struggles to keep basic services, such as electrical power, functioning regularly.
*Grain reserves should sustain consumption at about two-thirds of the pre-embargo level until the next harvest in May. But despite Government incentives to increase food production, "Iraq does not have the capability to become self-sufficient in food production by next year," Mr. Webster said.
*Poultry will be "unavailable" by spring, and such staples as sugar and cooking oils will be scarce. Vegetable production also may suffer because the embargo has cut off Iraq's supplies of seed from the United States, France and the Netherlands, he said.
 
Effect on Iraqi Military
 In the military, four months of economic sanctions so far have had an effect only "at the margins," Mr. Webster said, in part because Iraq's defensive stance in Kuwait requires little training or moving of equipment that leads to wear and tear. If that continues, he said, "Iraqi ground and air forces can probably maintain near-current levels of readiness for as long as nine months."
Ground forces have large supplies of ammunition and are receiving larger food rations than the civilian population, he said. A continuing stalemate would allow Mr. Hussein to rest his troops and conserve stocks of critical items such as lubricants. Even so, he said, parts shortages should begin to cripple the infantry's armor and its fleet of military trucks by late summer.
Mr. Webster said the Iraqi Air Force might begin to feel the embargo's pinch sooner, perhaps by March. The shortage of foreign technicians and parts for Iraq's fleet of French- and Soviet-made jets will probably force the air force to reduce its present rate of daily flights, for such purposes as training and reconnaissance, in three to six months.
He said that "major repairs to sophisticated aircraft like the F-1," one of the Mirage line of fighters built by the French manufacturer Dassault, "will be achieved with significant difficulty, if at all, because of the exodus of foreign technicians."
In Senate testimony on Monday, Defense Secretary Cheney questioned the usefulness of the embargo, saying the United States does not have "an indefinite period of time to wait for sanctions to produce the desired result" in Iraq.
Mr. Webster appeared to directly counter Mr. Cheney's statement that the Iraqis could double food production and basically feed themselves on short notice. The C.I.A. director's remarks also contradicted Mr. Cheney's contention that a long delay in beginning military action against Iraq might help Mr. Hussein's military, giving it time to deploy more troops and prepare more fortifications.
Mr. Webster cautioned that there was scant evidence so far that the economic sanctions had seriously disturbed either Iraq's civilian population or Mr. Hussein's resolve.
"We see no indication that Saddam is concerned, at this point, that domestic discontent is growing to levels that may threaten his regime or that problems resulting from the sanctions are causing him to rethink his policy on Kuwait," he said. He said Iraq suffered worse deprivation, in addition to great loss of life, during the eight-year war with Iran.
"While we can look ahead several months and predict the gradual deterioration of the Iraqi economy, it is more difficult to assess how or when these conditions will cause Saddam to modify his behavior," Mr. Webster said. "Saddam almost certainly assumes that he is coping effectively with the sanctions. He appears confident in the ability of his security services to contain potential discontent, and we do not believe he is troubled by the hardships."
In a closed-door session after his public testimony, Mr. Webster was said to have told committee members that economic punishment alone was unlikely to drive Mr. Hussein from Kuwait before the international coalition now arrayed against Iraq began to fragment.
Congressional officials said Mr. Webster told the committee in private that Iraq "can continue to exist as a nation for a protracted time," even in the face of a worldwide trade embargo, and that the decline in its armed forces would be slow to take hold.
The sharpest exchange of the day for Mr. Baker came when Senator Paul S. Sarbanes, Democrat of Maryland, said, his voice rising in anger:
"You and the President have said that this trip to Baghdad is going the last mile. I beg to disagree with you. The last best chance for a peaceful solution, the going the last mile, is to sustain the sanctions policy for a period of time sufficiently long to give it a chance to work. There's no expert who has testified, or holds the view, that it could work within four months -- none."
"Now, I cannot say to a family that loses a son or daughter in a conflict that may well take place in the next 60 to 90 days, that we exhausted every possibility for a peaceful resolution before this happened, because the sanctions option has not been exhausted," the Senator added.
Mr. Baker, clearly containing his own anger, responded: "Let me say, Senator, that right out my window at the State Department I look every day at Arlington National Cemetery, and I understand very, very well what's at stake here, and I think the President of the United States understands very, very well."
"We have not been precipitous," Mr. Baker said. "We have not been reckless."
 
Baker Cites His Reasons
 The Secretary of State began his hearing testimony by laying out why he thought that sanctions alone would not produce an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait. He cited reasons ranging from Iraq's ability to grow its own food to the character of the Iraqi Government, which he said is insensitive to pain inflicted on its people.
"We have to face some hard facts," Mr. Baker said. "If sanctions are to succeed, they must do more than hurt Iraq economically. They must hurt Saddam so much that he changes his behavior and withdraws from Kuwait."
After four months of a total embargo on Iraq, he said, "all available evidence suggests" that sanctions "have had little if any effect on his inclination to withdraw."
If the Senators really want a peaceful solution, the Secretary said, clearly addressing himself to the Democrats on the committee, then they have to help the Administration convince the Iraqi leader that "the alternative to peaceful compliance is to be forced to comply."

HEADLINE: Science Academy Urges More Computer Security

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

 BODY:
Warning that computers in the United States are not secure, the National Academy of Sciences yesterday urged the nation to revamp computer security procedures, institute new emergency response teams and create a special non-Government organization to take charge of computer security planning.
The report's authors noted the increasing dependence on computers to control almost every aspect of America's business and Government activity as well as critical systems like airline traffic control and vital hospital equipment. They said the nation had been fortunate not to have suffered a catastrophic failure. 
 The report, "Computers At Risk: Safe Computing In the Information Age," was prepared by 16 university and Government computer security specialists at the request of the Pentagon's Defense Advanced Projects Agency. The authors of the report, prepared by the academy's National Research Council, included David D. Clark, a computer scientist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology; M. Douglas McIlroy, a computer scientist at the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's Bell Laboratories; Peter G. Neumann, a computer security researcher at SRI International, and Willis H. Ware, a computer privacy researcher at the Rand Corporation.
 
'Luck Will Soon Run Out'
 "As far as we can tell, there has been no successful systematic attempt to subvert any of our critical computing systems," the report said. "Unfortunately, there is reason to believe that our luck will soon run out. Thus far, we have relied on the absence of malicious people who are both capable and motivated. We can no longer do so. We must instead attempt to build computer systems that are secure and trustworthy."
The panel began work in the fall of 1988 after a nationwide computer was jammed by a Cornell University graduate student who released a rogue program that had been written as a prank. Because of several flaws in the program, it went out of control and stalled thousands of computers connected to a network of business, Government and military computers known as the Internet.
"While we haven't had the equivalent of a Chernobyl-like disaster for computers, do we want to wait for something like that to happen?" asked Marjory S. Blumenthal, the academy's staff director for the study. "There are enough signs of potential vulnerability that we should act now."
The report cited threats to individual privacy, the danger of increased trust placed in computers used in safety-critical applications like medical instruments and air traffic control systems, corporate espionage and the increasing vulnerability of international computer networks to political attacks.
 
 Dual Responsibility
 At present, responsibility for developing computer security systems and standards is split between the National Security Agency, an intelligence gathering and military computer security organization, and the National Institute of Standards and Technology, which has responsibility for nonclassified computer security. Ms. Blumenthal said, however, that the institute has not had sufficient funding to develop secure computer designs.
"The current system isn't working, and people know it," said Marc Rotenberg, Washington director for the Computer Professionals for Social Responsibility, a national public interest organization.
The academy panel proposed that a private, not-for-profit organization -- to be called the Information Security Foundation -- be set up with private financing to develop security standards and to research security technologies.
The proposed group would be supported by computer emergency response teams, known as CERT's. The Defense Advanced Project Agency set up such an organization after the Internet incident. Based at the Software Engineering Institute in Pittsburgh, the unit is made up of a small group of specialists. It has a 24-hour hot line and can respond quickly to attacks on computer security.
 
 Security Equipment
 The National Security Agency has refused to permit the export of advanced computer equipment that protects the security of voice and data communications, but the report called for a change in that policy.
"If the United States does not allow vendors of commercial systems to export security products with relatively effective security features," the report said, "large multinational firms, as well as foreign cusomters will simply purchase equivalent systems from foreign manufacturers." Several European governments are now promoting competing security plans, the report noted.

HEADLINE: Slump May Even Hit Toys 'R' Us

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
The history of the toy business can be divided into two epochs: before Toys "R" Us and after Toys "R" Us.
With huge stores brimming with brand-name toys at low prices, all under the stern gaze of computer scanners that control inventory, Toys "R" Us is the world's largest toy retailer. By revolutionizing the often haphazard business of selling playthings, it forced competitors to duplicate its approach or lose customers. Most lost customers. 
 But this edgy Christmas sales season may slow the pace of even Toys "R" Us. Nervous about a possible war in the Persian Gulf and a likely recession at home, Americans may not spend much more than the $16.8 billion they did on toys and video games last Christmas, many analysts say. When the annual inflation rate, now running at more than 6.3 percent is taken into account, there might be a real decline in sales after the dust settles.
Just how bleak this Christmas might be was underscored Tuesday when Child World Inc., the nation's No. 2 toy chain, said it would seek to avoid bankruptcy by stopping payment of its old bills until Jan. 15. The company cited poor sales throughout its 182 stores, which are concentrated in the economically troubled Northeast. Child World also reported a third-quarter loss of $14.4 million compared with a loss of $4.1 million a year earlier.
Hoping to raise cash by drawing more customers, Child World said it would lower prices on many of its toys starting Saturday. That raised speculation by industry analysts that the move might start a price war that could hurt Toys "R" Us.
Michael Goldstein, vice chairman and chief financial officer of Toys "R" Us, would say only that "we are sorry to see any competitor in difficulty." He noted, however, that yesterday the company began what he said was a previously scheduled $100 million clearance sale on older toys and board games, with price cuts of up to 75 percent from manufacturers' suggested retail prices.
Toys "R" Us stock fell 62.5 cents, to $22.875, in active trading yesterday after negative comments from analysts about prospects for the toy industry in general after the Child World announcement.
While Toys "R" Us helped turn toy selling into a year-round business, it still gets half its sales and three-quarters of its profit during the Hanukkah and Christmas season.
Beyond the competitive pressures, the driving question for toy stores like Toys "R" Us this year is whether Nintendo, the leading video game maker and by far the toy industry's best seller, will continue to excite children. Nintendo and rival video games commanded 20 percent of all toy sales last year and nearly the same proportion at Toys "R" Us.
If Toys "R" Us is the Gulliver of toy sellers, then Nintendo is the Godzilla of toys, having crushed the competition and gobbled up more than its share of sales in recent years.
 
Go-Go, My Walking Pup
 In fact, the latest survey of toy stores by Toy & Hobby World magazine, a trade publication, shows that five of the top ten sellers continue to be Nintendo games and equipment. Nintendo's $99 game consoles are the nation's best-selling plaything.
But if Nintendo falters -- and some analysts say they see early signs of just that -- toy retailers worry that there are no blockbusters waiting to emerge. Sharply higher toy prices could also hinder sales growth, although toy makers have been careful to also offer moderately priced toys to better capture any unspent Nintendo dollars.
Still, with many of the hottest toys costing $45 or more, "just getting customers into stores this season, let alone getting them to buy, is going to be tough," said Sean McGowan, a toy industry analyst with Gerard Klauer Mattison & Company, in New York.
A hot seller so far is Hasbro's Go-Go, My Walking Pup, which costs about $40.
One of the best-selling new toys intended for girls is Mattel's Magic Nursery doll, which, at about $25, is less expensive than many other popular toys this year. The infant doll's novelty is that when the gown it comes wrapped in is put into water it disappears, leaving behind a waterproof birth certificate that says whether it's a girl or a boy. If the document says the doll has a twin, the purchaser can get a second doll free.
Board games like Shark Attack, made by Milton Bradley, at about $13, are also expected to do well.
 
Confidence About Market Share
 Because video games have been so dominant in recent years, analysts say, toy makers have slowed creation of new toys for boys 8 to 12 years old, the prime ages in thrall to Nintendo. As a result, even though Nintendo products are pervasive, most stores carry a slight majority of toys designed to appeal to girls,
Still, Toys "R" Us, with sales of $4.8 billion in the year ended Jan. 28, 1990, seems undaunted, confident that no matter what happens it will gain in market share. "If people are going to buy toys at low prices where they know they can get what they want, where are they going to buy them?" asks Charles Lazarus, the founder and chairman of Toys "R" Us, his hands pointing skyward. He does not pause for an answer.
Like a wary campaign contributor bankrolling both Democrats and Republicans, Toys "R" Us has invested heavily in both video games and traditional toys.
Toys "R" Us, with headquarters in a modest business park in Paramus, N.J., already has a 22 percent market share. Child World has about 5 percent and the Lionel Corporation, which operates mostly under the Lionel Kiddie City name, is No. 3 with 2.6 percent, according to Daniel Barry, an analyst at Kidder, Peabody.
 
Toys Are for Adults Too
 The success of Toys "R" Us is based on easy-to-reach stores with wide selection and deep inventory at low prices.
Toys "R" Us has also unleashed a torrent of advertising, aimed as much at adults as children. "You think The Sharper Image is the only toy store for adults?" asks Mr. Lazarus, an intense, owlish man.
Although Toys "R" Us will not say how much it spends on marketing, it is spending at least $15 million on a network television campaign. It bought 12 full-page ads in USA Today, which has high newsstand sales in airports, for the day before Thanksgiving, the busiest flying day of the year.
Mr. Goldstein, the chief financial officer, said, "We want to make sure that you can't live a normal life and not see our ads."
But third-quarter trends were troubling for Toys "R" Us, by far the most profitable toy retailer, as well as for the industry as a whole. Sales at Toys "R" Us stores open for at least a year inched up 1.6 percent in the August-to-October period, compared with a gain of more than 10 percent in the May-through-July period.
 
Starting With Furniture
 The company as a whole, including its usually thriving children's wear division, Kids "R" Us, had flat earnings of $28.7 million in the third quarter, and sales rose 11.5 percent, to $1.05 billion.
Toys "R" Us was started by Mr. Lazarus, who converted his father's bicycle repair shop in Washington into a children's furniture shop in 1948. He soon realized that parents bought toys much more often than they bought furniture, so he gradually converted several stores into toy supermarkets.
Now, most of his 451 Toys "R" Us stores in the United States (there are 98 foreign stores) are just off a main highway, near populated centers and a shopping mall. This avoids expensive mall rents but pulls in the same customer traffic. Toys "R" Us owns virtually all of its stores, thus controlling occupancy costs.
Because it stocks such huge quantities, the company has enormous buying power with manufacturers. Toys "R" Us stores can sell toys sometimes for a third less than the suggested retail price. The stores stock toys at levels double or triple those of competitors to reduce the chance that a parent will suffer the ultimate humiliation -- having to tell a whining 8-year-old that the store is out of G.I. Joe dressed in desert camouflage.
The stores also try to offer most of the items associated with, say, Barbie or Teen-Age Mutant Ninja Turtles and nearly all 300 of Nintendo's video games. Toy manufacturers benefit because they can sell not only their hottest toys but also entire lines of doo-dads that carry fat profit margins.
 
'Short on Dr. Mario'
 Moreover, Toys "R" Us stocks what are certifiably the hottest toys, as shown by computerized cash registers that track shoppers' buying trends. The registers tie stores as far away as Honolulu directly to Mr. Lazarus, the chairman, who has computer terminals in his office, his Manhattan apartment and his Long Island summer home. The computers are also used to report unusual events that may disrupt sales, like power failures, snowstorms and road construction.
Mr. Lazarus is especially watchful about shortages of hot toys. Peter Main, a top marketing officer with Nintendo of America, recalled an urgent phone call from Mr. Lazarus. "It looks like we're going to be short on Dr. Mario," a video game, he said that Mr. Lazarus told him before demanding, "What are you going to do about it?"
Other general merchandise discounters and department stores find it hard to mobilize for the D-Day invasion of Christmas every year. They must quintuple floor space devoted to toys, figure out from scratch what the hottest toys are and then stock just enough so they will be picked clean by Christmas Eve. This year, in particular, many are not stocking as many toys as in the past, wary of being left with unsold inventory.
That plays into the hands of Toys "R" Us executives in their quest for ever-increasing market share.
 "The last two weeks before Christmas, we'll be the only place with inventory," Mr. Lazarus said. "Everyone else is going to run out."

HEADLINE: Trade Talks Seem on the Verge of Collapse

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, Thursday, Dec. 6

 BODY:
World trade talks appeared to be just hours from collapse early this morning as negotiations reached a crisis over the European Community's continuing failure to agree to make larger cuts in agricultural subsidies.
After a late-night negotiating session that began Wednesday ended in acrimony and accusations, numerous ministers said the talks would fall apart at noon today, a deadline set by the conference chairman, unless the community adopted a more flexible position on farm protection. 
 "If nothing new comes up between now and the next 12 hours, it's over," said Brazil's chief negotiator, Rubens Ricupero.
The negotiations have been hurtling toward this critical moment since the final week of a four-year round of talks began on Monday. The United States and other farm-exporting nations have been pushing the European Community to agree to more substantial cuts in farm subsidies.
The trade and agriculture ministers of the 12 community nations met late Wednesday evening, and many negotiators among the 100 nations represented at this week's trade talks had high hopes that the community would finally make a more liberal offer.
But ministers at the meeting said the community, eager to protect its 10 million farmers, remained intransigent. "The community continued to stonewall," said John C. Crosbie, Canada's Trade Minister. "The ball is, as it has been from the very start, in the European Community's court."
Some officials said the talks might be suspended for several weeks to give the Europeans time to come up with new proposals, a prospect American officials oppose because they are under a Congressional deadline to submit a trade pact by March 1.
Nonetheless, Arthur Dunkel, Director General of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the Geneva-based organization sponsoring the talks, said he was "hopeful" that there would be a breakthrough by noon today.
The talks aim to spur economic growth by setting new, more liberal rules for the $4 billion a year in world trade. The rules would for the first time bring agriculture, financial services, textiles and patents under international trade rules.
The European Community's trade and agriculture ministers are scheduled to meet this morning, and many officials hope that they will give their negotiators more flexibility.
 
A Hint of Change

The Europeans have proposed reducing farm subsidies by 30 percent over 10 years, but have refused to make specific proposals on cutting import barriers or export subsidies. The United States, Canada, Argentina, Australia and other farm-exporting nations have proposed slashing farm subsidies by 75 percent over 10 years and export subsidies by 90 percent.
Farm subsidies often take the form of government payments to supplement the income of farmers whose crops sell for a lower price than one the government determines as fair. There are also export subsidies, money that governments provide to help lower the price of farm goods being sold abroad. Government programs to protect farmers cost the industrial nations $250 billion a year in higher taxes and inflated food prices.
Early Wednesday afternoon the European Community hinted that it would abandon its inflexible position on reducing farm subsidies. According to several negotiators, it outlined several new, but vague proposals to reduce farm protection.
 
'Dead in the Water'

Many negotiators said the community's proposals, which some people called trial balloons, might be too little and too late to give the talks the momentum they need. Besides, after the European Community's trade and agriculture ministers met Wednesday night, community officials came out talking tough, saying they would not give in to American pressures to change their position.
"There is no reason for us to bend the knee in front of the United States." said Otto Schlecht, Germany's state secretary for economics.
"For all practical purposes the Uruguay Round is dead in the water at this time," said Neal Blewett, Australia's trade minister. "There is very little chance of revival."
Since the final week of talks began, the two sides have stubbornly played a high-stakes game over who would make the first concession.
Ministers here say the latitude of community negotiators is restricted because they have to refer back repeatedly to the trade and agriculture mnisters of the 12 community nations.
Even as the Europeans hinted at a more flexible position on farm trade, they sought, according to American and other officials, to pick off Washington's allies by offering them individual concessions.
 
Taking the Offensive

Senior negotiators said the European Community had suggested that it would not raise tariffs on soybeans as part of a plan in which it said it would increase import barriers in some areas even as it reduced them in others. American negotiators said this move was intended to soften the opposition of Brazil and Canada to the community's position.
In recent weeks, the community has been isolated and on the defensive as the United States and other farm-exporting nations said its intransigence on liberalizing farm trade was frustrating the talks.
Tonight, however, community officials went aggressively on the offensive and asserted that Washington was isolated and the main culprit.
"The real difficulty is getting the Americans to negotiate," said John Cooney, a community spokesman.
But Victoria Clarke, a spokesman for Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, said this was "disingenuous." She said Washington had been negotiating on numerous issues, including textiles, intellectual property and financial services.
Rufus Yerxa, the deputy United States trade representative, said, "We do not believe that substantial progress is possible at this time given the impasse in agriculture."

HEADLINE: Productivity Is Revised Downward

BYLINE: REUTERS

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5

 BODY:
Labor productivity, a key measure of economic vitality, was revised sharply downward for the third quarter today, adding to mounting evidence that the economy is in retreat.
The Labor Department said non-farm productivity rose only two-tenths of 1 percent in the quarter instead of its previously reported increase of 1.6 percent. Productivity, defined as output per hour of work, rose three-tenths of 1 percent in the second quarter. 
 The department said the downward revision showed output as unchanged, while the previous report had put the gain in output at 1.5 percent.
The department also said that the number of hours put in by workers fell two-tenths of 1 percent, the first drop in this category since 1986.
Economists said the revision, which had not been expected to be this sharp, was in line with the belief that the economy was slowing and had probably drifted into recession.
"This is exactly the kind of picture you would expect to see from an economy that was going into recession," said Donald Ratajczak, director of economic forecasting at Georgia State University.
The economists said the pattern showed output slowing in the three months as demand slackened, but industry continued to retain workers while waiting to see if the downturn was temporary.
They say that evidence for the current quarter suggests that the waiting period has ended and industry has begun paring its work force in the face of a continued slowdown.
The figures were released against a backdrop of higher oil prices from the gulf crisis that also are weighing heavily on the economy and are thought by some to have already pushed it into a recession.
The Commerce Department said that manufacturing productivity rose 5.1 percent, led by an increase of 7.4 percent in the durable goods sector. Nondurable goods productivity was up 1.6 percent.
Overall productivity including farming rose four-tenths of 1 percent.

HEADLINE: Advanced TV Makes Debut in Japan

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Dec. 5

 BODY:
Finally, after all the debate over whether high-definition television will be a revolutionary technology for consumers and national economies, the vaunted sets went on sale this week in Japan.
They cost $34,000 apiece and the special-format broadcasts for HDTV are shown for only an hour a day. But for the three big electronics companies that have begun selling the world's first high-definition sets -- Sony, Matsushita and Hitachi -- the high cost and limited programming are no cause for distress at the outset. They are marketing HDTV now to show the dimensions of Japan's technological lead over the United States and Europe in this field and to whip up public demand for television sets that have the clarity and wide-screen look of a movie-theater screen.
 
Luring Crowds
 The giant-screen HDTV's are already being installed in hotel lobbies, post offices and town halls all over Japan, where crowds can gather to watch; there is even one in the waiting area down the hall from Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu's office. 
 These days the screens are being filled with a sparing selection of big sporting matches and colorful events that showcase the technology, like the enthronement ceremonies last month of Emperor Akihito, broadcast in what Japan calls "Hi-Vision." Next year, Japan's giant state-run broadcaster, NHK, plans to increase its HDTV broadcasts from one hour, to eight hours a day.
"It is much like the first transistor radio, or the first Walkman, or the first home VCR's," said Hisafumi Yamada, a manager in Sony's high-definition business development division. "You have to do something at the first stage, to get people accustomed to the idea. We think the demand is out there."
Experimenting on the sales shelves is nothing new here, especially in high technology, where Japanese consumers often test the first models. Five years from now, manufacturers say, they expect that more than a million sets will have been sold in Japan. By that time, the price is expected to drop to about $7,500.
But for Japan's electronics industry, the first consumer HDTV's are not only a chance to test public reaction to a technology that has already cost upward of $1 billion. It is also a chance to test corporate strategies.
It is no accident that the first sets are reaching the market just as the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company begins to digest its $6.13 billion purchase last month of MCA, the parent of Universal Studios. Along with Columbia Pictures, purchased last year by Sony, Universal is expected to quickly become a testing ground for new video "software" -- the industry's jargon for movies and other forms of entertainment -- that will exploit HDTV's features.
Sony has already set up HDTV production equipment on Columbia's lots, in an effort to convince directors that the images they can record on videotape are as rich and warm as those they get on film -- and far easier to edit.
"I do not necessarily agree with what they did, in buying up American studios," Keiji Shima, the chairman of NHK and one of the biggest advocates of Japan's Hi-Vision system, said the other day in a talk with foreign correspondents based in Japan. But the acquisitions, he said, should speed the solution of a major problem in the Japanese industry: Its video hardware has outpaced the development of programming that would give viewers a reason to replace their existing television sets.
 
A Move Toward Computers
 While consumers usually associate HDTV with television viewing, Matsushita and Sony are looking to the day when the technology will be a critical component of computers. There already are plans to mix high-definition images into what the electronics industry calls "multimedia," the mix of data, graphics, moving pictures and sound. "We are just beginning to think about personal computers for the future," said Hiroyuki Mizuno, the head of research and development at Matsushita. "But I think audio-visual will have to have a big part of the personal computer operation." High-definition television, he said, "could certainly be expected to be part of that."
Atop all this is the issue of components, mostly Japanese-made. High-definition television sets are loaded with memory chips and processors in which Japan excels. The result is that even American manufacturers will be relying on Japan to produce most of the vital parts -- unless Europe and Japan set up local content regulations that require that some specified portion of an item be made in the country where the item is being sold.
But the commercial advent of HDTV in Japan may also be the first chance to test the critical question still facing the technology: How big an improvement is it anyway?
The initial reviews of prototype HDTV systems were gushing: High definition, many of the industry's experts said, would be as large a leap forward as the arrival of color television three decades ago. The Japanese system uses more than twice the number of video lines that current American sets have. The result is much better picture resolution. Combined with the wide-angle view -- HDTV's have the rectangular proportions of a movie screen rather than the boxy proportions of a television set -- the big screens have remarkable clarity and, at times, the sense that the image is almost three-dimensional.
 
A Slow Start
 This week's start has not exactly bowled the industry over. Sony says it has 100 orders, but most were collected previously. Matsushita says it is prepared to manufacture up to 50 sets a month at the beginning.
The two companies are pursuing significantly different strategies. Matsushita is selling its models mainly to hotels and people in the professions. "There are not exactly consumer prices," a Matsushita official said.
Sony, meanwhile, turned out a separate "HDTV ready" monitor but without the "decoder" one needs to turn the scrambled signal into a television image. Until the circuitry is miniaturized and the price of the decoder comes down, Sony says it expects many of its buyers to use the big television -- it has a 36-inch diagonal screen -- for conventional shows, using the existing broadcast format. The television is even equipped to tune into several different conventional stations at once, placing each of them in different corners of the screen for monitoring.
But Sony knows that a few people -- the company calls them "vidiots" for their love of the latest -- will insist on high definition now. No matter that they have little to watch until at least next year, when NHK launches another satellite that will broadcast roughly eight hours a day of HDTV images. Whether watching it all will be worth it is, for the Japanese, the $34,000 question.

GRAPHIC: Photo: High-definition televisions have been installed in many public places throughout Japan, showcasing sports events and colorful spectacles. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: California Might Void Ernst License

BYLINE: By ALISON LEIGH COWAN

 BODY:
The State of California's licensing board is seeking to revoke Ernst & Young's license to practice accounting because one of its two predecessor firms had audited the failed Lincoln Savings and Loan Association.
Ernst & Young was formed last year by the merger of Ernst & Whinney and Arthur Young. Lincoln Savings and Loan, a subsidiary of the American Continental Corporation, had been an audit client of Arthur Young in 1986 and 1987. 
 Young resigned the account in late 1988, about seven months before Lincoln went into receivership. The collapse of Lincoln resulted in huge losses for the Government, which had to mount a costly bailout to protect depositors, and for American Continental's investors, whose securities turned out to be worthless. Roughly $200 million of American Continental debentures were sold to California residents after the issuance of the 1987 financial statements.
 
Lack of Warning Cited
 California's Board of Accountancy charged Arthur Young with being "grossly negligent" for approving financial statements that failed to give investors or regulators any warning of American Continental's true financial condition.
In particular, it contends that the accounting treatment of eight real estate transactions, booked by Lincoln in 1987, violated generally accepted accounting principles and inflated American Continental's pretax earnings by $62 million.
The Nov. 16 action, first reported in The Los Angeles Times yesterday, is highly unusual for a state licensing board, and it could result in severe penalties for Ernst & Young, ranging from probation to a revocation of its license, at a time when the firm is already under financial pressure because of a soft economy, an expensive merger and several costly lawsuits related to the savings and loan crisis.
 
 A Previous Case
 "This is really in a class by itself," said Michael R. Granen, California's Deputy Attorney General, who is the lead attorney representing the board in the action. He said he could recall only one instance in which California canceled a license of a major accounting firm before, and it was not onerous since the firm, KMG Main Hurdman, was merging at the time into Peat Marwick and thus no longer needed its old license to practice.
The Ernst & Young action is not expected to be reviewed by an administrative law judge for at least six months.
An Ernst & Young spokesman said the firm would "vigorously defend" itself in the action and expected to prevail.
But Mr. Granen disagreed.
"We have conducted our own investigation, including a review of the work papers of Arthur Young and we believe that based on the information they had, they never should have been booked," he said.

HEADLINE: Dow Soars by 30.70 on Gulf Peace Hopes

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Another steep decline in crude oil prices plus renewed investor sentiment that the Persian Gulf crisis may soon end peaceably helped pushed stocks sharply higher yesterday. Trading was the heaviest since mid-October.
Leading the market rally, the New York Stock Exchange financial index jumped nearly 3.5 percent, as a broad list of financial stocks advanced sharply after the Fed eliminated rules requiring banks to keep 3 percent of certain kinds of commercial deposits in reserve. 
 With the price of oil plunging $3.37 a barrel, to $27.29, the Dow transportation index moved nearly 2.5 percent higher and airline and other transportation stocks gained strong ground.
Moving sharply higher for most of the session, the Dow Jones industrial average ended the day at 2,610.40, up 30.70 points.
 
Trading Activity Up Sharply
 Trading activity soared to 205.8 million shares, up sharply from 185.8 million on Tuesday. It was the highest volume since Oct. 19, when the total jumped to 221.5 million shares.
Showing that the rally spread through the broad market, 1,087 stocks were higher, with 28 rising to new highs, while 485 were lower, with 36 hitting new lows.
The Nasdaq composite index -- which is heavily oriented toward small high-tech stocks -- rose nearly 2 percent. Sun Microsystems, for examle, rose 2, to 22 3/4 in heavy trading.
On the Big Board, Digital Equipment rose 2, to 58, and Hewlett-Packard rose 2, to 33 3/8. NCR, which is under takeover attack from A.T.&T., jumped 3 1/8, to 86 5/8. A.T.&T., yesterday's most-active Big Board stock, fell 1/4, to 30 1/8, on 5.1 million shares.
"The price of oil has gone down quite a bit," said Sung Won Sohn, chief economist for the Norwest Corporation in Minneapolis, "because Iraq accepted President Bush's offer for talks on a peaceful solution. Now there's some expectation that the probability of peace has gone up."
 
 Commodities Price Drop
 He said the market also rose sharply because the price of commodities, as reflected in the Commodity Research Bureau index, fell close to 1 percent. "That means the economy's probably getting deeper into recession," he said, "and the Fed is more likely to ease monetary policy, pushing interest rates down."
Still further evidence that the nation is now in a recession, he said, is expected tommorrow in new employment data. Economists expect employment to be down about 100,000 jobs, he said, forecasting that the Fed could lower interest rates one-quarter point by mid-December and another quarter-point toward the end of the year.
Eight of the Big Board's 10-most-active stocks were financial, all of which showed strong gains. Fannie Mae advanced 2 5/8, to 34 1/4, on 4.9 million shares, Citicorp 1 3/8, to 15 3/4, on 4.85 million and First Interstate of California 3 1/2, to 25 3/4, with 3.2 million shares changing hands.
Also on the active list, BankAmerica climbed 1 5/8, to 26 1/8; American Express 1 3/4, to 22 3/4; Chemical Bank 1, to 13 1/2; H. F. Amanson, the savings and loan company, 5/8, to 14 1/8 and the First Bank System of Minneapolis 1, to 14 3/4.
Toys "R" Us, which fell 7/8 Tuesday after two analysts cut their earnings estimates, fell another 5/8, to 22 7/8, in heavy trading after two more analysts issued negative comments. Pfizer fell 1 3/4, to 78 7/8, after Paul A. Brooke, drug analyst for Morgan, Stanley, said its Shiley heart valve could present new problems. Other drug stocks were strong.

HEADLINE: Archdiocese Plans Big Cuts In School Aid

BYLINE: By PETER STEINFELS

 BODY:
The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York has announced plans to cut subsidies to its parochial elementary schools by nearly half, a move that could reduce revenues of schools in poorer areas by 25 percent or more.
Diocesan officials have told the pastors and principals to submit proposals for economizing or raising new funds by Dec. 15. Some schools are holding meetings of parents or elected parish councils to discuss solutions. 
 The New York archdiocese, which covers Manhattan, the Bronx, Staten Island, Westchester and six other New York counties, has 243 parish elementary schools with an enrollment of 80,000 pupils. It also sponsors 29 diocesan or parish high schools with 16,000 students and a number of other educational programs.
 
'Money Is Tight'
 Two-thirds of the elementary schools receive subsidies, which supplement tuition revenues and parish funds. Their subsidies are scheduled to drop to $6 million from $11 million next year. Reductions are also expected for the high schools and other educational programs but have not yet been announced.
Msgr. Henry J. Mansell, Chancellor of the archdiocese, has attributed the financial problems in part to costly parish maintenance that was deferred for many years, increasing salaries of teachers and the movement of wealthier Catholics from the city to the suburbs.
"Yes, money is tight and we need to raise more of it," Joseph Zwilling, an archdiocesan spokesman, said. He stressed that the archdiocese was trying to plan ahead rather than suffer "panic," and that no school closings were planned at present.
In a Nov. 9 letter to the pastors and principals, Msgr. Hugh F. McManus, Vicar of Education for the New York archdiocese, said parochial school educators must craft a leaner school network, still capable of serving as many youngsters as it does now but in a more cost-effective way."
In poorer parishes, subsidies may provide more than half the school budget, although the bulk of support for most schools comes from tuition and parish Sunday collections.
Recently the elementary schools were grouped into clusters of two to six neighboring institutions to help bring about educational and financing efficiencies, diocesan officials said. They said the subsidy reductions would vary from cluster to cluster but school officials in several Bronx parishes reported being notified of 50 percent cuts, amounting to a quarter to one-third of their schools' budgets.
 
Little Growth From Tuition Seen
 Several school and parish officials, who said they preferred to remain anonymous while their clusters were still consulting with the archdiocese about the reductions, expressed similar doubts about finding ways of cutting costs by consolidating programs or reducing services.
They also said that schools could not expect much more revenue from tuition. One Bronx pastor said that parochial schools in his area, where half the families have incomes under $10,000, charged $750 to $1,000 tuition per student to parish members, with a sliding scale for families with more than one child enrolled.
One educator, who is not part of the archdiocese, said there is little left to cut in schools in poor areas. "Part of my fear is that the schools most in need will be taking the cuts," said Brother Brian Carty, headmaster of De La Salle Academy, an independent high school operated by the Christian Brothers religious order in Manhattan.
"There's no fat in these schools," he said. "They wring every last bit out of every dollar they get."

HEADLINE: Two Soviet Cultural Paths Cross in Washington

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5

 BODY:
Nikolai N. Gubenko, the actor and film director who became the Soviet Minister of Culture just under a year ago, and Dmitri S. Likhachev, a venerated scholar of the Russian past, made separate pilgrimages to America last month, their agendas providing eloquent evidence of the complementary roles played by two of the most dominant figures in Soviet culture today.
Mr. Gubenko, 49 years old, whose visit was sponsored by the United States Information Agency, recently ended a week of talks with the heads of Washington's cultural institutions to try to cement the connections that could bring life to his plans for a Soviet-American cultural center in Moscow, a joint-venture hotel that could bring much-needed hard currency to the arts in the Soviet Union and a broader series of cultural exchanges. 
 While Mr. Gubenko was looking for ways to pay for new creativity, Mr. Likhachev was looking for ways to renew his country's connection with its cultural past.
The 84-year-old Mr. Likhachev, whose visit was sponsored by Columbia University's Harriman Institute and the Library of Congress, was here primarily to lecture on Russian history and to do research in the Library of Congress on old Russian works that are unobtainable in the Soviet Union.
 
Linking 2 Traditions
 He also reached out to Russian emigres and the Russian Orthodox Church in Exile, trying to forge links between the traditions preserved by Russians abroad and the revival of religious and secular Russian traditions in art, music, education and scholarship now under way from Leningrad to Siberia.
"In a way, Gubenko is the minister for culture, the advocate, and Likhachev is the minister of culture, the keeper of the flame," said Jane A. Taubman, a professor of Russian at Amherst College who specializes in contemporary Soviet culture.
But both men, the elderly scholar who grew up steeped in the traditions of the St. Petersburg intelligentsia, and the wartime orphan who grew up surrounded by squalor, poverty and Communist zeal, share a vision of culture as a binding tie that could help prevent the economic and political atomization of the Soviet Union.
They also represent President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's continuing if fraying links to the intelligentsia. The support of Mr. Gubenko and Mr. Likhachev, a member of the Congress of People's deputies, lends a scholarly resonance to Mr. Gorbachev's views at a time when other leading intellectuals, from the historian Yuri N. Afanasyev to the head of the film makers' union, Elem G. Klimov, to the poet Oles Adamovich, have become outspoken critics of his policies.
 
The Many Russias
 It was not as advocates for Mr. Gorbachev but as advocates for cultural renewal that they visited the United States -- Mr. Gubenko to study the financial underpinnings of cultural enterprises like the Kennedy Center, the Smithsonian Institution and the arts and humanities endowments, and Mr. Likhachev to argue forcefully that the rich legacy of Russian culture deserves material support from abroad so that the paint on icons doesn't flake away for lack of humidity and the ravaged churches do not molder in disuse when there are new possibilities for restoration and reuse.
"Likhachev gave a brilliant talk about how many Russias there have always been," said James Billington, the Librarian of Congress, who is a noted scholar of Russian cultural history. "He talked eloquently about the Russia of the far north, the Russia of the eastern Baltic, the section of Novgorod that was inhabited largely by Finnish people, the Russia of Odessa, which was essentially a Jewish culture.
"He was making the point that the recovery of memory and of the Russian tradition is not a recovery of a narrow chauvinism but of a sense of the richness and complexity of the Russians' own past."
Mr. Gubenko said in an interview: "Certainly no one thinks that culture should be put above everyday needs. But there is a desire to have things of the spirit as well. Cultural processes in our country could stabilize our society when it is beginning to crack apart."
Mr. Likhachev sees evidence that the Russian tradition of scholarship and the links to Europe forged by Western-looking Russians since the time of Peter the Great at the beginning of the 18th century are being renewed, particularly in the changing Soviet schools. The amount of work going into the educational and cultural revivals, he said, puts the lie to Westerners who would dismiss Russians as lazy or greedy or interested only in themelves.
 
Changes in the Schools
 "You now have middle schools that have been changed into European gymnasiums, where they study Latin, ancient Greek and the classical tradition," Mr. Likhachev said in an interview. "You have young teen-agers, people in the 8th or 9th form, being taken out to learn the history of their neighborhood in Leningrad, building by building. These are miraculous children."
He contrasted this revival with what he called the chauvinism of adherents of the anti-Semitic Russian nationalist group Pamyat, saying that their understanding of Russian history was superficial, born not of a love of their own culture but of a hatred of others. "A year ago," he said, "I would have been happy to wear a lapel pin with the red, white and blue Russian flag. Now that the three-colored flag has become associated with them, I am reluctant to wear it."
The tug-of-war in Mr. Likhachev's world is between the westward-looking advocates of a Russian culture integrated with its neighbors and the Slavophiles' efforts to distance themselves from non-Russian cultures. In Mr. Gubenko's world, there is a different sort of dynamic. After three years of cultural offerings, particularly films and drama, focused on the Communist legacies of betrayal and destruction -- reviving the long-suppressed memories of a past that was long denied -- Mr. Gubenko wants to find some positive focus for the creativity unleashed by Mr. Gorbachev's policies.
One solution, he said, is more exchanges with the West, with a particular emphasis not on the big-name cultural attractions of the past but on smaller regional theater, music and dance ensembles, which can give a sense of "the moral regeneration of Russian culture in the provinces."
Both men say the countryside is the wellspring of Russian culture.
For Mr. Likhachev, the revival of Russian culture is centered as much in small centers like Yaroslavl as in Moscow or his own city, Leningrad. "It irritates me when people from Moscow get on steamboats and go off to tell small-town audiences, 'Restore your churches,' when the people doing the lecturing don't have any idea of what's going on, and the churches are already being restored by local organizations," he said.
Mr. Gubenko agrees. "The moral basis of our culture is in the provinces," he said.
What is needed to stimulate cultural development, both men said, is cash and cross-fertilization with other cultures. Mr. Likhachev said he would like to maintain contacts with the people who preserved Russian culture in exile.
He would also like to see the novelist Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn return to the Soviet Union from the United States because of his legendary stature as the man who told the truth about Stalinism and prison camps and because his presence would stimulate debate over his prescription for a separatist Russian state.
Mr. Solzhenitsyn has said he will not return until all his works are freely available in the Soviet Union. But Mr. Likhachev, perhaps thinking of his own life as a cultural icon, suggested another reason for hesitation. "I understand why he doesn't want to come," he said. "He wouldn't be able to work. Everyone would want him. He'd be pulled apart."

HEADLINE: PRO FOOTBALL;
Giants Need Remedy For Streaking Vikings

BYLINE: By GERALD ESKENAZI, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Dec. 5

 BODY:
Losses? Did someone around here lose two straight en route to a perfect season? Does anyone have to play the Minnesota Vikings, the hottest team in the league?
Coach Bill Parcells barely conceded today that his Giants' losses meant anything in the grander scheme of things. After all, it's how you finish, he said. 
 Perhaps. But this is what he told his players today, their first day back after the 7-3 loss Monday night to the San Francisco 49ers:
"I told the bumps-and-bruises guys, 'I don't need you three weeks from now. I need you now.' "
 
'Must-Win Situation'
 His team needs a victory. In fact, Carl Banks called it a "must-win situation."
That is why Parcells is not suffering his injured players gladly, and that includes the left tackle Jumbo Elliott, who has an injured left leg and hasn't played in two months. Meanwhile, another starter on the offensive line, Eric Moore, turned his left ankle in the 49ers' loss.
Parcells admitted he might have to pick up an unemployed free agent lineman for use against the the streaking Vikings, who come into Giants Stadium next Sunday. They have won five straight games after a 1-6 start.
But the Vikings have not won outdoors this season, and since 1988 they are 1-11 when they play outside the Metrodome.
A victory (or a Philadelphia and Washington loss) guarantees the Giants the National Conference East division title. The Giants won their first 10 games. Then came the Eagles and 49ers. Last year, the Giants also faced those two teams, in reverse order, and lost. Their record was 9-4. Now it's 10-2. The Giants won their next game last year, defeating the Super Bowl-bound Denver Broncos.
 
Banks Back
 "That situation was similar to this one," contended Banks, the outside linebacker who returned last Monday from wrist surgery and got into 10 plays.
"It was a must-win situation," he said. "We have a little more of a comfort zone, but we have to address it like a must-win situation. The picture isn't as pretty as it was at 10-0."
Will these two losses affect the Giants' ability to focus on the Vikings?
"I don't think that will be a problem," said Parcells, addressing the divisional and conference races. "There's a lot of things unsettled right now. Things will change a lot. A loss, or two or three, in the middle of the season, really, will not be how you're judged. You're judged not by the middle of the season but by the end."
Parcells also disclosed that his place-kicker, Matt Bahr, injured his back in the first half against the 49ers. Parcells insisted that did not influence his decision to go for the touchdown on fourth-and-goal from the 9 late in the game. A field goal would have brought the Giants within a point, but they would have needed another field goal from Bahr to win. The fourth-down pass play failed.
 
Bahr Practices
 Bahr's backache did not keep him out of today's practice. He kicked off, although none were booming shots. Raul Allegre, who began the season until suffering a groin injury, has been healthy for several weeks.
There has been no letup for the Giants these last few weeks. The Vikings are followed by the Buffalo Bills, currently leading the American Conference East.
"I'd rather have a bunch of hard games down the stretch rather than easy teams," Lawrence Taylor said bravely. "So you know how you can play in the playoffs."
And when practice was over, Fred Hoaglin, the offensive line coach, said of his injured players, "Moore's not as bad and Jumbo looked a little better."
They had to be. Parcells needs them now.
 
Bavaro Suspension Unlikely
 Although the league has not come to a decision on Mark Bavaro, it appears unlikely the tight end will be suspended. He was ejected from the Eagles game for making contact with an official, but films do not indicate that the official fell as a result of Bavaro's actions. . . . Jerry Burns, the Vikings' coach, was asked about his team's record away from the Metrodome. "We win on the road," he said. "We won in Seattle and Detroit." Both were in domed stadiums. . . . Erik Howard (calf), the nose tackle, and Lee Rouson (groin), the backup running back, are also nursing injuries that Parcells predicts will not sideline them.

HEADLINE: ESSAY;
Trusting Our Allies

BYLINE: By William Safire

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
"Will they be with us?" asked Senator Joseph Biden about our Persian Gulf allies, at the Senate Foreign Relations Committee hearing yesterday.
He was irritated at the we'll-hold your-coat attitude of the Soviet Union and others, but incensed at the "echoes of 25 years ago" in the position taken by Senator Jesse Helms.
That official media heavy had said he considered open hearings a mistake, said he would submit written questions in private -- "one of them which is extremely sensitive" -- and then (wrongheadedly) stalked off to fiddle with Senate ethics. 
 What was that byplay all about? What impelled Mr. Helms to hint at the security riskiness of hearings, and Mr. Biden to accuse Mr. Helms of McCarthyism?
If my suspicion is correct, both of these quite different Senators were coming at the same subject in characteristically divergent ways: they were concerned about the trustworthiness of the nations coalesced with us against Saddam Hussein.
Senator Helms may (or may not) have been alluding to a belief being bruited about for the past 10 days by a minority of world spookery that Saudi Arabia, in understandable panic just after the invasion of Kuwait, tried to obtain nuclear warheads for its missiles from China.
I hesitated to write about this speculation because I cannot confirm it, and did not want to discredit the solid information from other sources printed in this space (since publicly confirmed) about the Iraqi attempt to acquire an atomic device soon and weaponry within a few years.
But the concern is half out of the bag; let's examine the possibility as an exercise in intelligence evaluation.
This we know: Three years ago, China secretly sold CSS-2 "East Wind" missiles, with a range of 2,200 miles, to Saudi Arabia. The delivery was made via Islamabad, Pakistan, to three bases in the "Empty Quarter," between Riyadh and Jidda. About 500 Chinese technicians accompanied the missiles, suggesting that the missiles cannot be fired without Beijing's O.K.
We learned of this deal a year later. In China, the same type of missile carries nuclear warheads; why do the Saudis need a missile of that range, accuracy and huge cost if the payload is only a conventional bomb?
Comes the invasion of Kuwait. The Saudi King looks catastrophe to his kingdom in the face. He reverses policy by welcoming a huge force of Americans, and also (the spook minority thinks) asks the Chinese, with whom he has just established diplomatic and economic relations, for the rest of the order -- nuclear tips on the missiles in place.
The only evidence that the worriers point to is this: In the month after the August invasion of Kuwait, 500 more Chinese technicians arrived at the three missile bases, where 12 of the 36 missiles are operational. And a second link has been added to encrypted communication from the desert bases, to which the U.S. is denied access.
No big deal, says the majority; an expanded bureaucracy could be calling home more often. Overriding consideration: A proud China would hardly jeopardize its world standing for a bundle of Saudi money, or double-cross us in secret a second time.
I'm inclined to discount the story and go with the majority because the Israelis, with the most at risk, grumble about the missiles but do not sound an alarm about supposed attempts to buy nuclear warheads.
Although the request is unverifiable and the shipment highly unlikely, the expressed concern of a portion of the once-fooled intelligence community is a fact. With some vividness, it illustrates the degree of distrust that permeates relations among "the allies."
That distrust is well placed. The alliance is a bedfellowship of temporarily parallel interests.
To Senator Biden's pertinent question, "Who will be with us?" Secretary Baker replied: "There might or might not be soft spots."
We trust the British; we three-quarters trust the Turks, whom Iraqis fear most; we half-trust the French, who want to cut a deal, and the Egyptians and Saudis, who would serve in Kuwait but not Iraq; we quarter-trust the Chinese and Soviets; and we wholly distrust the terrorist Syrians, who would turn on us in a flash. Outside the fragile coalition, we trust the Israelis, who can be counted on in the crunch.
Who will be with us? Let's hope the vote-avoiding Congress does not turn out to be the softest spot of all.

HEADLINE: A Tradition Of Assisting The Neediest

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ

 BODY:
For some of those who give to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, the annual gift is a family tradition, like an heirloom, passed down from generation to generation. But unlike grandmother's tea set or souvenir from the World's Fair, it does not slowly become a valuable antique -- and many givers willingly reach a little deeper each year to counter the ravages of inflation along with those of poverty.
Attached to Albert J. Elias's check for $500 was a note that read, "Pleased I can continue the support of the Neediest Cases my mother began over 60 years ago." Harry Harlem, a Bronx pawnbroker, sent $50, a practice that his mother began more than 50 years ago. And Dr. Virginia Miles of Englewood, N.J., has sent in a contribution for 65 consecutive years. 
 Dr. Miles recently wrote: "When I was 9 in 1925, my allowance was 20 cents a week. My parents suggested I share with the '100 Neediest.' I sent 10 cents glued to a sheet of paper -- half my income!" Since then, Dr. Miles has continued to give to the Neediest Cases, including $150 this year.
 
A 'Reflex Action'
 In a telephone interview yesterday, Dr. Miles, a marketing consultant with a doctorate in psychology, said that contributing to the Neediest Cases has become a "reflex action."
"It makes me feel a little less ashamed of how terrible things have become," she said. "Here we are, one of the richest countries in the world, and we have people lying in the streets."
The fund was established in 1912 by the publisher of The New York Times, Adolph S. Ochs, to help the sick and poor in New York.
This year, $1,296,407.55 has been raised so far, and the proceeds will be distributed among seven charities, to be used for direct assistance for the needy. The New York Times pays for the campaign's overhead.
Mrs. Lenore G. Whitehorn of Scarsdale, N.Y., sent in her 50th consecutive contribution last week. She has been giving to the Neediest Cases Fund since her grandmother died in 1940.
"I remember years and years ago how my grandmother, Ida Elbe, would always send something in to the Neediest Cases," Mrs. Whitehorn said yesterday in a telephone interview. "I adored her, and I thought that this was the most fitting memorial I could give."
"It gives me a good feeling when there's so much going on that's rotten," Mrs. Whitehorn added.

HEADLINE: New York City Will Lose in Federal Road Plan

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "U.S. Plans a Shift on Road Spending" (front-page, Nov. 23), you fail to point out that the Federal Government's new proposal for highway spending would put New York City's highways and bridges at risk of being orphaned.
You state that more roads would be covered by the new Federal policy. However, the number of city roads eligible for the majority of Federal funding could drop to 16 percent of the number now covered. When that is included with the new formula for funding, which is based heavily on gas consumption and mileage, New York City stands to lose hundreds of millions of dollars each year.
Without the necessary Federal funding, our roads will deteriorate, fail to receive important safety modifications, engender further congestion and, overall, depress the economy of our region and that of the entire country.
New Yorkers are not afraid to contribute to infrastructure rebuilding. The Federal Government should recognize its shared responsibility in an infrastructure that feeds the national economy. New York wants a partnership with the Federal Government. The Bush Administration is looking for a divorce.
You also point out the Federal Government's untimely and misguided policy on taxation of alternative fuels. With alternative fuels in their infancy, the Federal Government should be providing incentives for their use, rather than discouraging them by suggesting taxes.
 
LUCIUS RICCIO
Commissioner of Transportation
New York, Nov. 23, 1990
